The latest news from China is seriously disquieting. The foreign indemnity was avowedly fixed at the extreme limit of China's ability to pay. It seems likely to be beyond that limit. Of course, it is to be taken into consideration that the Viceroys who have the collection in charge for the most part extort much more than they hand over.

LONDON, July 26. -- In spite of the, enthusiasm with which society has taken up automobiling, its devotees, both from a sporting and business standpoint, are woefully handicapped by the archaic English laws which class automobiles and steamrollers in the same category, as well as the bitter hostility of the country Magistrates, who line the suburban roads with police patrols, who every week bag scores of motorists.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The State Department is about to provide itself with a new and interesting piece of "office furniture" in the shape of a freshly cut "Great Seal of the United States," to replace the present old one, which is so worn with excessive use as no longer to make the proper impression upon the important State papers to which it must be attached.

We are becoming hardened at the sums which multi-millionaires have been paying for works of art; but half a million dollars for one tapestry does take away one's breath. That is the sum stated an good authority to have been paid for an "arras" of the fifteenth century at a private sale.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 26. -- A romance was disclosed to-day when the announcement was made of the engagement of Albert Edward Tower of the Hyde Park Road to Miss Mary Towne Bogardus, daughter of ex-City Chamberlain Eliphalet P. Bogardus.

THE Island of Thasos, in the north of the Aegean Sea, off the cost of Thrace, is likely to cause international complications unless the Khedive of Egypt acquiesces in the demand of the Sultan of Turkey and permits the island to be occupied by Turkish troops and a Turkish mili- tary post established there.

TORONTO, July 26. -- A terrific cloudburst broke over the Toronto grounds to-day as the Jersey City baseball team was at bat in the first part of the sixth inning, putting an end to further play. Toronto won in the second on a base on balls to Bruce, Downey's sacrifice and Toft's single Score:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial, "A Token of Good-Will," commands the respectful gratitude or the Italians of this city and country, who read and like THE TIMES for its fairness and honesty. I, for one, feel grateful to you as do the thousands of my countrymen who belong to organizations presided over by me.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 26. -- The Englewood Field Club and the Knickerbocker Athletic Club baseball teams played here this afternoon in a championship game of the Amateur League and Englewood met its third defeat of the season. Englewood had young Dunscombe, the star freshman pitcher of Princeton in the box, and Sergt. Owens of the Eighty-seventh Company of the Coast Artillery behind the bat.

THE tall, handsome youth in the duck trousers invited Her to promenade on the boardwalk after a thunderstorm, but she feared she would get her new white dress damp; so she said, "I am afraid to go out there. It is so slippery." Then the duck man got a roller chair and helped her into it, after which he held a lengthy conversation with her coiffure the whole distance of the beach.

P.R. MARTIN is believed to have discovered the lost channel of Last Chance Creek while sinking a well at his res- idence on Hollins Avenue, in Helena, Mon. Last Chance Creek or Gulch was a noted early-day placer diggings and produced upward of $15,000,000 in gold.

LAKE GEORGE, July 26. -- The week has been a lively one at the Fort William Henry Hotel, with numerous card parties, outings of the Strollers and the Canoe Club, and dances. Thursday evening a junior dance was given as a farewell to Miss Gertrude Herbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Herbert of Helmetta, N.J., who went to New York to-day, and on Tuesday will sail for Europe.

The week has been sentimental in character, there having been several weddings. There are many rumors of more to come. In fact at Newport everything has had to yield precedence to things matrimonial. The week to come has no such sensations in store. It is to be one of dinners and informal dances.
WEST LIBERTY, Ky., July 26. -- F.A. Hopkins has been nominated for Congress by the Democrats of the Tenth District.

SEATED with some congenial cronies in a cool corner of a roof garden the other night was James Connor Roach, actor, playwright, wit, and raconteur. They had been discussing wealth and what it meant to be a man of millions, when Roach said:

SHE was kneeling just inside the fence, stirring and patting the already prepared soil of a flower-bed with a pearl-handled trowel, ordered especially for this first Summer in the country. And as she stirred and pattered, her lips murmured a few bars of a French labor song, and her brow wrinkled and smoothed with the motions of the trowel.

This is the title given by Mr. JAMES RAYMOND PERRY to an imaginary country the Constitution of which is framed to apply to society the principle laid down by Mr. CARNEGIE, "It is a disgrace to a man to die rich." He explains the provisions and supposed operation of this Constitution in a most interesting article in the current number of The North American Review.
THE venerable Senator Pettus of Alabama is one of the most genial and popular, as well as one of the most influen- tial members of the body to which he belongs.

CORNELIA had two invitations to go to the Country Club on Saturday afternoon. The Watsons asked her to meet them at their house at 4 o'clock and drive out for dinner, and Archibald Cleever wanted her to go with him. For reasons very obvious to all who had given Cornelia's case even superficial consideration, she decided to go with Archibald.

To The Editor of The New York Times: For narrowness of view and intemperance of expression, the opinion of Judge Jackson in the Parkersburg injunction cases, as reported in THE TIMES this morning, seems somewhat remarkable.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 26. -- The wedding of Miss Sarah Stewart Van Alen to Robert Joseph Collier to-day did not attract the attention of the society people of Newport as did the Martin-Oelrichs wedding of Thursday. The two functions differed widely. One had been long heralded and invitations were numerous; the other came as a surprise, was in a measure of a private character, and the invitations were very few in number.

LUNCH was over and the people in the proportion of nineteen women to one man were streaming out of the hotel dining room and choosing seats on the broad piazzas where the cool, greenstriped awnings protected sensitive eyes from the reflected glare of the waters of the Sound.

Although just returned to duty after an illness lasting fifty-seven days, the result of injuries received in attempting to stop a runaway horse, Bicycle Policeman Thomas Mullarkey stopped another bolting horse after an exciting chase yesterday afternoon, and not only saved from injury the boy who had been driving but prevented a collision between the horse and an open Amsterdam Avenue car.

Honors are now even in the present series of baseball games between the New York and Brooklyn Clubs. Each team has won and lost two games of the four played, and the fifth will be decided to-morrow at the Polo Grounds.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., July 26. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, daughter of the President, has just terminated a visit at the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Pruyn of Albany, at Camp Santanoni, on Newcomb Lake. Miss Roosevelt had as a companion Miss Sarah Benedict of Albany.

LONDON, July 26. -- The upward trend of all American securities continues to be the one bright spot in the London markets. Pessimistic prophets still give utterance to forebodings, but less loudly than a week ago.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 27 -- Judge Robert Hingle, in the District Court of Plaquemine, yesterday decided the case of the waif of the Cheniere Cammada storm in favor of Capt. M. Torrebonne, declaring that the little girl in dispute was the latter's child. The case had aroused a great deal of interest as one of the most remarkable identifications on record.

Lord Salisbury's retirement has once more raised the interesting question whether he did actually dig for gold when he was in Australia in 1852. Now that he has more leisure he may satisfy curiosity by something of an autobiography. His latest autobiographer, Mr. F.D. How, gives the most complete account of Lord Salisbury's Australian experiences than has so far appeared in print.

Paolo Seroto, thirty-seven years old, a fish vendor, of 229 Mulberry Street, died as the result of wounds received yesterday during a family quarrel, and the police believe that his nephew, Cisco Rosolo, twenty-nine years old, who lived with him, and who has disappeared, is responsible for his death.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 27 -- The President, Mrs. Roosevelt, and all of the children of the family, excepting Miss Alice, attended services in Christ Church. Secretary Moody did not accompany the President. The Rev. H.H. Washburn said that all men admired physical strength and that thousands would gather, and had gathered, to see the prowess and power of the gladiator and the prize fighter.

BALTIMORE, July 27 -- It is impossible to obtain an authoritative statement on the rumor that negotiations are pending looking to the absorption by the Atlantic Coast Line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, which is controlled by J. Pierpont Morgan Co. In financial circles here the general impression prevails that the report is well founded.

The discussion before the Rapid Transit Commission growing out of the competition between the Rapid Transit Construction Company and the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company for the construction and operation of the extension of the subway to Brooklyn was instructive in many ways, and not least so in calling attention to the lack of homogeneity in the multiple-borough City of New York.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 27 -- The beginning of the eleventh week of the anthracite miners' strike finds apparently no change in the situation, although the rumor has been revived that an effort will be made soon by one of the large companies to start one of their collieries.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27 -- The slight improvement in the weather brought out a large audience at the Casino concert this evening, and the grillrooms were well filled with diners, dinners being given by Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Lehr, Miss Wetmore, Mrs. J. Stevens Ulman, Mrs. Thomas McKean, Mrs. John R. Livermore, Mrs. William B. Coster, and Miss Nathalie Schenck.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 27 -- The condition of the Rev. Father Martin Carroll at the St. Vincent de Paul Church, Brooklyn, is still serious, but his physician. Dr. W. Swan, says he does not entertain any fear as to the final outcome. Several months, however are likely to elapse before he fully recovers.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 27 -- William F. Cochran, a young man who carved out a fortune for himself in Baltimore, has Just bought for $77,000 the elegant house of the late O.F. Bresee, in Mount Vernon Place, near the Garrett mansion, in this city. The property cost Mr. Bresee $110,000.

CAROLINA, June 14 -- The burning African sun soon sucked up the snow of our nights in the ruins of Ermelo; but the air is always bitterly cold none the less, and every morning when we inspan the mules before dawn the veldt grass is stiff and white with frost. Yet we have seen ruined farms to-day where Boer women and children, have somehow managed to live throughout the whole war in spite of Winter.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 27 -- John Daly's Ocean Avenue Club is in total darkness to-night. The four other large houses are still open; yet from a reliable source It is learned, that anything that looks like gambling paraphernalia has been removed. Proprietor James has told his friends that he will close his club, the New York, tomorrow.
LONDON, July 28 -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Times says the Yildiz Palace officials are greatly disconcerted by the arrival of an Italian squadron at Tripoli.

Road drivers generally were pleasantly surprised yesterday to find a good roadbed, and though the best sport came late in the day, there were some lively brushes by fast horses. It wag generally believed that the Speedway would be heavy from the early morning shower, but a large force of workmen kept the harrows in constant motion, and the sun appeared shortly before noon and helped to dry the damp surface.

This is a prosperity stock market. It is only natural, therefore, that prices should advance as they have advanced; only natural to expect -- the wonderfully helpful and encouraging circumstances considered -- that they will continue to advance. Values are adjusting themselves to the changed times and the changed conditions.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Chairman Griggs of the Democratic Congressional Committee, who recently gave but a lengthy interview regarding the effect of combines, had more to say to-day about trust-made goods. Mr. Griggs thinks it remarkable that in commenting on his recent interview about prices quoted to foreigners has confined itself practically to tin plate by American concerns the Republican press and lead.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 27 -- The Canadians won the international cricket match by 62 runs. On Friday they scored 217 and the Americans 85, for the loss of five wickets. Davis, for the Americans, when play was resumed, made a splendid 66, and the side was out for 146. In their second innings the Canadians made 101 and the Americans started in to make 172 to win, but only scored 110.

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., July 27 -- John D. Rockefeller arrived at Paul Smith's Hotel this morning en route for the Upper St. Regis Lake, where he will remain at the camp of Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus H. McCormick during August. There are also in this party Mr. and Mrs. Sartell Prentiss of Chicago.

TACOMA, Washington, July 27 -- The steamer Discovery has sailed from Nome with nearly 100 American miners engaged by the Northeastern Siberian Concession Company to begin an exploration of the Siberian coast for gold and other metals. They are in charge of John Rosen, managing Director of the company, which holds the concession granted last Winter by the Russian Government to Col. Wonlarlarsky of the Russian Army.
LONDON, July 28 -- The negotiations for a British-Chinese commercial treaty have been practically concluded, says the Shanghai correspondent of The Times.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- In the August number of Postal Receipts, the official organ of the National Association of Letter Carriers, there will appear a letter from J. C. Keller. President of the association, attacking the statements made by Representative Loud of California. Chairman of the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, in opposition to the bill reciassifying the letter carriers.

A young Mexican panther got away from Director William T. Hornaday's animal family in the Bronx Zoological Park yesterday and spread terror not only among the visitors to the Park, but also in the neighborhood for miles around.

PARIS, July 27 -- The demonstration made to-day in connection with the decree of Premier Combes ordering the closing of the Congregationist schools proved to be quite as much of a manifestation in support of the Government as of opposition to its anti-Clerical measures.

CINCINNATI, July 27 -- National Secretary Anthony Matre of the American Federation of Catholic Societies, reports that the programme is completed for the second National convention at Chicago on Aug. 5, 6, and 7, and that the indications are that the convention will be the most representative gathering of Catholics ever held in the United States.

That American horseflesh is rapidly growing in favor in foreign markets statistics prove. Within the last six years Great Britain alone spent $35,000,000 in the United States in the purchase of horses, independent of the many millions which she spent for mules. Last year not less than 75,000 horses were shipped from this country to England.

LONDON, July 28 -- The Rome correspondent of The Times says that an official announcement of the settlement of the recent Italian-Swiss dispute is expected on Wednesday after a special sitting of the Swiss Federal Council.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 27 -- At the mine workers' National headquarters it was announced to-day that no time will be lost in pushing the habeas corpus proceedings for the release of members of the organization, arrested under the edict of Judge Jackson of the United States District Court at Parkersburg. Va.

There is to be found, perhaps, an enlightening commentary upon the course of the French Government to supervise -- not to abolish, it is well to remember -- the religious schools of the republic, in the fact that the fiercest opposition to the Associations law has developed among that part of the population which fought so long and so desperately to protect monarchical institutions from their inevitable doom.

The British Consul for the Hawaiian Islands writes in his annual report that from Jan. 1 to June 14, 1900, (the data on which the Organic Act for the government of the islands took effect,) imports from the United Kingdom were unusually large, in anticipation of the United States tariff coming into operation.
Senator Thomas C. Platt does not seem to attach much importance to the boom of Capt. F. Norton Goddard of this borough for Lieutenant Governor on the Republican ticket.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 27, -- An open letter to President Roosevelt, dealing with alleged atrocities by United States troops in the Philippines, has been adopted by a committee of representative anti-imperialists at a meeting just held here. The committee was appointed at a meeting held in New York City last Spring, which has since then been investigating army conditions in the Philippines.

At a meeting of the members of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, held in the church on West Forty-eighth Street yesterday. Mrs. Augusta E. Stetson, the most prominent of the local members of the cult, tendered her resignation as First Reader of the church. Edwin F. Hatfield, the Second Reader of the church, also resigned after a service lasting five years.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 -- Congressman McCleary may have a rival for his seat in the House of Representatives. State Senator Somerville may enter the arena. He has said that he is not a candidate, but admits that he may become such. There is a growing feeling that the present Congressmen have got out of touch with the folk at home, particularly on the matter of Cuban reciprocity and the lumber tariff.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 27 -- An inquest win be begun to-morrow on the trolley disaster of last night which caused the death of Sture B. Lindstrom, a motorman, the serious injury of three other persons, and injuries in less degree to at least fifteen others.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much of the present prosperity of this country is fictitious. The buying power of a dollar is not what it was when William McKinley was first inaugurated. Americans are beginning to realize that the Republican Party is dominated by the trusts.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 27 -- Gen. Fitzhugh Lee said to-night: "I believe that the crisis in Cuban affairs is now. The Cubans were promised an independent Government, and they have it. Now they will have to prove that they can give security to property and maintain order in the island.

CHICAGO, JUlY 27 -- The engagement has been announced of Miss Atta Medora McMullen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. McMullin of Watertown, N.Y., to Alson Skinner Clark, son of Mr. aha Mrs. A.B. Clark of Chicago. A.E. Clark is President of the Wadsworth-Howland Company, paint and color grinder.

The conclusions of Mr. Justice MAYER, after a careful and judicial review of the testimony submitted in the case of McAULIFFE, the Glennon witness, who died in Roosevelt Hospital from the effects of a brutal and murderous beating, may warrant the police of the Nineteenth Precinct in exchanging surreptitious congratulations; the impression on a decent citizen is quite another matter.

PRETORIA, June 20 -- But think what a labor lies before the "Repatriation Committee" lately appointed here under Mr. Duncan, the State Treasurer! In the Transvaal alone there are 20,000 Boer families to be set going again. The committee works day and night in the midst of extreme difficulties, partly due to that "dual control" which is always enough to wreck the best intentions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some time ago there appeared in THE TIMES a special dispatch from London touching the color question in that great metropolis. The writer went on to say that a negro from Liberia came to London to study certain industrial phases of London life with a view of returning to his home to apply the same.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 27 -- Expensive errors at critical periods on the part of the visiting baseball players contributed in the main to their defeat at Charlotte this afternoon. Home runs by Blake and Zimmer were features. Score by innings:

McCURTAIN, I.T., July 27 -- Two men were killed and two others seriously burned by an explosion of gas to-day in one of the Sans Bois Coal Company's mines, one mile west of here. The dead are Andrew Dazell and James Brown. The names of the two injured men have not been learned.

The latest candidate for honors of the sea in the matter of traveling long distances in small boats is Capt. William Finn, who arrived yesterday from Savannah in a strange looking craft called the Shad, now anchored off the foot of Twenty-fifth Street, Brooklyn. Capt. Finn is a rigger who has seen much of the world and lives with his wife and eight children at 221 Thirty-third Street, South Brooklyn.
PARIS, July 28 -- Jehan Georges Vibert, the painter, is dead. He was born in 1840.

MONTREAL, July 28 -- Montreal shut the Jersey City baseball team out to-day, Souders being most effective with men on the bases. The only run was scored on Quinlan's two-base hit, Johnson's sacrifice, and Stafford's infield hit. Score:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 28 -- J.P. Mullahy, Secretary of the Stationary Firemen's Association of Pennsylvania, was arrested here this afternoon charged with libel. Twenty-five complaints had been lodged against him by men who are now employed in various capacities by the coal companies in this section.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Representative Bartholdt of Missouri had this to say today about the Republican outlook in his State:

William S. Devery made a speech on trusts, imperialism, and other weighty subjects of political discussion at a gathering of business men and others of the Ninth Assembly District last evening. The meeting hall in the Grand Opera House, opposite the Devery headquarters, was crowded, and, although the men sweltered under the rays of many gas lights, they stayed to hear the ex-Chief of Police deliver his talk.

Another mystery was handed to the police to be cleared up when William Rogy of Washington Avenue and Ocean Parkway, Parkville, Brooklyn, stepped into the Parkville Station yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock and told the Sergeant that he had found his nineteen-year-old sister Jenny in an unconscious state, gagged and tied to her bed.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 28 -- Two men were killed, another is dying, and scores are nursing broken heads and bruised bodies to-night as a result of the bitter factional fight in the Republican Party in the First District for delegates to the Congressional Convention which will be held at Woodbury on Wednesday.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 28 -- The Brazos and Colorado Rivers are not rising this evening, but incessant rains along their upper courses during the past twenty-four hours will augment the floods and cause disastrous overflows of the lower valleys.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Representative George P. Burgess of Texas called at Democratic headquarters to-day, and while there was asked what he thought of the Republican activity on the trust question and of the attitude of the President on that question.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28 -- The Grand Circuit harness meeting opened here to-day with all conditions favorable for a successful week of trotting and pacing. The weather was warm and delightful until a rain storm came and drenched the track so thoroughly that the 2:00 pace, in which three heats had been decided, had to be postponed until to-morrow. Summary:

The reappointment of Messrs. CRANE and DEUEL and the appointment of Mr. BREEN as City Magistrates by Mayor Low were made in accordance with the recommendations of the Republican organization and that of the Greater New York Democracy. They are not all especially good, and certainly not so good as the importance of the posts, the high salary, and the long tenure required and should have made possible.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 28 -- The final reports from the May and June examinations that were sent out to-day from the university show that more than fifty students have been dropped from their respective classes to lower classes. A majority of those dropped are in the School of Science department.

Charles Griffith Moses Brother have sold for Henrietta D. Beaver to Alphonse Schrednitz the two five-story apartment houses 428 and 430 St. Nicholas Avenue, near One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, on plot 51 by 125.

Gold exports were resumed yesterday, and $3,696,654.45 of the yellow metal was engaged for export to-day to Berlin and Paris. Of this amount, the National City Bank ships $1,908,204.87, which goes "in transit" to Germany and is intended for a special purpose, so it is understood, although the bank officials would not give details of the transaction.

It was decided last night that there would be no row-off of the protested race between the four-oared junior gig crews of the Nassau Boat Club and the Nonpareil Rowing Club. This was the outcome of a special meeting of the Board of Governors of the Nassau Club held in the New York Athletic Club, at which Fred Vilmar presided.
During the storm lightning struck the Ingram Dye Works in Long Island City, setting the plant on fire. It was totally destroyed, causing a loss of $15,000.
LONDON, July 28 -- Increased demand for borrowings and renewed scarcity of funds were attributed to-day to the Stock Exchange settlement. Discounts were firm.

Among the prettiest of corset covers are those made of dotted Swiss, the smallest dots being used as a rule. They are gathered into a band at the neck and held by a ribbon, and gathered in again at the waist line and held by another ribbon. They cost only $1.25 each. A woman who wears pretty clothes says a corset cover like that is as easy to wash as a pocket handkerchief.

With its vault full of money and securities which it could not get at, the Phenix National Bank, at 49 Wall Street, conducted its business yesterday on borrowed capital. Time, acting through a time lock, had temporarily enjoined the opening of the vault, and President Parmly and Cashier Bull were powerless to quash the injunction.

HANOVER, July 28 -- After a day's rest the chess players engaged in the international tournament were informed that for the pairing of the sixth round, contested to-day, the fifteenth round of the Berger system would be used, and the players accordingly met in the following order:

The Rev. Dr. Stephen Livingston Baldwin, Recording Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church for twenty years, died of typhoid fever yesterday at the home of his son, Stephen C. Baldwin, at 127 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. Dr. Baldwin was born in Somerville, N.J., in 1835.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 28 -- The most terrific storm in twenty years visited this, section to-night. The lightning repeatedly struck various places in town. People traveling on trolley cars had experiences that will last them a long time. It is reported that the conductor and motorman of one car were killed near Glen Ridge.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Reports from Kansas indicate that the State politicians are in a fair way to be treated to a considerable surprise when the Senatorial fight ends. Representatives Curtis and Long, accounted two of the best politicians in Kansas, have been struggling for Senator Harris's seat, and the Kansas prophets were disputing which was most likely to get the place.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 28 -- President Roosevelt and his family, with the exception of Miss Alice, paid a farewell visit this afternoon to the officers and men of the Mayflower, which then started for Newport under orders from Washington, to join the Atlantic Squadron for target practice. The President took occasion to compliment Lieut. Edward McCauley, who early in the morning had saved one of two deserting members of the crew from drowning.

Charles F. Hill, trainer of the racing stable of Clarence H. Mackay, yesterday at the Brighton Beach race track made the announcement that he had received a cable message from Mr. Mackay directing him to dispose of the entire racing establishment because of the death of Mr. Mackay's father, John W. Mackay, a week ago last Sunday.

-- One of the correspondents whose many letters we published on Sunday seems rather seriously -- "seriously" in at least two senses -- to have misunderstood and misinterpreted the treatment which Mr. W. S. DEVERY is now receiving from the New York papers. "For years," wrote the correspondent, "the press have told us that DEVERY was everything that was vile and corrupt, and now they tell us that he is good and pure."

LONDON, July 29 -- A South African Blue Book which has just been issued shows that the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, has consented to a proposal made by Lord Milner, British High,Commissioner in South Africa, as the result of the good feeling prevailing between the Dutch and the British.

Col. R.B. WEDDLE, aged sixty years, or Ardmore, Indian Territory, formerly of New York, was killed in a runaway near Sulphur, Col. He was active in politics in New York prior to his removal to Ardmore. He was a veteran of the civil war.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 28 -- President John B. Nicklin of the Southern League has received the following self-explanatory telegram from the National Board of Professional Baseball Clubs, dated Niagara Falls. N.Y.:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 5 -- For the last two or three weeks the news that peace had been declared was confidently expected throughout Australia and New Zealand. Hope had become confidence and expectations certainly, so that when the actual announcement was made there was perhaps hardly the same triumphant demonstration that greeted the news of the relief of Ladysmith, or even, more, of the relief of Mafeking.

The fifth and final baseball game of the series between the Brooklyn and New York Clubs wag won by the New York team yesterday by a score of 2 to 0. The game was called before the latter half of the fifth inning was completed and then there were two of the home players out.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28 -- The leading attraction for the Summer residents this evening was the open-air theatre at Freebody Park, where vaudeville, including Pauline Hall, was presented. There were many theatre parties, every box and nearly all the orchestra chairs being occupied by cottagers.

OMAHA, Neb., July 28 -- All roads east of the Mississippi River, together with the Union Pacific in the West, will probably find themselves facing a demand from their trainmen for increased wages or stand a strike. The demand will be made on all roads at the same time and action will be forced immediately thereafter.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- New York exchange was at par to-day. Time and call loans 4 1/2 and 5 per cent. Swift Co.'s stock performed an acrobatic feat to-day on the local Stock Exchange as a result of the stories that the representatives of this concern and Armour Co. had reached a point in the negotiations for a merger where a consolidation was likely to result.

Two trains of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company crashed into each other in Adams Street yesterday morning , and about thirty persons were injured, two of them so seriously that it is believed that they will die.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 28 -- The strength of Alabama Coal and Iron issues continues to be one of the most interesting features of the market. There is a confident accumulation of these issues on a rising scale by interests which expect to witness a strong speculative movement in them shortly after they are listed.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- A.M. Rothschild, until two months ago the head of the State Street department store, firm of A.M. Rothschild Co., committed suicide to-day at his home, Thirty-seventh Court and Michigan Avenue, by shooting himself in the head, the wound inflicted causing almost instant death.

TACOMA, Washington, July 28 -- Vast areas of timber along thousands of miles of the heavily wooded Yukon slopes have been ravaged by fires and devastated of their splendid growth of spruce and birch timber within the last few weeks. In places the flames yet rage riotously, carrying destruction before them.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 28 -- William Nixon tried to win a woman's confidence in the guise of outlaw Tracy and is nearly dead as a result of his act. He told an actress in a music hall that he was none other than the desperado, and threatened her life if she told.

Perhaps what may fairly be called the meanest part of the manifesto of the anti-imperialists is the attack upon the Secretary of War. The manifestants are careful to distinguish and dissociate the Secretary from the President, whose agent and organ he officially and legally is.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- The local market to-day was somewhat dull, but bore up fairly well under depressing Wall Street advices. Cambria Steel was the feature in activity. The stock was freely offered throughout the morning, but was quickly taken by what are supposed to be inside interests.

Ex-Mayor Edward Cooper appeared in the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon as complainant against Herrmann Wilhelm Truebner, who represents himself to be the Baron von Manteuffel, son of Gen. von Manteuffel, once Governor of Alsace-Lorraine.

C.S. Titus, the representative of the Union Boat Club of this city, who was unsuccessful in his quest for the Diamond Sculls at the Henley regatta, arrived on the Atlantic Transport liner Minnehaha yesterday. Titus was accompanied by his wife, and both were cordially greeted by a number of friends, who had gathered on the pier to welcome them home.

It is easier for any camel to go through the eye of any needle than for a Republican Senator to see and admit the true reason for the failure of the Cuban reciprocity treaty. Senator O.H. PLATT of Connecticut begins an article in The North American Review in a spirit of candor and frankness that enlists the sympathetic interests of the reader.

BOSTON, Mass., July 28 -- The money market is showing very little change. It remains quiet and still inclined to work easier. Loanable funds are apparently in abundant supply, but demand is still light. The weekly statement of the associated local banks, issued to-day, shows a gain in the reserve of $19,857.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

There is a reaction in society this week. Beyond the set entertainments, such as dinners, luncheons, and the regular dances at Casinos, there is really nothing of importance. So far, there does not seem to be a wedding in prospect until that of Mr. Thatcher and Miss Davies on Aug. 9. Mr. Thatcher will give his farewell bachelor dinner at Sherry's on Thursday evening.

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., July 28 -- What is regarded as the severest earthquake ever felt in Southern California did much damage last night in Northern Santa Barbara County. The shocks lasted for fifteen minutes. The district most affected was from Lompoce to San Maria. The most curious result was the filling of a dry river bed with water.

Controller Grout made public yesterday a report of Accountant' Charles S. Hervey, showing that the charges of misapplication of city funds by the trustees of the Ameri- can Museum of Natural History were unfounded. Alderman Reginald Doull, Tammany, preferred the charges and protested against any further bond issues being made to the Museum of Natural History.

The reappearance of the stout campaigner Advance Guard, after a long rest, lent a spice to the mile and a furlong handicap, fourth on the card at the Brighton Beach track yesterday, that made that event the real as well as the nominal feature of the programme, the presence of the Canadian-owned horse making the race one of the toughest problems of the meeting for the betting element.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Certain distinguished leaders of the reorganized, or partially reorganized. Democratic Party are planning a new move with regard to the next House of Representatives. Among them, and the main source of their inspiration, is said to be Ben Cable, who, although he has been in Europe until recently, has been in touch with his fellow-leaders.

Mrs. William Van Slooten has begun an action in the Supreme Court of Brooklyn against H. McK. Twombly and James B. Haggin to recover 10 per cent. commission on money to the amount of $6,500,000, invested by the defendants, as she alleges, at the instance of her late husband, in copper mines in Cerro de Pasco, Peru.

SYDNEY, C.B., July 28 -- Prof. Alexander Graham Bell has nearly completed his flying machine, which he expects to test very shortly. The machine is being built under his personal direction and is radically different from Santos-Dumont's machine.

Yesterday's stock market opened with a show of weakness. Many stocks declined, some of them substantially. All the professional talent of the Stock Exchange opened their business week with energetic bear programmes. Stocks were sold short on a new scale.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 28 -- P.T. Powers, President of the Eastern League and National Association of Baseball Leagues, arrived in the city to-day. En route to Toronto with J.H. Farrell, President of the New York State League, and M.H. Sexton, Chairman of the Western and Three L. Leagues, be transacted important business for the National Association of Baseball Leagues.

Chief Rabbi Jacob Joseph of the United Jewish Congregations, the highest official in the orthodox Jewish religion in the United States, died at 11:45 o'clock last night in his home, at 263 Henry Street. He had been an invalid from paralysis for two years. When his death was announced hundreds of Jewish men and women gathered outside the house to lament their loss.
The panther which escaped from the Bronx Zoological Park an Sunday was captured last night and returned to his cage in the park.

From time to time THE NEW YORK TIMES has printed tables showing the valuations made on city real estate for purposes of taxation. In the list printed below are shown the assessments on such properties as have had their valuations changed since last year:

Deimel Dwyer's cold Africander won the Winged Foot Handicap at Brighton Beach yesterday. He carried 119 pounds, and equaled the track record for five and a half furlongs, running the distance in 1:06 3-5. He was favorite, with the Keene representative, Injunction, next in demand, while any price was good against Smiles and Kisses.

It was, of course, the plain duty of the Controller to investigate the serious charges made in the Board of Aldermen against the management of the American Museum of Natural History. It is the right of the board to know the facts, whatever they may be, and it is the right of the managers of the Museum that injurious statements, whether merely erroneous or malicious, should be probed and their exact value determined.

LONDON, July 30. -- The London Gazette last night contained a royal proclamation fixing Aug. 9 as the date for the coronation, which, it says, "We were constrained to adjourn to a day in August," and "which we have resolved by the favor and blessing of Almighty God to celebrate on the aforesaid date."
LONDON, July 30. -- The Times says the fleet has been ordered to assemble at Spithead on Aug. 7 instead of Aug. 11. The fleet will salute King Edward as he crosses from Cowea to Portsmouth on Aug. 8.

The trial for neglect of duty, bribery and perjury, of Patrolman S.J. Reagan of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, who was Wardman for Capt. Herlihy when the latter commanded the Eldridge Street precinct, was resumed yesterday at Police Headquarters before Deputy Commissioner Thurston.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Kreigh Collins of Kenwood wrested the Western tennis championship in singles from R.D. Little of Princeton to-day at the Kenwood Country Club tournament, in one of the most brilliant and bitterly contested matches ever witnessed in this part of the country. Collins, by perfect play, succeeded in winning the first two sets, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5.

The first dog ever admitted to the Poorhouse in Brooklyn entered there on Monday afternoon. He was taken in because his aged mistress, to whom he had faithfully stuck in her adversity, could not be parted from him.

PARIS, July 29. -- The agitation resulting from the circular issued by Premier Combes with regard to the closing of the unauthorized Congregationist schools has considerably abated, even in Brittany, owing to the circumstance that none of the recalcitrant schools will be forcibly closed until special decrees to this end have been signed for each department.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29. -- Reginald C. Vanderbilt gave to-night the first entertainment at Sand Point farm, which he recently purchased and has had materially improved for use this Summer. The entertainment took the form of a dinner for his male friends, twenty-four in number. The table decorations weae entirely of American beauty roses, and the rooms were decorated with tall stalks of pink hollyhocks.

BOSTON, July 29. -- The demand for money is still light, and rates, both for call and time money, are unchanged, although the latter are a little more firm than of late. Sterling exchange, though quiet, is firm in tone. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 5c discount. Call loans, 3 to 4. Time money, 4 1/2 to 5.

Yesterday's market was heavy throughout. Advances were exceptional. The declines averaged about 1 per cent. Rock Island dropped between 3 and 4 points. No new official disclosure was made of the plan for readjusting the company's capitalization, though the fact that some important insiders are smarting under "Wall Street criticism is manifest.

A shower of sparks, then a sheet of flame on the sidewalk of West Thirty-fifth Street, opposite the Herald Square Theatre, at 10 o'clock last night created a panic and sent a surging crowd into the street under the impression that the Herald Square Theatre was in flames.

Four men were seriously injured early yesterday morning by flying rock, which was uprooted by the explosion of three pounds of dynamite in the subway excavation between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets yesterday. The accident happened within little more than a hundred feet from the scene of the great explosion of Jan. 8, when several persons were killed and two hotels, the Murray Hill and Grand Union, were partially wrecked.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Representative Babcock of Wisconsin, Chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, was in the city to-day on a short visit, coming over from New York. Mr. Babcock spoke confidently of victory for the Republican Party in the coming Congressional elections.

LONDON, July 30. -- Many pages of The London Gazette yesterday were filled with Lord Kitchener's final dispatch on the Boer war, and his mention of the officers and men who distinguished themselves while he was in command in South Africa.

SARATOGA, July 29. -- This greatest of our inland Summer resorts afflicted with the same sombre Summer as all the rest of the North, but it is looking hopefully forward to the gayest season it has ever known. Clouds hang like a pall over the banks of foliage which rise out of the streets to tower above the houses, and either every day or every other day it rains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "No injunction was ever granted which denied a workingman the right to stop work, to agree with others to stop work, or to influence and persuade those willing to work not to do so." The above sentence occurs in an editorial on "Strikes and Injunctions" in THE TIMES of Saturday, July 26.

LONDON, July 29. -- Many American and English friends of the family were present today at a requiem mass in St. Mary's Catholic Church, Cadogan Square, for the repose of the soul of John W. Mackay. The members of the family present were Clarence Mackay the Princess Colonna, with her young son, and the daughter and two sons of the Countess Telfner.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29. -- The will of Cyrus O. Baker, the New York banker, who died at his home in Franklin Street, this city, on July 4, was filed for record here to-day. Thirty-eight bequests, ranging in amounts from $1,000 to $60,000, are made, and $10,000 is given to religious and charitable societies.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 29. -- The death of Patrolman Harry Miller, one of the victims of the political rioting that occurred here last night at the Republican primaries for the election of delegates to the Congressional Convention in this county, may occur at any time, as he is lying in a critical condition in the Cooper Hospital.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

Probably nobody expects that the South African war will lead to any real military reform in England. A war which, after all, the British Army did ultimately win is not going to convert the British Army from an agreeable resort for young men of means to a scene of hard work and merit.

ALBANY, July 29. -- An application was made to Attorney General Davies to-day by Benjamin Hilton of East Orange, N.J., asking that an action be begun on behalf of the State for the dissolution of the American Lithographic Company of New-York and for the appointment of a receiver to wind up its affairs.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 29. -- In a hard fought match on the grounds of the Saratoga Polo Club this afternoon, the Rockaway team defeated that of Lakewood in the first match of the series for the junior championship. The score was 11 to 7 1/2, Lakewood having been penalized one-half in the third period for a foul.
LONDON, July 30. -- The by-election for member of the House of Commons to represent North Leeds resulted in the election of Rowland Barran, Liberal.

BOSTON, July 29. -- The Journal says: "It comes from the best of authority that the plan for readjusting the capitalization of the Mexican Central Railway Company is finally in a practically completed form, and its formal announcement is only delayed by the perfecting of a few minor details. The foreign interests are now all in line, and are ready to assume their share of the burden that will be entailed in consummating the arrangements.

Transactions on the curb yesterday were fairly well distributed throughout the list, but a great many recessions occurred. Virginia Iron, Coal, and Coke bonds, Toledo Railway and Light, and Dominion securities were the only stocks which showed articular strength. Northern Securities, which have been quite active of late, sold off at one time over a point, but later recovered somewhat and closed at the same price as the preceding day.

TRENTON, N.J., July 29. -- The report of the trust companies, savings banks, and State banks in New Jersey at the close of business June 30 has been compiled by the Bank and Insurance Commissioner, and shows a big increase of assets and deposits as compared with the returns of Dec. 31, 1901.

The owl gained his traditional reputation for wisdom by looking wise and saying nothing. There is no reason to suppose that he ever was wise; but since tie appeared to be, and took care not to correct the popular impression on this point, he has held his place as the companion and confidant of Minerva.

MONTREAL, July 29. -- The Montreal baseball team would have shut Jersey City out again to-day but for O'Hara's error. McGee pitched finely. McCann was hit hard and had poor support. Raub's work was the feature. Score:

-- Painful duty has compelled us to criticise with some severity the proclamation of suspicions and credulities in the guise of facts recently issued from Lake George by certain amiable old gentlemen -- who ought to have found, in that delightful region, occupation at once pleasanter and more profitable for the Summer months.

We particularly commend to the attention of our anti-imperialist friends the case of Capt. WILD of the Thirteenth Infantry, and the manner in which it has been dealt with by that ruthless military despot, Gen. CHAFFEE.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 29. -- Railroad stocks followed the same course in this market as in New York, but otherwise the weakness in Wall Street found no reflection here. Reading, Lehigh Valley, Pennsylvania, the traction stocks, Consolidated Lake Superior, and Cambria Steel were the active issues.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 29. -- President Roosevelt is to make his next excursion from Sagamore Hill on Thursday morning, not to Newport or Richfield Springs, as has been reported, but to witness the gunners of the Mayflower at target practice. Miss Alice will probably go to Newport and later to the springs.

Though the former Police Chief DEVERY is a foolish and vulgar person, and though his illiteracy, his impudence, his coarse vanity are amusing enough, there is a significance in his present "campaign" worth a little consideration. It affords a striking proof of the nature of the motive animating the conduct of the numerous and powerful class to which he belongs, and in which he has held a place at once prominent, profitable, and influential.

Again the project of developing Newark meadows comes to the front, this time with what appears to be very substantial financial backing. Like announcements have been made so often and with so much circumstantiality that those for whom the subject has interest will be inclined to be skeptical of the imminence of the proposed improvements.

That the new vegetable remedy found in the Hawaiian Islands will give new life and strength to diseased digestive organs; allay all inflammation and restore the digestive fluids to their full strength and quantity, can no longer be doubted. Thousands are testifying to this fact weekly and the greatest praise and strongest expressions of satisfaction come from chronic dyspeptics and those who for years have tried to cure this disease with digestive ferments and drugs.

The wheezy old piano and the blatant notes of a cornet were discordantly mingled at an early hour this morning, when Inspector Harley and eight bluecoats made a raid on the Haymarket, at the corner of Thirtieth Street and Sixth Avenue. The scene when the raid started was much the same as goes on within the place every night.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The State Department has no hesitation in fully approving the energetic and sufficient action of Commander McCrea in taking care of the foreign Consuls and in preventing a bombardment without warning. The American and foreign interests in Cape Haitien are large, and an American Captain is required by the unwritten law to look after the life and property of other foreign residents as well as Americans in such cases.

Another chapter in the long fight of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Sternberger for the custody of their two children was enacted yesterday before Justice Dickey in the Supreme Court of Brooklyn, Mr. Sternberger, who is a son of the late Simon Sternberger, once a banker of this city, was a member of the New York Stock Exchange when the controversy began in 1895.

LONDON, July 29. -- Money was in brisk demand to-day, owing to the settlement and end of the month demands, beside requirements for the holidays, Aug. 2, 4, and 9, and calls on fresh issues of capital. Some foreign money was withdrawn from the market and discounts were harder.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 29. -- The weather conditions for the last day of circuit racing under the auspices of the Lake Yacht Racing Association, held off Ontario Beach to-day, were favorable with the exception of light wind, which throughout the day did not at any time exceed five knots and gradually died away during the afternoon.

ROME, July 29. -- Cardinal Gotti, Prefect of the Sacred Congregation of Bishops and Regulars and of Regular Discipline, was to-day appointed Prefect of the Propaganda to succeed the late Cardinal Ledochowskl.

Mr. BEN T. CABLE'S methods are revolutionary. In the whole course of the discussion about restoring harmony in the Democratic Party no suggestion has been made so astonishing as the idea attributed to him that "whether the Democrats control the next House or not, it is highly necessary to have a few really strong men in Congress who can give tone and dignity to the minority operations and lay a foundation for the Presidential campaign."

Hosea B. Perkins, who was at one time recognized as an orator of no mean ability, and more recently was called "the Silver-Tongued Orator of Washington Heights," died yesterday morning in his homestead on King's Bridge Road. Those who were children in New York twenty-five or thirty years ago remember him especially well as a Fourth of July orator, who would arouse their patriotism to the highest pitch.

In response to requests for information concerning the plan for an exchange of fellowships between the French and American universities, mentioned in a cable dispatch, the following statement was made yesterday at Columbia University:

Internal troubles in the Union Boat Club which have been brewing since early in the year, have culminated in the bringing of charges of professionalism against C.S. Titus, the American sculler, who competed in the recent regatta at Henley, England.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 29. -- The four days' race meet of the Island Park Racing Association opened to-day. The track was lightning fast, yet only fair time was made. The feature was the Capital City Stakes of $1,000, which proved easy for James W. Brawbine's bay gelding Locanda, by Allerton, who, excellently piloted by Brodbine, landed the race in straight heats. Summaries:

LONGWOOD, Mass., July 29. -- As if satisfied with the measure they had taken of the American lawn tennis players, the famous Doherty brothers of the English challenging team for the Dwight F. Davis international cup withdrew from the singles to-day in the Longwood open tournament.

Francis Lynde Stetson, counsel for the Northern Pacific Railway Company, is having a hard time of it in his effort to have Peter Power, the plaintiff in the Northwest merger suit, produced by his attorney, George Alfred Lamb, for the purpose of telling what he (Power) knows about the inception of the suit.

Florence Wilkeraon, eleven years old, an orphan, who lived on Blackwell's Island with her grandfather, Matthew Elias, the foreman of the cookshop, and was a great pet on the Island, was drowned yesterday while bathing off the Almshouse, in the East River.

New York's baseball players were decisively beaten by the St. Louis players on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The visitors outbatted the local aggregation, the final score being 5 to 1 in favor of St. Louis. Poor batting and Inability to hit at critical moments were what lost the game for New York.

LONDON, July 30. -- The Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, appeared in the House of Commons yesterday afternoon for the first time since his recent accident. He was greeted with hearty cheering, and later he was warmly congratulated by Sir Henry Campbell-Ban-Lerman, Liberal leader in the House.

LONDON, July 29. -- The one hundredth anniversary of the inauguration of the Goodwood racing meeting was favored with perfect weather. The social interest in the occasion was somewhat dampened by the absence of the King, but the party at Goodwood House included the Duke of Cambridge, Prince Christian of Denmark, and Prince, and Princess Edward of Saxe-Weimar.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 29. -- The markets chief concern centred around the group of Washington railway bonds and Cotton Duck incomes; the decline in City and Suburban (Washington) 5s and the Anacostla and Potomac 5s was checked by the wringing of an official admission that the maturing coupons on each set of bonds would be paid.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 29. -- Foxhall Keene has leased the camp of Howard Bucknell on the upper Saranac Lake, and it is being made ready for the coming of Mr. and Mrs. Keene, who are expected in a few days. The camp adjoins that of Talbot J. Taylor, brother-in-law of Mr. Keene, who, with Mrs. Taylor, are now on the upper Saranac.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 30 -- Eighteen hare fought heats were decided on the secoknd day of the Columbus Grand Circuit meeting, and the racing was the most sensational ever witnessed over the local track. The 2:09 pacers made a world's record for a six-heat race, the average time for the Six miles being exactly 2:06.

BERLIN, July 30 -- Trading on the Boerse to-day was dull. Advices from New York were discouraging. Bank shares and industrials were easier, and Canadian Pacifics relapsed. Internationals were quiet and prices were maintained.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30 -- There was little in the way of entertainment among the Summer residents to-day. The ladies' lawn tennis tournament in doubles attracted many to the Casino, and the one match played was an excellent exhibition of tennis which was well worth looking at. It was between Miss Maude Livingston and Mrs. Barger Wallach.

SARATOGA, July 30 -- In one respect this is the queerest of all "cure resorts." The most conspicuous visitors stay up late, get up late, and do not begin the day's enjoyment until afternoon. Saratoga is a quiet and almost pious place at noon. It is at nearly midnight that you see it at its gayest.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 30 -- The ball at the Malvern to-night drew out all the dancing crowd. Several large dinners were given previously. Mr. and Mrs. De Grasse Fox entertained at the Inn. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. A.Y. Stewart, Miss Sylvia Fox, Mr. and Mrs. N.I. Amory, Miss Livingston, Philip Stewart, H. Thorndike, Baron Frankenstein, and Mr. and Mrs. J.J. Emery.

Army. First Lieut. William J. Barden, Corps of Engineers, upon the completion of his present duties, is assigned to duty with the Third Battalion of Engineers and at the Engineer School of Application.
Mr. BABCOCK, the Chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, in trying to throw ridicule on the opposition to the tariff-bred and tariff-nurtured trusts, makes himself ridiculous.

By the use of a strong trudgeon stroke E. H. Adams of the Bath Beach Swimming Club, yesterday won the quarter-mile championship of Brooklyn. The competitions were held off the old iron pier at Coney Island, and Adams was opposed by George W. Van Cleaf of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, his strongest opponent, who has won national honors.

BOSTON, Mass., July 30 -- Call money is in notably good supply, and quoted rates therefor are frequently shaded. Time money is more firmly held. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds par to 5 cents discount; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4; time money, 4 1/2 to 5. Clearing House exchanges, $12,348,286; balances, $1,953,050.

Concerning the affairs of the American Lithographic Company, with reference to the application for the appointment of a receiver, Louis Marshall of the law firm of Guggenhelmer, Untermyer Marshall, representing the majority of the stockholders, said yesterday:
H.K. Kielhauser has been appointed northwestern Ohio general agent of the Union Casualty and Surety Company of St. Louis.
LONDON, July 31 -- Mr. Carnegie's gift of the Acton library to Mr. Morley is considered very appropriate, and meets with great approval. The Daily News says:

Mrs. Justin L. Sherwood, who was burned about the body while alone in her apartments in the fourth story of the apartment house at 156 West Eighty-fourth Street, on Tuesday evening, died early yesterday morning.

Pitcher Cronin won the baseball game for New York on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and more than atoned for the defeat of the local team by St. Louis the day previous. Only three runs were made in the game, and two of these were tallied by McGraw and Dunn.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 30. -- The market was largely interested in Cotton Duck issues to-day owing to the meeting held at Jersey City, at which the company was to receive the semi-annual report, and at the same time decide whether to pay any of the accumulated coupons on the income bonds.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 -- Local issues were generally firm to-day, but the market was very dull. New York's early weakness and late rally were alike ineffective, and the close here was lifeless, with a few small advances. Cambria Steel at the opening was offered down to 27, but advanced 1/4, as did Philadelphia Rapid Transit and Consolidated Lake Superior.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 30 -- The band wagon which was conveying the Ilion baseball team to Suburban Park this afternoon was struck at the Broad Street crossing in Lestershire by Erie Train No. 2. The driver was instantly killed and six others were injured, one seriously. Both horses were also instantly killed.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 30 -- Arrangements are nearly completed for observing the fortieth anniversary of the ordination to the priesthood of the Rev. Dr. Richard Lalor Burtsall, who has been for a number of years past in charge of St. Mary's Church, in this city. On Aug. 10, Dr. Burtsall will celebrate a solemn high mass of thanksgiving, assisted by his classmates and close clerical friends.

HOLYOKE, Mass., July 30 -- The second day's racing under the auspices of the Holyoke Park Association at Springdale Park was marked by many accidents. San Telmo took a wheel off Allie Snell's sulky in the 2:17 pace and was declared distanced. In the free-for-all and the 2:21 not there were also accidents, but they were not serious.

LONGWOOD, Mass., July 30 -- Considerable interest in the performances of the lawn tennis experts was manifest to-day at the tournament of the Longwood Lawn Tennis Club. The famous Englishmen, R. F. and H.L. Doherty of the challenging team did not actually engage in any matches.

-- Wild animals, as a rule, are as much afraid of man as man is afraid of wild animals, and always the "zoo," wild animal is simply petrified with fear, at the sight of a human who is not on the other side of iron bars. But there's that word "wild."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Democratic Congressional Committee is practically ignoring the "Philippine question" in its campaign work. Senator Carmack puts in several hours a day boiling down the anti-imperialism speeches that were delivered in the Senate last session, and has no end of matter ready for the printer.

It was a great day yesterday for the Ninth Assembly District and William S. Devery, The free invitation excursion, looked forward to by 20,000 women and children of the neighborhood of the Four Corners with an impatient expectancy, was realized, and the dreams of a fortnight became an actual fact.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- The Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad has been sold and the purchaser is said to be the Illinois Central. The latter company has quietly executed a coup whereby a presumptive dangerous competitor, the Louisville and Nashville will be kept out of Chicago.

Peter Dujke, a Danish gardener, was working around the house of Mrs. William E. Murray, at 65 West Ninetieth Street, yesterday, when he brought up with a spadeful of earth a diamond earring. He took it with him to his home, at One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street and Morris Avenue, and afterward sold it to Jacob Meyer, a jeweler at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-second Street, for 75 cents.

INVERNESS, July 30 -- Andrew Carnegie, who is now at Skibo Castle, spoke warmly and eloquently to-day of Abram S. Hewitt, whom he called "America's foremost private citizen." Mr. Hewitt, says Mr. Carnegie, is the "Grand Old Man" of the United States, honest, pure, exceeding wise, public-spirited, and patriotic.

The Rock Island Company filed articles of incorporation with County Clerk Maurice Stack at Jersey City yesterday. The capital stock is $150,000,000, divided into 540,000 shares of preferred stock and 960,000 shares of common stock. The preferred stock is to control the entire Board of Directors, and dividends of 4 per cent. are guaranteed up to 1903, and 6 per cent. up to 1916.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Shay of 73 Congress Street, Jersey City, brought suit yesterday before Judge Smith in the Hoboken District Court against R. William Johnson of 26 Jewett Avenue, Jersey City, to recover $116, which they claim is due them for taking care of a house at New York Avenue and Congress Street, formerly occupied by Johnson and his mother.

The St. Louis and San Francisco has leased the Chicago and Eastern Illinois, according to a report which was published in Wall Street yesterday, and which was generally accepted as true. The terms of the lease were not published, except in the most general way, and the officers and Directors of both companies declined to discuss them.

A new world's record for a mile and a furlong was established at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, when Frank Farrell's horse Bonnibert finished first for the Islip Handicap in 1:51, or Just one-fifth of a second better than the old record, held jointly by Watercure and Roehampton, and made over the same course.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 30 -- Abram S. Hewitt, who, for more than half a century, has been one of the virile forces in the life of the Nation, will to-morrow celebrate his eightieth birthday. He is the typical representative of a class of American citizens whose ultimate aim is the good of the State and the uplifting of the people.

Major Gen. Arthur MacArthur, commanding the Department of the East, was at his desk yesterday in the suite of offices, which he has had fitted up for his use on the fourth floor of the Army Building. Gen. MacArthur will be at his office in the Army Building daily until the beginning of the naval and military manoeuvres, which will take place late in August, or early in September.

If we were asked to say how this community is accustomed to manifest its respect for Mr. ABRAM S. HEWITT we should reply that it is by listening to him, by paying heed and attention to his utterances. It is the privilege of age, when age follows upon a life full of deeds and abounding in wisdom, to be listened to; doubtless it has no higher privilege, no pleasure more grateful to a fine mind.

President Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission took immediate action on the suggestion of Mayor Low after the tunnel conference by appointing yesterday the conference committee to represent the Rapid Transit Commission in conference with the Committee from the Board of Aldermen. He named himself, Woodbury Langdon, and Controller Grout.

Charles Griffith Moses Brother have sold for Jane V. Chalfin and John Alexander Beall, administrators of the will of Charles M. Connolly. the southeast corner of Ninth Avenue and Two Hundred and Thirteenth Street and the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and Two Hundred and Twelfth Street.

Reports covering fiscal year railway operations are conspicuous features of daily news reports in Wall Street just now. And they uniformly have one characteristic -- extraordinary increases in earnings. Better barometer of National prosperity there could not be. And nobody will ignore the inspiriting fact -- nobody but the professional speculators of Wall Street.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., July 30 -- A reign or terror, compared with which the scenes enacted during the riots of 1900 seem insignificant, holds Shenandoah in its grasp to-night. Since 6 o'clock this evening. Centre Street, which is one of the principal streets of the town, has been in the hands of an infuriated mob.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 30 -- An estimate of the corn crop of the State furnished by the Burlington Railroad Company places the probable yield for this year at 280,000,000 bushels. The acreage is estimated at seven millions and the yield at forty bushels to the acre. Compared with Nebraska's best corn year, 1896, this is a loss in acreage of 700,000, against a gain in the total yield of two bushels per acre.

REDLANDS, Cal., July 30 -- The will of Dr. Charles Kendall Adams makes the following disposition of his property: After certain bequests to relatives, Emma May Stanton, Neenah, Wis., and Prof. John C. Shedd, Colorado Springs, the bulk of the estate is given to his executors and trustees in trust for his wife during her natural life.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 30 -- The Republican State Convention to-day named the following ticket:
BERLIN, July 30 -- The German Emperor has conferred a number of decorations on Americans incidental to the visit to the United States of Prince Henry of Prussia.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 30 -- The feature of to-day's racing at Island Park was the Clay Stakes, purse $2.00, which called to the post the largest field ever seen at this track, and which was finally won by Baron de Shay after a hard and long drawn out contest. The track was fast, and the finishes in the several heats were exciting Summaries:
In, The Evening Post of May 19, 1902, there appeared the following editorial remarks:

BOSTON, Mass., July 30 -- With the announcement to-day of the assignment of the Dudley Hosiery Mills at Newton, Upper Falls, came a report in financial circles of the misuse of notes of the Bowker Fertilizer Company, to the extent of $120,000, by Treasurer Henry F. Coe of the hoisery mills, who also had been Treasurer of the Bowker Company.

ERIE, Penn., July 30 -- Favorites lost all of the three races on the card, which were postponed from yesterday, and the talant was badly hit. There was a large attendance for opening day and the events were Interesting. There are four races on the card for to-morrow, and the fields are well mixed.
In, The Evening Post of May 19, 1902, there appeared the following editorial remarks:

BOSTON, Mass., July 30 -- With the announcement to-day of the assignment of the Dudley Hosiery Mills at Newton, Upper Falls, came a report in financial circles of the misuse of notes of the Bowker Fertilizer Company, to the extent of $120,000, by Treasurer Henry F. Coe of the hoisery mills, who also had been Treasurer of the Bowker Company.

ERIE, Penn., July 30 -- Favorites lost all of the three races on the card, which were postponed from yesterday, and the talant was badly hit. There was a large attendance for opening day and the events were Interesting. There are four races on the card for to-morrow, and the fields are well mixed.
LONDON, July 30 -- The demand for money was active to-day owing to the Stock Exchange, settlement. The market was dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were firm.

The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club will begin its two days of Midsummer racing this afternoon. To-day will be given over entirely to special races for boats in the one-design classes that are so numerous this year. This will be the first time that these small boats have been brought to-gether in a day of racing set apaft exclusively for them.

The incidents attending the funeral of Rabbi JOSEPH on Wednesday will be recalled with shame by every self-respecting citizen of New York. For their part in the affair the police are greatly to blame, and it is no injustice to those in charge of the police arrangements to say that they have shown their unfitness to be intrusted with the kind of responsibility which the handling of a peaceable crowd involves.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 31. -- A home run by Gettman with two men on bases in the eighth inning won to-day's game for Buffalo. Four errors by Buffalo in the first three innings gave Jersey City a lead of six runs, and it was an uphill fight for the local men. Catcher Shaw sprained a tendon while sliding for a base early in the game. He will be laid up for some time, Score:
LONDON, July 31 -- Money was in active request to-day and discounts were steady.

AN ANTE-NUPTIAL AGREEMENT -- Henry B. Baker before his marriage in January, 1900, to Dora Johnston, made an ante-nuptial agreement to bequeath to her, in case she survived him, $20,000 in lieu of dower, and if he failed to make such provision in his will then such sum was to be a charge against his estate.

Although he could not speak definitely. Chief Engineer W.J. Wilgus of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad talked freely yesterday relative to the proposed changes in the Park Avenue tunnel and suburban traffic system outlined in the Mayor's talk. Naturally, he declined to disclose the probable location of the intended union station in the Bronx.

THE TIMES was happily inspired when it undertook to mark Mr. Hewitt's eightieth birthday, which falls on July 31, by a special commemoration of his career and public services. The personal tributes which it has gathered from far and near constitute a sort of anticipatory monument to a man who has long enjoyed in a remarkable degree the respect and admiration of his fellow-citizens.

Trading on the curb yesterday continued in the same irregular and somewhat weak manner. Oregon Short Line bonds were again active and weak, losing a point in trading in 130 bonds. Union Pacific rights were quite active at slightly lower figures. Northern Securities were stronger and gained a quarter of a point on transactions in about 4,000 shares.

ALBANY, July 31 -- In a letter accompanying the reports of the Delaware. Lackawanna and Western Railroad and Syracuse, Binghamton and New York Railroad Companies, made to the State Railroad Commission for the quarter ended June 30, 1902, General Auditor Post says: "The decrease in gross earnings is due to the coal strike."

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 -- Robert McCarter, counsel for the plaintiffs in the case of J. Aspinwall Hodge and others against the United States Steel Corporation, asked Vice Chancellor Emery to-day to compel counsel for the corporation to file the additional pleadings, for the filing of which he had asked time.

SARATOGA, July 31 -- It seems nearer to New York than Hoboken when one looks the Saratoga crowds over. At the dances in the United States and Grand Union Hotels last night there were so many familiar faces that one might fancy the Waldorf close by. At the States are the families of Isidor Wormser, Jr., Simon Bernheimer, John W. Gates, George Gould, H.L. Herbert, A.J. Grenet, and Walter P. Bliss, all of New York.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., July 31 -- A wedding in the forest was the novelty for the campers of the Upper Saranac Lake region at noon to-day. Dr. Charles Hollister Judd and Miss Gertrude Bucknell, both of Philadelphia, were married at Chapel Island, a picturesque islet near the northern end of the lake, by the Rev. William C. Richardson, pastor of St. James's Church, Philadelphia.

New York's baseball players were beaten by the St. Louis team at the Polo Grounds yesterday because they were unable to hit the ball. St. Louis won by a score of 3 to 2. The Western men batted in good season and bunched their hits to advantage. Both teams played fine games in the field, but the better work was done by McGraw's men.
HANOVER, July 31 -- The chess masters engaged in the international tournament here began the ninth round this morning, being paired as follows:

Abram S. Hewitt, celebrating his eightieth birthday to-day in his summer home at Bar Harbor, is made the subject of loving tribute by several of the notable men who have been associated with him in some part of his varied career. There will be no dissent among those who know from the message sent from Scotland by Andrew Carnegie.

The Maritime Building, a twelve-Story structure running through from Bridge to Pearl, streets, opposite the new Custom House site, and facing on its westerly Bide the private street known as Custom House Place, has been sold by the Maritime Building Company to the Chesebrough Building Company.

DETROIT, July 31 -- Judge George H. Durand of Flint, who filled a vacancy on the Supreme bench of this State in 1892, and who is classed as a gold Democrat, was nominated for the Governorship by the Democrats of Michigan to-day. Judge Durand did not attend the convention nor authorize any one to state that he would accept the nomination if it should be accorded to him.

Health Commissioner Ernst J. Lederle said yesterday of the suggestion that the report on the prevalence of ophthalmia in the public schools, read at the monthly meeting of the Board of Education on Wednesday, was exaggerated:

In yesterday's security market they who believe in the healthfulness of conditions had much the best of it. Some short accounts of size were covered. But the effective influences of the day represented the confidence of investors and traders who prefer to trust prosperity's abounding evidences rather than the sorry pessimism whose habit is to submit to a licking two or three times a week.

LONGWOOD, Masa, July 31. -- Welllayed lawn tennis matches in the doubles for the Eastern championship to qualify for the Nationals at Newport to-day enlivened the tournament on the longwood Lawn Tennis Club. The redoubtable Bob Wrenn and his brother George L. Wrenn, Jr., made their first appearance in the series.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The opinion at the Treasury Department is that the balance sheet for July, which shows a deficit of about $7,500,000, affords very unreliable data from which to estimate the standing of the Treasury at the beginning of the year.

The deplorable culmination of the disorder in the anthracite districts in the murderous riot at Shenandoah need not surprise any one. It is the natural, and indeed inevitable, result of the policy of the operators in encouraging the belief among the strikers that they so completely control the situation that they may do what they like with impunity.

Collector Stranahan yesterday, under orders from Washington, seized the twelvethousand-dollar pearl necklace belonging to Mrs. L. Harrison Dulles of Philadelphia, which she had neglected to mention in her declaration of dutiable effects on her arrival on the Kronprinz Wilhelm, and which was taken from her by Special Agent Theobald on the pier of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company a few days ago.

LOS ALAMOS, Cal., July 31 -- Another severe earthquake shock was felt here at 7:3O to-night. It was almost as heavy as that of early this morning. There is now a reign of terror prevailing here. A slight shock was felt in San Barbara and Santa Maria at the same time. The most severe earthquake in the history of this place occurred at 1:20 this morning.

BOSTON, July 31 -- There is an abundance of call money offering, but the demand is light, while, on the other hand, the time money is ruling quite firm. Sterling exchange remains quiet and firm. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2; New York funds, par; call loans, 3 1/2 to 5; time money, 4 1/2 to 5; Clearing House exchanges, $18,201,935; balances, $1,438,935.
