George Edward Harding, the architect who drew the plans for the Holland House, the Commercial Gable Building, and many other of the large buildings, called at the City Hall yesterday afternoon with three other architects to ascertain the provisions of the proposed ordinance to amend Section 105 of the Building Code in relation to fire-proof buildings.

IT was the first meeting of the "Moonshine Club," following the "miracle of grace." as old Parson Shelby called it, that occurred at Shiners' Bend on Owl Creek the Sabbath previous. But one member of the club had been present on that memorable occasion; which fact accounted for the manner in which the others crowded about him now, in big-eyed, open-mouthed expectation.

FIRE ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- It is understood that Government dispossess proceedings will soon be commenced to abate conditions that have not only nearly destroyed the fishing in Great South Bay, but affected seriously its social life as well.

CHARLESTOWN, West Va., Aug. 2. -- The trial of John Richards and others, members of the United Mine Workers, charged with contempt of court, came to a close today, and Judge Keller fixed Aug. 12 as the date for the argument. All the defendants were released on their own recognizance until that time.

THE French Chambers have adjourned with hardly any of M. Combes's rather ambitious programme carried out. The first two articles of the much-discussed "loi Rolland" passed the Senate on the first reading of the bill after a very acrimonious debate, but the remainder of the project was not even considered.

NEW YORK is not the only city which suffers from police brutality. A concierge was recently fined by a Paris Magistrate for having interfered with three policemen who were arresting a cabman and treating him rather roughly. One of the witnesses was the correspondent of an American paper, who saw the scene from his window, and was so struck by the brutality of the police that he wired off an account to his journal.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The triumph of the Liberal Party at the North Leeds election might easily be overrated, but it has undoubtedly given fresh hope to the Opposition, and it was surely due to the influence, first, of Nonconformist feeling about the Education bill, and, secondly, to the continued agitation about the corn tax.

The war manoeuvres which are scheduled to begin during the latter part of this month and the gun tests which have been going on for the past fortnight under the direction of Gen. Wallace Randolph and a board of ordnance experts, direct attention to a recent series of experiments with high explosives and detonating fuses carried on by the Ordnance Corps.

PEOPLE who ride on the elevated road -- and who does not? -- have been peering curiously for some weeks past at queer little square white houses that have made their appearance on stations of the Sixth and Ninth Avenue lines. These little structures seem to be built of asbestos, and they have round brass portholes somewhat higher than a man's head.

IT was an Eighty-sixth Street cross-town car, and the girl boarded it weighed down with bundles. Unmistakably she was an artist, for she carried a paint box and a stretcher, and under her arm was tucked a campstool.

Because he arrested a woman for no cause that he could explain, Policeman Joseph A. Murray of the East One Hundred, and Fourth Street Station was severely censured yesterday by Magistrate Pool in the Yorkville Court. The prisoner was Mrs. Annie Cooper, wife of Frederick Cooper, who lives at 246 East Twenty-fifth Street and is employed by Fiss, Doerr Carroil, horse dealers.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The fashionable hotels are still full, and nearly fifty Americans arrived at Claridge's alone by the midweek steamers, although many of these only staid in London a day or two, and were then off to Scotland or on English trips, or to the Continent.

THE Summer study of natural history has recently become a popular form of recreation in the mountains and at the seashore, and thousands of those who leave the city for a change of air and scenery carry with them complete equipments for the study of one or more of the natural sciences.

THE Summer study of natural history has recently become a popular form of recreation in the mountains and at the seashore, and thousands of those who leave the city for a change of air and scenery carry with them complete equipments for the study of one or more of the natural sciences.

TAIN'T no place to brag on; an' what them painter chaps calls a vistay is sum what knocked into a cocked hat by the stump fence, an' the co'ncrib, an' that bar'l o' leech lye in the corner -- that is, lookin' at the vistay frum the stoop. Still, there is allus sumthin' to distarb the eye when a pussun squints at natur'.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The fashionable hotels are still full, and nearly fifty Americans arrived at Claridge's alone by the midweek steamers, although many of these only staid in London a day or two, and were then off to Scotland or on English trips, or to the Continent.

Residents on West One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street between Edgecombe and Bradhurst Avenues were thrown into a panic during the height of the storm yesterday noon by the caving in of the north side of the street for a distance of seventy-five feet, carrying with it one entire stoop and doorway, iron fences, lamp posts, sidewalks, and curbs.

President Robert C. Morris of the Republican County Committee, Collector Stranahan, Assistant Corporation Counsel John Hutchinson, and St. Clair McKelway were among those who attended Senator Platt's Sunday-school on the piazza, of the Oriental at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

SHENANDOAH, Perm., Aug. 3 -- The fact that local priests gave warning that there would be an attack on the soldiers here has done much to impress the people of this place that there is a secret Nihilistic organization within the Mine workers' union, which deliberately foments trouble.

CHRISTIANIA, Aug. 3 -- A dispatch to the Morgen Bladet from Tromso says that Capt. Johannsson of the America, which arrived at Honningsvaag, Norway, on Aug. 1, with Evelyn B. Baldwin, the arctic explorer, on board, has asked to be examined before a maritime court concerning incidents which occurred on board the America in the course of the voyage of the Baldwln-Ziegler arctic expedition.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Children's Day was observed to-day in the Auditorium, and at the morning and evening services, arranged and conducted by Musical Director Tali Bsen Morgan, the congregation numbered 10,000, the largest of the Summer. The Auditorium had been decorated with flags and bunting, and on the platform were potted plants and wild flowers.

MADRID, Aug. 3 -- The report of the Bank of Spain for the week ended yesterday shows the following changes: Gold in hand, increase, 227,000 pesetas; silver in hand, decrease, 343,000 pesetas: notes in circulation, increase, 4,580,000 pesetas. Gold was quoted yesterday at 36.80.
BARBOURVILLE, Ky., Aug. 3 -- One more oil well came in yesterday evening and another was partly drilled in making six strikes this week, which breaks the record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The intimation from a Boston dispatch that the Democrats of the Bay State purpose to launch an Olney Presidential boom at their coming State Convention excites small interest, here. Washington politicians are not inclined to rate Mr. Olney as a Presidential possibility; at least, he is not a prime favorite with the Democrats who chance to be here Just now.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- In its issue of this morning The Daily Mail says that one of the great porticos of St. Paul's Cathedral threatens to collapse unless thorough repairs are undertaken.

-- As custom has made it in order for any and all to inform the world, after a fight is over, just how and why it happened, we beg leave to use the privilege. For all the current theories and criticisms Of the JSFFRIES-FITZSIMMONS fight seem to us to be wrong and to miss the subtle meaning of the Cornishman's defeat.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 3 -- The entire Eighth Regiment was called to arms during last night as a result of three attacks made by a band of men in ambush, who threw stones at the troops now in camp on the plateau outside the town.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3 -- The social event of the day was the tea and reception given by Mr. and Mrs. Peter D. Martin at the Cadwalader cottage this afternoon. The reception was given to afford an opportunity to display the presents given to the bride on her recent wedding, and invitations were general, and practically everybody in society was present.

There is no longer need of waiting for the expressman to come and strap the trunk at the last minute. There are nice new trunk straps which are warranted to enable every woman to be her own trunk strapper. It is an "everlasting cinch," this trunk strap. It is the trunk strap inventor who uses these words, and he does not mean them for slang.

About 400 cyclists took part in the opposition century runs held over the Long Island roads yesterday by the two bodies which claim the control of organized century road riding, and despite the heavy rain of the early afternoon, which made the roads very muddy and heavy on the return trip, there were no accidents reported, and almost the entire number of starters completed the run.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Several persons were seriously injured to-night at an Italian celebration by the premature discharge of a bomb during a fireworks display on North Third Street. Five thousand Italians from different parts of Westchester County, New York City, and New Jersey celebrated the feast of the patron saint Madonna Vedel Arco.

The residents and storekeepers of Harlem and the lower Bronx have complained to the police that they are receiving a great quantity of counterfeit half dollars and Quarter dollars. The money is of perfectly good appearance, and it is only after it has been used for some time that its valueless properties can be discovered.
PARIS, Aug. 3 -- May Yohe reached Paris this morning, but up to to-night she had not seen Putnam Bradlee Strong or learned where he is.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 -- Gen. Jacob H. Smith, who returned last Friday from Manila, will spend several days in this city and then go to his home in Portsmouth, Ohio. Speaking on the subject for the first time since his arrival, Gen. Smith said to-day of his forced retirement from the army:

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- A cyclone of great force settled upon the city of St. Catharines, Ontario, and vicinity early this afternoon, doing considerable damage both in the city and on the outskirts. No lives were lost, but there were several narrow escapes.

Close observers of the security market situation will be much disappointed if the present week does not witness substantial development in activity. There is an extended short interest, created upon the theory that something very bad was going to happen last week as sequel to Rock Island capital readjustment plans -- Wall Street bankers being counted upon by bear speculators to undertake disciplinary measures.
VENICE, Aug. 3 -- A great window in the Dominican Church of St. John and St. Paul fell in to-day, after having been shaken by a clap of thunder.

Two interesting and important books have just appeared in England dealing with a problem of great and immediate interest to Englishmen, of the astonishing progress of the United States in lines of manufacture which Great Britain seemed at one time to have practically pre-empted, and the invasion of Great Britain and her markets by American products.

Four army Secretaries of the Young Men's Christian Association have just reported at the international headquarters in New York. W.A. Reid comes from Alaska, where, with his dog team, he kept up association work among the line of forts throughout the Winter, having his headquarters at Fort Gibbon.

"Apropos of the opening of the new season and the continued production of plays mostly foreign," a manager said yesterday, "a peculiar state of affairs exists just now. Managers are eager to have something new, but are simply afraid to experiment, to try anything that doesn't bear the stamp of previous success.

A man who had been crabbing yesterday came over on the 2 o'clock trip of the ferryboat Texas of the Broadway (Brooklyn) Twenty-third Street ferry line. He put a crab on each ear of a cat, one on each foot, three on the cat's tail, and stuck some more on the cat's sides. Then he let the animal go in the womens' cabin.

Over 200 athletes competed in the inaugural track and field games of the Chattahoochee Tribe No. 95 of the Improved Order of Red Men, which were held at Celtic Park, L.I., yesterday. The track and infield were in very bad condition owing to a heavy rainstorm which deluged the grounds early in the afternoon.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 3 -- The first race meeting over the splendid new race track built and controlled by a syndicate of New York millionaires, with William C. Whitney, August Belmont, and F.R. Hitchcock at the head of the association, will be opened to-morrow under conditions that appear to guarantee a brilliant success for the new venture socially as well as financially.

"The Republican Text Book for the Campaign of 1902" is issued to-day. It is intended for the use of Republican speakers in their efforts to induce the voters to return a majority of Republicans to the next Congress, and also for the use of the less-informed Republican newspaper writers.
PARIS, Aug. 3 -- A Socialist demonstration in support of the Government on the schools question was held in the Place Maubert, in the Latin Quarter, to-day.

Every journey Mr. BRYAN makes to the East, every speech he delivers here, every political demonstration gotten up or attempted in his honor, causes a loss of votes to the Democratic Party and diminishes the probability of Democratic victories at the polls.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In yesterday's TIMES I noticed with much satisfaction the new ruling of Secretary Shaw's that it is not necessary for a returning American from foreign countries to have duty free $100 worth allowed him by law, consisting of wearing apparel only.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 3 -- A heroic rescue from drowning took place here this afternoon. The rescuers were John B. Meyers, a member of the Union League Club of Philadelphia; William Bell and brother of the Philadelphia Traction Company, and Lee Carey of Baltimore. J. Romaine, a New Yorker, was swimming and had gone out a considerable distance beyond the bar, beyond which it is not considered safe to go.

The Rev. Father Richard Dunphy, who has been visiting at the rectory of St. Andrew's Church, at City Hall Place and Duane Street, was severely injured last night by falling from a moving Eighth Avenue street car at the Thirtieth Street crossing. Father Dunphy was in the act of alighting, when the car suddenly started ahead, causing him to lose his balance and fall to the ground.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- M. RoutKowsky, the financial agent of the Russian Government at Washington, has, by direction of his home authorities, made the following official statement regarding the recent note of the Russian Minister of Finance relating to the Brussels Sugar Convention:

A hundred of Harlem's most prominent Jewish citizens met yesterday afternoon at 1,351 Fifth Avenue and completed arrangements for a monster mass meeting to be held Wednesday evening at the Harlem Lyceum, One Hundred and Seventh Street and Third Avenue, to protest against the attack made upon the mourners at Chief Rabbi Jacob Joseph's funeral by the police and the employes of Hoe Co.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Without any Intent to disparage the recent Saratoga letters to THE TIMES, I must say that the great resort has been up to this date dull to a deadly degree, and stagnant as all dead things are. This may be now confessed because it is going to be different hereafter.

The German Soldiers' Monument in Philadelphia is to be made by Albert Moritz Wolff of Berlin, Prussia. He has modeled an infantryman with the Prussian helmet on head, who grasps a flag in his right hand and holds his musket in the left. It will be cast by the Gladenbeck Bronze Com- pany, and the Emperor has contributed 1,000 pounds of metal to the casting.

Hard and fast practice was indulged in yesterday by the English lawn tennis players on the turf courts of the Crescent Athletic Club, at Eighty-fifth Street and the Shore Road, Bay Ridge. The Doherty brothers, in the company of Capt. W.H. Collins, arrived from Boston early in the morning.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 3 -- Dozens of crack steam yachts, the flying squadron of the New York Yacht Club, are at anchor in the lower harbor here to-night, and to-morrow the main body of the fleet, including the fastet of the sailing yachts, will join them in preparation for the annual cruise to the eastward of the oldest yacht club in the country.

A cholera mortality at Manila of forty to fifty per day causes the authorities charged with the administration of the Philippines very serious anxiety. From the latest monthly report at hand of the Board of Health of the Philippine Islands and the City of Manila, that bearing date of April 15, we learn that Asiatic cholera made its appearance March 20, when two natives were found suffering from it at one of the hospitals.

The rapid growth of its business compels THE TIMES to seek new quarters. More space is required for its business offices, for its editorial rooms, and for its mechanical departments. Many sites have been examined and considered, mostly down town, where no suitable lot or building was to be obtained.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Republican text book for the campaign of 1902 has been issued by the Republican Congressional Committee. The book, which is in pamphlet form, containing 380 pages, makes liberal quotations from the speeches of both McKinley and Roosevelt and also extracts from their messages to Congress in support of Republican doctrines.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 3 -- Archbishop Ireland, preaching this morning in the Cathedral, made an appeal to Roman Catholics against criticism of the United States Government's attitude toward the Church in the Philippines, and denied that the agitation which had arisen in various parts of the country had the sanction of the Church authorities.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 3 -- President Mitchell at the United Mine Workers, made another visit to Scranton to-day. Before going he said that there was no change in the strike situation. He did not think that an attempt would be made to resume work at any of the collieries during the coming week.

As one of the Central Park attaches, familiarly known as "Tommy," was engaged yesterday morning in the task of collecting the bits of paper which visitors throw on the grass and paths, he went after some paper which was blown back of some bushes not far from the entrance to the Park at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 4 -- With more than a hundred fast and famous yachts grouped about the Corona, flagship of the New York Yacht Club, Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard to-day received the Captains of eighty-seven yachts and presided at a fleet council which acted on the matter of changing the plans and course for the club cruise and fleet races.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 4 -- Hendrik Willem Mesdag, the painter of sea scenes, is dead.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 4 -- Society was afloat this afternoon. Several sailing parties, the race of the thirty-footers, and Capt. Bush's affair at the Pot and Kettle Club were the principal events of the day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- The formal announcement of the engagement of Miss Kathleen Neilson, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Neilson, to Reginald Claypool Vanderbilt, the youngest son of the late Cornelius Vanderbilt, was made by Mrs. Neilson to-day, and immediately the florists were besieged with orders for flowers to be presented with congratulations to the young lady's apartments at the Margaret.

"Ernie" Hjertberg, the trainer of the Columbia University track team, last night beat Peter Hegelman, who, with Patrick Cavanaugh, won the six-day race in the Madison Square Garden last Winter, in a fifteen-mile professional match foot race at the grounds of the New West Side Athletic Club, in West Fifty-fourth Street, by two laps and ten yards of the nine-lap track, or about a quarter of a mile.

ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- The 127 savings banks doing business in thirty-one counties of New York State had on July 1, 1902, aggregate resources of $1,167,633,337, which was an increase for the year of $62,606,573, and for six months of $36,118,713.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is given out that the leaders of the Republican Party in the ensuing campaign intend to keep prominently before the people "the full dinner pail" and the hard times which they say resulted from the passage of the Wilson tariff bill. There must be silence on the trust question, (because they expect from the trusts the sinews of war.)

A correspondent in one of the principal cities of the anthracite basin courteously differs from the opinions expressed in these columns relative to the responsibility of the operators for the continuance of the suspension and thinks that if we understood the situation better we would hold different views.

Borough President Louis F. Haffen opened bids yesterday morning for the asphalting of the roadway of Washington Avenue from Third Avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street to Pelham Avenue, a distance of over three miles. To complete this work it will require 66,000 square yards of asphalt payement, 12,000 cubic yards of concrete, and 31,000 linear feet of curbstone.

SARATOGA, Aug. 4 -- With a splendid and fast race for the great event of the day, the $10,000 Saratoga Handicap, an attendance even in excess of the expectations of the management and delightful weather for the sport, racing was inaugurated on the new Saratoga course today.

NEWPORT, Aug. 4 -- There were many social functions to-day and to-night. Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish, Mrs. J. Armory Codman, Mrs. William E. Carter, Mrs. Thomas Newbold, Mrs. George A. Huhn, and, Mrs. R.L. Fowler gave luncheons.

After delivering a scathing rebuke to Policeman Joseph A. Murray of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station, who arrested Mrs. Annie Cooper of 246 East Twenty-fifth Street last Saturday morning, charging her with soliciting, Magitsrate Pool, in the Yorkville Court, discharged the prisoner yesterday morning.

Greene Taylor have sold for a client 63 West Fifty-second Street, a four-story brownstone-front dwelling on lot 20 by 100.3. It is said that the property has been acquired by operators who recently bought the adjoining parcel, No. 65. Both houses will be remodeled on the American basement plan.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Night fell on the field of the Saratoga Polo Club this evening before the Saratoga team and the Meadow Brooks completed their game in the handicap series for the Ballston Cup, the Meadow Brook players finally winning by the score of 14 to 11. The contest was not begun until 5 o'clock, when the field had dried somewhat and was in comparatively good condition.

The New York Yacht Club cruise, which starts from New London to-day, is one of the most notable events of the week and interests all those who are fond of aquatic sports. The racing element of society has gone to Saratoga, where the season has begun with much brilliancy. Newport and adjacent resorts to-day and to-morrow, until the arrival of the yachts in Newport Harbor, are devoid of the masculine element.

BAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Ada Sweetser was found dying this morning by neighbors in a miserable room of a small cottage on a narrow lane, a short distance off the Bayville Road. She was a character in the village, where it was known that she received regularly small sums of money sent by her relatives.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- After two men were out in the eighth inning of today's baseball game, and the score stood 2 to 0 in favor of Jersey City, the Rochester team fell on Planmiller's delivery and scored four men. In this inning alone the winning team made six hits and four runs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- New York exchange was 15 cents premium to-day. Time and call loans, 4 @ 5 per cent. There was more spirit displayed to-day on the local Stock Exchange than there has been for some time. The interest, however, was confined mainly to the Box Board issues. Box Board opened a point above the closing price for Saturday on the local Exchange, and advanced rapidly to 14 for the common.

HANOVER, Aug. 4 -- The twelfth round of the international chess masters' tournament was played to-day according to the eleventh round of the Berger system, which brought the players together in the following order:

Peter L. Power, the at present nebulous client of George Alfred Lamb, scored yesterday another evasion of examination before Special Examiner Richard A. Mabie by the lawyers who represent the Northern Pacific Company. According to the suit instituted by Lamb, Power seeks to restrain the Northern Pacific Company from retiring preferred stock owned by him.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- Robi of Munich beat the world's six-hour cycle record at Friedenau yesterday. He averaged thirty-seven miles an hour. Dickentmann of Amsterdam and Huret of Paris were among those defeated.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 4 -- In a speech delivered at the banquet of the Knights of Columbus to-ady Senator William Michael Byrne spoke of the action of the Knights of Columbus in protesting against the misrepresentation of Catholic interests in certain unnamed recent publications and commented generally on the present situation in the Philippines from a religious standpoint.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The State Department has received the following cablegram from Minister Squiers, dated Havana, Aug. 4:

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 4 -- The management of the Institute of Technology is arranging to establish a special course for those graduates of Annapolis and West Point who intend to enter the Ordnance Department of the Government. The course will deal solely with the making and designing of large guns for coast defense.

Friends of Richard Benjamin Van Horne, son of Sir William C. Van Horne, the Canadian millionaire and railroad builder, who went to the dock to greet the young man upon his arrival from Cuba yesterday on the Munson Line steamship Curityba, were alarmed to learn that he had been taken off the ship the night before and was detained in the Quarantine Hospital on Swinburne Island, in the lower bay.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 4 -- When the time arrived yesterday for the Rev. Dr. William Bryant Brown to leave his residence, at 87 Chestnut Street, East Orange, to officiate at the funeral of a neighbor, the clergyman was dead. After luncheon he had retired to his room, and it is believed that he died of heart disease.

PROPERTY OWNERS' RIGHTS IN STREETS. -- Where land is laid out on a map into lots and streets, purchasers are entitled, the Fourth Appellate Division holds, to have the streets kept open to the full width. After a large plot of land in the city of Buffalo had been divided into lots and streets provided for, Mrs. Catherine Collins came in time to be the owner of one of the lots.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- The money market is still unusually quiet, and rates are changing very little from day to day. There are no signs as yet of any hardening tendency. Sterling exchange continues firm, with posted rates unchanged. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds 5c discount.
BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- At a meeting of the shareholders of the Bowker Fertilizer Company to-day the proposed merger of the company with the American Agricultural Chemical Company was ratified.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Admiral Taylor denies the story wired from Washington to the effect that he believes the United States and Germany may so to war in 1907. When asked if he had set a date for a conflict between the two countries he said:

A Board of Officers is appointed to meet in Washington Aug. 6, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the purpose of preparing questions for use in conducting the examination of candidates selected from civil life for appontment as second, lieutenants in the army, with instructions for the guidance of local boards and of examining the papers when returned and rating the candidates in the several subjects of the examination.

Like the first, the second baseball game of the series now being played between the New York and Pittsburg teams on the Polo Grounds was won by the "Champions" yesterday, the score being 9 to 7 against the local players. Manager McGraw changed the batting order of his team, placing Browne, the right fielder whom he signed some time ago, on top of the list.

"A Chinese Honeymoon" is meeting good fortune at the Casino. The striking tableaus of "The Defender" continue to attract large audiences. "Florodora" began a two weeks run at Manhattan Beach last night. Soon the sylvan scenes and sweet songs of ''The Wild Rose" will be no longer seen and heard at the Knickerbocker.

Mr. WILLIAM S. DEVERT, sometime Chief of Police -- which position he filled in his own way and to the consternation of right-minded citizens -- and now a politician and aspirant for the responsibilities and advantages of district leadership, is at the moment attracting a great deal of attention.

Although it was a very warm day and most Wall Street men were sighing for the country, Russell Sage celebrated his eighty-sixth birthday yesterday by appearing at his office five minutes earlier than usual. It took but a few moments for the office men to extend their congratulations, whereupon Mr. Sage plunged into his daily work, and from then until lunch time it was impossible to see him, except on important business.

NORFOLK, Conn., Aug. 4 -- With the largest entry list that it has ever known, the law tennis championship for the Connecticut State title was begun to-day on the courts of the Eldridge Gymnasium under the auspices of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- A new commercial treaty between Russia and Germany is regarded as still a long way off, but the Tageblatt thinks that this is one of the subjects to be discussed by the Russian and German Emperors. Some Government Journals express regret that there is still a strong anti-German feeling in Russian political and social circles.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- Play was started to-day in the annual handicap lawn tennis tournament for loving cups offered by Mrs. Dennison Hatch on the Casino courts. Col. John Jacob Astor and Mrs. Robinson are paired in the doubles. They were defeated in their first match by C.F. Hamlin and Miss Burden, who had the advantage of a long handicap.

Nine-year-old Harold Hartshorne is perhaps the youngest defendant in this country who has been sued for $50,000 damages. This is the amount that Marie Bentz, the former governess of the youthful Hartshorne, wants for a beating that he is alleged to have administered to her.
Grain receipts at Chicago last week the largest in months.

After some deliberation yesterday afternoon the International Lawn Tennis Committee of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association decided to rearrange the programme of the English-American competitions. The new schedule as given out places the singles matches on Wednesday and Thursday with the doubles match on Friday.

Negotiations are pending and are understood to be rapidly nearing successful completion by which the St. Louis and San Francisco will come into the control of the Central of Georgia Railway. These negotiations have been under way for some time, but they have been carefully guarded, and it was not until yesterday that information about them leaked out.

Sergt. John W. Cottrell, who has been in command of the police squad at the Jefferson Market Police Court, was yesterday taken by Col. Partridge from the head of the eligible list and promoted to a Captaincy to fill the vacancy created by the retirement of Capt. William Thompson of the Madison Street command, the Seventh Pre- cinct.

A story of a double life -- that of Frederick G. Littlefield of 354 Mott Avenue, Bronx -- was told yesterday in the Detective Bureau in Mulberry Street by Chief Detective Titus before a glittering array of heavy solid silver table ware and other articles of luxury.
SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 4 -- "I am getting to be an old man. I have not many years to live. If I accomplish all I have set out to do things must move with celerity."

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 4 -- The running of a co-operative country store does not seem to have been a success among the farmers in the vicinity of North Branch, Somerset County, according to a bill filed in the Chancery Court to-day by Joseph Peterson of Bridgewater Township. The bill asks that a receiver be named to take charge of the concern and wind up its affairs.

In yesterday's security market was exhibited dullness without weakness. This conflicts with theories prevailing in purely speculative circles wherein it has recently been much urged that with any slackening of activity there were bound to come prompt quotation recessions.
Entries for the Grand Circuit meeting at Brighton Beach next week have closed, and all the classes have filled well.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 4 -- The Rev. John Williams, pastor of St. Barnabas's Episcopal Church, one of the leading and wealthiest congregations in the State, last night gave out an open letter in favor of unionism among workmen, which is causing great comment to-day, since Union Pacific shop men striking in this city and many of the highest officials of the road are members of Mr. Williams's church.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- President Roosevelt and his family enjoyed a happy day of it. They were up early and went on a long, hard horseback ride. They came back in good time to receive Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, who were to be their guests at luncheon, and arrived on Commodore Gerry's yacht, the Electra.

Wholesale and retail coal dealers who were seen yesterday were unanimous in declaring that unless the coal strike ends soon the coal question will be a serious problem for householders. Nominally the retail schedule price for anthracite at present is $8 a ton, but there is really no fixed price.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 4 -- The 700 or 800 employes of the Cleveland City Railway Company, of which Senator M. A. Hanna is President, met in a down-town hall tonight and presented Senator Hanna with a valuable cane.

The committee of the United Hebrew Community, representing all the congregations of that faith in the Greater New York, took practical measures yesterday for official investigations of the circumstances that attended the riot at the funeral of Rabbi Joseph on Wednesday last.

There was a very interesting debate in the House of Lords July 19 on what may almost be called things in general. For it consisted of a carefully prepared and lucidly expounded series of questions by Earl SPENCER, the successor of the Earl of KIMBERLY as the Liberal leader in the House of Lords, and a series of answers by the Marquis of LANSDOWNE, the Foreign Secretary.

John D. Crimmins appears to be the purchaser of several hundred building lots in the Astoria section of Long Island City, according to deeds drawn on Saturday which are to be filed to-day with the County Clerk. It is believed that the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company is the real buyer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- The Government suit against the alleged Beef Trust was sent a step forward here to-day by the filing in the United States Circuit Court of demurrers of the defendants, both as individuals and as corporations.

Mayor Low and School Superintendent William H. Maxwell visited last evening the new roof gardens of the east side schools, and the Mayor was greeted with great enthusiasm. The roof playgrounds at two of the schools and at one school in Brooklyn have bands of music. When the Mayor appeared on the roof of the school building at Ludlow and Hester streets the boys and girls around the band stand tried to shake his hands.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

Competitions will be barred at the Baltusrol Golf Club this month, but there will be the usual informal play. Louis Keller, the Secretary, has gone on a vacation, to be gone until sometime during September, when the Baltusrol folks will run off a long list of events that will include the three-cornered team match for the Griscom cup between the women's leagues of this city, Boston, and Philadelphia.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 4 -- The Northwestern States are now in the midst of the greatest harvest ever known. Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota have produced more wheat, oats, barley, and flax than crop experts have credited to this territory, and this has been accomplished under adverse conditions unparalleled since the settlement of the country.

Justice Stockler, in the Supreme Court, yesterday reserved decision on an application by Mrs. Louise M.G. Finnell for alimony and counsel fee pending the trial of her action against Louis P. Finnell for a separation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator Carmack of Tennessee, Chairman of the Literary Committee of the Democratic Congressional Committee, had something to say this afternoon about the Repubican campaign text book.

In charging the August Grand Jury yesterday, Justice Warren W. Foster said: "The condition of public business, I am pleased to say, is exceedingly fortunate, and, as far as I am aware, there is nothing but routine to engage your attention. Other matters, however, may develop, and I may have occasion to address you again.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A number of misleading stories about the coast defenses of the United States have obtained publication since preparation for the war game began. From some of these stories the inference readily could be drawn that through inefficiency of the officers of the army charged with supervision of the coast defenses lamentable conditions prevailed all along the coast.

The Tribune very properly and very effectively throws on the greedy beet sugar men the larger share of responsibility for the revival of the anti-tariff agitation which is making things so troublesome for the Republican managers.

The slight tendency to criticism -- it could not be called opposition -- manifested in the South toward the work of the Southern Education Board appears pretty much to have disappeared. What there was of it was due, we think, mainly to misunderstanding, or failure to understand, the purpose and methods of the board.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 4 -- While the situation in this region is calm, the troops encamped here showed more activity to-day than they have on any day since they were ordered to Shenandoah. There was nothing on the surface to indicate anything, yet there was a feeling of uneasiness which caused the commanding officers to increase their vigilance and hold the soldiers in a state of preparation.

At Washington Park yesterday the Brooklyn baseball team won the second game of the series from Cincinnati's players by a score of 3 to 1. From the first inning, when each side scored a run, the game was fast and well played, no runs being scored until the latter half of the seventh, when Keeler's men made two tallies, and these were what won the game.

Politics promise to play no mean part in the annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen at Worcester, Mass., on Friday and Saturday. Four delegates will have to be elected to the board, or Executive Committee, as it is called, which body governs amateur rowing in this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Administration is watching with great interest the progress of legislation in Cuba relating to the proposed $35,000,000 loan. Officials of the Administration are endeavoring to determine whether the issue of such a loan would be in violation of the Platt amendment.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5 -- The first run of the New York Yacht Club in the annual cruise from New London to Newport today provided pleasing contests for a vast number of boats. The forty-mile trip from Sarah's Leuge to the Brenton Reef Lightship was begun in light airs and was finished in a good sailing breeze.

William S. Devery established last evening a "flimsy agency" for the sending out of news of the district fight which he is waging for the Tammany leadership of the Ninth Assembly District. The first sheet sent out gave details of the free vandeville and opera which are to be given this evening and on Saturday at the American Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Representative Newlands of Nevada is inclined to believe that when the Cuban question comes before Congress again there will be serious consideration of a proposition looking to annexation. He thinks that the progress of events in Cuba indicates that nothing short of annexation will solve the Cuban problem.

Still dull, still strong. Few new features get into the stock market. Raiding tactics accomplish little. Such buying as appears in volume seems chiefly to be for the account of interests who buy to absorb.

Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff arrived yesterday on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse from a vacation trip in France and Southern Europe, and announced that he would not be a candidate on the Gubernatorial ticket this Fall. He was not through with politics, he said, but for one campaign he would be a "standard bearer in the ranks."

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- New York exchange to-day was 10c premium. Time and call loans ranged from 4 to 5 per cent. Can common was an exceedingly active stock in the local list to-day, and was in demand at 12 1/2@13, while Can preferred also sold in regular lots at 60@60 1/2. National Biscuit common was also active on the Stock Exchange during the early session, being in demand at 47 3/8@47 1/2.

The active men in the Iowa Convention who secured the unanimous declaration for "such changes in the tariff from time to time as may become desirable through the progress of our industries" and who urged "the policy of reciprocity as the natural complement of protection" "necessary to the realization of our highest commercial possibilities," are being soundly rated by the extreme Eastern protectionists.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 5 -- As a result of a collision on Lake Erie between the City of Venice, ore laden, and the steamer Seguin, a steel lumber vessel, of Rondeau, Canada, last midnight, the former vessel was sunk and three lives were lost, while several persons were more or less seriously Injured.

It has just leaked out of the quiet halls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art that some time ago the donation was made to the Museum and accepted by the Trustees of a rich art collection, valued at probably more than $500,000. The name of the donor and the nature of the collection are not to be made public until the exhibit is opened.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., Aug. 5 -- The Camden Inter-State Street Railway strike, which has been on since Sunday last, was declared off to-day, and all the cars on the Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia divisions are being operated to-night on schedule time by union crews.

Louis Frankel has sold for Louis Frankenthaler, for $46,500, the seven-story tenement with stores 242 East Seventy-seventh Street, 29 by 102.2; also, for Marcus Nathan the three four-story double flats 1,474, 1,476, and 1,478 Brook Avenue, 75 by 100, for $45,000.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Diavolo, the American bicyclist, sustained a terrible fall just after turning the loop in his act at the Aquarium to-night.

When the Italian Royal Mall Line steamship Sardegna reached port yesterday from Naples she had in tow a little battered, waterlogged, almost dismasted schooner which she had picked up when she was fifteen days out, disabled and short of provisions. On board "The Notice of Providence, R.I.," for so read the name on her stern, were fifty-three men and eleven women, a large number of people for a sixty-three-ton craft.

The Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse arrived yesterday after a quick passage of 5 days, 19 hours, and 48 minutes, and her saloon cabins crowded with 735 passengers. There were 647 in the steerage. One steerage passenger, Antonio Madejezyk, died on Sunday and was buried at sea. A fireman named Hans Behrends was taken down with typhoid fever during the trip, and was removed to Quarantine.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 5 -- Nellie Farrell, who committed suicide in New York, was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson Smith, 1,921 North Second Street, New Albany, Ind., and the widow of Oliver McMackin, a well-known harness horseman.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- The Secretary to the President, Mr. Cortelyou, has telegraphed to Senator Lodge and Senator Hoar that the President will reach Boston on Saturday, Aug. 23, late in the afternoon and will go at once to Nahant, where he will pass Sunday with Senator Lodge. The next morning the President will go to Newport, making ten-minute stops at Taunton and Fall River.

HANOVER, Aug. 5 -- The chess players engaged in the International Masters' Tournament met this morning to contest the thirteenth round, which was played according to the fourth pairing of the Berger schedule. The men faced each other as follows:

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 5 -- Call money is in plentiful supply and quoted rates are frequently shaded to specially favored customers. Sterling exchange is showing a slightly easier tone, but posted rates are unchanged. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 5, 8, and 10 cents discount; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4; time money, 4 1/2 to 5; Clearing House exchanges, $19,834,913; balances, $1,058,237.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The first contest for the Hitchcock Cups was contested to-day in the annual tournament of the Saratoga Polo Club by the Bryn Mawr and Country Club of Westchester teams, the latter finally winning by a small margin.

-- Without a knowledge of all the circumstances -- a knowledge only to be obtained by a favored few -- it is distinctly unsafe to draw deductions from such an episode as the presentation of a cane to Senator HANNA by the men employed on his street railway in Cleveland. The spontaneity of such gifts is always more or less dubious, and the motives which induce men to contribute to them are varied and complex.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- A story current for several days that a second operation for appendicitis will be performed on King Edward after the coronation is denied. According to all authoritative reports, the King is making an excellent recovery, and it is considered unlikely that his physicians would allow him to endure the fatigue of the coronation ceremony if another operation were impending.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 5 -- At the freight rate conference between the railway presidents and the farmers at Colfax to-day, President Mohler of the Oregon Railway Navigation Company announced that the roads, on or before Aug. 15, would give a ten per cent, reduction on wheat shipments to the Pacific Coast.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Injunctions were secured to-day from Judge Chytraus by Waite, Thorburn Co., grain commission men, against three other Board of Trade firms to prevent settlements in the July oats deal. President Warren is restrained from indorsing down margins to the firms who bought July oats of the complainants to the extent of $20,000.

NORKOLK, Conn., Aug. 5 -- Hugh Tallant, the Harvard University lawn tennis veteran, displayed excellent form in the second day's play of the Connecticut State championship tournament here to-day. The courts of the Eldridge Gymnasium exactly suited his stroke, and he defeated two expert New Yorkers, M. McGurney and Robert Le Roy, by easy scores.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- A dispatch from Philadelphia contains a report of an interview with David B. Henderson, Speaker of the House of Representatives. In opening the interview, Gen. Henderson said he had made a very careful review of the situation in the West, and had studied it attentively, to try to discern the drift of the sentiment among the people.

The fight for good government in Pennsylvania was opened on Monday evening by an address from HENRY BUDD, the Chairman of the Citizens Auxiliary Committee in Philadelphia. It was a strong though temperate address, perfectly courteous in its treatment of Judge PENICTPACKER, but merciless in the analysis and exposure of the Judge's statement that Pennsylvania has no ills that are worthy of mention.

When David Hirschler, a passenger on the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, came down the gangplank yesterday afternoon the eagle eye of Special Customs Officer Timothy Donahue noticed that his pockets were bulging out more than those of a well-fitting coat should.
OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- President Roosevelt was up early this morning, and spent the greater part of the day at his desk.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The Central New York Association harness races opened here to-day with 250 entries, fine weather, and a good attendance. The racing was the best seen here in years. Index won the 2:30 trot, dropping one heat to West Shore Boy. Cora took the 2:18 pace in three straights, and was never headed.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- James McNeill Whistler, the artist, has written a witty and characteristic letter to The Morning Post, in which he acknowledges "the tender little glow of health induced by reading, as I sit here in the morning sun, the flattering attention paid me by your gentleman of ready wrath and quick biography."
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5 -- The second day's play in the handicap mixed doubles lawn tennis tournament at the Casino this morning completed the first round and decided two matches in the second round.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 5 -- Probably the most important development in the Shenandoah region to-day was the arrest and commitment to the county jail of two wounded Lithuanians who participated in the riot of last Wednesday. The arrests were attended with considerable show of military force, the men being taken into custody by constables who were surrounded by a platoon of infantrymen.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 5 -- The Portuguese colony here, which has been anxiously awaiting the arrival of the schooner Notice from Brava, was thrown into a great state of excitement to-day when news of the schooner's disastrous passage, with the loss of Capt. Ramos, reached here from New York.
President TRUESDALE of the Lackawanna Railroad, controlling the anthracite output of the Scranton district, has made a public statement from which we quote as follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Bishop McFaul of the diocese of Trenton, who was the father of the movement to consolidate the Catholic societies of the United States, in an address to the American Federation of Catholic Societies to-night made a vigorous reply to Archbishop Ireland's defense of the manner in which the friar and other Catholic questions were being handled in the Philippines.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Money was in increased demand to-day.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Aug. 5 -- President Castro of Venezuela left Caracas on Sunday to conduct the second and what he believes will be the final campaign against the revolutionists. He proceeded to Charayave and Cua, little places about a day and a half from the capital. He had with him 3,100 men, and expected to meet en route 3,500 more from La Victoria and Valencia.

Substantial progress, according to all concerned, was made by the committees representing the Board of Aldermen, the Pennsylvania Railroad, and the Rapid Transit Commissioners toward an agreement upon a franchise for the building of a tunnel by the Pennsylvania Railroad under the North River at a conference which was held yesterday in the offices of the Rapid Transit Commission.
MUNICH, Aug. 5 -- The betrothal of Archduchess Marie Annonciade of Austria and Duke Siegfried of Bavaria, which was announced from Vienna on June 15, has been broken off by mutual consent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- When Chairman Griggs of the Democratic Congressional Committee was asked yesterday what he thought of the recent interview of Chairman Babcock of the Republican Congressional Committee on the trust question, he said:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- After Rochester had practically won to-day's baseball game with Jersey City, McAleese let down, gave Schock a base on balls, made a fielding error, gave Mack and McCann a hit each, and Shoch and Mack scored. Rochester could do nothing in their half and lost the game.

Probably the most important meeting of orthodox rabbis over held in the United States came to an end yesterday, when the convention which met in this clty on Monday a week ago, the day on which Rabbi Joseph died, adjourned.

New York's baseball team was shut out by the champions from Pittsburg at the Polo Grounds in the third game of the series yesterday. Mathewson and Tannehill were the opposing pitchers. The big New York player pitched a splendid game, but Tannehill pitched a better one. Each gave only one base on balls.

HAVANA, Aug. 5 -- The Secretary of the House of Representatives said to-day that the bill authorizing a loan to aid sugar planters had not even been discussed in the House, much less passed by that body.

NEWPORT, Aug. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt gave their first large dinner this evening at Beaulieu, thirty-two guests being present at the dinner and the musicals which, followed. The table decorations of American Beauty roses were most handsome.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 5 -- Gov. Chester B. Jordan and his Executive Council had an agreeable duty to perform to-day in aiding and abetting the marriage of Miss Alice Hay, daughter of the Secretary of State, and William F. Wadsworth, son of Congressman Wadsworth, of New York.

The interest and dividend disbursements scheduled for August represent the considerable sum of $61,042,822. For the eight months from January to August inclusive the division of earnings in interest and dividends represents $629,416,214. The largest disbursements for the present year were those of July, $139,462,383.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The resignation of Ambassador White has been expected by his friends in this city for many months, particularly since the death of his son, Frederick D. White of Syracuse, in July, 1901.

Unannounced and unexpected, Commissioner Partridge last evening paid a visit to the West Thirtieth Street Station. He inspected the building, made a speech to the outgoing platoon at 6 o'clock, and caused a decided flutter among the police of the "Tenderloin." His visit, he stated, was not connected with the running of the precinct, but to see for himself the condition of the West Thirtieth Street Station, and whether a new station house was needed.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 5 -- The disappearance of the fog and cold east winds has brought forth again the world of society.

Army. First Lieut. James B. Gowen, Sixteenth Infantry, will report to Major Leven C. Allen, President of the examining board appointed to meet at Fort McPherson, at such time as he may be required by the board for examination to determine his fitness for promotion.

SARATOGA, Aug. 5 -- Again the lustrous line of carriages made a formidable and impressive pageant, as all the horses took many of the thousands to the race track. The day was a golden one, with an unflecked sky, and to the music of the Twenty-second Regiment Band the throng flocked to the band stand, the clubhouse and the betting ring.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 5 -- The political campaign in Vermont, which has a bolting faction in the Republican Party headed by Percival W. Clement, contesting against Gen. J.G. McCullough, the regular Republican nominee for Governor, was opened here in Gen. McCullough's behalf to-night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The State Department to-day made public reports from Ambassador White at Berlin, dated July 12 and 14, that, according to an official proclamation, the meat inspection law will go into force in its entirety on April 1, 1903, with the exception of the section which relates to doing away with the second examination of meat once officially inspected.

A conference lasting three hours took place yesterday afternoon at 143 Liberty Street between the Presidents of the coalcarrying roads, at which the situation in the coal fields was discussed in all its aspects. President George P. Baer of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad presided.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The Summer meeting of the Hudson River Driving Park Association opened to-day with a card of such length that the harness races composing it, lasted until after 7 o'clock and the 2:19 trot was unfinished on account of darkness. It was a bad day for the favorites, (St. Roga, Maxine, Hero, Alcyoner, and Afton L.) not one of which won a race, and only one got in the money.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- During races of the Grand Circuit meeting here to-day a collision occurred in the first heat of the 2:24 pace on the first turn, the drivers of King Charles and Grasshopper being unseated. Cooper, who drove Grasshopper, was not hurt, but Maloney, the owner of King Charles, got a black eye and a badly skinned cheek.

The New York Yacht Club cruise is of most interest just now. The start from New London yesterday and the gathering at Newport to-day will change that latter place from the state of being an Adamless Eden, which it was for twenty-four hours. The Vanderbilt-Nellson engagement is still much discussed there.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

The Marquis de Rudini, a son of the former Premier of Italy, arrived yesterday on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse so ill with appendicitis that he had to be carried from the steamship strapped to a stretcher. He was taken in a carriage ambulance to Dr. William T. Bull's private sanitarium at 33 East Thirty-third Street.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 5 -- At the bottom or Vineyard Sound lies the schooner Senator Grimes of Calais, Me., bound for that port from South Amboy, N.J., with coal, as the result of a collision to-day. After the barge Chemung, in tow of the tug Scranton, had run into the schooner and caused some damage, the barge Musconetong, also in tow of the Scranton, struck the schooner amidships and caused her to sink.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The National Retail Butchers and Meat Dealers' Protective Association met in convention here to-day, About fifty delegates were present. Most of the session was devoted to the addresses of the officers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- The whole local list was in good shape to-day, and some of the issues were very active and strong. Philadelphia and Erie and Union Traction made new high records, the latter being traded in eagerly because of a renewed report that the City of Philadelphia will sell its stock to the Pennsylvania Railroad.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- The business of Schlesinger Mayer, the State Street merchants, has been purchased by a new corporation headed by Henry Siegel, of Siegel, Cooper Co., New York and Chicago. The new company, under the same name, has a capitalization of $3,000,000 in bonds and $3,500,000 in stock.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 6 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt arrived off this point early this morning on board the Sylph. The trip up the Sound had been pleasant. The President left the Sylph early and boarded the Mayflower, the target practice of which he had come to witness. The usual salute was fired as he boarded the vessel.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 6 -- William Stein, the Stale Mine Inspector for the Shenandoah region, to-day announced that five colleries under his jurisdiction which have an estimated value of $1,500,000, have been rendered useless by reason of having been flooded and have been permanently abandoned by the companies owning thm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- An interesting situation has developed at Panama which may result in a call upon the United States to protect British interests there.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The Dedham polo team just toyed with the Saratoga team in the second match for the Hitchcock Cups at the annual tournament of the Saratoga Polo Club this afternoon and won by a score of, 21 to 10 1/2. The difference in the figures would have been greater had there been no handicap, as the Saratogas only managed to earn two goals and were twice penalized for safeties.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- Rochester took the two baseball games played here to-day with Jersey City, the first by a narrow margin, the second shutting them out. Shoch's error in the first game gave Rochester the winning run. Becker was very steady and his strike outs and Blake's home run were features.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 6 -- No trace has been found of James D. Edge, note teller of the First National Bank of this city, who disappeared on Monday last, leaving, the bank officials say, a shortage of $2,000 in his accounts. The officials of the institution are surprised by his act, as he had been employed by the bank for thirteen years, and had been held in high esteem.

Following the foreclosure proceedings that were instituted by the Nassau Trust Company against the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, McDonough Street and Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, comes a lively controversy between the Rev. Dean Richmond Babbitt, the rector of the church, and Andrew T. Sullivan, President of the Trust Company.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Money was in better supply to-day through Government disbursements, and the indebtedness to the Bank of England was largely repaid.

URBANA, Ohio, Aug. 6 -- Senator M.A. Hanna addressed the Urbana Chautauqua to-day on the topic "Labor and Its Relation to Capital." The Senator had first been met at Springfield by a large escort, and was taken by special trolley into the camp grounds near Urbana.

Henry Hellman has sold for a client to Amos F. Eno 46 West Sixty-fourth Street, a five-story flat on lot 30 toy 100. This parcel adjoins a plot of four lots on the Broadway front of the block already owned by Mr. Eno.

Margaret A. Bergen, an old Irishwoman who for more than half a century was a maid and nurse in the wealthy and prominent family of the late William Shakespeare Caldwell of New York and Richmond, Va., and who died in Paris recently, bequeathed $14,000 of the $19,000 she had saved to the Baroness von Zedtwitz and the Marquise des Monstiers Morinville, daughters of Mr. Caldwell, who are said to be worth several millions.

SARATOGA, Aug. 6 -- There has been too little humor here to befit an American crowd. We have gone to the extreme with our betting and our making of money out of pleasure. It will be too bad if we outdo the English, who take their pleasures sadly, and come to taking ours seriously. One sees how we are tending when there happens along such a figure as that of "Pittsfaurg Phil."

There was a general talk of striking among the motormen and engineers of the Manhattan Railway Company yesterday over the refusal of Vice President Skitt of the company to sign a new agreement submitted on their behalf. No definite programme appeared to be prepared and the strike talk was principally confined to the older men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The War Department has known for some time that portions of the friars' lands in the Philippines have been disposed of to companies, and in all the recent negotiations conducted by Secretary Root any contingencies which might arise through these transfers have been taken into account.

THE TIMES is the first, but is evidently not to be the last, newspaper to follow the pioneer lead of The Herald up town. It announces this morning that it has made all arrangements for the construction of a new building at Forty-second Street and Broadway, to which it will remove as soon as completed.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 6 -- The most picturesque wedding known in Virginia for many years took place at sunrise this morning at The Oaks, a famous country home near Coles Ferry, in Charlotte County. The contracting parties were Miss Mary Blair Rice, one of the most beautiful young women in the State, and C. William Beebe of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- In the course of the discussion of the Appropriation bill in the House of Commons yesterday the Government was severely criticised by various members regarding its policy in Europe and China.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Arms Pocketbook and Leather Novelty Company, capital $75,000, with $3,000 paid in. Incorporators -- H.N. Smith, George T. Mills, and F. Lee Palmer.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- Nine of the biggest and fastest sailing yachts in the New York Yacht Club fleet raced over the thirty-eight miles of the Vineyard Sound course to-day in a grand sailing breeze that was almost a gale for the Astor Cups given by Col. John Jacob Astor, and in both classes there was an exciting race and a decisive victory.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 6 -- Fully 7,000 negroes gathered this afternoon, in the agricultural building at Piedmont Park for the opening session of the Negro Young People's Christian and Educational Congress, which is the most extensive convention of colored, people ever held in the United States.

MANILA, Aug. 6 -- Gen. Chaffee will leave Manila next Monday on board the army transport Ingalls for his final tour of the Philippine Islands. He purposes to visit the principal stations in the southern islands, including Lake Lanao, in the Moro country of Mindanao.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 -- Money continues unchanged. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent.; New York Funds, 5, 8, and 10 cents discount; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4; time money, 4 1/2 to 5; Clearing House exchanges, $19,231,924; balances, $1,475,547. Stocks were dull but strong, except that the coppers were neglected and somewhat irregular.

GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The continued wet weather is causing a shortage in the production of honey, which is likely to result in a famine in that sweet commodity. The rain keeps the bees in their hives, and also deprives them of food by washing the nectar and pollen from the flowers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Bureau of Insular Affairs of the War Department today received a report from the Board of Health of the Philippine Islands and City of Manila dated May 15, 1902. This report was prepared by Major L.M. Maus, Surgeon United States Army, the Commissioner of Public Health for the Philippine Islands.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 6 -- Miss Jessie Gordon Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner Sherman of New York, was formally introduced to society here to-day at a reception given at Keewaydin, Mr. Sherman's splendid Summer home on Strawberry Hill. Despite the most inclement weather there was a large number of guests.

The return of the Baldwin-Ziegler arctic exploring expedition, certainly unsuccessful so far as the accomplishment of any useful results are concerned and possibly with grave scandals to be investigated by the courts, will tend to confirm the already settled opinion of the average citizen that polar exploration is about the least satisfactory employment of men and money which could be found.

About two weeks ago a man appeared in New Rochelle and announced himself as a yachtsman who desired to purchase a second-hand schooner. He dressed well and he seemed to be of good breeding. He gave his name as John E. Willard and appeared to be about twenty-five years of age.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The Spinaway Stakes, named in honor of one of the greatest fillies the American turf ever produced, was the chief event to-day, and made a splendid finish and a sensational result. With four horses abreast at the finish, the decision went to the Ben Brush filly Duster, from J.R. F.P. Keene's stable, while the warm favorite, Judith Campbell, a star performer from the West, finished third.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 6 - A complete tie-up of the entire electric road system of New Haven was ordered by 500 discontented motormen and conductors at 4:15 o'clock this morning, and at 5 o'clock not a car was running except two that were in charge of Yale students, who were employed in July for the Summer.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The second day's card at the Hudson River Driving Park this afternoon consisted of the umfinished 2:19 trot, postponed from yesterday, and three set races, all of which were finished. Summary:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- Newport society devoted its time to-day to yachting, many Summer residents attended the Astor Cup races as guests on the yachts which accompanied the racers, and others drove to the Ocean Drive to see the race from the advantageous point of view that place affords.

Miss Clara Barton, the President of the American Red Cross Society, who has been attending the conference of the International Red Cross Association at St. Petersburg, returned yesterday on board the Hamburg-American Line steamship Pennsylvania. The veteran nurse stepped down the gangplank with a sprightliness that belied her seventy-two years of age, and she was surrounded immediately by friends who were eager to greet her.

In yesterday's market some show of new activity appeared and quotations were strong. The continuing feature of apparent buying for absorption was evident. Where the smaller professional traders of the Stock Exchange did anything it was as a rule on the selling side.

One man was drowned and a second had a narrow escape from a similar fate last night at the foot of West Ninety-sixth Street, on the North River, when 2,000 excursionists of the Russell D. Williams Association were returning from their outing at College Point, Long Island. The man who was drowned is unidentified.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 6 -- The chief race to-day in the regatta of the Royal Yacht Squadron was for the Emperor's Cup, and was won by the Irex on time allowance. She finished fifth. The Cicely finished first and the Navahoe second, but after deducting time allowance the Irex was declared the winner, with the Cetonia second and the Fiona third.

The mass of the Republican Party believes that if any schedules of the present tariff are turned by manufacturers to the disadvantage of the American people they should be changed. They believe that Congress should prevent favoritism in the way of freight rates to a few, and, if further legislation is needed, that it should be enacted at once.

Mayor Low decided yesterday to have a committee of citizens, appointed by himself, investigate the east side riots attending the funeral of Rabbi Joseph and recommend what action should be taken in the matter. Mayor Low sent the following letter to the members of the committee:
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The feature of the third day of the Grand Circuit meeting was the defeat of Roamer in the 2:14 pace. The race went to six heats. Summary:

John W. Gates was in town yesterday and he spent several hours of the day in his office. Wall Street jokers had it that he had come to get more money for his operations in the betting ring at Saratoga, which are on a cash basis. He called at J. P. Morgan Co.'s office, and it is supposed that his visit was in connection with Louisville and Nashville affairs.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6 -- The owners of the thirty-footers did not allow the attraction of the Astor Cup races to Interfere with their daily contests to-day, and the little boats had a race as usual this afternoon. There was a lively breeze blowing from the southwest, and the Dyer's Island course was selected for the race, giving the boats a run before the wind, with windward work on the return.

With races and polo at Saratoga and the New York Yacht Club cruise along the shore, the resorts have much to occupy their guests and residents. Everywhere there are reports of entertaining, luncheons, dinners, and small informal dances. So far there have been no very large affairs given at any of the watering places.

Pittsburg's champion baseball team won the fourth and last game of the series from the New York players on the Polo Grounds yesterday by a score of 2 to 0. The visitors tallied two runs in the first inning and two more in the first half of the sixth, but the game was called just then on account of rain, and the score for the first five innings went on record in favor of Pittsburg.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- New York exchange was quoted at 3Oc premium to-day. Time and call loans range from 4 to 5 per cent. The apathy which has prevailed in the Wall Street market for several days extended to the Stock Exchange to-day, and the locals were exceedingly dull. There were a few deals, but they were scattering transactions and in odd lots for the most part.

HAVANA, Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Squires, wife of the United States Minister, recently drove from her house in Mariahao in a hired carriage with a footman on the box, to call upon the wife of the French Minister at the Hotel Inglaterra. When the carriage stopped at the hotel the footman went in to announce the visitor.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 6 -- Harry Tracy, the outlaw, who for two months has been chased by armed men and tracked by bloodhounds, and eluded them, is dead. To avoid capture the Oregon outlaw shot himself through the right eye at 8 o'clock last night, blowing off part of his head.

Senator Thomas C. Platt and Lieut. Gov. Woodruff held a conference yesterday at 49 Broadway to discuss the State political situation and also the question as to whether Mr. Woodruff is to be named on the ticket with Gov. Odell. Lieut. Gov. Woodruff said after the conference:

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The royal yacht Victoria and Albert, with King Edward on board, left Cowes at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon for Portsmouth, which was reached shortly after 2 o'clock. The yacht was moored alongside the dockyard jetty. Two Japanese warships fired salutes and were followed by all the commissioned ships in the harbor.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 6 -- Receiver Potter of the defunct Omaha Loan and Trust Company is said by attorneys in the case to be preparing a report containing startling charges of misappropriation of funds belonging to Eastern mortgage holders. An order to bring the books into court was refused by the Circuit Judge, but to-day an order was granted allowing attorneys to make examination of records in which they were interested.

The Rome correspondent of The London Chronicle has furnished that journal with a review of the American negotiations at the Vatican which should be even more interesting to American than to English readers. His account gives a plausible explanation of some things that were very much in need of explanation.
An old man who said his name was Thomas Andrews was found in the Pennsylvania Railroad ferry house at Jersey City on Tuesday night.

When seventeen-year-old Louis Weiman of 292 Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, was arraigned yesterday in the Lee Avenue Police Court before Magistrate Higginbotham on a charge of being implicated in the robbery of a horse and buggy from the barn of John Rheinhart at Hicksville, L.I., he declared to the magistrate that he had been compelled to become a horse thief at the point of a revolver.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was carried on within somewhat narrow limits and there were few developments of a kind to attract special interest. The movement in prices was principally a continuation of the tendencies developed during Tuesday's trading, and there were few or no new features.
It is not surprising that the Administration should regard the proposed loan in Cuba as a delicate and serious matter. The possible responsibility of our Government makes it so.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 7 -- Col. George W. Hooker died at his home in Brattleborough, Vt., on Wednesday night, of heart disease. Ten days ago he suffered from an attack of heart failure, but had so far recovered that he was again about. On Wednesday night he had a relapse, and died in a very short time.

Army. The following-named officers of the Corps of Engineers will report to the Secretary of the Navy for duty on a battleship and cruiser, respectively, in connection with the army and navy manoeuvres: Lieut. Col. William R. Levermore, Capt. Charles S. Bromwell.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Outside of a very few persons in the Navy Department it was not known until to-day that the navy had lost the great naval reservation in the Philippines awarded to it last Fall by order of the President.

When the Patten Line steamboat Little Silver was on her way to the city from Long Branch yesterday morning the pivot of the heavy steel walking beam gave way. The beam, deprived of support, crashed down through the superstructure and landed on the engine, smashing a cylinder head.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- While no authoritative statement has been made by any of the persons chiefly interested in either the Morgan shipping combination or the much-mooted rival combine of British interests, to-day's developments indicate that the project to establish a Canadian-British line, in conjunction with another line to South Africa and Australia, is not likely of early realization, and that the British Government has already entered into an arrangement with the Morgan combination.

DOVER, N.H., Aug. 7 -- The racing at the Granite State Park this afternoon was the best of the season thus far. In the 2:24 pace Alice Holmes was the favorite, but it took five heats for her to win. Summary:
LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Money was wanted for large transactions to-day and discounts were steady.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- New York exchange was quoted to-day at 35c premium; time and call loans, 4 to 5 per cent. Box Board was in brisk demand on the local Stock Exchange, and the prices were lifted sharply as a result to 63 for the preferred and 14 1/2 for the common. National Biscuit was fairly active, but the prices were steady around 47 1/2.
LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Everything is in readiness for King Edward's coronation to-morrow. The King's health is as good as could be expected, and his strength continues to increase satisfactorily.
BUFFALO, Aug. 7 -- Rain at Fort Erie this afternoon necessitated postponing the finish of the 2:14 and 2:07 trots until tomorrow afternoon. The meeting was to have ended to-day.

Brooklyn Citizen. THE NEW YORK TIMES informs the public this morning that it is going to forsake Park Row in the course of the coming two years, and make its place of publication at the corner of Broadway and West Forty-second Street, where a building of the most modern kind is to be erected for its use.

Details of the proposed acquisition of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois by the St. Louis and San Francisco were announced officially yesterday. They are practically the same as those that had been announced heretofore.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Saratoga has never seen such a game as was played on the polo grounds this afternoon. It was the final match for the American championship, and was played by the Bryn Mawrs against the invincible Lakewoods. George Gould and family hurried back from town to see it, and, as the French would say, "all the world was there."

One can never forecast the decision of organized labor in any given set of conditions, but it is scarcely possible that the locomotive engineers of the elevated system will give the company the great and unexpected advantage of replacing them with men who would gladly take their places at very much lower wages.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 7 -- President Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt returned here at 7 A.M. to-day, delighted with their trip to see the men of the Mayflower at work smashing targets. The President had several guests at luncheon. All were late in arriving, and the President wondered. They explained that the train had killed a milkman and his horse near East Winfield.
