In the absence of Fire Chief Edward F. Croker, on vacation, Deputy Chief Charles D. Purroy yesterday, on orders from Fire Commissioner Thomas Sturgis, preferred charges against Patrick F. Ryan, Chief of Construction and Repairs, the latter having been under suspension for more than three months.

--That Prince T'SAI CHEN, while making his speech to his humble countrymen in Chinatown, said to his more elderly hearers, " Tell your young men to be virtuous," is very easy to believe, since Princes in all lands are extremely fond of giving punky and platitudinous advice of that sort, and China is particularly the home of it.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 13 -- The English bulldog Sport, owned by Mrs. McMaster Mills, wife of the President of the Plaza Bank of New York is worth at least a thousand dollars more to-day than he was yesterday. This sudden rise in value is owing to the fact that the dog is supposed, and with good cause, to have secreted somewhere in its interior three diamond rings which have adorned the hands of its mistress.

NEWARK, Aug. 13 -- J. William Clark has been appointed administrator of the estate of William Clark, the millionaire thread manufacturer, whose will was filed for probate late yesterday afternoon. Excepting the six charitable bequests amounting to $56,000, the estate, which is estimated at about $5,000,000, will go to the testator's family.

The incorporation at Trenton, N.J., on Tuesday of the International Harvester Company was followed yesterday by a full statement of its formation, plan, and scope by one of its officers, all of whom have been elected. The company's capitalizaticn, as stated, is $120,000,000 common stock in shares of $100 each.

A Wisconsin legislator, whose conscience may have troubled him by reason of the consciousness that he is "something of a liar himself," has prepared a bill for introduction at the beginning of the next session which is designed to deprive fishermen of the pleasure of exaggerating the size of their catches.

Samuel Goldsticker has sold for Mrs. Lottie Gray Horton the five-story Building 11 Dey Street, 25.8 by 91. The buyer is Warren Leslie, who recently purchased through the same broker the adjoining parcel, No. 9, and who now controls a frontage of 51 feet, beginning about 150 feet west of Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Navy Department has received word that the Cincinnati sailed yesterday from Porto Cabello for Barcelona, under the instructions cabled to Commander McLean directing either the Cincinnati or Topeka to proceed immediately to that point. Commander McLean evidently decided to go himself and leave the Topeka to protect American interests at Porto Cabello.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 13 -- The Presidents of the local assemblies of the Unites Mine Workers of the Wilkesbarre District met here to-day, and adopted resolution condemning the Rev. Father O'Reilly of Shenandoah for his criticism of the officers of the United Mine Workers. President Mitchell and the district Presidents were eulogized for their efforts to better the condition of the miners.

A board of officers to consist of Major Henry L. Harris, Artillery Corps; Capt. Charles S. Riche, Corps of Engineers, and Capt. George G. Gatley, Artillery Corps, will convene at the United States Engineer Office, Galveston, on Aug. 25, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the purpose of revising the projected fire control system of Galveston.

The Belleville Catholic Club will hold a set of open athletic games at Hillside Park, Bellevile, N.J., on Saturday, Aug. 23, at which the following events will be contested: 100-yard run, handicap; 300-yard run, handicap; 880-yard run, handicap; 600-yard run, novice; one-and-a-half-mile run, handicap; one-mile relay race, and running high jump.

Members of the underwriting syndicate of the United States Steel Corporation received yesterday a third dividend of 5 per cent on the amount of their underwriting, which was $200,000,000, making a total profit on the underwriting of 15 per cent., or $30,000,000.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Aug. 13 -- Gen. Jacob H. Smith is seriously ill to-night at the home of his brother-in-law and attorney, Judge James W. Bannon. His illness began last night, but was not considered serious until late this afternoon, when several physicians were called in.

The most sensational testimony given last night at the hearing of the Mayor's committee appointed to inquire into the facts of the recent riot at the funeral of Rabbi Joseph was that of W.M. Weinberg of the Equitable Life Assurance Society who lives at 488 Grand Street, within a half block of the Hoe manufacturing plant, the scene of the disorder.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 13 -- The General Superintendents of the largest coal companies in the anthracite field held a secret meeting at the offices of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company here to-day. A brief meeting was held in the Reading offices at 11 o'clock, and shortly after noon the entire party went to Tumbling Run, a pleasure park, where a luncheon was served.

QUEBEC, Que., Aug. 13 -- Judge Caron of the Superior Court to-day released Capt. Greene and Col. Gaynor, the American contractors who are wanted in the United States for alleged frauds against the Federal Government involving hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Some "short" contracts were covered in yesterday's market, some overextended bear traders beginning apparently to get glimpses of the fact that it takes more than a loud voice and churning imagination to exterminate National prosperity. The announcement that Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan had sailed from Europe to New York may have exerted some influence upon the sentiment of traders.

The last baseball game of the series between the Toronto and Jersey City teams at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday lasted ten innings, and was won by the Canadians with a score of 3 to 2. The score:

STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Miss Helen Miller Gould will give a lawn party to-morrow afternoon at Kirkside, her handsome Summer residence near Roxbury. Elaborate preparations have been made to entertain the guests, and the preliminary sale of tickets has been beyond all expectations.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Many elaborate descriptions have been printed this week of the crown which the Archbishop of York placed on the head of Queen Alexandra in Westminster Abbey last Saturday, but the fact has hitherto not been revealed that all the diamonds in it, except the famous Koh-i-Noor, will soon be placed on sale.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 13 -- William O. Garrison, County Collector, is short $25,000 in his accounts, according to a sealed letter left in his-safe. The letter's assertion is verified by the County Counsel, who, with the Finance Committee of the Board of Chosen Freeholders, spent the entire day going over the accounts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Has it ever struck the people at large that pension reform (with its 140 odd millions) is quite as important as "tariff reform?" From time to time the general Dress takes a pot shot at the pensioners, which is rather tough on the aforesaid persons, who are in no wise to blame in this age of grabbing at everything in sight.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Call money is still in fairly good demand at rates slightly above those recently ruling, and time money is also held very firm and with the banks disinclined to let it out freely. Clearing House rate, 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 5 cents discount; call loans, 3 1/2 to 4 per cent.; time money, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $21,146,297; balances, $1,819,242.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 13 -- Advices from Washington indicate that President Roosevelt is inclined to recognize hereafter the Addicks faction instead of the Du Pont faction, whenever he has any Federal plums to distribute in Delaware. This is the news brought to Washington to-day by a recent visitor in Oyster Bay.

NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 13 -- The announcement of the programme for the post conference addresses which are to follow the General Conference at Northfield has just been made. The conference closes on the 17th, and the post conference addresses begin on the 19th and last Until Sept. 7.

There was no more strike talk among the motormen, engineers, and firemen of the Manhattan Railway Company. At the meeting of the firemen to-night, and the engineers and motormen to-morrow night, it is expected that the agreement signed in their behalf will be ratified.

While the ocean going tug Jacob Kuper was off St. George, S.I., about 7 o'clock yesterday morning, on her way from Erie Basin to the American Cotton Company docks at Tompkinsville, her boiler burst with great force, throwing the crew of eight men high into the air. After the explosion only fragments of the tug could be seen floating.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- The police obtained their first clue of value in the Bartholin case to-night, and developments that will go far toward solving the mystery are expected within twenty-four hours.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 13 -- Shippers, consumers, and speculators must reckon with Manitoba and the Northwest Territories this year, for the yield of small grain there has been enormous. Figures on the production in the territory which supplies the 637 elevators of Manitoba and the Territories have been compiled by authorities, who Save made an exhaustive inspection of practically all of the fields.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- The Indian troops who came here for the coronation, to the number of 1,300, were reviewed by King Edward at Buckingham Palace this afternoon.

Two $5,000 stake races at the Brighton Beach track yesterday made an ambitious programme, and one that drew a fair attendance and also made good sport. The course was lighting fast with dust flying from the opening of the sport to the finish, in spite of the repeated efforts of the track managers to water it and keep down the dust.

John Reilly of 342 First Avenue, who says his wife deserted him, carrying their child with her, rushed into the apartments of Joseph Heine at 796 Eight Avenue last night and tried to carry off Heine's three-year-old son. He was put out, only to make a second attempt at Fifty-second Street and Eighth Avenue later, when a crowd was about to mob him.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 13 -- Henry Watterson, who has been spoken of as a Democratic candidate for Governor of Kentucky and for President of the United States, caused a sensation in the political circles of the State to-night by announcing that he was not a candidate for the Governorship; that he could not fight a machine, and that he would not hold an office which could be purchased with money.

Conflicting rumors regarding the baseball war between the National and American Leagues continue to fly around, and supporters of the game hereabout are perplexed to the degree that every new report is taken with more or less doubt, for nothing can be verified.

Only two witnesses were on the stand in the hearing yesterday in the case of Peter Power against the Northern Securities Company. They were Walter Content of H. Content Co., stock brokers, and William Terhune, bookkeeper for that firm. Their testimony was to the effect that the firm was not in any way concerned in the Peter Power litigation.

The Republican State Committee, at its meeting in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, next Saturday, in addition to setting the date for the State Convention, will have certainly one and possibly two other important propositions to dispose of, They are the settlement of the question of representation in the new Twenty-fifth Congress District, and the selection of a successor to Judge John F. Parkhurst of Steuben as State Committeeman.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt gave a dinner at Beaulieu this evening for forty guests. The table decorations by Hodgson were of American Beauty roses in silver vases, with garlands of roses and ferns on the table.

BREST, Aug. 13 -- Soldiers, have been requisitioned in several places in Finistere in the last two or three days in order to protect Police Commissaries engaged in closing religious schools from threatening crowds.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 13 -- The Marie affair of yesterday seems to have given society a lively awakening. It has been followed by a gay and busy day. The tournaments at the Kebo Valley Club drew forth the morning crowds, and to-night the third August ball at the Malvern was a brilliant affair.

The foreign trade statistics of the United States during the past two years have illustrated the fact that in commerce, as in other things, the unexpected is prone to happen. When Europe was convulsed by a paroxysm of fear concerning the invasion of its markets by a flood of American manufactures, conditions were shaping here which created a domestic consumptive demand so unprecedented that in many lines exports fell off and imports increased.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 13 -- In a game full of fast riding Point Judith defeated Devon in the semi-final contest for the Narragansett Polo Cups by a score of 12 3/4 goals 4 to 10 this afternoon. The victors put up the snappier game, and were better mounted than the visitors. Devon was allowed nine goals, and only earned one in addition.

Members of the Hope Baptist Church, at Broadway and One Hundred and Fourth Street, are exercised over remarks against Miss Grace Merritt, a member of that church. In reference to the authorship of anonymous letters that were received by several of the young members of the congregation prior to the first of the year.

PORT CHESTER, N.T., Aug. 13 -- The steam lighter Star, owned by Charles E. Wager of the Lively Lighterage Company of 524 East Eighty-sixth Street, New York, was burned to the water's edge and her hull gutted late this afternoon in the harbor here. The Star had been here with a load of 750 barrels of cement.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 13 -- New York exchange was 20 cents premium to-day. Time and call loans, 4@5 per cent. Trading in local stocks was again quiet to-day. Box Board opened a shade stronger for both the common and preferred shares, but beyond that the market did not display any new feature.

It would be interesting to know, if there were any way of finding out, to what extent the recent coronation of King EDWARD has tended to emancipate from silly superstition the great multitude of people who, because of an alleged prophecy by a gypsy charlatan or take witch, to the effect that he would reign but never be crowned, have regarded it as impossible for him to experience what has just happened to him.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 13 -- The annual marine carnival on Wesley Lake took place this evening and was enjoyed by 30,000 spectators, who occupied an immense grand stand at the foot of Grand Avenue, and other points of vantage on the banks of the pretty sheet of water. More than fifty boats were in the procession, which passed in review before the ten judges on the lower bridge.

The defense of Capt. Herlihy's ex-ward man, Stephen J. Reagan, charged with neglect of duty while in the Eldridge Street Precinct, in not closing up certain disorderly houses and with violation of the police department rules in carrying to Capt. Herlihy the questions asked of him in an interview with the District Attorney, began before Deputy Commissioner Thurston at Police Headquarters yesterday morning.

Mrs. Arthur R. Teal of Katonah, N.Y., accompanied by a Mr. Barrett and his two sons, neighbors yesterday called at Police Headquarters in Jersey City and asked Inspector Samuel Archibald to aid them in finding Mrs. Teal's husband, the Rev. Arthur R. Teal. He left home on Tuesday telling his wife he was going to Bedford, a town about three miles from Katonah.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa., Aug. 13 -- The third annual reunion of the Society of the Army of the Philippines began in this city to-day with nearly 2,000 delegates and veterans in attendance, among whom were Gens. MacArthur, Wheaton, and King. After a brief reception early in the day the society was called to order in Arcanum Hall by the President, Gen. Irving Hale.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Cubans who make their home in Washington ridicule the proposition of Senator Elkins and others that Cuba forthwith be annexed to the United States. Annexation may come in ten, twenty, or thirty years, they say, but not in six months or a year. The Cuban problem, it is declared, will not be settled by the immediate absorption by the United States of the republic it has just created.
LONDON, Aug. 13 -- Money was in brisk demand to-day. Discounts were firm on the short supply of money and the large number of American bills in the market.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 13 -- The Executive and Car Service Committee of the American Railway Association met in annual conference here to-night. Sessions will be held until Friday night. It was announced the convention would discuss railroad matters only, and that the coal strike would not be considered.

YONKERS, Aug. 13 -- The employes of the Union Trolley Company went on strike again this morning, but like the one of Saturday last it was of short duration. The strike to-day was started because the men had received no word from President Maher relating to the demands made by them last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 18 -- In the local market the movement was steadily upward, and several new high marks resulted. Philadelphia and Erie rose to 72. While there are many rumors to explain the strength of this security, none is acceptable. Allegheny Valley preferred appeared after a long absence, and sold up to 34 1/4; Huntingdon and Broad Top jumped 4 points, due to increase in earnings and prospects, and the preferred gained 1 3/8.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 13 -- Seaboards virtually monopolized to-day's market. Tips from New York to buy Louisville and Nashville were construed by speculators here as indicating the imminence of an Important deal in the South in which the Seaboards would figure prominently. The main buying locally, however, was for New York interests, the bulk of the day's sales changing the ownership in favor of out-of-town purchasers.

PIERRE, S.D., Aug. 13 -- The Farmers National Co-operative Exchange Company has filed articles of incorporation showing a capital of $50,000,000. The purposes of the corporation are to buy, sell, and deal in grain, provisions, live stock, and all kinds of produce on commission and otherwise, and for that purpose build and equip grain elevators, warehouses, cold storage plants, stockyards, and whatever may be necessary to carry on the business of the corporation.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A theological controversy is a dangerous thing -- this is, therefore, but a suggestion not to be defended, if attacked.

This year the seventh annual tournament of the Westbrook Golf Club will be an open instead of an invitation event. It will be held on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, Sept. 10, 11, 12, and 13, the entries closing with H.B. Hollins, 15 Wall Street, on Sept. 8, at 8 P.M., and for the foursomes and the handicap at 10:30 A.M. at the clubhouse on the day of play.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 14 -- In Common Pleas Court No. 3 this morning, the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad Company filed exceptions to the $30,000 bond of the Pittsburg, Carnegie and Western Company, covering any damages that would result from bringing the Wabash into Pittsburg through the South Side.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 14 -- At Gaffney, S.C., to-day, Congressman A.C. Latimer and ex-Congressman J.J. Hemphiil engaged in a fist fight. The fight did not occur on the stand, but in the court house before the audience had been dispersed for dinner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Unless reports that come to Washington from all parts of the country are misleading there is no great popular interest in the Cuban question, and no general demand for Cuban reciprocity. This is the conclusion reached by many persons who would be glad to be persuaded that there was a strong popular backing for the cause to which they are attached.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Evening Star to-day published the following from a staff correspondent now in New York:

Morris Buck, alias King and Hamilton, was arraigned before Magistrate Corneil, in the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday, charged with fraudulent use of the mails. He was at once turned over to the Federal authorities.

While leaving the church in which she had but a half hour before been married, Mrs. Josephine Bracco, twenty-one years old, a young Italian woman, was attacked yesterday by a discarded admirer, knocked down on the sidewalk, and slashed across the right cheek. She is now in the Flower Hospital in a serious condition, with a stiletto wound extending from her mouth to her right ear that will leave a life disfigurement.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 14. -- For the first time in his thirty-two years of driving Charles Doble, driver of Frank Yokum, was fined $100 here to-day for not driving his horse to win the last heat of the 2:12 pace. Summary:

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 14 -- The first polo game for the Rhode Island Cups was played here to-day at the Point Judith Country Club, the Myopia second team beating the Westchester freebooters, 13 goals to 8. The game was somewhat remarkable for the number of men thrown, these including W.E. Carter of the Westejhesters, F. D. and A.L. cochrane of the Myopias.

NEWPORT, Aug. 14 -- In the ladies' lawn tennis tournament at the Casino this morning were decided the semi-finals, leaving Miss Edna Barger and her sister, Mrs. Barger Wallach, to finish the contest in the finals to-morrow. The matches were something of a disappointment to the larger number of Summer residents present.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 -- Indications are that there will be the liveliest kind of fight over the selection of a successor to the late Senator McMillan. It is evident that the Michigan Central Railroad, an influential factor in Michigan politics, will take a hand. That company is anxious to bring out the construction of a railroad bridge over the Detroit River.
Lockwood M. Seely has been appointed Newark agent of the American Insurance Company of Boston.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 14 -- W.A. Lancaster and M.H. Boutelle of this city, attorneys for the mysterious Peter Power of merger suit fame, have withdrawn from the case, also Bulkley, Gray Moore of Chicago.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Spirited and dashing tennis to-day resulted in William A. Larned being returned the winner of the Long Island championship title in the singles, while in the doubles the famous team of English experts, R.F. and H. L. Doherty, captured the honors. Both of these contests were played on the courts of the Meadow Club, at this place.

DENVER, Aug. 14 -- John Lambert, representing John W. Gates, to-day announced the future policy of Mr. Gates in the control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company. An entirely new board, composed of Eastern men, will be elected, he said, and the industry will be built up on a much larger scale than heretofore, making it a powerful competitor of the United States Steel Corporation.

There was a very searching inquiry made yesterday into the relations of Peter Power with the suit brought in his name, to annul the merger of the companies comprising the Northern Securities Company. For three hours testimony was taken, and every incident bearing directly or indirectly upon the case was inquired into in detail.

The deplorable and riotous resistances in France to the effort of the Government to close up the unauthorized nuns' schools continue and increase in ferocity and bitterness. It almost seems as if the Government had managed to supersede the Dreyfus case, as a "burning question," with an issue even more embittering.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14. -- The International Typographical Union may secede from the American Federation of Labor unless the Chicago printers are reinstated at once by the Chicago Federation of Labor. Members of the union may refuse to pay dues into the Federation. This course was advocated this afternoon in speeches by President Lynch, Secretary Bramwood, and others at the International Typographical Union Convention.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 -- The Seaboard issues were less prominent to-day from a bullish standpoint, due to a growing conviction that the upward movement has about reached its culmination. There was some buying, intermixed with a very palpable profit taking, but the response to the buying on the part of outsiders was less urgent and aggressive.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 14 -- An important meeting of the Board of Directors of the American League was held at the Hollenden to-day,the session lasting- nearly five hours. The meeting was called by President Ban Johnson for the purpose of discussing the future plans of the League, and to make a report on the season as far as it has gone.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A distinguished lady humanitarian of your city, who is one of your correspondents, has favored me with a cutting from your paper of May 22 last containing an account of the "Royal Bullfight in Madrid." I have collected several descriptions of Spain's in-human sport, and if the phrase, "Just as we sow so shall we reap," is true, terrible indeed must be the punishment for her sins.

Earnett pitched a splendid game for the Jersey City baseball team yesterday. He held the Montreal team down to four scattered hits and shut them out from run-getting. Jersey City got three runs in the first inning on three errors, and the home team outplayed the Canadians at every point.

A.A. Housman is reported to have purchased for $250,000 the Austin Corbin stock farm, forest preserves, and residence at Babylon, L.I. The property contains about 1,000 acres, and its original purchase, together with improvements, cost the late Mr. Corbin about $1,000,000.

Failure on the part of that decidedly mysterious organization, the "Aero Club of America," to offer a prize of $25,000 for a journey through the air from Coney Island to the Statue of Liberty and back, is the reason given by M. SANTOS-DUMONT for the sale of his "ship" and his sudden departure for the more appreciative land of France.

BERLIN, Aug. 14 -- A quiet tone prevailed on the Boerse to-day, but prices were maintained, and the market became stronger on private advices from London to the effect that a favorable money market is expected shortly in New York.

SARATOGA, Aug. 14 -- In one more particular Mr. W.C. Whitney's shrewdness has made itself manifest. The price of $3 for admission to the race track, which aroused such general opposition, no longer has any critics left. Yesterday's crowd at the races was the largest which ever assembled here, until to-day's multitude distanced it completely.

Undoubtedly the failure of the Government to secure the extradition of GAYNOR and GREENE amounts to a miscarriage of justice. But it is difficult for a fair-minded American to read the report of the decision of Judge CARON without having to acknowledge that the responsibility for the miscarriage rests upon our own shoulders.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- That President Roosevelt is to interfere in the Senatorial deadlock in Delaware is denied here. He is undoubtedly aware that J.E. Addicks has a tremendous following in the Southern counties, where the fishermen vote is, and among whom Mr. Addicks has a wide personal popularity.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Green B. Morris's colt Cunard won the classic Ken ner Stakes at a mile and a quarter this afternoon from a fair field of three-year-olds. Cunard won easily by a length and a half from the 6 to 5 favorite, Gold Cure, in 2:05 3-5, record time for the track.

SARATOGA, Aug. 14 -- In the final handicap event for the Ballston Cups, played in the annual tournament of the Saratoga Polo Club on its field this afternoon, the Bryn Mawr team was victorious over the Meadow Brook players by a score of 14 goals to 9 1/2. The Bryn Mawrs allowed the Meadow Brooks 6 goals by handicap.

SARATOGA, Aug. 14 -- The Very Rev. Martin Carroll, rector of St. Vincent de Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, died at midnight last night. Father Carroll never recovered from the shock consequent upon the amputation of his leg, an operation made necessary by an accident due to a trolley car here.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- The demand for money is still relatively light, and while the banks generally are holding a conservative attitude, there seems to be ample funds to meet all present requirements. Sterling exchange was weak in tone today, and posted rates were shaded 1/4 cent all around.

PITTSTON, Penn., Aug. 14 -- The Warnke Washery Company's attempt to operate the Duryea washery to-day was followed by bloodshed and riot, and to-night the town is in a state of siege, the people believing that they will be the victims of the gang that has terrorized the place all day.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Money was in strong demand to-day, despite the fact that settlement requirements were smaller than usual. Discounts were firm. The supply of American paper is larger than for months past, and it is inferred that New York, by thus anticipating produce shipments, is attempting to keep money easy in America.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Manuel Gomez and Felipe Pelaez of Cuba to-day instituted suit in Chancery to have set aside an agreement between themselves and the Havana Canal Company, a New Jersey corporation, and which agreement, it is charged, was procured by fraud on the part of the company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Navy Department is in receipt of the following dispatch from Commander Rodgers of the Marietta, dated Port of Spain Aug. 12:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- It was published all over the country this morning that the President had found fault with the Republican text book, just issued by the Congressional Committee, and that the book would be revised before going into circulation.

The live-story building 9 Dey Street and the similar adjoining parcel, No. 11, both of which were purchased recently by Warren Leslie through Samuel Goldsticker, have been resold through the same broker to the New York Telephone Company, owners of the adjoining ten-story building running through from Cortlandt to Dey Street.

STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Favorable weather conditions helped to make Miss Helen Miller Gould's lawn party this afternoon at Kirkside a great success. The proceeds will be devoted to furnishing a Delaware County room in the Naval Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association in Brooklyn.

The Coney Island police and employes of Balmer's Bathing Pavilion dragged the surf from 7 o'clock last evening until long after midnight in a fruitless effort to recover the bodies of two men, whose clothes were found in dressing rooms in the pavilion, and who are believed to have been drowned.

That hasty and ill-considered generalizations are apt to be misleading is illustrated by a study of the recent vital statistics of New York, so far as these relate to infant mortality. During the hottest weather of a normal Summer much sympathy is felt and expressed for the poor babies of the tenements, who must necessarily suffer intensely and "die like sheep" in the blistering days and scarcely more tolerable nights of the hot waves.

TROMSOE, Norway, Aug. 14 -- The United States Consul at Bergen, Victor E. Nelson, has suggested that the British Vice Consul here endeavor to settle the differences between Evelyn B. Baldwin, the Arctic explorer, and Capt. Johanssen of the America. Capt. Johanssen will not accept the suggestion, as the Vice Consul is the owner of the Baldwin-Ziegler expedition's ship Frithjof.
Army. Brig. Gen. Frederick D. Grant, United States Army, is relieved from duty in the Division of the Philippines. He will proceed to San Antonio and assume command of the Department of Texas.
OLD ORCHARD, Me., Aug. 14 -- Ten heats were paced on the kite track this afternoon, one of them In the postponed 2:24 class. Summary:

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- Gov. Odell met with a surprise to-day when he came to Oyster Bay. The arrival of men of distinction usually has been honored by the villagers with salutes of giant powder exploded between anvils, and a gathering at the station to look over the lion of the hour.

TRENTON, Aug. 14 -- The preliminary report of Pierre Lorillard, Jr., James F. Fielder, and George D. Finlay, executors under the will of Pierre Lorillard, was filed this week with Secretary of State Dickinson. This report shows the income of the estate, together with the disbursements, since the death of the tobacco man.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 -- The professional golf tournament at the Lenox Golf Club to-day was won by Wilile Anderson of the Pittsfield Country Club, the National open champion, who defeated Bernard Nichols of the Hollywood (N.J.) Golf Club by one stroke in the thirty-six holes. Anderson's score was 149 and Nichols's 150.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Commissioner Yerkes of the Internal Revenue Bureau has directed that immediate steps be taken for the collection of the tax on profit and loss accounts, or undivided profits accounts, of banks, trust companies, or private banks, under the war revenue act of June, 1898.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Apropos of Emperor William's telegram to the Prince Regent of Bavaria, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, the Wiener Allgemeine Zeitung publishes an article headed "The Telegraph Kaiser."

CHATHAM, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Wilberforce Ogden, the young theological student whose disappearance from the home of his father, William W. Ogden, ten days ago, was found at 8 o'clock this morning in the hay loft of the barn, and not more than fifty feet from the family home.
EVREUX, France, Aug. 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair were traveling to Paris from Trouville to-day, when their automobile crashed into a tree fifteen miles from here. Both were killed.

Broadening tendencies showed throughout yesterday's market. Most of the conspicuous stocks were very strong. Some of them went up substantially. On the other hand, some stocks seldom traded in fell sharply on small sales, New York, New Haven and Hartford, for example, dropping 2 points on a single hundred shares, while Nickel Plate second preferred on 600 shares declined 5 points.

Considerable life was shown by outside stocks yesterday, and the trading in a number of issues was followed with interest. While in the Seaboard stocks and some few others the day's transactions brought about more or less substantial reactions, the market as a whole was strong and among the net gains were several that were larger than any recorded recently.
Gov. David B. Hill has contributed an article to the Courier here on James Arkell, whose funeral wes held to-day.

From the outset of the baseball game played on the Polo Grounds yesterday the Cincinnati team had a winning lead, and, although the New Yorks played a good uphill game, they were beaten by the score of 6 to 3. This wound up the series between these clubs, and last night the teams went West.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair left San Francisco on May 30 for a trip to Europe.

SALEM, N.D., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Maude Lorillard Taller of New York City, youngest child of the late Pierre Lorillard, the millionaire tobacco manufacturer, was to-day in the State Circuit Court at this place granted a divorce from her husband, T. Suffern Tailer, who has for years been prominently identified with the coaching interests of New York.

The Bronx Borough Division of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America is up in arms against Mayor Low and Park Commissioner John E. Eustis for the attitude they have taken toward the organization in its efforts to have the mechanics employed by the city join its ranks.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 14 -- The coal mines in the Springfield district are to be purchased by a New Jersey corporation known as the Illinois Coal and Coke Company, and will be operated under one management. Options on twenty-three of the mines near this city have been secured by Newton Jackson of Philadelphia, who heads the corporation.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 14 -- The third annual open tournament for the President Isham Cup began on the Ekwanok Links to-day in ideal weather. The medal for the best gross score in the qualifying round at 18 holes went to N. Mallouf of Garden City, with 78. Findlay Douglass, who holds the amateur record of the course at 75, got 79 in his qualifying round, while Travis was 2 behind at 81, the bogey score.

Disgusted, as he said, at being unable to obtain a legitimate offer of a prize for an exhibition of his airship's sailing powers, Alberto Santos-Dumont, the aeronaut, sailed for France yesterday on La Touraine. The sailing of the aeronaut was entirely unexpected among his friends and associates here, and especially to the Directorate of the Aero Club, which consists of George Francis Kerr, with headquarters at 74 Broadway.
The latest issue of the Athenaeum contains the following interesting advertisement:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 15 -- The twenty-five deputies on guard at the Warnke washery, Duryea, when the riot took place yesterday, and who were arrested and jailed by the authorities on the charge of inciting a riot and felonious wounding, were brought down from, the prison at noon to-day and given a hearing before Judge Halsey.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Several weeks ago there appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS a letter from one D.F. Hannigan which discloses some very pertinent opinions on "English Novels and American Readers." We are asked "whether the taste of American readers is not in fault in preferring American novels of an inferior quality to good English fiction."

Mr. Charles Josselyn's volume, "The True Napoleon," must at least be acknowledged to represent an immense amount of reading and patient research as to all that could be found in books already issued which would throw strong light upon his subject. The book's sub-title, "A Cyclopedia of Events in Napoleon's Life," indicates its author's purpose.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug.15 -- The novel feature of the annual pony races to be held here to-morrow by the fashionable colony is a Gretna Green race, the second on the card. In this race the conditions are that a lady and gentleman must ride hand in hand from the starting point to a given line.
Army. Second Lieut. Louis Solcllac, Jr., and Walter O. Boswell are assigned to the Sixteenth Infantry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- New York exchange was at par to-day; time and call loans, 4@5 per cent. Such speculative interest as was shown in the local market to-day was for the most part manifested in Box Board. There continues to be a fair demand for this stock, and prices showed a further advance immediately after the opening this morning.

Deputy Sheriff Plunkett has received an attachment against Robert Weinberg for $1,792 in favor of Max Kraut for merchandise sold to him from July 16 to Aug. 1. It was obtained on the ground that Mr. Weinberg had departed from the State to avoid creditors.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Henry Gleason, the head waiter in the Berkley Arms Hotel, was shot last night by Bernard Hatzel, the chief steward. Gleason was about to assault with a chair Mrs. E. Garner, the manager of the hotel, when Hatzel shot him twice in the breast. The wounds are not considered dangerous.

That fascinating bouquet which we call an Anthology, and which a Grecian singer initiated, seems to have become a somewhat favorite form in literature in recent years. Usually it is drawn from a broad and various group of writers, but sometimes, as in Matthew Arnold's selections from Wordsworth and Byron, it merely culls the best fruit from a single source.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 15 -- The second polo game for the Rhode Island Cup was to have been played today between Lakewood and Westchester, but Lakewood won the match by default. I.T. Burden was unable to play for WestChester. A special game, however, was played for cups offered by Mrs. George J. Gould, Spencer of the Devon team playing in Burden's place.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In bringing to notice the "vicious" strain in Sir Richard Calmady which is so potent an influence in poor human nature. Mr. C.F. Adams does not seem to have found the fine moral of the entire story, which to me is apparent above everything else, and to show which the temporary fall of poor Sir Richard is an essential part of the book.

Lachman Goldsmith have bought from the Knickerbocker Real Estate Company the two-story brick buildings 216 to 220 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, 62.6 by 100, together with the abutting three-story buildings 209 to 217 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, on plot 75.6 by 100.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- The American yacht Uncle Sam of the raceabout class, which was bought by Emperor William from Francis R. Riggs of New York, after the boat had won the Emperor's Gold Cup at the international regatta at Kiel, has been overhauled and turned over to the navy.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Application for a receiver for the Commercial Dime Building and Loan Association of Paterson was made to Vice Chancellor Reed to-day by Theodore Backes of the Attorney General's office. The Vice Chancellor granted an order, returnable Sept. 9, directing the association to show cause why it should not be declared insolvent and a receiver be named.

John M. Ryan, Chief of Construction and Repair to Apparatus of the Fire Department, was tried yesterday by Commissioner Sturgis on omnibus charges prepared by Deputy Chief Charles D. Purroy, brother of Henry D. Purroy, the anti-Tammany politician. The technical charges were: "Conduct prejudicial to the good reputation, order, and discipline of the department and willful neglect of duty."
CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 -- The International Typographical Union, which has been in session here all week, has disposed of more than 300 propositions for changes in its laws, as well as many resolutions.

Boston is the scene of the greater part of the third "Randy" story, "Randy and Her Friends," and it shows the sweet little heroine conquering city girls and their mothers by simple, unaffected goodness, as aforetime she conquered her country neighbors. The great merit of this series is the absence of the silly and feeble-willed parents with ill-mannered and slangy daughters.

THE Navaho Indians of Chaco Canon, New Mexico, are best known in the Eastern States for their brilliant blankets, the manufacture of which has been encouraged of late years by Messrs. Talbot B. Hyde and E.B. Hyde, Jr., who have introduced their fabrics especially to New York.

In a recent number of The Independent Dr. David Starr Jordan of the Leland Stanford, Jr., University, California, writes with much sense as to the higher education for business men -- that is, for men intended for the management of affairs on a large scale.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Henry F. Dimock of New York gave a reception and musicals at Canary Cottage to-day. It was attended by 300 guests. Mrs. Seabury Fordand Myron Whitney, Jr., sang. Among the guests were:

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- The semi-official announcement made after yesterday's Cabinet meeting to the effect that the Royalists are directing the agitation against the closing of religious schools in Brittany has evoked considerable comment. Catholic leaders and the Catholic press deny that the movement is anti-Republican.
HAVANA, Aug. 15 -- In the House of Representatives to-day it was resolved that none of the fortresses or arsenals of the Cuban Republic can be leased or sold by the Government.

In spite of the heroic efforts of two boys who saw his danger and tried to save him. Charles Kracka, eleven years old, of 1,360 Avenue A. was drowned early last evening in the East River, off Seventy-seventh Street.

In proceedings for legal separation or a man and wife, now pending in one of the local courts, one of the allegations of the aggrieved husband, and altogether the strongest of those embodied in his affidavit, is that the wife insisted upon retaining a singing servant girl in the house and that her singing established conditions which were intolerable.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 -- Seaboards continued to hold the primary place in to-day's trading, but the belief that the advance has already discounted all benefits to accrue under any deal induced considerable sales to realize. The price held fairly well during the major part of the day. The 4 per cent. bonds were strong, gaining 1 1/2 points.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Vice Chancellor Reed to-day granted an injunction against the Republic Savings and Loan Association of Newark, that has branches in many sections of New Jersey, and declared that he will name a receiver on Tuesday. Alleged bad investment in tenement property in New York City caused the Banking and Insurance Department to apply for the injunction as a safeguard to the members of the association.

OF the two volumes "Merton College" and "New College," as portions of the series "College Histories of Oxford," the first has the claim of seniority. Mr. Fernard W. Henderson in his preface to "Merton College" writes that "the first part of his book consists of a narrative of events in chronological order; the second, mainly of an account of the buildings of the college."

Greater mystery than before, yesterday surrounded the supposed drowning in the surf at Coney Island on Thursday afternoon of James A. Gray, son of ex-Commissioner of Corrections John Mprrissey Gray. Democratic leader of the Eighth Assembly District of Kings County, and Henry Walker Hollenberg of New Rochelle, who disappeared suddenly while in bathing near Balmer's pavilion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- At a conference to-day at encampment headquarters, presided over by Gen. Eli Torrance, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, the following programme of exercises for the 1902 encampment was adopted:

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 15 -- The Hon. J. Israel Tarte, Canadian Minister of Public Works, in a speech before the Canadian Manufacturers' Association here, declared that Canadians must no longer allow their markets to be slaughtered by American manufacturers, and the trade of the continent carried through American channels.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 15. -- A startling story was brought out to-day at the inquest held before Justice Shurtleff into the death of Marcus Rogers, whose body was found in the Walloomsac River here yesterday, when Levi Perham, aged nineteen, confessed that the man had been murdered, and implicated himself and the wife of the dead man as the participants in the crime.

Since the days when Mark Twain proved to the satisfaction of his friends, if not to his enemies, that he did not steal his story of "The Jumping Frog" from a Hellenic source, there has been nothing more remarkable than the varied interpretations given by Frank Norris, Jack London, and Charles Forrest McLean to what was once, in all probability, an actual occurrence.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 15 -- The August trotting meetings of the Worcester Driving Park Company closed to-day, and like yesterday it was a bad day for the men who backed the favorites, as two lost of the three picked to win. The only favorite to win was Jessie Wilkes, in the 2:26 pace. She got away with first money in straight heats, nothing but Victor being able to make a show against her.

Now that the Rhodes bequest is, one assumes, in the way of being made available for this country, ambitious American students are beginning to inquire what there really is for them in an Oxford education. The decadence of England has become so common a theme, in England quite as much as outside of it, that it may not seem as if there were much.

Without a touch of pipe clay the author of "West Point in the Early Sixties" tells of his reminiscences of the cadets, many of whom occupied distinguished positions during the civil war. The character of the West Point joke is fully explained. Sometimes in after life the joke is practically carried out.

In the tables of assessments on the capital, surplus, and undivided profits of the New York banks by the Department of Taxes and Assessments, printed yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES, an error was made in the lines where the word "Merged" was used.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- The sudden death of Charles L. Fair and his wife by the collapse of their automobile near Evreux, France, yesterday means a great loss to San Francisco. Just before his departure for Europe in May last Mr. Fair had practically completed plans for $5,000,000 worth of improvements to the Fair property in this city, and it was his intention on his return to sign contracts for the work.

I stood before the handsome residence of Mrs. Charles Toll, on Capitol Hill, Denver, and wondered which was the proper door to approach, as I had been sent to interview her cook, and the correct form seemed one of great importance to me Just at that moment. Mrs. Toll is the sister of Senator Edward O. Wolcott of Colorado, and occupies an important social position in the western city.

For the past six or seven centuries, or ever since the epical ballad of the Nibelungenlied has been popular in Germany, it has been the pride and boast of the little town of Pochlarm on the Daunbe that its whilom lord, Ruediger, "father of all virtues," played a prominent role in the tragedy when Kriemhild took her revenge on Hagen and her brothers for the murder of her heroic husband.

IN the sub-title of this book is an apt description of its main intent: A Study of the Evidences of the Gospel's Superphysical Features in the Light of the Established Results of Modern Psychical Research."

Quiller-Couch's In the report of an interview with A.T. Quiller-Couch, which appears in The Book Buyer of August, Mr. Quiller-Couch is quoted as being "struck that anyone should have thought it worth while to come such a great distance to see me."

A READER, What is a reader? Happy are those who read what they please, or when they please. Oh! the bliss of reading yourself to sleep. It is not to be understood that there are certain books endowed with anodynous qualities, but there are blessed volumes, so restful and soothing that they induce happy dreams, and tend toward somnolency.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Hannah Nelson of New Market, N.J., mother or Mrs. Charles L. Fair, who, with her husband, was killed on Thursday in an automobile accident in France, will leave on Sunday night for California, in response to a telegram from Joseph Harding of San Francisco, the dead woman's lawyer, who has informed her that the bodies will be sent there immediately for burial.

LONDON, July 31 -- The late Mr. Kegan Paul was a man of letters and also a publisher. This is a rare conjunction, for the average publisher knows next to nothing of literature, and holds that his business is simply to know what will sell.

While anthracite which has been bought at $9.50 a ton wholesale is expected to be put on the market in a week or so at $11 and $11.50 a ton retail, some of the dealers yesterday raised the present retail price to $10 a ton. According to dealers who were seen there was at least one instance where it was sold at a higher figure.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 15 -- Senator Foraker was a guest of his Toledo friends for about five hours to-night. He came in at 6:38 and left at 11:35 over the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad for Cincinnati. While here he was kept busy answering queries about the story that he would be a candidate for the Vice Presidency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- It was said at the papal legation to-day that owing to the death of the Cardinal Prefect at Rome and the various formalities necessary to be gone through with, the appointment of a successor to the late Archbishop Corrigan will not be made until late in November, or possibly December.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- That the President of the United States does not worry about superstitions was shown to-day, when his luncheon party numbered just thirteen. Nor, presumably, did the dread of the supposed ill-omened number enter the heads of any of the others, for no one called attention to the fact.

It seems to be a pretty fair deduction from the observed phenomena that M. COMBES will not long continue to be the Premier of the French Republic. As THACKERAY said about BULWER, "his intellectual nature is not physically adapted" to the kind of contest in which he is engaged, and which he himself forced on Without any effective pressure from outside.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 15 -- There is great excitement among the 600 poor persons who are stockholders of the Mutual Loan and Building Association, the largest association in this county, over the announcement that the association has suspended, owing to the alleged defalcations of its Secretary, William Malcolm.

A dozen persons more or less injured, one -- a woman -- so badly that she may die, a panic on a crowded car, and the arrest of a car driver were some of the results of a runaway accident yesterday afternoon at First Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 15 -- The town council of the borough of Shenandoah has offered a reward of $500 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons who murdered Joseph Beddal; another reward of $200 for information leading to the arrest of persons who assaulted the town police, and $200 for the information leading to the arrest of all other persons who participated in the riot.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: My attention has been called to your review of my book "71 Days' Camping in Morocco." In justice to myself and my publishers, I must point out the carelessness of such criticism as the following: "The style -- with its numerous co-ordinate clauses strung together by 'and,' its many split infinitives, and irregular paragraph structure -- proclaims the amateur, but at no time does it become dull."

Does the study of history give the student a more correct view of the immediate future and qualify him to pass judgment on present tendencies? Is the old phrase, "History is philosophy teaching by example," near enough to the truth to be of real value to the historian, and through him to his contemporaries?

Police Commissioner Partridge, accompanied by Senior Inspector Cortright, made an extended tour of observation on the lower east side yesterday afternoon. Inspector Cortright was not in uniform, and the visit of the two officials attracted little attention excepting upon the part of the police, who recognized them and passed the word along the line.

So many writers of books, which, if not poor, are but indifferently good, have recently attained to hand-made paper and other attributes of the deluxe edition that it begins to seem more honorable to escape such flattery.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 15 -- Under superb golfing conditions of turf and atmosphere the tournament at the Ekwanok Country Club went through the semi-final round for the four cups to-day, and the principal event -- that for the cup offered by President Isham -- leaves Walter J. Travis of Garden City and last year's National champion, to play C.B. Corey of Wollaston.

After sixteen years of retirement from the literary field, Mrs. Augusta Evans Wilson has come forward with her eighth novel, written, as the dedication indicates, at the request "of kind readers, known and unknown."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Complying with the request of the Secretary of State, the Treasury Department will detail an expert architect from the office of the Supervising Architect to go to Peking in order to complete the plans and specifications for the new United States Legation building there and to superintend its construction.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Friedheim, which is this year, as last, occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones, was to-night the scene of one of the most elaborate dinner dances ever held in Newport. Preparations for the dance had been in progress for several weeks, and workmen only late this afternoon completed the fitting of the house and the temporary additions for the event.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Luther R. Marsh, widely noted as a spiritualist, died at his home at this place late this afternoon, after an illness lasting several weeks. He was eighty-nine years of age. Notwithstanding his great age, Mr. Marsh, up to a few weeks ago, was actively engaged in literary work, and, just before his last illness, had filled several pulpits.

In our Washington dispatches yesterday morning it was reported that some of the earnest advocates of commercial reciprocity with Cuba think that the American people will not respond to the appeal to the public conscience in that matter, but can be aroused by a demonstration that reciprocity is in the interest of the United States.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- The minuet to be danced at Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish's Colonial ball on Friday evening next is being rehearsed at Mrs. Fish's villa on three and four afternoons a week, under the direction of Miss Helen Weaver, who is a charming and graceful dancer.

There is nothing probably which every man resents more promptly and emphatically than to have his word doubted; but there is nothing which God endures so constantly and so graciously. To call another "a liar" men consider an unpardonable offense, whether it be directly or by implication.

What was considered by the lawyers for the Northern Securities Company to be the most important testimony so far adduced in their behalf in the case of Peter Power against the merger corporation was brought out in the hearing in the Federal Building yesterday, Among other things, it was testified that Gov. Van Sant of Minnesota was one of the backers of the Peter Power case.

PARIS, Aug. 15 -- The fatal accident to Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair near Evreau, yesterday is the sensation of the city and the leading topic of conversation among American residents and in automobile circles.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Five favorites were beaten this afternoon, the only winning first choice being Old Hutch in the mile selling race. Old Hutch won easily by a length and was bid up $700 over his entered selling price, his owner, C.H. Smith, bidding him in Olefiant, a Western two-year-old, was made the medium of heavy play in the opening dash.

RICHMOND, Ind., Aug. 15 -- A number of Indiana men are now engaged in completing the details of a colonization plan which they have in hand. They are organizing the Florida-Alabama Agricultural Society, and have purchased 50,000 acres of land in Southern Alabama.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- Money rates are still held relatively firm, but the demand at the same time is not extreme. Sterling exchange remains quiet and with its tone still showing considerable weakness. Clearing House rates 3 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount; call loans, 3 1/2 @ 4; time money, 4 1/2 @ 5; Clearing House exchanges, $22,025,894; balances, $1,810,222.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 15 -- Judge H.C. Faulkner of Barbourville has been in the city several days endeavoring to get rates from the Louisville and Nashville Railroad to ship oil to the nearest markets. He was unsuccessful.

The following canto from Dante's "Inferno," entitled "A Vision of Editors," has invariably been omitted from the editions prepared for publication. It seems to have been the feeling of his various translators that the great poet may, perhaps unconsciously, have allowed personal experiences to unduly embitter and influence this portion of his otherwise calm and veracious narrative.

The week-end was well rounded in Newport by the large and lavish entertainment given by Mrs. Pembroke Jones at Friedheim. At Saratoga races and dinners were the attraction, with dances at the principal hotels, which were very well attended. The other resorts have excellent programmes for this evening and many house parties are arranged for over Sunday.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Tennis of a higher class than is usually seen in mixed doubles was played to-day in the semi-final and final contests of the Long Island championship tournament, now nearly finished on the courts of the Meadow Club. The fact that the English experts, R.F. Doherty, H.L. Doherty, and Dr. Joshua Pim, played in these contests acted as the magnet which attracted a large and fashionable gallery.

Assistant Superintendent Mack of the Railway Mail Service at New York, yesterday received an official communication from Postmaster Grier of Allegheny, Penn., in which resentment and desperation were but thinly veiled by words of studied formality and calm. According to the indorsement thereon, the document dealt exclusively with fleas.

Commissioner of Accounts William Hepburn Russell, who is also deputy leader of the Greater New York Democracy, made an explanation yesterday as to the appointment of George H. Nason, formerly Coroner in Brooklyn, to the position of Examining Inspector in the Commission of Accounts office at $1,800 a year.

THE village library is growing more and more an indispensable adjunct to American village life. It comes into existence and thrives naturally, almost spontaneously, in the large towns, or even in the smaller towns.

George Gordon Battle, acting as counsel for Andrew F. Power, promoter and treasurer of the New England Manufacturers' Association, said yesterday that the order of arrest obtained from Trustee Steckler against Gov. Kimball of Rhode Island was in the Sheriff's hands for execution. It could not be executed, however, unless the Governor came to New York, and Mr. Battle did not know when that would take place.

Jersey City defeated Montreal again yesterday at West Side Park, and should have shut out the visiting Canadians without a run were it not for an error of Oakes in left field during the eighth inning which allowed the Montreals to tally once. The home team really won the game in the fifth inning, when they scored 2 runs on Griffen's safe hit, a three-base hit by Mack, and Butler's drive for two bases.

Money market manipulators disported for a little while on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Pulling hard and pulling altogether they succeeded in rushing the rate for call loans up to 0 per cent. Probably as many as two relatively unimportant transactions were made at that figure.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15 -- Drawings for the match play of the eighty-three experts who have entered for the National lawn tennis championship at the Casino next week, were made to-day, and the result was most satisfactory, inasmuch as none of the stronger players will have hard matches until the second or third round.

This curious and interesting volume was prepared in large part by the Rev. Edward T. Corwin, D.D., who obtained a great part of his material from the records of the Dutch Reformed Church in Holland. Other sources of information were our own colonial records and a number of historical works.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department has received from Minister Conger an interesting Chinese imperial edict concerning the raising of the war indemnity. The edict shows that China is seeking to devise a plan for meeting the indemnity, and is fearful that the heavy taxes on the people will incite them to further disorder.

An article in that August Atlantic, we are glad to see, brings Browning again before the public in his simplest and most natural aspect, not as a laborious puzzle against which the wits of men and women lose their edge, but as "The Browning Tonic" -- a fresh, vitalizing influence, imparting spiritual ozone to the air.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Major C.W. Studdert and others, who were concerned in the alleged fraud and conspiracy in connection with Yeomanry horse sales in Ireland, were to-day summoned for trial before the court of Clare County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The State Department has received from Minister Conger an interesting Chinese imperial edict concerning the raising of the war indemnity. The edict shows that China is seeking to devise a plan for meeting the indemnity, and is fearful that the heavy taxes on the people will incite them to further disorder.

An article in that August Atlantic, we are glad to see, brings Browning again before the public in his simplest and most natural aspect, not as a laborious puzzle against which the wits of men and women lose their edge, but as "The Browning Tonic" -- a fresh, vitalizing influence, imparting spiritual ozone to the air.

The second volume of Prof. Gordy's "Political History of the United States" is an endeavor to present the history of this country from 1800 to 1829 so far as it relates to the rise, development, and overthrow of parties in American politics. Prof. Gordy seems to have accomplished the unexpected in producing a work which, in its discussion of our early nineteenth century politics, is totally free from rancorous party spirit.

PITTSTON, Penn., Aug. 15 -- Careful investigation at all of the Erie Company plants in this vicinity of the story that men have been kidnapped from New York and held prisoners to work in the mines is denied here.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The Philadelphia market to-day continued active, and some of the specialties reached new top figures for the present movement. Most of the business to-day was in Cambria Steel, Consolidated Lake Superior, Philadelphia Electric, and the traction stocks.

The Republican politicians will meet in force at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to-day and settle many of the details of the coming State and local campaigns. There was a gathering of some of the old campaigners of the Republican Party last evening and the questions at issue were discussed.

THIS is the first of a series of three volumes in which is to be presented, mainly through letters, the outline of the life of the French litterateur Hippolyte Tainc, who is perhaps best known to English readers by his "History of English Literature" and his "Ancien Regime."

In April of last year the interesting news was announced in America that Columbia University had received, through Prof. A. V. Williams Jackson, the princely gift from the Parsis of Bombay of five manuscripts of the Avesta. This year the university is further enriched by a sixth codex, which Prof. Jackson has just received to present on behalf of the Parsi high priest Dastur Kaikhosru Jamaspji and the former owner, M. Pavri.

A CITIZEN -- The manner of addressing royal personages varies in different countries, but the form used in writing to the Kng of England may be employed for other rulers without any great departure from etiquette.

In the paper on "The Mutual Relations of Capital and Labor," read by Mr. ABRAM S. HEWITT before the Church Congress in Cincinnati, in 1878, are found many passages which, in the light of subsequent experience, may be regarded as prophetic. For such prophecy the inspiration needed is clear insight and the intelligence to recognize the existence and note the trend of the forces which make for social regeneration.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- The pressure for money was relaxed to-day, although the supply was nor plentiful. Discounts were firm, affected by the growing demand for money by New York and talk of gold exports to that centre.
THE new novel, by F. Hopkinson Smith. "The Fortunes of Oliver Horn," which has been running as a serial in Scribner's Magazine, will be published in book form by Charles Scribner's Sons Aug. 29.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 16. -- These August days are finding this mountain resort enjoying one of the most prosperous seasons in its history. All the hotels, boarding houses, and cottages are filled to overflowing, and the Summer people have settled down into a round of entertaining gayeties which keep them well occupied all the time.

AFTER having vanished from view for more than a year, the planet Eros has now been rediscovered. The astronomers of the country are on the qui vive, for this elusive wanderer of the skies is looked upon as the means whereby they will be enabled at last to calculate the exact distance from the earth to the sun.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 16. -- Pittsburg won both games by all-around better playing than Philadelphia put up. Both games abounded in brilliant fielding plays. Leach's steal home from third while Iberg was pitching one of his slow curves set the local enthusiasts wild. Scores by innings:

MATTEAWAN, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- To-day at Brewsters, where the country home of President H.H. Vreeland of the Interurban Street Railroad Company is situated, he tendered a clambake to the men at the head of the various departments under him, and Mrs. Vreeland afterward gave the party a reception at Rest a While, the Vreeland country home.
Gen. Henry N. Hooper, for many years a resident at Brooklyn, died, last Wednesday at Point Loma, Cal., whither he went in June last for his health.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 16. -- At a dinner given in honor of the Road Committee of the Essex County Board of Freeholders by the Automobile Club of New Jersey at Pompton Plains yesterday nearly every member of that board went on record as favoring the granting of a speed of twenty miles an hour to automobiles outside the limits of the city.

THE Belle Meade thoroughbreds, in which at one time Richard Croker was interested, will be sold at public auction on Oct. 22 and 23, and Gen. W.H. Jackson will retire from breeding horses. The decision on the part of Gen. Jackson to retire from active life deprives the American turf at once of the best-known breeders and one of the most celebrated stock farms on earth.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Over 4,000 visitors have ararrived at this resort during the past week. There is not a vacant room at any of the large hotels, and many new arrivals have had to seek accommodations with the campers over night.

One of the best professional matches of the decade was played yesterday at the Deal Golf Club, between Willie Norton, professional of the home club, and J.W. Andrews, professional of the Seabright Golf Club. The match was at 36 holes, the best two out of three. Norton, having won two matches straight, took the $200 purse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Navy Department to-day received a mail report from Commander McCrea of the gunboat Machias, dated Cape Haitien, July 31, detailing the conditions as he found them upon his arrival from Colon, whence he sailed for Haiti under instructions of the department. The report is, in part, as follows:

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The fifth annual tournament of the Ampersand Golf Club will be held on Sept. 4, 5, and 6. There will be a qualifying round of eighteen holes, with a prize for the lowest score. The first sixteen will Qualify for the Ampersand Cup and the second sixteen for the Consolation Cup.

DOWN TOWN a wiseacre is a man who has made a million "bucking the Street." Up town a wiseacre is a man who knows enough to leave the Street alone. There is a certain inconsistency in the two definitions, but both exist.

FRONTENAC, Aug. 16. -- The coming weeK will be a gala week in the Thousand Island region. Indications pointing toward immense crowds at this resort and at Thousand Island Park particularly. Gov. Odell and party will arrive on the river Monday afternoon to attend the annual session of the New York State Orange, before which body the Governor will make an address on Tuesday.

The Board of Fire Underwriters of New York, represented by William A. Anderson, Superintendent of their Survey Bureau, outlined their policy against the Building Department yesterday. Mr. Anderson took a decided stand against Superintendent Stewart of the Building Department in the supervision of buildings in course of construction.

Benedict Beck, who lives with his wife and sixteen-year-old son, Benedict Beck, Jr., on the third floor of an apartment house at 135 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, the corner of Lexington Avenue, rescued his wife and himself from fire last evening.

IT was not a new hard-luck tale to the man to whom it was told. The young man, neatly dressed and dapper looking, was not out of work, had not lost his purse, was not poverty-stricken at all, but he had come down from Rye to go over to Newark to play golf with some charming girls, and in changing his clothes had forgot to transfer his pocketbook to the trousers he put on.

THE polo field at Meadowthorpe had never in all its history witnessed such a sight. Eight fair horsewomen, in the full glory of fresh white shirtwaists, stood facing each other, four on each side. One team was distinguished from the other by broad red sashes worn over their shoulders.
HER Majesty beamed over the coffee cups at the Boy. She had arrived in town unexpectedly just as he was about to start for their Summer home at Daisyhurst to spend his Saturday to Monday holiday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Minister Squiers has sent to the State Department a mail dispatch from Cuba, giving in detail the text of the Cuban loan bill, as it recently passed the Senate, and of the House bill. He says concerning them:
To the Editor of The New fork Times: In Senator Hanna's address at Chautauqua last Saturday, he is quoted as follows:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The United States, Hotel will be the headquarters of the Republican State Convention, which has been called to assemble here on Tuesday, Sept. 23. The State Committee will meet here on Monday evening, Sept. 22.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- The United States War Department has bought of Herr Ehrhardt, a gunmaker of Dusseldorf, the right to re-arm the American field artillery with Herr Ehrhardt's new piece. Capt. Henry D. Borup of the United States Ordnance Department is now at Dusseldorf on this business, probably to learn thoroughly how the gun is constructed.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The remarkable weather features continue, but in spite of the somewhat unpropitious state of affairs the visitors keep coming, and the hotels are filled to overflowing. At the Stevens House all records have been broken in the number of persons accommodated at the hotel.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 16. -- Lenox cottagers are remaining here this season in larger numbers than usual, instead of going to the seashore. Some of those who went to the shore a week or so ago have returned, as they find the Berkshires more congenial. The weather has been so cool that open fires blaze in the great fireplaces in the evenings at most of the country houses.

Because his wife, Emma, was an ardent Catholic church worker and a member of several Catholic societies, Charles C. Rubson, who was a Protestant, ended yesterday afternoon a series of disputes on religion by murdering her and then committing suicide in their rooms over their general furnishing store, known as the Willis Avenue Bazar, at 480 Willis Avenue.

BOSTON, Aug. 16. -- Light business was done in money to-day. Rates were still firmly held, and with some little fresh apprehension showing concerning the immediate future, due in part to the call rates in New York and due also to the unfavorable bank statement. Clearing House rates were 3 1/2 per cent. New York funds were at 10c discount.
THE total length of the Panama Canal will be 46.6 miles, including an extension of 3.1 miles through the Bay of Panama.

SOUTH BETHLEHM, Penn., Aug. 16. -- New York athletes carried off nearly all of the prizes at the Forester's Day sports on the Bethlehem Fair Grounds this afternoon, in the presence of thousands of people though the events were all closely contested. Summaries:

The scandal respecting the remount department of the British Army is the sorest and most mortifying to patriotic Britons of any of the shortcomings developed by the war in South Africa. Ever since the Crimean war it has been plain that the business methods of the British civilian by no means extended to the British staff officer.

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The preserves of Paul Smith and William Rockefeller adjoin near the foot of St. Regis Mountain. The mountain, however, is entirely within the Rockefeller preserve. During the course of a Summer at Paul Smith's Hotel and upon the St. Regis chain of lakes it is the ambition of nearly every one to ascend to the top of the mountain, from which about sixty lakes may be seen.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Aug. 16. -- The great water power canal of the Soo, which has Just been finished after four years of construction and an expenditure of $5,000,000, is regarded by engineers as the finest work of its kind in the world.

SO great is the power of a name that every Sicilian in New York and many Italians continue to tremble when the Mafia is mentioned, although that organization only a few days ago received a body blow when its leaders were sentenced to thirty years' imprisonment. Such was Antonine Ajello, an importer and exporter of olive oil, with several branch stores, one of them at 2,428 First Avenue, this city.
Col. Charles Denby, formerly United States Minister to China, is to be invited to deliver the address at the dedication of the Nancy Hanks Lincoln Monument in Lincoln City, Ind., Oct. 1.

Recent events have thrown a strong light on the practice, to which attention was called in these columns several weeks ago, of blackmailing corporations by bringing injunctions and similar proceedings against them just as they were about to consummate some important transaction.

THE gowns seen at Newport this season seem to be even more beautiful and more diaphanous than those of last year. Perhaps the fact that there have been comparatively few pleasant days this Summer at the City by the Sea brings out so many excuisite frocks when a day of sunshine and fine air does bless that resort.

THERE were published in the newspapers during the week two biographical sketches of the highest interest to those who admire what Americans like to think of as the typical American combination of characteristics for success -- honesty, generosity, and simplicity, allied with sagacity and energy.

Business last week was of somewhat wider range and of greater volume than might have been anticipated from, the recent course of the market, although few individual transactions have presented features of special significance.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 16. -- The wails and lamentations because of the inclement weather have given way to shouts at joy at the sun's reappearance. Society has straightway plunged hungrily into the vortex of gayety, as if to make up for the opportunities snatched from them by the fog and rain.

Only local athletes competed in the annual open games of the New West Side Athletic Club on the club grounds in Fifty-fourth Street yesterday, and the large crowd of spectators which gathered in the small enclosure saw some fair sport in which club rivalry dominated quality of contest.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Favorable weather conditions have prevailed at Cape May during the week and made it exceedingly pleasant and delightfully cool for the thousands of visitors who have been here from nearly every section of the East, including more than the usual number of New Yorkers.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- While the month of July did not bring as many, visitors to Lake George as usual at that season, August bids fair to more than make up for the difference. The Fort William Henry Hotel, the largest on the lake, has every room occupied, which has not occurred before in more than twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Secretary of the Treasury declines to discuss it -- all officialdom is studiously non-committal -- but this can be relied upon:

WINSTED, Conn., Aug. 16. -- Twenty-two years ago this Summer Mrs. John P. Cook of 373 North Main Street lost her wedding ring while at work in the garden in the rear of her home.
