At that time she had been married three years. Every Summer since then she has searched the garden for the ring, but not until yesterday did she find it.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In reply to your correspondent who advocates making New York City a State by itself, under the name of the State of Manhattan, I desire to say that the country can get along very well without New York, but New York cannot get along without the country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 --The Newport season has entered the ball or dinner-dance stage, and from now on to the end of the season, perhaps as late as the middle of September, there will be at least two, and sometimes three, large social functions a week, with dancing a feature of each of them.

PROBABLY no other hotel in the world but the new Potter, in Santa Barbara, Cal., has the peculiar distinction of being set upon a battleground of the ancients, builded up into a miniature mountain by successive tiers of dead and crumbling warriors -- Califoraian warriors, who once gruarded the beautiful coast at the foot of the Santa Ynez Mountains from the invasions of the insular tribes of the Pacific.

Clearly the Chinese imperial edict concerning the raising of the war indemnity goes too far or not far enough. The indemnity, in spite of the efforts of the United States, to some extent seconded by some of the other Powers, was raised to the utmost limit of China's supposed or assumed ability to pay.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- The local stock market was optimistic to-day, despite the fact that there was less aggressive trading. Marsden Company was the feature, the stock being advanced half a point, closing at 4 3/4 on the strength of the earnings of International Smokeless Powder, of which the Marsden Company owns a controlling interest.

Yesterday's market was narrow. Traders were disposed to await the weekly Clearing House statement, made public only a little while before the adjournment of business. It had been forecast as certain to be very disturbing. The worst thing it showed was a shrinkage of about a couple of millions in surplus reserves.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 16. -- The annual polo tournament of the Point Judith Country Club has been the all-absorbing attraction for society at Narragansett during the past week, and everybody has flocked to Wildfield Farm in gay trap, stylish victoria, and up-to-date automobile to view the polo matches and to see the advent of the young Gould boys and the Vanderbilts in their contests for polo honors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to express my surprise at your editorial in yesterday's TIMES on trades' unionism. It would seem, that your fear of the high price to be paid for hard coal the coming Winter has seriously warped your usually sound Judgment. As to trades unionism, the writer considers it to be the worst curse that at present afflicts the American people.

The Republican State Committee, in session for seven minutes at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, selected Saratoga Springs as the place and Sept. 23 as the date for the holding of the State convention. The headquarters of the committe will be at the United States Hotel, where the committee will meet on the night of Sept. 22.

THE world will soon be reading accounts of a celebration of a kind which, most people supposed, would never be witnessed again -- a celebration as elaborate as an old Roman triumph, as gorgeous as a scene from the Arabian Nights.

OUR State Department is watching the present crisis in Venezuelan affairs with far more than the interest usually accorded South American revolutions. We have become so accustomed to the frequent changes in the Governments of Venezuela and the republics on the Isthmus that we ordinarily give them only perfunctory attention.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The demand for accommodations for August and September in this section continues. The hotels have no vacant rooms, and many people have been obliged to find quarters with private families.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 16. -- William Malcolm, ex-Secretary of the Mutual Loan and Building Association, refused to-night to make a statement as to what became of the $100,000 that he is accused of misapplying.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16. -- Attorney Charles J. Haggerty announces that the last will of Mrs. Charles L. Fair, who with her husband was killed in an automobile accident in France on Thursday, has been found in a safe-deposit vault. He refused to make Known the contents of the document.

WHEN the girl handed me a small silver filagree jewel box I expected to see some priceless gem, or at least a valuable trinket, but instead I found a half-burned cigarette with the familiar gold seal of manufacture stamped at one end -- the same brand I usually indulge in.

THE Society of American Buttonists, a remarkable society with a still more remarkable purpose, has just been organized. Its charter members are five in number, but they are men of mark in their parts of the world, even if the purpose for which they will hold annual meetings did not make them so.

THAT a letter from an ex-Cabinet official should have created almost a revolution in the methods of the German press is something that Americans will find it hard to realize, yet the fact remains that this result has followed a certain expression of views by Count von Berchem, who was Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs in the time of Prince Bismarck.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Accord to a statement made by Abram Nelson, t half brother of Mrs. Charles L. Fair, the latter's relatives have received more callers to-day than in all their existence. Mrs. Hannah Nelson, the mother, is suffering from slight prostration, and all visitors are seen by Abram Nelson, who is hustling behind the counter of his tiny grocery store just as if nothing unusual had happened.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Notwithstanding the fact that Manager McGraw was not present, the New York baseball team played and won a good game from the local nine to-day by the score of 6 to 3. The visitors were unusually strong at the bat, Brodie making a home run and Bresnahan the only three base hit in the game.

Laura Biggar was popular as an actress about ten years ago, when she was the wife of Burt Haverly, who some years later brought suit against Henry M. Bennett, the millionaire theatrical manager, accusing him of alienating his Wife's affections.

FROM various sources appeals for the adoption of the metric system in the United States have been made within the last few months. Whether these recommendations receive official sanction, or not, it is certain the question will be agitated considerably during the next year.

The friends and wife of William Leonard, a prisoner in the Tombs, are making an effort to have the District Attorney present his case to the Grand Jury. Leonard lived, with his wife, a bride of seven months, at 166 East One Hundred find Ninth Street. On the night of April 13 he, accompanied by his wife, attended a dance in the Harlem Lyceum, at One Hundred and Seventh Street and Third Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent in the London letter of your last issue made a strange mistake in saying: "The Campanile, like all Venetian buildings, was built on wooden piled driven in to the mud."

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Archie Roosevelt is saving for his sister Alice two turtles that were caught on the Sagamors Hill property yesterday, and which escaped from captivity seventeen years ago.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Laura Biggar entered Dr. Charles C. Hendrick's sanitarium at Bergen Point shortly after the death of Mr. Bennett. She is suffering from nervous prostration, and is still a patient in the institution.

THERE arrived in New York last week forty nuns who form a part of the great dispersion occasioned by the French Act of Associations. Thirty-six of the expatriated sisters, members of the Filles de la Croix at Brest, proceeded to Shreveport, La., and the other four had Fall River as their destination.

Few of the many persons who visit a bank for the purpose of making a deposit, drawing funds, or transacting other business have any idea of the large force of clerks required to attend to the routine work of the institution.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:
ASPECIAL CABLE to THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday told of English society preparing for "Cowes week" after the coronation and after that for Scotland.

Probably one of the most unique of the anthracite coal-producing and carrying companies is the Delaware and Hudson. While there have been many rumors as to change of ownership within the past few months the officials of the company maintain serene indifference to all the reports, content with the showing they are piling up for the shareholders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- A conference will be held on Monday to decide the design to be placed on the gold dollar to be coined as a souvenir of the St. Louis Exposition. The question is to be decided by ex-Gov. Francis of Missouri, J.T. Morgan, engraver of the Philadelphia mint, and Robert E. Armstrong, secretary to Secretary Shaw.

The Jewish World publishes a careful estimate of the number of Jews in Greater New York, based for the first time on the only sure statistical foundation -- the number of Jewish burials as recorded by the Board of Health. These amounted in 1901 to 7,997, and as the death rate in the most congested Jewish district is little over fifteen per thousand, this implies a population of 533,133 in the middle of 1901.

SARATOGO, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The annual polo tournament of the Saratoga Club was closed to-day when the Meadow Brook team vanquished the Westchester players by a score of 8 3/4 to 8. It was a handicap contest, the last in the competition for the Hitchcock cups, which covered a series of four games.

FROM exploring rural Westchester and Western Long Island, those New York Summer "stay-at-homes" who are taking and enjoying the out-of-the-ordinary holiday trips described in THE NEW YORK TIMES can this week turn to their profit and advantage as to relief from the conventional hum-drum "day-off" excursion, to a jaunt by boat and rail to and through States Island and New Jersey.

THE one bulwark of European and Aslatic nations which has withstood the assaults of the "American invasion" -- the newspapers -- is to be seriously threatened in at least one foreign country -- Japan. While the newspapers of London, Paris, Berlin, and other Continental centres successfully preserve their customary dullness, Japan is to have real up-to-date American ideas thrust upon her by way of New York.

The trial of Chief of Construction and Repairs to Apparatus Patrick F. Ryan was continued yesterday at Fire Headquarters. As was the case on Friday, no positive evidence was given that work done in the repair shops and charged to Commissioner Scannell and Chief Croker was for them as private individuals, and not necessary to them in the exercise of their official functions.

YES," said the gentlemanly burglar, "there is one class of men that I occasionally stumble upon in my midnight work which I prefer to avoid. An inventor is always an unknown quantity, and it is unpleasant business ransacking his house. He might be as harmless as a child, or he might prove more diabolically cruel and cranky than an escaped lunatic.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- In the yacht race here to-day Eliz, owned by R.S. Clark, son of Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark, outdistanced all competitors, but on account of the handicap was given second place, while Eli Yale, sailed by G. Benjamin White, won the race and the Merchants' Cup.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 16. -- A report to-day says:

VII. MY DEAR SISTER: I really think you should give up your Summer school work and come here at once. I know, dear, that it is important to mentally cultivate the furnace men's children during the heated term; and I know how much the Rev. Mr. Easeman needs your help, and how musical is his voice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been reading with interest your discussions of the coal strike, together with the correspondence thereon appearing In your columns. But I consider your reply to your ultra-conservative correspondent, published last Monday, very "lame" indeed.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- There have been a large number of departures from Paris this week, including those of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ogden Armour of Chicago, P.A. B. Widener and E.B. Dahlgren of Philadelphia, and Mr. and Mrs. O.H.P. Belmont, Miss Damon, and Mr. and Mrs. Samuel of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- It has been a week of unwonted calm in "the fertile, temperate, envied Isle Of Fate," as John Davidson enthusastically calls his native land in his coronation ode, and the Long Vacation has begun with the promise of more suitable weather than the London season had.

The security market continues to be governed by general conditions and influences. The week just closed has been one of sustained strength and moderate increase in the volume of transactions, with perceptible growth of commission abuse business.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- Society is talking of nothing but the fatal accident to Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair, which must clearly be attributed not to carelessness or rashness, but to a broken screw in the steering gear following on the bursting of a tire.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 16. -- In the first polo game of the season for the Point Judith Cup, Point Judith defeated Myopia, this afternoon in a match which ended strong and exciting by a score of 12 1/2 to 9. Myopia had the better of the play at first, but Point Judith by excellent team work and brilliant playing by Bob Collier and Brooks showed that it was the better team.

TO the average farmer, who cultivates less than 200 acres, a section of land seems indeed a large amount to inclose under one fence. But in the Southwest there are numerous farmers who conduct farms containing 10,000, 20,000, and even 50,000 acres, and who are now employing armies of men to gather the harvest.
KING EDWARD VII., as is well known, is much interested in all matters relating to flying ships, and especially is he interested in Santos-Dumont and his efforts.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The final match of the Long Island lawn tennis championship series was played to-day, and resulted in Stewart Waller successfully defending his title and trophy as the Eastern Long Island champion. Stewart Waller defeated Guy Phelps Dodge, the challenger, by the score of 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Secretary Shaw will deliver a speech on Tuesday a Morrisvllle, Vt., his native town, at the request of the Republican Campaign Committee of that State. The speech is expected to be devoted almost exclusively to the tariff, and to take strong ground against any general revision of rates a the present session of Congress.
STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The Height of the August season has brought many additional visitors to Stamford, and there is every indication of a long and prosperous Summer.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The doubt surrounding the relations of Henry M. Bennett, the deceased millionaire of Farmingdale, and Laura Biggar, the actress and principal devisee under his will, was increased yesterday when a casket containing the body of a child was received here.

Forty-five yachts started in the annual regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Club yesterday, an immensely large number, as the largest yachts summoned to race were those of the 36-foot class. It was a perfect day for racing, with a clear sky, a smooth sea, and a whole-Sail breeze from a point east of north.

CAPTAIN H.M. Chittenden, chief of United States Engineers for the entire Missouri River since the abolition of the Missouri River Commission, believes the career of the Missouri River as a means of transportation is at an end.

The fish market where the scaly and other denizens of the water are laid out in rows to tempt our palates is a place that offers many an interesting sight. The shapes and colors of fish are often beautiful even in such conditions, but it is the live fish and frequently just those which are never brought to market as food which surprise and delight every one who is open to impressions of beauty.

It is a curious indication of the immense extent of the interests of our people that very little popular comment is elicited by the fact that the volume of immigration pouring into the country is larger than it has ever been before, with the exception of two years1881 and 1882.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Bishop O'Gorman of Sioux Falls, S.D., presented to President Roosevelt to-day a letter from the Pope, which would indicate that the question of the removal of the friars from the Philippines as outlined during the conference of Gov. Taft and the representatives of the Roman Catholic Church at the Vatican had been settled, and in accordance with the propositions of the Administration.

THERE is at present an air of activity pervading the Botanical Gardens in Bronx Park. Under the supervision of Director Britton the entire working force is busily engaged in arranging the new exhibits, which are coming in so steadily and in such large numbers that they have almost excluded the garden's capacity.

EAST HAMPTON, Aug. 16. -- This has been a gala week at East Hampton, with its tennis tournament and hard-fought finals, its round of card parties, and dinners and luncheons and dances, and glorious days on the beach, where along the shining sand are pitched gay-colored awnings and umbrellas of every hue, from underneath which interested onlookers watch the gay scene in the water.

Janitor John H. Loughlin of the City Hall had considerable amusement at the expense of a number of friends just before the Fitzsimmons-Jefferies fight in San Francisco. The usual City Hall crowd heid animated discussions in the lobby regarding the probable winner and each man expressed a choice.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 16. -- The last week has made a very great change in the prospects for a good season at this resort Although July ended with the outlook anything but encouraging. August has come in with promise of better things for the balance of the Summer, the number of arrivals especially since last Saturday, having been very large.

Somewhat peculiar conditions exist at the present time with reference to the means for conveying information about automobiles to those who are interested but have no time or inclination to make a serious study of the subject. The difficulties are commonly underrated, probably because most people mentally associate automobiles with bicycles, and remember how easily a sufficient practical knowledge of bicycles was Acquired during the period of their introduction.

So much has been heard lately regarding the increased business done by the trust companies, and the prediction is so freely made that these corporations are fast eating into the business of the banks, and that in a few years the New York companies win lead the Clearing House banks in point of deposits, that comparison becomes interesting.
Second Lieut. Bertram P. Johnson, Twenty-fourth Infantry, is transferred from Company M to Company C.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 16. -- The local market was divided in interest to-day, the distribution of favors belng among Seaboard, Alabama Coal and Iron, and International Trust. There was a palpable effort made to prevent Seaboards from reacting, with very satisfactory effect. The issues held steadily in view of the offerings, but it was impossible to score an advance and hold it.

THE man in the red turban was the last speaker. His peroration was particularly eloquent. Up to that time the events of the meeting had had but little effect on Honoria, but his vital words were fatal to indifference, and when finally she passed out of the hall the spirit of helpfulness was strong within her.
BOSTON, Aug. 16. -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, in the next issue of The National Magazine, will have an exhaustive article on the new civil government for the Filipinos. In part, Mr. Lodge says:

So far the season at Newport has more than justified anticipations. In fact, there is very little change from year to yea. From now on there will be some very notable entertainments, and among them the vaudeville performance to be given by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, at Beaulieu, the ball of Mrs. Astor, the musicale of James J. Van Alen, and the colonial masquerade of Mrs. Fish.

OWENSBOROUGH, Ky., Aug. 16. -- The agent of the American Express Company at Fordsville was robbed of $28,000 last night under peculiar circumstances. J.W. Boatner, who shipped the money to Fordsville, is under arrest at Irvington, and J.C. Schlitzbaum, the agent of the company, is being held at Falls of Rough.

A case has been decided in St. Louis, and a physician who was made defendant was mulcted in a substantial fine for relieving his feelings when exasperated beyond toleration by the vagaries of the telephone and pouring into it a stream of picturesque and variegated profanity. His defense was that he was not swearing at the operators, but at the system.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- The Bankers' Trust and Investment Company passed into the Sheriff's hands to-day as the result of an attachment for $55,000 damages brought against the concern by the Paxton Electric Light Company of Paxton, Ill. The President, A.F. Norval, disappeared about ten days ago and J.B. Hessenius, the Second Vice President, said that if he knew where Norval was he would have him arrested for embezzlement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Definite information was received at the Navy Department to-day from Commander Nickels of the Topeka, dated Porto Cabello, which corrected the misapprehension which arose out of the garbled dispatch received Thursday last from which the department assumed and announced that Porto Cabello had fallen into the hands of the revolutionists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- John Bright, ridden by Winkfield and backed from 7 to 1 to 6 to 1 at post time, won the rich Hariem stakes in easy fashion, with Aladdin second and McChesney third. The stake was the feature of the closing day of the Harlem meeting, and drew out a field of ten of the best horses in the West, as the prize to the winner, was worth $4,835.

The theatres and roof gardens that have remained open this Summer soon will end their season, and managers are preparing, with pleasurable emotions, to cast up the totals at the box office. The three months of Summer will have been, to the most of them, almost as profitable as the Winter term, thus disproving the theatrical adage that all the profits of a house must be gathered in forty weeks of the year.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- Prof. Sartorius von Waltershausen of Strasburg University, one of the leading German authorities on political, economy, will publish in the next issue of the Zeitschrift fur Socialwissenschaft a long article, entitled "The United States and Middle Europe."

THE lovers of light-harness sport have looked long for something like a sensational performer aside from the pacers. At last they have been rewarded, for in the blind trotter Rythmic there has appeared a harness race horse who gives every promise of upsetting all the traditions of the trotting turf and one who, if he lives up to the expectations of his trainer, will crowd Cresceus close for the championship honors.

NEW YORK is to have a "Grand Boulevard and Concourse," planned to be one of the most magnificent driveways in the world. Bids will be opened by President Haffen of the Borough of the Bronx on Wednesday of this week and the successful bidder must begin operations at once.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I venture to Invite your attention to the unjust and inequitable rulings of the Secretary of the Treasury in the two following matters:

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- Some difference of opinion has been noted in the City this week in regard to the recent developments in American securities, but the most reasonable is that the outlook in the United States is distinctly good, while the veriest pessimists predict another seven or eight months of good times in America.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 16. -- This great Mecca of the pleasure seekers never entertained a greater multitude of visitors than is now quartered within its precincts, crowding the hotels and boarding houses and the amusement places.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit a constant reader and admirer of THE TIMES to thank you for the editorial paragraph this morning on automobiles, suggested by the Fair accident.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of this gentleman, who had nearly filled his hundred years, removes one of the most delightful and most picturesque old men of the century, and everyone who has known Peter Cooper, Mr. Gladstone, the Hon. Mr. Hewitt, and Parke Godwin, know how delightful an old man can be.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial of Thursday, Aug. 14, permit me to explain to your readers why a settlement was effected between the management of the Elevated Railroad and its engineers, while the operators of the anthracite coal mines remain stubborn, resisting all overtures toward a settlement of the strike.

THE Navy Department has undertaken to make extensive improvements of the coast defenses of the United States entirely separate from and independent of the army, and it is believed that with the utilization of material already available, a large amount of work can be done with slight additional expense.

A GIANT automobile, with accommodations for a number of "spellbinders," a male quartet, and a brass band, will tour the State of Minnesota during the approaching State campaign. It has been drafted into service by the State Central Committee of the Prohibition Party.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 16. -- The habeas corpus case of ex-Insurance Commissioner William H. Hahn, wanted in New York State on the charge of embezzlement from the Manhattan insurance Company, was finished this afternoon. L.C. Mengert, in opening his argument for the defense, referred to the attempt to take Mr. Hahn to New York as a blackmailing scheme, declaring that the Speaker of the Assembly of New York had no power to sign the requisition.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 16. -- ?The strike in the anthracite region is as firm as the everlasting hills. Confidence and quiet reign supreme."
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The reception to Rear Admiral Schley and the annual concert were the principal events of this week at the Catholic Summer School at Cliff Haven.

By a sort of eminent domain billions of small, red ants -- hymenopterous; genus Linnaen -- have taken possession of New Orleans. The quaint, historic City of the Gulf is overrun with countless numbers of the pests.

WHEN the next annual statistics of the consumption of cigars and cigarettes in New York are made up there are likely to be some figures that will cause crusaders against the use of the weed to either put forth redoubled efforts or give up the fight entirely.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- Emperor William's telegraphic offer to the Regent of Bavaria, Prince Luitpold, to donate $25,000 from his private purse for buying works of art, has caused a political commotion of extraordinary proportions. It is treated as a constitutional question involving the right of the Emperor to intervene in local questions of the Confederated States.
Cycling on the city streets, with a chance to speed a short distance will have to await the pleasure of the contractors engaged in excavating for the rapid transit tunnel.

IT WAS lonesome. I tried to keep busy and forget it, but every time I stood in the station house door, an listened to that big freight engine just snortin its way up grade, an' knew wouldn't see Matt again for days, couldn't help feelin' it. I was young then, an' hadn't much sense, an' I'd stand there as long as I could hear a sound of the train.

Between sips the worthy beer-drinking Bavarian is rapping out an oath on the meddlesome Kaiser for his officiousness in reproving the House of Representatives of Bavaria for refusing a small appropriation to buy works of art. The voters in the German Kingdom next largest to Prussia are touchy folks.
A Brooklyn man, with a wife who has her own way about doing things, catches her now and then.

GREAT natural cataclysms are always preceded by certain warnings and premonitory symptoms. At the same time, what might be regarded as such warning's have occurred in times past without being followed by disaster. Should any unprecedented cataclysm occur in the immediate future, however, the historian would infallibly point to the extraordinary succession of events which has preceded it.

IX. I WAS glad to read in the papers the other day that the remains of the Ark had been discovered in a fine state of preservation up in Alaska," said the Idiot. "It's a nice thing to have these fine old curios restored to us, and I hope the time will come when New York or some other big American city will be provided with a museum in which they may be properly displayed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The discussion of the ship subsidy question and the present great steamship combine are two of many facts which may be cited to show that the United States as a Nation is becoming more and more interested in the carrying trade of the great commercial nations.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Skillful, the two-year-old colt by Mirthful-Skadi, purchased by Charles Ellison at the sale of the Clarence H. Mackay horses on Tuesday last, upset all calculations by wining the $10,000 United States Hotel Stakes from a first-class field this afternoon. Skillful was a maiden up to the time of his victory, and so little was his chance considered that he was at 20 to 1 in the betting.

CRUELTY thy name is woman. I know there are many people who will take exception to that statement, but I am in a position to prove everything I say, and the opinion of a member of my family should be heard with consideration.

The National event of the lawn tennis season is at hand. On Tuesday the twenty-seoond annual tournament for the National championship title in the singles and the doubles will begin on the turf courts of the Casino at Newport. This is the real Mecca of all lovers of lawn tennis, and this year the attendance at the shrine promises to be greater than for many years past.
MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Aug. 16. -- Mrs. William McAleer and her daughters, Misses B.A. and M.J. McAleer, are at the Montanesca once more. Mr. McAleer is a Congressman from New Jersey.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The pressure for money was somewhat relaxed to-day, dividends helping the market. Discounts hardened.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 16. -- The Summer hotels in this vicinity are breaking all records for business, despite the backwardness of the weather. This is all due, no doubt, to the activity in army and navy circles. New London is the centre of a great military district, which during the coming army and navy manoeuvres will be the centre for all movements of either branch of the service.

THE American invasion of European markets, which is being discussed with apprehension in Continental trade centres, is being duplicated in another quarter, in Northwestern Canada, where an American agricultural movement has started, and has already acquired enough momentum to justify the term invasion.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius N. Bliss, who spend the Summer at Oceanic, where they are the owners of a handsome country seat, have left there for the White Mountains, to be absent the remainder of the month. They expect to return to Oceanic in September.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Please allow me space in your columns which to make answer to your editorial laste Wednesday on trades unions. I will give some, of the facts as many of us-here see them; the reader may make his own deductions.

The Festival of St. Rocco di Ruoti Dimos, a Neapolitan saint of great fame about the provinces of Conserta and Baselicata, Italy, was celebrated enthusiastically by Italians of the lower east side last night. The principal celebration occurred in the neighborhood of East Houston Street and Mott Street and was under the auspices of the Saint Rocco Society of this city.
Not one single failure to cure dyspepsia in any of its forms has been reported since the new vegetable cure MI-O-NA was found and it has been tested in thousands of cases.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- "There is no man of my acquaintance," said a newspaper correspondent in discussing the death of the late Senator McMillan, "by whose death I would have suffered a greater personal loss than by that of Senator McMillan. In twenty years' acquaintance with public men I can recall no one whose life I consider more of a pattern than his.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 16. -- The Kebo Valley Club is the social Mecca. The well-known resort of the Summer residents has never been so popular as during the present season. The dinner dance to-night eclipsed that of last week, which exceeded in attendance any club affair given in the past.
CAREFULLY locked away in one of the fire-proof safes of the New Jersey Historical Society there now are two valuable documents that tell of the early colonization of the State.

HAVANA, Aug. 16. -- La Discusion, discussing the increased customs duties voted by the Senate, says they serve three purposes -- to increase the revenue, to put Cuba in a better position to negotiate a commercial treaty with the United States, and to protect local industries.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- The coffins containing the bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair arrived in Paris at 4 o'clock this afternoon and were placed in the vault of the Church of the Madeleine, in the presence of a representative of the United States Consulate, Mr. Ellis. manager of the Hotel Ritz; Brotey, Mr. Fair's chauffeur, and Mrs. Fair's maid.

WORK was begun last week on preparing the "bed" for the new United States battleship which is to be built at the New York Navy Yard as a test of the question, "Where can a battleship be built most economically and expeditiously -- at a Government navy yard or under contract?"

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- In the daredevil style of riding that made Gretna Green a famous speeding spot for eloping couples bent upon hasty marriage, the younger fashionable set this afternoon raced over the Southampton plains. The race in which they competed was a part of the annual pony games.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The Autumn theatrical season is already beginning, and between now and October there will be a dozen or more important first nights.

MOUNTAIN LAKE PARK, Md., Aug. 16. -- Several thousand persons greeted Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, who delivered an address to-day before the Chautauqua Assembly on "Labor and Capital -- the Workman's Side of the Story." President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers of America, who was also to have spoken, was unable to be present.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 16. -- A net score of 79 made by Dudley H. Barrows won first honors for the Golf Committee Cup on the Hillside Tennis and Golf Club course this afternoon. F.G. Talmadge and Robert Abbott won second and third honors, respectively. The scores :

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The field day for St. Joseph's Catholic Church was a great success, the attendance being very large and the programme containing many novel features, including feats with automobiles.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 16. -- The season is now fully at its height and, in local parlance, to-morrow will be "one of the big Sundays of the Summer of 1902." The arrivals have during the past few days greatly outnumbered the departures, and the aggregation of visitors, both season and transient, far exceeds that of any previous August, which is always the biggest and most prosperous month in Saratoga.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 16. -- The golf tournament at the Ekwanok Country Club was concluded to-day with match play for the four cups, and an interesting handicap event in which twenty-four players participated. The principal event or the day was the match between former champion Walter J. Travis of Garden City and Charles B. Cory of Wollaston, Mass., of the Wollaston Golf Club, for the President's Cup.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There would seem to be some further explanation necessary in regard to the rule of certification and appointments under the civil service law. Your correspondent, who signs himself "Thirty-eight," asks whether those who passed the examinations for the Tenement House Department but were passed over when the appointments ware made, can yet hope for appointment.

The Tenth Pennsylvania Regiment proposes to erect in Pittsburg a monument to Col. Alexander Leroy Hawkins, who lost his life at the battle of Malolos in the Philippines. Col. Hawkins was a veteran of the civil war, and saw a good deal of service under Gen. Merritt at Manilla before the final battle.

CHINCH bugs, those populous, devastating, injurious insects which during the past four or five years have caused losses of millions of dollars to American farmers, have at last lost their prestige. The damage to be feared from them is no longer great.

DETROIT, Aug. 16. -- Frank C. Andrews, formerly Vice President of the wrecked City Savings Bank, this afternoon was found guilty of misapplying the funds of that institution after a trial that lasted four weeks. His attorney, Mr. Kirchner, at once notified the court that an appeal would be taken to the Supreme Court, and a stay of proceedings for sixty days was granted.
Prof. SARTORIUS vou WALTERSHAUSEN has hit on the germ of a progressive idea of protection against the invasion of Middle European markets by the United States.

After a pursuit of more than a mile and a half Michael Ryan, giving his address as 300 West Houston Street, was arrested last night on a charge of highway robbery. When Policeman John Murphy, who made the arrest, finally took his prisoner into the Leonard Street Station both were ready to drop from exhaustion.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 17. -- The Cincinnati team to-day defeated the Pittsburgs for the first time this season. It was probably the best played game seen here this year, not an error being made. The Cincinnati team batted out a victory. Poole, the ex-Pittsburg pitcher, winning from his old comrades.

NEW ROCHELLE, Aug. 17. -- James Pot- ter, a builder, of City Island, was probably fatally injured in Neptune Park here this evening by being impaled on the shaft of a surrey. The victim, who is thirty-five years-old, was riding a bicycle down a rather steep hill, when he lost control of his machine.
The sculptor Daniel C. French has finished his equestrian portrait of Gen. "Fighting Joe" Hooker at his Summer studio near Stockbridge, Mass.

SHERIDAN, Wyoming, Aug. 17. -- Word received to-night from the Town of Buffalo, Wyoming, reports the place as almost deserted, because of the flocking of the miners and prospectors to the Big Horn Mountains, where the fabulously wealthy and long-lost Cabin Gold Mine has been rediscovered.

From her father's house and from the midst of her friends gathered to celebrate her engagement to another man, Joseph Gedealia, a Turk, tried last night with the aid of six of his friends to carry off Sara Lifshitz, dark and pretty and only nineteen. This is the story of the new Lochinvar -- who came out of the East.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- A soldier named Tracey, attached to the Garrison at Fort Gabriel, Dutch Island, opened fire on Policemen Wright and Westlake during an altercation to-day, probably mortally wounding Westlake and giving Wright a scalp wound.

Two days hence Mr. J.P. Morgan will be home, his extended vacation over. He returns with health. And in financial quarters where it is not an affectation to profess knowledge of his disposition and purposes it is accounted certain that soon following his appearance in Wall Stret market broadening will develop.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 17. -- Clorita, bay filly, four years old, by Loyalist-Lythe, has teen purchased from W.H. May by Eastern men for $5;000. She is now at Saratoga. A message from May's son announces the sale, but does not give the name of the purchaser.

The bicycle races at Vailsburg yesterday were witnessed by a crowd of about 6,000. The feature of the day was the five mile professional handicap, the winner being Floyd MacFarland, who was on the scratch mark. There were thirty-four riders in the race, and MacFarland, was not able to overtake the long mark men until more than four miles of the distance was covered.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- By declining to wit- ness the naval review, says the Paris cor- respondent of The Times, the Boer Generals have almost become reinstated in favor with some of their French friends. Tele- grams from the correspondents of some Paris papers are full of sarcastic comment, the correspondents using such phrases as "Chamberlain's discomfiture," "Fischer's clever manoeuvre," "An additional defeat of British amour propre."

F.C. Moore, Chairman of the Conference Committee named by the National Board of Fire Underwriters and seven other prominent insurance bodies to formulate a uniform set of policy clauses and forms for use throughout the United States, has issued his report embodying the work of the committee, which held a number of protracted sessions in December, January, and April.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The Boer Generals, Botha, De Wet, and De la Rey, who reached here on Saturday from South Afri- ca, left London at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning for Cowes, Isle of Wight, to see King Edward on board the royal yacht Victoria and Albert.

Many of the trotting turfmen who came to New York last week with the Grand Circuit harness performers visited the Speedway yesterday, and through the morning the famous drive was crowded with horsemen and horses. As a result of the big turnout, for which the fine weather conditions were responsible, there was more good racing than has been seen at any other time this Summer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- New York's baseball players won two games here to-day from Selee's men, taking three straight from Chicago as a starter on their Western trip. They won the first game by 3 to 2 mainly through the poor base running and fielding of the local players. By bunching their hits in the sixth inning the visitors won the second game, 3 to 1.

For a time yesterday Coney Island was not certain whether it was real good or downright wicked. Rumors that Capt. Knipe had added three brand-new detectives to his force, and intended to wind up the remainder of the season with a period of strenuous morality and law-abiding observance of the Sunday regulations, had occasioned a feeling of disquiet in the early hours.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17. -- The St. Louis and Brooklyn baseball teams played eighteen iInnings to a tie this afternoon. It was the longest professional game ever played in St. Louis. Umpire Brown deemed it too darK to continue after the players had battled for three and a half hours, and called the contest.

ALBANY, Aug. 17. -- The Twenty-seventh Congressional District of the State is in a ferment just now. It is caused by the act- ive canvass among the Republicans who want office. Utica is the central point, and from it the political heat radiates with more or less intensity.

Minister SQUIERS, in- reporting on the effect of the advance in the Cuban tariff on imports to meet the interest and sinking fund of the proposed loan, if authorized, gives the present tariff rates on a number of articles. These show plainly enough the very great advantages that Cuba could offer to us in exchange for a reduction of duties on sugar and tobacco in our markets.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17. -- President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers of America arrived here at noon to-day, on his way to Spring Valley, Ill. While in the West Mr. Mitchell will go to Chicago to confer with leaders of the miners of Illinois. He expects to return to Wilkesbarre Wednesday.

New York Italians observed yesterday the feast of San Donato di Anletta, the saint who, centuries ago, remedied deformities of the body and cured fits, paralysis, and similar afflictions. In the large and beautifully decorated archway in front of 272 Mott Street, the statue representing St. Rocco di Ruoti Dimos, whose festival was celebrated Saturday, was supplanted by an effigy of San Donato.

Henry Ferrara yesterday fought a duel with his successful suitor, Giuseppe Sparafore, in Mott Street near Broome. Each of the men fired five shots from his revolver, but neither of the duelists was wounded. Joseph Notaro, eighteen years old, a bootblack, a bystander, was brought down with a bullet wound in his leg.

JAMESPORT, L.I., Aug. 17. -- A recep- tion was last night tendered to Hugh Mc- Laughlin and his wife of Brooklyn at the Great Peconic Bay House, where Mr. and Mrs. McLaughlin are spending the Sum- mer. The reception is an annual affair, given in honor of Mrs. McLaughlin's birth- day anniversary.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 17. -- David T. Gillmer, who was Mayor of this city about twenty years ago, killed himself this morning by shooting himself over the right eye with a .32-calibre revolver. Mr. Gillmer was sixty years of age. He had not yet dressed this morning, and was alone in his room. His sons heard a shot, and running to their father's room, found him dying.

The relation of the militia to the coal miners caused an excited discussion at the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday. The matter was brought up by Delegate Quinlan of the Pipe Caulkers' Union, who said he had been informed that there is a regiment of militia in Pennsylvania composed entirely of members of the United Mine Workers.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 17. -- Among the arrivals on the St. Louis at New York to-day was Major John Biddle Porter of the Judge Advocate's Depart- ment, who accompanied Judge Taft to Rome. Major Porter said:

CHATHAM, Mass., Aug. 17. -- At Camp Nauset the members of the American Canoe Association spent the day in enjoyment or camp life. The sailing canoe race for the Eastern Division trophy, postponed yesterday, was sailed to-day, Herman D. Murphy of the Winchester Club being the winner.
At two widely separated points in the political field the Republican Party is this year to have its stamina and its self-respect severely tested.

Favored by perfect weather the Harlem River oarsmen swarmed to the different boathouses yesterday and took full advantage of the pleasant conditions, and the forenoon was devoted to practice by the racing crews, who have but two weeks left for training, before the races of Labor Day. The oarsmen who are fond of barge rowing started for Point View, Donnelly's, and Willets Point, on the Sound, while a few rowed up and down the river.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- The Boerse last week had an irregular tendency. The week opened with the appearance of the semiannual statement of the Deutsch Genossenschafts Bank, admitting heavy losses through unfortunate industrial ventures, and calling for a stockholders' meeting to reduce the capital of the bank by 6,000,000 marks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The Navy De- partment is watching with interest the work of other countries in experiment- ing with submarine boats and is endeavor- ing to equip the Navy with means of de- fense against this new feature in warfare, fare.

Unquestionably The Manufacturers' Record of Baltimore is the most adroit and probably the most efficient critic of the plans of the Southern Education Board. We had occasion the other day to refer to what we considered some of the mistaken notions of those who comment unfavorably on the work and purpose of the board.

The latest addition to New York's building's for charitable uses is the one now nearing completion at Woody Crest Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-second Street, just beyond Central Bridge, which has been built by the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless.

The surrender of Tien-Tsin to the Chinese is an act of tardy justice and pacification. It has been delayed chiefly by the friction between the trading powers, which desire to do the largest possible amount of peaceable business with China, and the military powers, which desire to keep China intimidated, with a view to the ultimate partition of the empire into " spheres " of exclusive influence and concessions.

John Lagerquist, forty-four years of age, of 132 Huron Street, Greenpoint, was rescued from drowning in the East River yesterday morning by Policeman John Farrell of the Greenpoint Avenue Station. Lagerquist was bathing in the river off Java Street and his cries for help when he had cramps attracted the attention of the passengers on the ferryboat Greenpoint.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been a peculiar characteristic of the American conception of things to consider an offer of charity to a self-respecting class of people as an impudence on the one hand and as a very suspicious act on the other. The offer of charity to inventors as a class savors of many other things than charity.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Aug. 17. -- The West Verginia Central Railroad is urging the immediate delivery of 1,000 steel hoppers, ordered some time ago, for their coal trade. Thirteen of these cars arrived yesterday, and others will be hurried to completion by the contractors.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- St. Mary's Catholic Church observed its golden jubilee anniversary, to-day with special services, in which a large number of the dignitaries of the Roman Catholic Church participated. The occasion was made especially interesting by the presence of Cardinal Gibbons, Bishops of five other dioceses of the country, and the Right Rev. Thomas J. Conaty, D.D., rector of the Catholic University at Washington.

ROME, Aug. 17. -- The Pope is in such good health that it was not thought necessary to suspend the Saturday audiences, as has hitherto been the custom, in order to give the Pontiff strength for a fatiguing ceremony such as the great Name Day reception of to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 17. -- Early last week, and almost coincident with the meeting of the Republican State Central Committee at the Allyn House here, ex-Speaker John H. Perry of Fairfield with- drew as a candidate for the nomination for Governor. Among the conservative element of the party the nomination of Mr. Perry for the first place on the ticket would have been looked upon as ideal.

Are the working classes becoming extravagant? In recent years the average wage has immensely increased, and its purchasing power is greater now than, say, ten years ago, but is any substantial portion put by for the proverbial rainy day? Light on this subject is shed by the report of the Chief Registrar of Friendly Societies which has just been issued.

-- Owners and managers of trolley railways are warned by The Electrical World and Engineer that the only way to avoid legislative interference with their business that will seriously hamper its conduct is to make voluntarily and at once some changes in their plant and methods of operation as will put an end to the ever-lengthening series of ghastly accidents on their lines.

Neither here nor abroad has the significance of the great crops of the year been fully appreciated. The Government report of Aug. 10 indicates a yield of 2,561,490,000 bushels of corn. This is an increase of more than 1,000,000,000 bushels over the actual yield of 1901. The indicated wheat crop is 646,611,000, a decrease of 102,849,218 bushels from the record crop of 1901.

Borough President Cantor of Manhattan has sent to Mayor Low his quarterly report, together with reports from the various bureaus of his department, covering in detail what has been done toward the improvement of the Borough of Manhattan stince the new charter went into effect on Jan. 1.

The street railway companies of Manhattan owe the city about $1,250,000 for repaving the streets in and about the tracks of the various roads. Deputy Controller Stevenson is arranging for a concerted movement on the part of all city officials having to do with this matter to compel the railroad companies to settle.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18 -- Society has had a brilliant and lively day. It has been the gayest of the season. It was notable chiefly for the long recital of Mme. Blauvelt. The Casino, where the recital took place, was crowded with guests. Mme, Blauvelt was in magnificent voice and sang with such inspiring effect that the audience was completely carried away with enthusiasm.

At about 7:30 last night a young man and a young woman entered the store in West Eighth Street, Coney Island, where the offices of several New York newspapers are situated, and told the reporters who were present that they wished to be married. They gave their names as George W. Snow, twenty-eight years old, of 128 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, and Louise Purvis, eighteen years old, of 430 DeanStreet, the same borough.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 18 -- The Cudahys have finally accepted the terms of the Packers' Trust and have agreed to sell their plants, located at South Omaha, Cudahy, Wis.; Chicago, and other places, to the combination. An Omaha afternoon paper to-day says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the question of giving taxpaying women the right to vote upon all measures pertaining to the spending of the revenue is likely to come up before the next Legislature, it may be well to call the attention of the public to the issues involved. The matter is not nearly so simple as it looks.

CHATHAM, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The Grand Trunk Boat Club of Montreal vanquished the Americans after a great struggle in the war canoe race, the leading event of to-day's programme of the American Canoe Association at Pleasant Bay. The race was for the championship of America, and the positions at the finish were: Grand Trunk first, Medford Boat Club second, and Wabewawa of New London third.

Aubrey Boucicault was engaged yesterday by W.N. Lawrence as leading man for "Hearts Aflame," which opens at the Bijou Sept. 8. He will play the part of Paul Chateris. Mr. Lawrence has had some difficulty in finding a man capable of filling the part, and only at the last moment secured Mr. Boucicault.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- A by-election for a successor to William Johnston, Conservative Member of Parliament for the South Division of Belfast, who died on July 17, resulted yesterday in the election of Thomas Sloan, the nominee of the Protestant Association, by a majority of 826 votes over those cast for Charles W. Dunbar Buller, the Unionist candidate.

WILLIAM D. WANN, sixty-six years of age, a retired hotel proprietor and a member of the Democratic and Knickerbocker Athletic Clubs, died in Roosevelt Hospital last evening after an operation, for spinal disease. On the 9th inst. he was taken to the hospital from his residence at 27 East Forty-sixth Street.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Frank Farrell's horse The Musketeer broke a world's record in the second race at Saratoga to-day. He ran the seven furlongs in 1:25 flat. In 1894 at Coney Island Clifford established the old record at the distance on a circular track, 1:25 2-5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The above is the thought suggested to my mind by the scenes daily enacted at the Manhattan end of the bridge at the homecoming hour. It is humiliating to see the supposedly refined men of our beautiful Brooklyn, by whom we expect gallantry or at least common civility exhibited, make a grand rush past the officers and far up the driveway to meet their respective cars.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A prospect highly disagreeable to the enemies of Gen. Miles has been opened by the civil war veterans, who are to hold their encampment here next month.

The funeral of the Rev. Father Martin Carroll, the pastor of the Church of St. Vincent de Paul in North Sixth Street, Wllliamsburg, was conducted yesterday morning, and it was the largest in that section of Brooklyn in many years. Father Carroll died on Wednesday last of injuries sustained in a trolley accident in Saratoga.

For the purpose of making some satisfactory arrangement whereby Park Commissioner Eustis could allot sites in Macombs Dam Park for the Nassau, Harlem, Wyanoke, Metropolitan, Crescent, and Bohemian Boat Clubs, and move them without serious inconvenience, a meeting of oarsmen was held last night at Huber's Hotel.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- New York's baseball players won their fourth successive game from the Chicago team to-day, scoring five runs off Taylor, while Mathewson held the locals down to four scattered hits and shut them off from getting a single tally.

A well-dressed man about fifty years of age committed suicide last night by leaping from the ferry boat Oswego, while making the trip between the foot of West Forty-second Street and Weehawken. As soon as the cry of "man overboard" was given the boat was stopped. For five minutes it remained near the spot, but no trace of the man was seen.

Fire Chief Edward F. Croker caused a sensation in the department yesterday by suddenly appearing at his office at Headquarters in East Sixty-seventh Street, while everybody supposed he was spending his vacation time quietly at Good Ground, L.I.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 18 -- Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, to-night made arrangements here to sail for Europe Wednesday.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 18 -- George A. Whitney, Secretary of the Western Oil Men's Exchange and local homesteading agent for the Canadian Government, is colonizing the Pennsylvania strikers and expects to take from 5,000 upward of them to Canada. Whitney said to-day:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Representative Eddy of Minnesota, who has just returned to Washington from an extended trip through the Northwestern States, said today:

BREST, Aug. 18 -- The closing by the authorities to-day of the sisters' schools at Ploudaniel, Folgoet, and St. Meen, the last villages in Brittany where unauthorized schools were still open, met with determined resistance. The inhabitants were on guard throughout the night, and the toesin was sounded when the approach of the gendarmes and troops was signaled, at 9 o'clock in the morning.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 18 -- In the First Presbyterian Church of this city yesterday there was great excitement when the Rev. W.I. Sweet of Everett, Mass., in his excitement Incident to preaching a stirring sermon, did about $100 worth of damage.
NEWPORT, Aug. 18 -- Miss C. Ogden Jones gave her usual Monday afternoon reception and musicale at her cottage, on Ochre Point.

First Baseman Harry O'Hagan, the newly appointed player manager of the Rochester Eastern League Baseball Club, made a sensational triple play, unassisted, at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. It was in one of the early innings of the opening game of the Rochester-Jersey City series, which was won by the visitors with the score of 10 to 6.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 18 -- Queen Titania, the Ruler of Fairy Land, who is to be the guest of honor at the twelfth annual baby parade to-morrow afternoon, reached Asbury Park to-day and was accorded a reception worthy of her position. This evening a court ball was given in her honor at the Coleman House, when the keys of the resort were turned over to her by Harold B. Ayres, President of the Carnival Association.
Chairman George M. Van Hoesen of the Tammany Hall General Committee, when asked last evening about the political condition of Tammany Hall and as to the leadership of the organization, said:

In a recent talk to the boys of an industrial school in which he is much interested, Mr. JOHN W. GATES gave utterance to the following extraordinary bit of practical business advice: "MARSHALL FIELD once told me that he always tried to be right 51 per cent, of the time. There's a lot in that, young men.

The retirement of Charles M. Schwab from the Presidency of the United States Steel Corporation is now commonly accepted as determined upon, notwithstanding recent official denials and present reluctance in official quarters to confirm the report.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The Orange County Hunt is making great preparations for its coming season, when hunting will be conducted on a larger scale than ever before attempted here. E.S. Craven, the new master of hounds, for a month or two past has been domiciled on the Richardson farm, where the kennels are located, and has had under his daily supervision two packs of Irish fox hounds.

Of the many dramatic incidents in the long Irish struggle for freedom few are as characteristic as that of the uprising under Robert Emmet, which was the subject of a play by Mr. Brandon Tynan, produced last night at the Fourteenth Street Theatre, in which the author took the leading part.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 -- Rain stopped the Velodrome races here to-night at the time when the final quarter-mile National amateur championship was to be run. Marcus L. Hurley won the first semifinal, E.F. Root of Boston won the second, "Teddy" Billington of Vailsburg the third, and Oscar Diggs of Hartford the fourth.
VIENNA, Aug. 18 -- Dr. Leopold Schenck, author of "The Determination of Sex," died to-day at Schwanberg, Styria.

Mr. CANTOR'S quarterly report is extremely creditable to its author. In particular, it is signalized, among reports of like character, by the desire and capacity it shows on the part of its author to take large and long views in the matter of public improvements, especially in those which concern the aspect of the city, as well as its healthfulness and convenience.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Money was in good request to-day, the rates were stiff, and supplies were small. Discounts showed a hardening tendency, being affected by the stringency of the New York market. The supply of American bills offered is increasing.

The most interesting and the most important development disclosed in Wall Street yesterday showed in the break in the sterling exchange market. Under curiously inspired manipulation exchange rates a fortnight ago were jacked up so as to make it appear that Europe was intent upon drawing gold from here on a large scale; and some exports were made -- with some "engagements" made with hurrahs conceled in quiet.

A fifty-five-foot timber bridge over the sidewalk in front of the excavation for a twelve-story million-dollar hotel at 127 to 135 West Forty-third Street caved in at 7:30 o'clock last evening, breaking a sixinch water main and a four-inch gas main, letting loose enough water to fill the excavation.

In the absence of the Surrogates yesterday. Jay Candler of 48 Wall Street, attorneys for Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, applied to Justice Giegrerich of the Supreme Court for authority to examine a private safe of Charles Fair in the vault of the New York Stock Exchange Building Company for any will of the Victim of the automobile accident in France, in which his wife also was killed.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Late yesterday afternoon the Boer Generals Botha, De Wet, and De la Rey left their hotel and proceeded to the docks to embark on the steamer Batavler, bound for Rotterdam. In spite of the secrecy of their movements a large crowd awaited the Generals and cheered the departing visitors.

The committee, consisting of Nathan Bijur, Louis Marshall, W.H. Baldwin, Jr., Thomas M. Mulry, and Edward B. Whitney, appointed by Mayor Low to investigate the trouble around R. Hoe Co.'s factory, on Grand Street, at the time of the funeral of the Rabbi Joseph, met yesterday morning and listened to several witnesses who tried to explain the affair.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 14 -- Midsummer though it is within the tropics, with the sun almost overhead, the social season is far from being dead. In fact, in this Summer land the Summers are far cooler than in the so-called Summer resorts of the States, save only Maine and some of the mountain resorts.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The Shah of Persia, Muzaffar-ed-din, and his suite, who arrived at Dover yesterday and stopped at the Lord Warden Hotel, reached London to-day and took up their residence at Marlborougrh House as guests of King Edward.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The Times's correspondent at Hongkong says that the Chinese have not been observing the terms of the convention of 1885. In spite of the fact that the British Foreign Office declares that it has not received Consular information on the subject, the opium trade has been completely stopped at Canton and Swatow for several months.

The programme for the harness racing meeting of the Empire City Trotting Association, to be held on the Empire City track through the week of Sept. 15-19, has been announced by Secretary Horace Wilson, with a total of $45,000 offered in stakes and purses. The premiums will range in value from $5,000 to $1,000.

The Australian M.P. who recently boasted of royal lineage must now recognize that the statement is one of those things which are better left unsaid. After many years Sir William Harcourt's reference to his descent from the Plantagenets is still remembered aginst him. Kings as ancestors are, indeed, almost as common as blackberries.

Trading on the curb yesterday was quite broad, but somewhat irregular and weak Quite a number declines, for the most part fractionl, were recorded. A few stocks, advanced considerably, with Manhattan Tuansit and Seaboard Air Line as the features. Otis Elevator common advanced 1 1/4 points on trading in 400 shares and closed quite strong.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Gov. Odell, accompanied by Mrs. Odell and his private secretary, James G. Graham, arrived in Clayton this afternoon at 5 o'clock from Albany. When the Governor had alighted he was met by Ira Sharpe of Lowville, Chairman of the Educative Committee of the Grangers' Association: George A. Fuller, another member of the committee, and Howard S. Folger, general manager of the Thousand Island Steamboat Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- The local stock market was quite active, but it was kept within circumiscribed bounds, in that nearly 90 per cent. of the full day's trading was five stocks -- Philadelphia Company. Cambria, Steel, Marsden Consolidated Lake Superior, and Philadelphia Electric Company.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 18 -- The Superior Court in general term to-day declared the Rogers Law unconstitutional. This is the law which extended all the street railway franchises to a uniform date of 1946, or fifty years from the passage of the act. The suit was brought by attorney Theodore Horstman for a taxpayer.

DENVER, Aug. 18 -- Two important features to-day in the fight for control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company were the rejection by the Osgood faction of a proffer of compromise from the Gates faction and the filing of the answer to the Gates suit for an injunction against the officers in the Federal Court.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 18 -- New York exchange to-day was 10 cents discount; time and call loans, 4 to 5 per cent. There were few features, of interest in the market today. Box Board showed, some tendency to run off at the opening, but the buying on the decline seemed to be fairly good, although organized support seems still to be lacking.

NESQUEHONING, Penn., Aug. 18 -- In a clash between strikers and deputies here to-night Patrick Sharp, a striker, of Lansford, was shot and killed almost instantly by a deputy. The shooting caused considerable excitement for a time, but order was soon restored without any other persons being injured and the town is now quiet.

No career in American industrial life has been more spectacular than that of Charles M. Schwab. Born amid very humble surroundings and self-educated, he was at the age of thirty-nine elected President of the largest corporation in the world -- the United States Steel Corporation -- at a salary generally understood to be $1,000,000 a year.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 18 -- The will of the late Senator James McMilian disposing of an estate variously estimated at from $6,000,000 to $10,000,000 was filed for probate to-day. It contains the following public bequests:

The arrival of the Duchess of Marlborough and Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., on the Kronprinz Wilhelm, this afternoon, will be the one event in town, which will interest society. The entire party will go direct to Newport. Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., will visit for a time her sister, Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18 -- It was announced at Baltimore and Ohio headquarters to-day that an order would be placed within a few days for 100 additional locomotives, for delivery next Spring. With this new order for locomotives, the company will have placed orders for 254 locomotives, 4,000 steel hoppers and gondolas, 1,300 box cars, 700 flat cars, 50 passenger coaches, 24 baggage and mail cars, 3 dining, and 2 parlor and dining cars.

Randolph Guggenheimer and Isaac Untermyer have purchased from the Atlantic Realty Company the Hudson apartment house, at the southeast corner of Ninety-fifth Street and Riverside Drive, giving in part payment the property 66 New Bowery.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 18 -- The local market to-day was distinguished by the pronounced strength of Seaboards and of International Trust. There was good buying of the former under the impression that developments in the railway situation of the South are bound to move greatly to Seaboard's advantage.

Juvenile wagon thieves up town have placed their depredations upon a basis which would do credit to a legitimate commercial enterprise, according to the police William Meyers, twelve years of age, of 160 East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, was caught in Seventh Avenue yesterday afternoon while driving away with one of the delivery wagons of the Manhattan Meat and Vegetable Market, kept by Charles Weisbeckar at 268 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street.

The Hon. WILLIAM E. CHANDLER of New Hampshire is no longer an advocate Of Federal interference in the elections of the people. In a letter to The Sun he complains that lynchings are on the increase in the South, "and lynching is a common and customary method of putting to death obnoxious colored men to keep the colored race in terror and the colored voters away from the polls."

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The announcements at noon to-day that William Malcolm, ex-Secretary of the Mutual Loan and Building Association, had resigned as City Treasurer and that the Board of Directors of the association had decided to suspend business came as a shock to the 600 stockholders of the concern.

READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The grand circuit meeting opened on the Readville track to-day with fine weather and some sensational wins for horses little favored by the betting fraternity, the favorites in each event being beaten. Major Muscovite, who won the 2:08 pace, had sold for $5 in pools of $450 before the race.

It begins to look as if the anthracite operators were desirous of resuming the mining of coal. So far as appears, this desire is not the outgrowth of any realization of their public responsibilities, but is prompted by the fear that if they trifle with the situation any longer other fuels will have made such inroads upon the field of anthracite that their trade will be seriously impaired.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Robert R. Remington committed suicide at the Newport Reading Room this afternoon by shooting himself three times in the head. Mr. Remington's reported engagement to Miss May Van Alen, so the gossip here runs, was broken several days ago, and it was brooding over his disappointment which is believed to have influenced the young man to take his life.

One thousand members of the International Brotherhood of Blacksmiths and Helpers went on strike yesterday morning to enforce demands made a week ago, on all the employers. The demands were $3.50 a day, minimum wages, with 10 per cent, advance in wages for all who had been earning more than $3.50 a day, a general nine-hour workday, and 10 per cent, increase in wages and a nine-hour workday for the helpers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 -- William Jay Turner, acting as counsel for the State of Alabama, has had an attachment issued against the Pennsylvania Company for the Insurance of Lives and Granting Annuities, executor of the estate of Thomas G. Corbin, United States Navy, who died a few months ago leaving an estate valued at $750,000.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 18 -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, accompanied by Miss Ellen Drexel Paul of Philadelphia, made a flying trip to this city to-day in an automobile, leaving Newport after luncheon and arriving at the home of her grandmother, Mrs. George C. Lee, in Brookline, in time to dress for 6 o'clock dinner.

-- For fear that the Summer residents in and around Wood's Hole may not get their fair share of excitement -- the region being very pleasant, but equally quiet -- we hasten to call their attention to the fact that Dr. BEAMAN DOUGLASS of this city not only thinks, but has confided to The New York Medical Journal his opinion that at Wood's Hole there seems to be "an absolute divorce between brains and wealth."

An interesting report has just been issued by the Foreign Office on the trade of Korea for the year 1901, by Mr. H. Goffe, Acting British Vice-Consul At Chemulpo. It states that the chief difficulty with which foreign trade has to contend is the disastrous condition of the currency throughout the Empire.

The committee appointed by the Retail Coal Dealers' Association to fix the schedule price for coal was expected to meet this week to consider the question of further advancing the retail price of anthracite. It was learned yesterday, however, that the committee has decided to take no further steps immediately, and may wait a week or two longer for developments before further raising the schedule price, which is $9 a ton.
Rogers Sollo have been appointed Chicago and Cook County agents of the Pennsylvania Fire Insurance Company to succeed F.S. James Co.
OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- This was a day of mystery at Sagamore House. The President had many visitors who had little or nothing to say as to why they had come.

In a letter sent to the Mayor of Yonkers, the Police Commissioners, and Police Captain Woodruff, yesterday, Surrogate Theodore H. Silkman complained of the poolrooms which, he charges, are running in that city openly and without any police interference. He says that Yonkers has lost.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Aug. 18 -- In a very interesting match, Myopia defeated Point Judith in the final game for the Narragansett Cup and individual prizes, this afternoon, by a score of 14 3/4 to 10. Point Judith, which on Saturday easily defeated Myopia without any handicap for the Point Judith Cup, was allowed two goals, and in the first period, had everything its own way, making the score 7 to 2 in its favor.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 19. -- The John W. Gates faction of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company has lost another round in its battle for control of that company. Judge Rluer of the United States District Court to-night denied its application for a preliminary injunction to prevent officials of the company from refusing to allow it to vote proxies it claims to hold at the stockholders meeting to-morrow in this city.

The curb market yesterday showed some slight improvement in prices, owing in part to the firmer market on the Board Fractional advances were quite frequent throughout the list, with the largest occurring in Manhattan Transit, Northern Securities, Standard Oil,, and Otls Elevator common.

The reception given the Boer commanders in London, from the formal audience by the King to the cheers and applause of the populace when they appeared in public places, was an interesting illustration of the rapidity with which the wounds of war are scarred over in the process of healing by first intention.

Col. William G. Bates of the Seventy-first Regiment has been accused by Major Clinton H. Smith of the same command with having put in an improper claim to the Board of Audit, which has heen examining the account of the officers of the regiment, representing claims for reimbursement by the State for property destroyed by the armory fire last February.

President John R. Voorhis of the Bureau of Elections, said yesterday that the attention of the District Attorney's office would be called to possible frauds in the enrollment blanks from the various Assembly Districts. President Voorhis would make no specific assertion that proof of fraud had been found in the returns to the Bureau of Elections by representatives of the various district leaders.

Suffering from dire poverty, from which there seemed no escape, Mrs. Eleanor Wallack, wife of J. Lester Wallack, actor and grandson of Lester Wallack, committed suicide early yesterday morning by inhaling illuminating gas at her home, 253 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street. Mrs. Wallack had returned from a vain quest to better her husband's financial condition, and after telling him of her failure left the room on a pretext of illness.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 19. -- A murderous assault was made on Dr. L. J. Fabian of 708 Brown Street this morning by a patient, who then hurried, out of the house and escaped. The doctor was listening to the action of the patient's heart when he was felled with a terrific blow of an ice-pick.

Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, arrived in this city last night. He is on his way to Europe to recuperate from the effects of overwork and overexertion. He expects to come back in a few months a perfectly well man, and he has no intention of resizing the Presidency of the big corporation of which he is the head.

The deaths of two women and two children and the serious injury of two other persons, besides minor injuries to many men, women, and children, resulted from a fire which yesterday morning ate its way from the first floor to the top of the double-decker tenement at 35 Essex Street.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Apparently incensed over the notoriety they have suddenly attained the Nelson family of New Market, heirs of Mrs. Charles L. Fair, have secluded themselves from the public gaze, but the little grocery is still kept open for business, with Mrs. Abram Nelson in charge.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Word has just reached this city from Essex, Ontario, of a terrible accident which occurred near that place about 12 o'clock last night, causing the death of John Brown and two ladies named Scraums, all prominent young people in the vicinity of Essex.

Among the many reasons which Havana gossip gives for the resignation of Senor EMILIO TERRY, Secretary of Agriculture in President PALMA'S Cabinet, the opposition encountered by his project of a loan of $4,000,000 for the benefit of the sugar plantation owners seems the most plausible.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 19. -- A public reception was accorded to the Boer Generals on their arrival here to-day from Rotterdam. Gen. Eyter paid a tribute to their heroic deeds. Gen. Botha replied, expressing the appreciation of the Boer officers at the warmth of their reception, and referring to the consolation which it had been to them to know that, while they fought, their women and children were being supported by Dutch generosity.
