ASBURY PARK, Aug. 19. -- Queen Titania, the ruler of Fairyland, visited this baby's paradise to-day, and the little ones, 500 of them, honored the sovereign by marching in review before her. The procession, the twelfth of its kind for Asbury Park, was viewed by fully 100,000 delighted spectators, who crowded the board walk and pavilions, the streets adjacent to the line of march, and the massive grand stand erected in Ocean Avenue.
MORRISVILLE, Vt., Aug. 19. -- Five thousand persons listened with great interest to Secretary of the Treasury Leslie M. Shaw, who was the principal speaker at a Republican rally here to-day.

BOSTON, Aug. 19. -- On call, money rules from 4@ 41/2 per cent, to the best borrowers. Time money ranges from 4 1/2@5 per cent, for four to six months, with mixed loans generally 5 per cent. The market for commercial paper is dull; 4 1/2 @5 1/2 per cent., according to grade. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 19 -- Charles M. Schwab stopped in Philadelphia long enough to-day to refute statements made relative to his physical condition.

SARATOGA, N.Y, Aug, 19. -- Charles H. Thompson, better known as "Butch" Thompson, died here to-day after a long illness following injuries received in a runaway accident ten years ago at Long Branch. The direct cause of his death was Bright's disease and cirrhosis of the liver.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The volume Containing statements of appropriations, new offices, , required by law to be prepared and published at the end of each session of Congress under the direction of the Committees on Appropriations of the Senate and House, has been completed for the first session of the Fifty-seventh Congress by Thomas P. Cleaves and James C. Courts, chief clerks respectively of those committees.

While the brief but violent thunderstorm which broke over the city shortly before 6 o'clock last evening caused a drop of fifteen degrees in the temperature, bringing instant relief from the heat and humidity, the sharp lightning which accompanied the storm struck in several densely crowded portions of the city and caused widespread terror.

With Peter Power safely confined in Ludlow Street Jail, the lawyers for the Northern Securities Company, who have spent time and money in the effort to get the socalled "vanishing plaintiff " on the witness stand, yesterday changed their tactics and for the first time in a considerable period announced that it was not convenient to proceed.

Simultaneous calls for ambulances and physicians coming over the telephone wires to Fordham, King's Bridge, and other outlying portions of the Borough of the Bronx at 11:15 o'clock last night gave the news of a most serious trolley accident which happened at about that time to a heavy car of the Union system at Mosholu Parkway and Jerome Avenue.

The trial of Chief of Construction and Repairs to Apparatus Patrick F. Ryan was continued yesterday at Fire Headquarters. Daniel D. Daly, an upholsterer at the repair shops, said that he did work on a brougham Which was said to have come from Commissioner Scannell, a phaeton, and an exercising cart. He used the same materials, only of different colors, as those used for department vehicles, except some silk was used on the brougham.
By the following special order, Edward F. Croker, Chief of the Fire Department, was relieved from duty yesterday by Commissioner Sturgis:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 19. -- It is reported here that the taking on of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad by the Frisco system and the latter's incorporation of the Chicago and Memphis Railroad Company will result in the establishment of a sharp competition between the Frisco on the one hand and the Illinois Central on the other for the passenger and freight traffic between Memphis and Chicago and between Chicago and the Gulf.

Owing to a heavy rainstorm, the second game of the Jersey City-Rochester series in Jersey City yesterday was called at the end of the seventh inning in favor of Rochester by 2 to 0. Loose fielding by the Jersey team was responsible for the two runs which their opponents made in the first and seventh innings.

Yesterday's market broadened somewhat, but not enough to provoke much enthusiasm. Commission house transactions were larger than they have lately averaged. Changes of size sufficient to be of interest were as a rule advances.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 19 -- The third annual Bar Harbor Horse Show opened this morning. If the two succeeding days can hold their own with to-day's exhibition, the show will surpass, anything of its kind that has taken place here.

Consuelo, Duchess of Marlborough, for the first time since her marriage, seven years ago, returned to New York yesterday. The Duchess, according to her friends, did not look a day older than she did when as Consuelo Vanderbilt she became an English peeress. She was accompanied on the way over by her mother, Mrs. O.H.P. Belmont; her brother, William K. Vanderbilt, Jr.; O.H.P. Belmont, and Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Following is the general summary of crop conditions issued by the Department of Agriculture:

Duff Brown have sold for Mrs. William Stevens to a Mrs. Steinau, for about $22,000, the three-story dwelling 457 West One Hundred and Forty-third Street, 18.9 by 53 by 100. The buyer will occupy the house.
It was at the very beginning of the French Revolution that a bewildered courtier hastened to his royal master with the announcement: "Sire, it is not a revolt, it is a revolution."

Police Commissioner Partridge took another tour around some of the precincts on Monday. In the afternoon he went up into the Bronx and visited the High Bridge, King's Bridge, Bronx Park, and Wakefield Stations in company with Inspector Cross. In the evening he visited the Charles Street, West Twentieth, and "West Forty-seventh Street Stations in Manhattan.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Henry A. Dickinson was unanimously renominated for the Assembly to-day by the Cortland County Republican Convention, and W.H. Foster of Homer was renominated for his fourth term as County Treasurer. Delegates to State Congressional, Senatorial, and Judicial Conventions were elected as follows:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 19. -- Stories of President Schwab's illness are giving way to rumors to the effect that his trip abroad is for the purpose of completing the organization of European steel manufactories which J. Pierpont Morgan has made possible by the steamship merger. An inkling of this was given by a Director of the United States Steel Corporation to-day when discussing Mr. Schwab's illness.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 19. -- New York dealers have begun buying hard coal in this section in small quantities. Five hundred tons are to be sent from Lynn next week that a New York wholesale dealer may be aided in supplying his customers.

Three indictments against policemen because of their alleged misconduct in the riot at the funeral, of Rabbi Joseph were returned by the Grand Jury yesterday. Two were against Roundsman James H. Jackson of the Delancey Street Station, and are for assault in the second degree, while the other on a similar charge was against a policeman whose name was with-held, and who is understood to be on vacation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- One of the most notable dinners of the evening was that given by Mr. J.A. Biddle at Berger's. There were thirty-eight guests, and a strikingly attractive table arrangement was made by Mr. Berger and Wadley Smythe. In the centre of the large pavilion a table was placed in the form of a hollow square.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- New York exchange to-day was 10 cents discount; time and call loans, 4 to 5 per cent.

One of the most daring and cleverly accomplished robberies of its kind committed in Brooklyn in a long time took place yesterday afternoon in the busy shopping district of that borough, when a tray filled with diamond rings, said to be worth about $4,000, was stolen from the jewelry store of A.A. Webster Co. at 440 Fulton Street.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- A regular Pennsylvania train on the New York and Long Branch Railroad, bound north, was run into front the rear at the Belmar station this evening by a special Central Railroad of New Jersey train. The Pennsylvania train had stoppd at the Belmar station to take on passengers.
The Merchants Mutual Fire Insurance Company has been Incorporated at Atlanta.

Much as the public desires the early termination of the strike which has tied up the anthracite trade for four months, it would be more to the public advantage that it should last indefinitely than that it should be settled through the agency of Senators QUAY and PENROSE of Pennsylvania, in furtherance of a political deal such as these gentlemen would be apt to arrange.

In the leisurely course of the Central American mails we learn that about the middle of July the Captain of the British cruiser Psyche called at Ruatan and read a proclamation to the effect that the Bay Islands belong to Honduras; that they are not a British possession, and that the inhabitants have no claim to British allegiance or to British protection because of such allegiance.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- Trading was somewhat restricted in the local market today, but prices. were well maintained, and there was some variation from the course of the past ten days, Electric Storage, Reading, Lehigh Valley, and Lehigh Navigation coming to the front after, a period "of dullness.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 -- Again the steadiness of the famous English lawn tennis players, R.F. Doherty and H.L. Doherty, gained the victory to-day. They won the opening doubles match of the twenty-second National championship tournament on the Casino courts after five of the fastest and hardest sets that were ever played on this historic field.

BOSTON, Aug. 19. -- The police think that in the arrest of Charles T. Hubbard, they have secured a man who has been wanted in this city and in other places for several years. In the Municipal Court this afternoon, eh was held, on two specific counts of obtaining money on false pretenses, in $500 bonds, on each count, for appearance next Tuesday.

NEWPORT, Aug. 19. -- E.P. Remington arrives here at 7 o'clock to-night, and at 11 o'clock left with the body of his brother, Robert R. Remington, who committed suicide yesterday afternodn. Mr. Remington said that he received late yesterday afternoon in Pittsburg, Penn., a telegraphic dispatch from Daniel B. Fearing, notifying him that his brother had died suddenly in Newport.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19. -- The strength of the various trust companies shares was the feature of to-day, though the general market was strong. The speculative fever seems to be spreading among outsiders, so that the buying is rapidly broadening. There were really no "soft spots" in today's market.

LONDON, Aug 19. -- Money was not plentiful in the market to-day, but was in good demand, in connection with, the payment of calls, due to recent new issues of capital, amounting to about $5,000,000. Discounts were firm. There is no prospect of rates being materially easier while the market is largely indebted to the Bank of England.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- This was grievance day in the towns of Mount Pleasant and Greenburg. Unlike former years, there were very few objections to the assessments. This was due to the fact that in both towns the valuations remained practically the same as last year.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 19 -- After winning four straight games from Chicago, the New York baseball team played a strong game against the champions here this afternoon. At the last moment, by a sharp batting rally on the part of the Pittsburgers, the visitors were beaten in the ninth inning, the score being 5 to 4 in favor of the local aggregation.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Aug. 19 -- The public reception planned some time ago as a fitting mark of respect to Gen. Jacob H. Smith took place to-night.

ISLESBOROUGH, Me., Aug. 20. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt and Miss Ellen Drexel Paul, who arrived here last night, are guests of the family of Dr. Richard H. Derby of New York at their beautiful Summer home here.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 20. -- A meeting of the Stewards of the Jockey Club was held at the race track here this morning. The Stewards present were August Belmont, F.R. Hitchcock, H.K. Knapp, and Andrew Miller. Andrew Miller was appointed Steward to represent the Jockey Club at the Coney Island Jockey Club Autumn meeting.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- After an investigation by the Chicago police extending over a fortnight and a two days' Coroner's inquest, the authorities are still in doubt whether the body of the murdered woman found at Seventy-fourth and State Streets was really that of Minnie Mitchell.
HAVANA, Aug. 20. -- It is doubtful if any attempt will at present be made to float the proposed loan of $35,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The publication of the President's New England itinerary to-day aroused more comment for what it did not contain than for what it did. There was much curiosity about the non-appearance of Rockland, Me., on the list of homes of distinguished men whom the President will visit.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20. -- Two baseball games were played here to-day between the Boston and St. Louis teams. Each won and lost both contests being very closely contested. The local players were completely shut out in the early game and the visitors got their only tally in the eighth inning.

Several policemen told Police Commissioner Partridge yesterday afternoon that if there were fewer unnecessary details enough men are on the pay rolls to furnish a three-platoon system, give the citizens better protection, and secure to the members of the force time needed for rest. The statements and the figures were given at the session of the commission appointed by Mayor Low to report to him desirable changes in the police law.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 20. -- Miss Frances Hinkle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Howard Hinkle of Cincinnati, and A. Clifford Shinkle, also of Cincinnati, were married hero at noon to-day in St Savaur's Episcopat Church. It was a brilliant social affair.

PANAMA, Aug. 20. -- The Government gunboat Boyaca, which left here July 29 to carry 300 soldiers to Agua Dulce, and which was captured by the revolutionists, is now at sea, flying the rebel flag. The rumors that the Boyaca was sunk are therefore refuted.

J. Pierpont Morgan, after an absence of several months in Europe, returned to New York yesterday on the White Star Liner Oceanic. As usual, about a score of newspaper men went down the bay to meet him. Mr. Morgan was disinclined to talk, however, contenting himself with expressing disbelief in the report that President Schwab was to retire from his official position in the United States Steel Corporation.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 20. -- Judge John I. Mullins of the District Court issued an injunction which caused a postponement of the annual election of officials of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, which was to have taken place at 3 o'clock this afternoon.
The New York Theatre yesterday passed, from the possession of the Sire Brothers into that of Klaw Erlanger. The price said to have been paid by the purchasers is $2,000,000.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 20. -- J.J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railroad, to-day announced a reduction in grain rates in the Dakotas and Minnesota amounting to about 10 per. cent. This reduction applies to the Great Northern and Northern Pacific, and in these States alone will aggregate $1,000,000, which, however, Mr. Hill says he is doubtful if the farmers will benefit by.

Charles Richert, a candy manufacturer, who occupies a fashionable brown-stone house at 157 Hooper Street, Williamsburg, had an encounter with two burglars last evening, one of whom assaulted him with a jimmy. The robbers secured an entranee by forcing open with a jimmy a door leading to the yard.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- Mrs. Oliver H.F. Belmont and her daughter, the Duchess of Marlborough, arrived here this afternoon from New York, coming at an earlier hour than was announced, evidently in order to avoid notoriety. They were accompanied by Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs. Mrs. Belmont and the Duchess of Marlborough were driven, at once to Belcourt and Mrs. Oelrichs to Rosecliff.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Grey Friar, quoted at 12 to 1, won the Grand Union Hotel Stakes this afternoon in clever fashion from Judith Campbell, while Whitechapel, who, coupled with Rigodon, an added starter, was favorite, finished third. Ten two-year-olds started. The value of the race was $7,000 to F.R. Hitchcock, owner of the winner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- This is the first time in the history of a political campaign when a Campaign Committee in publishing its campaign text book found it necessary to apologize for the language of the President of the United States, in his message to Congress," said Charles A. Edwards, Secretary of the Democratic Congressional Committee, to-day.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill stopped off in Rochester to-day on his way to Orleans County, where he will address the Orleans County Pioneers' Association at its, annual picnic to-morrow. He was accompanied by Bird S. Coler, who is also on his way to Orleans County to look after his extensive interests in the brownstone quarries of Medina.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 24 1/4d per Ounce and in New YorK at 52 1/2c per ounce. Mexican dollars at 41 1/4@43c.

CHATHAM, Mass., Aug. 20. -- This was the busiest racing day of the week at Camp Nauset, the headquarters of the American Canoe Association, the principal event being the nine-mile sailing canoe race for the association trophy, which was won by Herman D. Murphy of the Winchester Club, who now takes possession of the prize held the past year by Farnum P. Dorsey, also of Winchester.

The arrival of J. Pierpont Morgan yesterday appeared to have given the impression that the end of the coal strike was in sight. Although the operators denied that his return would have any effect in changing their policy, few people were inclined to think that it would have no effect in bringing the strike to an end.

Over 300,000 shares were dealt in on the Stock Exchange yesterday and the market generally was very strong. Many advances of consequence were reported. Commission house transactions were on a substantial scale. The coal stocks and the iron and steel issues were, as a rule, conspicuous in the day's improvement, though many of the railway issues were materially advanced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Commissioner Yerkes of the Internal Revenue Bureau has issued a circular letter to collectors directing them to report the names of banks which have not made complete amended returns for the year ended June 30, 1902, and in case of neglect or refusal to make proper returns, collectors will report them for assessment.

The Board of Health yesterday sent to the Rapid Transit Commission a report of Charle's F. Roberts, Sanitary Superintendent, showing that the conditions existing in the excavations are in many places a menace to the health of persons living along the line of the tunnel. The unsanitary conditions mentioned were disconnection of sewers, stagnant water, the escape of sewage, the use of the excavations as dumping places, and the prevalence of foul odors.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 20. -- The war game in which the rival fleets of Commander John E. Pillsbury and Admiral Francis J. Higginson are pitted against each other began at noon to-day. The North Atlantic Coast is now threatened by a powerful squadron of hostile ships from the attack of which an equally able fleet will attempt to defend this country.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 20. -- Nine workmen are known to have been killed, five are missing, and four others were badly injured by the explosion of two steel digesters in the Delaware Pulp Mills of the Jessup Moore Paper Company on the Christiana River this afternoon.

-- We have seen many descriptions of Mr. CROKER'S residence at Wantage, ranging from those that made it out something, but not much, less than Windsor Castle, to those that pictured it as something, but not much, more than the tar-paper cabins which once ornamented the crags of Harlem.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20. -- Manager Captain "Joe" Kelly's baseball players had an easy time with Hanlon's Brooklyn men in the two games played here this afternoon. Kelly sent Phillips in to pitch against the visitors in the first game, and while there were twelve hits made off him, they were so well scattered that only two runs resulted.

In a letter to a citizen of Wilkesbarre, replying to one in which the Christian duty of the operators to end the present strike was set forth with perhaps more of sincerity than of convincing clearness, President BAER says:

Discrepancy in the size of a husband and wife, difference of nationality, disagreements on religion, jealousy of a pet dog and cat, drunkenness, outbursts of violent temper, wounded pride, frustrated attempts at suicide, and a mother-in-law were among the charges and counter-charges which disturbed judicial dignity and made it difficult for the bailiff to preserve order during the hearing of a divorce case in the Supreme Court yesterday.
W.E. Finn has sold to James D. Matthews 308 and 310 West Fifty-eighth Street, two four-story dwellings on plot 42 by 100. Mr. Matthews will erect a nine-story apartment hotel on the site.

BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- Four and six months money rules from 4 1/2@5 per cent., the latter figure mostly where the transaction are not between banks and their regular customers. Year money is 4 1/4 per cent, upward. There is no free movement of outside commercial paper under 5 per cent. It is said good names passed at 5 per cent.

The indifference of the people of this State to the views of BENJAMIN B. ODELL upon the subject of the trusts is pervading and profound. But one million and a half voters of the State of New York would be put under obligations to him by a frank and full expression of his views about the canals.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 20. -- As Myopia second defaulted to Lakewood in the semi-finals for the Rhode Island Cup to-day, no polo game was expected, but since the Lakewood men were on hand a special match was played for a silver cup offered by George J. Gould between Lakewood and a team from the Point Judith Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Philadelphia earned another victory over the local baseball team to-day with a score of 4 to 2. This made the sixth successive losing game which the Chicago men have played since their return from the East. The home team was unable to hit Frazer with men on bases, and three costly errors helped to swell the score of the visitors.

OYSTER BAY, Aug. 20. -- President Roosevelt to-day, in no uncertain terms, expressed his disapproval of factional differences in the Republican Party. Cecil A. Lyon, Chairman of the Republican State Committee of Texas, called on him and presented his side of the controversy which has arisen among the Republicans of the Lone Star State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The mimic naval war began at noon to-day. Admiral Higginson and Commander Pillsbury, in command of the rival fleets, respectively designated "Blue" and "White," the latter, under command of Commander Pillsbury, being the attacking fleet, were supplied with confidential instructions, which went into effect at noon.

Broadway strollers were surprised at Thirty-fourth Street at 9 o'clock last evening to see a quietly dressed man speak to Policeman Perigo of the West Thirtieth Street Station, who then approached a well-dressed aristocratic looking young man who was walking with the throng, when the latter broke into a run and dashed south, with the policeman after him.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- A dispatch from Wellington, N.Z., to The Times says that the representatives of the press have been excluded from the inquiry into the alleged overcrowding of the troopship Britannic.

James K. Hackett and his wife, Mary Mannering, were among the arrivals from Europe on the White Star liner Oceanic yesterday. Mr. Hackett said he and Mrs. Hackett had enjoyed their vacation, but were nevertheless happy to get back to New York. Concerning his theatrical plans, Mr. Hackett said that he would open in Philadelphia with "The Crisis," Sept. 22.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The second day's races at Goshen were exciting. Good time was made as the track was in excellent condition and the weather fine. Seven thousand people witnessed the events. In the 2:22 class, pacing, unfinished from yesterday, Willie Osborn, who was a strong favorite, was distanced in the first heat to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, August 20. -- The local market to-day kept pace with New York in strength and activity. The features were Cambria Steel, United Gas Improvement, Philadelphia Rapid Transit, and International Powder. Rapid Transit and Cambria Steel made new high records, the former at 14 1/2 and the latter at 27 1/8.
LONDON, Aug. 20. -- Money rates and discounts were maintained to-day.

Full of enthusiasm over his mission, Prof. G.R. Parkin, head of the Tipper Canada University, at Toronto, who has been delegated by Lords Milner, Rosebery, and Grey; Dr. Jamieson, and Messrs. Biet, Mitchell, and Hawksley, the committee, in charge of the Cecil Rhodes educational bequests, to travel through America for the purpose of formulating a scheme to put the American scholarships in force, arrived here yesterday, on the White Star liner Oceanic.
According to Cleveland dispatches the general plan of the Everett-Moore syndicate to reorganize the Lake Shore Electric Railway will be made public in a few days.

Transactions on the curb yesterday improved considerably over those of the first two days of the week. A number of substantial gains occurred principally in Northern Securities, Otis Elevator common, and American Writing Paper preferred. A few sharp declines took place; but the upward tendency and greater activity of the rest of the list was more than Sufficient to Offset the declines.

At the moment yesterday which was expected to mark the climax of the efforts of the Northern Securities Company to condemn and humiliate George Alfred Lamb, attorney for the elusive Peter Power, the clouds suddenly rolled away and Mr. Lamb emerged smilingly, basking in the sunshine of the railroad lawyers' approval.

Bishop Henry C. Potter of the Episcopal Diocese of New York returned from Europe on the White Star liner Oceanic yesterday, apparently greatly improved in health. One of the first things he was asked was the date of his marriage to Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark of this city and Cooperstown.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 20. -- F.C. Smink of Reading, Penn., E.J. Converse of Chicago, W.P. Tyler of New York, and Howard Vansant of Pittsburg, wealthy steel men, who are spending the Summer here, played a remarkable game of golf on the links of the Country Club at Northfield this afternoon.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 20. -- Mr. and Mrs. Giraud Foster returned from Bar Harbor to-day, where they have been spending the last few weeks. Mrs. Foster will give a large dinner party to-morrow night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- The second day's play in the National lawn tennis championship on the Casino courts was filled with an abundance of good work by the experts. Perfect weather conditions and turf in prime order brought out a big gallery. There was one feature of the day which caused the American followers of the sport to do a lot of figuring.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 20. -- Queen Titania, the ruler of fairyland, held high carnival this evening in the beach auditorium, which was filled with babies and children who had won prizes in yesterday's parade. During the evening the Queen, through her private secretary, John W. Myers of New York, announced the names of the prize winners, and gave them their trophies.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 20. -- The officials of the State Penitentiary and the citizens of Frankfort were thrown into a state of wild excitement this morning by a riot in the prison started by an attempt to gain their liberty on the part of three desperate murderers, Lafayette Brooks of Morgan County and Wallace Bishop and T. Mulligan of Kenton County.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 20. -- The local market to-day was generally active and higher. Seaboards lapsed back into less prominence and were the least bullish of the more prominent issues. Nashville Railway securities caught the eye most conspicuously owing to its sudden spurt into activity at a time when the Street anticipated a reactionary movement.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 20. -- The Cape Parliament assembled to-day. Sir Walter F. Hely-Hutchinson, Governor of the colony, announced in a speech that martial law would be removed on the passage of a bill indemnifying the Governor and all persons concerned for acts committed under martial law.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 20. -- The second day of the Horse Show was marked by a continuance of the perfect weather that attended the opening. It brought forth a holiday crowd which quite filled the stands and paddock at Robin Hood Park. From all over the State large excursions came down this morning.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 20. -- The American auxiliary yacht Utowana, owned by A.V. Armour of New York, which was the first of the contestants for the Earl of Crawford's Coronation Cup to round the mark off Cherbourg, France, yesterday, passed Prawle Point on her return at 12:10 P.M. to-day.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 20. -- The man who was killed last evening when the special train of the Central Railroad of New Jersey ran into a train of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Belmar has been identified, as Richard De Armand of New Orange. The other person killed was Alice Bishop, eight years old, who had been spending the day at Belmar with her uncle, W.J. McGrath of Rahway.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 20. -- Lyman E. Cooley of Chicago spoke before the TransMississippi Congress to-day and advocated the improvement of the Mississippi River. He introduced resolutions commending the improvement of the river between Cairo and St. Louis to make the stream permanently navigable to compete with railroads and to furnish an outlet to South America for the products of the Northwest.

The new Secretary of the Treasury whom President ROOSEVELT has brought out of the West is a disappointing man. We had heard much of his independence of character and of his almost austere manner of living. It was known that he had fearlessly preached sound financial doctrines in regions where silver infidels abounded.

READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 20. -- The Grand Circuit card this afternoon was the one arranged for yesterday, and which the rain prevented. The track was sticky, but in spite of this drawback Direct Hal broke his own record 2:06 1/2 and the Norfolk Stake record of 2:06 3/4 by pacing the third heat in 2:06.

OLCOTT BEACH, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The one hundredth anniversary of the settlement of Niagara County was celebrated here to-day under the auspices of the Niagara County Pioneers' Association. Gov. Odell and Mrs. Odell arrived on the private car of President W. Caryl Ely of the International Traction Company after breakfasting at Lockport with Senator Ellsworth.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 21. -- When shown a copy of a dispatch from San Francisco giving the details of Mrs. Charles L. Fair's will, Mrs. William Smith of Newmarket, a sister-in-law of the dead woman, verified the report and declared that a duplicate of the alleged will was in the possession of Mrs. Hannah Nelson, the mother, at the time she left for the West, but that she had secreted it from the public.

Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, sailed on board the French liner La Lorraine for Europe yesterday. He was accompanied to the steamship by George W. Perkins of J.P. Morgan Co., ex-Judge E.H. Gary, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the United States Steel Corporation; Joseph H. Schwab, Max Pam, T.F. Baker, S.A. Pope, and Charles Sorck.

ALBION, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Ex-Gov. David B. Hill spoke to a crowd of 8,000 persons at the Orleans County Pioneer picnic at Oak Orchard to-day. The speech was a general one, Mr. Hill saying he thought it poor taste to inject politics at such a time.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 21. -- The champion trotter Cresceus (2:02 1/4) stepped a wonderful mile here this afternoon over the State Fair Grounds track, going in 2:04 1/4, and clipping one-quarter of a second off the track record for trotters, made by Nancy Hanks in 1892. His time by quarters was -- 0:31 1/2, 1:02 1/2, 1:34, and 2:04 1/4.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21. -- It is said here that the will of Mrs. Charles Fair, which is now in the hands of attorneys Knight Heggerty, disposes of an estate consisting of cash, real property, and railroad and Government bonds approximately valued at $300,000.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Aug. 21. -- An autopsy held here to-day on the body of Robert R. Remington, who is supposed to have committed suicide at Newport, R.I., on Monday, has resulted in the report that the suicide theory has been doubted.

PARIS, Aug. 21. -- No announcement conconcerning the successor of Jules Cambon, French Ambassador to the United States, has yet been made. Inquiry at the Foreign Office to-day elicited the statement that the selection of M. Carobon's successor would probably be made this week.

Some long-sought testimony was adduced in the hearing yesterday of evidence in the Peter Power suit against the Northern Securities Company. George Alfred Lamb. Power's attorney, went on the stand and "told all he knew." Peter Power, hitherto so elusive, but now serving a thirty days' sentence in jail for contempt of court, also told his story.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- The various States of the Nation, President Roosevelt, and prominent Government officials will cooperate and participate in the production of the international Olympian games of 1904. All foreign countries will be represented. France has promised to send its army cadets, and has asked for the games in 1908.
LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The rates for money were steady to-day, and there was a rather better supply, owing to a considerable distribution of dividends.

A syndicate, in which Walter C. Plant and Harry S. Houpt are interested, has bought the old Hotel Bayard property, at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street, and will erect thereon a twelve-story hotel, costing about $600,000. This property was purchased last Spring by Miss Mary Emma Coleman for $285,000, and the present selling price is said to show a large advance over that figure.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 21. -- "I have always been a Democrat, and that don't mean that I am not one now," J.J. Hannahan said to-day after his luncheon with the President, and in explanation he added: "President Roosevelt is the most democratic President any one ever heard of. He made us as much at home in as frank and manly a way as any man I have ever met.
LONDON, Aug. 21. -- Thomas Nevins of East Orange, N.J., died at his residence, Mount Shannon, Castleconnell, County Limerick, Ireland, to-day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- In an interview printed in a Washington paper today Representative Joseph G. Cannon of Illinois was asked:

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 21. -- The battleships of Rear Admiral Higginson's squadron, defending the New England coast from an imaginary attack by a fleet under Commander John E. Pillsbury, were plainly to be seen in the clear atmosphere from this point this morning. The other vessels of Admiral Higginson's command were scattered along the horizon, or in view at nearer points, maintaining guard of the coast.

Capt. O'Brien and the detectives of the Leonard Avenue Station took two prisoners into the Tombs Police Court, yesterday morning who, they assert, are the burglars who have entered more than forty sweat-shops lately and stolen more than $20,000 worth of goods. The prisoners, Jacob Rockman, 325 Madison Street, and Myer Goldman, 15 Bowery, were arrested the night before at Canal Street and Broadway.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 21. -- The fair weather held to the last, and the third annual horse show closed in the proverbial blaze of glory. The last day was full of features. Socially it was the most successful of the week. The dressing was again pronounced brilliant. Luncheon parties were numerous on the various coaches.

Though the arrival of Bishop Potter from Europe gave rise to the idea that, as a member of the Civic Federation, he would take advantage of J. Pierpont Morgan's return to make a last appeal to him on behalf of the striking coal miners. It was learned yesterday that the Federation has little hope of settling the strike.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 21. -- The American auxiliary yacht Utowana, owned by A.V. Armour of New York, arrived here to-day, winning the ocean yacht race for the Earl of Crawford's Coronation Cup. The race, which was for auxiliary steam craft, was started Monday from the Nab Lightship to Cherbourg and back, around the Eddystone Lighthouse.

Chief Post Office Inspector Theodore W. Swift is jubilant over what he declares to be a successful raid upon green goods operators, consummated, with the assistance of several other Government officials, on Wednesday, after a patient vigil which has lasted for months. Not only was the entire band of alleged swindlers captured, but their headquarters, at 25 Water Street, Newark, was invaded and a stock of paraphernalia seized.

An excellent feature of the present tenement house law is that which imposes upon the owners of such buildings the obligation to declare themselves and toe registered on the books of the Tenement House Department, and which further legalizes the service of notices upon such owners as fail to declare themselves by posting the same in a conspicuous place in the house.

The defense of Patrick F. Ryan, Chief of Construction and Repairs to Apparatus in the Fire Department, to the charges preferred against him, based on the report of the Commissioner of Accounts, was begun yesterday afternoon at Fire Headquarters. The evidence for the Chief was presented by his counsel, Delos McCurdy.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21. -- While the New York weakness had some effect upon the local market the latter behaved remarkably well. Trading in Wall Street issues was light, and brokers here turned their attention to stocks that have long been on the shelf. Lehigh Valley, Lehigh Navigation, Tide Water Steel, and American Cement were more active than usual.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 21. -- General Manager Howe of the Armour Packing Company and General Superintendent Talliferro of Cudahy's were suddenly called to Chicago last night and speculation is rife as to the cause. Coming on the heels of the rumored sale of the Cudahys' plant to the Meat Trust, it is the concensus of opinion among packing house men that their sudden departure has to do with the sale.
A.R. Davis has been appointed Cleveland agent of the Franklin Fire Insurance Company of Columbus.

DENVER, Aug. 21. -- The resignations of Messrs. Gates, Mitchell, Blair, and Lambert as Directors of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, announced by John W. Gates at midnight, were sent to the headquarters of the company shortly before the time for the annual meeting, but no action was taken by the board, as there was no meeting of it.

The executive branch of the Republican County Committee at a meeting yesterday afternoon adopted, without a dissenting vote, the Assembly district as the unit of representation in the selection of delegates to conventions at the primaries to be held on Sept. 16.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.-- The report from Williamsport, Penn., that E.P. Remington doubts that his brother, Robert R. Remington, committed suicide, was a genuine surprise to Newport. There seems to be no doubt entertained here that it was a deliberate case of suicide.

Two games were played at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, between the local and Buffalo teams. The first game was won by the visiting players, 6 to 1, but the second resulted in a twelve-inning tie, each side having scored two runs when the game was called on account of darkness.

Commissioner STURGIS of the Fire Department ought to be given to understand in the most emphatic manner and at the earliest possible moment that his fellow-citizens do not approve of him. From no possible point of view can his position be defended.

In the Supreme Court yesterday Adrian Iselin instituted an action against John D. Adams, Treasurer of the Piqua Club Association, and John H. Ballantine, the owner of almost all of the stock of the association, to foreclose a mortgage of $400,000 on the premises at Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, occupied by the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- All Saints' Memorial ChapeL was the scene this noon of its second wedding of the Summer, a wedding which united two families well known throughout the country and children of fathers distinguished for their services to the Stars and Stripes.
Changes in the stations and duties of Commissaries:

There must be millions of Germans who have never heard of Puget Sound. When Mr. J.J. HILL, the President of the Great Northern Railroad and the Northern Securities Company, declares that "the shortest and cheapest route from the cotton fields to the Orient is by the way of Puget Sound" some Germans, therefore, may be sufficiently interested in the matter to hunt up Puget Sound on the map.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 21. -- In the double-header which was played to-day by the New York and Pittsburg baseball teams each won and lost a game. The local players in the first game hit Mathewson's pitching six times safely and scored two runs. Leever held the visitors to three scattered hits, while the fielding was so good that New York was unable to get a man home.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21. -- "Tom L. Johnson will be the Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1904. He suits us Western men from the ground up," said Frank P. Walsh of Kansas City, the next National Committeeman from Missouri, succeeding William J. Stone, who is practically United States Senator-elect.

The exodus from town began yesterday. This evening there will be a dance at the Meadow Club, at Southampton, and several house parties are planned for the week's end. At Newport to-morrow evening Mrs. Fish's Colonial ball will be held and several smaller entertainments are scheduled.

The Fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club will be sailed on Monday, Sept. 1. Entries have been invited from the New York, Eastern, Seawanhaka-Corinthian, Atlantic, American, New Bedford, New Haven, New Rochelle, Corinthian of Marblehead, Hull, Indian Harbor, Riverside, Horsehoe Harbor, Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia, Sea Cliff, Knickerbocker, Huguenot, Shelter Island, and Manhasset Bay Yacht Clubs.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 21. -- At midnight Superintendent Hayes of the Pennsylvania Colliery at Morea called up headquarters and asked Gen. Gobin to send troops to that place. He said that the foreigners were on the streets discharging firearms, and that he feared an attack on the non-union firemen and engineers was contemplated.

Further ill-natured features disappear from the money market. Those lenders who have been urgently insisting that funds at this centre were bound to grow dangerously scarce, and who have been stiffly insisting upon better than quoted time money rates, were yesterday offering concessions.

ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21. -- In his address at the annual Sanderson Academy dinner here to-day, Prof. Charles Eliot Norton, who as usual was the presiding officer, discoursed upon war. Among other things he said:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- The former tennis doubles champions of England, R.F. Doherty and H.L. Doherty, to-day won the American lawn tennis championship in the doubles. They defeated Holcombe Ward and Dwight F. Davis in three straight sets, the score being 11-9, 12-10, 6-4. This is the first time that an invading team of Britishers has ever been successful in winning a National title in this line of sport on the courts of America.

Gen. SIGEL, had been such a familiar figure on our streets, and seemed always so brisk and alert in his ways, that it is not easy to realize that he was seventy-eight years old. There is something about a German, of a certain type, which not only enables him to grow old gracefully, but hides from the common apprehension that he is growing old at all.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 21. -- When the second day's session of the thirty-sixth anniversary of the Universal Peace Union opened to-day the report of Treasurer Charles P. Hastings of Philadelphia was read. It showed a balance of $762.46 in the treasury after a disbursement of $1,385.80 for the past year.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Redmond gave a dinner at the Casino grill rooms to-night, which was the largest of the evening. The dinner was served in the inclosed section of the piazza, which was transformed into a very pretty dining room by the decorations of Wadley Smythe.

The curb market did not maintain yesterday the improvement shown on Wednesday, and declines occurred very nearly throughout the entire list, the largest losses occurring in Virginia Iron, Coal, and Coke, Tennessee Copper, Seaboard Air Line issues and Rock Island common. Distilling Company of America, securities were quite active, and they advanced sharply.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Green B. Morris's three-year-old Sombrero showed his liking for sloppy going by galloping home an easy winner in the Huron Handicap to-day, three lengths in front of Andy Williams. Sombrero was a strong favorite for the race, and led all the way. John A. Scott, aided by a running start, made every post a winning one in the handicap for two-year-olds.

TUPELO, Miss., Aug. 21. -- A telegram was received here early this morning by Sheriff Long from Deputy Sheriff Samuel Young from Shannon, asking that the Sheriff come immediately to that place, as it was reported three negroes had been killed and that James Randolph, one of the best citizens of the county, who had assisted in the arrest of the negroes, had been shot through the head and shoulder.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 21. -- The local market to-day was less active and less aggressively bullish, though the general tone was satisfactory. There were some issues which receded fractionally, but this was due to profit taking and not a break in the feeling of confidence. There were various points which were slightly better, thus indicating a readiness to advance if general conditions grow auspicious.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Major George A. Armes, a retired army officer, was shot but not seriously injured at his home a few miles outside this city to-day by J. Roland Johnson. Major Armes was able to come to the city, and go to the Army Hospital for an operation to extract the bullet.

"I am satisfied that gamblers in Yonkers are paying for protection, but I was astounded when friends in New York told me I was said to be one of the four or five men among whom the corruption fund was divided."

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Board of Trade grain markets were in a wild state of excitement this forenoon. The most sensational feature of the business was a rise of nearly 5 cents a bushel in the price of corn for next month's delivery. Wheat and oats were also sensationally higher.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Jewelry worth $1,000 is said to have disappeared from a trunk somewhere between Fire Island and this city. It belonged to Mrs. L. D. Guerin, wife of the proprietor of the Mansion House here. She went to Fire Island two weeks ago, and a week later started for home.

BOSTON, Aug. 21. -- At the Clearing House to-day money was in large supply at 4 per cent. New York funds sold at par and 2 1/2 cents for cash. Call loans are quoted at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent., and time money at the same figures. Exchanges, $20,141,626; balances, $1,985,627. The market for stocks was dull and featureless. Complete transactions were as follows:

Gen. Franz Sigel, veteran of many battles both in Germany, the land of his birth, and in America, the land of his adoption, and one of the most distinguished German-Americans in this city, died at 11:45 o'clock yesterday morning at his home, 563 Mott Avenue, Bronx, from general debility, after an illness of several months.

In the Presbyterian Hospital is Mrs. R. M. Springer, wife of a Colorado mine owner who is registered at the Astor House, but is spending all of his time at his wife's bedside. As "Callie" Mills, or "Diana," she was a Washington correspondent for several years.

ST. PAUL, MINN., Aug. 22 -- When J.J. Hill talks of crop conditions, he speaks with authority, and the Great Northern's President says that a conservative estimate of the wheat crop of this year of Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, Idaho, Washington and Northern Oregon will reach upward of two hundred and fifty million bushels of wheat.

The recent action of the teamsters of Chicago in declaring against sympathetic strikes and agreeing that they would not engage in one under any conditions unless two-thirds of their union membership should vote in favor of it, marks a progress toward a clear conception of the true function of organized labor which is gratifying and encouraging.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- The American liner St. Paul, which sails for New York to-morrow via Cherbourg, was to carry the bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair. The bodies, however, are still in the Church of the Madeleine here, the order for their removal having been countermanded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- "There is no question that a very large majority of the people favor Cuban reciprocity as proposed by the majority of the Ways and Means Committee, and erroneously termed the President's policy," said Representative Eddy of Minnesota to-day. "Although I do not agree with the public in this matter, any other statement would be a perversion of fact.
"Hurrah for Kunzeman! What's the matter With Kunzeman? He's all right. Hooray!"
Feb. 13. Dear Mary: I am flattered at the advertising you give me.

ST PAUL, Minn., Aug. 22. -- Although yesterday's discussion of the trust question and the later action of the resolution's committee in ignoring the question had been regarded as the end of consideration of that problem before the TransMississippi Commercial Congress, such proved not to be the case.

MANILA, Aug. 22. -- Civil Governor Taft reached here this morning at daylight on board the United States gunboat General Alava from Singapore, Straits Settlements. He was welcomed with an enthusiastic popular demonstration.

In these years of phenomenal prosperity for the women's college, the girls' boarding school and "finishing school" seem to prosper quite as well. There are now "finishing schools" of every description. A girl can come to the city and be chaperoned anywhere she chooses to go, paying some attention to literary studies.

The English Bookman for August is a George Eliot number. In an illustrative sense it is particularly attractive. There are many unpublished portraits reproduced, and among them Sir Frederick Burtons's famous picture. The publishers of The Bookman express their indebtedness to Messrs.

Fire which is supposed to be of incendiary origin, and which for an hour or more yesterday afternoon gravely threatened the great main building of the New York Catholic Protectory, on the heights above the old village of Westchester, put the discipline of the institution to its severest test, which it magnificently withstood.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The final game of the polo tournament at the Point Judith Country Club was played to-day, and Devon of Philadelphia won the Rhode Island Cup and individual prizes, by defeating Lakewood, 8 3/4 to 8 1/2. Devon was allowed nine goals and played such an excellent defensive game that Lakewood was unable to overcome the handicap.

George W. Cisco, a mechanical engineer, of 329 West Eighty-second Street, was drowned in the North River off Eightyeighth Street yesterday by being upset from a rowboat by the wash of a scow. He and the rowboat were sucked under the scow and neither body nor boat was recovered.

Apropos of "The The Escape of Christmas Kalends of Thomas A. Janvier. Provence," by Thomas A. Janvier, which is in preparation at Harper Brothers, a story was told the other evening relating how the genial author of "The Passing of Thomas" and "An Embassy to Provence" once escaped being a shining light in the guild of professional American humorists.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Hiram Cronk, the only soldier of the War of 1812 now upon the Government pension rolls, is dying at his home in Bunbrook, this county. Cronk is in his 103d year, and has had the distinction of having lived in three centuries. About three months ago his health began to fall, and for some time he has been confined to his bed and is daily growing weaker.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22. -- The activity and gayety which came with the Horse Show have continued throughout to-day. There have been a number of affairs, principally dinners and luncheons. Mr. and Mrs. J.L. Ketterlinus gave a musicale at Bide-a-While, which was attended by most of the Summer people.
LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Money was much wanted in the market to-day in connection with tenders for $5,000,000 in Treasury bills. Discounts were firm.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Aug. 22. -- The announcement that Premier Bond will visit Washington to revive the Bond-Blaine convention negotiations has aroused great interest here.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The attendance at the Goshen races to-day exceeded that of any previous Friday in the history of the track. The two unfinished races on Wednesday, the 2:16 and 2:20 classes, were captured to-day by Beidia and Kid Shea, respectively. Ex-Senator McCarty's mare, Jantina, took the 2:24 class in three heats.

The advice contained in this title is familiar to all Americans, but it is commonly employed rather on ethical than on literary grounds. But we learn from several of our esteemed contemporaries that the practice of reading the Bible is declining in this country, that a Biblical allusion which a generation ago would have been universally understood now is likely in a promiscuous assemblage to fall quite flat, and so on.

The Medical Journal to-day will print an article from a correspondent in Manila on the cholera situation in the Philippines. The attempts which are being made to control the disease are likened by the correspondent to the "spectacle of a dozen men vainly attempting to stamp out a prairie fire."

Thirteen persons were more or less badly hurt in the New York Central Station yesterday afternoon when the Boston express which arrived at 1:58 o'clock crashed into the bumper of track No. 4. Those who were hurt, and most of the other passengers, were on their feet, and all were thrown violently forward by the shock.

Among the oldest and most successful schools of the country and around which center most interesting historical associations of the early years of the Republic, is Friends School at Providence. Five years before Washington took his seat as President it began its first session.

As far back as 1764 one Thomas Green came to Hartford, opened a printing office, and established The Courant, of which Senator Hawley is editor and proprietor. Years ago Mrs. Lydia H. Sigourney shed a mild lustre over the quiet city by her poetical effusions, and two of the landmarks to-day are her former homes on Asylum Avenue and beautiful Sigourney Street.

AT one of those evening gatherings where writers and artists congregate, which were in vogue some years ago, among the guests was a Titania like little woman in gray, with filmy lace about her neck, and a silver bang fringing her forehead.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Mr. Andrew Lang is one of those fortunate men who can believe a great deal. In the course of an article in The Morning Post he expresses his belief in telepathy, crystal gazing, and the divining rod, and intimates that it is by no means impossible that fairies exist and have been seen by credible witnesses.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- The Philadelphia stock market was irregular to-day and a number of stocks that have hitherto been active were hardly touched. Others, which have been but little traded in of late were active and very strong. Philadelphia Rapid Transit, Cambria Steel and Iron Traction were neglected and suffered somewhat.

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- Sixteen Governments and about sixty Chambers of Commerce and industrial associations, says the Brussels correspondent of The Times, will be represented at the International Congress on Commerce and Industry, which meets at Ostend next Monday.

Such a queer girl is Meta Cardew, whose great delight is to dance on the edge of a precipice. Meta is in a certain measure "highly proper," though she does many incomprehensible things. She thinks she is in love with Jack Lawrence, a London stock broker, but with her wild fancy Meta does not understand how she can care for a man who buys and sells things.

When it was announced early in the Summer that Princeton University had rejected the entrance examination papers of eighteen out of thirty-one young men from a certain preparatory school because of unmistakable evidences of "cribbing" that had been discovered, there was manifest a very considerable amount of public astonishment.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- At the Clearing House this morning money between banks was in good supply at 4 per cent., though perhaps not so plentiful as was the case yesterday. New York funds continue in good demand, with sales at par for cash. The President of one of the largest national banks in Boston says:

"In one hand he held a pistol and in the other a knife." That is a line printed in a popular romance, and the situation demanded such a display of arms. Your sympathy had already been excited, because in the description of the personage the hero had lost his left hand in a rencontre with the Indians and the illustrator of the story had drawn a one-handed frontiersman.

J. Pierpont Morgan was interviewed yesterday afternoon by a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES as to his attitude regarding the coal strike. Despite the fact that the operators have gone on record as saying that Mr. Morgan will not interfere in any way in the strike, the financier himself was careful not to make a positive statement on the subject.

The special meeting of the Kings County Republican General Committee last night, which was called for the purpose of selecting the dates for the various local conventions, was largely given over to a series of fierce attacks upon the so-called reformers who are striving to wrest control of the county organization from the hands of Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, Col. Michael J. Dady, and their lieutenants at the coming primaries.

Stead, printed as a kind of a prologue in the volume before us. A candid friend who had read a story by a young writer turned to the blushing author and remarked that the story lacked something. "Your people," he said, "have brains and wit but no blood."

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 22. -- The Rev. Dr. George C. Lorimers pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church of New York, returned from Europe to-day on the Dominion Line steamship New England. He was in Boston but a few hours, and then left for New York. Dr. Lorimer was in England when Gen. Lucas Meyer, the Boer General, died.

To one who all his life has been familiar with the calm serenity of mind that chiefly distinguished the Quaker of a generation since, there is something alternately amusing and pathetic in the efforts of modern devotees of what they are pleased to call "the higher thought" to reach a similar attitude of repose.

Francis B. Robert has sold for es-Gov. George Hoadly to Mayer S. Auerbach 103 and 105 William Street, adjoining the southwest corner of John Street, a plot 42 by 77, now covered by two five-story brick buildings. Ex-Gov. Hoadly bought this property in 1895.

The love of man for woman it is scarcely a new topic for a romance, nor has Mr. McCutcheon treated it in a new way. The old methods are good enough for the modern tale of love, intrigue, and adventure, and the hotheaded knight of the eighteenth century, with his silken cloak and his clanking sabre, has merely changed clothes with the modern young gentleman in frock coat and Prince Albert, whose weapons are pistols.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- This morning there was a weird chase in the grounds surrounding the Department of Agriculture. The participants were Policeman Charlton, the pursuer, and William Walker, colored, the pursued. There were suspicions abroad that Walker had been guilty of appropriating to his own use two empty crates belonging to a citizen of Anacostia, and it was in order that the suspicions might be verified or disproved that Charlton was chasing Walker.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- Social circles here are excited over the elopement and marriage of Miss Marie Nassr, sixteen years old, and regarded as the handsomest young lady in Toledo, with A. George Yarid, an educated and well-to-do young Syrian, who came here from New York and went into the importing business.

With buoyancy in two or three special stocks for exception, yesterday's market was commonplace enough. It was distinctly strong, though. Losses induced by the raids of room traders on the day before were generally recovered, even Colorado Fuel and Iron rising a point or two -- making a more profitable level, perhaps, at which insiders can do some more unloading on their friends.

IS John D. Crimmins among the prophets? Is the noted politician, whose fame has more than captured the country-side, in the list of literary aspirants? So it would seem. John has published a book, yes, and written it, too.

PROF. FRIEDRICH HIRTH, who has been appointed head of the new Chinese Department of Columbia University, was born in the neighborhood of Gotha, Germany, in 1845. His father was an attorney and counselor at law, his mother was the daughter of a French emigrant who had escaped the guillotine during the great revolution.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- After the play was finished to-day in the lawn tennis matches, two important problems connected with the struggle for the National championship honors appeared to be solved. The Englishmen are not invincible, for Dr. Joshua Pim lost to Leo E. Ware in straight sets, while H.L. Doherty came near to being beaten by Richard Stevens.

The home market improved over the condition of the day previous, and a number of gains were made. Only a few, declines occurred, noticeably in Seaboard Air Line issues, while the rest of the market was fairly strong and active. American Writing Paper securities, Montreal and Boston Copper and American Light and Traction common, were, the stocks which made the most substantial gains and retained the same.

VOLUME I. of Doubleday, Page Co.'s Variorum edition of FitzGerald's works has finally appeared, and the remaining seven volumes are to come out this Fall. This new evidence of an American "Literary invasion" has been widely commented on by the English press.

Peter Power, the "vanishing witness," is again a free man. He was associated with George Alfred Lamb, a lawyer, at 135 Broadway, in the suit against the Northern Pacific Railroad Company to restrain that corporation from merging its property with two other roads in the Northern Securities Company.

SPECIAL attention has been directed of late by THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS to a few of the many bibliographical treasures of England purchased directly by or on behalf of American collectors.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The entertaining contribution of Hugh Wade on "Metaphors," published last week, reminded me of an amusing anecdote told of former Congressman Timothy J. Campbell, who became famous by saying to Grovor Cleveland that "the Constitution should never stand between friends."

Not a bit afraid of running risks was Polly Locke, but then she had been brought up in Kansas, and had faced cyclones. Polly is in a pension, call it a boarding house, in Paris, and declares her intention to make the grand tour, take in Marseilles, the Riviera, Genoa, Pisa, Rome, Florence, Verona, Milan, and what may be the purpose of this extended trip?

Manners are serious matters, and the Society of Self-Culture here treats them seriously. Some of the most serious manners, such as those engendered by argumentation and altercation, are not taken up; for, although they may be correct in conveying their intended impressions, they do not come under the head of social usage.

Richard Mansfield, who this season will be seen in probably the most elaborate production of Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" to be put on the stage, arrived at New York on the Cunard liner Lucania yesterday afternoon, after a brief sojourn in England.

A very interesting diary is that which Auguste Laugel kept in our civil war period, a part of which is being published in The Nation. This French visitor not only visited or met at social functions the most of our celebrities in New York and Boston, but he had a letter from President Lincoln passing him within the military lines near Richmond when Gen. Grant was in command.

In the controversy now in progress growing out of the effort to induce the Board of Aldermen to change or modify so much of the Building Code as relates to the use of fire-proofed wood, the position of Superintendent STEWART has been misunderstood. That officer is not opposed to fire-proofed wood, nor has he advocated its abandonment for a return to untreated wood.

Commissioner Lindenthal's sweeping changes in the plans of the Blackwell's Island Bridge are to be adopted. The last vestige of opposition to the radical changes was swept away yesterday when a delegation, representing forty associations of taxpayers of Queens County, called at the office of the Department of Bridges, ready to attack and argue against Mr. Lindenthal's propositions.

Mr. Franz Boas's "Kathlamet Texts," the most recent publication of the Smithsonian Institution, (Bureau of American Ethnology,) is the latest contribution to American folk-lore. Kathlamet is the dialect of the Upper Chinook, and it covers, or once did cover, a wide extent of our Northwestern territory.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Frank L. Kramer of East Orange won the onethird of a mile Grand Circuit Championship race at the National Circuit bicycle meet, which was held here to-day. Major Taylor was to have been a contestant, but did not appear.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Sir Gilbert Parker, who has Just gone to Carlsbad, vigorously denies the yarn published in a Chicago paper concerning the original of Charley Steele in "The Right of Way." He says that he never knew the man Cantwele, from whom it is said Steele is drawn, that he never saw him, and never even heard of him.

WORDS of praise have been written of a man who has given up an assured income from busiess to devote himself to literary work, as a result of which sacrifice our volumes of history have received a valuable addition.

Mr. William Archer is well known not only as a brilliant talker himself, but as a cause of conversation in others. His skill has aroused to strenuous speech an American professor -- anonymous, but not difficult to identify -- whom he found toying with a cigarette in the smoking room of a London club at 11 A.M.

Mrs. Mary E. Stewart of 30 West Ninetyseventh Street, is searching for John Armstrong. Jr., a brother, whom she has not seen since his babyhood. She says that the Society for the Protectjon of Children from Cruelty, to which he was committed in 1883, has in the years between repeatedly declined to give to her or to the boy's father any information as to his whereabouts.

Probably no text in the Bible is, so familiar to men -- and so frequently quoted by men -- as the text which says, "For God so loved the world that He gave His onlybegotten Son, that whosoever believeth on Him should not perish, but have eternal life," (John, iii., 16, R.V.) It has been translated into more languages of the earth than any other saying.

Prospect Park will be the general meeting place of local cricketers to-day, when six of the clubs contesting for the championship of New York will play there. The chief game will be the match between Brooklyn -- last year's champions -- and the team of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, this year's leaders.
LONDON, Aug. 22. -- The Essex County Chronicle says it hears that Cecil Rhodes bequeathed to the Countess of Warwick lands in South Africa which have been sold for $1,000,000.

THE fifth and sixth volumes of Capt. Brinkley's remarkable history of Japan continue the story of that country's growth and development into modern times. The fifth volume commences with an account of financial conditions in which the author gives figures and facts calculated to restore the confidence of foreigners in Japan's ability to manage her financial problems successfully.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The surviving members of a committee appointed twentythree years ago by the Eighth New Jersey Regiment Association to draft resolutions on the death of Gen. Joseph Hooker held a meeting in the City Hall here to-day to draft similar resolutions on the death of Gen. Franz Sigel, the news of whose death was received to-day.

A woman representing herself as Mrs. Jean Harris Hunter, the widow of a onetime member of the Chicago Board of Trade, was arraigned before Magistrate Hogan in the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon on the technical charge of vagrancy and held in $500 bail for examination to-day.

Several glaring illustrations have of late been furnished of the amazing opinion of Judge PARKER of the Court of Appeals of this State, that the right to privacy is not a right which in the State of New York anybody is bound to respect, or which the courts will lend their aid to enforce.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In the July number of Harper's Magazine Prof. Woodberry, Professor of Comparative Literature in Columbia University, applies his comparative judgment to the "Beginnings of American Literature," and in a manner that is interesting for two reasons.

Much is heard nowadays among those interested in education of the new English Education Bill. One of the leading opponents to the measure -- which has the official sanction of the British "Government" -- is the Hon. James Bryce, M.P., author of "The American Commonwealth." Mr. Bryce holds that legislation on this subject in England ought to take five general directions:

TO the general public the name of William Blake is almost unknown, and, strange as it may seem, even among what may be called educated people, scarcely a majority have any definite idea either of his personality or his work.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 22. -- Marcus Hurley took the amateur championship of America at the Coliseum board track tonight by winning the half-mile championship and securing second place in the twomile championship. Root of Boston won the two-mile race after one of the prettiest finishes ever seen on this track.

It is a long time now since Mr. Charles Dudley Warner's Adirondack sketches, called "In the Wilderness," came into being, yet there is folded away in a lap of those mountains a memory of both man and book perennial in its vigor and freshress. Old Mountain Phelps, the one-time guide, philosopher, and friend of Mr. Warner, and the subject of "A Character Study," is still living, though that phrase hardly conveys an accurate impression.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 22. -- An order for the building of one of Edwin Reynolds's Manhattan style of engines has been received by the Allis-Chalmers Company from the Southern Electric Light Company of Philadelphia. The machinery is to be delivered at the earliest possible date.

Arugment on the order of Justice Giegerich to Fire Commissioner Sturgis to show cause why a peremptory writ of mandamus should not be issued against him directing him to reinstate to active duty Chief Edward F. Croker, who was "relieved" by Special Order No. 121, was heard yesterday before Justice Hall in Special Term, Part I of the Supreme Court.

The late Charles Kegan Paul, the distinguished British publisher, is reported by The London Spectator to have been asked whether publishers were "slow to recognize genius." "He thought not," says The Spectator, "and as for the stories of 'masterpieces' going the round of the publishers, he for one did not believe them at all.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- A heavy holding track caused many withdrawals today, and the fields ruled small. It was an afternoon of reversals of form and bad riding, O'Connor, through careless horsemanship, throwing a race away with Carbuncle, and in addition being left at the post on Mamie Worth, the heavily backed favorite for the two-year-old filly handicap.

For the past few months the leading magazines have contained advertisements of a number of institutions which offer correspondence courses in authorship. One or two of these concerns have a department of poetry, in which, it is said, a person may study the art of versemaking under competent instructors, and at length receive a diploma certifying that he has covered the subject and has obtained a reasonble profi- ciency.

Systems, of teaching almost everything have been very greatly changed within recent years, and in the matter of elementary education methods have been subjected to a veritable revolution. This has been especially so in the old-fashioned subjects of reading and arithmetic -- two of the primitive "Three R's."

PITTSBURG, Aug. 22. -- Hanion's Brooklyn baseball team, crippled through the disability of Catchers Farrell and Ahearn, was beaten in both games of the double header by the champions here to-day. This was the second double defeat within three days for the Brooklyn players, as they lost two games in Cincinnati on Wednesday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Peekskill is worrying to-day through fear that it may lose the Baker Underwear Factory. About ten years ago the company was organized here, and it built a factory that has been enlarged twice. It established branch factories at Richmond, Vt., and Tarrytown and Buffalo, N.Y.

BOSTON, Aug. 21. -- Mr. James Jeffrey Roche, the poet and the author of "Her Majesty the King," now holds the controlling interest in The Pilot, of which he has been editor since the death of John Boyle O'Reilly, after serving for some years previous as chief editorial writer.

At West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday the Rochester and Jersey City baseball teams played another double-header and divided the honors. Buffalo won the first game by a score of 10 to 1, and the second went to the credit of the local club by 7 to 3, mainly through the effective pitching and excellent batting of Pfanmiller.

Mrs. Emma Vernon of 1,565 Broadway, Williamsburg, is anxious to find the father of a pretty three-year old boy named Ralph Lawrence Smith. The boy is said to be the son of a well-to-do Manhattan business man, and has been in the care of Mrs. Vernon since he was ten days old.

The Philadelphia Public Ledger quotes at some length the views of Judge R.M. BENJAMIN of Illinois, who has lately studied the laws of Pennsylvania with reference to their bearing upon the present attitude of the coal operators -- a title, by the way, which has become something of a misnomer, since they do not operate.

Those interested in the non-Government military schools of the country -- of which there are more than a hundred -- are expressing great delight that the War College Board has taken up the question of the regulation of the United States War Department to these institutions, and that the regulations on the subject are to be revised.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The United States is a free country; we have laws for the protection of child labor, slavery is abolished, and each citizen is free to accept whatever position is best suited to his capabilities. Under these conditions I believe it absurd for an intelligent man to strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A significant indication of the way in which the issues of the Fall campaign are shaping themselves is furnished from the document department of the Republican Congressional Committee. It is said at that department that of all the speeches sent out by far the greatest number consists of copies of Senator Gallinger's speech on "Prosperity and Protective Tariff."

That a solution of the railway situation in the South is close at hand was demonstrated yesterday when the Board of Directors of the Southern Railway Company, decided to defer action on the preferred stock dividend, which it declared would have ended the voting trust, and to recommend to the stockholders an extension of the voting trust for a period of at least one year.
WOMEN, politics, and fishing had been discussed by the group of good fellows in the hotel lobby. Suddenly the Missouri Colonel, who had been making an astonishing record as a listener, said:

The fifty-fourth annual regatta of the Atalanta Boat Club took place on the Harlem River yesterday, and the members of this old rowing club enlivened the occasion by contesting among themselves in boat races, slippery dobbin, and tub races.

Three-year-old Alice Copstein of 1,470 Webster Avenue was run over and instantly killed at 6:30 o'clock last evening by a Webster Avenue trolley car near Her home. The wheels did not pass over her body, as she remained between the tracks; but the trucks and motors of the car crushed out her life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Gen. A.W. Greely, Chief Signal Officer of the Army, who has just returned from Alaska, reports that before the end of the year Alaska will be connected with the United States by wire. In two weeks, he says, many hundred miles of telegraphic communication will have been established in that Territory between the coast towns and those remote in the interior.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 23 -- The fine weather that prevailed during the week has been taken advantage of by the Summer visitors at this resort, especially those who are fond of outdoor sports. Seabright and Monmouth Beach have the best golf links and tennis courts to be found anywhere, and a number of the cottagers and hotel guests at those two places are considered expert players.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The prices of American securities have been going up all this week, and the markets have been firm and most promising. That the Continent has been buying American rails in considerable quantities is admitted, but the assertion is still frequently made that there are practically no local transactions in them.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 23 -- The August carnival and ball last evening at the Fort William Henry Hotel was the most brilliant social event which has marked the Summer season there for many years. The function was held in the Casino in the hotel park, and was attended by about 500 guests, who included the members of the cottage colony and guests of other hotels.

IF there was one thing that Squire Eph Yokum valued it was horseflesh. His farm, wife, daughters, and all were as nothing in his eyes, said the neighbors, compared to a thoroughbred "beasty." Possibly this was not saying much, for the Squire's farm was simply a little gingery patch of earth and rubble tilted at an angle of 45 degrees between heaven and Modonk Valley, Ky., on Firefly Ridge.

WAWBEEK, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Hoffman Miller and the members of his family have Dr. Herter's camp Birch Island this Summer, and Foxhall Keene has taken possesion of Howard Bucknell's camp across the lake from the Wawbeek.
