Mr. Bucknell is spending the remainder of the Summer at the camp of his mother, Pine Point Lodge.

UNCLE SAM is going to man the guns of battleships with farmer lads who, prior to enlistment, never got a whiff of salt sea air. No other nation in the world has ever made this experiment. Last week, when two training ships came to the Port of New York after long cruises in the West Indies, the officers were able to state that the experiment of making plowboys into full-fledged sailors was successful.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- City people continue to arrive in large numbers, and hotel men assert that there will be little decrease in business until after the second week in September.

TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 23 -- Though Americans, in the Orient are slightly at a disadvantage through the superior numbers of Englishmen and other foreigners, the fact remains that trade opportunities are not grasped by us as they should be. The peculiar trade of the far East requires constant study on the part of our exporters.

READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- With the best card of the week the Grand Circuit meeting at the Readville track ended this afternoon. The great feature was Dan Patch's mile in 2:00 1/4, in his effort to break Star Pointer's figure of 1:59 1/4 on this track five years ago to-day. Dan Patch made a great bid in his first heat to get inside the record, going the half in 0:59 flat, and then breaking.

THE Tailer, family, which comes originally of good old New England stock, is identified with club life in New York. T. Suffern Tailer, who is the son of Edward N. Tailer, is one of the most picturesque members of the family. His club is nominally the Union, but he is looked upon as having been the mainstay of the different Tuxedo organizations.

Sculpture is being applied to public buildings in this country in so much more liberal a way than ever before that the opinion of a sculptor who has had some experience in the architectural use of statuary was sought, in order to discover whether sculptors regarded the situation with favor or disfavor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your discriminating and suggestive editorial on public art in your issue of Aug. 17 is worthy of very careful consideration on the part of all who may be interested in the subject of parks and outdoor art. Permit me to say that already steps have been taken in the direction suggested.

PANAMA, Colombia, Aug. 23 -- Information has been obtained here from revolutionary sources, that up to Aug. 17 the Government Gen. Morales Berti, who has been fighting the insurgents at Agua Dulce, had not surrendered. Fighting in the Agua Dulce district continues daily, but there have been no big engagements since the battle of July 30.

In preparation for the Inter-State Rifle and Revolver Shooting Tournament at Sea Girt, N.J., which begins next Friday, the rifle range and butts have been rebuilt practically, and a new executive building erected. There are now 103 targets at from 25 yards to 1,000 yards. The entries received to date for the competitions show that increased interest is being taken by the military authorities, both of the regular Army and the National Guard.
This year's pleasure jaunt of the Putnam Phalanx of Hartford, Conn., is to be to the White Mountain regions and Portland, Me. They will start on Saturday next and expect to be gone just a week.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew and Mrs. Depew and Chauncey M. Depew, Jr., were among the arrivals on the American liner Philadelphia yesterday morning, which made a record trip on the way over, and it was a little past 6 o'clock when the cutter left the Barge Office for the trip down the bay.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 23 -- Not since the visit here of President Hayes, twenty-five years ago, has a Chief Executive been accorded so brilliant and thoroughly general a reception as that tendered here to-day to President Roosevelt. As representatives of the city. Acting Mayor Freeman, President of the Board of Aldermen, and City Clerk William E. Clarke met the President as he alighted, and extended to him the welcome of the people.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in your issue of the 16th, entitled "Words of Wisdom and Acts of Folly," afforded me great pleasure. It deals very properly with the situation in the coal fields of Pennsylvania.

Frank Castle, amanuensis for the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur of the Calvary Baptist Church, who was accused of stealing $40, some books, and a typewriter from the clergyman's study in the church, was arraigned before Magistrate Barlow, in the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday morning, and held for trial.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Good time was made on the Goshen track this afternoon. Three races closed the annual meeting. Alice Mapes, the favorite, owned and driven by W.H. Snyder ot Brooklyn, captured the 2:15 class pacing, in straight heats against eleven competitors. The favorites in the other two races were badly beaten by Miss Brock and Deputige.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 23 -- After a day of rest from the gayety of the Horse Show society here bloomed forth again to-day. Despite the inclement weather, it has been lively. In the afternoon private theatricals were produced at Mizzentop, the Summer home of R. Hall McCormick. At the Pot and Kettle Club to-night Mrs. William Lawrence Green and Mrs. I. Megargee Wright gave the largest dance of the season.
LONON, Aug. 23 -- Money was more plentiful to-day and rates were easier. Discounts were quietly steady.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- The Philadelphia market to-day was dull and narrow, but in spots was strong. United Gas was the feature. It was strongly bought by local houses, and the price was run up nearly two points to 114 1/2, due partly to the declaration of a Director that the company has completed a deal for the acquisition of large properties in Rhode Island and Connecticut.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 23 -- Polo by day and moonlight automobiling and carriage driving at night and luncheons and dining in the open at the Point Judith Country Club and in the Grecian Gardens have absorbed society at Narragansett during the past week.

Minnie L. Klein, cashier of the Joseph Kraus Company, cigarmakers, at 535-9 East Seventy-fifth Street, was held up by two men in the building of the firm yesterday and robbed of $329, which she had just drawn from the Nineteenth Ward Bank to make up the pay roll. The hold-up occurred on the stair landing between the first and second floors, a few feet from the office of the firm.

Over two hundred thousand shares per hour were traded in during yesterday's short session of the Stock Exchange. Quotations for the active list reflected strength. Commission house transac- tions, representing outside interest, were on a substantial scale, indicating, accord- ing to the popular view, final readiness upon the part of the public to come into the market.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- The first polo game at the Westchester Polo Club grounds at Bateman's Point was played this afternoon between the Country Club of WestChester and Myopia First in the first round for the Brentons Reef Cup. The Westchester Club won by 13 to 5 3/4, both teams playing from scratch.

The idea that a great public building should be so designed that its decorative features are considered from the start and so become closely knit, integral parts of the structure, is familiar to most architects, but it is far from being generally understood and appreciated by the public.
THE reason I haven't been engaged in dead earnest for more than six months was because I couldn't think of any novel way to announce the engagement," said the girl with wavering affections.

Trading on the curb yesterday was extended over quite a number of stocks, and for a Saturday was fairly active. Several sharp advances occurred, principally in American Writing Paper stocks and White Knob Copper. Fractional gains were made in a large number of the stocks, and improvement was shown very nearly throughout the entire list.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 23 -- The Ocean Grove Camp Meeting services were opened last night and the attendance was the largest on record, over 6,000 people being present. The Tabernacle was crowded, and people stood outside, unable to gain admittance. The actual number of communicants was 1,806, or more than 300 above the previous high record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- There is to be a shake-up among the Internal Revenue agents in charge of divisions, one result of which will be that F.G. Thompson, who is in charge in New York, will go to Albany, and will be succeeded by John W. Sinsel, now in Cincinnati.

ASIDE from its exceeding interest as a unique spectacle, the New York Aquarium has, if its management so willed, great possibilities as a public educator. That it has thus far only partially lived up to its possibilities in this direction must be admitted even by its warmest admirers.

Through hard hitting and good all around playing the Jersey City, team easily defeated the Buffalo players yesterday at West Side Park, Jersey City, by a score of 8 to 1. The fielding of the visitors was very poor, and no less than six errors were marked against them. Woods, the local pitcher, held them well in hand for live scattered hits and a single tally.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The many intelligent Americans who have visited Stratford-on-Avon will sympathize with the Englishmen who have lately been protesting vigorously against the gross vulgarization of that place -- the shop in the church lobby, the overcharging of visitors, and the air of paltry meanness which rests over this profitable monument to the Shakespeare idea.

WHITEFACE, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The women who are spending the Summer at Whiteface Inn are devoting much time to the game of golf, and their efforts have been stimulated by Miss Elsie M. Supplee and John Kisterbock, who have offered cups to the winners of the tournaments. Miss Supplee has donated two cups, which are to be the first and second prizes.

NEWPORT, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- President Roosevelt's second day of his journey through New England was a busy one Leaving Hartford, Conn., at 8 o'clock this morning, he arrived at Newport at 9:45 this evening, after having made speeches along the route at Baltic, Plainfield, Willimantic, Providence, and River Point.

OVER in Bay Ridge, between Forty-second and Fiftieth Streets, a great work is unostentatiously being completed, which is nothing leas than the transforming of hilly land into an absolutely level and graded plot of ground, utilizable for railway and docking terminals.

For the Huguenot Yacht Club's eighth annual regatta, which was sailed yesterday, there was a fine sailing breeze that made the amateur sailors rejoice. Forty-seven yachts started, with the thirty-footers the largest of the fleet.

Central Office Detective Frank Price was passing the residence of Victor I. Cumnock, 126 East Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday morning, when he saw a Japanese emerge from the house, which was evidently closed for the Summer, and after walking a short distance meet a countryman, who was evidently waiting for him and who carried a slip of paper in his hand.

The frock worn by the Duchess of Marlborough when she disembarked from the Kronprinz was notable for its taste and its suitability to her very tall and extremely-willowy figure. As the huge steamship drew near the pier, the Duchess, from her figure and the poise of her head, was easily recognized by numbers who had never before seen her, but who knew her by her resemblance to her published pictures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The communication published in your esteemed paper of recent date, (Aug. 15,) which reaches you from far-off India from a philanthropist well known in England as well as in his native land, is of pressing import.
Policeman Flanagan of Jersey City was halted on Grove Street at 11 o'clock Friday night by a well-dressed young couple, who at first appeared somewhat embarrasssed.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The strike at the Baker Underwear Company contin- ues. There were not a score of girls at the machines this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Attorney General Knox returned to the city to-day from his vacation, spent principally at Atlantic City. He will remain only until Monday, when he will leave for New York preparatory to sailing for Paris next Wednesday on the Oceanic.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- The new first-class battleship Maine, looking for all the world like a ship already commlsisoned in the navy, save for the big Cramp flag astern, raced around the Cape Ann trial course today to prove her right to fly the United States ensign. She did it before she finished.

SARATOGA, Aug. 23 -- John F. Carroll is prepared to spring a colonization sensation on his return to New York. For several weeks Mr. Carroll has suspected that colonization was going on in his district, and he set his lieutenants to work to make an investigation. To-night he received a report.

Somewhere on the Atlantic Ocean, bound for Holland, Bessie Finklestein is closely guarded to keep her from making a second attempt at killing herself. On the same steamer, the Rotterdam, of the Holland America Steamship Company, Second Officer A. Levi is modestly avoiding congratulations of the passengers, and Quartermaster Van Huss is sharing in the glory of having assisted in the rescue of Miss Finkelstein.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23 -- Horse Show week has passed in a blaze of glory. It was a brilliant and gay week throughout. The principal winners were A.J. Cassatt, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad; Edward Morrell, Mrs. William Lawrence, Mrs. Green, and Mrs. Clarence Moore.

Whether to order a surrey or a tonneau is one of the moot questions of the day among automobilists who want to own a machine adapted for all-round use, touring included. Whether to make surreys or tonneau is an equally important question among manufacturers. The tonneau style has had a great vogue, first in Europe and subsequently here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At an early stage of the present deplorable strike in the coal regions, when Bishop Potter and Archbishop Ireland, as members of the Civic Federation, expressed a desire to mediate in the dispute between the mine owners and their laborers, they were haughtily informed in a letter from the mine owners that this was a matter of business and not of religion.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 23 -- This is a season of cakewalks, and the waiters from each of the hotels are now having their pleasure and the visitors of the hotels and cottages are thoroughly enjoying and well attending these events. They usually begin about 10 o'clock in the evening and last until 1.

Daniel Murphy, foreman for James Fitzgerald, a paving contractor, was shot at 7 o'clock last night by one of four Italian laborers with whom he had trouble when paying off the employes at Fitzgerald's office, at 537 West Thirty-fifth Street. He was taken to Roosevelt Hospital. Before being taken to the hospital Murphy identified one of the laborers, Rosalla Leone, of 451 West Thirty-ninth Street, as the man who shot him.

WHEN the recent illness of King Edward appeared likely to have a fatal termination the Jacobites of Great Britain prepared to issue a proclamation claiming the Crown for "Queen Mary III, and IV.," and declaring her to be the true monarch and the "representative of the Royal House of those realms."

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Aug. 23 -- The general adoption of flower gardening by all leading American railroads is at most but a short way off. An unexpected enlargement of this branch of railroad evo- lution is apparent this season. One trunk line east of Chicago alone last Spring distributed 30,000 blooming plants to station agents.
SIMPKINS had ideas, but none of them seemed to be worth much. At least they had brought him in very little revenue, and if revenue is not the test of value what is?

There is great scarcity of coal of all sorts, and the price in several cities has been advanced to a prohibitive figure; in places this really seems to have been done with the intention to put off the buying of coal so far as possible until matters are adjusted, when it is hoped that the price will soon be reduced to normal figures, but elsewhere high rates are due to actual scarcity.

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The annual meeting of the members of the St. Regis Yacht Club will be held Aug. 28 at the camp of Anson Phelps Stokes on the Upper St. Regis Lake. The interest in the yacht races continues unabated and a large number of people watch the struggles.

THE meet that day was at the White House Inn. Within the quaint hostelry all was confusion and clatter, the sound of voices rising over all, while without the scene was quite as busy. Tim Martin, the famous huntsman of the Meadowthorpe Hounds, sat on his horse at the side of the road, his charges clustered around him.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Great interest is being manifested by the society people of the Rockaways in the coming Horse Show, which is to be held on Saturday, Aug. 30, and on Monday, Sept. 1, at the grounds of the Rockaway Hunt club. The entries of all the fashionable folk have been received by the management.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The seventh week of the eleventh session of the Catholic Summer School of America at Cliff Haven was an unusually interesting period.

WASH no 'count? Don' say dat, Sah," Uncle Mose was wont to plead. "He's jes' projecin'. Boys will projec', yo' know, Sah. Dey's fo' all de worl' lak calves an' colts an' kittens; w'en dey's young dey kicks up dere heels, den dey steadies down an' chews dere cuds an' pulls dere loads an' ketches dere mice, jes' lak 'sponsible t'ings mus'.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 23 -- Lee Smith, the third of the band of American train robbers who recently held up a Mexican Central train and obtained a Wells-Fargo money package containing $52,500, has been captured in the mountains near Balleza, Mexico, according to a private telegram received here to-day.

The great clock in the lofty circular reading room of the Library of Congres at Washington is at last decorated with the bronze figures originally intended for it. Sketches for some of these figures, which are the design of Mr. John Flanagan, were shown last Winter by the Sculpture Society at the National Arts Club.

The savings banks of Greater New York show phenomenal growth during the past five years. The total deposits of the savings institutions in New York, Kings, Queens, Westchester, and Richmond Counties now aggregate $730,282,698, or enough to give each man, woman, and child in Greater New York a little over $220.

Pale and weeping, the attractive elderly woman who described herself as Jean Harris Hunter, widow of Alexander Hunter of the Chicago Board of Trade, faced nine complaining witnesses yesterday in the Tombs Police Court, where she was re-arraigned on the technical charge of vagrancy, but in reality to answer for a large number of ingenious swindles that, as alleged, she has perpetrated in many parts of the country.

GREAT BRITAIN is once again paying the tribute of the "sincerest flattery" to the United States in the proverbial manner -- by imitation. And the compliment to America is greater in this instance than ever before, because the institution to be imitated is one which, until a short while ago, the English fondly believed was inferior to the similar institution in their own country.

WHEN Gov. Odell comes to town and finds himself with an hour to spare he delights to gather a few of his old personal friends among the political reporters of the Amen Corner about him in a quiet corner of the Fifth Avenue Hotel cafe and chat with them over a drink.

A ROTUND German who had been looking on the beer when it is amber boarded the Coney Island owl car the other morning. Just before the car started he espied a dealer with the last of a supply of live crabs, which he was trying to get rid of at any price.
IT IS to be a fairly long novel, with lots of heart interest, and plenty of adventure," said George Walker, as he grew enthusiastic over the plot that he had outlined to Miss Florence Miller.

COCHICHEWICK has a Fire Department. It is very proud of that Fire Department. That pride is manifested on many occasions -- when no fires are consuming the dwellings of the villagers. When the Fire Department arrived in the town there was a great street parade, with a brass band and an orator.

Stephen B. Elkins of West Virginia ventures the opinion that coal land is a better investment than New York real estate, and others seem of that opinion, judging from the operations heard of from day to day. Every railroad in the country which is hauling soft coal is making money, and there are efforts to secure land, so as to increase tonnage for the future.

SARATOGA, Aug. 23 -- Saratoga is to-day the wickedest place in the country. I write this deliberately, without any desire to be sensational, but with a strong belief that the facts should be known and not "scamped" or blinked at.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- The two days' open-air Horse Show under the auspices of the Southampton Horse Association opened on Friday on the old grounds of the association at Interlaken. Judging from the enthusiasm manifested by the cottage colony so far it is a memorable success.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am an old man, fast verging on three-score years and ten. I had not the advantage of a high school or college education; what little I know I have learned by reading (newspapers principally) and conversing whenever possible with men who knew more and were better informed than I.

A STUDY of slang and of expressions in daily use seldom fails to develop something entertaining. Judgments differ and sometimes opinions as to what constitutes slang may be warped because of the local conditions or usages which govern our estimatings of things.

IF THERE is one thing that Wall Street is fond of doing it certainly is the Western guest. There are, of course, some notable exceptional cases in which the guest has appropriated to himself the title role in the serio-comedy entitled, "The Man That Broke the Bank."

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 23 -- Gen. and Mrs. McCoskry Butt of New York entertained a hundred or more invited guests at their Summer home in the Pequot colony on Tuesday evening. The feature of the evening was a clambake made and served in old-fashioned form. All the prominent society people of the Summer colony were present.

WHILE doubtless many Americans think undue secrecy surrounds the batteries of our new seacoast guns, their sense of security might be greater if they were kept in ignorance of some of the details attending the installation of new material. The American citizen, however, demands to see and know just how his taxes are being expended from day to day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article in Monday's TIMES about Patent Office abuses encourages me to add a few new ideas to the admirable observations and conclusions contained in that article. The future glory of the United States, its material progress, its rank in the forces of civilization will depend largely, as it does now, on the force and capacity of her inventors.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 23 -- The battleships of Admiral Higginson's fleet, which are defending a lengthy strip of New England-coast from a "foreign" fleet, put to sea under urgent orders at 9:30 o'clock to-night, indicating that some news has been received of Commander Pillsbury. The weather conditions at 10 o'clock tonight are slightly in favor of the enemy, the sky being overcast and an easterly blow prevailing.

CATSKILL, Aug. 23 -- The last two weeks in August and the first week in September are recognized as the three heaviest weeks at the resorts in this region, and to-night it would be hard to find a hotel in the region that is not full.

A very amusing complication has arisen in connection with the demand of the Dominion Iron and Steel Company of Sydney, N.S., for the payment of the bounties offered by act of the Dominion Parliament for the encouragement of the metallurgical industries. The company's books show that it has produced enough pig iron and steel to entitle it to bounties amounting to about $200,000.

TO HARRY O'HAGAN, manager of the Rochester Baseball Club of the Eastern League, belongs the distinction of having, without any assistance, accomplished a triple play on the diamond, a feat which no other baseball player ever succeeded in completing.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 23 -- The Board of Governors of the Montclair Athletic Club, at a meeting held recently, decided to place a football team in the field this Fall. A call has been sent out for candidates. Among those who will play are Hirsh of Yale, Burgess of Harvard, Underhill and Harrison of Princeton, and Milne of Amherst.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As germane to your article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 4 on "The Future of Tenement Buildings," I submit the following:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- Mrs. Joseph S. Stevens gave a luncheon at Hill Top Cottage this afternoon in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Bird, the other guests being Mrs. Whitney Warren, Mr. and Mrs. F.O. Beach, Mr. Lanier, Mr. Gregory, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Stevens, and Mrs. Ritchie.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The season is still at its full height, and this has been one of the most brilliant weeks of the fashionable series for 1902. The arrivals continue to be unusually heavy, the departures comparatively light, and to the uninitiated it is a source of wonderment how Saratoga is able to provide for the incoming thousands of health and pleasure seekers.

PANAMA, Colombia, Aug. 23 -- The complications caused by the refusal of the Pacific Steam Navigation Company of Liverpool to transport troops from Buenaventura to the Isthmus on board the steamer Ecuador are not yet ended.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Bureau of Insular Affairs of the War Department has made public the report of Frank H. Bowen, Acting General Superintendent of Public Instruction for the Philippine Islands, upon charges made in the United States against the school system of the islands, alleging that it was used as a proselyting agency against Catholics, and generally used to the prejudice of Catholicism.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 23 -- The children's carnival, which began Monday evening with the ball at the Coleman House, tendered to Queen Titania, the Ruler of Fairyland, and concluded with the midsummer's night festival in the beach auditorium Wednesday night, was a success in every way.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 -- J.C. Mercer Biddle, a wealthy Philadelphia clubman, a conspicuous figure in Quaker City society, and the head of the Biddle family, was very quietly married at the parsonage of St. Andrew's Lutheran Church on Aug. 11 to Miss Anna Teresa Brennan, who has been a resident here since last April, during which time Mr. Biddie had paid her close attention.

Max Mate, fourteen years old, of 38 Orchard Street, sat last night in the Juvenile Asylum on Washington Heights thinking it over. He is only fourteen years old but he knows a good deal more than some boys. He was shooting craps at Henry and Jefferson Streets, when Policeman Langdon of the Madison Street Station joined the party.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- Mrs. Hannah Nelson, mother of the late Mrs. Charles L. Fair, has arrived here from her home in New Market, N.J. She is accompanied by her son, A.G. Nelson of Plainfield, N.J. Mrs. Nelson, who is seventy years of age, was greaty fatigued by her journey across the continent.

It is not to the discredit of lovely woman that she has been endowed with many adorable and exquisite qualities in lieu of the physical courage which is so conspicuous a characteristic of her natural protector. That there should be raised a question as to the relative bravery of the two sexes must be a cause of distress to all chivalrous men.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 23 -- Hanlon's Brooklyn baseball team played its last game of the season with the local team to-day and won by a score of 9 to 8. Both sides did heavy batting, but the bunching of hits by the visitors was more opportune. In the fourth inning Hughes, Sheckard, Dolan, and Donovan hit Leever for three bases each, bringing in four earned runs.

IN about six weeks from now the steamship Silver Town, with 3,000 miles of cable coiled in water-tight tanks, which she is now taking on board at London, will leave San Francisco for Hawaii. Two weeks later the Pacific cable will have been laid to Honolulu, and the continuation to the Philippines will begin.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 -- McGraw's and Donovan's baseball teams played their next to last game of the season in this city yesterday. It was a pitchers' battle between Taylor and Currle, in which the former won. The final score was New York 4, St. Louis 3. In the first inning, with two men out, the visitors scored one run.

YOU know the Woman Across the Way, of course! In a town of tall and variously peopled houses there is always a Woman Across the Way -- nameless -- mysterious -- a window apparition, framed in lace curtains, with the width of the street as a great gulf fixed between.

FRENCHMEN during the religious disturbances which are agitating their country have awakened to the existence of an extraordinary secret society which is said to be involved in the controversy. This extraordinary secret society is known to its members as the "F.D.L.C.," which, being interpreted, stands for "Les Freres de la Cote," (The Brothers of the Coast.)

Frank Kramer of East Orange, N.J., won the quarter-mile championship race yesterday afternoon at the Vallsburg board track in 0:30 2-5. This victory for Kramer earns for him the title of champion at the distance, besides scoring double points in the percentage table of the National Cycling Association.

SARATOGA, Aug. 23 -- The Democratic State Committee to-day decided to hold the Democratic State Convention at Saratoga on Sept. 30. The committee was in session just eight minutes. It was called to order by Chairman Campbell and nearly all the committeemen answered to their names. The few not present were represented by proxies.
SHARON SPRINGS, Aug. 23 -- The event of the week at Sharon was the concert at the pavilion Monday evening.

Henry Miller of 120 Eldridge Street, Morris Cross of 149 Madison Street, and Abe Stein of 185 Madison Street, all with aliases and photographs in the Rogues' Gallery, who were arrested on Friday night by two of Capt. Titus's men on the charge of systematically stealing elothing from lofts, were arraigned before Magistrate Barlow in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning and held in $1,000 bail each for a further examination on Monday.
THE famous Shakespeare Cliff at Dover, England, has been saved from decapitation by the enthusiasm of the Southeastern and Chatham Railway, to whom it belongs.

That modern sanitary science is equal to any emergency, provided the basic principle of following an outbreak of disease to its source be observed, was proved in the recent outbreak of cholera at Cairo, Egypt. There the first case appeared on July 23 in a quarter favorable to the spread of the scourge.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- The past week has had three noticeable features, the lawn tennis tournament, the arrival of the Duchess of Marlborough, and the colonial ball given by Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish at Crossways.

The hull of the Stillman Witt, the first steamboat owned by Cornelius Vanderbilt, lies rotting at an old wharf in Duluth, Minn. Few can recall the career of the old boat, for she went out of commission over a score of years ago.

With a fine track and aided by ideal weather conditions, new records were made in two events at the mid-Summer speed contests of the Long Island Automobile Club at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday. About 3,000 people witnessed the races and exhibitions, but they had few opportunities to enthuse.

Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, who returned to New York recently after a seven months' tour through the Southwestern States am Mexico, brought back definite information concerning the Aztec Indians in the latter country which will prove an unusually valuable addition to anthropology. He learned positively that in Mexico now are the descendants of the wonderful people that Cortez and his fellowlexplorers found there and subjugated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The powers of the worker is great, if he will only use it for his own particular benefit, and why should he not do so instead of throwing away his power and substance by voting for trust representatives and grafters. Republican and Democrats alike, who have given our country's government a name for rascality.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 23 -- The rush to the shore this afternoon and the bookings for to-morrow indicate that the travel for the two days will be nearly or quite as large as for the corresponding two days a week past, but next week will doubtless show a material reduction, and the week following will see a thinning out in the hotel circle.
THERE was a little two-line para- graph in the papers a few days ago containing a piece of news which, it is more than likely, will prove to-have results of very great importance.

The constantly increasing number of transactions affecting property available for improvement with tenements indicates a gradual recovery from the effects of the Tenement House Law -- a conslusion which is borne out by an inspection of the docket at the Tenement House Department.

In regard to the litigation that was instituted, soon after the Boer war began, in connection with liability of underwriters for the value of gold seized by the Boers when in transit from the mines, the London correspondent of The Chronicle says:

THIS is the season when the Atlantic Ocean, is most covered with wrecked vessels that will not sink. In Winter they do not last long, but Summer, kind to tramps of all sorts, allows them to float up and down the seas, a constant menace to navigation. The United States Hydrographic Office, which keeps track of these lone travelers, has issued a bulletin describing those seen lately by incoming vessels.

NEW INN, one of the most curious old landmarks of London, is now being torn down to make room for the coming Central London Avenue. The property was purchased by the London County Council for L157,000.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Game old Advance Guard scored an easy victory in the race for the historic Saratoga Cup at a mile and three-quarters this afternoon. There were five starters, the American Derby winner, Wyeth, being added. Advance Guard was favorite for the event. The race was one of the prettiest ever seen over a distance of ground.
Two events during the past week have directed Wall Street consideration of the affairs of the Southern Pacific Company.

J. Pierpont Morgan remained in his office until about 3:40 o'clock yesterday, although most of the clerks went home soon after noon. Before he went away he was asked if he would supplement what he he said on Friday about the coal strike with something more positive.

DEAR FANNIE: I wish I could die. I've thought of some other things to do, but none of them fit. Perhaps, when you have read this letter, you'll want to die, too; but the thing I shall write which I hate to I do not write to make you want to die, but because you ought to know it.
LOOKING over the expanse of the ocean, Alexander bewailed that there were no more worlds to conquer. At this critical juncture Parmenius rushed up to announce the discovery of the Philippines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The prevalent and increasing tendency toward the covering up and concealment of wrongdoing is a most potent evil threatening the future existence of our political and religious life.

Closely following the Peter Power disclosures (the amazing allegations of Lawyer Lamb and his dummy plaintiff, involving conspicuous Wall Street figures as the promoters and proprietors of "strike" litisation,) comes a chapter in the New Jersey injunction suit against the United State Steel Corporation, wherein David Lama proposes to forbid the Steel Corporation finance plan for the retirement of $200,000,000 of its preferred stock.

SOCIETY will soon be asking the inevitable question that follows every Summer season, "Did they get in?" It is strictly personal, and it may refer to one family or a set of families, and it is the final summing up of the campaign.

NEWPORT, Aug. 23 -- The preparations for the entertainment to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt on Monday night are being pushed night and day so that everything will be in readiness for their novel and costly function. The engagement of the "Wild Rose" company from the Knickerbocker Theatre of New York is only a part of the plan which Mrs. Vanderbilt has arranged for the entertainment of her guests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cynicism shown by the anthracite coal operators in denouncing "political interference" after United States Senator Hanna's unsuccessful effort to effect an amicable settlement of the great strike has caused a good many persons to regard Senator Quay's interest in the subject somewhat lightly.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 23 -- The season shows no signs of drawing to a close yet. Few rooms are to be had at any of the hotels.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Maximiliane Staedler, a woman writer of Munich, has sent a circular letter to leading artists in Germany asking their views on the Kaiser's criticism of modern art. The results of the inquiry are to be published in book form.

Another step was reached yesterday in the famous suit at law of Dubois versus The Cities, when Arthur H. Masten, Special Master in Chancery, filed his report in the Clerk's Office of the United States Circuit Court. It contanis 700 typewritten pages and deals with the amounts to be paid to Judson Harmon, Seymour Harmon, and Henry Clark Johnson for legal services in the plaintiff's behalf.

CHILDWOLD, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Notwithstanding the unusual season both in city and country, the number of visitors at Hotel Childwold has this year broken the record. The cool weather is favorable for exercise, and those who are not playing golf are busy walking the trails.

A PROBLEM that may now be well on the road to solution, despite the fact that all similar efforts have failed for 100 years, is the raising of raw silk in this country, the marketing of it to American manufacturers, and the growing of the silk worm on a large scale.

The new race track at Buffalo, on which racing will be conducted under the sanction of The Jockey Club, will be opened for its first meeting next Saturday. The equipment of the course is thoroughly modern. The plant includes a grandstand, with seating capacity approaching 4,000, built entirely of steel, with concrete floor for the seating.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 23 -- Henry Clay Frick has been brought out as a candidate for the United States Senate. Mr. Frick is in Massachusetts at present, and in consequence his views could not be learned.

A DISPATCH from Victoria, B.C., the other day said that the treasure hunting brigantine Blakley had returned from an unsuccessful trip to Cocos, where she had been to search for treasure supposed to be burled on the island by the crew of the Nova Scotian bark Mary Deer.

This week is the forerunner of the new season. Several first-class attractions already are on, the Broadway and the Garrick opening this week. Within another week or ten days nearly every Broadway house will be ready for business. The majority of the principals are back from their vacations, and all plans are practically settled for the first half of the season.

The contention of one Sutton on an appeal from a judgment convicting him of a violation of Section 5,072 of the Statutes of Vermont, making it criminal to defame a court of justice, was that Judge Watson, who presided at his trial, was disqualified from so acting by reason of the fact that he was a member of the court alleged to have been slandered.

The remarkable development of the banks in New York City during the past five years has been more than equaled by the trust companies during the same period: and if the same gain is made during the next five years, champions of the trust companies prophesy that they will then be far in the lead of the banks.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- Miss Bessie Abbott, coining from Mont Dore, passed through here on Tuesday with her mother and sister on her way to La Ferme, on a visit to the Marquis and Marquise de Montault at their chateau. She returns on Sept. 1.
The following article from a correspondent, condemning the policy of excluding Chinese labor from the Philippines, appeared in The London Times yesterday, (Aug. 23):

MORE than 3,000 visitors, each with $10,000 or more to spend, are in New York. They are buyers for out-of-town firms and serve as a sort of advance guard for twice as many more who will be here between now and the middle of September.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

MR. SCHWAB'S "breakdown," or "threatened breakdown," or "slight illness," or "indisposition," or "tired feeling," or whatever it may be that has started the rumors is moving all the lazy fellows on both sides of the Atlantic to noisy sympathy.

What is known as "nature study" is just now the popular educational fad in England. It represents a reaction from overdependpnce upon the conventional curriculum which is characteristic of the professional pedagogue, and if not carried too far or developed in wrong directions will be productive of very wholesome and beneficial results.

An active market and a strong one closed the Stock Exchange week. Commission house transactions were in new volume. Out-of-town orders begin to be noticeable market features. The "public" is not so careless of what goes on round about Wall Street as recent inactivity may have seemed to suggest.

A NEAR relation of the late Baron Munchausen on the maternal side, lineally descended from Ananias and Sapphira, was telling a party of friends about treeing a bull buffalo in one of the great trees of California.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Aug. 23 -- The annual midsummer hop took place at the Belmont House on Friday evening. The opening march was led by Alexander Elliott, Jr., and Mrs. John L. Kirk, followed by Mr. and Mrs. M.J. Pendergast, Mr. Kirk and Mrs. Elliott, Mr. and Mrs. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. Woodruff, Mr. Young and Miss Riley, Mr. Potts and Miss Black, Mr. Burnett and Miss Bradley, and many others.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 4 per cent. New York funds sold at par and 5 cents discount for cash. Call loans were 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.: time money 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Clearing House exchanges were $18,036,150, and balances, $1,563.75.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 23 -- This week was the banner one of the season at this resort.
MERCY ME!" sighed Mrs. Pedagog, as she put down the morning paper to attend to the steaming coffee pot "I don't know what we are coming to through all these strikes we're having."

THE "honor scroll" of life savers for the Summer of 1902 is now being made up by the officials of the Volunteer Life Saving Corps. Heroes to the number of sixty-five have already shown their right to wear medals by valiant rescues of people at the risk of their own lives from watery graves.
THEY sat in the hammock, he and she, swinging the hours away in a happy manner peculiar to lovers. Finally he whispered in her shell-like ear:

KINGSTOWN, Island of St. Vincent, Aug. 21 -- A highly interesting ceremony was witnessed yesterday in the blessing of 116 houses erected by the Government for the settlement of sufferers by the recent eruption of La Soufriere.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- King Lewanika has departed for his kraal in Barotseland, Northwestern Rhodesia, with much impedimenta, one of the most cherished items of which consists of six silk hats.
THE abolition of the "likin" in China, which was announced in a recent decree from Peking, removed one more of the picturesque institutions of the Celestial Empire.

The latest discovery in the way of a rheumatism specific points to the industrious bee as holding the key to the mystery which has baffled investigators since the beginnings of medicine. As in the case of most great discoveries, this seems to have been found out by accident.
In an affidavit made by George W. Perkins of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co., in connection with the present litigation, official history of the Steel Trust's bond conversion plan is given.

Ex-Chief Devery changed his usual Sunday programme yesterday. Instead of riding around to be admired, he went fishing with three friends. Devery caught more than 500 pounds of fish, so he said, and caused them to be distributed among neighbors, friends, and the poor.

Uncle Sam's in a fair way to have his head turned by the interest taken in him by royalty. We have it on the authority of European writers celebrated for their acumen that nothing exerts such a startling change in the deportment and the manners of a subject as notice, however perfunctory, from some one within whose veins trickles a little stream of royal blood.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Whether or not the exhuming of the body burled in Calvary Cemetery as that of Minnie Mitchell shall develop that the missing girl's family was correct in accepting the body as that of their missing daughter, the police have secured ample evidence to indicate that some young woman was lured into the basement of the Bartholin house on the Wednesday night that William Bartholin and his sweetheart vanished from sight.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The timid who were superstitious enough to believe that the tidal wave predicted by the Rev. Mr. Jones would come had their chance to believe its arrival was not far off this morning. An unusual storm prevailed off Cape May between 11 and 12 o'clock, when a succession of waterspouts formed, probably eight miles at sea.

The fine weather yesterday had the effect of stirring local oarsmen to such activity that every boat in the boathouses on the Harlem River was put in commission by the pleasure oarsmen. The racing element started early for the usual haunts on the Sound, at Donnelly's, Willets Point, Point View, and Berrian's Island.

Commissioner Homer Folks of the Department of Public Charities has sent to Mayor Low his second quarterly report. The improvements made in the hospitals and almshouses are set forth in detail. Commissioner Folks reports that during 1901 the diet at the Almshouse was very seriously reduced below the amount required for the proper nourishment of the sick and aged as indicated by dietary tables prepared by experts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The death of Ensign Frederic R. Holman of the navy on Aug. 13, aboard the Celtic while on the way from Manila to Sydney, Australia, is reported in a dispatch received at the Navy Department to-day from Capt. Speyers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Two baseball games were played here to-day between Brooklyn and Chicago. The visiting team won the first by a score of 7 to 2, and was beaten in the second 8 to 5. In the first two innings of the early game Hanlon's men made six runs by lively batting and the help of errors by the local fielders.

The first War Minister in the late "Cabinet of Republican Defense" was doubtless a brave soldier, an admirable organizer, a distinguished aristocrat, and, withal, a wholesome public servant and citizen. He had proved himself to be worthy of these titles even before his term in the Waldeck-Rousseau Ministry conspicuously identified him with them.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 24. -- Details of the capture of the Colombian Government gunboat Boyaca by the insurgents outside Panama have reached here. The Boyaca was captured on Aug. 1 by the insurgent gunboat Padilla after a short and unequal fight. She had on board at the time nearly 300 soldiers under the command of Gens.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Harry Pike, aged thirty-three years, who came here from New York City and secured the position of night cook in the Washington Hotel, Broadway, early in July, met with a tragic ending at 2:30 o'clock this morning, for which Joseph White is held on the charge of homicide.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 24. -- The naval search problem on the New England coast was terminated at 5:40 this morning by the signal "Surrender; demand unconditional," from Rear Admiral Higginson's flagship, and the reply "Accept surrender," from the foretruck of the Prairie, Commander Pillsbury's flagship.
The Sulphur Springs (Texas) Gazette has a plan to destroy the boll weevil.

Thousands of men, women, and children yesterday paid homage to the memory of Gen. Franz Sigel, whose body reposed in state for more than three hours in the main hall of the Melrose Turn Vereln, on Courtlandt Avenue, in the Bronx. Many thousands were turned away because time did not permit of their passing through the hall.

One interesting feature in the supplemental affidavits filed by the United States Steel Corporation with the Chancery Court of New Jersey is an official denial that a long list of parties named by David Lamar's complaints are participants in the syndicate agreement. These are parties whom Mr. Lamar schedules as J.P. Morgan Co.'s associates and who are now officially eliminated:

One of a crowd of fifteen Italians was run over and fatally hurt at Jerome Avenue and Potter Place last night by a Union Railway Company trolley car. The other Italians mobbed the motorman, John O'Neill, of West Farms, pulled him off the car, and attempted to drag him to a tree frith the apparent intention of hanging him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- "The Submarine and Land Telegraphs of the "World" is the title of a monograph prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics which will appear in the forthcoming monthly summary of commerce and finances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- "So far as the action of the Republican Party is concerned," writes Representative Newlands from his home in Nevada in a letter received in this city to-day, "whatever may be its verbal expressions, it is against the President and not in sympathy with his reform views, though it will exploit them before the public for the purpose of securing an extension of power.

The by-election in Kent, in which the Conservative majority of 4,800, given at the general election of 1900, has been cut down to 800, is very well adapted to startle the Ministry and to encourage the Opposition. It is accepted on all hands as symptomatic, the Government candidate being the same who ran before, and having in the meantime done nothing to forfeit the personal confidence of his constituents.

GEN. DE GALLIFFET AND THE DREYFUS CASE. -- The curious animosity expressed by Gen. de Galliffet toward the unfortunate Dreyfus is explained in Dreyfusard circles in Paris on the ground that it is only a phase of the ex-Minister of War's scheme to grain popularity in a less worthy and more ostentatious manner than is offered should he simply sphere to his principles of 1899.

KIEL, Aug. 3. -- Striking results have just been obtained by the German battleships in the firing competition held in the Strand Bay, near Kiel. The German Emperor watched the firing from the bridge of the Kaiser Friedrich III., in a fresh breeze from the northwest. The Kaiser Friedrich III. opened the firing with her 15 centimeter quick-firing guns on a floating target towed by the cruiser Hela.

Recent investigations to determine the quality of the air in the underground tubes of London give results of interest as indicating what may be expected in the tubes and tunnels of this city. These show that the atmosphere inside tunnels into which no locomotive discharges its mephitic and offensive breath is vitiated by about twice as much carbonic acid as the statute recognizes as permissible in the air of crowded workshops and factories.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24. -- Dr. Jeremiah W. Jenks, special Commissioner of the United States in the Orient for the War Department, and Professor of Political Economy and Politics in Cornell University, has returned from his year's journey throughout Europe and Southeastern Asia, and is passing a few days with friends at Stanford University.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 24. -- Leander Smith, colored, angered because Boyd Clinton was paying too much attention to his wife, shot and instantly killed Clinton in the Hotel Canfield basement last night and then shot his wife, who is dying in the City Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- An official report of the trial trip of the first-class battleship Maine over the Cape Ann course yesterday was received at the Navy Department to-day from Capt. Train, the President of the trial board. It reads as follows:

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The Tlmes's correspondent at Oporto says that the Portuguese, who are not allowed to import foreign flour, have just discovered that they have been living on bread adulterated with such things as ground rice husks, china clay, and sawdust.

NAHANT, Mass., Aug. 24. -- President Roosevelt arrived here this evening to be the guest of Senator Lodge. Traveling on Sunday was something new for the President, but in this instance he was obliged to depart from his usual custom, as he went to Newport for no other purpose than to attend the christening, and it was necessary to make the short journey to Nahant to-day in order to maintain his schedule.

Bijou Fernandez has cancelled her contract for the part of Allison Deyo, which she played in "Hearts Aflame" at the Garrick last season. Miss Fernandez's mother made objection to the part, an the pleas of the author, Mr. Haines, failed to have the judgment reversed.

NEWPORT, Aug. 24. -- The largest social affair to-day was a luncheon given by Henry Walters on the steam yacht Narada in honor of the Duchess of Marlborough, forty-five guests being entertained. The luncheon was served on four tables, decorated with American Beauty roses, vases of the same flowers being used also to decorate the salon.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- United States Senator Hanna arrived in Buffalo to-day from Niagara Falls. He was accompanied by his daughter, Miss Ruth Hanna, and her friend. Miss Phelps of Cleveland. They were on their way home to Cleveland from Niagara Falls. After a drive around the city they returned to Cleveland to-night on the boat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me, Mr. Editor, to express my profound appreciation of your editorial entitled "Free Speech in Ashfield and in Broome Street," which editorial appeared in the edition of the 23d inst. The parallel there drawn between the anti-imperialist and the Anarchist evidenced a power of generalization and a keenness of discrimination rarely to be met with elsewhere than in the editorial sancium.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Cupid made a jail delivery here last night. Adam Floyd was about to be married to Miss Anna Griner at her home when a constable appeared and seized the bridegroom on a charge of petty larceny.
We call the attention of President ROOSEVELT to the misconduct of one of the servants of the people, WILLIAM MICHAEL BYRNE by name, United States District Attorney for Delaware.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 24. -- In a head-on collision between two trolley cars on the Bay Shore Terminal line late this afternoon three people were killed and many others badly injured.
Senator Thomas C. Platt, greatly refreshed by his outing at his son's camp in the Adirondacks, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

NEW ALBANY, Ind., Aug. 24. -- In a disastrous freight wreck on the Southern Railway near Georgetown, ten miles west of here, early to-day Engineer "Red" Duval, Fireman B. Cox, and Brakeman Ross of one train were killed outright, and Engineer Harry Goodall and Fireman George Myers of the other train were probably fatally hurt.

In a variety of ways the New York security market may have to submit to searching tests this week. Of bad business conditions none can be discovered. All commercial, industrial, and agricultural conditions are good conditions. Some further pessimism can be counted upon from the money market critics who have spent six futile months in daily apprehension of high rates, canceled loans, squeezes, and enforced liquidation.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 24. -- A political combination is being formed in this city which will seriously affect the future leadership of Senator McComas on the Republican side and the expectations of Mayor Hayes on the Democratic side. Ex-United States Marshal William F. Airey and A. Freeman Rasin, the Democratic boss of Baltimore, are said to have joined forces.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24. -- New York's baseball team and the local players fought an eleven-inning battle here this afternoon, which was won by the St. Louis team by a score of 4 to 3. The visitors held the lead up to the end of the seventh inning by scoring in the second and sixth innings. St. Louis tied with two tallies in the eighth, and each side made one in the tenth.

President ROOSEVELT in his speech at Providence declared it to be his belief and judgment that the Federal Government must assume the power to control the trusts and corporations, and if Congress has not that power already under the Constitution the power must be conferred upon it by a Constitutional amendment.

A score of husky descendants of the old families of "Corcoran's roost," who have passed down in local history as earlier advocates of the strenuous life, attempted yesterday to revive the reputation of the "roost" along the same line, by "doing up" a policeman, which was the favorite pastime in the years gone by.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25. -- United States Senator A.G. Foster of Washington, who is in this city, is authority for the statement that President Roosevelt will reach this coast next Fall. The Executive will be accompanied by his wife and family, and will remain, it is said, in San Francisco for at least three days.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 25. -- The track at Narragansett Park was lightning fast this afternoon, and the Grand Circuit opened with an afternoon of record-breaking. Every heat winner lowered old marks. The 2:20 pacing stake developed the most excitement, and lengthened into a fiveheat contest.

In another column Mr. HENRY LOOMIS NELSON rehearses the short and simple annals of the poor New Rochelle taxpayer. The facts are presented with the knowledge and emphasis that come from personal interest in the matter, and they deserve attentive study, for they illustrate many evils too common in American municipalities and the great difficulties encountered by those who, with more or less wisdom and sincerity, attempt to remedy those evils.

The success of "The New Clown," which was produced last night at the Garrick, hangs by a very delicate thread. As first played in London last Spring, the principal part was taken by Mr. James Welch, an exceedingly capable low comedian of the higher sort, with a natural grace and vivacity which was thoroughly trained by apprenticeship to Mr. Beerbohm Tree.

The neighboring city of New Rochelle furnishes a short story in municipal corruption. The truth has been brought to light by the intelligent and patriotic services of Mr. Columbus O'D. Iselin. Nearly a year ago Mr. Iselin, being one of the large taxpayers of the young city, made up his mind to ascertain its financial standing.
The scenes of New England life in "Quincy Adams Sawyer" continue to attract at the Academy.

For some time business men on the lower west side have complained of the lack of dock facilities, especially as they related to the coal, wood, brick, lumber, lime, cement, iron, sand, and other business interests in that section. There has been much correspondence between Jeremiah Pangburn, Secretary of the Coal Trade Protective Association and Dock Facilities Committee, and the officers of the Dock Department.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- The National conference on uniform State laws began its meeting to-day at Saratoga, and will continue to-morrow. It meets each year two days previous to the meeting of the American Bar Association, which body lends great aid to the work of the conference.

-- With apprehension practically indistinguishable from terror, we await the effects that will be produced, and the denunciations that will be excited, when a remark which was uttered by President ROOSEVELT just before he departed from Newport makes its way up into the lofty regions inhabited by the only inhabitants of the United States who still "cherish the ancient ideals" and who clearly see "the doom toward which we are rushing."

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- Rates for money hold firm. Clearing House rate, 4 per cent.; New York funds, par and 5c discount; call loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; time money, 4 1/2@5 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $14,787,736; balances, $1,052,238. The weekly statement of the associated local banks issued to-day shows a loss in the reserve of $247,885.

LYNN, Mass., Aug. 25. -- Nahant and Lynn to-day again divided honors in welcoming the President. He spent a quiet morning and afternoon at the Lodge house, and at 2:30 o'clock started for the platform in Nahant where he was to deliver his address. Simultaneously with the moving of the procession a battery near by fired a salute of twenty-one guns.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The experiment of an Autumn season of cheap opera in English was successfully started at Covent Garden to-night with the production of "Carmen." Zelie de Lussan appeared in the title role, and Anna Nikisch, an American, made her debut as Micaela. Both created a good impression.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- The polo team of the Country Club of Westchester won the Brenton's Reef Cups to-day by defeating the Point Judith Country Club in a hard-fought game. The match took place on the grounds of the Westchester Polo Club at Bateman's Point. The final score was 12 3/4 to 5 1/4 in favor of Westchester.

The appointment of Mr. CHARLES DENBY, Jr., to be "Chief Foreign Adviser" to the Viceroy of Pe-chi-li is an event of high significance. No doubt Mr. DENBY is personally acceptable to YUAN-SHI-KAI, but the purport of the appointment is far more National than personal.

A series of three games was begun in Jersey City yesterday by the Worcester baseball team. The visitors gave a very poor exhibition of fielding, eight errors being marked against them. The home players batted freely, the best work being done by Halligan, Griffen, and Mack. Capt. Carr of the local club was put out of the game in the first inning for protesting a decision made by Umpire Sharkey.

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- The week's work for President Roosevelt in his trip through New England began in earnest this afternoon, when he departed from the beautiful Summer home of the junior Senator of Massachusetts, Henry Cabot Lodge, at Nahant, and amid the enthusiasm of the greatest number of people he has faced since the Pittsburg visit on July 4, rode into Lynn under cavalry escort and spoke from a platform at City Hall.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

Among the passengers to arrive from London on the Minnehaha yesterday were J.E. Dodson and his wife, Annie Irish, who make their debut as joint stars in October under the direction of Joseph Brooks. Mr. Dodson went to England in the early Spring to play the part of Simonides in the production of "BenHur" at the Drury Lane.

William S. Devery defied his enemies last night. He denounced David B. Hill, and said that he would be a delegate to the State Convention and that neither the ex-Governor nor any other politician would dare to lift a finger to keep him out of the convention hall. Mr. Devery's indignation reached a high pitch.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Speaking at a meeting of the Milford Docks Company in London yesterday, the Chairman, Mr. Newbon, said he had reason to hope that Milford would become the terminal port of the British-Canadian fast mail service.

Harry de Windt, the famous traveler, who started from Paris on Dec. 19, 1001, for a long, roundabout journey to New York for the purpose of investigating the possibility of building a railroad between the two points by way of Siberia and the Bering Strait, arrived in this city yesterday and registered at the Imperial Hotel.
L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for E.J. Donner to Daniel B. Freedman the American basement dwelling 243 West One Hundred and Second Street, 18 by 100.11.
LONDON, Aug. 26. -- In an editorial article to-day The Times says that the economic situation in the United States is watched by business men in Europe with the keenest interest.

Two firemen were injured, two women rescued, about forty employes driven to the street in panic, and damage to the amount of $50,000 done in a fire which started early last night in the four-story plant of the Perfecta Packing Case Company at 504 and 506 West Fourteenth Street and destroyed the building.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- There were an unusual number of dinners to-night, several of them for parties which went later to the Vanderbilt entertainment. Among those giving dinners were Mrs. Pembroke Jones, Mrs. Ogden Goelet, Mrs. Joseph F. Stone, George G. Haven, Mrs. J. T. Thompson, Mrs. J. De Forest Danielson, and Gen. Lloyd S. Brice.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The total value of the precious metals produced by the United States in 1901 amounted to $111,795,100, which was $1,964,100, or 2 per cent. less than the yield for 1900, according to the report of the Director of the Mint, George E. Roberts.

Activity and advancing prices characterized yesterday's stock market. Saturday's excellent bank statement, the continuing favorable crop news, the knowledge of pending and important railroad deals, more especially in respect to the Southern group of railways, the many evidences that the coal strike is disintegrating, and the confident declarations as to the future expressed by Mr. Morgan and Mr. Keene -- these were among the factors contributing to the improved and improving market tone.

BAR HARBOR, Maine, Aug. 25. -- Abram S. Hewitt, when asked to-day whether he did not consider that arbitration was the only means remaining which might end the anthracite coal strike, and if he did not think it an equitable solution of the difficulty, said:

William Ziegler, the promoter of arctic exploration, whose life aim is the discovery of the north pole by an expedition equipped by him, confirmed last evening at his country home, at Noroton, Conn., a report that the relief ship Frithjof, which is believed to be at Franz Josef Land, carried an expedition party whose work will be distinct from anything that Evelyn Briggs Baldwin may do.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A report issued by the Census Office to-day shows a capital of $40,813,793 invested in the manufacture of locomotives in the twenty-eight locomotive works reporting for the United States in 1900. This represents the value of land, buildings, machinery, tools, and implements, and the live capital utilized, but does not include the capital stock of any of the manufacturing corporations engaged in the industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- The Philadelphia market moved about in a confused state to-day and presented a peculiar aspect, in that it was broader, but the day's aggregate trading was much smaller than the recent average, some of the more prominent stocks being laid aside, while the interests heretofore identified with their movements turned their attention to other shares.

NAHANT, Mass., Aug. 25. -- Among the incidents of the President's day here was the arrival of a barge containing a number of the President's admirers at the entrance of the driveway at the Lodge residence. After swinging a large American flag over the gates they, gave "three cheers for Roosevelt" and departed.

John F. Carroll returned yesterday to the city after a sojourn of about two months at Saratoga. His return marked the beginning of active open hostilities between Mr. Carroll, who for years was practically the leader of Tammany Hall, as the deputy of Richard Croker, and Charles F. Murphy, at present a triumvir, who has aspirations to be the leader of Tammany Hall.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- Another victory was added to-day to the unbroken record of the famous English lawn tennis players. H.L. Doherty, the champion of England, won in three straight sets from the old-time Harvard player, Leo E. Ware. The result brings the Dohertys opposite each other in the semi-final round.

HELENA, Mon., Aug. 25. -- Residents and prospectors of Hope Gulch, twelve miles from Helena, are wild with excitement over discovering a vein of gold ore which runs $800 to the ton, and this vein is believed to be the lead of rich deposits which in early days made the Gulch famous as a placer camp.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25. -- The local market developed nothing in the way of feature to-day, but was rather favorable in tone. International Trust and United States Fidelity and Guaranty Trust both manifested an upward tendency and were counted among the firmest issues in the list. Trading generally was more or less sluggish, due to a growing disposition to wait, the purpose of the wait being to cipher out the probable future of Wall Street.

J. Pierpont Morgan reached his office at noon yesterday and left at 3:30 P.M. without seeing any committee in reference to the strike of the coal miners. Mr. Morgan simply waved his hand in dissent to a group of reporters, who wanted to talk to his as he was leaving, and drove rapidly away in his carriage.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The demand for money increased to-day, and supplies were restricted. Any prospective ease is regarded as likely to be momentary, and it is anticipated that there will be a general stringency for some time to come. Discounts were firm.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 25. -- Hanlon's Brooklyn baseball nine played their last game of the present season here to-day and the local team won by the score of 8 to 6. In the first inning Kitson, who pitched for the visitors, was hit safely six times and this, together with three fielding errors by the Brooklyns, scored five runs for the home team.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- One of the issues of the Congressional campaign, it is beginning to appear, is the case of Rear Admiral Schley. It is not an issue everywhere, at least not at present, but in certain States it is unquestionably an important factor in the situation.

At the stated meeting of the anti-Quigg Republicans of the Nineteenth Assembly District, at 171 West Sixty-fifth Street, last night, called to hear a report of a committee that had under consideration the selection of a leader for the district, Dr. E.M. Moffett presided and there were about sixty present.
LONDON, Aug. 26. -- The Times publishes the text of a valedictory message from the Shah of Persia to King Edward. It was sent from Calais, and is in French. The message follows:
LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Money was in good demand to-day for the payment of railroad dividends and for Stock Exchange purposes. Discounts were firm.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt and his party, amid the booming of a salute from the guns of a light artillery battery, were received in this city by Mayor Leonard and Postmaster Byron Truell and members of the City Government to-day.

Believing himself to be incalculably wealthy, intent on buying everything that is for sale, and possessed of the idea of establishing at the Thousand Islands the finest Summer resort in the world, William H. Riker of 222 West Twenty-fourth Street has negotiated during the last fortnight for the expenditure of several million dollars.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Advance Guard captured the Champlain Handicap at a mile and a furlong this afternoon through sheer sameness, wearing down Dublin in the last few yards and winning at the end by half a length. Dublin who was the best horse at the weights, but the bad start he got and ill-judgment of pace on the part of Shea, his rider, caused his defeat.

In his discussion of the coal strike situation Mr. ABRAM S. HEWITT makes certain statements which are of sufficient interest to challenge attention if correct and to invite contradiction if wrong. We refer especially to the following synopsis of the issues of the strike now in progress:

The movement of prices in yesterday's stock market -- the most active in many days, with a total of more than a million and a quarter shares -- was highly irregular, but, the facts considered, altogether natural. In the early trading, conducted on a scale of unusual activity, prices advanced through the list, as a result of a not unsubstantial public demand coincident with a continuation of bankers' buying.

LEWISTON, Me., Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt was extended a most cordial reception to-night by the citizens of Lewiston and Auburn on the occasion of his visit to the twin cities. The President arrived in Auburn at 6 o'clock, and was escorted to City Park, Lewiston. where from a platform he spoke.

LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 26. -- For twentyfive minutes to-day the city entertained the President of the United States as its guest and then watched him depart for New Hampshire and Maine, giving him a hearty cheer as the train, pulled out.

Justice Giegerich, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, denied the application of Charles T. Barney for an injunction restraining the further construction of the rapid transit tunnel under Park Avenue from Thirty-fourth to Forty-second Street, on the ground that there had been a substantial departure from the plan as authorized by the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26. -- The local market developed nothing of interest to-day, though there was an apparent recrudescence of some recently exploited rumors. The strength of Atlantic Coast Line was the nearest thing to a feature, its upward movement giving rise to notions that Sea-board is on the verge of starting in on another advance.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26. -- Miss Julia Lamont, daughter of Daniel S. Lamont, former Secretary of War, died suddenly to-night at Sorrento. The news came as a great shock to the friends of the Lamonts here, for, although it was known that Miss Lamont had been in poor health for some time past, she had of late showed signs of improvement, and her complete recovery was expected.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- There were more evident signs to-day of the mimic War which is to take place off Newport next week, particularly evident to the inhabitants of the city, who were aroused from their early morning sleep by the booming of heavy cannon, and many thought that the army and navy manoeuvres had begun.

The leap from the Brooklyn Bridge proved tempting for one more man yesterday who had tired of life. He is believed to be Michael Cody, colored, of 16 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn. His identity was indicated from papers in his pockets. The man was taken from the water and now lies unconscious it the Brooklyn Hospital.
PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 20. -- It was 2:10 when the Presidential party reached here. As the train rolled into Union Station a National salute of twenty-one guns was fired by the Portland Naval Reserves.

ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Possessed by the "speed madness," Frank J. Matthews, a well-known real estate broker and clubman of Jersey City, ran his automobile at full speed over the Park Avenue bridge across the tracks of the New York and Long Branch Railroad at this place shortly before 3 o'clock this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- As a result of the efforts of Vincent De Messimy, Chicago importers now have the benefit of direct trade relations with the exporters in France. Heretofore they had to operate almost entirely through agents and commission houses in New York. This was so much of a handicap that no jobber here ever attempted to handle certain classes of high-priced goods.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- In a tennis match filled with brilliant playing, but wholly demonstrating the superiority of the English player, R.F. Doherty, over the American, the former champion of England, to-day won the final match of the All-Comers' championship tournament on the Casino courts.

NEWAKK, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Judge Kirkpatrick, in the United States Circuit Court, this morning dismissed the petition of W. C. Buliitt of Philadelphia for leave to interplead as a party complainant in the suit instituted by the Land, Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia against the receivers of the National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America, of which John H. Mack and Henry Tatnall are receivers.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- In an editorial today The Times says it is clear that President Roosevelt has made up his mind to appeal from the party wire-pullers to the people. The President evidently thinks, The Times says, that the question of trusts is an issue whereon the battle of the next campaign can be fought with fair prospects of success.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- In spite of fatigue of the Vanderbilt theatricals and ball, and the late hour at Which the festivities were concluded, the larger part of the guests leaving when the milkmen were going their rounds and the sun was making its appearance in the east, the society people were out in force to-day to attend the tennis match between R.F. Doherty and M.D. Whitman at the Casino.
Meyer D. Rothschild has bought the three and four story dwellings 140 to 150 West Fifty-third Street, on plot 115 by 100.5, beginning about 185 feet east of Seventh Avenue.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 26. -- Champion Frank Kramer increased his lead in the race for the championship of 1902 tonight at the Coliseum board track by winning the half-mile professional championship. Taylor won his heat, but failed to qualify for the finals. The meet was marked by an unusual number of falls, but none of the was serious.

Vials of wrath were poured out on the head of George Alfred Lamb at the hearing yesterday of the case of Peter Power against the Northern Pacific Railroad Company. Mr. Lamb was vigorously attacked by Treadwell Cleveland, who accused the younger lawyer of perpetrating a "malicious lie" in his statements concerning Peter Power and Camille Weidenfeld in this case.

Mascagni's managers, Mittenthal Brothers Kronberg, received cables yesterday announcing that the composer will not change his place of residence from Italy to America in spite of his feeling over being deprived of the directorship of the Rossini Lyceum, in Pesaro, because the authorities objected to his trip to the United States at the head of an opera company.

At New West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, the Worcester team outplayed the local men at every stage, and won a tedious game by the score of 12 to 3. The fielding of the home players was wretched. They gave the poorest exhibition of the season. Ten errors were charged against them, and these enabled the visitors to score 12 runs off 11 hits.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Consul Mansfield of Valparaiso, Chile, writes the State Department that there is manifested in that country great industrial activity and that American enterprise and capital are visible.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- The polo game at Bateman's Point to-day was between the First and Third teams of the Westchester Polo Club, the local organization. Each had a handicap of eight goals. The First won by a total score of 15 to 13 3/4. The game was in the first round for the Newport Cup.
