AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt to-day passed through three States, delivered eight speeches, and received the plaudits of a quarter of a million of people.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- An order issued to-day by the Post Office Department increases the mail facilities between New York, Philadelphia, and Washington. There is to be a daily (except Sunday) dispatch, of the through registered pouches from Washington to Philadelphia and to New York at 6 P.M.

Without doubt the appointment of Col. KITSON to the command of the British Staff College at Sandhurst is the most serious result thus far of the agitation caused by the disclosures of the South African war. It is true that Sandhurst had special troubles and special scandals of its own.

William M. Crombie has been agreed upon by the organization and the associated Republicans of the Nineteenth Assembly District to succeed ex-Collector of the Port Bidwell as leader. The selection is acceptable to Charles S. Whitman, who announced his withdrawal from the race.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 26. -- The town of Valdes is now in communication with the outside world by means of a telegraph line. Its first message to the outside world was received to-day after traveling over about 3,000 miles of wires, stretching from Copper River to Yukon, thence through Alaska, Northwest Territory, British Columbia, and Washington.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt who, in course of his tour of New England, visited this city to-day, was greeted by a crowd estimated at 40,000. They packed the route through which the President was driven from the station to Washington Square, where he delivered a 20-minute address and filled all available space around the stand from which he spoke.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Arrangements were practically completed to-day between John Sloane ana Gov. Crane that President Roosevelt should lunch with John Sloane at Wyndhurst, Sept. 3, when the President and party drive through Berkshire County.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- There seems to be a fair supply of money, but banks are firm in their rates and borrowers seem more willing to meet the advance. The trust companies and institutions outside of National banks, who have recently been putting out funds as low as 4 1/2 per cent. for six months, are apparently now loaned up.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a reader of your excellent paper and as one possessed of a high sense of humor, I cannot refrain from commenting upon that conglomeration of assertions which were promulgated through the oratorical efforts of the Rev. Dr. Frank Morse of the Calvary Baptist Church, this city, an account of which you give in this morning's issue of your paper.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- With the reported formation of a giant packing trust comes the announcement that a new packing plant, together with public stock yards, will soon be in operation at Thirty-ninth Street and West Forty-eighth Avenue. The new concern is said to have ample capital behind it, and is preparing to engage in the general packing business.

John W. Gates and John C. Osgood returned to town yesterday from the contest in Denver for the control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, which had engaged their entire attention for the last ten days, Both of the men, however, made it evident yesterday that there was to be no cessation of hostilities, and that their coming away from Denver meant nothing more than a shifting of the scene of action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The Chinese exclusion act, passed during the last session of Congress, applies to the Philippine Islands, where the Chinese laborer has been very generally employed in the past, the Chinese passing between the Islands and China with the same freedom accorded to other nationalities.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The first day's racing of a four days' meet in the Hudson and Mohawk Valley Circuit was held this afternoon on the half-mile tragic of the Newburg Driving Park. The racing was spirited. Alice Mapes, a Grand Circuit performer, was a heavily backed favorite in the 2:13 pace and was distanced.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26. -- "Christy" Mathewson of the New York baseball team was in good form to-day, and succeeded in shutting out the local players, holding them to eight scattered hits. Thielman, formerly of the New York team, was the opposing pitcher, but the visitors found his curves, batted him hard, and bunched their hits to good purpose.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Following is the Agricultural Department's weekly summary of crop conditions:

BAR HARBOR, Maine, Aug. 26. -- Mrs. William Lawrence Green and Mrs. S. Megargee Wright gave a dance at the Pot and Kettle Club to-night, which was attended by a large number of guests. Many went up by launches to the club house, which lies a mile or more north of the harbor, on the bay side.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 26. -- The climax of sensational pacing races was reached in the $10,000 Park Brew Stakes at Narragansett Park this afternoon. Ed Geers piloted Direct Hal to victory in three straight heats, in the second of which the black stallion's record was lowered front 2:06 to 2:04 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Awards have not yet been made following the bids for postal pneumatic service in Boston, New York, Brooklyn, Philadelphia, Washington, and St. Louis. The matter is in the hands of Assistant Postmaster General Shallenberger. With the exception of New York, where one company bid, the Bachellor or Philadelphia Company, the American Pneumatic Tube Company of Boston was the lowest bidder on all the routes advertised.

In the matter of the application of one MICHAEL MARTIN, who appears to be the Peter Power of the interest behind the Barney dumping scows and the towboat Captains, for an injunction restraining Commissioner WOODBURY from continuing the operation of filling behind the crib at Riker's Island, on the ground that such filling is a public nuisance dangerous to life and detrimental to health, Judge GIEGERICH has "taken the papers and reserved his decision."

Jacob Kunzenmann, leader of the Greater New York Democracy in the Fourteenth Assembly District, was buried yesterday. He had been a politician all his life, and having often changed his mind regarding his political policies, therefore was mourned in his district by members of all parties, for politics to Kunzenmann was subservient to friendship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- President Roosevelt's order to Gen. Miles to visit the Philippines reached the War Department in the mail to-day. Gen. Miles is instructed to "proceed about Sept. 15 to the Philippines to inspect the army there with reference to instruction, discipline, and supplies."

DOVER, N.H., Aug. 26. -- For the first time in the history of Dover, which was founded in 1632, one of the oldest places in the country, a President of the United States was a guest here to-day. Thousands joined in the welcome to President Roosevelt, and the decorations were elaborate on every side.

No new plans for arbitrating the coal strike, no matter by whom they are inspired, will be considered by the operators, and no influence that President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers can bring to bear on them will change their position one iota.

According to an announcement made yesterday by Tax Commissioner Rufus L. Scott, it has been decided by the Board of Tax Commissioners to enforce hereafter the law fixing the assessment of real estate at its full value. To this end a circular of instruction is being prepared for the guidance of the deputies and clerks of the Tax Department, who on Tuesday will begin the work of revising the tax rolls of the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The daily advices to the War Department of the progress of the cholera epidemic in Manila and the Philippines continue to indicate that there is no hope of checking the disease until the typhoon season is well on.
OLD ORCHARD, Me., Aug. 26. -- In his visit to this place the President spoke as follows: "My Fellow-Citizens, Men and Women of Maine:

Capt. Chapman last night took two plainclothes detectives, his axe, and thirty patrolmen, and made a raid on an alleged poolroom at Sixth Avenue and West Fourth Street. Forty-nine prisoners were locked in the Mercer Street Police Station, and Capt. Chapman was jubilant.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 -- The leading social event of this evening in Newport was the dinner dance given by Mrs. Ogden Goelet at her villa on Ochre Court on the Cliffs, the entertainment being in honor of her daughter, Miss May Goelet. Two years ago Mrs. Goelet gave a similar entertainment, but to-night's far exceeds that in the beauty of illuminations and decorations of the house and the illumination of the grounds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A young woman employed in the Government Printing Office has been removed from her job because of her way of dressing her hair. It appears that she was employed once before and it was found that her theories of hairdressing were incompatible with the requirements of the Government service.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- President Eckels of the Commercial National Bank some time ago sent out requests to the correspondents of that bank throughout the West for a brief statement of opinion as to the business outlook for the coming Fall and Winter, and of the ability of the Western banks to handle the Crop movement.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 27 -- Two hundred delegates were present at the opening session to-day of the sixth annual convention of the League of American Municipalities in the furniture exposition building. By to-morrow it is expected that there will be two hundred more delegates presnet, making the convention one of the largest ever held by the league.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- Money on call ranges from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Time money is nominally 5 per cent. At the Clearing House this morning money was in better supply at 4 per cent. New York funds sold at 10c discount. Exchanges amounted to $17,832,781; balances, $1,600,228. The stock market was dull and inactive all day.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- A reunion of the Fairbanks family was held to-day in Dedham at the old Fairbanks homestead, in which in unbroken succession have dwelt eight generations of Fairbankses, and to it have come its descendants from all over the United States and Canada and even from India.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The American Bar Association began its twenty-fifth annual meeting here to-day. There was a large attendance of delegates when the meeting was called to order by President U.M. Rose of Little Rock, Ark., who then delivered an address.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Headed by the names of 567 members of St. Joseph's Church and several religious societies, a monster petition to-day was filed with Vicar General John A. Sheppard to be laid before Bishop O'Connor, calling for the removal of Father Chelbowski, now in charge of the largest Catholic church in this city.

ELLSWORTH, Me., Aug. 27 -- The Presidential train arrived here at 5:45 on schedule time. The President on alighting was introduced by Senator Hale to the local reception committee, headed by Mayor Greeley, and then he was conducted to a gayly decorated platform close by. As usual applause greeted his appearance, and Senator Hale also came in for a round of cheers.
William S. Devery was in a defiant mood last night. He carried with him all over the Ninth District a copy of the paper said to have been issued by the John C. Sheehan organization attacking him.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- Directors of the Reading Railroad Company met this afternoon, and at the conclusion of the meeting announced that they had declared a semi-annnual dividend of 1 per cent, on the first preferred stock of the company, payable Oct. 1. This cuts the dividend in half and has the effect of prolonging the voting trust now controlling the affairs of the company for a period of two years.

The police successfully kept secret for nearly two weeks all news of a big diamond robbery. Some meagre details of the affair were made public last night after the alleged offender had been arrested in Montreal.

Mr. WILLIAM L. SAUNDERS reviews in American Industries, with admirable clearness and perspicacity, the history, and present status of the international complications growing out of the ruling of Secretary GAGE imposing a counter-vailing duty on Russian sugar imported into this country to offset the export bounty alleged to be paid by Russia.

WILKESBARRY, Penn., Aug. 27 -- Operations were resumed to-day at the Dorrance mine of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company, in this city, and the Cranberry mine of A. Pardee Co., near Hazleton. The No. 40 and the Maltby of the Lehigh Valley and the Avondale of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western started to ship coal on Monday.

No one, as far as could be learned, called at the office of J. Pierpont Morgan, or on any of the coal operators, with a scheme of strike settlement yesterday, though it is expected that an appeal of some kind will be made to Mr. Morgan or the heads of the companies to end the deadlock by consenting to a compromise.

HINTON, West Va., Aug. 27 -- Great excitement exists in the vicinity of Red Ash and Beury to-day, caused by the Constables removing the striking miners from the company's houses. About forty families who were notified to leave the houses of the Red Ash Coal Company refused to vacate, and when the constables began to remove their household goods a volley of shots was fired at the officers from the opposite side of the river.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas Gallaudet died yesterday morning in his residence, 112 West Seventy-eighth Street. He had passed the Biblical limit of life by ten years and had spent the greater part of it in the silent world of deaf-mutes. About his bed when death came were the members of his family.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 -- One of the largest dinners of the season was given tonight by Mrs. Spottswood D. Schencks at Berger's in honor of Miss Kathleen Neilson and Reginald C. Vanderbilt. The dinner was served in the large room, which was artistically decorated by Wadley Smythe with tall palms, bay trees, and flowering plants.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 27 -- Local interest centred itself in the Seaboards to-day, chiefly owing to the reported completion of a traffic arrangement between it and Detroit Southern. The Seaboard's recent acquirement of a small road in the West Virginia coal fields renders such a move somewhat possible.

The decision of Judge HALL is in favor of Chief CROKER upon every point involved. It sustains, on legal grounds, the view of the case taken in these columns on reasons drawn from the interests of the municipal service and from general principles of honesty and fair dealing.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Green B. Morris's three-year-old Sombrero broke the mile and a half track record here this afternoon, going the distance in 2:31 4-5 for the Albany Handicap. The previous record was 2:35 1/2. It was an especially fine performance, as the son of Star Ruby and La Toquera was conceding from six to thirty-six pounds' weight to his opponents.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 27 -- Nearly all of Bar Harbor society was present to-day at the reception given by Augustus C. Gurnee at the Kebo Valley Club. It was the largest function that has taken place here this Summer, there being close to 1,000 guests. Oumiroff, the Russian baritone, and Adamowski gave a brief recital.

That the fight of John W. Gates and his associates to gain control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company is not to be given up, at least for the present, was made apparent from two facts yesterday. The first was a motion in the Colorado courts to remove the cases now pending before State tribunals to the United States courts.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 27 -- It is learned here that George Gould, President of the Missouri Pacific, who left New York several days ago on a tour of the lines of that system, will reach Texas some time next week, and will make an inspection trip over the new lines of the International and Great Northern.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Fire Commissioner Sturgis of New York spent to-day at this place. He knew nothing of the decision in the Croker case until informed by a reporter. Then he said:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 27 -- The Valley Iron Company, capital stock, $1,000,000, of which stock to the amount of $750,000 has already been placed, was formally organized here to-day. Its property includes nearly fourteen thousand acres of mineral lands in Dale County, Ga., and De Kalb County, Ala., between here and Chattanooga.

Automobilists in a big machine and a patrol wagon filled with policemen took turns in a chase after two alleged burglars yesterday morning, in which hundreds of pedestrians joined as it continued for about half a mile.

WATERVILLE, Me., Aug. 27 -- A stand had been erected close to the station, and from there the President greeted a large number of people, many of whom had come from a distance in all sorts of conveyances to hear him. The President spoke briefly. He said:

Charles T. Yerkes, Chairman of the Underground Railway Company of London, arrived at New York on the White Star liner Majestic last evening. Mr. Yerkes soon will return to England. In regard to the underground system, Mr. Yerkes said, among other things, that the company's interests were not in any way connected with those of J. Plerpont Morgan.

BAKGOR, Me., Aug. 27 -- The special train bearing the President and his party arrived at 12 o'clock, on scheduled time. The President was met at the train by President Beal Of the Eastern Maine State Fair Association, Senator Hale, Congressmen Littlefield and Powers, and others.

We should have regarded as incredible the report that Attorney General KNOX was to visit Paris for the purpose of inquiring into the title of the New Panama Canal Company to its property had not Mr. KNOX himself announced that as the object of his journey.

More than 1,000 persons were thrown into the wildest kind of a panic when two transatlantic liners were in collision in the harbor yesterday afternoon. The vessels that came together were the Italian liner Liguria of the Navigazione Generale Italiana and the Mediterranean fruit steamship Peconic.

In the proceedings to show cause in the case of Edward F. Croker, Chief of Department, against Fire Commissioner Thomas Sturgis, Supreme Court Justice Hall yesterday handed down a decision granting the full relief asked for by the relator. The essence of the decision is:

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- The second day's racing in the Mohawk and Hudson Valley Circuit on the half-mile track of the Newburg Driving Park was held this afternoon. Favorites won the first and third events, but King Chimes, favorite in the free for all, got only second money. Summaries:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 -- In a masterful exhibition of high-class lawn tennis, William A. Larned to-day was successful in defending his title as American champion in the singles. He defeated the famous British player R.F. Doherty, formerly champion of All-England, who is reputed to be the best man that the courts of Great Britain have ever produced.

A man and a woman were killed and another man was fatally wounded early yesterday morning in a tragedy which took place in the apartments of Lizzie Hall, twenty-six years old, at 214 East Twenty-fifth Street. The woman was one of the victims of the shooting. The man who was killed was known as Arthur Campbell, a window dresser, thirty-five years old, of 213 East Twenty-sixth Street.

What was described as "a divergence of views" at Washington was revealed in the preliminary arrangements for renewing the existing contract for the production of postage stamps for the Post Office Department. For many years the supply of stamps was provided by a private corporation.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- Gens. Corbin and Young of the United States Army, (who, with Gen. Wood, are to attend the German Army manoeuvres,) arrived here to-day and found at their hotel Emperor William's invitations to attend the gala opera performance to-morrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- W.G. Rogers, said to have been employed by Wells, Fargo Co. in their New York office as hill clerk and who arrived here yesterday ffom the East on a sight-seeing tour, was shot and killed at the Santa Fe Railway yards early to-day by Watchman Sullivan.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 27 -- The Governor's Troop, under command of Capt. Ott, left here at 7:30 o'clock to-night on a special train over the Philadelphia and Heading Railway for the Panther Creek Valley.

An executive meeting of the Board of Directors of the Eastern Baseball League was held yesterday at the Victoria Hotel for the special purpose of disposing of the protests made on games played in the present season. Among those present were Edward Mack, Toronto; P.H. Hurley, Worcester; George P. Cressy, Providence; George W. Sweeny, Rochester, and President P.T. Powers.

Mr. BAER and his confederates are not the first nor the only men to maintain that the manner in which they manage an industry, not merely of public utility but of public necessity, was their "private business." It is not so long ago since RICHARD CROKER put forward the same plea with regard to the Municipal Government of New York.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Pizzini, parents of Mrs. Kenneth R. Cobb, who was killed yesterday in the automobile accident at Elberon, arrived here, to-day from their home in Richmond. Va., after having stopped in Long Branch and viewed the remains of their daughter and visited Mrs. William B. Pizzini in the hospital there.

LOWVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Gov. Odell arrived here by special train at 11 o'clock, accompanied by Private Secretary Graham, Congressman James S. Shennan, Senator Garry A. Willard, Thomas Wheeler, and Others.

Trading on the curb yesterday, although marked by the same dullness as on Tuesday, continued on the like broad plane displayed for some time past. Quite a large number of declines occurred, the principal ones being in American Writing Paper, Rock Island, and Otis Elevator common. Seaboard Air Line issues recovered considerably, the common gaining 1 1/8 and the preferred 1/3 point.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Most of the local stocks traded in to-day showed a firm tone. The movement of prices, however, was narrow, and there was no noteworthy feature to the market. There was a fair amount of business in Box Board, the common selling around 14 1/2 and the preferred at 64@64 1/2.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 28 -- Records continue to be broken at the Grand Circuit races at Narrangansett Park. The free-for-all pace was to-day's special feature, and the second heat in 2:02 flat was the fastest mile in a race this year. Anaconda, 2:01 3/4, beat Prince Alert, 2:00 3/4, in straight heats.

Shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning the steam yacht Kanawha of H.H. Rogers, the Standard Oil man, was in collision with the Long Island Railroad ferry-boat Rockaway. The collision occurred just above the new East River Bridge, at a point in mid-stream off Delancey Street. Mr. Rogers was on board his yacht at the time.

From all indication's the record for attendance on a New York race track will be broken to-morrow at the Sheepshead Bay race course, when the Futurity is run. Never in the history of the big event, the most valuable prize of the American turf, was popular interest aroused to the present pitch.

There was much speculation yesterday as to why the ferryboat Nassau, that runs between Long Island City and Wall Street for the convenience of business men, whose interests are down town, was out of commission. Late in the afternoon the cause of the laying up of the boat became known, and an unusual cause it turned out to be.

Ada Gray, the veteran actress, who won fame as Lady Isabel in "East Lynne," died on Wednesday at the Home for Incurables at Fordham, N.Y., and was burled in the Actors' Fund plot in Evergreen Cemetery.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 28 -- The strains of " Hail to the Chief" from the Manchester Cadet Band, and the first gun of a Presidential salute by a battery of the New Hampshire State Militia, mingled with the cheers of a great multitude to-day as the train on which was President Roosevelt came into the Boston and Maine Station here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- There was some further slight pressure to sell Swift Co.'s stock at the opening of the local market to-day, but later in the session prices showed some tendency to recover. It developed that the recent selling of the stock has been based on what appears to be a well-grounded report that the organization of the much-talked-of meat combination has been postponed.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 28 -- The event of the day here was the reception given by Capt. Thomas J. Bush this afternoon at the Pot and Kettle Club. It was attended by several hundred guests. Capt. Bush was assisted in receiving by Preston Davie, William Prescott Wolcott, and Roger Pierce.

Trading yesterday on the curb developed no new feature of importance. Prices on the whole were steady, with fractional declines and advances occurring throughout the list. Rock Island issues made the largest advance among the prominent and active stocks, while Safty Car Heating and Lighting continued to show strength, some 60 shares being traded in at an advance of 2 1/2 points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- In view of rumors as to Secretary Shaw's plans for relieving the money market in the event of a possible stringency, the Secretary, who is in New York, to-day authorized Assistant Secretary Ailes to make the following statement:

HAZLETON, Aug. 28 -- A call was issued here to-day for a general convention of the People's Alliance of the six ant -- hracite coal counties and the Cities of Philadelphia and New York, to be held in this city on Sept. 4. It is stated that a movement will be set on foot to terminate the miners' strike.

SARATOGA, Aug. 23 -- John G. Carlisle of New York, ex-Secretary of the Treasury, delivered the annual address to-day before the American Bar Association. He spoke upon the power of the United States to acquire and govern territory, which, he said, was a question growing out of the acquisition of territory from Spain.

The State Board of Arbitration and Conciliation of Massachusetts publishes statistics which appear to show that the storm centre of labor disputes this year is in New England. Between Jan. 1 and July 31 there occurred in Massachusetts 430 strikes, or something over two a day.

BERLIN, Aug. 28 -- King Victor Emmanuel of Italy, accompanied by Emperor William, the Empress, Crown Prince Frederick William, and Signer Prinetti, (Italian Minister of Foreign Affairs.) and escorted by a detachment of cuirassiers, made his state entry into Berlin this morning.

The first of the two regattas with which the American Yacht Club signalizes the revival or the yachting spirit among its members was sailed on Long Island Sound off Milton Point, Rye, yesterday afternoon. It was the first open regatta that has been held under the auspices of the club for four or five years.

Mascagni might not be coming to America this Autumn but for the chance playing of the intermezzo from "Cavalleria Rusticana" by the orchestra of the Hotel Navarre in this city one Sunday evening last Spring. At that time it happened that Aubrey Mittenthal of Mittenthal Brothers called at the hotel to see S. Kronberg, the impresario, who then lived there.

THE WEIRS, N.H., Aug. 28 -- Fully 30,000 people joined in welcoming the President of the United States on his visit to the encampment of the New Hampshire Grand Army of the Republic here to-day. It was one of the largest crowds ever seen here, and enthusiasm also was almost without precedent.
NEWBURY, N.H., Aug. 28 -- President Roosevelt to-night is the guest of John Hay. Secretary of State, whose Summer home is situated a few miles from here along the shore of Lake Sunapee.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28 -- On the Westchester Polo Club's field to-day the Point Judith team allowed 10 goals to the Devon Club of Philadelphia, and won easily by a score of 15 to 12. A,W. Spencer of Devon in the third period was disabled by an accidental blow. He retired, and to equalize matters Reginald Brooks also left the game, which was finished with only three on a side.

TAMAQUA, Penn., Aug. 28 -- The first clash between the striking miners and the troops took place this morning, and as a result five prisoners are in the guardhouse at the Twelfth Regiment camp, and Capt. J. Beaver Gearhart of Company F. Twelfth Regiment, is suffering from a wound on his shoulder, made by a stone thrown by a striker.

NEWPORT, Aug. 28 -- Beechwood, the villa of Mrs. William Astor, at Bellevue Avenue and the Cliffs, was the scene tonight of a ball, the first entertainment of any kind given by Mrs. Astor this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Representative Hopkins of Illinois, a member of the Ways and Means Committee and the probable successor of Senator Mason in the Senate, has added his voice to the chorus of Republican leaders against any revision of the tariff, believing it would be suicidal to disturb business interests with threats of revision.

-- We notice in many of our contemporaries an inclination -- which they have not resisted -- to treat Mr. JAMES J. VAN ALEN with great severity because of the report that he recently declared the United states "not a fit place for a gentleman to live in," and added, not only that England was such a place, but that it was the only such plaoe.

The Jersey City and Providence baseball teams began a series of games yesterday, in which the fourth position in the Eastern League championship race will be decided. The local players won by a score of 3 to 1. McCann, for Jersey City, pitched a strong, steady game, and held the visitors down to three hits.

Charges of bribery and deception made by the William W. Brauer Steamship Company against Dock Department officials and Michael J. Dady of Brooklyn, were dismissed yesterday by Justice Mayer in the Court of Special Sessions, who in his decision fully exonerated all who had been accused.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, Aug. 28 -- In the all-comers' event in the international tennis tournament on the Queen's Royal Courts to-day Kreigh Collins beat S. Wright, and Leroy won with ease. In the handicap John Neely, to whom Harold Hackett owed half a point, beat the Yale man in straight sets.

Residents of a large section of the city in the vicinity of Melrose and West Farms, in the Bronx, were left without water for the twenty-four hours that ended at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, because a curious accident happened at that hour on Wednesday, at Boston Road and Southern Boulevard.
Details will be found in another column relative to the proposed increase in the capital of the Century Realty Company and regarding the organization of the Remington Construction Company.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 28 -- Two hundred Republican delegates from Monmouth, Middlesex, and Ocean Counties, which comprise the new Third Congress District, met in convention in Educational Hall this afteroon and renominated Congressman Benjamin F. Howell, the New Brunswick banker, for a fifth term.

With the Astor ball the great festivities of a brilliant week at Newport end, and with the famous race Saratoga will see a general rush for town and other places. In the meantime there is much going on everywhere. This evening at Southampton the weekly dance occurs, and to-morrow a like festivity at Oyster Bay.

Grand Duke Boris, cousin of the Czar of Russia, came to New York last evening and took in some of the sights. In Chicago he had spent several days, and had liked the city, except that there had been more freedom of the press than he had known at home. He believed that the freedom had been overdone to the exent that the reporters had written of events that he was sure had never happened.

If the operators have at last determined to begin the mining of coal they have reached a wise conclusion. They have defied public opinion long enough, and longer than it was prudent for them to defy it. But they must not delude themselves with the belief that they can fool the public by a mere pretense at working the mines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whether or not it is Mr. Roosevelt's ambition to be elected President, it should not hinder him from acting and stop talking. The new method of insuring the confidence of the people by delivering speeches in various parts of the country is productive of good results only when "promises" and "beliefs" are put in execution.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Secretary Shaw has issued the following circular regarding the free entry of personal effects under the act of 1897:

One of the big automobiles of the New York Electric Vehicle Company fell into the Rapid Transit subway on Broadway, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, last night, falling thirty feet, and flinging the chauffeur, Edward Morris of Ninety-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue, into the trench.

CONCORN, N.H., Aug. 28 -- The President's special reached Concord promptly at 5 o'clock, and was greeted with a salute of twenty-one guns. A large crowd had gathered at the station, and they voiced their welcome in hearty cheers while the President and his party were taking their carriages.

We have, we believe, already expressed the wish that the State Department might issue a primer of the Monroe doctrine for gratuitous distribution throughout the newspaper offices of Continental Europe. Quite incidentally, of course, and just to show what we were doing to enlighten the irresponsible guides of public opinion, copies of the primer might properly be mailed to the Chancelleries of the countries in question.

WILKESBARRE, Aug. 28 -- Coal operators here to-day took up the reply of President Mitchell to Abram S. Hewitt. They assert that by resolutions passed at the United Mine Workers' conventions, the strike leader's contention in one particular is shown to be incorrect. Mr. Mitchell said:

A running commentary by MARK HANNA, THOMAS C. PLATT, NELSON W. ALDRICH, and the beet sugar Senators, jointly and severally, upon President ROOSEVELT'S speech in praise of the simple life would be the most delightful reading in the world.

MANCHESTBR, N.H., Aug. 28 -- While the President was at Nashua he received a dispatch announcing that W.A. Larned had defeated Doherty at tennis and immediately he sent a telegram of congratulation. Larned served with the President in the Cuban campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- Activity in Philadelphia Electric gave the market in this city a good deal of snap for a time, but all the animation faded away after noon, and prices for the most part declined. The notable exceptions were United Gas Improvement and American Railways, the latter touching 52, its highest record.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 -- The local stock market continued to hold firm to-day, though the trading was quiet. There are important events in store which may have a material influence on special issues soon, but there is nothing doing to move prices at this particular moment. Seaboards are remaining sluggish, there being no signs at present of an immediate resumption of its bullish leadership.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Money was in active demand to-day for the settlement, and the resources were depleted owing to withdrawals by the banks for month-end requirements. Discounts were firm.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- The Saranac Handicap for three-year-olds, the feature event of the closing day's card, resulted in one of the most keenly contested races of the meeting. Hermis, recently acquired by the stable of L.V. Bell, won after a head-and-head drive with Whisky King from the three-eighths to the winning post.

The Directors of the Century Realty Company have decided to recommend to the stockholders an increase in the capital of that corporation from $1,000,000 to $3,000,000. Of this amount, $1,000,000, which will be issued immediately, will be offered to the present stockholders at $125 per share to the extent of their present holdings.

Total transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday fell materially below the figures recorded lately, barely 650,000 shares being traded in as compared with the high figures on Tuesday of more than 1,300,000 shares. The falling off in activity is, however, understandable and natural.

Sir Edmund Barton, Prime Minister and Minister of External Affairs of New South Wales, Australia, who was one of the most conspicuous members of the recent conference of British Colonial Premiers in London, is in New York on his way back to Australia. He is accompanied by Sir John Forrest, Minister of Defense, and Austin Chapman, member of the New South Wales House of Representatives and Government whip.

Major Frank U. Robinson, Second Cavalry, and Contract Surgeon Henry L. Brown are detailed as members of the examining board convened at Fort Sheridan, vice Capt. Samuel E. Allen, Artillery Corps, and Contract Surgeon Charles F. Smith, relieved.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The Rand mining industry, says The Times's Pretoria correspondent, is apprehensive regarding Colonial Secretary Chamberlain's intentions as to the war taxation of the Transvaal, as adumbrated in his speech in the House of Commons on July 29.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- On call money rules from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent, to the best borrowers. Time money is quoted all the way from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent, for four to six months, 5 per cent, being perhaps the more general figure. There is more commercial paper selling, though rates are firm at 5@ 5 1/2 per cent., with exceptions at 4 3/4 per cent.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28 -- After months of preparation, in which nearly one-half of the officers of the army and navy have been hard at work, the final war manoeuvres by an army of defense against an enemy made up of a large number of ships of the navy will begin at midnight on Sunday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Completing the final details of the great harvester machinery combine, which will have a capital of $120,000,000, is the work which has brought George W. Perkins, the right-hand man of J. Pierpont Morgan, to Chicago, and which, he declares, will keep him here until Tuesday at least.

NASHUA, N.H., Aug. 28 -- For the first time since leaving on his tour of New England, President Roosevelt last night slept aboard the train. He remained up until a late hour talking over old times with " Bill " Sewall, his ex-guide, whom he insisted should accompany him to Ellsworth and back to Bangor.

The Blue Sky Press of Chicago has lately issued its first reprint, a beautifully made edition of Robert Browning's "In a Balcony," and has succeeded admirably in producing a volume the mechanical details of which are entirely worthy of its text.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The stock of copper on hand in the United States on Jan. 1, 1902, is estimated by the United States Geological Survey to have been at least 300,000,000 pounds -- six months' production. It is assumed that, even at the beginning of the year 1901, the stocks of copper in this country were beyond the working limit.
Second Lieut. Otis R. Cole, Nineteenth Infantry, is transferred to the Twenty-seventh Infantry. He will Join the latter regiment.

The Deputy Tax Commissioners, who do the work of going about the city and de- ciding what assessments shall be placed on the real estate and personal property in their respective districts, received instruc- tions at the Department of Taxes and Assessments yesterday afternoon as to how their, work should be done this year.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ont., Aug. 28. -- The Niagara international tennis tour- nament was continued here this afternoon on the courts of the Niagara Lawn Club. In the men's singles Wright, Collins, Fischer, and Hackett won their matches in straight sets. It looks as though they will meet in the semi-finals.
TIEN-TSIN, Aug. 29. -- According to the military commanders, all the foreign troops, with the exception of the legation guards, will be withdrawn from China next Spring.

FMARION CRAWFORD'S latest novel, which will be published shortly by The Macmillan Company, is entitled "Cecilia, the Last of the Vestals." This is the story of a young woman of modern Rome, the scene of Mr. Crawford's "Saracinesca," "Don Orsino," and "Sant' Ilario."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 29. -- The Grand Circuit meeting at Narragansett Park was brought to a close this afternoon in a blaze of glory. Dan Patch, the unbeaten son of Joe Patchen, paced an exhibition mile in 1:59 1/2, reducing his record from 2:00 1/4 and getting within a quarter of a second of the world'e record of 1:59 1/4, made by Star Pointer at Readville five years ago.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Gov. Odell laid the cornerstone of the new hospital here this afternoon. It was made a gala occasion, and a great reception was given to the Governor. He was met by a committee at the station, where an imposing parade was formed, and proceeded to the hospital.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29. -- According to information unearthed here, it is said that William Bartholin, who is wanted by the police in connection with the murder of his mother and the disappearance of his sweetheart, Minnie Mitchell, is a member of the noble house of Bartholin-Eichel of Denmark. It has also been discovered, it is said, that he has a half-brother, Frederick Bartholin, at present living in Chicago, prosperous and highly respected.

The case of Fire Chief Edward F. Croker has at no time been more interesting than it was yesterday by reason of developments that, taken in their entirety, at least suggest the possibility that he may not tie reinstated to his duties and privileges as Chief of Department before October.

The Providence baseball nine won a close game from the Jersey City team yesterday on the latter's home grounds. The score was tied when the visitors began the ninth inning, but an error by Woods and a bad throw by Halligan allowed Dolan to make a circuit of the bases and score the winning run, when he should have been put out easily at first base.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The officials of the Department of Agriculture are suffering from severe mental strain as a result of a well-meant interview given out by Secretary Wilson to a Washington newspaper some time ago.

The Macmillan Company Mr. Riis's have in preparation a new New Book, book by Jacob A. Riis, author of "The-Making of an American," to be called " The Battle with the Slum." It includes the material in Mr. Riis's "A Ten Years' War," which volume he has rewritten, and added a third more material to it, and the new volume is now a complement to "How the Other Half Lives."

Trading on the curb yesterday displayed unexpected activity and strength. The market was even broader than it has been for some time, and advances occurred throughout the entire list, with the excep- tion of St. Louis Transit, which lost half a point, and one or two other issues in which small fractional declines were recorded.

MENZO DIEFENDORF died on Thursday in his home, at 1 West Eighty-seventh Street, after an illness of nearly two years. He was born at Fort Plains, N.Y., and was educated in Union College. He entered the practice of law in 1852, and he was well known at the New York bar until his retirement two years ago on account of his health.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Aug. 29. -- Gell Gobin, who is in command of the State troops in this section of the mining country, to-night issued an order which is in effect a command to the militia to fire upon the strikers whenever they are attacked. The order is the result of the increased violence in the districts affected by the strike during yesterday and today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The District School Commissioners are beginning to feel seriously uneasy about the coal strike and its effect upon the public school sys- tem in this city. The year's supply is usually contracted for and a great part of it delivered during the month of July. Proposals were asked for last month, but the lowest price bid was $8.70 a ton, $3 higher than the price paid in 1901.

The Long Island Highway Protective Society filed its certificate of incorporation with Supreme Court Justice A.V.S. Cochrane for approval yesterday. The objects of the society are the protection of the interests and the rights of the people in the highways of Long Island, the co-operation with the authorities for the enforcement of laws governing motor vehicles, and of other riding and driving equipages and the general care of the highways on Long Island.

Very few recently returned passengers from Europe, we suppose, failed to read Secretary GAGE'S defence, in The North American Review, of the inquisition, in some cases horrible, and in all annoying, to which they had been subjected at the New York Custom House. And without doubt there was not one such passenger who did read it who read it without strong indignation.

It is very characteristic of the advance of thought in the South that the negroes are beginning to write books dealing with the social and political problems that confront them as a race. The merits of Booker Washington's two volumes -- one of autobiography and the other of brief sermons on character building -- are already well known.

We give space to the letter of a correspondent who seems to chide us for not including in the list of books depreciative of the United States Mr. Kipling's "American Notes," even while she insists that that book ought not to be so included.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Senator Lodge reviews the next volume the supplement to the ninth edition of " The Encyclopedia Britannica " in The Times of London for Sept. 5. Previous volumes were reviewed by Lords Avebury and Davey and Profs. Bryce and Case.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- New York's baseball team, minus McGraw and Bresna- han, was defeated by the Philadelphias to-day with the score 6 to 2. Iberg was an enigma to the visitors for seven innings, but in the eighth, with two men out, the New York men found the ball and scored two earned runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Two telephone girls in Washington have a European trip in prospect in consequence of the recent discovery that a New York telephone girl was the heiress of a Scottish Earl. The Washington girls are Carrie and Louise Schnebel, two sisters, in the long-distance office at Fifteenth and F Streets.

TAMAQUA, Penn., Aug. 29. -- In an encounter between troops and strikers at Lansford this morning Capt. W.H. Heim of Company K, Twelfth Regiment, wag slightly injured. A half dozen strikers were bayonetted by the soldiers as a result of the encounter.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The Standard this morning says it has learned that negotiations are still in progress for the creation of a British steel combination on the lines of the United States Steel Corporation, but that they have not yet reached a very definite stage.

William Frederick Ignatz Schoo, a huge German, escaped from prison in Germany, where he was sentenced to ten years for shooting a policeman who arrested him in Hamburg on a larceny charge, was captured last night in a barber's shop on Morris Avenue by Deputy United States Marshals Bernhard and Gardner.

ROME, Aug. 29. -- Mgr. Guidi, who yesterday was appointed Apostolic Delegate in the Philippine Islands, was born in April, 1852, at Alatri, Province of Rome. He studied at the Gregorian University and Collegio Romano until 1870, when he entered the Pontificial Seminary, where he took the degree of philosophy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Colombia will formally demand of Nicaragua an explanation in regard to the latter country's alleged participation in the revolution against the Colombian Government, and will back up her demand with the most formidable land and naval forces she can muster, as soon as the present rebel activity on the isthmus has been crushed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- Considerable interest is taken here in the fate of "Cedarcroft," Bayard Taylor's old home at Kennett Square, in Chester County. It has bean inevitable that the property would eventually fall into profane hands, and it is even desirable that some one should take hold of it and lift it out of its present state of dilapidation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- In a letter to a newspaper here the Rev. S.E. Bishop, one of the oldest American settlers in Honolulu, gives a pitiful account of the fate of thousands of Porto Ricans who were shipped to Hawaii in the last year or two to supply labor on sugar plantations. The Porto Ricans are said to be extremely anxious to return to their old home.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 29. -- Benjamin W. Babcock, fifty years old, of this place, was found dead on the beach this morning, a victim of apoplexy, according to Coroner Nugent. Babcock had been missing from home since Saturday.

The occasion when the words of this les- son were spoken was a very solemn and important one, for the people of Israel were assembled for the last time to listen to the last words of their great leader. Both he and they knew that they would never again thus stand face to face with each other.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- William E. Ha- gan, one of the most noted experts in handwriting in this country, died this morning at his residence in this city. Mr. Hagan was a native of Troy, where he was born Nov. 24, 1826. Early in life he went to New York, and studied chemistry and medicine.

BOSTON, Aug. 29. -- Money is no firmer. Call money has been loaned fairly liberally to the best borrowers at 4 per cent., over Labor Day. The general asking rate, however, remains at 4 1/2 per cent. There is comparatively little doing in collateral transactions. For from four to six months the rate is nominally 5 per cent., though this would be shaded on the choicest names and collateral.

Grand Duke Boris of Russia spent his first day in New York yesterday. He went to church, to luncheon at the University Club, as the guest of Richard T. Crane of Chicago; to dinner at the Union Club, as the guest of Charles McDonald, a Wall Street broker, and to the Casino, where he enjoyed "The Chinese Honeymoon."

In a letter to The Philadelphia Public Ledger Mr. B.G. WELCH makes a very good point as bearing upon the right of the anthracite operators to maintain the position that the management of their business is a matter of concern to themselves alone, and that it is none of the public's business whether they mine coal or not.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 29. -- America's crack marksmen gathered in large num- bers at Sea Girt to-day for the opening of the inter-State shooting tournament, managed by the National Rifle Association of America, the New Jersey Rifle Association, and the United States Revolver Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- The event of chief local interest to-day was a vigorous buying movement in Electric Company of America. That stock, which has been doz- ing for six months, was aroused from its slumber and lifted to the highest of the year on purchases of nearly 7,000 shares. The incident exerted no influence in other directions.

There it lay in a sarcophuagus, say a wooden box, not alone, but jammed in tight with a dozen more unfortunates, and exposed to view on Ann Street. And there had been a stormy season. A strip of tarpaulin as a cerement had barely covered the miserable books, for books they were, and they showed signs of the pelting storms.

A good American sitting among his broken idols and ruefully rubbing the welts and bruises his patriotism receives from the bastinado which Mr. Ernest Crosby wields in "Captain Jinks, Hero," may, nevertheless, find balm in the thought that he wrote it in six weeks -- as his publisher announces.

READERS will find printed below lists of the contents of the principal American magazines for September. The lists are restricted to periodicals which appear once a month, and, while the contents are not absolutely complete, the omissions relate mainly to regular and familiar departments and some of the minor contributions.
IN the biographies of great men and women the prejudices of the writers so often take the lead in the portrayal of character that one cannot always be sure of gaining true impressions of the subject.

THE Royal Society of British Artists is the only serious rival which the Royal Academy has found in its path, and it did not give the Royal Academy half as much trouble as expected. In its infancy, before it had the handle of Royal attached to it and while it still could hardly stand, it was easy work to crush it.

On the eve of a three-day holiday it would not have been unnatural had inac- tivity shown in the stock market, with prices inclined to sag more than to advance. It is notorious that traders and operators generally are very much indisposed to carry stocks over any holiday, much less one extending from Friday until Tuesday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29. -- Now that the national tennis tournament is over and the courts at the Casino are open for gen- eral playing the Summer residents have taken up the game again with renewed vigor, and the demand for opportunity to use the courts is so great that restrictive rules regarding the length of time they may be occupied by individual players have to be rigidly enforced.

VIENNA, Aug. 30. -- The Neue Freie Presse says that the terrible treatment of Siberian political exiles at the Alexandrovsk settlement has led to a strike of the convicts, who are refusing all nourishment until they are more humanely treated.

-- All the authorities on Oriental industry and commerce seem to agree in the opinion that to develop the natural resources of the Philippine Islands with any approach to speed and completeness, it is necessary to remove the restrictions upon Chinese Immigration. With an abundant supply of coolies, working hard for low wages, land can be brought rapidly under cultivation, roads and railways built, exports increased, and the prosperity of the islands assured.

NEWPORT, Aug. 29. -- The night before the battle finds the army of defence in the several ports along shore between New Bedford and the east entrance to Long Isl- and Sound practically in readiness to repel the attack of the hostile fleet under the command of Admiral Higginson.

HOW great liberties may the novelist take with tie facts of history? Poetic license is proverbial. A Spenser can forplay what pranks he please; can misspell for the sake of rhyme; sing the most astounding anachronisms; mingle most diverse elements, and put upon his stage in the same action creatures of fable and his- toric personage, Grecian goddesses and English Queens; heathen myths and Christian revelation.

THE book-world knows much of many great American private libraries of the past -- those that have been publicly sold, such as Brinley's, Murphy's, Barlow's, and Ives's; but it knows little of the fine native collections that have never come into the auction room but have been dispersed at private sale or bequeathed to public institutions.

Some of the National banks in this city will accept Secretary SHAW'S "invitation" to take out new circulation. Others will pay no attention to the suggestion of the Secretary of the Treasury, either because they see no necessity for increasing the volume of bank notes or because it would be unprofitable or inconvenient for them to make fresh issues.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The Ameri- can Bar Association to-day elected the fol- lowing officers: President, Francis Rawle, Philadelphia; Secretary, John Hinkley, Baltimore; Treasurer, Frederick E. Wad- hams, New York; Executive Committee, ex- officio -- Francis Rawle, Philadelphia; U.M. Rose, Little Rock; Frederick E. Wadhams, New York, and John Hinkley, Baltimore.
THE literature of the French Revolution is such a stupendous aggregation that one hesitates to welcome any fresh addition to the mass, but Mr. Alger's is one of quit uncommon interest and importace.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Matthew, on West Eighty-fourth Street, was crowded to its utmost capacity yesterday afternoon by a congregation that assembled to pay the last tributes to the late Dr. Thomas Gallaudet, the friend of deaf-mutes. The chancel and altar of the church were decorated profusely with white roses and white and purple asters, and the effect of the sunlight shining through the half-opened stained glass windows upon them was beautiful.

Epicedial or elegiac poetry, which is common to every literature, ancient and modern, is prominent in all the periods of English verse. It is noticeable not only in the work of Chaucer and Spencer, but it appears early in that of the earliest Anglo-Saxon writers. It is not, of course, unnatural that so great and striking a mystery as Death should stir the soul to pictorial and strophed expressions of attachment and lament.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In an article called " International ' Appreciations,' " the context of which suggests " International ' Depreciations,' " as being a somewhat more applicable title, you say: " The last of the old insolently insular "books about the United States was a very foolish one by one Sir Lepel Griffin, and that must be quite twenty years of age."

"While the lamp holds out to burn," said Dr. WATTS in one of his comforting moments, "the vilest sinner may return." Likewise, the victim of the speed madness may hope for a cure and safety at any time prior to the inevitable catastrophe which transfers to his surviving relatives all concern about the matter.

The evident determination of the anthracite operators to raise the embargo so long and successfully maintained by the United Mine Workers probably has a more intimate relation to the return of Mr. J.P. MORGAN to this country than any one connected with the business may think it expedient to admit.

" Sydney C. Grier's " " The Warden of the Marches," delayed in publication since December, 1901, and " Like Another Helen," published in England in 1890, now appear off these coasts, two three-deckers of the pattern approved by the present Lord Admiral of English fiction, with a squadron of five to follow, which, in plain speech, means that Messrs.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 29. -- Three things stand out prominently to an impartial investigator of the anthracite strike, viz., the plan of the operators to magnify each gain, the apparent hopelessness of the miners' officials, and the grumbling of the business men of the region. Neither of the contending parties shows a sign to yield, and both declare through their officials here that there are no plans making for a settlement of the troubles.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- Mr. Well's "Sea Lady" has been received with such unanimous praise that I began to think that my first impression of it was not altogether what it should have been. But in spite of a renewed examination of the book, I do not see my way to change my mind.

The proceedings in the case of Peter Power vs. the Northern Pacific Railway Company, begun eight months ago in the United States Circuit Court, District of Minnesota, Fourth Division, terminated abruptly yesterday, so far as the case for the defendant is concerned, in Room 70 of the Post Office Building.
Charles Gulden has sold 45, 47, and 49 East Eighty-fourth Street, old buildings, on plot 50 by 100, together with the abutting vacant lot at 42 East Eighty-fifth Street, 23 by 102.2.

A month or more ago M. Jules Verne was reported in The London Daily Mail as saying that the day of the novel is ending. We had the courage at the time to join with others in suggesting that he was mistaken, and the fact that the novel business is booming seems to have impressed still others more than M. Verne's premortem obituary on fiction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Gen. Chaffee has advised the War Department by cable that one of the five complete cavalry regiments now in the Philippines can be spared from duty there, and orders were issued to-day to send home the Ninth. Six troops of this regiment will sail on the Logan on Sept. 16, and the remainder of the regiment on Oct. 1.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Noticing F.A. Crandall's note in regard to Land Commissioner Hermann's " Louisiana Purchase " in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, I was reminded that to Rufus Blanchard, the cartographer and historian of the Northwest, the country is really indebted for forcing the Interior Department at Washington to correct its maps as to the northwestern boundary of the Louisiana Purchase.

Miss Violette Hall's "Chanticleer, a Pastoral Romance," is one of the many recent manifestations of ecstatic devotion to nature with an elaborate and rubricated "N." The narrator of the story and her husband, losing their house by fire and their furniture by the excessive zeal of Kindly neighbors and servants, decide to strip their daily living of everything unnecessary and to exist after the model of Thoreau.

Title to property in the Bronx estimated to be worth more than $300,000 is in dispute because a woman has appeared who says that she is the widow of George Walton, who in selling the property swore that he was unmarried. He died suddenly in City Island on Feb. 25, 1901. Walton left no will, and it was not suspected that he had left a wife.

William Morris, when he was traveling about Iceland, avoiding the geysers and other tourist-attracting features of the landscape as he would the plague, and hunting out places associated with the heroes of the Icelandic sagas, was deeply impressed by the fact that the events, real or imagined, of the far past were unforgotten by even the humblest inhabitants of that melancholy island.

NEWPORT, N.H., Aug. 29. -- President Roosevelt was to-day entertained in a manner much to his liking. Instead of making numerous addresses, meeting com- mittees, and indulging in handshaking he plunged into the forest of the Corbin Pre- serve in the Croyden Mountain region and hunted big game, and just before dark suc- ceeded in shooting a boar.

IN THE library of Cornell University there is a collection of "biblioteca dantesca" consisting of nearly 7,000 separately bound volumes -- the gift of a generous gentleman and scholar, Mr. willard Fiske. The catalogue of descriptive titles is to be found in two large octavo volumes, each containing 300 closely printed double-column pages.

Dear Marna: Have you very nearly finished, for if not the Swampside Reading Circle wish to wait upon you in private, each armed with a hatpin. We really cannot stand you much longer. Has anybody told you that you are a goose? Dana was all right when he married you. He had the making of a most excellent husband.

Sulzer's Park, at Second Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, bulged on all sides with the throngs at the annual afternoon and evening festival of the Downtown Tammany Club of the Second Assembly District. Big Tammany chieftains there were in plenty to lend distinction to the occasion, but Thomas F. Foley, leader, was the man of the show all day and all night.

The following letter is the appendix to a conversation between an American who known no German and a German who, as win be seen, knows much English, about the merits of Bayard Taylor's translation of the " Dedication of Goethe's ' Faust ' ";

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Rates for money were firm to-day, and borrowings from the Bank of England increased on account of the consols settlement and month end re- quirements. It is estimated that $25,000,000 is owing to the Bank of England, and it is believed that this is largely by speculators, in consols, thus partly accounting for the rise in discounts in spite of the steady in- flow of gold from abroad.

COLLECTORS and students of Americana have long been interested in the undetermined question regarding the discovery and naming of Labrador, but have never sufficiently considered a contribution to the subject from the pen of Senor Dr. Ernesto do Canto.

In publishing our recent account of how a young woman of Denver, Col., jumped suddenly from a position which she had filled with distinction as cook in a wealthy family into the position of a literary notability, living by her pen, we cast no aspersion upon the art of the kitchen.
GINASIE STEVENS enjoyed the distinction of being the only eligible young man at Lake Geneva.

SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The weather the past week has been delightful and the liverymen have been reaping a harvest in consequence. Driving parties to Richfield, Cooperstown, and Otsego Lake have been numerous, while the shorter trips to Cherry Valley and Prospect Hill have been even more popular.
Katharine Worley smiled sweetly at this remark, perhaps with a subtle meaning showing in her face, for Kitty Langley exclaimed:

NEWPORT, Aug. 30. -- An almost continuous succession of automobile mishaps has occurred here within the last twenty-four hours. Clement C. Moore's machine last night ran into a bicyclist on Bellevue Avenue. The bicycle was damaged and the rider slightly injured.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- English domestic affairs have been very quiet this week. It is the dead season in London. Every one who is any one has gone to mountain, moor, or sea. In the fashionable quarters of the West End the houses are shut up and the street are almost deserted.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Hawk Island, the Summer home of Bishop Potter, on Lake Placid, in the shadow of Whiteface Mountain, has been prepared for the coming of the Bishop, who is expected to come direct to the mountains from Cooperstown. Mrs. Davidge, the daughter of the Bishop, has been occupying the camp this Summer.

The local disciples of Izaak Walton are greatly disappointed at the absence of the gamy bass from the praters of the Potomac this season, few of the fish having been caught by hook and line fishermen about this city this Summer. The reports from the lower river are to the effect that bass had been unusually scarce there this year, and the German carp is held responsible for the scarcity.

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- The Boston baseball team won the last game of the home series from Brooklyn this afternoon. Eight safe hits off Hughes in the first three innings brought victory. It was not until the ninth inning that the visitors aroused the crowd by nearly tying the score. With two men on bases, Keeler was thrown out by Greminger but Dolan followed with a hit, scoring Farrell.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial in to-day's issue in regard to the manufacture of post-age stamps by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, permit me to say that I was the lowest bidder in 1894, when the bureau took the contract from private parties, and that I had manufactured the stamps for over twenty years, although the American Bank Note Company was making them at that time.

PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The activity of the Adirondack real estate market has been clearly illustrated here within the last week. Two transactions reflect the great advance in Adirondack land values, particularly camp sites, even in the last three years. One of the sales, was at Island, Point, in the Lower St. Regis Lake.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In People vs. Budd, 117 N.Y., 1, the Court of Appeals upheld the legislation of this State regulating the charges to be imposed by the owners of elevators as warranted by the police power of the State. The present coal situation makes this opinion apropos at the present time.

NEWPORT, Aug. 30. -- This has been the liveliest social day in Newport this season, with a larger number and a greater variety of entertainments. Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones entertained a party of fifty on the steam yacht Narada, including the Duchess of Marlborough. The yacht was prettily decorated by Hodgson.

NEWPORT, Aug. 30. -- Here we are at the end of August, and in the gayest of the season, with the horse show and two large balls yet to come, and numerous dinners and receptions that will carry the social festivities well into the middle of September. August has been a brilliant month, with nearly a dozen big social functions, at least eight of them balls of more than the usual elaborateness.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Aug. 30. -- This week all Exchange operations in Americans were very quiet, and such interest as was excited has been derived from Wall Street. The condition of the American market here hag been practically unchanged. All the movements have resulted from movements in New York.

Ever since the creation of the Rapid Transit Commission there has been a strong demand for a direct cast side line into the Borough of the Bronx. Numerous appeals have been made to members of the commission by organizations and individuals interested in the district concerned, with little or no effect beyond a general approval of the scheme.

THE principal housemaid of the House of Lords is the subject of a parliamentary paper, which gives an account of how the Lord Great Chamberlain championed her interests against the parsimonious predilections of the Treasury and the Board of Works.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The principal topic discussed here during the past week has been the approaching marriage of Cooperstown's wealthiest ana best-known resident, Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark, to the Right Rev. Henry C. Potter, Episcopal Bishop of New York. No date has yet been given out, and the exact time is still a matter of speculation.

NEW LONDON, Aug. 30. -- Hostilities in the game of war begin at midnight tonight, and the army officers and men at the forts to be attacked are on the alert for the coming of the naval enemy, whose whereabouts. It is expected, will, be communicated from the outlying signal stations just as soon as the first ship comes within sighting distance.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30. -- Robert McLaughlin, a manufacturer of this city and a pioneer in the prohibition movement, died to-day, aged sixty-four years. He was Treasurer of the City Savings Bank and of the Old Town Merchants and Manufacturers' Association. Mr. McLaughlin had the distinction of being the first man in Maryland to vote the Prohibition Party ticket.

One of the most interesting facts in economic geology, and probably the one which is of greatest importance as affecting the trend of industrial development, is the steadily extending area of oil production in this country. Announcements of new discoveries separated by hundreds of miles are so familiar as part of the daily news gatherings as to attract scarcely more than passing notice as items of general interest.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 21. -- The resignation of the Secretary of Agriculture, Senor Terry, has been the chief topic of discussion during the past week. Two or three reasons are suggested, one being that Senor Terry hopes to become the Consul to Paris. The one generally accepted, however, is his disappointment over the failure of his plan to raise a loan of $4,000,000 for the benefit of the planters.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Aug. 30. -- This beautiful mountain resort seems to suffer no decrease in its number of Summer visitors. In fact, more applications are received by some of the hotels than can be entertained during the remainder of the season.

All the arrangements are practically complete for the Middle States regatta, which will be held on the Harlem River to-morrow. All the contestants are in the best of condition, and, aside from a little light, rowing to-day, their work is done.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 30. -- There is no apparent let-up to the season. Society has been as gay to-day as at any time during the month. The Kebo Valley Club was the particular centre of life. The regular dinner dance to-night was unusually large for so late in the season. Three parties were given, and at the ball which followed there were several hundred guests, the crowd overtaxing the capacity of the dancing room.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt is not up to date on the Constitution. He proposes an amendment thereof in order to regulate trusts, -- a most difficult proceeding and probably one that would fail. We have had several examples lately of how the Constitution may be stretched and strained.

Should the occasion arise relief of a not unsubstantial nature is to be given the money market. As a consequence whatever concern there has been in Wall Street and elsewhere as to the outlook is fast disappearing -- thanks largely to relief measures undertaken by the banks and the Treasury Department jointly

THERE are people who think there is nothing in the art of typography, that the style in which printed matter is "displayed" is a subject of no importance and affords no opportunity for the exhibition of taste. The subject matter itself, say these people, is the important thing; that the works of genius will speak in clarion tones, even through the medium of the vilest type and the stupidest mechanical arrangement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The Prime Minister of New South Wales, Australia, Sir Edward Barton, with Lady Barton, their son and daughter, and a party of Australians, consisting of Sir John Forrest, Minister of Defense, and Lady Forrest; Austin Chapman, a member of the New South Wales House of Representatives, and Mr. Flannery, private secretary to the Prime Minister, are in Washington on the way home from the coronation of King Edward.

Labor Day, which was started nearly twenty years ago as a purely labor festival and has since become a National holiday, will be marked in this city to-morrow by the first Labor Day parade of the building trades unions in twelve years. Other organizations will have picnics and reunions, usually followed by sports and athletic contests of various kinds, and social organizations and clubs will hold appropriate celebrations.

IN ONE respect the new American possessions are having what many call a deleterious effect upon the American peciple. They are increasing not only the number of smokers, but the smoking of the old smokers, for the cheapress of the weed has a great deal to do with the consumption.

Security market transactions for the five business days of last week were on a larger scale than for some time past, with here and there quite surprising outbursts of activity -- and, as usual, of late, activity as a rule resulted in the establishment of higher prices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Remarkable progress in manufacturing industry appears in the statistics of the manufacture of structural steel and iron in the United States, compiled by the Census Bureau. It is shown that in 1900 the total production of iron, Bessemer steel, and open hearth steel for structural purposes was 856,083 tons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- The Fleetwood Handicap, at six furlongs, was won at Hawthorne race track to-day by Toah. Brigadier was second, two lengths away, with Sidney C. Love third, four lengths separating second and third horses.

A law which will go into effect to-morrow will put divorce mill lawyers out of business. Its enactment is the result of fraudulent suits that brought about the conviction of two lawyers and caused another to find a habitat in Europe.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 30. -- The cool nights of the last week caused the visitors to this resort to turn their attention to indoor forms of amusement. Log fires were burned in the open fireplaces of nearly all of the hotels.

With a big hole in her port bow, the bottom of which was only a few inches from the water, her timber bracing badly sprained amidships, and minus all of her passengers, the Saugerties, a side-wheel steamboat, plying the Hudson between New York and Saugerties, put into her pier yesterday morning.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Mrs. Harrison, widow of ex-President Benjamin Harrison, will arrive in a few days, it is expected, to occupy her camp, Berkeley Lodge, on First Lake of the Fulton Chain of Lakes. Berkeley Lodge was the home for several Summers of Mr. Harrison, and he took much comfort there.

Four first-class houses open this week with new pieces, and several others with well-known revivals. In the majority of the theatres, concerts, and roof gardens special Labor Day performances will be given.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The impression produced by the inaugural meeting of the Buffalo Racing Association to-day is that it marks the entrance of this section into metropolitan racing, A crowd of 15,000 people, including prominent representatives of society, turned out for the opening day, although they have not heretofore patronized running races here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being a constant reader and ardent supporter of your paper, I have been somewhat surprised recently to notice the discrepancies between the news and the editorial comment upon the anthracite coal strike.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 30. -- Lewis G. Bernard was this afternoon elected Chairman of the Hamilton County Executive Committee. Bernard is the veteran lieutenant of John R. McLean in this city, and was recognized leader of local opposition to Tom L. Johnson in Democracy's ranks. Richelieu Hall was the scene of another fierce struggle between Bernard and Henry Heilker, the rival candidates for Chairman of the Democratic Campaign Committee, today.
THE two-minute pacing horse arrived five years ago. The two-minute trotting horse, expected each season since, now is very near at hand, if the predictions of horsemen are to be believed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article in this morning's TIMES regarding the Democratic Party making an issue in some States of the Schley affair prompts me to write a few ideas which have occurred to me in reference to the coming campaign. Since the Democratic Party went out of office there has not been a time when it had such a magnificent opportunity as it now has.
BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- A correspondent with the Presidential train telegraphs as follows:

Among the passengers on the Holland-America liner Statendam, which docked at Hoboken last evening, was Josef Zseni, chief clerk of the country in which Budapest is situated, and President of the Hungarian National Confederation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing the great interest you have taken in discussing the present coal strike, for the good of the public, I wish to compliment you on bringing out the point (What Are the Strike Issues?) in to-day's edition. When this, is known the public will not be reaching conclusions without a proper rock foundation.
WINDSOR, Vt., Aug. 30. -- On his way from Corbin Park here the President stopped at Cornish, N.H.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Augustus Bietz, a French chauffeur employed by Lawyer William B. Guthrie of New York, was arrested at Glen Cove this evening charged with violating the Cocks speed law in running his automobile at a faster speed than the law allows. In the vehicle was Mr. Guthrie and a woman, said to be a member of his family.
CHILDWOLD, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Dr. Reginald S. Sayre of New York is a guest of Mr. and Mrs. Coe Downing Tows, at Camp Isola, on Lake Massawepie.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- In the religious world the most important event this week has been the publication of the Wesleyan Methodist Pastoral. The Pastoral says that the closeness of intercourse, the immense powers now possessed for the production and distribution of wealth, and the almost worldwide co-operation and competition for these ends, bid fair to revolutionize the conditions of industrial and commercial life.

To me the line of lights from north to south as far as the eye could reach indicated the city of mystery, the city of my dreams. I stood upon the rounded bow of the heavy ferryboat as it plowed its way through the dark waters of the Hudson River, heading like an arrow for that sparkling island, and I wondered what would be my fate therein.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- At the close of July the Treasury deficit was $7,507,876.
