The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It was said in a recent review in your columns that "the adjective is the enemy of the noun." Will a careful study of the works of the best writers bear out this sweeping assertion?

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 5, on Board Dispatch Boat Avenel, Newport, R. I. -- Five vessels of the invading fleet of Admiral Higginson succeeded in getting between Forts Adams and Wetherell at the entrance to Newport Harbor and Narragansett Bay shortly after 10 o'clock to-night in the most magnificent sham battle ever contested by the American army and navy.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- The effect of the heavy dealings in Pennsylvania and Reading for the last two days in the Philadelphia market was seen to-day in a decided broadening of interest in this city, not in the stocks named, but in the wide diversity of securities dealt in. Pre-eminent, however, in the movement was Philadelphia Electric.

Until lately the discussions as to the future Rhodes scholars have been a vast sea of words surging about a tiny reef of knowledge. There have been those who optimistically ignored the practical difficulties of the undertaking, and those who have so, magnified them as to make them an insuperable obstacle; but matters of fact have been conspicuous in the discussions by their absence.

AT the entrance to the village of Elstow from Bradford there stands a small, quaint and tumble wayside cottage. A weather-beaten notice board affixed above the doorway informs the wayfarer that this is "Bunyan's Cottage." The public not unreasonably supposes, and very many are in fact told, that this cot is the identical one in which the famous John Buayan was born.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5. -- "I am seriously alarmed at the news of the renewed activity of the Martinique and St. Vincent volcanoes," said Louis H. Ayme, United States Consul at Guadeloupe, who is in Chicago on sick leave, to-day. He added:
LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The Cape Town correspondent of The Times says that the most important division thus far in the session of the Cape Parliament was taken in the Assembly on Thursday.

SARATOGA, N. Y., Sept. 5. -- The State Prohibition convention assembled here today and was called to order by J. H. Durkee of Rochester, Chairman of the State Committee. Addresses were made during the Young People's League hour by Edward E. Blake of Brooklyn and R. E. Blight of New York.
CHATHAM, Sept. 5. -- Gov. Odell spoke to-day at the Columbia County Fair Among other things he said:

The distinction between the journalist and the man of letters, the writer who must never forget his readers and the writer who must never remember them, is so obvious that it is vexatious to find the two confounded, merely because some men of letters have written for newspapers and some journalists have had their work bound in books.

Thomas W. Lawson, who last year caused to be built the gigantic scow yacht Independence, and who sought to compel the New York Yacht Club to admit her to the trial races for the honor of defending the America's Cup, was deeply aggrieved because the club refused to allow his yacht to compete unless entered in the name of a member of the club.

These miniature volumes, 3 by 5 inches, imported examples of Newnes's thin-paper editions of the English classics, show an extraordinary amount of literary material in a very small space. They are well made; the type is large and clear cut; each has a photogravure frontispiece and title page printed on Japanese vellum from drawings by Edmund J. Sullivan.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- I do not know whether to sympathize with Mr. Bernard Capes or to congratulate him. Recently a London publisher issued what he called a new novel by Mr. Capes, entitled "The Mill of Silence."

Is the bookkeeper born, and not made? A great many used to think that keeping accounts was a natural gift. Mr. Prince Albert Wright in his "Bookkeeping Simplified" explains the entire process of accounting -- in fact, the work is encyclopedic. Here is the entire bookkeeping phraseology systematically presented.

DEAL BEACH, N. J., Sept. 5. -- Fine weather made the golfing very enjoyable to-day in the first annual tournament of the Deal Golf Club. It will wind up tomorrow with Brokaw and Travis as the finalists for the Deal Cup.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The following questions, to an American certainly not wanting in interest, were published twice in Notes and Queries, London, without eliciting a reply. Can you or any of your readers give the desired information?

The Contest Committee of the Automobile Club of America, which is composed of Winthrop E. Scarrett, George F. Chamberlain, John A. Hill, and Secretary S.M. Butler, has issued a preliminary announcement of the 500-mile reliability contest from this city to Boston and return, which will be held by the club Oct. 9 to 15.
Sir: You will probably expect, after my telegram, that I should enter into a few more details about the fatal accident on the Wetterhorn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Chairman Agnew of the Virginia Republican State Committee is of the opinion that a safe prediction cannot be made at this time as to the probable result of the November election in that State. The uncertainty is created by the new registration law. Only one county has completed its registration, so that neither side has any idea what the relative strength of the parties will be.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why should not the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania acquire the anthracite coal fields by legal methods and then mine the coal and sell it to the public on reasonable terms? The hours of the miners would be easier and there would not be this annual strike which puts such a damper on the legitimate business interests of this land.

HOW in thandah such a man as that ever got into the club I'm sure I don't know. I believe his family's all right, and of course he has plenty of oof, but then, you know as I've often said to Weginald. 'Whatever happens, this club must keep select. Persons that work must be made to understand that they are unsuitable.'

To the Editor of The New York Times: The overestimated opinion which you and many of our newspapers have of the efficiency and worth of Chief Croker cannot be passed over without some explanation. Chief Croker did not obtain his place purely from meritorious and efficient service in the department, but because of his connection with Tammany Hall and the strong influence of his English uncle, Sir Richard.

POPE LEO XIII, will on the approaching celebration of his Papal jubilee receive a present which so far has never been surpassed. It is a topaz found in the mines of Minas -- Geraes, in Brazil. This stone weighs no less than 1,784 grams, but what doubles its value is the work which has been expended on it.

The bronze German Grenadier, designed by Moritz Wolff of Berlin for the graves of German veterans at Philadelphia, has reached that city. The figure is over eight feet high, and represents a Color Sergeant with his rifle in the left hand raising a tattered battle flag on high in his right. The metal was supplied by guns captured in the Franco-German war.

WITHIN the past ten days the sharp eyes of Wall Street have been raised for a few moments to contemplate a new figure in the world of control -- John Cleveland Osgood of Redstone, Col., who enjoys the proud distinction of having whipped the celebrated Chicago plunger, John W. Gates, in a desperate battle for the control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see that no one has commented upon the address of U.M. Rose, President of the American Bar Association, regarding two points which the writer thinks worthy of comment.

DURING the first week of the clever young man's stay at Prospect he had been filled full of conversation concerning "Li" Pembrook. Morning, noon, and night the good people, who merely wanted to interest the city chap, had fired "Li" at him. He thought of "Li" walking or sitting, eating or reading, and he dreamed of the wonderful chap who had such a strenuous life and did such wonderful things.

Those so-called "conservatives" who for the past year or more have been clamoring with much persistence, but with little effect, as to the danger of what they were pleased to style the inflated values on the Stock Exchange must put down another of their week's work to the profit and loss account.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- When the Rev. John J. McGrath of St. John's Roman Catholic Church of the place delivered a sermon to the women of his congregation, telling them that Sunday bonnets were becoming so elaborate and expensive as to interfere with the proper conduct of services, he struck a sentiment which long ago was well rooted in the minds of many preachers in this section.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To "refuse continuing the discussion" at a particularly proper time, and to demand "not to be drawn further into a controversy," has in this country been generally considered as the subterfuge of the literary coward or as evidence of a victory in logics and facts of the other side to the dispute.

IT WAS the beach at East Hampton, not the Island of Despair, and Miss Alice Brevort had not been shipwrecked thereon, neither was she dressed in skins, nor was the sunshade she carried wholly made of palm leaves; the gaudy bird on her hat may once have been a talking companion; it now spread its plumes above her in silence.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- From a proposal made in Chicago that the German turner societies aid the striking coal miners has grown a National movement to that end, participated in by Bohemian. Polish, and Norwegian turners and singing societies and labor organizations of Germans. Secretary Leopold Neumann of the Chicago District, who was first to propose assistance to the strikers, has received letters from all parts of the country.
LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The statement of the Board of Trade for August shows a decrease of $2,623,000 in imports and an increase of $471,500 in exports.

IF THE shade of Edwin Forrest or the elder Booth has not been forever frightened away from the Bowery by the strange tongue that is spouted in the old theatre with the columns in front, it may again take heart. Shakespeare has come back to the Bowery; Hamlet, Otello, and -- oh, prerogatives of polite society -- Ibsen, Maeterlinck, Sudermann, and d'Annunzio.

With a bang and a whoop and a rattle of drums, "King High Ball" swooped down upon the New York Theatre stage last night and displayed himself for the first time in this city. Not in many a day has there been such a glistening of gold and silver foil and seldom has there been such a terrific blowing and pounding of musical instruments.

NEW LONDON, Sept. 6. -- Through his chief of staff, Thomas H. Barry, Major Gen. MacArthur to-day sent a telegram to all commanders, expressing his entire satisfaction with the work of the army during the war manoeuvres. The dispatch follows:

DEMOLITION has been begun on the old United States Hotel, that projects its northeast corner into Fulton Street at Water Street. It means the sacrifice of another landmark of fifty or more years ago in the lower east side of Manhattan Island. It was really a landmark, its cupola in the days of its prime having been a signal place for the observation and announcement of the arrival of the clipper ships from foreign ports.

The financial growth of the United States during the past quarter of a century has been phenomenal, and the remarkable way in which the different States have decreased their bonded indebtedness has never been equaled by any othr country in the world.

MANY people are now cogitating over a problem that involves morals, quickness, method, business, talent, and other qualities that go to make or mar the successful man. It affords ground for speculation and discussion that bring many interesting subjects under consideration, and was presented as follows a day or two ago in THE TIMES:

Rough-riding troopers of Squadron A engaged yesterday in the first polo match of their Autumn tournament on the field at Van Cortlandt Park. It was a handicap affair, in which the Class A players allowed the Class B team two goals and then defeated them by the score of 6 1/4 goals to 3.

TWO black, eager faces bent suddenly forward as the dice -- bones, they called them -- rattled upon the low roof of Wung Sin's laundry. As the tiny cubes tumbled over and over, deciding the ownership of the two coins which lay between the youthful gamblers, the "shooter" called, fervently: "Come seben! Dis fo' a pain o' shoes!"

A new type of shallow draught screw steamer, which has been designed by Messrs. Yarrow Co. of Poplar, yesterday ran a preliminary trial trip on the Thames. The vessel has been built for trading purposes on South American rivers where shallow draught is an essential feature in the navigation.

SOME years ago a local politician and saloon keeper of some influence in the old Fourth Ward -- Pat O'Brien by name -- was much troubled by the water main of the street leaking into the front cellar of his house, and interfering, among other things, with his keeping chickens of which he was very fond.

Not so very long ago mountaineering in Switzerland and other parts of the Alpine region was taken somewhat seriously; it was regarded as a health-giving though dangerous and difficult sport, but within recent years the number of tourists who make holiday among the Alps has so greatly increased that the ascent of a high mountain has come to be looked upon as something in the nature of a mere pleasure excursion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial on "Coincidences of Statecraft" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 31, concludes with the words: "Indeed, wherever England has a nice little commercial or diplomatic embroilment, there Germany bobs up, quite as pious and greedy as she is, and much more unscrupulous.

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN BACHE, druggist, 782 West Side Avenue, Jersey City a great grandson of Benjamin Franklin, and his brother, Walter Livingston Bache, still cherish the hope that they will be able to secure from the Cities of Philadelphia and Boston the original fund of $5,000 in each place left by the will of their famous ancestor, and the earnings of the money, which in Boston amount to about $380,000 and in Philadelphia to about $90,000.

LORAIN, Ohio, Sept. 6. -- The Democratic State campaign was opened in this city to-night. A tent with a seating capacity of 3,500 people was crowded. A drenching rain began to fall during the speech of the Rev. Herbert Bigelow, candidate for Secretary of State, and continued during the rest of the meeting.

CHICAGO, Sept 6. -- The body of a man, thought to be William Bartholin, murderer of his mother and sweetheart in Chicago six weeks ago, was found to-day in a field near Lowther, Iowa, 290 miles from Chicago.

THERE have just been finished at Springfield, Mass., two model cars that will be made the basis for letting the contract for fitting the subway with rolling stock. The Wason Company, says The Springfield Republican, has completed these cars and sent them to New York. They are a miniature exposition of car building.

For some years past the importance of rendering the Japanese Government independent of foreign countries for a supply of iron and steel has attracted much attention in that country. In 1890 an attempt by the Naval Department to get a bill through the Diet for the establishment of iron and steel works for naval purposes was a failure.

THE oyster has come to the front in Maryland as a live issue. It has come to stay, too, and for the next decade, or until the question is settled, the tariff, currency, negro domination, and every other issue is going to take a subordinate place. It has been growing in importance for several years until now it has assumed such proportions that party lines are in a fair way to be obliterated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of Sept. 5, headed "Tom Johnson to the Fore," you make several statements which seem to me to be in very bad taste, if not dishonest. The statements are partly true. But because they are partly true they are, in the connection in which you have used them, more viciously false than if they were not true.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your articles on the coal strike are truly critical, while fairly impartial. Your endeavor is to report the inside in place of filling your columns with "both sides." This is especially true of your editorial in to-day's issue, which deals with the idea of ownership and its real meaning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hardly a week has passed since January without announcement being made in the newspapers that sums of money ranging from a modest several thousand dollars to several million dollars have been appropriated for the improvement of the city and the conditions of living among its inhabitants, on the recommendation of Mayor Low, Borough President Cantor, or some other city official.

LAWYERS of New York now talk of the days when the great lights of the legal profession appeared in criminal cases, and the masters of forensic ability crossed swords of logic and eloquence with human life and liberty at stake. The death of William F. Howe, the last of the line of prominent pleaders before the criminal bar, has brought forward the facts of the decadence of criminal practice in New York.

CITIZENS of Charleston, S.C., are much exercised over a strange phantom which they say has suddenly made its appearance in their fair city. During the past week or ten days reports have come in from various outlying districts which do not tend to allay the fears of nervously disposed persons.

MAMBAJAO, Camiguin, P.I., July 30. -- They are saying now in the Philippine Islands that the work of the Educational Department has been a failure. To prove that this is not only evidence of poor judgment on the part of the Civil Government, but also of the United States, if it is a failure, it is only necessary to consider the matter of appropriations from the Insular Treasury.

A press report states that the Wabush Road has placed an order with the Carnegie Company for 25,000 tons of steel rails. These rails are to be used in laying a track from Zanesville, Ohio, to that point on the West Virginia Central where the Wabash makes connection. The Wabash will have a line into the Connellsville coke region.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why are the coal operators not at liberty to employ sufficient miners to find work 300 days in the year? This would be two-thirds of the present number who, we are assured, can be employed only 200 days annually. Each miner would earn 50 per cent. more than at present, laborers and boys in proportion.

The annual report of the New York, Ontario and Western Railway Company for the year, ended June 30 last, issued yesterday, contains many references to and statements regarding the coal strike. In the report President Fowler says to the stockholders:

MR. DEVERY, who prides himself on never having read a book except a "police blotter," has during the last two months originated more epigrammatic sentences than any politician who has ever aspired to be leader of Tammany Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One often hears the remark: "The right of workmen to join unions and ask for recognition of their unions cannot be denied, especially by their employers who belong to associations or combinations."

It is really not creditable to our general average of intelligence that the American Embassy in London should have been compelled to issue another statement warning Americans against efforts to interest them in "unclaimed" estates of great value and high anti-quity in the British Islands.

A good many of the peers' and peeresses' coronation robes have been secured by theatrical costumiers. A quantity of the rich stuff seen at the Abbey will probably contribute to the gayety of the patrons of Christmas pantomime in both London and the provinces. -- Leeds Mercury.

In the Philippines the question of Chinese immigration has already become a burning topic of dispute, but the Americans have imported their prejudices as well as their armies, and all present indications seem to point to a policy of rigid exclusion of the yellow alien from the newly acquired possessions.

The House of Lords, sitting as a court of final appeal, has just rendered a decision in a case which establishes a precedent of first importance touching the question of the effect of the probability of an outbreak of war upon a contract of insurance entered into between the subject or citizen of one power and a subject or citizen of another and possibly imminently hostile power.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- The money situation at the end of the week was much the same as it has been for several days past. The tone was still very firm, even though the business doing, as is always the case on Saturday, was extremely light. Clearing House rate, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 20 per cent. discount; call loans, 5 per cent.; time money, 5@6; Clearing House exchanges, $23,749,540; balances, $1,999,764.

JOHN E. SEYBOLD, the Syracuse collector, has come into possession of a specimen of the rare 12-pence black stamp of Canada. It is on the original envelope, being thus unique, as it is believed, says The Utica Herald-Dispatch, to be the only one extant in that form.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The fierce encounter between Jerry Hunter and half a hundred policemen at North Beach on Monday night and the consequent incidents thereto forcibly impresses one with the unnecessary brutality and inexcusable foul language of many of the police force of this metropolis.

DEERFIELD, in Massachusetts, where the Arts and Crafts Exhibition closed recently, has solved the problem of the "decaying village," if not of the abandoned farm, in a way that may lead to the industrial rejuvenation of rural New England.

THE results of the various assaults made during the past week by the North Atlantic Squadron upon the chain of forts at the eastern entrance to Long Island Sound seem at present to be enmeshed in such a tangle of conflicting claims advanced by the partisans of the two services as to afford a fine "war game" between a "sea lawyer" and a "Philadelphia lawyer."

A SCHOOL of wireless telegraphy is to be opened in a few days at Babylon, L.I., and a course of instruction for applicants has been outlined. Thus a new profession is about to be opened up for aspiring young Americans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of Richard Mansfield's announcement that he will this coming Winter play Julius Caesar, taking the parts of both Caesar and Brutus himself, it may be of some interest to your readers to recall the following from Blackwood's Comic Zadkiel for 1855:

With the beginning of September trading in bank stocks usually becomes active, and for that reason it will be interesting at this time to compare the prices at which these securities are selling with their "book values" or the amount which would be realized should the banks be liquidated with the present surplus and profits.

Trading on the curb yesterday was not so active as had been expected after the strength and broadness displayed during the earlier part of the week. Although a few stocks declined somewhat sharply, quite a number advanced fractionally and offset the losses. Trading in Northern Securities was at prices that ranged between 117 and 116, and closed the day with a net loss of three-eighths of a point.

Within the last three months three new police stations have been opened in the Borough of the Bronx, thus breaking the record in the borough and in the Police Department. The new stations are substantial, commodious, and handsome brick structures, replacing old, dilapidated wooden buildings not originally intended for the uses to which they were put when the Police Department obtained possession of them.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Arthur L. Wills was the only contestant for the Boys' Cup on the Hillside Tennis and Golf Club course this morning. He won 3 points. For the Golf Committee Cup this afternoon the following scores were made:

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the United Mine Workers' organization displays such a lamentable lack of business instinct in the bills which it wants the Legislature of Pennsylvania and the Congress of the United States to pass, as outlined in to-day's TIMES, isn't it fair to assume that it has been equally impracticable in the demands made upon the coal operators?

Charles R. Flint's twin-screw yacht Arrow beat her own and all other records yesterday over an officially measured course on the Hudson River, between Ardsley and Irvington, by making a nautical mile of 6,080 feet in 92 seconds, or a statute mile in a little more than 1 minute 18 seconds, or at the rate of 39.24 knots or nautical miles, or 44.13 statute miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- The Post Office Department closed a contract to-day with the New York Mail and Newspaper Transportation Company for pneumatic tube service for postal matter over the old lines that were in operation from 1897 to 1900, when they were discontinued owing to the failure of Congress to appropriate for them.

BURGIN, Ky., Sept. 6. -- The President received a warm and noisy welcome here to-night. Responding, he said that he had been in Kentucky before, and that he appreciated to the full the pre-eminent qualities of Kentucky's men, Kentucky's women, and Kentucky's horses. [Cheers and laughter.] Continuing, he said:

Another change in the affairs of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club will be ushered in to-morrow. Then it will hold to its old name, and the cherry diamond emblem will still be worn by its athletes, but as a club organization, in the real sense of that word, it ceases, and will in reality become a popular public athletic organization.
Under the heading "Municipal Socialism," a correspondent of The London Times contributes the fourth of a series of articles at once interesting and suggestive:

There is a very positive opinion among the real estate men of New York that the sale and rental of houses here is a more accurate barometer of economic conditions than the quotation prices of stocks on Wall Street. As one of the men largely interested in real estate put it yesterday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Probably no single individual, not excepting even President Roosevelt, is the subject of more thought and discussion to-day than Tom L. Johnson of Ohio, to whom you devote a lengthy editorial this morning. His is the one figure in public life representative of an official doing something of immediate practical good.

Secretary of State John T. McDonough has put a large-sized crack in the Republican slate for the State ticket by refusing to accept a renomination. He came from Albany yesterday and went to the Hoffman House.

ON BOARD THE BATTLESHIP ALABAMA, Block Island, Sept. 6. -- No man in Rear Admiral Higginson's fleet knows today which has won in the manoeuvres of the past week, the navy or the army, but so important were the lessons learned and so valuable the experiences of the days of "war" that the question of victory is comparatively of minor import.

A special meeting was held in Manchester recently of the Association for British-Grown Cotton. Count Gleichen, the Secretary to the Sirdar in the Soudan, was present, and delivered an address on the prospects of growing cotton in the Soudan. He explained that small experiments in cotton growing had been made in the Soudan, and Lord Cromer was much interested in the success of the enterprise.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Forty-seven of America's best marksmen met in competition at Sea Girt to-day in the President's Match for the military championship of the United States. Each contestant fired seven shots at the 200, 300, 500, 600, 800, and 1,000 yard targets. The contest began at 10 A.M. and was not finished until nearly dusk.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- At the Pitlochry, Perthshire, Scotland, Highland games today A.O. Cameron put the twenty-pound shot 60 feet 5 inches and the fifty-six-pound weight 30 feet 8 inches, breaking the world's records.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- George E. Cole, President of the Legislative Voters' League, and Frederick M. Blount, Vice President of the Chicago National Bank and the Republican leader of the Twentieth Ward, came to blows in the main reception room of the Union League Club a few days ago as a result of a political discussion.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 6. -- The last dinner dance of the Summer at the Kebo Valley Club occurred to-night. It was a brilliant finale to the most successful season the club has ever had. Waldron Bates was the host. The house and grounds were beautifully decorated. Nearly all the Summer colony came to the ball, so that the dancers overflowed the ballroom and the verandas were made to do service.

JUST how to pronounce the name of our President is a matter that puzzles a great many people. His name has given rise to a greater variety of pronunciation than that of any statesman who has ever occupied the front rank.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a constant reader of your paper I feel impelled to call your attention to an absolutely erroneous statement which appears in your editorial column this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great deal has been written and said about the merits of the coal strike, sometimes by men in favor of the miners and sometimes by men against them. I am one of the former, but I am always in favor of what I believe to be justice.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Although no official notice has yet been received, it is generally understood that the Inter-State Commerce Commission expects to be in Chicago on Sept. 25 and 26 to hear complaints that certain Chicago and St. Paul lines have been cutting flour rates. Some of the Missouri River lines also are accused of manipulating grain rates between Kansas City and Chicago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many have doubtless read with surprise Mr. Hewitt's observations on the strike situation in Pennsylvania. He thinks there is nothing to arbitrate. Some still survive who lament that he was not like minded in 1876 when Samuel J. Tilden was elected President of the United States.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Sept. 6. -- President Roosevelt has won the hearts of Englishmen so thoroughly by his virile character that the expression of relief was universal when it became known that he had only received slight injuries in the accident last Wednesday.

Mrs. Chris Sonniksen has left San Jose for Dawson City. She goes by way of Nome, and thence up the river to the northern El Dorado. The going of Mrs. Sonniksen was not chronicled in society events because she is a full-blooded Chug-Chi, the most northerly tribe of Indians on the American continent.

MAJOR ISAAC B. BROWN, Deputy Secretary of Internal Affairs at Harrisburg, Penn., discovered an old document a few days ago that is of more than ordinary interest. It was the original of a resolution passed by the Continental Congress on the day after the signing of the Declaration of Independence, written in John Hancock's bold chirography, and containing his autograph in two places.

MADRID, Aug. 20. -- The unconventional doings of the young King of Spain are causing embarrassment to his entourage, as his Majesty, in the exuberance of his spirits, frequently shocks the susceptibilities of the Spanish grandees by his boyish jokes and pranks.

A TALL. gaunt man, with a hungry expression and a leather case, walked into the headquarters of the Professional Woman's League the other day and asked for Mrs. Knowles. He was dressed entirely in black and closely resembled the late-afternoon shadow of a medical student.

IT IS the intention of Superintendent Maxwell of the city public schools that in one respect at least to-morrow shall be notable. Every child above the age of six years who applies for admission to the schools shall be accommodated, declares Mr. Maxwell, in either whole or part-time classes.

DOWN New York Bay, along Butter-milk Channel, across which cow were driven at low tide, traditions say, two centuries ago, there is a sight that old New Yorkers, and latter-day ones as well, would gaze upon in astonishment if once they saw it.

The startling theory brought by Prof. Schoetensack of Heidelberg before the Berlin Anthropological Society at a recent meeting will, if accepted by science, cause a return to the old belief of the origin of man in one spot and explain the essential unity of the human race without regard to color.

TO the French people of Canada Sir Wilfrid Laurier is the greatest if not the only great person living. Some time ago a "habitant" arriving in the City of Quebec met an old friend and fell to talking politics. In the course of conversation he happened to mention the name of Queen Victoria and the friend informed him that the Queen had been dead for a year.

There is no present indication that the Democrats will be appreciably stronger in the United States Senate after March 3, 1903, than they are now. At the close of the last session of Congress they had 33 seats and the Republicans 55, the two Delaware Senatorships being vacant. If there is no great political overturning this Fall, it is predicted the Democrats will just about hold their own.

This Fail, for the first time it is believed, the new apartment houses of the seven-story elevator type will occupy a position in the real estate market that is not unduly beset by unfavorable conditions. As a result there will be a better opportunity than any yet afforded to determine their exact standing in point of popular approval, and, incidentally, their prospective future as a form of real estate investment.

A LITTLE dispatch from Duluth, printed a few days ago, but squeezed out of sight in the press of news of our material greatness and intelligence, set forth that the people of that progressive, enlightened, and peculiarly American centre of civilization had risen up against an ordinance which expelled the fortune tellers, and had forced its repeal.

The International Congress for the Amelioration of the Lot of the Blind, which has just concluded its sittings in Brussels, brought together representatives of the principal countries of the world, many of them being well-known specialists in the care and treatment of the blind. The debates of the conference were of a thoroughly practical nature, and brought out many useful points in connection with the education and general treatment of the blind.

LONG BRANCH, Sept. 6. -- There was some spirited golfing before a large "gallery" over the new 5,653-yard, eighteen-hole course of the Hollywood Golf Club to-day between four of the best professionals in the country. They were Will Anderson, the open champion; Isaac Mackie of Fox Hills, who played together, and Bernard Nichols of the Hollywood Club and George Low of Dyker Meadow.

SUPERINTENDENT SPENCER of New York's Aquarium has been a very busy man the past few days. Quite recently a consignment of fish from Southern waters arrived, in charge of Purser Pierce of the steamship Esperanza. Since that time Mr. Spencer has devoted all his spare time in poring over piscatorial authorities and colored plates, trying to identify his new charges.

The Middle States regatta on Monday marked the conclusion of the local rowing season as far as racing is concerned, for, although there is talk of an open regatta on the Potomac at Washington next month, the chances are not in favor of its being held and none of the local clubs have kept their crews in training for any such remote contingency.

With the coming of the first cool days of Autumn the sport-loving followers turn toward football. This year there promise to be more and better matches on the gridiron than ever before, because of the manner in which every class has turned toward the game which gives to the spectator an abundance of spirit and dash, and necessitates an immense amount of physical skill and development.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ever since the earth was projected from chaos into the cosmic universe it has been confronted with problems. There have been problems sociological and political. These, at the outset, were wont to be determined according to the strength or weakness of the contending factors.

NEWPORT, Sept. 6. -- Grand Duke Boris had another busy time to-day. He was the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Oelrichs at luncheon at the Ciam Bake Club, drove with Mrs. Oelrichs, and with her went to the children's entertainment in aid of St. Mary's Church, later witnessed the polo games, and this evening was the guest at Mrs. Ogden Mills's dinner.

DEAL BEACH, Sept. 6. -- Walter J. Travis added the First Cup to his collection of trophies to-day in the closing round of the Deal Beach Golf Club tournament, for G. T. Brokaw, although he made a strong bid in the afternoon, could at no time get a lead on the veteran player. The other cup finals were won by Proal, Tiffany, Martin, and McClave.
Society, as a class, feels run down and exhausted when the advent of August releases it from a long succession of dances, dinners; and "crushes" in town, and allows it to think of recuperation.

IF YOU do not happen to possess a single-breasted waistcoat with a notched collar -- and it is scarcely likely that you do, for they have been out of fashion for about fifteen years -- it will be necessary to visit a tailor at once, if you would show acquaintance with the latest style in men's wear for this Fall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I write in reference to the statement in to-day's TIMES accredited to Sir Edward Barton, the Australian Premier, now in Washington, that "It seems incredible to me that a little group of half a score should defy the needs of 75,000,000 people. Starving to death and freezing to death are much the same thing."

The contest for the Democratic leadership of the Ninth Assembly district was carried on with more vigor last evening than at any time since the battle started between ex-Chief of Police William S. Devery, Frank J. Goodwin, and John C. Sheehan. Three meetings were held, and the streets of the district were crowded with the enthusiastic followers of the factions.

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, Sept. 4. -- An official account of the outbreak of Mont Pelee, Island of Martinique, during the night of Aug. 30, was received here today. It confirmed the previous news on the subject, and added that at the time the report was forwarded 1,060 deaths had been reported, that 150 persons were severely injured, and that Morne Rouge and the greater part of Ajoupa Bouillon had been destroyed.

ROME, Aug. 20. -- Is the much-calumniated Erythrea colony going to be, after all, a source of wealth to the peninsula? Gold has certainly been found, and now it is said the prospects of a new industry are very great. It will, I am sure, come as somewhat of a surprise to most people to hear that Italy is a large manufacturer of cotton goods.

The forthcoming National championships of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States give promise of being the most interesting competitions ever given by the parent body, and for the first time in a great many years other sections than the Metropolitan district will be represented. Thomas F. Riley, the New England member of the Championship Committee, has promised to send on a team of New England athletes, including McVicar, the New England five-mile champion.

M. Gaston Leroux publishes in the Matin an article on the infant mortality caused by bad and adulterated milk. He quotes statistics of a most painful nature, which would seem to demonstrate beyond doubt that an enormous percentage of the children who die annually in France are literally poisoned by bad milk.

TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 6. -- Canada is rapidly becoming a nation of sharpshooters. This is one of the results of the Boer war. If the other colonies of Great Britain have learned this lesson, the next campaign in which England is engaged will be a bloody affair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me to correct some of the statements contained in your editorial concerning Tom L. Johnson? THE TIMES has a well-deserved reputation for accuracy of statement, and I believe it is your desire to state only what is true. I am acquainted with Tom L. Johnson, and know more about his career than the writer of the editorial referred to.

WILKESBARRE, Sept. 6. -- President Mitchell of the Mine Workers' Union absolutely refuses to discuss the prospect of a special session of the Legislature and the enactment of a compulsory arbitration law, although he is on record as being against any measure which compels both sides in a contest to abide by the decision of arbitrators.

TO SAY that "Monroedoctrinitis" is a new disease would not be precisely accurate, for it has existed in some forms in various parts of Europe for a considerable time. Recently, however, the scourge has spread with alarming rapidity, the character of the disease becoming of a more virulent type year after year.

BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- As the United States cruiser Des Moines, which is to be sent overboard at the Fore River shipyard at Quincy on the 20th of this month, is the most important war vessel completed in a Massachusetts shipyard since the days of the early American Navy, Secretary of the Navy Moody has designated Miss Clara N. Carleton of Haverhill to represent the State at the launching ceremonies.

Heroic and prompt action on the part of a boy and girl alone saved three children from perishing in flames which destroyed practically the entire interior of the cottage home of William Stephens, a carpenter, at 1,294 Hoe Street, not far from East One Hundred and Seventy-second Street, in the Borough of the Bronx, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

WHEN a man has been dancing attendance on a girl for three years, and his attentions have been accepted for most of that time, it does seem as though he should be shown a little consideration. But when I had asked Mary Hanray to cut Bob Elverson off her list she had turned me down cold.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to thank "Honesty" for the excellent advice he gives to clergymen in last Sunday's TIMES. I have also noticed that ministers, like other poor people, are apt to live up to or beyond their income. In fact, I have always done it myself.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- The methods of the State Board of Equalization, charged with allowing thousands of Illinois corporations to escape proper assessments on their capital stock, are being investigated by a special Grand Jury. Detectives were at work today and last night seeking evidence, and when the inquisitors reconvene on Tuesday afternoon several members of the board will be questioned closely.

VIENNA, Aug. 21. -- M. Cvetkovic, the well-known Croatian engineer, has supplied me with the following details of the aero-hydrostatle vessel which he has just invented, and which he declares will enable the journey round the world to be made in a few days.

Oarsmen suffered from the depredations of a sneak thief yesterday while the regatta of the Lone Star Boat Club was in progress. The oarsmen and their guests were participating in the racing over a course from One Hundred and Forty-fifth to One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street on the Harlem River.

POSEN, Prussian Poland, Sept. 6. -- The Emperor's personal inquiries into the circumstances that aggravate social feeling here will probably result in some measures designed to lessen the local tension. He told Archbishop Stablewski Thursday that he regretted the fact that the Germans and Poles could not live in the same community without hating each other, and expressed the hope that the virulance of this feeling might be ameliorated.

Within ten days or two weeks that product of the Summer season, the roof garden, will have disappeared. With its closing the return rush from field, forest, and shore sets in, and consequently the theatrical season, from the box office view, may then be considered as being launched.

Two marble-front dwellings will be erected by George W. Vanderbilt at 645 and 647 Fifth Avenue, a part of the unimproved plot at the southeast corner of Fifty-second Street, diagonally opposite Mr. Vanderbilt's residence, at the northwest corner of Fifty-first Street, and adjoining the Union Club's new house at the northeast corner of Fifty-first Street.
TOM," said William Sweetem, the head bookkeeper for Billings Co., as he rushed excitedly into the room of his bosom friend, "wake up and dress yourself. I want you to do something for me in a hurry."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of to-day entitled "Tom Johnson to the Fore" contains nothing inaccurate up -- or shall we say down? -- to the point where you say: "Having enjoyed without protest or complaint the benefits of a protective tariff which added largely to his fortune, he became a free trader and a railer against Dingleyism, the trusts, and monopolies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We expect nothing better from some papers than that they should misrepresent facts to serve their own ends. But we expect honesty and approximate accuracy from THE TIMES, however, and it is with astonishment that I find THE TIMES misrepresenting Tom L. Johnson on the tariff question.

It is decreed that the Summer season is about over. There will be hunting and a few dinners, but no dances of any importance during September. Mrs. Astor remains rather late, but she never comes to the city before Autumn is much advanced and the time for the Horse Show is near. The Duchess of Marlborough has left there to be a week at Hempstead.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- There was hard riding this afternoon by the huntsmen who followed the Essex hounds on the run of twelve miles across rolling country from here to Bridgehampton. The run was made by the leaders in 35 minutes, the fastest time ever made behind a pack here.

An astonishing story comes from Binghamton, N.Y., telling of the formation of a corporation with a million dollars capital to develop commercially the discovery of a chemist of that place by which whisky, brandy, and other highly stimulating beverages, as well as such sophisticated gratifications as the several varieties of the cocktail, may be embodied in tablets like lozenges and the elements of a boisterous and memorable debauch carried in the vest pocket.

IT WAS on the Sixth Avenue "L." At One Hundred and Fourth Street he got on. There was the mark of the thoroughbred in everything about him. He took one of the cross seats, and with a glance out of the window at the heavens, which were fair, hung his umbrella over his arm with a smile, as if at his needless thoughtfulness, and began correcting some "page proofs" that he held in his hand.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 6. -- September has come, but the social army shows no disposition to strike camp and move cityward. The perfect conditions of weather have had the effect of keeping here many who would otherwise have gone a fortnight ago. The social calendar for the next two weeks is a good and sufficient indicator of the probable length of the season.

It is always interesting to know what impression a foreigner receives from works of native art, what rank he gives to various artists. In a certain way he comes to the subject with an impartiality not so easily attained by those who have followed the artist's whole career and have known his work a longer time.

The full explanation given by President Baer to the two United States Senators from Pennsylvania of the position of the coal operators in the present conflict with the United Mine Workers, and the report of Commissioner Carroll D. Wright to the President of the United States, have combined to establish conditions which render practicable the settlement of the existing difficulties honorably, fairly, and to the satisfaction of all in interest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The attempt of this morning's TIMES to give "the measure, the length, breadth, and thickness of Mr. Tom L. Johnson's economic and political principles" suggests a number of thoughts.

WHAT proves to be the hugest tree yet found among the giant forest throng of California, already famed in song and story, has recently been discovered in a wild, unfrequented nook of the State. It was officially measured for the first time on Aug. 23 by John Muir, the famous naturalist, discoverer, and writer, who has done so much to make known the natural wonders of the Pacific slope.

SOMEWHERE in an ancient and honored book it has been said that "Man shalt not live on bread alone," but during the past few months the thrifty husband has frequently reminded his wife that, notwithstanding the Scriptural injunction, it were better and less expensive to lean a little more heavily on the staff of life than to continue the National devotion to meats.

PARIS, Aug. 28. -- Officials in the Quai d'Orsay who are not occupied in watching the little comedy that is being played by the German Kaiser and his Polish subjects in Posen have considerable to say to their friends about the strained relations between the United States and Turkey.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The journalists' conference this week has been enlivened by a discussion on dramatic criticism initiated by Sir Edward Russell, editor of The Liverpool Daily Post, who lectured on "The Drama's Laws."

The bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fair, who were killed on Aug. 14 by their automobile crashing into a tree on the side of the road between Paris and Trouville, arrived from Cherbourg last night on the American liner St. Louis. The steamship anchored in Quarantine at 9 P.M. and will dock at her pier at the foot of Fulton Street between 7 and 8 o'clock this morning.

The Jewish World published yesterday a detailed balance sheet of the accounts of the Jewish Colonization Association, the trust created by the late Baron de Hirsch with the magnificent donation of $50,000,000, for the purpose of helping his persecuted co-religionists. It is best known by its formation of colonies of the Argentina.

Mr. Frederick R. Coudert's Seawanhaka knockabout. Heron, lies at the bottom of Long Island Sound, off Centre Island Point, in six fathoms of water. She was sunk in collision with her racing rival, the Lucille, in the regatta of the Seawanhaka-Corinthlan Yacht Club yesterday afternoon. The accident happened as the boats of the knockabout class were coming to the line at the start.

Quite generally prices declined on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Previous to the publication of the bank statement there had been selling throughout the list in the belief that the figures would be bad. When they were published they were even averse than had been expected, surplus reserves being cut down by more than $5,600,000 and a loss in cash of more than $8,000,000 being reported.

To-morrow is the fiftieth anniversary of the opening of Wallack's Theatre, in many respects the most celebrated of theatres in America. The anniversary of that event will be observed at the theatre to-morrow night, where "Mrs. Jack" is now being presented.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 6. -- President Roosevelt and party arrived over the Baltimore and Ohio at 8:30 this morning from Washington. He was greeted by a vast crowd at the station, and smiled his appreciation, despite his badly discolored face. His right cheek was rather badly swollen and contused, and his left eye showed signs of discoloration.

-- Rarely indeed has there flashed a brighter light upon any branch of our Municipal Government, with resulting revelations more picturesque or more edifying, than was the speech delivered before the Board of Aldermen by Alderman DAVID STEWART on "The Perils of Being an Alderman."

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- An official investigation is to be made by the city authorities of the allegations made by Father James J. McKeever, rector of St. Rose of Lima's Church, concerning the misconduct of certain physicians on the house staff of the City Hospital. The Mayor and other officials are incensed over the nature of the charges, and they express their feelings emphatically.
PARIS, Sept. 6. -- The steamships leaving Europe for the United States have rarely been so crowded as this year, and large premiums have been paid to secure berths.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- Major Gens. Corbin and Young and Brig. Gen. Wood were presented to Emperor William to-day at the Markendorf parade field, near Frankfort-on-the-Oder, after the parade was finished. Gen. Corbin was presented first. The Emperor welcomed him most cordially. Among his Majesty's first words were hearty thanks for the attentions shown to Prince Henry during the latter's visit to the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES is my morning paper, not only because it gives the news that is "fit to print," but because in ninety-nine cases out of a hundred its editorials are "print to fit."

THE NEW YORK TIMES is asking its readers to decide which of two boys should have a job, the one who untied a bundle and was an hour in doing it, or a boy who cut the string with his knife in a fraction of a second. Here is another for THE TIMES. The New York Commercial advertised for men to put up bulletins in front of the office.

There is a roller engine weighing several tons, which was built to smooth out the asphalt streets, but has found another field of usefulness with its enormous power. It has been stationed for some time near Maiden Lane and Nassau Street, where there has been repair work in the pavement. This has been remarkably slow in its completion because the engine has found another sphere of utility.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- Except for Philadelphia Electric, which was dealt in to a greater extent than all other stocks combined, the Philadelphia market presented few striking movements, though before the brief session closed new records were made for the year. American railroads touched 53, and Philadelphia Electric went to 9 3-16 on sales of 15,000 shares, Messrs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I write for information as to why it is considered desirable or necessary that we acquire possession of the Danish West Indies. It would appear that many of our newspapers are strongly in favor of their acquisition, but the majority of the press and the people seem to be indifferent in the matter, and any good reason for their purchase is not plainly evident.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of L. Napoleon Levy in THE TIMES of last Sunday, in which he protested against assessment of real estate at its actual value will encourage to greater efforts for equitable assessment of real estate those who believe in honesty in raising as well as in expending the city's revenue.

Sir William Mulock, Postmaster General of Canada, who has been attending the Colonial conferences in London, arrived yesterday on the Cunarder Campania. Before leaving for Ottawa he had something to say about Government ownership of franchises, which subject, however, he admitted had not been discussed at the conferences.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Saturday afternoon last, while in possession of health and all his faculties, and returning to his suburban home and family, a man was hit and mortally wounded in a train traversing the eastern edge of the Hackensack Meadows by a bullet from a rifle, and a wife and five children are bereft in consequence.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- The finals for the Westchester Polo Cups were played this afternoon at the Westchester Club grounds before a good-sized gathering of society people, including the Grand Duke Boris. The Point Judith team won by 17 goals to 13 in a very pretty contest, in which the Point Judith team showed its superiority in the first and last periods, in which it easily outclassed Westchester.

Considerable controversy has been waged during the past week as to the question of lawn tennis players defaulting their matches. This was brought about by the talk that the Americans should have given Whitman an opportunity to go through the all-corners' tournament at Newport without wearying him by playing hard matches.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read very carefully the article published in the issue of your valuable paper of Sept. 3 relative to the quarrel between Senors Jimenes and Moscoso, which took place at the Hotel Muro, 116 West Fourteenth Street.

WHEN I came to New York six months ago," said the girl with the pretty shirtwaists, "I looked about me and said, 'All men are cheats.' In making this assertion I was not prejudiced in favor of my own sex. I meant the masculine term to include the whole human race, for, so far as I had been able to judge, the women were just as big cheats as the men.

The final series of baseball games between Pittsburg and New York for this year was begun yesterday on the Polo Grounds, and the pennant winners defeated the local players by the score of 0 to 3. Mathewson did not pitch up to his best form, and the visitors hit him rather freely.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Sept. 6. -- In the scientific world the meeting of the British Association next week at Belfast is being looked forward to, but it is not likely that Prof. James Dewar, President of the association, will startle people as Tyndall did many years ago when the association met at the same place.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The London money market has found itself better supplied with cash than was generally expected, the installment on the new consols being easily met on Thursday without much borrowing from the Bank of England. This abundance was probably due to heavy disbursements by the Government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article on the financial conditions of Australia and New Zealand may bear investigation regarding indebtedness. It is true that Australia and New Zealand have increased their national debt for the most excellent purpose of purchasing the railroads, telegraphs, and other public utilities which a nation should own, and which they find from experience to be a very profitable asset.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 6. -- President Roosevelt and his party to-day passed through the States of West Virginia, Ohio, Kentucky, and Tennessee. The reception during the day in West Virginia and Ohio was enthusiastic, but uneventful, and it was nightfall when Kentucky was reached.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- The Emperor William was present this morning at the launch at Stettin of the North German Lloyd steamer named after himself. His Majesty arrived at the port, with the State Secretary for the Navy, Admiral von Tirpitz, on board the torpedo boat Sleipner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While Mr. Jay Cooke's views upon labor and capital are about all that one might expect from a capitalistic point of reasoning, they are very far from being equitable to all parties concerned. He states that "Rockefeller's money is all here," and that "Morgan won't eat his millions."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- A press dispatch from Rome receives a few days ago announced that the Princess Rospigliosi, an American woman, who formerly resided in this city, had again appealed to the Propaganda for annulment of her marriage contract with Frederick Parkhurst of Bangor, Me.

Bates and Major Marsh of the Seventy-first had sent in improper claims against the State, has followed up his letter by preparing formal charges that are to be sent to Major Gen. Roe.

MANILA, Sept. 7. -- Capt. J.J. Pershing, who is in command of the American forces at Camp Vicars, Island of Mindanao, reports to Gen. Chaffee that several of the Moro chiefs whose followers have attacked American soldiers have rejected all friendly overtures, and that he has been unable to reach any understanding with them.

TRENTON, Sept. 7. -- James Risdon, who ran away from his home in Trenton in 1887 when eighteen years of age, returned yesterday a millionaire and the owner of Klondike interests. When he went away he had no intention of leaving his parents for more than a few weeks, but, finding work scarce in Philadelphia, he drifted to Indianapolis, and then to Louisiana, Texas, and Mexico.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 7. -- Had Herman Neuman, the aleged forger, been as careful to change his cuff buttons as to alter the rest of his personal appearance, he might not now be on his way to New York in the custody of an officer of the law. But, like many other persons who devote all their energies to an effort to evade capture, Neuman forgot one essential thing.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 7. -- The spread of incendiarism in Cuba has begun to alarm foreign fire insurance companies, and it is stated that one British assurance association and another whose head office is in Canada are seriously considering withdrawal from Havana and other cities of this island.

It was by a stroke of luck that the curtain went up on time on Saturday evening at Wallack's where "Mrs. Jack" is on the boards. The delay was due to Edith Bowman and Mary Post. They wear costumes that are difficult to be put on without assistance. The first night they dressed in time by going to the theatre before dinner and helping each other.

The chief event yesterday on the Vailsburg board bicycle track, the five-mile motor-paced race, was productive of a series of broken world's records, new figures being piled up in sensational style. The first new marks were earned by Howard Freeman of Portland, Oregon, who won the second qualifying heat in 6:56, clipping 14 seconds from the former record held by Joe Nelson.

BOSTON, Sept. 7. -- One of the Government powder magazines at old Fort Winthrop, on Governor's Island, upper Boston Harbor, blew up this evening with a detonation that was felt all over the city and which was heard at points twenty miles away. The explosion is supposed to have been caused by boys setting fires on the island.

The automobile of a Chicago man abroad undertook to climb a church spire, and after the amputation he bought a wooden leg at Berlin.

RICEVILLE, Iowa, Sept. 7. -- The body which was buried here yesterday and which was believed to be that of William Bartholin, was exhumed this afternoon and positively identified as that of the Chicago double murderer.

BOSTON, Sept. 7. -- One of the Government powder magazines at old Fort Winthrop, on Governor's Island, upper Boston Harbor, blew up this evening with a detonation that was felt all over the city and which was heard at points twenty miles away. The explosion is supposed to have been caused by boys setting fires on the island.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- Sentiments of a radical nature, censure of President Baer, Gov. Stone of Pennsylvania, President Roosevelt, and of mine owners generally, and blame for the conditions now existing in Pennsylvania were expressed by speakers at a mass meeting at the First Methodist Church to-night, and the expressions were applauded by the audience.

The strike of the anthracite coal miners was made a special order of business at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union. James P. Archibald, the Recording Secretary, brought the matter up by calling attention to the open-air mass meeting called by the central body, which will be held on Madison Square next Saturday, at which President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers is expected to speak.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 7. -- There was an air of mystery about the little steamship Maid of Patuca, which sailed from Baltimore last evening for South America, which savored of the filibustering expeditions of the days of the Cuban revolution.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 7. -- President Roosevelt was the guest to-day of the citizens of Chattanooga, and right royally they entertained him. He came to Chattanooga primarily to attend the National Convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, and to-morrow he will be the guest of the railroad men, but to-day Chattanooga entertained him.

MOUNT VERNON, Sept. 7. -- Mrs. William P. Conners of Syracuse was in Mount Vernon to-night at the home of a friend. She declares her husband is dying on Blackwell's Island, New York City, as the result of a beating inflicted either by the police or the attendants on the island. Mrs. Conners declares she will spend all the money she has in bank in order to punish whoever injured her husband.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7. -- An amateur circus is to be given for church purposes by the Summer Amusement Club under the direction of William J. Hoggson of New York in the fields opposite the Havemeyer schoolhouse the coming week. Flaming lithographs are posted, which give the features of the circus.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7. -- An amateur circus is to be given for church purposes by the Summer Amusement Club under the direction of William J. Hoggson of New York in the fields opposite the Havemeyer schoolhouse the coming week. Flaming lithographs are posted, which give the features of the circus.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- The Rev. Joseph Wilson Cochran, pastor of the Northminster Presbyterian Church, preached this evening upon arbitration as the proper method of settling disputes between employers and employed, with particular reference to the coal strike. He said:

When the city is suffering from a protracted heated term charitably disposed persons in town and country contribute generously to the various charities engaged in transporting sick and enfeebled children from the crowded tenements for a week or two's outing in the country or at the seaside.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- Chief of Police O'Neill says there is no doubt as to the identification of the body found in a field in Iowa as That of William Bartholin. Coey, the dentist that filled Bartholin's teeth, was taken to Iowa last night, with Detective Rohan, and has fully identified his work on the teeth.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 7. -- Had Herman Neuman, the aleged forger, been as careful to change his cuff buttons as to alter the rest of his personal appearance, he might not now be on his way to New York in the custody of an officer of the law. But, like many other persons who devote all their energies to an effort to evade capture, Neuman forgot one essential thing.

When the city is suffering from a protracted heated term charitably disposed persons in town and country contribute generously to the various charities engaged in transporting sick and enfeebled children from the crowded tenements for a week or two's outing in the country or at the seaside.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- A mystery surrounding a supposed murder, believed to have been committed near here thirty-three years ago, has been cleared up by the discovery of the supposed victim in Minneapolis, Minn.

MOUNT VERNON, Sept. 7. -- Mrs. William P. Conners of Syracuse was in Mount Vernon to-night at the home of a friend. She declares her husband is dying on Blackwell's Island, New York City, as the result of a beating inflicted either by the police or the attendants on the island. Mrs. Conners declares she will spend all the money she has in bank in order to punish whoever injured her husband.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 7. -- President Roosevelt was the guest to-day of the citizens of Chattanooga, and right royally they entertained him. He came to Chattanooga primarily to attend the National Convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, and to-morrow he will be the guest of the railroad men, but to-day Chattanooga entertained him.

-- Jealous, apparently, of the amount of attention, attracted by the racing automobilists, The Marine Journal vehemently protests that exhibitions of "speed madness" are by no means confined to the land, and it pleads for a, fair division of the animosity now monopolized by the terrors of highways not aqueous.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- Sentiments of a radical nature, censure of President Baer, Gov. Stone of Pennsylvania, President Roosevelt, and of mine owners generally, and blame for the conditions now existing in Pennsylvania were expressed by speakers at a mass meeting at the First Methodist Church to-night, and the expressions were applauded by the audience.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 7. -- The spread of incendiarism in Cuba has begun to alarm foreign fire insurance companies, and it is stated that one British assurance association and another whose head office is in Canada are seriously considering withdrawal from Havana and other cities of this island.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 8 -- William N. Beach, a New York clubman spending the Summer here, attempted to make a record between Stamford and the metropolis this morning in the forty horse power racing automobile recently sold by E.R. Thomas of New York to a Mr. Thaw, a Pittsburg millionaire.

Yesterday's "double-header" between the New York and Pittsburg baseball teams on the Polo Grounds was a treat to the local supporters of the game, as both contests were won by McGraw's men. They outplayed the champions at every stage, their fielding, batting, and base running being excellent.

Three new public school buildings, providing sittings for about 6,300 pupils, were opened on Manhattan Island yesterday. It was the first day of the school year, and throngs of children with their mothers and fathers went to the school buildings of the city, and at a considerable number of them hundreds of children were turned away.

An eighteen-year-old boy who was employed as elevator operator in the Douglass Building, at 13 West Seventeenth Street, carried three unconscious girls from the building and released some thirty others from their imprisonment on the sixth floor, above a fire which raged on the fifth, about 6 o'clock last evening.
J.J. WILKINSON, for many years prominent in Virginia politics, and an ex-member of the Legislature from Pittsylvania County, died suddenly Sunday night of heart disease, at Newport News, Va.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I felt very much grieved over your editorial to-day on Tom L. Johnson, but consoled myself with the thought that it must have been written in a moment of thoughtlessness rather than in dead earnest.

Although transactions in the outside market yesterday showed some diminution from the large totals recorded last week, there was still considerable animation in the market and a number of issues were traded in to a considerable extent. Following the course of the Stock Exchange market, outside stocks generally were strong, and in several instances the net gains recorded amounted to several points.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Elizabeth Kennedy made her debut here to-night as Mme. Trentoni in Clyde Fitch's well-known play "Captain Jinks of the Horse Marines." The house was crowded with the Summer contingent, and people from many different sections of the country received the performance favorably.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- Can and Biscuit were the leaders on the Chicago Stock Exchange to-day. Biscuit opened at 48 and sold at 48 3/. A line of 1,000 shares was liquidated here and on the New York Exchange, after which the stock became rather firmer. The advance was from 48 to 48 1/2, and the reaction broke prices to 48 1/4; preferred, 104 3/4.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- In connection with the United Irish League meeting held at Birr last month, says a telegram from Dublin to The Times, summonses are being issued under the Crimes act against Michael Reddy, M.P., E. Haviland Burke, M.P., John O'Donnell, M.P., Mr. Lowry, (Chairman of the Birr Board of Guardians,) and two local members of the league.

WILLKESBARRE, Sept. 8 -- All reports emanating from various sections of the country, alleged to be from prominent political personages, that this week marks the crisis in the anthracite coal strike find no confirmation. The testimony of both sides is that the situation is unchanged.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 -- Judge Colt of the United States Circuit Court to-day entered a decree in the case of the United Gas and Coke Company against Henry F. Whitney and others, Trustees, and the Central Trust Company of New York against the same, ordering the sale of the property of the New England Gas and Coke Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The abuse of power is ever the outcome where wholesome restrictions are impossible or untried, and conscious and unchecked greed dominates. The trust is the natural outcome of our social evolution, as is trades unionism. The trust abuses its power.

To the Etiitor of The New York Times: Honni soit qui mal y pense. This motto, emblazoned on the coat of arms of England, suggested itself in reading your editorial on Tom Johnson of Cleveland. Happily he is big and able enough to survive your harsh, adverse criticism of his character and motives.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Bradford B. McGregor, who underwent an operation on Saturday for the removal of a stone in the kidneys, died of acute Bright's disease soon after 11 o'clock on Sunday evening. The physicians knew early that the termination of the case would be death, and they informed the family and friends, including Mrs. McGregor.

GILMORE, Iowa, Sept. 8 -- The Willis lumber yard, Counselman's grain elevator, Rollins's general store, the Post Office, and a barber's shop were wiped out by lire here to-day, entailing a loss of $75,000.
First Lieut. Frederick Herman, Ninth Cavalry, will report at Fort Robinson. Neb., for duty at that post, pending the arrival of his regiment in the United States.

Charles E. Schuyler Co. and David. H. Scully have sold the six-story elevator apartment house known as the Ruth, at 449 to 453 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, 75 by 87 by 100. The price is reported to have been about $155,000.

SARATOGA, Sept. 8 -- The Saratoga County Democratic Convention which met at Ballston Spa this afternoon adopted resolutions extending encouragement to the striking motormen who for more than a week have tied up the Hudson Valley Railway, a hundred-mile trolley system extending from Troy to Lake George.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 8 -- The Illinois Stats Board of Equalization will meet in annual session in this city Sept. 16 at 10 o'clock, the time provided by law, when the statement of assessments from the various counties over the State shall be in the hands of the Auditor.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 8 -- Philadelphia and Cincinnati broke even on a double header to-day. In the first game the home team won on opportune hitting. In the second contest the visitors hit Iberg freely, while Thielman kept the hits scattered. Both games were poorly played. In the fifth inning of the second game Hulswitt and Maloney indulged in a lively fist fight, and both were put out of the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- A resolution recommending immediate arbitration for the settlement of the miners' strike, and calling upon the State authorities to use whatever power the law or their position may give them to end the strike, was unanimously adopted to-day by the Methodist Episcopal preachers' meeting here.

For at least nearly 1,000 dwellers in New York City yesterday was by far the brightest day of the whole year. It was the day set apart for the distribution of money among the blind of the city who are determined to bear their affliction without resorting to the municipal institutions for a home.

Tammany leaders who are fighting for supremacy in the primaries to be held on Tuesday next started in yesterday to wage political warfare of the bitterest kind. In every district in which there is an apparently close contest the factionists are charging frauds in enrollment and transfers and threatening wholesale arrests of leaders and "floaters."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 -- The strength of Alabama Coal and Iron stocks and the coincident strength of International Trust were the primary features of the local market to-day. The Coal and Iron issues were the most conspicuous. Their aggressive movement was ascribed to the twofold influence of known excellent results in the way of profits, and to the possibility of some deal in which other neighboring companies of a like nature may be involved.

William S. Devery thoroughly enjoyed and eulogized himself last night from a wagon used as a stand at the northeast corner of Twenty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue. At the next corner there was a meeting in the interest of John C. Sheehan.

NEWPORT, Sept. 8 -- This afternoon Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave a reception on the steam yacht Nourmahal in honor of Grand Duke Boris, which was in the nature of a farewell to the distinguished visitor, as he left after the return of the yacht for New York.

-- That death is rather less than more a respecter of persons when the persons happen to be "Christian Scientists" is a fact as well known -- to those who have given the matter any attention -- as it is easily explicable by the added perils to life involved in the practices, some stupid, some criminal, and all absurd, taught by the EDDY woman.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- City Judge Kellogg this evening refused to issue a warrant in connection with the poolroom case presented by the District Attorney and Sheriff on information supplied by Surrogate Silkman.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 8 -- President Roosevelt to-day was elected an honorary member of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen. He attended the executive session of the order in the morning, walking from the hotel to the auditorium, a distance of a few blocks, escorted by Grand Master Sargent, a committee of the brotherhood, and a detachment of Troop B, State Guard.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 8 -- A fight to-day between striking miners at Maltby resulted in the death of one man and the fatal injury of another. Both victims were Italians.

Aqueduct Commissioner Maurice J. Power died at his home, 317 East Nineteenth Street, last night of diabetes, from which he had been a sufferer for some time. He was seized with an acute attack about a week ago and pneumonia supervened.

R.C. Beers, a stock broker of Hartford, Conn., appeared in the Tombs Police Court yesterday as complainant against Jerome B. Melville, whom he charged with having defrauded him out of $1,314.36 by means of a stock brokerage transaction.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 8 -- President Roosevelt braved the elements late this afternoon and in defiance of a hard rainstorm was driven through streets lined with people to a stand on Main Avenue, nearly a mile from, the station, where he spoke to 12,000 persons who stood in quiet while a drenching rain poured down upon them.
ATHENS, Tenn., Sept. 8 -- President Roosevelt arrived here at 3:15 P.M., and after a brief stop the train continued on to Knoxville. He was greeted here by a large crowd.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- While the sinking of the Haitian rebel gunboat Crete-a-Pierrot by a German warship is not likely to involve the United States in any way, the State Department officials feel a certain amount of curiosity to learn the details of the offense for which the Haitians were punished.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- The buoyancy in Wall Street became contagious and spread to-day to the Philadelphia market, which took on decided strength in the final half hour, and the local specialties shared in the rise. Philadelphia Rapid Transit went to 15 5/8, the highest ever recorded, but the greatest strength was in Pennsylvania, Reading, Lehigh Valley, United Gas Improvement, and Electric Storage Battery.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Not only have the reputed millions of the Conde family shrunk to nothing, but out of the wreckage of the Swits Conde estate comes a charge of embezzlement.
