In these tables, for an abstract of which we are indebted to the Washington dispatches of The Tribune, the figures are given for children between the ages of ten and fourteen.

Final preparations were made last evening by the politicians making the primary fights for the voting to-day. John F. Carroll held a meeting of the election district Captains of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District, and the ex-deputy leader of Tammany Hall took the count himself. When all the reports were in Mr. Carroll made the announcement that a conservative estimate showed that he would receive at least 1,600 votes in the district primaries.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 15. -- The Supreme Court to-morrow will hear reports of the referees in the suit to compel payment by the Union Pacific Railroad Company of $635,000 penalties imposed for alleged violations of the Nebraska maximum freight rate law. The referees will recommend that the suit be dismissed, and if the court follows precedent it will accept the reports and end the litigation.
New York, Sept. 12, 1902. To the Honorable Seih Low, Mayor of the City of New York.

Tammany district leaders agreed last evening that the test of strength between the followers of John F. Carroll and Charles F. Murphy would come at a meeting of the Executive Committee to be held within a few days after the primaries.

Perfect racing weather and an entry list which included many of the best-known harness horses in the country, attracted a crowd of several thousand persons to the opening day events of the Grand Circuit meeting of the Empire City Trotting Club at the Empire City Park, Yonkers, yesterday afternoon.

The campaign for the Democratic leadership in the Ninth Assembly District closed last night with a general distribution of " dough bags " by the Devery and Sheehan people and the assertion by Devery that Frank J. Goodwin had made arrangements at a conference at the Hoffman House during the afternoon to turn his strength to John C. Sheehan.

President Roosevelt has summoned to Oyster Bay to confer with him to-day Senators Hanna of Ohio, Spooner of Wisconsin, Lodge of Massachusetts, Aldrich of Rhode Island, Allison of Iowa, and O. H. Platt of Connecticut.

OMAHA, Sept. 15 -- Judge MePherson, in the Federal Court, to-day, on application or the Union Pacific Railroad Company, granted a temporary injunction restraining the striking shopmen of that road from placing " pickets" about the gates and grounds of the Union Pacific shops. The hearing is set for Sept. 23.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 15. -- In an interview over the long distance telephone to-day John Mitchell at Wilkesbarre said:

The rope that suspended Marie Licastri as, one of the angels in the Italian celebration for Saint Fortunata far above a watching crowd in Elizabeth Street last night, slipped from the grasp of the man who held it on a seven-story building, and the child fell toward the street below. The guide rope, being tangled, remained taut, and the girl's body swung over the street and struck the building at the second story.

OYSTER BAY, Sept. 16. -- There came here to-day one of the most remarkable expeditions to see a President that have occurred in the history of the country, with the exception of such as have been made to a Chief Executive in war time. Five Senators and the Postmaster General called on Mr. Roosevelt.

PANAMA, Colombia, Sept. 16. -- Commanders Potter and McLean of the United States cruisers Ranger and Cincinnati, respectively, and the Acting United States Consul here, Mr. Ehrmann, had a conference yesterday with Gen. Salazar, commander of the Government forces on the isthmus, which lasted over an hour, and in the course of which many important points were discussed.

The report that the Clark estate has sold its vacant block front on Central Park West, between Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Streets, was revived yesterday. No buyer's name was mentioned in connection with the report, nor could confirmation or denial of it be obtained at the offices of the Clark estate.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- The money situation is still naturally very firm, with call rates mostly at G per cent., and in some cases as high as 7 per cent., quoted. Time money is in light demand, and the banks are also disinclined to let money out under the present conditions, even at going ratew. Sterling exchange remains weak, but with only a limited business doing.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 -- The Alabama Steel and Wire Corporation has filed a certificate of incorporation with the Secretary of State. Its authorized capital stock is $5,000,000, in $100 shares. Of the shares 25,000 are to be preferred stock and 25,000 common. E.T. Schuler and G.H. Schuler of Birmingham. Ala., and Samuel I Knight of New York are the incorporators.

BIZERTA, Tunis, Sept. 16 -- M. Pelletan, the French Minister of Marine, made a remarkable speech at an entertainment of the municipality yesterday evening, which, it is expected, will cause the French Foreign Minister, M.Delcasse. some trouble to explain. After pointing out the importance of Bizerta as a bulwark of France, M. Pelletan proceeded:

When Nicholas Fish, banker and society man, was found dying in West Thirty-fourth Street night before last, he had been in a saloon with two women and a man. According to the police, the man was Thomas J. Sharkey, private detective, who was arrested early yesterday morning and locked up on the charge of having struck the blow that caused the death of the banker.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- The market in Philadelphia took on a brighter appearance, but the condition of the money market forced trading down to a low ebb, yet funds were more freely offered than on the preceding day and all at 6 per cent. The only activity was in Philadelphia Electric.

In an editorial contribution to The Engineering and Mining Journal Dr. R. W. RAYMOND attempts a defense of the practices which are the chief grievances of the present strike, and that he is not quite successful is due less to his cleverness in argument than to the fact that the practices which he discusses apologetically are indefensible.

Proceedings in involuntary bankruptcy were commenced yesterday against the firm of Meyer Jonasson Co., wholesale and retail suit and cloak merchants, at 817 Broadway. The firm has stores in Boston and Pittsburg, as well as, in New York, and was considered the most important cloak house in the United States.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Gov. Odell addressed a crowd of thousands of people of Otsego and adjoining counties at the Central New York fair here this afternoon. He was accorded an enthusiastic reception. The race track and grounds all about the roof garden from which he spoke were packed with people, and he received close attention from them.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, Sept, 16. -- David B. Henderson, Speaker of the House of Representatives, has declined to accept the nomination for Congress from the Third Iowa District.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 16. -- An important meeting of the traffic managers of the various Western roads was held here to-day to consider ways and means for ending the bitter rate war on various articles of freight to Colorado points.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 16 -- The prospects of a harmonious convention to-morrow of the Democrats of Massachusetts were particularly bright at the preliminary gathering of the party leaders to-night.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 16. -- A new five-mile record for steam automobiles was made to-day in the race meeting, of the Cleveland Automobile Club. It was made by Rollin White of Cleveland in 6:43. In another steam automobile class, five miles, Paul Deming of Cleveland won by five-eighths of a mile in 9:53 1/2.

The attendance at the Gravesend track yesterday, with about as commonplace a programme as well could toe devised on offer, quite equaled the gathering on the opening day of the meeting. For want of a stake fixture, the mile and a furlong handicap had the most prominent place, and made a fair contest, with a very satisfactory result, as this was one of the two races of the afternoon that went to post favorites.

Yesterday's stock market was listless and without feature. Trading dwindled to proportions comparatively insignificant in the light of recent activity, total transactions barely exceeding 400,000 shares. Such dealings as there were were for the most part professional and altogether without significance, though on the floor it was said that the buying was of a better character than the selling.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- Coal dealers to-day advanced the price of all sizes of anthracite $2 a ton, or to $12. The coal companies have practically no anthracite on hand, and are out of business for the anthracite trade. Practically no consignments of hard coal have been received in Boston since May 1.

Two incidents at the first meeting of the thirtieth annual convention of the International Association of Fire Engineers at the Grand Central Palace yesterday indiceated more plainly than anything that has been written or said the attitude of the firemen toward the dependency of their positions on politics.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 16. -- The Western Passenger Association held a meeting here to-day for the express purpose of giving further consideration to the request of the Minneapolis and St. Paul merchants that the railroads run six cheap merchants' excursions from points within a radius of 200 miles.

George G. Tyson, Vice President of the firm of Tyson Co., who operate cigar and news stands in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, the Gilsey House, the Murray Hill Hotel, and other leading hostelries, was arrested yesterday on a warrant sworn out by Internal Revenue officials, charging the firm with several violations of the revenue stamp law.

When a man and a woman are engaged, it is well known, diplomatic relations are a trifle strained. At the Garden Theatre last night they were so strained that Aunt Jeannie was not able to tell her young man about a very serious and interesting affair she had on hand, which laid her open to utter misconstruction and caused the young man much needless unhappiness.

NEWPORT, Sept. 16. -- M. and Mme. L. Breitner, who have been playing for a number of the Summer residents during the past three weeks, gave a farewell recital this morning at the residence of Mrs. E.J. Berwind. The patronesses included:

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 16 -- The Republican State Convention assembled tonight. An important feature of the session was a resolution offered by State Senator Kennedy, indorsing President Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination in 1904. The resolution was referred to the Committee on Resolutions.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- A dispatch to a news agency from Peking says:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Matters on the Isthmus of Panama are rapidly assuming a serious complexion. The Cincinnati arrived at Colon yesterday, and Commander Thomas C. McLean immediately went ashore to investigate conditions. He found that traffic on the isthmus was being interfered with by Government troops, not by revolutionists, and that they had the hardihood to stop his train both on the way to Panama and on the way back.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Short loans were obtainable at easy rates and money was plentiful in the market to-day. Discounts were firmer in anticipation of a 4 per cent, bank rate within a month, combined with the situation in New York and the uncertainty regarding large shipments of gold from London, though it was considered probable that the Continent will be able to supply most of the American requirements.
Changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Medical Department:

The arrival and departure of European ships to-day will bring a marked change in the New York social conditions. The Duchess of Marlborough, it is announced, will depart for Europe. That will take several friends to the pier to bid her bon voyage. The White Star ship will come in with many Americans who have been abroad all Summer.

Police Captain Timothy J. Creeden, who was stricken with something much like apoplexy at his desk in the East Eighty-eighth Street Station Sunday, was reported better at his home in Woodlawn yesterday.
DOVER, Del., Sept. 16 -- The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated the following ticket:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Agricultural Department to-day issued the following weekly crop summary:

"Advance Australia" is the proud motto of the antarctic Commonwealth. Just now "Retrograde Australia" would appear to be a more fitting description. We were pointing out a day or two ago some of the mischievous results of the Australian immigration laws. And last Sunday we printed the interesting letter of a Melbourne correspondent about the troubles in Australia.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 16. -- In the course of his address to the delegates at the convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of Connecticut to-day, the Rev. Walter J. Shannon, President of the National Union and retiring President of the State Union, had the following to say:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Thirty members of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators, and Paper Hangers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, were called out on strike at the White House today by Daniel Lear, the Washington business agent of the brotherhood.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Speaker Henderson's declination of the nomination for Congress was such a total surprise to Washington that most of those who heard the news refused to credit it at first.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 16. -- Representative Cornellus A. Pugsley, who is a member of the Banking and Currency Committee of the present Congress and who has given a great deal of study to the subject of banking and currency in this country, was seen at the Westchester County National Bank this morning and asked for his views concerning the present financial condition in Wall Street and the present high rate of money.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The Times, criticising Nance O'Neil's revival, at the Adelphi Theatre, of Giacometti's "Elizabeth, Queen of England,'' says a mistake has been made in cutting out the lovemaking. Hence there is no unity in the play and no reason for the tragic display of remorse in the last two acts, for we have seen nothing to convince us that Elizabeth was in love with Essex.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that we are taking our place with the foremost nations of the world, is it not nearly time that we toned the exultant shouts of our successful diplomacy. Mr. Sharrett has done splendid work in China. Why lessen the dignity of his achievement by injudicious talking on his return? He is reported by several newspapers as boasting of how he "called England's bluff."
No Greater New York Democracy leaders were elected.

The Democrats have one year more in which to make the issue of tariff reform their own. Before the Presidential campaign of 1901 opens, the Republican Party, obedient to the popular demand, will pledge itself to undertake a revision of the tariff. The Democrats will then have missed their opportunity.

New York was again beaten by the Brooklyn baseball team at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The score was the same as the day before -- 7 to 2. "Bill" Donovan pitched an excellent game, only two hits being made off him. One of these was in the first inning and the other in the ninth, and each was productive of a run.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 16. -- Officials of the Western Maryland and West Virginia Central Railroads treat lightly the report of a community of interests arrangement between the Goulds and the Pennsylvania.

Every member of the Pennsylvania Railroad Tunnel Conference Committee except President Cantor voted affirmatively yesterday afternoon for Controller Grout's resolution that a favorable report on the revised franchise should be submitted to the respective boards represented by the conferees.
J.P. Morgan was at the pier yesterday morning when the White Star liner Oceanic cocked after her record-breaking trip. When he was asked the purpose of his visit to the pier he replied:

Another witness of the quarrel resulting in the death of Nicholas Fish was located yesterday when two Central Office detectives apprehended Mrs. Margaret Pickles, a sister of Mrs. Nellie Casey, who was with Mrs. Libbie Phillips when they were drinking with Mr. Fish in Ehrhardt's saloon on West Thirty-fourth Street.

"Take heed to yourself, the Devil is unchained." So ran the message of warning sent to King JOHN when the news came that RICHARD of the Lion Heart was out of prison. The wiser leaders of the Republican Party have for some years occasionally turned an uneasy ear to the West, expecting and fearing a message of similar import.

The interborough semi-professional baseball series will be resumed at Equitable Park, sixty-seventh Street and Eleventh Avenue, on Sunday. "Kid" Carsey's Metropolitan team will play the "Brooklyn Field Club team, and Judging by the games recently won by the Brooklyn players the contest should prove to be one of the closest or the season.

Several changes are to be made in the methods of the Health Board Inspectors in examining the children of the public schools. As far as possible, pupils are to be examined in rooms other than regular class rooms. The inspectors have already been instructed not to use their bare hands in examining children's eyes.

WASHINGTON, Sept 17. -- The Democratic Congressional Committee is having trouble in getting speakers for the Fall campaign. Every effort has been made from the headquarters in Washington to secure men to take the stump, but more excuses than promises have come in.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Sept. 17. -- Speaker Henderson is as positive to-day in his declination of the Congressional nomination as he was last night, notwithstanding the flood of telegrams from all parts of the country protesting against his decision and imploring him to reconsider the same. President Roosevelt sent a telegram, but the Speaker replied that his decision was final.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 17. -- As in the other States where Republican conventions were held, Connecticut Republicans to-day formally indorsed the Administration of President Roosevelt and favored his renomination for the Presidency in 1904.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The beet-sugar business in Europe is laboring under a heavy handicap this year. Consul General Prank H. Mason at Berlin, reporting on this to the State Department under date of Aug. 21, says that the wet spell has assumed the character of "an impending calamity to the cereal harvests of the year."

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Sentiment in favor of tariff revision is spreading like wildfire among Republicans of the Northwest, it is declared. Speaker Henderson's retirement is taken as a tacit, though none the less strong, testimonial to the strength of the general demand for a loosening of the tariff bonds.
Major Ira MacNutt, Ordnance Department, will proceed on official business to Port Monroe.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Sept. 17. -- Mines on New River are increasing their output dally, and are working about half the regular force. Miners are being forced out of the company houses every day, and as the weather gets colder they must either move away or go back to work.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacoa, Sept. 17. -- President Castro of Venezuela has retreated from Ocumare before the advance of the revolutionists.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 17. -- A special from Skagway, Alaska, says that about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon an unidentified man walked into the Canadian Bank of Commerce, a revolver in one hand and a dynamite bomb in the other, and demanded $20,000, threatening, if refused, to blow all in the bank into eternity.
"This, I suppose," paid one of our prominent citizens, with reference to the election of Mr. DEVERY as Tammany leader in the Ninth District, "is what you call 'representative government.'"
L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for James O'Brien the four-story American basement dwelling 257 West Seventieth Street, 16.8 by 100.5.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The residence of John D. Rockefeller, at Pocantico Hills, was destroyed by fire this evening. It is supposed the fire started from an electric wire or from a chimney.

When W.R. Morley returns to New York on Saturday to coach the Columbia eleven be expects to have the services of six experienced football players now in college as candidates for the present vacancies in the make-up of the team.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 17. -- The Republicans of Alabama to-day nominated the following ticket:
BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- Congressman Charles E. Littlefield of Maine, when asked what effect the withdrawal of Speaker Henderson might have on the National situation, said:

Mr. CHARLES A. SCHTEREN is, we think, mistaken in saying that the trip to Europe from which he has just returned was without "political significance." On the contrary, according to his own explanation of its purpose, it had a significance of the greatest interest, which a good many stanch Republicans like himself and engaged in similar business will not fail to perceive.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- Money continues practically unchanged, at least so far as quoted rates are concerned, although there is a noticeable better feeling in evidence and a little mere willingness to make loans. Sterling exchange is quiet and steady. Clearing House rates, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25c discount; call loans, 6@7 per cent.; time money, 5@6 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $23,384,382; balances, $1,737,226.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The will of Bradford B. McGregor, the Standard Oil stockholder who died at Mamaroneck on Sept. 7 after an operation, and who married Miss Clara Schlemmer of New York a few hours before he submitted to the surgeon's knife, was filed in the Surrogate's office to-day.

The attention that educators are giving to manual training in the public schools is a sign of the new century and proves that men are becoming more and more sensitive to the weak point in the modern system of machine-made articles, whereof the good side is cheapness. Along with the development of machines goes the progressive sterilization of individual activity; the artisan becomes a workman and the workman an ignorant tender of a machine.

Lacking one essential -- the actual flames -- there was a great fire display at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, yesterday morning. The centre of excitement was in the Grand Central Palace, where the International Association of Fire Engineers is holding its convention.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- Money was easy today. The new issue of u2,000,000 of Treasury bills next weak will reduce the floating supplies. This will increase the amount of outstanding bills to u23,133,000, and it will probably be considerably further increased before the year ends. Discounts were firm.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 17. -- The local market lacked activity and feature. It has lapsed into that waiting attitude which frequently characterizes when New York is perturbed. The buying demand was at a minimum which caused holders to keep back their offerings until the outlook is more auspicious.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Eight Republican Assembly District Conventions were held in Erie County to-day for the purpose of electing delegates to the State Convention, which is to meet at Saratoga on Sept. 23.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- The market was somewhat restive to-day, but the general tendency was upward. The only decided change was that of a two-point advance in American Railways to 54, marking a new high record. The movement followed a 3 per cent, rise to 109 1/2 in the company's bonds.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 17. -- William Hughes, a lawyer of this city, was nominated this afternoon by the Democrats of this Congressional district, consisting of Passaic, Sussex, and Bergen Counties, to run for Representative in opposition to Col. Barbour, nominated a short time ago by the Republicans.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 17. -- The coal operators report that they are now working twenty-eight collieries, and twenty-nine washeries, which they declare are producing about 28,000 tons of coal a day. These figures the strikers say are absurd, and that they will, within a short time, publish a statement showing just how much coal is being produced, and the number of men at work.

Business in the outside market yesterday was much brisker than on the earlier days of the week, and in nearly every stock where there was any substantial variation in price from Tuesday's figures the change was on the side of gains. Transactions also were on a larger scale, and the market appeared to have recovered very largely from the more or less unfavorable conditions which had prevailed for two or three days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- A.W. Machen Chief of the Rural Free Delivery Bureau of the United States Post Office Department, returned here to-day from a round of inspection in the West, chiefly in Wisconsin, Minnesota, and Michigan.
Kansas, Oklahoma Central and Southwestern Railroad chartered in Oklahoma with a capital of $11,500,000.

The general advance in rates of fire insurance premiums, averaging 25 per cent., promises to result in important benefit. Experience has shown that cheap insurance, instead of being a benefit to the community, becomes a positive detriment to every interest affected by offering inducements to neglect all precautions for safety against fire.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 17. -- Acrimony was not wanting for a time in the Democratic State Convention in Tremont Temple today, but in the end harmony was restored and the State ticket finally named was enthusiastically greeted. The ticket follows:

E.E. Smathers's famous trotter Lord Derby (2:05 3/4,) defeated his old rival, The Monk, owned by C.K.G. Billings, in a special race for a gold cup valued at $3,000, and the amateur wagon championship of the world, at the Grand Circuit meeting of the Empire City Trotting Club, at the Empire City track, Yonkers, yesterday afternoon, winning two of three heats.
LONDON, Sept. 18. -- "The gold situation has not materially altered during the week past," said a partner in one of the largest banks here yesterday, adding:

ESSEX, Conn., Sept. 17. -- David Hayden, an insane veteran of the civil war, shot and probably fatally wounded two of the most prominent citizens of Essex this afternoon, and when the authorities were about to capture him blew the top of his head off with a shotgun.
There was a conference at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night between Senator Platt, Gov. Odell, State Chairman Dunn, and Lemuel E. Quigg, to discuss the coming State Convention at Saratoga.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 17. -- The Armour Packing Company, acting for other packing companies in Chicago and other cities, in what is known as the Beef Trust, has secretly agreed to an advance of 25 per cent. to the sausage makers. This agreement was made by a committee representing the employes and a Superintendent of the Armour plant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- With the double purpose of protecting the long-suffering Jews of the Balkan States and of averting the danger of an immigration into the United States of a horde of poor people, Secretary of State Hay has adopted the unusual course of appealing to the powers of Europe to force one of their protege to observe the obligations of humanity in the case of the Jews.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- Some perplexity follows the apparent change on the part of Secretary Shaw in regard to his disposition to accept "other" securities from National banks with whom Government moneys are deposited.

-- We have our doubts about that story we published yesterday of a dog who saw a railway bridge on fire, and, understanding the seriousness of the situation, barked so persistently that at last his reluctant master got up out of bed, followed the imploring dog through the chilly night till he could see what was burning, and then gave a warning that saved an on-rushing train from destruction.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- Chief Watts of the Bureau of Criminal Investigation says that his men are making no efforts to locate Mrs. Margaret Pickles, the missing witness in the Fish murder case, who is said to have come to Boston. The New York police. Chief Watts says, have not asked that a search be made here.

Here is one of the most attractive of children's coats. It is of a heavy white silk, with the effect of two side plaits on either side of the front, but these given a businesslike effect by being stitched down by two straps of silk running to Just below the waist line and finishing with a point. Below the waist line the plaits are let out and give the coat its fullness.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 17. -- Attorney General Mullan has filed with Gov. Cummins an opinion in relation to the Rock Island reorganization in which he holds that under the Iowa statutes this corporation is not opposed to the public policy in a sense which would enable the State to arrest the transaction or maintain an action of "quo warranto" for the dissolution of the corporate franchise.

FONDA, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- The Montgomery County Agricultural Society had as its guest to-day Gov. Odell. Thousands of people of this and adjoining counties gathered at the Fair Grounds, where the State's Executive delivered an address. Congressman John K. Stewart of Amsterdam introduced Gov. Odell, who said, in part:
The heads of the Greater New York Democracy talked hopefully of its future yesterday, scouting the idea that its failure to achieve any success on Tuesday was a serious if not a fatal blow.

The usual religious service preliminary to the opening of the academic year at the General Theological Seminary was held last evening in the seminary chapel. Bishop Potter made an address in which he paid loving tribute to the late Dean Hoffman. Prof. Ritchie conducted the service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The personal element in the sensation caused by Speaker Henderson's withdrawal continued to-day to be uppermost in all discussion, of the subject, but another phase of the matter is rapidly forcing its way to the front. This is the question raised by the Speaker's uncovering of the dissension which exists in the Republican Party over the tariff issue.

Hungary celebrates this week the one hundredth anniversary of KOSSUTH'S birthday, Sept. 19, 1802. From every church, within the realm there rises the Te Deum Laudamus to heaven for having blessed the Magyar people with such a devoted and illustrious son. All political differences and racial antipathies that may exist are forgotten, and all classes unite to celebrate the anniversary of his birth.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18. -- The local market was dull and featureless except for the rise of 3 points in Consolidation Coal and the break of 5 3/4 points in Baltimore Brick. The former was said to be due to the excellent prospect of larger earnings by reason of better prices for soft coal, while the latter was attributed to reaction from recent manipulation.

About a dozen residents of the Borough of the Bronx spoke before the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday afternoon in advocacy of the east side and Jerome Avenue extension of the tunnel. The Rapid Transit Commission is already on record as being in favor of the Jerome Avenue extension providing there is a Bronx Borough extension.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 18. -- Rain here to-day interfered with the attendance at the county fair and also caused the postponement of the baseball game between the Riverhead and Central Islip nines. Summary of races:

"What a queer back there is to that hat," a woman remarked, looking at a smart chapeau of gray squirrel fur in one of the shops, "but I suppose some sweet young girl would look very pretty and sweet in it." It was not a hat which must belong necessarily to the "sweet young thing," for the world has not learned to recognize the automobile hat, which it was.

For the week-end there are horse shows at Millbrook and Bernardsville and golf at the other out-of-town resorts. Many wellknown persons were in town yesterday, a number of whom attended the funerals of Samuel D. Babcock and Nicholas Fish. Society, however, is in the country, and "Westchester County and Long Island are very gay now.

PANAMA, Sept. 18. -- The report which has been current lately that Colombia intends to declare war upon Nicaragua because of the help President Zelaya is alleged to have given to the Colombian revolutionists, is contradicted by Colombian officials stationed in Panama.

A theatre to be known as the Harlem Auditorium is to be erected by the Harlem Auditorium Amusement Company at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, on the site utilized in recent political campaigns as Camp McKinley and Gamp Low. Nelson Roberts, who has been identified with theatre interests in Pittsburg and in this city with Koster Bial, will be general manager and director.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Owing to phenomenal traffic, the Illinois Central Railroad is badly in need of equipment for freight. Unable to get cars which have been ordered, the management has taken a novel method of increasing its freight shipment. Orders have been issued to assemble all discarded box cars on the entire system and patch them up for emergency business.

A spirited game of polo was played yesterday afternoon on the Squadron A. field at Van Cortlandt Park between the first squadron team and the Rumson Polo Club. The visitors won by 1 1/2 goals, the total being 7 for Rumson and 5 1/2 for the troopers. It was a hard-played and exciting game, particularly in the last period.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 18. -- Sterling exchange, in response to the easier money conditions, is showing fresh strength, and posted rates to-day were advanced one-half cent all around. The Clearing House rate to-day was 6 per cent.; New York funds sold at 25c and 20c discount: call loans, 6@7 per cent.; time money, 5@6 per cent. Exchanges, $19,933,002; balances, $1,517,176.

SYDNEY, Cape Breton, Sept. 18. -- Lieut. Robert E. Peary arrived here to-day on the steamship Windward from the arctic regions. He did not reach, the north pole in the course of his trip of lour years, but he says that in his last dash with that object in view he made important discoveries. The most northerly point reached was 84 degrees 17 minutes, northwest of Cape Hecla.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Secretary Root, after an absence of nearly two months, was at his desk to-day. He looks much improved in health by his sojourn at Carisbad and the rest from official duties. He had not been long in his office before Secretary Moody called to pay his respects, and a little later Mr. Adee, acting Secretary of State, came in.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- The Central Cross-Town Railroad Company of Buffalo was to-day granted permission by the State Railroad Commission to issue a first consolidated mortgage for $3,000,000. The proceeds are to be applied to refunding former bond issues on the property and for equipping fourteen miles of road for underground electric trolley services.

The great endurance contest between Joseph Laboda and an upright piano ended yesterday, after three days of continuous struggle, when the police headed off a lynching party and dragged Joseph to the lock-up.

There was a further rise in prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday under the lead of the standard railway shares, in which there was a continuation of the confident buying, which has been in evidence now for some time and which, because of the high money rates, has been much a matter of comment.

George McC. Miller of counsel for the Mitchell-Blair-Gates Proxy Committee of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company gave out the following statement yesterday regarding the status of the litigation in the fight to wrest control from the Osgood faction:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Secretary of the Navy Moody received the following dispatch to-day from Commander McLean of the Cincinnati:
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The Times says it much regrets to learn that the Marquis of Salisbury, who is in Switzerland, is unwell and confined to his bed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- China is on the verge of another Boxer uprising which may equal that of 1900, according to mail advices received at the State Department from Minister Conger, dated last month.

Police Headquarters got a shock yesterday that fairly dazed the whole establishment. Mayor Low's letter to Commissioner Partridge with reference to the funeral riots on the east side constituted the bombshell. Sergeant James Brady got up early and asked the Commissioner to retire him, which was done.

NEWPORT, Sept. 18. -- The musicale given by Robert Burton at the residence of Mrs. Charles Daniels and Mrs. Harry Hamlin this morning was largely attended. The musicale took place in the large ballroom of the Osgood villa and was an enjoyable and informal affair. Mr. Burton was assisted by Miss Eugenia Lessler and Heath E. Gregory and the audience was very enthusiastic in its applause.

As Is well known, the results of the last French census caused widespread anxiety. They showed that the population of France stands practically where it did five years ago. The increase during that period was 330,000, but nearly the whole of it was contributed by Paris, which is rather cosmopolitan than French, and occurred chiefly among the Belgian and other foreign residents.

WILKESBARRE, Pernn., Sept. 18. -- President Mitckell to-night denied the reports that he had prepared a demand in which terms for a settlement of the big strike were modified and had forwarded it to J. Pierpont Morgan with a note saying that the financier would be given until Oct. 20 to accept the proposition.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 18. -- It was stated here to-day that at the conference held by Messrs. Mitchell, Gompers, Wilson, Duffy, Nichols, and Fahy in Wilkesbarre this week, a proposition was formulated to be laid before J. Pierpont Morgan, embodying terms upon which a settlement of the miners strike might be reached.

Mirth and jollity reigned yesterday, notwithstanding the drizzling rain, over the links of the Kichmond County Country Club, Staten Island. Over twenty golfers, members of the Produce Exchange Golf Association, participated in their sixth semi-annual handicap tournament.

BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- The German Foreign Office has received a note from the British Government inviting some action on the part of the signatories of the treaty of Berlin of 1878 regarding Roumania's treatment of the Jews. The British note is shorter than that of the United States on the same subject, but it pursues the same end.

Details will be found in another column relative to the building of a new hotel at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, and regarding the new theatre to be erected at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street.

--We are delighted to find in The Knoxville (Tenn.) Sentinel support for our theory that President ROOSEVELT has devoted enough of his small leisure from the cares of State to convince himself that the old stories about a " Mecklenburg declaration" are true, and that the decision against its authenticity, upon which all the other real investigators of the subject have agreed, was entirely wrong.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- A description of the new North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm II., recently launched at the Vulcan Yards at Stettin, Germany, which in many respects will excell all other passenger steamships afloat, has been sent by the United States Consul, J. E. Kehl, stationed at Stettin.

These are times for Democrats to survey the rich future and forget a disgraceful past. Every Democratic State Convention that ignores or repudiates the Kansas City platform of BRYAN speeds the party on its way to regained confidence and restored power.

The members of the bankrupt firm of Kanter Cohen, giving a reason for their refusal to obey the usual order that required them to file schedules and turn over their book's of account, , said that if they did so their action might incriminate them and compel, them to become fitnesses against themselves.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 18. -- An unexpected result of the merging of the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railroads is the gradual absorption of every small railroad in the State by these two lines. So rapidly has this process gone forward that to-day only two small independent lines exist.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The twentieth day of the Hudson Valley railway strike saw a car start from here over this division in charge of Deputy Sheriffs and militia, and manned by non-union men. As the car proceeded on its progress through the bank square, the conductor was struck by a bystander and the car stopped, the militia getting off and clearing a space.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 18. -- The St. Louis baseball team tied the Pittsburg champions in the seventh inning by bunching hits and scoring 3 runs, but lost the game in the tenth, when Hackett gave a base on balls and Was hit safely twice. Score by innings:
Capt. William R. Grove, Commissary, will proceed to Fort Riley for temporary duty in connection with the supply of troops during the army manoeuvres.
OYSTER BAY, N. Y., Sept. 18. -- Secretary Cortelyou made public to-day the following outline of the President's tour to the Northwest, beginning to-morrow and extending until Oct. 7.
LONDON, Sept, 19. -- Some remarks by a Hungarian ex-politician in regard to the Kossuth centenary celebrations are sent by the Vienna correspondent of The Times.

The course of prices in the outside market yesterday was still upward, and among the more active issues a number of advances that amounted to a point or more were recorded. In some cases the reactions were more or less substantial, but nevertheless the net gains, outnumbered the declines and the day's trading showed in general a continuation of the favorable conditions which prevailed on Wednesday.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Sept. 18. -- George Huber of New York City was before Judge Safford for a hearing on the charge of murdering his wife, to-day, and was bound over to the Grand Jury. The tragedy occurred on Sunday at Monterey, and was due to the jealousy of Huber for the apparent fondness of his wife for the company of Andrew C. Fearing, also of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Gov. Albert B. Cummins of Iowa, whose uncompromising stand for tariff revision has led to the sensational withdrawal of Speaker Henderson from politics, was in Chicago today and discussed the matter with frankness.

A meeting of the Tammany Hall Executive Committee will be Held at 4 o'clock this afternoon. The question discussed yesterday was whether Charles F. Murphy would be made the sole leader of the Wigwam to replace the triumvirate of Messrs. Murphy, McMahori, and Haffen, who are now supposed to control the, affairs of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Two days have elapsed since Speaker Henderson's declination of the Congressional nomination in the Third Iowa District, but the Republican situation is thought not to have cleared in the least. It continues to be the uppermost topic of conversation in political circles, but the Republicans are still regarded as much confused as ever.

Rain caused a postponement of the harness races and the contest between Anaconda and Prince Alert that was to have been held at the Empire City track, Yonkers, yesterday, and the match will take place to-day. Yesterday's programme will all be run to-day, and the Friday, programme will go over to Saturday.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 18. -- More than 1,000 persons, including quite a sprinkling of ladies, gathered in Commonwealth Hall here to-night and nominated a city ticket, with which those associated with the recently organized Citizens' Union hope to drive from power the representatives of the Republican machine, who are alleged to have so long mismanaged the affairs of the municipality.

The thirty-sixth annual match at quoiting for the Bell Medal, held by the Grand National Curling Club of America, took place at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. As an extra inducement to bring out keener competition and a larger field of throwers, President Alfred H. Munson of Utlca, N. Y., offered a very handsome trophy to become the personal property of the winner of the Bell Medal.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Rates for money were easy to-day, and discounts had a tendency to be easier in harmony with the hardening of exchange and less nervousness regarding the probability of gold shipments to New York, though Lombard Street confidently expects that New York must make demands.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The United States' initiative in protesting to the nations which are parties to the Treaty of Berlin of 1878 against the treatment of Jews in Roumania meets with approval here.

The construction of another large apartment hotel of the first class was announced yesterday. It will be on the southeast corner of Sixtieth Street and Fifth Avenue, facing the Metropolitan Club, have a frontage of 50 feet on Fifth Avenue and 200 feet on Sixtieth Street, be fifteen stories high, and cost, with the lots and without equipment, $2,500,000.

YONKERS, N. Y., Sept. 18. -- Monsignor Bernard O'Reilly celebrated the completion of sixty years in the priesthood to-day with, a diamond jubilee, features of which were a solemn high mass in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, at which a special Papal benediction was bestowed by the Rev. Father McGean of St. Peter's Church, in Manhattan, and a banquet in the afternoon in the rectory.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18. -- The visit of the Most Rev. Thos. Rodriguez, C. S. A., of Rome, to America as Prior General of the Order of St. Augustine has resulted in an effort on the part of the authorities to solve the Philippines friar question. Most of the friars on the islands are Augustinians. They are to be supplanted, if it is found practicable, by American priests of the order.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- All that remains of the John D. Rockefeller home on Pocantico Hills the still smoking heap of ruins. There is one chimney that still stands to mark the site of the building John D. Rockefeller, Jr., was about the place all day supervising the work of removing the furniture to the Kent house from the barn, to which it was carried last night.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 18. -- Weights similar to the one attached to the body of the woman found in the Morris Canal are used in this city by Michael A. Mullen, a livery stable keeper, of 261 "Washington Street. All his horse weights are stamped as is the one found with the body, and all weigh twenty pounds.

There is a possibility of a revolt in the State Republican Convention against the agreement reached by the Republican leaders at their recent conference in this city to give the nomination for Lieutenant Governor to George R. Sheldon. The sweeping victory won by Lieut. Gov. Woodruff in the Brooklyn primaries led to talk in Brooklyn yesterday that the Kings County delegation would demand his renomination.

The dead body of Mrs. Annie Pulitzer, wife of Joseph Pulitzer, a tailor, living at 160 West Forty-sixth Street, was found early yesterday afternoon lying in the Morris Canal a few hundred feet west of the Hackensack River bridge, and between that and the Passaic bridge in the Hackensack Meadows, in Kearney Township, just over the Jersey City line.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- In his report to the Secretary of the Navy upon the combined operations between the army and navy, Adimral Higginson is most generous in his distribution of praise among the officers of the squadron, and especially does he commend Rear Admiral Coghlan for his very able and efficient assistance.

With great enthusiasm and loud acclaim the Fire Chiefs in convention at Grand Central Palace yesterday elected Edward P. Croker, the youthful head of the New York Fire Department, President of the International Association of Fire Engineers.

David Lamar has surprised Wall Street again. Although he aroused the animosity of J. Pierpont Morgan on account of his activity in the suit of Hodge against the United States Steel Corporation, he had the courage yesterday to enter the lion's den -- for a few moments only. After spending a few moments in Mr. Morgan's presence, he was glad to retire as gracefully as possible.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 19. -- New York society people to the number of 100 were entertained this evening by Col. Robert B. Baker at his country place, the Cross Roads, next to the Fairfleld County Golf Club, in a manner novel to this part of the country. Col. Baker was assisted by William H. Temple and Devaux Powell.

BERLIN, Sept. 19. -- "The American note to the Berlin signatories," says the Vossische Zeitung, "represents one of the most interesting documents in contemporary history, and is one of the most remarkable political acts of the present day, for it is the first time that the diplomacy of the United States draws into its sphere of activity occurrences within a European commonwealth.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- Henery James's new book, "The Wings of the Dove," is perhaps the longest book that he has written. Once in a while some industrious man engraves the Declaration of Independence on a sixoebce, or the Lord's Prayer on an old-fashioned three-cent piece and people say that the feat is a wonderful one.

The coal strike, or the President's speeches, or the combination of the two has probably suggested the reissue of two books by Mr. Freeman Otis Willey on industrial problems. The first of them, entitled "The Laborer and the Capitalist," which was first published in 1896, suffers from the fact that it now appears without any revision to bring it up to date.

Capt. Titus, Chief of the Detective Bureau, announced at 10:30 o'clock last night that Mrs. Anna Pulitzer was murdered by William Hooper Young, a grandson of Brigham Young, the famous Mormon leader. The murder, said the chief detective, was committed in the apartment of Young's father, at 103 West Fifty-eighth Street.
IT is that there are prim, starched, dignified personages who would resent the treatment of entomology in a humorous manner, as par-taking of sacrilege, or as a personal assault on themselves.

Upon one side "Out of the West" is a political story; upon another, a love story, and upon a third, a study of the effect of environment upon heredity. The origin, rights, and sufferings of the Populist Party and the marriage of the New York man, Frank Field, to Edith Hull, "the Colorado Joan of Are," are the means through which the psychological problem is worked out.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 19. -- Eight gangs of riveters, thirty-two workmen in all, employed at the Crescent shipyards here, went on strike to-day because, as they alleged, through the management of their foreman their wages had been reduced from $3.41 a day to $2.77. The strike will tie up work at the yards should it last any length of time.

Conventions were held in all of the Assembly districts of Manhattan last night to nominate delegates to the State Republican Convention to meet in Saratoga, on Tuesday next. In most of the districts the conventions were mere formalities, the delegates and alternates having been named by the district leaders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- Secretary Shaw announced before leaving Washington this afternoon for the West that during the week he had authorized the distribution in round numbers of $10,000,000 in public funds among banks throughout the country which have bonds available for security.

THE library which is described below was one of the most remarkable book and manuscript collections ever formed. Could it come to the hammer to-day in its entirety its dispersion would awake competition throughout the whole world of letters.

Charles F. Murphy, Tammany leader of the Eighteenth Assembly District and President of the Dock Board during the administration of Mayor Van Wyck, was elected leader of the Tammany organization yesterday. The meeting at which the Croker-Sullivan-Murphy faction won the contest against the followers of John F. Carroll was one of the most exciting, from a political standpoint, held in years in the Tammany headquarters.

LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Andrew Lang has finished the second volume of his "History of Scotland from the Roman Occupation," which Messrs. Blackwood will publish this year. Mr. Lang's literary zeal is as great as ever, and the output of his literary labors continues to astonish his contemporaries.
CHRISTIANIA, Sept. 19. -- Capt. Sverdrup has telegraphed to the Government as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19. -- Representatives of twelve railroad systems of the South and West to-day completed, details for extensive colonization work in the Southwest, along the lines of the roads concerned. The purpose is to brims about a much greater development of that section than is possible by the individual efforts of the various roads.

BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- Boston beat Philadelphia to-day in what developed in the ninth inning into a lively contest. White, who batted for Iburg, drove a hot ball to left that bounded off Cooley's foot into the bleachers, and the batter scored on the hit, sending in two other runs. Score by innings:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Now that the result of the Minnesota primary election is known, after a delay due to the confusion incident to the inauguration of a new system, the impression prevails here that President Roosevelt is beginning his Western tour under discouraging conditions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the committee appointed by Mayor Low to investigate the recent riot on Grand Street has made its report, a few words in connection with the same may at this time be opportune.

BOSTON, Sept. 19. -- In the money market rates are still firmly held, but at the same time there are indications that the banks are more ready to let money out. The present demand is, however, still extremely light. Sterling exchange continues quiet and steady. Clearing House rate, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 20 discount; call loans, 6@7; time money, 5@6; Clearing House exchanges, $21,270,816; balances, $1,449,757.

One of the most delightful hats seen this Fall is really worth mentioning. It is a hat of soft, fine light gray felt, and such a relief after all the heavy beavers, draped velvets and furs. The felt is so soft and fine that it is not much more than a piece of cloth, and this soft effect is heightened by the finish of the edge, which is embroidered.

Fifty years ago C.W. Bardeen published a volume on "Civil Government," which passed through many editions. Of late a new demand has arisen for a book so well fitted for schools where civics are taught. We all want a political education. With the complexity of modern life, the difficulties of social organization are increasing, not diminishing.

Trading on the StocK Exchange yesterday was much more active than In recent days, although the dealings were not so well distributed, interest converging on a few issues. The market, however, as a whole was decidedly strong, although the dullness in certain of the inactive issues gave the trading an appearance of irregularity.

BELFAST, Sept. 19. -- Sir Thomas Lipton arrived to-day at Bangor, on Belfast Lough, on board the Erin, to confer with the officials of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club, through which his challenge for another series of races for the America's Cup will be dispatched shortly.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: When Napoleon in exile would be entertained if possible he asked for a copy of "Clarissa Harlowe," remembering what a delight the book had been to him in his youth. It disappointed him utterly; the only entertainment it gave him was that of making out what the budget of Lovelace must have been.

Although no schedule price was agreed on formally yesterday by the retail coal dealers, there was a general understanding that until further notice the retail price of domestic anthracite will be $11 a ton, an increase of a dollar on the latest schedule price. Higher prices may be and are charged by some of the dealers.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Dr. Walter W. Skeat. in "An Etymological Dictionary of the English Language," treating of this word, derives it from the low Latin "dispedicare." through the old French "despecher," and modern French "depecher." and says: "The spoiling 'dispatch' is very common, but 'despatch ' is the more correct."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The schedule for the football team of Georgetown University was given out to-night by Manager Frank T. Fitzgerald, Jr., as follows:

"Players of the Present," a supplementary volume to "Plays of the Present," has just been published by the De Vinne Press for subscribers of the Dunlup Society. In 1886 a number of actors, artists, and authors, with some lawyers and merchants, established this society, and during the first five years of its existence it published fifteen books on the American stage.

Trading In the outside market yesterday was very animated, but it was principally in the Rook Island issues that unusual activity was shown. In general the upward movement, of prices which was resumed three days ago continued and-further substantial advances were recorded in a number of the most prominent issues.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 19. -- The fourth annual Lenox Horse Show, which was held to-day at Highlawn Farm, was a great success in spite of cloudy and threatening weather. There was a larger attendance than ever before, and many society people were present.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Boods: A recent allusion of your Tendon correspondent to "unknown books" and to books that have failed suggests that a long list of "book that have been forgotten" night be made many of which would be far more readable than the bulk of those which are being so rapidly issued at the present time, and which we read largely because it is the fashion so to do.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 19. -- In an awful crush of humanity caused by a stampede in the Shiloh Negro Baptist Church, at the corner of Avenue G and Eighteenth Street, to-night, seventy-eight persons were killed and as many more seriously injured.

WAN has always struggled to comprehend the meaning of his existence," says Mr. Orlando J. Smith, and he, for his part, goes on struggling. He opposes the agnostic, who, as far as I understand his position, thinks that knowledge about the meaning of his existence is impossible.

THE want of any ready means of finding out just what is the state of our insular possessions has long been felt by serious readers. What is it, such readers ask, that we are really trying to do in the Philippines, and what progress have we really made in the doing of if?

Mr. George P. Upton some years filled what seemed to have been a long felt want by publishing his little book on the standard operas. He told the stories of the works and gave some other data, presumably of use to lovers of music. The popularity of this little book led him to put forth others dealing with standard works of the musical repertory.
LONDON, Sept. 19. -- Notwithstanding the renewed advance in New York exchange there was an indisposition in the market to-day to permit discounts to decline, though money was abundant and cheap.

Joseph Conrad's now story would be notable if only for the description of a terrible storm in the China seas, which gives it its title "Typhoon," So vivid is the description that you feel you are actually on board the steamer Nan-Shan and that you cling to her bulwarks so as not to be blown into the raging waters.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Stanley Spencer, the well-known English aeronaut, yesterday successfully accomplished a remarkable flight over London in an airship of his own invention. It is estimated that his ship traveled nearly thirty miles.

It is no wonder Secretary HAY'S note should have attracted European attention. The notion that the "European concert" could be held accountable "before man," and before the opinion of mankind, for anything it might choose to do, is evidently a novelty in diplomatic circles.

MR. RILEY'S bibliography of 200 titles is merely a list of the books he has consulted in the course of this research. It does not fairly represent the abundance of that literature, both friendly and inimical, which Mormonism has produced. Mr. Riley has himself compiled a card catalogue of 1,200 titles. In his bibliography there is one notable omission -- that of the recent "Story of the Mormons," by William Alexander Linn.

That is a highly serious-looking uprising of the so-called "Boxers" in the Province of Sze-Chuen, which was much disturbed by the same cause two years ago. Apparently the uprising is really against the Viceroy, who has been outrageously "milking" his province, even beyond Chinese custom or precedent.

Rain again interfered with the trots at the Empire City track, Yonkers, yesterday, and the management has decided to run off Thursday's and Friday's programme to-day, which will make it necessary to start the racing at 10 o'clock in the morning.

The continuance of the coal strike with so little change in its character and aspects is a fact well calculated to wear out the patience of the public and give great encouragement to those who advocate extreme and possibly dangerous expedients to force a settlement of the pending disagreements.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Wilikie Collins is counted rather oldfashioned these days, and his tales are reyarded as little more than sublimated shilling shockers. it is interesting, therefore, to note that Miss Wilkins, the New England realist in miniature, in her last story in one of the current magazines, has closely paralleled In plot and treatment one of the most fantastic of Wilkie Coltins's tales.

The movement to defeat the nomination of George R. Sheldon for Lieutenant Governor by the State Republican Convention and bring about the renomination of Lieut. Gov. Woodruff gained ground yesterday, and predictions were being freely made in Republican circles yesterday that Mr. Woodruff would be his own successor.

Cheered on by a crowd of well-dressed men and women who had poured out of Sherry's and Delmonico's at the first sounds of the fire engine, two firemen attached to Engine No. 65 rescued two women by the use of scaling ladders yesterday afternoon from a smoke-filled boarding house at 30 West Forty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Thomas B. Reed, ex-Speaker of the House of Representatives, who is in Washington, expressed himself to-night as being greatly interested in the outcome so far as it affected the Republican Party of Speaker Henderson's declination to run again for Congress.

One embarks upon the rippling pages of "The Right Princess" with the pleasant expectation of being borne peacefully along the purling stream of a Summer novel. There are the not unusual ingredients of the pretty girl in blue, eagerly sought by scions of English nobility, who display a readiness as common in fiction ay it is rare in real life, to play the part of King Cophetua.

Charles Foutsch, a boy who lived at 430 West Fifty-third Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Meade in the West Side Court a week ago yesterday on a charge of petit larceny. It was alleged that he had stolen shawls from a carriage owned by a liveryman in West Fifty-third Street. He told the Magistrate that he was twelve years of age, and he was sent to the Children's Court, where he was found guilty.

Our French friends have a sort of historical writing which is common enough among us, but for which we have no descriptive title so apt and adequate as their "memoires pour servir." It is in this class we must place the almost innumerable magazine articles, reviews, correspondence criticisms that have swarmed in our periodicals and newspapers since the close of the war for the Union.
VIENNA, Sept. 19. -- The Protest of the United States on behalf of the Jews of Roumania was received in official circles here with mingled feelings.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Secretary of the Navy Moody to-day made public the following cablegram from Commander McLean of the Cincinnati:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The hearing in the case of Miss Laura Biggar, or Mrs. Henry M. Bennett, as she is seeking to prove herself to be, was brought today before Judge Heisley, sitting in the Orphans' Court here. She seeks to secure the bulk of the estate of the late Henry M. Bennett of Pittsburg and Pleasantvllle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Those persons who, in order to avoid admitting the existence of a split in the Republican Party over the tariff question, are endeavoring to prove that Speaker Henderson gave false reasons for his withdrawal have offered a large number of explanations today.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 19. -- Mrs. Laura D. Mellier of West Bell Place to-day sued Marion Lambert of the Lambert Pharmical Company for $2,600 damages alleged to have been caused by a bull terrier named Jack, once owned by Mrs. Lambert, but which has recently been stolen.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept, 19. -- Lafayette Gruff of Gloucester was hanged in the county jail here to-day for the murder of his wife, Mary Ann Gruff. The crime was committed March 11 at the home of Mrs. Gruff's aunt, Mrs. Susan Gowie, at Westmont, near here.

A Woman of the Directory. Lionel Strachey, the translator of "Memoirs of Countess Potocka," has just completed translating for Doubleday, Page Co. the "Memoirs of a Contemporary," by that remarkable woman of the French Directory, Ida Saint-Elme.

Ellen Glasgow's thin volume of verse, printed by the De Vinne Press, comes robed in elegant simplicity; or, one might almost say, in Quaker splendor. A single poem, no better nor longer than the others, gives the book its title, while its bold, black type seems grateful and inviting to the eye. In this cool and sober grayness we should suspect that serious thinking, at least, with fluent art, might find its fit environment.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19. -- Split heats and heavy betting marked the light harness racing at Electric Park to-day. The three events on to-day's card went over until to-morrow, after the favorites in each had won two heats.

A news dispatch printed a few days ago described the anniversary of an authoress. She confessed with apparent coyness that she still "scribbled," but was not sure that she would ever again "publish anything. At least that is what the news story said. Perhaps she did not call it scribbling, Perhaps she spoke in some other terms, but it seems altogether likely that she indulged a flippant simulation of indifference to her art.
