Oranoff, with his inexhaustible and irresistible rubles, is not Mr. Hulbert's hero, however.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19. -- Local Issues predominated in the Philadelphia market to-day, with Philadelphia Electric, which rose 9 1/2 points, leading in point of activity. Philadelphia Rapid Transit reached a high record price, and many other issues were higher than they have been for months. Reports of a possible merger of Philadelphia Electric and Rapid Transit were repeated freely on the Street, but there was no official sanction for them.

In "A Gossip on Romance," Robert Louts Stevenson says that the top sparkle of enjoyment in reading a romance is reached only when the interest of character is so subordinated to the interest of incident that the reader becomes himself the hero of the adventures upon which he hangs breathless.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 19. -- Five thousand miners from the upper anthracite valley gathered on the Dickson City rifle range of the Thirteenth Regiment this afternoon and listened to addresses of encouragement and admonition from their leaders. One thing was urged by all the speakers, and that was that the strikers refrain from any violence.

It is understood that all details of a transaction involving another fine dwelling on upper Fifth Avenue, in the neighborhood of Mr. Carnegie's mansion, have been agreed upon, and that announcement regarding it will probably be made to-day.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I wish "Elizabeth's" husband might tell us just what he thinks about his wife and her German garden, and I wish it more than ever since reading her article "On the Giving of Cooks" in the September Century. But, of course, there are some things concerning which a man's lips are forever sealed by honor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The United States consumes now eight times as much sugar per capita as in the first quarter of the last century, four times as much as the average per capita during the decade ending with 1830, and twice as much as in any year prior to 1870.

The week's end brought more than the usual number of house parties with it. The Lenox Horse Show was one of the attractions to take many to the Berkshires. There were horse shows also at Bernardsville and at Millbrook. People are beginning to arrive in town from Newport and from Bar Harbor.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 19. -- At one moment this morning Peter Hernia, condemned to die on the scaffold an hour later,' was quietly talking to a priest of his future destiny. Then by a sudden jump and a pull the murderer grabbed a fivefoot bar of lead pipe from the wall of the jail, poured forth a volley of oaths and blasphemies, and defied any one to approach him.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The British Foreign Office last evening authorized the announcement that his Majesty's Government had communicated with all the signatory powers of the Berlin Treaty with a view to developing their attitude and purpose in relation to the Roumanian Jews, as called to the attention of the powers by United States Secretary of State Hay.
HERE are some of the lines that create laughter in "Aunt Jeannie," the play in which Mrs. Patrick Campbell is appearing at the Garden Theatre:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on Sunday, the 14th, entitled "Popular Contributions to Strike Funds," is one which commends itself in great part to the approval of those who, without any bias, wish to see a just settlement of the issues between the coal operators and their employes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Hewitt, it appears to me, has gone to such extremes in his numerous utterances on the coal strike that I feel compelled to remark that this noted philanthropist, this sage of our city, who has so truly and sternly preached the stewardship of wealth, seems for the moment to hare forgotten his stewardship of wisdom.

IT TAKES more than nerve and good eyesight to shoot big game -- it takes money. Not only are the expenses involved in securing a proper outfit generally heavy, but it is necessary to consider railroad fares and the cost of the license for the season.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 20. -- McLaughlin, Pittsburg's new pitcher, won his first game on the home grounds by doing fair work himself and having excellent support. The features of the game were the remarkable catches of Sebring and Leach. Score by innings:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ernest Richard, the writer of your article, "The German, the Pole, and the Czech," has seen fit to correct your editorial bearing on the early culture of the Poles and the Czechs, or (Bohemians.) but, judging from his statements, I fear that he himself is sadly in need of a broader and deeper knowledge of the subject on which he writes.

The majority of the thousand or more passengers from Southampton and Cherbourg, who arrived here yesterday on the American liner St. Paul, did not know that a fire, which at one time looked serious, occurred on the steamship early Friday morning.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20. -- President Woodrow Wilson's inauguration will be held on Oct. 25. On Oct. 14 Dr. Francis Landey Patten, predecessor to President Wilson, will be elected to the Presidency of the Princeton Theological Seminary.

UP NORTH -- If you are skating, and both feet suddenly slip out from under you and point straight in front, it is a sign that you are going to fall down. You should hunt for an easy place to light. If you survive the lighting you should roll over three times and think of your early Sunday school training.

SO MANY people have been coming into town of late for stays of a day, or three or four, that the fashionable restaurants have presented an extremely gay appearance. The gowning has been in most cases less elaborate than during the Winter and Spring, but, nevertheless, beautiful, and some of the coats worn have been brought back from Paris during the Summer by those of their wearers who have been abroad since Spring.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 20. -- Up to noon to-day eighty-seven dead bodies of victims of last night's panic at the Shiloh Baptist Church, colored, had been identified. There are a number of corpses yet unidentified. As nearly as can be figured at this hour the number of dead is 115, while no accurate estimate can be placed on the number of injured. Among the dead are:

The annual music festival at Worcester, Mass., will take place on Sept. 30 and Oct. 1, 2, and 3. There will be seven concerts, the first on Tuesday evening, Sept. 30, and the others at the rate of two a day. At the first concert George W. Chadwick's "Judith" will be repeated, with Mrs. Stein, Mr. Campanari, Mr. Van Yorx, and Mr. Witherspoon as soloists.

COMMISSIONER PARTRIDGE'S recent plea for the removal of Police Headquarters from its present location in Mulberry Street to Broadway and Forty-seventh Street adds another element of interest to the growing popularity of Long Acre Square. Already a great commercial, theatrical, club, and hotel centre, it is destined to be even more so in succeeding years.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 20. -- Chancellor Andrews in his opening address to the students of the State University to-day, made the statement that too much of a "bugaboo" had been made of the question of imperialism. He thought some public men had tried to scare the people because of trusts.

ENTIRELY aside from the ambitions ascribed to Archbishop Ireland, it is considered absurd by Catholics of the United States that there should be only one Cardinal in this country. There should be at least a dozen, say some authorities on the subject, if the same ratio is to prevail here that obtains in, say, Italy.

REGINALD RONALDS has arrived. This signified much for the Knickerbocker Club, which gave him a right royal reception. There are few men who are such general favorites as he. He was one of the four who went from that club, one evening in May, to join the Rough Riders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have at hand yesterday's issue of The City Record, and the list of trial jurors in Kings County presents many curious features which are incomprehensible to me. I have often wished there existed in a city government an officer whose privilege and duty it would be to criticise the acts of any or all other officials.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The trusts have hitherto been little more than a name to English readers of newspapers, who have imagined them as something which the fertile genius of Americans had called into being solely for American domestic uses. It is now being realised that their application is not to be restricted to the New World, and that England has to face the dread ordeal which the trusts involve.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our worthy Mayor has lately, in a pleasant, colloquial way, given the public some very interesting talks as to the needs of Greater New York. And it is only fair play to the taxpayer that he be allowed to talk back a little. So I shall take that privilege If THE TIMES will permit me to use a small space of its columns for that purpose.

SHE is a Christian Science mother, and she is faithfully bringing up her offspring in the way in which they should go according to her Christian Science lights. Her children know their Christian Science better than most children know the ordinary Church catechism, and, as this experience of the mother has proved, endeavor to live up to it.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Allow me, in the interest of true reform, to express a few words of criticism with regard to the new system of school inspection instituted by Commissioner Lederle of the Health Department.

The open-air mass meeting in Madison Square last evening in support of the striking miners was as great a success as the meeting of the previous Saturday evening, which was spoiled by a rain storm, was a fizzle. John Mitchell arrived in town from Wilkesbarre in the afternoon in order to plead the cause of the miners.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -- Trading was small in the local market to-day and but few stocks were affected by the heaviness in New York. The major part of the list closed with small advances. Philadelphia Electric overshadowed the dealings in all other stocks, the sales reaching a total equal to that of nearly all other shares combined.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 20. -- Concerning the 20 per cent. tariff on art treasures, including paintings and statuary, which has been severely criticised by J. Pierpont Morgan and P.A.B. Widener, both of whom declare that $30,000,000 is tied up in art treasures owned by Americans which would be imported if the duty was removed.

The ministers of various denominations are having a great deal of what would appear to be unnecessary trouble concerning the way women dress for church, especially as to their heads. Hats of fashionable shape and trimming, and especially what are known as picture hats, have been repeatedly denounced as sinful abominations, blanketing the preacher from those behind the wearers and attracting a degree of attention from other women inconsistent with devotional concentration.

IT IS said that ex-Chief Devery spent $31,000 in order to become leader of the Ninth District. During the campaign the question frequently was asked: "Where did he get it?" Also, although Mr. Devery declined to enlighten the public on this point, some of his followers undertook to do so for him.

ACCORDING to advices from Athens, a very curious disease, extremely infectious and resembling smallpox among human beings, has broken out among the statues in the Egyptian Room of the National Museum at the Greek capital. Stephanos Skouloudes, the distinguished political and archaeologist, noticed a few days ago some strange green marks on one of the bronze statues of the famous Egyptian collection presented to the museum in 1881 by Mr. Demetrios of Alexandria.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have refrained from replying to your query as to which, the careful or the expeditious boy got the job in your story of the merchant and the two boys, related some weeks ago, thinking it was so easy that most of your numerous readers would give the correct reply at once.

The heat lightning of ex-Speaker REED'S comment does not illuminate the Henderson incident. "I do not see why," he says, "when a man in the political world assigns a good reason for sudden action on his part, even if it be precipitate, he cannot be believed." The trouble in the case of Mr. HENDERSON is that he is believed, and that the reason he assigns for his action is extremely disagreeable to his party associates.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 20. -- In his speech here to-night at the Music Hall Building of the Fall Festival, the President said:

To the Edtor of The New York Times: In view of the many recent, unnecessary, and heart rending accidents caused by the reckless driving of automobiles, some action should be taken by the authorities, as well as by the citizens and the proprietors of the Somerset Inn, if they do not wish to drive people from Bernardsville, as a "dangerous place."

NO feature of the life to which he is just returning will interest the college boy more than the fraternity "rushing" season which occupies the first days of the Fall term. Whether known as "rushing," "cultivating," or "campaigning" this season is full of importance to the student, for it largely determines the complexion of all the fraternities and, indeed, often determines the future of many freshmen.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Manipulation, abetted by rains, worked for advances in grain today. Regardless of injunctions against corners and fictitious prices the shorts in September wheat became frightened and put the price up on themselves.

A PART from his apparent fitness for the Papal Delegateship to the United States, the Pope's selection of Mgr. Falconio has given satisfaction to the Catholics of this country in that the Vatican's new representative is an American citizen.

BERLIN, Sept. 12. -- The American church now under construction at the Nollendorf Platz, was this week the centre of a novel and most interesting celebration. The roof of the new edifice has just been completed, and, as it is customary in Germany on such an occasion, the event was marked by a special festivity.

XIV. HULLO, Idiot, old chap," observed Mr. Brief as the Idiot entered the dining room lisclessly and expressed a desire for "a little of everything this morning," because he was not very hungry. "What's the matter? More strenuous life?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Information has been received here that Col. J.W. Powell, Director of the Bureau of Ethnology of the Smithsonian Institution, is critically ill at his Summer home in Haven, Me.

THOUGH for the most part this interesting journal is a discreet translation from the original hieroglyphics, the last two entries were found to be written in English on pink notepaper, presumably with a fountain pen, and from this and other evidence are believed to be spurious.

IT IS the opinion of Annapolis graduates that the most important change Commander Wainwright has made in the curriculum of the Naval Academy during his term of office was making the study of Spanish compulsory.

QUINCY, Mass., Sept. 20. -- Named by a daughter of Iowa and started on her downward rush by the hand of a Massachusetts girl, the protected cruiser Des Moines was launched shortly after noon to-day from the yard of the Fore River Ship and Engine Company. Hundreds of people saw the ship plunge into the water, and for some time after their cheers echoed along the river banks.

Although the Carlisle Indians, as usual, played the first football game of the season with Lebanon Valley College yesterday, it was hardly more than a practice game, and the real opening of the season will occur next Saturday, when most of the leading college teams will play their first schedule games.
In the Louisville Courier-Journal last Sunday Henry Watterson said, among other things:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 20. -- James Staples, banker was to-day appointed conservator over Augustus A. McKelvey by the Probate Court, on an application made toy Charles W. McKelvey, brother of respondent. After hearing all the evidence the court found that respondent has been and is now suffering from mental infirmaties of a permanent and progressive nature, and is incapable of managing his affairs.

WE HEAR a great deal nowadays about the progressiveness of Americans, and especially the position away cut in advance of the rest of the world occupied by American journalism, but it has remained for an editor in slow old London to be the first to make an announcement which some shrewd observers have lately come to expect.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Your recent editorial on Mayor Tom L. Johnson of Cleveland, the notable ex-Congressman and Democratic leader of Ohio, was Interesting and timely. Timely, because you call attention to the undoubted Democratic Presidential nominee in 1904, and interesting owing to the fact that you only exhibited the worst side of Mr. Johnson's public career, both as a politician and as a business man.

ENGLAND has just awakened to another danger which confronts her. It is one of serious moment to Great Britain, and of peculiar interest to Americans. Up to the present no device has been suggested whereby this danger may be obviated. The facts have been known for some time at the Admiralty, but it is only lately that the main details have been revealed to the general public.

About the billiard rooms of this city and in the clubs where the game holds a prominent place there is an air of activity, and the attaches of the establishments are founding up the ivory balls and putting cues in trim with new tips. Once more the billiard season is at hand, and the rainy days of last week filled many of the rooms to overflowing, so that tables were in great demand.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Much has been said about the methods by which Speaker Henderson runs the House, in consequent of the complaints that have been so frequently and bitterly made, during the last session by the Democrats and some Republicans, that the House has ceased to be a deliberative body.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- One result of the coal famine in Washington due to the strike is that oil is coming into heavy demand as fuel. The business of selling coal ranges is also falling off, while the trade in oil stoves is increasing tremendously. There does not seem to have been much increase in the demand for gas stoves.

FOR a long time there has been no end of speculation among the jackies at the navy yard as to what has become of Perny, the Brazilian parrot that created such a furor in naval circles several years ago, when the cruiser Montgomery came home from the South Atlantic Station to undergo an extensive overhauling.

Among all the theatres that have opened there are not as yet any signs of distinct successes. Two plays are soon to be removed after short and rather poor runs, and there are others which continue simply because the house must be kept open or else because the managers want a forced run for the benefit of out-of-town theatres, where a New York trademark is necessary.

GYPSY LEE, the old and renowned fortune teller who lives at Devil's Dyke, near Brighton, England, is being much scoffed at just now that the celebrated prophecy of which she was always supposed to have been the authoress has happily failed of fulfillment. King Edward VII. has been crowned in spite of all predictions, but Gypsy Lee is now most emphatic in her denial of ever having foretold anything to the contrary.
UP at the Yale Club the other evening a group of 'Varsity men were gathered around a table in the grillroom yarning of athletic "stunts," past and present.

THE tired city man who turns longingly to thoughts of "the old farm" of his boyish memories and is impelled to go there or to some place as nearly resembling it as may be that, like Antaeus of the classic fable, he may recuperate his wasted energies by once more touching Mother Earth, would do well to forget all traditions of pastoral life or prepare himself for the shock of a great disappointment.

IT has been decided that a portion of famous Trinity Cemetery will have to be cut away to make room for the driveway now in course of construction that is to join Riverside Drive and the Boulevard Lafayette.
Ex-Fire Chief James Dale of Brooklyn died yesterday afternoon at his homes, 271 Hicks Street, that borough. He had been ill for some weeks with nervous indigastion and heart trouble.

YES, I came from Kentucky, or rather -- my mother did," said the Southern woman, "but I was taken away from there when I was so young that I do not remember it. I met with a serious trouble once just from saying that my mother was a Kentuckian, and I never more mention the fact.

E.C. Schaeffer of Pennsylvania, who has won every championship swimming contest during the present season, reached the climax of his victorious career by winning the swimming championship of the Amateur Athletic Union at Travers Island, the Summer home of the New York Athletic Club, yesterday afternoon.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 20. -- A new Canadian record to-day and low figures in other events made the nineteenth annual games of the Canadian Athletic Union notable. The events were held on the grounds of the Montreal Athletic Association. There was a large attendance, the conditions were admirable, although rain in the morning had a tendency to make the track slow.

DOWN in a little corner of the South-west, marked by the junction of the States of Tennessee, Missouri, and Arkansas, taking in the wilderness known as the Snake Lands, the male inhabitants to-day are brightening up their "shooting irons" in anticipation of to-morrow's stern duty.

CHAPTER I. THE cozy little parlor of the MacGiffs looked very homelike and peaceful that morning. But appearances are deceitful. The beautiful Mrs. MacGiff was in tears on the costly parlor divan, and her husband was pacing the floor, with anger written on every lineament of his handsome face.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Secretary Hay's note to the powers which signed the Berlin treaty of 1878, on the subject of Roumanian's treatment of Jews, has aroused widespread interest in the Jewish community of London. Israel Zangwill, the author, who is an authority among his coreligionists and a ceaseless worker for the improvement of the position pf the poorer among them, said to a representative of The Associated Press:

FUNNY things happened that day. No one has ever been able to explain just how they happened, and probably no one ever will. Prof. Hegel of Leipsic states as his opinion that the psychic centre of the universe shifted, whatever that may mean, and that as a consequence the minds of men turned a complete somersault, so to speak, so that all characteristics and fancies reversed themselves.

The three noteworthy features of the market in the week just past have been the phenomenal advance in St. Paul, the high money rates -- more in evidence in the earlier than the latter part of the week -- and the firmness of the market in the face of these high rates. Not only did prices on the Stock Exchange fall to go down; they advanced -- in some cases most substantially.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was perhaps a little early in the season for Mr. Corbin to pass, as he did on Monday night last, from the scarification of particular plays by American authors to the "pounding" of the American playwright in general. The latter congenial entertainment, however, always has its uses as well as its excuses.

OF THE many projects adopted by the Pan-American Congress at Mexico City last Winter, it now appears that one, considered at the time as of very little importance, is the first to be definitely acted upon. This is the one embodied in a resolution proposing an international congress for the study of coffee.

WHILE the new Weber and Field's burlesque was dragging itself to a conclusion on the opening night before the many cuts in dialogue and action had been made that result in a more snappy performance, a man approached a friend who happened to come into the lobby and asked if the "show" was over.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps no newspaper in the United States has as many readers of Canadian birth as THE NEW YORK TIMES. The cause of this is, no doubt, the conservative manner in which THE NEW YORK TIMES handles the question of the United States vs. Canada, and makes comparison with a fairness entirely free from any spirit of jingoism.

With due regard for the dangers of building too great expectations upon an uncertain foundation, it must, nevertheless, be a matter of considerable satisfaction to the real estate fraternity to notice that last week's business, in addition to the ordinary run of reasonable trading, has included a number of transactions of the first magnitude and of the sort that would be creditable to the market even in its most active periods.

-- Everybody coming into the city one day last week on the morning trains over the New York Central and the New Haven Roads was held up in the tunnel or its approaches for from twenty minutes to half an hour, and the amount of howling and growling done by the commuters -- every one of whom is invariably in a desperate hurry to reach his or her place of business -- was simply enormous.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your anonymous correspondent, "Y," in last Sunday's issue of THE TIMES, takes exception to my statement that "it is not a question of identity of interests, but the robbed versus the robbers "-- and he then presents a mental picture of "a machine" with the statement that "without the experts the laborers could produce nothing."

The weekly Clearing House statement, issued yesterday shortly before the close of business, made an unexpectedly unfavorable showing. The surplus reserve account was completely wiped out and a deficit substituted, the surplus reserves decreasing $2,357,125. At the same time there was a loss in cash of over $7,000,000, specie decreasing $5,768,100, and legal tenders decreasing $1,563,600.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "S.C.," in his letter in your issue of Sunday, Sept. 14, puts, I think, the cart before the horse when he lays the blame for the strike on the labor leaders. Is it not true that men (society) create conditions, and the conditions in turn create the man?

APPARENTLY Richard Croker will not have to undergo the fatigues and annoyances of a long journey and a long stay away from his quiet English home this year. The primaries seem to have left him in complete control, and the wrangling and fighting which will enliven the organization between now and next Fall's Mayoralty campaign will only make his return then the more welcome.

Manager "Ed" Hanlon of the Brooklyn baseball team was well pleased yesterday afternoon when his men won the last game of the series from the New Yorks on the Polo Grounds. The score was 6 to 3 in favor of the visitors, and the victory was won by the Brooklyn batters bunching their hits in the fifth inning for three runs.

UNDER the big oak by the fifteenth tee Mr. Arthur Glendenning was sitting at his ease. He was some ten strokes behind his opponent, Col. Bogey, but this did not bother him in the least. Bogey not being one of those players who tack their score cards in conspicuous places on the clubhouse bulletin board and mention their victories to every one they meet.

CARLISLE, Penn., Sept. 20. -- The opening game of this year's football season was played here to-day between the Carlisle Indians and Lebanon Valley. The score was 48 to 0 in favor of Carlisle. When compared with last season's work the figures are evidence in themselves that the Redskins will have one of the best teams in the country this year.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 20. -- The engagement is announced of Miss Ellen R. Davies to Edwin Newton Wise, Jr., of South Carolina. Mr. Wise is a son of Capt. Edwin Newton Wise, formerly of Alexandria, Va. The Wise family are identified with the early history of Alexandria, being among the original settlers prior to the Revolution.

Oarsmen for a long time have been debating the question of holding a regatta annually, similar to the meeting in England at Henley on the Thames, that has become famous throughout the world, and which attracts rowing men from all parts of the earth to the beautiful Thames River every year.
Treasury relief will show in this week's money market.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- C.W. Purington of Chicago, the Siberian traveler, was asked to-day his opinion in regard to trade conditions in East Siberia and China at present. He spoke encouragingly of the outlook for American commerce there. At present, he said, the largest item in the imports of machinery is that of agricultural implements.

Changes in the outside market yesterday were for the most part unimportant. There was further profit taking, which served to check any further upward movement in prices, but there were no serious losses as compared with Friday's closing prices. The bank statement, which was reflected by a drop in the Stock Exchange market, was without result, so far as outside stocks were concerned.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Evelyn B. Baldwin of the Baldwin-Ziegler Arctic expeditions, arrived in London to-day on his way home. He had little to add to what has already been cabled regarding his experiences, but he gave extended details of technical interest to Arctic navigation on the work accomplished and the stations established.

Three of the postponed races of the Empire City Trotting Club's Grand Circuit meeting were decided at the track near Yonkers yesterday, the rest of the events being declared off under the rule of the National Association.

KACH-CHA, the unbaked, was the name he gave when he came to them at Jellasore and offered his services in whatsoever capacity the sahib might wish. He was a native of the country they were going through, he said, and could guide them expeditiously and cheaply.

Tammany, after the election of CHARLES F. MURPHY as leader, presents a curious spectacle. Judged by the well-founded accusations brought against the leader and his supporters, the organization has fallen upon times as evil as those in which CROKER was the boss and VAN WYCK was Mayor.
"I shall tie thankful when the President is safely back in the White House," was the exclamation of one of the Republican leaders apropos of the departure of Mr. ROOSEVELT for the West.

IT IS fairly safe to assert that there is no city in the world which can boast of such amusingly paradoxical signs as those to be seen in and around New York. The amusement is all the more when one discovers a total absence of willful intent to be funny, in fact, they are the essence of innocent wit, published unwittingly.

We are much in sympathy with the desire of Commissioner PARTRIDGE to remove the Headquarters of the Police Department from its present location to Long Acre Square, albeit no little expense to the city would be involved in such a change.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 20. -- Andrew Burnham, who was an inspector of hulls for the port of Boston for forty years, died yesterday afternoon at the home of his son, Albert S. Burnham of Revere, of old age. Mr. Burnham had not been active during the past five or six years.

To have inspired Mr. Clark to write the Very interesting letter on the American playwright, which is printed in another column, is so gratifying that one may well be content with having gained only his partial concurrence; and yet it might be wished that he had taken the pains to see that he is really much more nearly in agreement with the article than he assumes.

The facts upon which are grounded all other features showing the progress of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company in the making of new high records of earnings are, of course, the development of the territory served by the company's lines, and the growth of traffic consequent upon that development.

THERE was recently found in this city a curious collection of pictures in which Emperor William of Germany would be particularly interested. They are nothing less than portraits of his ancestors, the Counts of Zollern and Hohenzollern, as they looked before and after the Crusades.

A new organization to exhibit and sell work by American oil painters, water colorisis, and sculptors is announced in Philadelphia, under the chartered name of American Art Society. Its first exhibition is to open on Oct. 8 at Earle's Galleries, in Chestnut Street. Private view is set for the evening of Oct. 7, and the exhibition will close Nov. 5.

Wall Street's week passed without exciting incident. Much ado was made at the start over tight money threats, and call loan rates were hippodromed around 20 per cent, for a time with a good deal of energy, but, unnaturalness showing in the performance, the security market stolidly refused to go to pieces.

When D.B. Spiridon, a merchant who lives at the Hotel Lafayette-Brevoort, went down to the pier yesterday morning to meet the incoming French liner La Touraine, he expected to greet his sister-in-law, Mrs. A. Stapely Spiridon, who was an American girl, and the wife of a wealthy Greek dealer in antiques, now resident in Nice.

PARIS, Sept. 20. -- W. Seligmann, the well-known banker, and one of the oldest members of the American colony here, celebrates to-morrow with Mrs. Seligmann their golden wedding, and at the same time his eightieth birthday. A fete will be given at St. Germain. Yesterday the American Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting in Mr. Seligmann's honor, and presented to him a congratulatory address.

ANDERSON, Ind., Sept. 20. -- The Republican campaign opened in this city to-night with Charles W. Fairbanks as the speaker of the occasion. The Senator was greeted by an enthusiastic gathering, and his speech was frequently interrupted by applause. The Senator also opened the campaign at Newcastle this afternoon, speaking to a large and enthusiastic assemblage.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on "The American Idea," in to-day edition of THE TIMES, you use these words: "It was a Frenchman, Napoleon Bonaparte, who expressed the idea,"

To the Editor of The New York Times: If Mr. Henry Watterson believes he has made a hit by castigating the folly of some exuberant high-livers, be they men or women, by divulging, exposing to the world the sores, the weaknesses to which human nature is heir to, he sadly mistakes his time, place, century, and people.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- One of the longest trolley trips ever recorded in this country has just been completed by Robert H. Darragh the local street railway expert and publisher. He covered the distance between Flint, Mich., and Boston, with the exception of a few breaks in Ohio and New York State, entirely by trolley.

BOSTON, Sept. 20. -- There was very little doing in the money market to-day, and the situation remained practically unchanged. Sterling exchange continues quiet, but steady. Clearing House rate, 6 per cent.; New York funds, 25c and 20c discount; call loans, 6@7; time money, 5@6; Clearing House exchanges, $19,403,191; balances, $1,739,769.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The long talked of trolley road from Saranac Lake, in the Adirondack, to Westport, on Lake Champlain, via Lake Placid, Elizabethtown, and Ausable Forks, seems now to be a certainty. The names of the capitalists can only be surmised at present, but it is said that the deal Is being financed by R. L. Keen Co., of 25 Broad Street, New York City.

THE PUMPKIN PIE, pleasant reminder of the past, is once more abroad in the land. Not yet quite the rich, golden, juicy pumpkin pie which comes in with the 1st of October, attains its perihelion on Thanksgiving Day, and languishes only with the closing of the Winter -- but still the pumpkin pie.

THE crusty bachelor had returned to his boarding house. The thought of the advanced price of coal had added to his already strong satisfaction in being single, and it was with something of a keen relish that he replied to the query of the prying landlady.

THE tardy application of the European powers of the perfectly plain lessons of the South African War is a warning to this country which should be heeded at the earliest opportunity. The slow percolation of the new ideas through the Continental head is due partly to overweening conceit, and partly to the fact that few foreign officers witnessed the operations in the Transvaal throughout the struggle.

Controller GROUT attempts in a recently published statement to justify the new policy of full valuation and buttress it about with fact and argument. What he really succeeds in doing is to make it appear that the money for needed public improvements can be had without any radical change in the method of assessment.

ONE WOULD not be surprised to learn that the attempt of the Northern Methodists to raise $20,000,000 as a twentieth century fund had been abandoned as impracticable. But the fact is that $17,000,000 has already been subscribed, and the remaining $3,000,000 may be fairly said to be in sight, says The Watchman of Boston.
At last David Belasco, after a long struggle, has a theatre in New York which, he can call his own. And he will open it Sept. 29 with Mrs. Leslie Carter in "Du Barry."

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 20. - Edward Rosewater, editor of The Omaha Bee, the leading Republican newspaper west of the Mississippi, will bolt the Republican Congressional ticket nominated in Omaha to-day and will fight Congressman David H. Mercer through the Fall campaign. Mr. Rosewater fought Mercer at the primaries yesterday, but failed to prevent his renomination.

A ACCORDING to the figures of the Alpine Club of Switzerland, sixty-three persons have been killed while climbing the mountains this Summer, and since that time two other deaths have occurred. This makes a total far in excess of that of any previous year.

PARIS, Sept. 12. -- I shall devote my letter this week to Emile Zola's forth-coming novel "Verite." In political as well as in literary circles it is the talk of the hour. It began its serial run two days ago in L'Aurore, and next January it will be published in book form in four languages besides French -- English, German, Italian, and Danish.

GREAT BRITAIN'S possession of her two new South African colonies has soon been followed by profitable discoveries of mineral wealth. Already, only a few weeks after the termination of the Boer war, it is announced that another gold field, probably as rich as the Band, has been found, and a number of prospecting parties are at work at different points.

XII. FANNIE DEAR: You write me such sweet and confidential letters now that I am compelled to confess what I was inclined to conceal, in spite of our agreement to write "cross-my-heart" letters to each other. Here goes, then: Robert wants me to elope with him!

A LONDON "comic" paper once contained a joke accompanied by a diagram and a chart, the point of which was -- as nearly as could be ascertained, for the diagram and the chart were a trifle confusing -- that Dr. Conan Doyle had found the title for one of his most popular detective stories, "A Study in Scarlet," in the faces of Londoners who were just back from the seashore.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- Nearly all the State Republican politicians of prominence have arrived here, and the United States Hotel, which is the headquarters of Senator Platt and the State Committee, was to-night the scene of political activity. Senator Platt came up on an early morning train.

The early Autumn season has brought out the attractions of the suburban and mountain resorts. It is as yet a bit early for Morristown and the Hudson. Lenox has had its Horse Show and on Friday and yesterday there were a large number of men going there for house parties. The week has seen much shifting of the various menages at Newport and Bar Harbor.

ONE of the features of the celebration of the thirty-second anniversary of Garibaldi's triumphal entry into Rome, not down on the official programme for either yesterday or to-day, is a pilgrimage to Rosebank, S. I., where the Italian patriot lived during a temporary stay in this country.

TO the average non-automobilist, who is accustomed to reading accounts every now and then of the running down of pedestrians by reckless drivers of automobiles, the announcement from Newport that W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr., had decided to retire permanently from automobiling as a sport, because of the prejudice against it and the restrictions imposed by the authorities, probably came as a surprise.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Sept. 20. -- The American demand for gold has again been the dominant factor in the London money market. Operations have been conducted secretly, but undoubtedly the bullion market's supply of bars was swept clean early in the week, and it is fairly certain that most of it went across the Atlantic, though Austria is said to have taken a little.

Six schooner yachts got away from Gravesend Bay on the second attempt yesterday morning for the Atlantic Yacht Club's ocean cruise. Two of them, the Muriel and the Sachem, gave up before getting outside of Sandy Hook. Four of the yachts, the Thistle, Endymion, Iroquois, and Coronet were still at it this morning scurrying along down the Jersey coast toward Cape May with a strong east wind, almost a gale, on their quarter.

To The Editor of The New York Times: When, last year, at the production of J.M. Barrie's "Quality Street," no one questioned the originality of this play, there crept into my mind slight but none the less tenacious doubts in that omniscience and unimpeachable soundness of judgment of Monsieur le Critique in which I had hitherto so implicitly believed.

The annual clambakes yesterday of the New Rochelle and Larchmont Yacht Clubs are treasures of memory, and, incidental to the jollifications, there were demonstrations of or experiments in the De Forest wireless telegraph system, there being instruments at the New Rochelle clubhouse on Harrison Island, and at that of the Larchmont Club, four miles away as the crow flies.

ST. THOMAS, Danish West Indies, Sept. 20. -- Unprecedented difficulties are being encountered in repairing the cables between St. Lucia and St. Vincent and St. Vincent and Grenada. They are seemingly buried in volcanic mud, which, combined with the great depth attributable to the alterations of the sea bed, puts an enormous strain on the cable gear.
A RECENT crime in England promises to develop into an interesting case from the fact that for the first time in Great Britain thumb marks are to be used as a means of identification.

Loyalty to the horse has perhaps never before been shown to so large an extent by the cottagers of Bernardsville. N.J., and the immediate vicinity as was done yesterday on the polo field of the Somerset County Club. The Bernardsville Horse Show was inaugurated, and it received so cordial a reception that the universal sentiment was to repeat the affair, only on a larger scale next year.

ONE of the most curious fashions of the past Summer in the Adirondacks was the wearing by young men of brass baggage checks on leather straps for watch fobs. To see a number of youths immaculately dressed on the porch of a fashionable hotel with a common "brawss for me luggage," in place of the ordinary seal, was in truth a remarkable sight.

A NEW stone to commemorate the burial of New York's last Dutch Governor, Peter Stuyvesant, in a vault under St. Mark's Church has just been placed in the wall on the east side of the church, looking toward Second Avenue. The old stone had become so weatherworn that its inscription for years was almost unintelligible.

United States Senator Elkins of West Virginia was greatly Interested in the Washington dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday in which it was told how the beet sugar Congressmen of Minnesota had triumphed in the primaries on Sept. 16. He seemed to think that he and his Senatorial associates who fought Cuban reciprocity had a certain share in the victory which Mr. Tawney and his friends in Minnesota had won.

LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Of actual news this week there has been a great dearth, the newspapers being reduced to giving prominence to comparatively trivial matters, which at other times would attract little notice.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Secretary Moody to-day sent the following cablegram to Commander H.C. McLean:

MR. WU A PRISONER. Wu Ting-Fang, the Chinese Minister, outwitted several newspaper reporters who lay in wait for him at the Fifth Avenue Hotel on the evening of Sept. 3. On Labor Day Mr. Wu had addressed a meeting at Binghamton, N.Y.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 20. -- The Denver Post to-night prints the following: "The Post is in a position to state positively that plans have been consummated for the greatest railroad merger in the history of the United States. George J. Gould, in alliance with the Rockefellers and dependent interests, is organizing what will be known as the Transcontinental Securities Company.
THE exquisite, quiet taste of the Lady of the White House is reflected in the new porcelain service which Mrs. Roosevelt has selected for the use of the family of the Chief Executive of the Nation.

While trying to arrest three men who were acting disorderly at Fifty-fourth Street and First Avenue last night Policeman Rodgers of the East Fifty-first Street Station was knocked down and beaten. More than 2,000 persons assembled at the scene or the assault, and the taking of one prisoner to the station required the united efforts of six policemen.

MONSIEUR J.A.A.J. JUSSERAND, the newly selected Ambassador to represent France in Washington, is a man of remarkable attainments. He belongs to the class of broad-minded French politicians who rest from their professional duties by cultivating their intellect, says The Boston Transcript.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 15. -- As Spanish gold and silver is constantly changing in value, and by law all coins bearing the likeness of Queen Isabella, issued in certain years, were reduced in value, there has come to be a general feeling that Cuba should have a certain monetary standard which should not be subject to fluctuations.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 20. -- The unusually successful celebration attending President Roosevelt's visit here came very near being marred to-night with a panic that would have caused a countless loss of life.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- Herr Bochumer, Secretary of the Steel Union, writes commenting on the unusual demand for German steel rails on the part of American railroads. This demand has been quite large for the last six months.

Much interest was taken in the trading in the outside market during the last week. There were a number of important advances in prices, and in some sections of the market the trading was on a very large scale. Early in the week the market was unfavorably affected by the same conditions which checked speculation in the Stock Exchange market, the principal unfavorable influence being the high rates prevailing for call loans.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- A blood-stained dagger, several articles of feminine apparel marked with the name or initial of Mrs. Anna Pulitzer, and nearly 100 letters addressed to William Hooper Young were found in a trunk which arrived at the Polk Street offices of the Wells-Fargo Express Company early this morning.

THE "liquid lens" has not come to America as yet, but from all accounts it is revolutionizing photography abroad, making possible achievements in rapid work that hitherto have been thought to be out of the question. In fact, the new development in photographic art is being hailed as no less a wonder than the Rontgen rays.

The fiscal year of two of the important lines in the soft-coal trade ends with June 30, and their reports have just been issued. There is nothing more interesting at this time than the coal business, and the soft coalers are doing an increased business by reason of the idleness in the anthracite regions.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- The golf ball controversy has reached Berlin, and is now quite a burning diplomatic question. The British Ambassador, Sir Frank C. Lascelles, started it last week by bringing from England some specimens of American balls, and he illustrated their quality by beating the Danish Minister, C.R.E. Von Vind, in a match, whereas Von Vind usually had the better of Lascelles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- With the return to town of the much-scattered Diplomatic Corps the capital will mark many changes in the personnel of this contingent which adds so greatly to the picturesque interest or each social season. Thirty-six foreign powers now maintain diplomatic relations with the United States, each of them with an embassy or legation at Washington.

WHEN Mayor Low was at Great Barrington last Autumn, resting from the fatigue of a strenuous political life, he enjoyed several drives about the Berkshire country. On one of these he observed, a milestone indicating the distance to Stockbridge as four miles, when he knew they were within a much shorter radius of that town.

WITH the steamship lines running into New York the past fortnight has been a record breaker, not only because half a dozen liners have managed to better their own or some other liner's record, but also because the rush of home-ward-bound Americans has been greater than any previous September.

A WOMAN residing in Montclair, N. J., has received the following communication from King Edward VII. regarding a seal, said to be one of the seven official seals of Great Britain, which has been missing from the British Museum for seventy years.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 23. -- The Australian public has been shocked at the treatment to which returning contingents from South Africa have been subjected, especially with regard to the troopship Drayton Grange. This vessel was most shamefully overcrowded upon leaving South Africa.

The Treasury Department having called for statements of the National banks as to their condition at the close of business Sept. 15, but a few days after the call for reports of the State banks or deposit and discounts had been made by the State Superintendent of Banking, an excellent opportunity of comparing the growth of the Manhattan institutions during the Summer months is afforded.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 20. -- The exceptionally fine weather that has prevailed for the last two weeks has kept many here who otherwise would have gone to Newport or Lenox. Thus far, it has been a rare and delightful September, and there has been little diminution in the cottage element and in the colony of hotel people.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am induced to send you an observation of some interest to all Americans, which was made by an intelligent and impartial observer of our National political contests during the last decade. The man who noticed the fact of which I shall speak was an Englishman of distinction.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 20. -- Nine collieries and washeries were started during the week, and all are successfully operating. Next week, it is stated by the operators, more will be in operation. There has been a general increase at all the places and the operators are very well satisfied with the outlook.

Brushing such as is seldom witnessed outside of a race track took place on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning when the famous rival pacers, Rotha J., 2:12 1/2, and Quadriga, 2:08 3/4, driven by their millionaire owners, James Murphy of Chicago and Nathan Straus, met in a contest for the honors of the road.

Although the threatening weather resulted in a very small attendance at the Vailsburg cycle track, Newark, yesterday, all of the events except the motor cycle race were decided before the rain began to fall. In the five-mile motor-paced heat race Joseph Nelson made new records for the intermediate miles.

In the very sensible appeal for submission to the people of the plan to utilize the canals of the State. Mr. HEBERT, Chairman of the Canal Association of Greater New York, quotes some apposite remarks by Mr. DEPEW, made in 1891.

The question of the Pennsylvania tunnel franchise was again brought up at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union, and came perilously near touching on the subject of party politics, which the central body is always supposed to avoid. Discussion on the question was shut off in time to prevent a political dispute.

The celebration of the thirty-second anni- versary of the occupation of Rome and the unification of Italy, which began Saturday, was continued yesterday at Brommer's Union Park, One Hundred and Thirty-third Street and Willis Avenue, where a monster picnic was held. Italian societies from Brooklyn, Queens, and Richmond attended in large bodies, all wearing gaudy uniforms and carrying guns and swords.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to make a practical suggestion whereby the efficacy of our Humane Society can be greatly increased -- a work which, as we understand it, is now seriously hampered for want of funds. Why cannot the ground floor of that spacious building (Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street) be turned into offices, and the large rental accruing be made over into the Treasury of the society?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Apropos of President Roosevelt's speeches on the trust question. Senator Hernando D. Money of Mississippi, at Democratic Congressional headquarters, said to-day:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The valuations for taxes in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx for 1901 were as follows: Real estate, $2,428,997,016; personalty, $440,468,558. The rate was .0231733, which gave a total tax on real estate of $56,287,877 and on personalty of $10,167,109, amounting together to $66,456,986.

With the approach of cool weather the bowlers awaken to activity, and already the indications are that the coming season in Greater New York will be a record breaker in the history of the sport. The first of the local bowling tournaments to begin the season of 1902-3 is the Fifth Avenue Palace tournament of Brooklyn, whose first games will be rolled to-night on the Fifth Avenue Palace alleys.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- Secretary of the Treasury Shaw admitted that the abolition of the Sub-Treasuries had been under consideration for some time. He said, however, that what recommendations he had to make would be included in his report to Congress.

It was only to be expected that the extinction of the surplus reserve account of the Clearing House banks -- as shown by Saturday's statement -- should have been followed by a vigorous selling movement, partly for the long account, but more largely by the cynics and pessimists in the Street, who are ever ready to magnify into a mountain of calamity what actually is a superficial and transitory disturbance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The coal famine has tied up the Washington Monument. There is not enough coal to feed the boilers, and the elevator had to stop running. Hence tourists visiting this city will have to lose one of the standard sights of Washington until the deficiency is made up. Soft coal will probably have to be used.

ROME, Sept. 21. -- The consecration today of Mgr. Guidi, Apostolic Delegate in the Philippines, as Archbishop, which took place in the Church of Santa Maria in Aquiro, assumed considerable importance, as it was conducted by Cardinal Rampolla, who, after the Pope, is the highest political personage of the Vatican.

DETROIT, Sept. 21. -- For the second time in its history the City of the Straits is entertaining the Chief Executive of the Nation. President Theodore Roosevelt arrived in the city at 8 o'clock this morning over the Michigan Central Railroad. He found Detroit awaiting his arrival in gala attire. Flags were flying from every staff in the down-town section, and the city was bright with bunting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- President Roosevelt's declaration against a revision of the tariff and his argument that tariff tinkering is not the way to cure the trust evil accords with what Washington people have expected of him. There is no doubt that Washington has been much mystified by the positive assertions made in New York that the President was going to talk in favor of tariff revision.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- "Let the new light shine a while." Standing on the Chicago Union Station platform, bronzed of face and white haired, David B. Henderson, Speaker of the National House of Representatives, gave utterance to these words to-day. His tone was firm. There was nothing of bitterness or resentment in it.

SARATOGA, Sept. 21. -- Senator Depew this evening sat around on the veranda of his hotel, and entertained a group of politicians with reminiscences of his European trip and new stories which he picked up on his travels. One of his stories was about Devery, and would indicate that the fame of the newly elected, Tammanyrejected leader of the Ninth District has become international.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- George R. Sheldon, the organization's candidate for Lieutenant Governor, had an exciting interview to-night with Lieut. Gov. Woodruff. Mr. Sheldon has been very much annoyed since his arrival here about the stories in circulation about his trust connections.

DERBY, Conn., Sept. 21. -- The police have in custody here a man who answers the description of Hooper Young of New York, who is wanted in that city for the murder of Mrs. Annie Pulitzer. The man vigorously resisted arrest, and when brough to Headquarters, refused to give his name or account for his presence in this vicinity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- The bank deposits of the people of the United States aggregate $8,300,000,000, an average of $108 per capita. Ten years ago they aggregated $4,232,700,000, or just half the amount of to-day, and twenty years ago they were $2,600,000,000, or a little more than onequarter of those of to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- An official report made to the United States Geological Survey gives statistics of acidents, fatal and otherwise, which occurred in the process of mining coal in eighteen States Land Territories during 1901. In these eighteen States and Territories the total number of lives lost in 1901 was 1,467, and the total number of men injured was 3,043.

On a specific charge of stealing books valued at $15.77 on Aug. 18 last from his employers, Brentano's, the Union Square book house, but accused also of having taken nearly $2,000 worth of goods in the same manner during the past seven months. Fred Evans, a well-appearing young man, residing at 101 West Eighty-sixth Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Flammer in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday.
PANAMA, Sept. 21. -- So far as can be learned here, there has been no friction whatever between soldiers of the Colombian Government and the American bluejackets who are guarding the railroad line.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The issue of the day is the economic question. It is convulsing all nations. Military repression, dynastic traditions, and ecclesiastical authority fail to put down this world-wide economic agitation. It is, in fact, the latter-day gospel of humanity, the demand of the world's wage slaves, (men, women, girls, boys, and child wage-slaves alike,) the universal human proletariat for the right of existence.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Interest here to-day centred in the question as to whether Lieut. Gov. Woodruff was a candidate for renomination. The Lieutenant Governor arrived to-day. He was besieged for information as to his attitude and he talked freely, but what he said did not bring out his intentions in a positive light.

A case of shoes was thrown off a moving freight train on the New York Central at Inwood several days ago, and Detectives Johnston and Tierney of the King's Bridge Station waited and watched for further developments. Yesterday two men filled suit cases with shoes from the case. The detectives held them up at the point of the pistol, but had to fire five times around the head of one man to subdue him.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Partial information was obtained to-night as to the platform which will be presented to the convention. The following is a fair synopsis of the document:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Gov. Odell sent word here to-night that he positively would not come to Saratoga during the convention. It had been planned that he should come Wednesday, the last day of the convention, so that he might be the personal recipient of the nomination. He says in positive terms to-night that he believes it would be undignified for the Governor of New York to attend the convention for any purpose.

Apropos of the recent discussion in THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the American playwright and his art, David Belasco emphatically declares that the playwright of this country has a great future, a part of which is behind him.

Dr. Thomas L. Dedrick of Washington N.J., who had disagreements with Lieut. Peary, the arctic explorer, and left the latter's expedition on Aug. 27, 1901, arrived in New York yesterday morning after an absence of four years in the Far North. Concerning the criticisms of his actions in the arctic regions he was inclined to be reticent.

Archibald Stalker, whose identity is almost hidden by his full name, the man being much better known by the familiar abbreviation of "Archie," will be burled in Evergreens Cemetery at 2 o'clocK this afternoon. The men who will attend the funeral will be in a great measure those in one way or another connected with the theatrical business, though the more successful actors were not Stalker's intimates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Suppose the coal operators, for reasons sufficient unto themselves and God, decide to close the anthracite mines for four years, for forty years, or forever, instead of four months, have the people no alternative except to get off the face of the earth? The situation is simply ridiculous, and it would be "to laugh," were it not rapidly verging on the tragic.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 21. -- The Standard Oil Company has begun the construction of its million-dollar pipe line in Kentucky, and in a few months the oil producers of this State will be able to market their product at a big advance over the price at which they are selling. The main line will be a six-inch pipe, and will start from Parkersburg, West Va.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Sept. 21. -- The Iowa Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church was aroused yesterday by the unexpected presentation of the case of the Rev. P.J. Henness, one of its members, now living in South Dakota. Mr. Henness left his wife during the last year and refused to state his reason.

ALBANY, Sept. 21. -- It is believed here that James H. Palmer was arrested for the theft of Major Bird's suit case in the Delaware and Hudson Railroad station at Saratoga Aug. 19 last. Major Bird was on his way north and left his car to go into the station restaurant. As the train was moving out he returned to his seat to find his suit case gone.

The ambition of the Dominion of Canada to become a great maritime power and to enter into serious rivalry with the Morgan syndicate for the control of the steam marine of the North Atlantic has perhaps had a larger amount of serious attention than that to which it is entitled.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 21. -- The Rev. Dr. Henry C. McCook, one of the foremost clergymen of the Presbyterian Church, resigned as pastor of the Tabernacle Presbyterian Church to-day, after a service of thirty-three years. Dr. McCook, whose health has been Impaired for the last three years, was too ill to announce personally his resignation to the congregation.
OCEAN GROVE, Sept. 21. -- The religious season at Ocean Grove closed to-day, when four meetings were held. In the evening a general love feast was held in the Auditorium, and thousands participated.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Sept. 21. -- But for the heroism and timely assistance of two young women William J. Hawkins, twenty-nine years old, of 427 Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, and Harry D. Burdett, thirty-five years old, also of Brooklyn, probably would have been drowned here this morning.

J.G.N. Whittaker's ninety-two-ton schooner Iroquois won the ocean race of the Atlantic Yacht Club from Sea Gate to the Northeast Lightship, off Cape May, and return. She defeated the 126-ton Corohet, the 140-ton Endymion, and the 235-ton Thistle on corrected time, and beat all the yachts except the Coronet on elapsed time.

In view of the impending Republican and Democratic State Conventions, Henry B. Hebert, Chairman of the Canal Association of Greater New York, desirous of bringing out an expression of public opinion in favor of a speedy enlargement of the Erie Canal, said yesterday:

In asserting and endeavoring to maintain the contention that since they own the land yielding coal, such land is private property, with which the owner may do as he pleases, and, being private property, it is no concern of the public whether they mine coal or not, the anthracite operators appear to have spoken without taking advice, or else they have been badly advised.
NEWPORT, Sept. 22 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Roger Morgan, who returned Saturday from an extended tour in Europe, have arrived here.
LONDON, Sept. 22.-- Money was wanted in the market to-day for the new Treasury bills. Discounts were strengthened by the position of the New York banks.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The Roumanian Bulletin, published in London with the object, as it is announced, of " bringing to the knowledge of the civilized world authentic facts relating to Roumanian persecution of the Jews," contains a number of letters from eminent persons addressed to the editor.

Sunburned by a Summer spent in boating on the Thames near Maidenhead, Kyrle Bellew arrived here yesterday on the Minnehaha, preparatory to the opening of his season Sept. 29 in Newark, with " A Gentleman of France."

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 22 -- To-morrow afternoon at 4 o'clock, at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. H.B. Stokes at Orienta Point, Mamaroneck, a pretty wedding is scheduled to take place, the bride being Miss Florence Lockwood Stokes, the youngest daughter of the household, and the groom Frederick Ambrose Clark.

MANILA, Sept. 22 -- Up to Sunday the force commanded by Capt. John J. Pershing of the Fifteenth Infantry, operating against the Moros in the Island of Mindanao, had met with slight resistance and had captured seven forts, killed twenty-five and wounded twenty Moros. There were no American casualties.

" Memory," Lord Rosebery once remarked, " is that familiar and comfortable feeling that steals over one when one hears the good things of one's friends." It was with the kindliest of suggestions that the saying came to mind last night at Daly's Theatre in hearing the opening performance of the new musical comedy, " The Country Girl."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor said to-day that the striking miners in the Pennsylvania coal fields were prepared to hold out for months. He said the miners were disposed to make concessions, but the operators had refused all overtures from them, and that the men now "are not going to yield."

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for a client the plot of nine lots on the south side of One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, 272 feet east of St. Ann's Avenue, and the plot of six lots on the north side of One Hundred and Fortieth Street, 500 feet east of St. Ann's Avenue. These lots are part of the tract purchased about five years ago by Henry Morgenthau from the late Collis P. Huntingdon.

HAMILTON, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Dedham outplayed Myopia at nearly every point this afternoon in the final game of the polo cup series, winning by the score of 11 3/4 to 6 goals. Neither team was handicapped. The match was brought to an abrupt close in the third period, when R.M. Appleton of the Myopias was run into by Hamlin of Dedham and knocked from his pony.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 22 -- The scandal arising from the revival of the quarrel between King Leopold and his daughter, the Princess Stephanie (Countess Lonyay) is agitating all classes. Popular sympathy on all sides is expressed for the Princess, who, although deeply affected by the incident, makes no complaint.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Lemuel Ely Quigg, who is to be temporary Chairman of the convention, arrived to-day and had his photograph taken seventeen times by National Committeeman Gibbs and others when he was posing off guard.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- A number of new laws in regard to Finland, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times, are about to be drawn up in the capital and sent to Helsingfors.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Secretary of the Treasury Leslie M. Shaw delivered an address at North Side Turner Hall to-night in the interest of Congressman H.S. Boutell. The Secretary, who took for his subject "Commerce," said in part:

The successes of the Chicago turfman, J. A. Drake, with the race horses that he brought to New York under the care of Trainer Enoch Wishard, have met a sudden check, as an illness of a somewhat mysterious character has attacked the horses of the stable, and it was announced yesterday that in all probability the Drake establishment would have to take a rest.

The bidding up and claiming of selling-class horses made an enlivening side issue to the racing at the Gravesend track yesterday, and furnished a measure of solace to the general public for the failure of a most unusual proportion of the popular favorites.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 -- The banquet this evening tendered the President at the Light Guard Armory by the Spanish war veterans was the culmination of an extremely busy day for the President. At 11 o'clock he drove to Light Guard Armory and attended the opening session of the third annual reunion of Spanish war veterans. He was given a tumultuous welcome by the soldiers, and his speech was enthusiastically received.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The Associated Press is in a position to announce that diplomatic relations between Great Britain and Venezuela are on the verge of being severed.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 22 For Governor -- BENJAMIN B. ODELL. Jr., of Orange County.

If the only effective resistance which the United Mine Workers can offer to the resumption of mining in hitherto idle pits and the increase of shipments over roads which have carried no coal for months is expressed in violence and incendiarism, the continuance of the strike is a crime against every interest involved.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Congressman Griggs, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, sees in President Roosevelt's speeches while on his Western tour precisely what agrees, according to the Chairman's ideas, with Democratic doctrine.

The annual report of the Wabash Railroad Company for the year ended June 30 last was made public yesterday. The report says that the expectations of a continuation of prosperity during 1901-02, set forth in the annual report of 1901, were more than realized, each month showing an unbroken record of increases.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Edmund Haviland Burke, M.P.; Michael Reddy, M.P., (Chairman of the Birr, King's County, Rural District Council;) William Lowry, (Chairman of the Birr Board of Guardians,) and Michael Hogan have been arraigned under the Crimes act at Birr, charged with intimidating shopkeepers into joining the United Irish League.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Delegations from all sections of the State continued to arrive here to-day on every train, and Saratoga has now assumed something like its appearance during the Summer season. The United States Hotel is crowded. The Grand Union and the smaller hotels are comfortably filled.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Forced to fight by the methods of the "cigar trust," those business interests which it has affected met to-day and decided to begin a tobacco war in this city. A thorough combination was formed and the struggle will begin in every shop, factory, and store not in the control of the trust.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Trading was active in the market to-day, especially in Philadelphia Electric, Electric Company of America, and Cambria Steel. The latter was bought and advanced to 29 by a house which represents Pennsylvania Railroad interests. Manipulation in Philadelphia Electric and Electric Company of America was apparent, two strong bull pools operating in both stocks.
An athletic track for the use of the public is practically assured, as John E. Eustis, Park Commissioner of the Bronx, is favorably disposed toward the project of having one in Macomb's Dam Park.

Disguised as a tramp and so besotted with whisky that he apparently could not tell where he had been since he left New York, William Hooper Young was captured night before last in Derby, Conn. He has admitted his identity, and will be brought to this city early to-day. When he had consented reluctantly to acknowledge that he was the man the police sought, he answered a question to his guilt with the words:

William S. Devery outgeneraled his Democratic opponents in the Ninth District last evening. The call issued by Tammany Hall for the convention to elect delegates from the district to the Saratoga Convention directed that it be held at 293-295 Eighth Avenue, the headquarters of the Horatio Seymour Club, the Frank J. Goodwin organization.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was quiet and prices were irregular. Very few stocks showed totals that approached those recorded on the most active days of last week, and there were no new accessories to the rank of the active stocks. Following the course of the Stock Exchange market, curb stocks showed generally a reactionary tendency, but in a very few cases only were the losses more than fractional.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Anthracite coal sold at $16 a ton here to-day, and wood was put up $1 a cord. It is said that hundreds of poor colored women who do washing for their livelihood have been forced to abandon that pursuit because they could not get coal at a price they could pay.
SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 22 -- Sheriff Schadt of Lackawanna County to-night at 7:30 o'clock telegraphed Gov. Stone to send troops to his assistance.

The provisional estimates of the heads of the municipal departments are being filed in the Mayor's office ready for action by the Board of Estimate. Several of the departmental chiefs want large increases in appropriations for 1903, but Mayor Low and Controller Grout have announced that no large increases will be allowed.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 22 -- There is no great demand for money in Boston. The feature lately has been the large New York borrowing here. Boston banks dealing with New York have all been large lenders at 6 per cent, for six months. On call, money rules from 6 to 7 per cent. Time money is nominally 6 per cent, for all rates, with exceptions on both sides of this figure.

-- We are grieved to find in that highly valued visitor of ours, The New York Medical Journal, the statement that "one might as well argue with the ostrich on the folly of burying his head in the sand, to escape observation as with a Christian. Scientist on the existence of those particulars whereby alone we become cognizant of the existence of universals at all."

Thomas J. Sharkey, the private detective accused of having caused the death of Nicholas Fish, the banker, during an altercation at the Heinebund Cafe, 265 West Thirty-fourth Street, on Sept. 15, was held yesterday for the Grand Jury by Coroner Jackson in $10,000 bail. He was taken back to the Tombs.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- It is clear, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, that the intervention of the United States in regard to the Roumanian Jews has given diplomacy something to do.

Mayor Low gave out for publication yesterday three letters received from District Attorney Jerome, Police Commissioner Partridge, and President Deuel of the Board of City Magistrates, regarding the recent report on the disturbances connected with the burial of Rabbi Joseph.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 -- At the banquet of the Spanish War Veterans to-night President Roosevelt, in opening his address, thanked the people of Detroit for the reception given him to-day and throughout his two days' visit. The President then said:

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 22 -- The third encampment of the Spanish-American War Veterans' Association convened in the Senate Chamber of the State House at 10:30 A.M. to-day, Gov. Durbin delivering a short speech of welcome.

A meeting of the creditors of Meyer Jonasson Co., manufacturers of cloaks and suits at Broadway and Twelfth Street, was held yesterday afternoon at the Broadway Central Hotel, which was attended by a majority of the 300 creditors of the firm.

It was quite clear beforehand that Secretary HAY'S manly and generous protest against the behavior of Roumania would receive a sympathetic reception in England. We might have expected that Great Britain would follow it up with one of her own, as we are informed that she has done.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Navy Department is in receipt of the following cablegram from Commander McLean of the cruiser Cincinnati, dated Colon, Sept. 20:
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Unfavorable weather was the principal cause of an upturn in prices to-day on the Board of Trade. September wheat closed 4 7/8 cents higher and December 1/2@ 5/8 cent up. September corn at the close was 3 cents higher, September oats 1/4 cent higher, and January provisions from 5 to 7 1/2 cents higher.

In his letter to Gov. ODELL, which we publish this morning, Mr. WILLIAM F. KING calls emphatic attention to one point of advantage in the development of the canals that is of the utmost importance. This is the effect of that development on the prosperity of the entire State and especially on that of the interior counties.

The course of yesterday's stock market differed much from ordinary Wall Street forecasts. There had been apprehension of extreme weakness; but actual net results were in no sense serious. Again high rates for money ruled, the quotation for funds on call soaring to 20 per cent., with a closing figure of 12, most of the day's business being transacted, however, between 7 and 12 per cent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- New York exchange was quoted at 10c premium to-day. Time and call loans, 5@5 1/2 per cent. Local stocks were quiet, and reflected the Eastern weakness. Swift Co. sold up to 165 1/2, where it met selling pressure and was forced back to 162 1/2. There was a scattered trade in American Can, Shipbuilding, and a few others.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- John J. Nicholas, dry goods dealer in this city, filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy this afternoon, with debts given at $21,175.12 and assets $16,633.40. Tefft, Weller Co. of New York are creditors for $8,949.72. There are about a dozen other New York creditors for amounts ranging from $50 to $200.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- There was some liquidation in the local market today, but the support accorded the various issues was such that declines were, as a rule, limited to small fractions. There were a few exceptions to this very general rule. Pennsylvania declined 1 1/8, and Reading 15-16, both in sympathy with New York, as selling orders in the two stocks were quite persistent from that city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, is reported to have said privately that the coal strikers are in a position to keep up the strike for six months or longer.
