The demand for soft coal, owing to the scarcity of anthracite, has led to the importation of some French coal of a bituminous grade. It is not considered of as good a quality as the Pennsylvania soft coal and was offered yesterday by the agent of a company at $4.45 a ton, while the Pennsylvania soft coal was sold at $7.30 a ton on board, an increase on Friday's prices.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Mr. Hay's note to the powers several restrictions imposed on Roumanian Jews were enumerated, but he ignored the most outrageous crime committed by a Government against a whole class of people forming loyal subjects to the throne and Government, namely, the law of 1894, forbidding education to the Jews.

Isabella Rose, born Bergen and known on the stage as Belle Rose, was killed yesterday with a pistol at the Royatt apartment house, 330 West Thirty-third Street, by her husband, Henry C. Rose, well known in the theatrical world, who has been stage manager at the Garrick for Charles Frohman's presentation of "There's Many a Slip."

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a theory now so prevalent in our country that it may be called the American theory. It is, The Lord has use for us. The inference always drawn by the people who accept this theory is that because the Lord has use for us we are nearly all that we should be.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The tobacco war has been ended by the amalgamation of, the American and British interests. An official statement covering the details and subscribed by the officers of both concerns was given out this afternoon.

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- Comte Boni de Castellane, who, with the Comtesse Boni de Castellane, is still at Biarritz, has just purchased the historic Chateau de Grignan from the family of Adhemar de Montell.

SINCE the inauguration of the anthracite coal strike the production and the transportation of coke have taken a, decided boom. At many times, and especially of late, It has been impossible for the railroads to handle even the supply which was ready to be shipped.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Except in corn, trade on the Board of Trade to-day was light and the tendency was lower. The demand from shorts in September wheat was again a feature, and that option closed 3/4 c higher, while December was 1/4 @ 3/8 c lower. December corn closed 1 cent lower.

While the French liner La Savoie was trying to make her dock yesterday she bumped into a New York Central lighter lying near by and damaged it considerably. Then the liner ran into her pier and tore away much woodwork from its end, but from neither collision did La Savoie suffer any damage herself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter in your issue of yesterday on "Limiting Apprentices" is forceful. No unions restrict the creation of lawyers, doctors, artists, , or cooks and coachmen, , but the right to be a mechanic seems to be jealously guarded by the arbitrary rules of the unions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of an old Toronto boy in last Sunday's issue is most interesting, and perhaps you will allow one over fifty-seven years in Canadian and United States trading to attempt reply, adding other ideas.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 27. -- The annual fair of the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society closed to-day. The racing was postponed from day to day, and to-day Thursday's programme was run. The other races were declared off. Early in the morning there was a horse show in the field. The track was very heavy.
FOR the first time millionaire art collectors are to have an opportunity of buying treasures which were buried by the same eruption of Vesuvius that destroyed Pompeii.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The contracts for carrying the mails by pneumatic tube service in Boston, New York Philadelphia, Chicago, and St. Louis were awarded today by Acting Postmaster General Shallenberger. The service in each of the cities will begin as soon as the system is constructed.
LONDON, Sept. 27. -- An American woman who has a son at Oxford University has stirred up a hornet's nest by writing to The London Times complaining of the filth and discomfort of his college rooms.

The neighborhood of Park Avenue and seventieth Street was startled shortly before 1 o'clock yesterday morning by an explosion, which shattered the windows of several houses and frightened the patients in the Presbyterian Hospital, which is not far away. In the Normal College a class of students had been rehearsing for an entertainment.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Tuxedo has passed a very successful week. The horse show at the week's end proved very successful, especially on Saturday. During the week there were many social functions, dinners, luncheons, and teas.

Within a few days it is probable that Commissioner Woodbury will be told of "tribute" that his ash cart drivers are said to be levying on the poor of the east side. A committee of the Janitors Society of New York will call on the Commissioner and ask him to give his aid in making radical changes in the system of his department in collecting garbage on the lower east side of the city.

BACK of a simple announcement of an oil strike that was sent out in the press dispatches a few days ago is a romantic story of unusual interest. Few people who read the telegrams stating that the Jager OH Company had made a big strike of petroleum on its lands near Spring Valley knew the real conditions that brought about the rich find.
I. IT WAS Commemoration week at Oxford; the old town was full to overflowing, brilliant with groups of strangers flitting hither and yon, sightseeing and junketing from morn till eve.

HICKORY, N.C., Sept. 27. -- There is a strong possibility that "the Old North State" may this Fall be the pivotal area of the Congressional election. Despite the disfranchisement of a large number of negro voters by the insertion of the "grandfather clause" in the State Constitution, this State, always stalwartly Democratic, is this year manifestly in doubt.

CARLISLE, Penn., Sept. 27. -- The Carlisle Indian football team met the Pennsylvania College eleven of Gettysburg here to-day and won by a score of 25 to 0 in two twenty-minute halves. Last year Gettysburg defeated the weak Indians' eleven.

There was considerable surprise yesterday when it was announced and confirmed at the office of Parsons, Shepard Ogden that the partnership was to be dissolved, the three members to establish offices of their own.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Though recognizing in the request of the Cuban Government for the withdrawal of the remaining American troops a very natural desire to remove all traces of foreign occupation, the indications are that the authorities here will order the withdrawal only upon the completion of the permanent treaty contemplated in the Platt amendment.

Col. Bates of the Seventy-first Regiment has received the resignation of Lieut. Charles H. Briner of Company K, because of the latter's intention to hake his home in Philadelphia. He joined the regiment as a private in Company K in February, 1897, and during the war with Spain served with the volunteer regiment as a Corporal and Sergeant.

SOON after Philopoemen conquered Machanidas, the tyrant of Sparta, and thus won freedom for the Achaean League, an extraordinary honor was paid to him at a public festival. "The Persians," a dithyrambic song by the Milesian poet Timotheus, was being recited by Pylades, and, as soon as he uttered the words:

Caught in the Act. TOM, the house boy, had stolen a pair of his young master's shoes. The driver, who happened to be Tom's father, was called upon to give the boy a whipping. With a great show of wrath the old man had given him several blows, when the master directed him to desist and walked away.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 27. -- Vice Chancellor Pitney, when seen at his home here to-day, said that at a conference of Judges yesterday, at which he was not present, he understood that it was agreed to remove the ban from New York lawyers. He had, however, received no official communication to that effect.

INTO the Wigwam of the Sachems of the Tammany Society there walked last week a man who proclaimed himself "boss of Tammany Hall." He announced that the reign of Richard Croker was over. Charles F. Murphy, known to the politcians as "Silent Charley," then went to the desk made famous by John Kelly an Richard Croker.

NEW YORKERS who have the time and inclination to devote a few moments to the history of their city have had the truth clearly forced upon them that the present year has been notable for the obliteration of landmarks. A wave of destruction has swept over the country. Many others are doomed, while a few, like the Jumel house and the Hall of Records, are in a doubtful position.

LENOX, Sept. 27. -- The past week has been one of much enjoyment, especially among the younger set. So many people who came on for the Horse Show have remained to enjoy the beautiful Autumn weather that the town presents the liveliest appearance of any time this season.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The campaigns for and against the Education bill continue to be pushed. The country is split into bitterly opposing camps, which flood the papers with speeches and letters as virulent and verbose as ever delivered or written in connection with the South African war.

A TREE adrift in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean is the rare sight reported by Capt. Freeman of the British steamer Sidra, which recently, says the Baltimore American, arrived in port, with a cargo of pig iron from Benisaf, in the Mediterranean. It was early morning, when in 35.19 degrees north and 38.22 degrees west, that an unusual looking object was seen floating ahead of the steamer.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, Mr. Jennings, in your issue of this date, makes use of the following language:

PARIS, Sept. 27. -- Charles M. Schwab is reported as better from Aix, where he has been stopping. His brother-in-law, Dr. Ward, has left on a ten days' tour through Italy, to visit the principal industrial centres of that country.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Congresses continue to be held on various subjects, the two most interesting such meetings this week being that of the Congregationalists at Glasgow and that of the Roman Catholics at Newport, Monmouthshire.
FORT RILEY, Kan., Sept. 27. -- To-day's warfare between the armies of the Blues and the Browns consisted of preparing to fight without fighting.

Census Bulletin No. 242, on "Patents in Relation to Manufactures," is a document which has more of interest for the superficial reader than value for the critical one. By the grouping of comparative statistics it is made to appear quite plausibly that there is "an approximate parallelism between inventive activity and manufacturing growth."

LIVING pictures of Colorado are to be exhibited throughout the United States by medium of a special trail. There will also be a number of paintings on the outside panels of the cars illustrating the principal cities, scenery, and picturesque objects of this State, says The Denver Post.

A ROTUND German grocer who conducts a store in the suburbs of Brooklyn recently incurred the enmity of the boys in that vicinity. How the feud started no one seems to know, but it certainly engendered plenty of hard feeling. At first the boys avenged their supposed wrongs by jeers and occasional missiles.

IN AN article in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday it was stated that a "new war scare" had developed in the United Kingdom, owing to the realization that all the cables across the Atlantic Ocean which Great Britain can use pass in shoal water on the Newfoundland coast, and that it would be his headquarters.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- I have just returned from, a 10,000-mile ride through the West, and am a little sore yet from the breaking down of old tissue that had narrowed my views of that great country west of the Mississippi River.

Bear fighting as a popular amusement was revived at the Central Park menagerie yesterday, when nearly a thousand men, women, and children saw Garibaldi, a cinnamon bear, weighing 450 pounds, driven into the cage of Rocky, a grizzly of double his weight, by keepers who knew that the meeting would apt to result in a terrific fight.

THE stereotyped remark about some of our modern machinery having almost human intelligence gains new force as the result of the invention of a Louisville man. Mr. A.C. Schuman of 560 Second Street, that city, has been granted patents on an adding machine that computes all four sums in arithmetic -- addition, subtraction, division, and multiplication, according to the Louisville Courier-Journal.

The Finland, one of the two largest ships ever built in the United States, arrived in New York yesterday from the yards of the William Cramp Sons' Ship and Engine Building Company, Philadelphia, and will be put into the New York Antwerp service of the Red Star Steamship Line. Her first trip will be made next month, sailing from this port on Oct. 4.

IT IS officially announced that the trains on the Sixth and Ninth Avenue elevated roads will be run by electricity on and after Oct. 15. Great gangs of men are now at work along the entire length of both roads perfecting the apparatus. Another set of workmen is preparing the rolling stock for the change.

Painters who are returning from Europe and also know M. Raffaelli are bringing over boxes full of his invention, the oil-paint stick with which he thinks to create a revolution in the method of painting in oils. It consists of a short pencil about as long as a color crayon, but thicker, which has a thin skin over the paint to keep it in shape.

Prices were generally higher in the outside market yesterday, and transactions were relatively larger than on Thursday or Friday. American Writing Paper and a few other issues were traded in quite actively at advancing prices. In some stocks the gains recorded resulted from the purchase of very small amounts.

Brooklynites who travel daily to and from their work in Manhattan by the socalled "midnight trains" of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad on the Bridge are indignant over a sudden change in the schedule of the trains that has been made by the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company and which went into effect early Thursday morning.

The new hundred-thousand-dollar building of the East Side Young Men's Christian Association will be opened to-morrow night. The new structure occupies nearly seventy-five feet front at 158 to 162 East Eighty-sixth Street, while it extends clear through to Eighty-seventh Street. The building fronting on the latter street was opened in 1897.

One Hundred and Fourth Street, north side, 450 feet cast of First Avenue, for a one-story brick stable and offices, 25 by 100, and four one-story frame sheds, 135.4 by 16 and 105.4 by 19; Kane Wright of 412 East One Hundred and Fifth Street, owners; J.H. Amsler of 895 Washington Avenue, architect; cost, $20,000.

AFTER much careful study and recent personal examination of the earth in which it was found, several of the leading geologists and archaeologists of the United States have decided that the discovery of the so-called "Lansing skull" is an occurrence which adds considerably to the sum of established scientific data.
The ladies of the W.C.T.U. have filed their protest against the use of the above poster by the United Wine and Trading Company, proprietors of PEARL WEDDING RYE WHISKEY.

THE curious contrasts in costumes seen on the street, in the modish restaurants at the luncheon and dinner hours, at the theatres, and also in the smart shops are natural concomitants of la petite saison, when it is still too warm for many to don with any comfort frocks designed for early Autumm wear, and, on the other hand, too cool for some to be comfortable in the gowns usually worn in September.
BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- Ernst Adolf Meissner, the animal painter, died this week at Munich.

The Rev. Dr. Frank W. Gunsaulus, who has returned to Chicago after a Summer's absence in Europe, is reported as saying that it is not true that he was offered the pastorate of the London City Temple, now held by Dr. Parker. "My work and life are here in Chicago," he said; "I have no intention of deserting my field here."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- In the contests at the ninth annual swimming championship races of the Atlantic Association Amateur Athletic Union, held under the auspices of the National Swimming Association of Philadelphia, at Lafayette, this afternoon, allowance had to be made for the high water and swift current, flowing at about three miles an hour.

That New York City will have two rival baseball clubs at the beginning of next year's playing season is now believed to be not only possible but more than probable. During the last three days whatever doubts those who follow the National game very closely may have had as to the thoroughness of the much-heralded invasion of this city by the American League have been almost entirely dispelled.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 27. -- Further details of the merger of all the railroads on the Peninsula of Yucatan have been received by the Mexican Government. The amalgamated corporation is called the Consolidated Railroad Company of Yucatan. It has a capital stock of $30,000,000, and its general offices are located at Merida.

Listed among the preferred stockholders of the Steel Trust is Helena Frederick, prima donna of the De Angelis Opera Company. It would not be fair to tell just how many shares the lady owns, but they would be sufficient to keep her from going into vaudeville or the poorhouse in case she should lose her voice and have to leave opera.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Appreciation, not mimicry, is the sincerest form of lattery. It may, I think, be assumed that a powerful, well-established and prosperous journal would be naturally altogether on the side of the present economical order, and so averse to admitting into its columns matter, howsoever uninfluential, that seemed in any degree to further the forces of social or economical change.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Can you tell me why the southeast corner of Broadway and Worth Street is allowed to be maintained as a freight yard by truckmen without any regard for the rights of pedestrians, and in violation of all law? I counted no less than 148 cases which obstructed the sidewalk at one time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The newspapers seem to be greatly disturbed over the antics of William S. Devery. I don't see anything so very unusual about Devery's performances. He is a perfectly legitimate product of our beautiful, elastic political system. He acts quite as well, considering his want of training, as do the majority of more "respectable" politicians.

-- Weather could not be much more trying than that which our British cousins have experienced during the past few months, and all of them, the learned not less than the unlearned, have assumed that terrible consequences to health have resulted from the almost complete deprivation of sunshine, the superabundance of rains and fogs, and the untimely cold.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Elliot Danforth and John B. McDonald were among the notable arrivals here to-night. Edward M. Shepard passed through on his way to Lake George, where he has a Summer home. Mr. Shepard's resignation from the firm of Parsons, Shepard Ogden has again started rumors of his candidacy for the Gubernatorial nomination.

A SHORT time ago a movement was perfected in Lewiston, Me., to transform the enormous deposits of peat known as Farwell's Bog, in Lewiston suburbs, into merchantable and desirable fuel. From advices at hand, it looks as if the proposition were no vision or at all impracticable, says The Lewiston (Me.) Evening Journal.

Good running, splendid field contests, and fast bicycle riding were the features yesterday at the athletic games on the Vailsburg track, just outside of Newark, N.J., given under the auspices of the West End Athletic Club.

The Hagenbeck animals all have been landed from the Patricia and placed in the old Twelfth Street Skating Rink in Hoboken, preparatory to being sent to the New York Theatre next week. The press agent yesterday took down his "Jungle Book" and spun his first yarn, illustrating the wonderful memory of the elephant, Mamie.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The most effectual and necessary change now needed in the United States Constitution is to repeal or nullify the fifth clause in Section 9 or Article I., which now prohibits any tax upon exports to foreign countries. That provision now makes the United States the only Nation in the world that has not the power to levy such taxes on exports as it may deem expedient.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 27. -- In an address at the Grant County Fair, at Elbow Lake, late yesterday. President J.J. Hill of the Great Northern Railway and Northern Securities Company said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The three letters published in your paper on Sept. 22 under the headings, "On Trust Conspiracies," "An Anti-Trust People," and "Would Coerce the Coal Operators," which refer to the anthracite coal situation, embody in themselves a thought which should be the principal question for the voters of our country in the next Presidential campaign.

BELFAST, Sept. 4. -- English and Scottish members of the Auctioneers' Institute who are attending the Autumn meetings of the organization in Belfast reached the Ulster capital in considerable numbers this morning. Doubtless most of the visitors from Great Britain arrived here under the impression that their Irish brethren, could teach them very little.

WHAT is planned to be, when completed, the largest public school in the United States, and probably in the world, is being built in the very heart of the east-side district of New York, which is often and sometimes contemptuously referred to as "The Ghetto."

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- The officials of the Foreign Office say that Charlemagne Tower's appointment as Ambassador to Germany is regarded, with, special satisfaction, since an excellent reputation precedes him. Very great regret is expressed at the Foreign Office and in all circles over Mr. White retirement.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The money market and the Stock Exchange both spent most of the time this, week watching New York and wondering what is going to happen there. Much interest was aroused by the statement quoted from THE NEW YORK TIMES that measures for financial reform will be initiated at the next session of Congress, involving the abolition of the Sub-Treasury system.

Capt. Ahearn of Engine Company No. 59 and five men were overcome by smoke shortly after midnight last night in the cellar at 2,517 Eighth Avenue, a five-story tenement house, while fighting a stubborn fire, which had started in a coal bin. The men were cut off in some manner, and had it not been for the arrival of Battalion Chief Short there would probably have been serious results.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27. -- To-morrow in this city a fine bronze statue will be unveiled to the memory of Louis Kossuth, the Hungarian patriot, and thousands of Visitors will witness the ceremonies. Hungarian-Americans are arriving from many parts of the United States.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 27. -- D.M. Ferry retired from the race for the United States Senate this morning. In his announcement he favors the election of Gen. Alger. The leaders among the local politicians, who were supporting Mr. Ferry, have declared for Gen. Alger's election. Mr. Ferry's announcement follows:
WHEN we cold-blooded Anglo-Saxons so for our Summer holiday we go, and that is about all there is to be said about it. But with our friends in France these things are differently managed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is not the recent developed opposition to the new method of taxation, under which the actual value of property is to be taxed, instead of a percentage thereof, directed rather against the manner of ascertaining values than the system itself?

"ED" McSWEENEY, the New Brunswick sailor, who for several years has been periodically astounding habitues of South Street resorts with his wonderful yarns about the things he has seen and experienced on the deep seas, got back from Brazil on Friday, and brought a batch of stories that, according to his pals, have never been and never will be equaled in all the history of the New York water front.
IN ENGLAND, Ireland, Germany, Switzerland, and France old pipes, made of clay, wood, and metal, have frequently been found, and they closely resemble modern pipes.

XV. MR. POET," said the Idiot the other morning as his friend entered the breakfast room, "come over here and sit down by me. I want to propose a scheme by which I think you and I can make our immortal fortunes."

In the "Empire," a resort of questionable character on West Twenty-ninth Street, between Broadway and Sixth Avenue, murder was committed yesterday morning. The alleged murderer is Thomas Tobin, alias Tierney, whose right name is said to be Kelly, an employe of the place. The victim was James B. Craft, a resident of Glen Cove, L.I., where he had a wife and a nineteen-year-old son.

He Prepared for Burglars. I HAD been keeping bachelor's hall while my wife was away," sadly remarked the man whose wife had been in the country. "Of course, it was generally late when I turned in at night, and, as we had been a good deal worried by sneak thieves in my part of the city, I was afraid they might make a raid during my absences.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept 27. -- As a result of a feud between three farmers in Madison Township, "Tom" Elliott was fatally wounded and his brother, "Joe," slightly hurt by a shotgun in the hands of Louis Picklou yesterday. The shooting occurred on the farm of Mrs. C.H. Warne, a widow, who lives between Browntown and Matawan.

IT has often been remarked as peculiar that one of the oldest organizations and undoubtedly the wealthiest in the United States should be quartered in a small apartment in an office building. The Chamber of Commerce, however, is now soon to move from its cramped quarters in the New York Mutual Life Insurance Building and occupy its palatial and imposing home on Liberty Street, near Nassau.

IF, IN the course of human events, it ever happens that the Philippine Islands should become a sovereign State, part of or independent of the United States, it needs no great stretch of imagination to prophesy that its emblem will be the stately and useful bamboo tree, which is so beloved of all the Filipinos.

A hide broker of many years' association with the business, in conversation regarding the assertion of some tanners that hides were being weighted, said: "When I was young in the business I sold a car of hides to a tanner whose tannery was remote from Boston. A claim was entered for shrinkage in weight which was so extraordinary that I took a train for the tannery.
THORNTON slowly uncoiled his length from the easy chair in which he had been sitting, stretched himself, and with a lazy sigh remarked, "Well, I've got to dig back and write a story."

IS THERE anything more subtle than humor? Yes, the appreciation of humor! Who may say with absolute assurance that this or that is humorous? A man slips and falls on the ice. Everybody within eyeshot laughs at the mishap. That is a very common incentive to humor.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- Henryk Sienkiewicz, the Polish author, advises the Prussian Poles not to allow themselves to be driven into extreme acts or words through the anti-Polish agitation. He has addressed the following appeal to the Polish people:

WHILE October is not a month of particular festivity among the starry hosts, it is one of the most enjoyable seasons of the year for studying the evening sky. The gradually lengthening darkness, the crisp atmosphere, and whatever of the lingering Summer warmth we may find invite to the contemplation of the heavens.

AMONG recent curious swindles devised in Europe to take advantage of the credulity of American millionaires is that of an ingenious gentleman who has discovered some mysterious method of producing Stradivarius violins as well as instruments "made" by other masters of this craft, which when put up at auction sell at between $4,000 and $5,000.

PANAMA, Colombia, Sept. 27. -- The Government gunboat Chucuito left here this morning escorting a gasoline launch with a commission on board, bearing to the insurgent Gen. Herrera the answer of Gen. Salazar. Governor of Panama, to the former's peace proposals. George B. Parker and H.L. Gooding of Washington and George Cross of Newport News, Va., the American gunners who recently arrived here for service on Government gunboats, were on board the Chucuito.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Chairman Frank Campbell of the Democratic State Committee is in town to-night, and will proceed to Saratoga to-morrow to prepare for the convention. He said when asked as to the probable outcome:

Capt. Robert A. Brown, Fourth Cavalry, will Join his troop. First Lieut. Thomas L. Rhoades, Assistant. Surgeon, will proceed to San Francisco and report to the commanding General for assignment to duty at the Army General Hospital.

PEARL-BEARING clams are disappearing from the sandbars of Arkansas and the Mississippi River at a rate that threatens to make the species extinct in less than two years. The beginning of the end has commenced, and unless new fields are discovered soon the pearl-fishing industry of the United States will be a thing of the past.

BOSTON Sept. 27. -- The local money conditions to-day were practically unchanged, with quotations nominal and demand light. Sterling exchange continued quiet and soft in tone. Clearing House rate, 6 per cent; New York funds par; call loans, 6@7 per cent.; time money, 4 1/2 6. Clearing House exchanges, $10,316,496. Balances, $1,742,087.
James Sorahan, a longshoreman, shot and fatally wounded his brother, Henry, at midnight last night, and also shot, but did not seriously wound, the latter's wife, Bridget.

This week the very last of the important theatres open, the new Belasco again presenting Mrs. Leslie Carter in "Du Barry" Monday night, and the Irving Place with a new play, "Youth of To-day." A number of other theatres put on new plays and revivals of a promising kind.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Complete stagnation prevailed on the local market to-day. Buyers and sellers alike were unwilling to operate, the result being that only 21,709 shares of stock and $27,300 bonds were dealt in. Prices did not move more than eighths and quarters, but a majority of the issues in which there were dealings scored fractional losses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not wish to impose upon the wellknown liberality of THE TIMES to its contributors, but I beg leave to reply to Mr. M.T. Richardson's article, "The Co-operative Commonwealth," written in answer to my letter of the 10th. Under Socialism, certainly, every one of suitable age must work.

He is adequate, knowing, sinewy, and agile, and behind his kindly smile is a bundle of qualities for which the heedless Western world, judging superficially, does not give him credit. He is the Jack of the Rising Sun, and his modesty of demeanor is merely the cloak that conceals from the gaze of every passer-by many stern, sterling qualities.

WHEN the Batleys were walking home from the park Saturday afternoon they turned down a side street and ran across a bric-a-brac store in the window of which was exhibited the most charming character sketch in stucco that Mrs. Batley had ever seen. Upon pricing it she found that the masterpiece could be bought for 99 cents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The President's physician dressed the wound in his leg this morning and subsequently announced that the condition of the injury was satisfactory. The inflammation is receding slowly, but it may be a day or two yet before the physicians can state definitely that granulation has set in without involving the bone.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The chasm which is recognized by "Wisconsin Republicans as existing in the party in that State has been bridged over so far as the present campaign is concerned. From advices received here the prospects are good for the success of the State ticket and reelection of Senator Spooner.

The weekly Clearing House statement issued yesterday was unexpectedly favorable, not only wiping out the deficit in the surplus reserve account, but bringing the surplus figures up $3,236,625 beyond the 25 per cent, limit -- this as the result of a total increase in surplus reserves of $4,878,675. At the same time loans decreased $13,352,600, specie increased $1,973,600, legal tenders decreased $182,900, and deposits decreased $12,351,900.

Columbia's football players have got down to real work, and with yesterday's hard scrimmage on South Field begin to show good playing form. It is unquestionable that Columbia's showing in men, and in their ability, is better for this time, of year than it has ever been. Whether the team will improve as much after college opens, both in material and in ability, as it has always done, is still a very uncertain problem.

MEMBERS of the Coffee Congress to assemble here on Oct. 1 will doubtless be interested to learn that coffee by the cup costs in this city anywhere from one cent to fifteen cents. It is almost as good at five cents in the German Quarter as at fifteen in Fifth Avenue, and much of the one cent coffee is no worse than a great deal that is sold at ten cents.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept 27. -- The Republican State campaign was opened in this city to-day. An industrial parade of a large number of uniformed marching clubs was one of the features of the afternoon's programme. Ten thousand people assembled at Grace Park to listen to the speeches. A large platform had been erected, which was filled with distinguished Republicans from all parts of the State.

A SHORT time ago frequenters of the Latin Quarter of Paris were treated to an amusing comedy in three scenes. The characters were a cabman, with his horse and vehicle, a young, woman, And a Police Inspector.

HAVANA, Sept. 18. -- Sunday, the 14th, the anniversary of the death of President McKinley, was celebrated in Havana as though this were an American city. Masses were said in many churches in memory of the sad event and sermons preached in others. Cubans have the greatest admiration for the martyred President, because of his attitude toward them.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Cornell's football eleven could only roll up 5 points against Colgate to-day on Percy Field, the visitors surprising the Ithacans with their strength and well-executed formations.
Lieut. Peary, accompanied by Mrs. Peary and their little daughter Marie, slipped into this city quietly last night at 11 o'clock on the regular express from Boston.

[Copyright, 1902,] LONDON, Sept. 27. -- As the meeting of Parliament approaches there is increased activity among the opponents of the Education bill, who are holding meetings throughout the country and organizing a league pledged to passive resistance by the refusal to pay rates if the bill is passed.

Price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday were highly irregular, the fluctuations in some of the issues being more violent than any seen in recent days. Almost without exception the inclination of prices was downward, notably in St. Paul and Louisville and Nashville, the former of which fell over four and the latter nearly five points from the high figure of the day.

NONE of the many changes in the buildings on Manhattan is so apparent and impressive to the occasional visitor to New York as is the passing away of its old hotels to make way for business houses. This is especially true of Broadway below Forty-second Street.

Clearly Commissioner PARTRIDGE'S proposal for new Police Headquarters does not err on the side of modesty. He is not content with insisting that the Central Office of the police shall be truly central. He designates the actual block which it ought to occupy, and this is one of the most valuable pieces of real estate on Manhattan Island.

McKEESPORT, Penn., Sept. 27. -- Eight men, each with charred faces, burned bodies, and terribly, scorched heads, were taken to the McKeesport Hospital as the result of an explosion at Furnace B. of the Carnegie Blast Furnace plant, Duquesne, this evening. Two of the victims have since died, and there is but little hopes that any of the others will recover.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was one of Mohammed's teachings that the insane were specially possessed of the Divine spirit, and hence must be protected and venerated. It would appear that this doctrine has insinuated itself into our law in a reversed form, to wit: The murderer flies to insanity for exemption.

NO USE, Tatters, there isn't any other way out of it. You and I must part." Tatters shook his silky gray mop out of his eyes and whined softly at the dreary tone of Gerry's voice, which had lost its infectious gayety of late. Gerry had become strangely quiet -- for Gerry -- who used to toss things about with a breezy indifference that kept Tatters busy dodging them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I certainly do not understand how Bishop Potter can defend the saloon as the cure of the ills of workingmen. I take it, from his views on the question, that he must be absolutely ignorant of the conditions existing in the houses where strong drink is used by the father who frequents the saloon at the expense of his unfortunate wife and children.

To THOS who watch the political fortunes of President Roosevelt Mr. Sheldon's dismal cropper at Saratoga is most significant. Mr. Sheldon, it must be borne in mind, was the deliberate choice of Senator Platt and Gov. Odell. Not until the convention assembled was the advisability of running him seriously questioned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I don't understand what the coal strikers of Pennsylvania demand. At one time it is said that it is the recognition of the union, and at another time that it is a question Of wages. Then it is said that the strike will be settled in two weeks, and when the time expires it appears to be further from solution than ever.

It is an evident fact that friends of Manhattan, to use the Wall Street term, have no lack of "confidence" in the future of their property, none in its ultimate ability to make larger returns to stockholders than the 4 per cent. now being paid. At current figures for the stock, the latter, representing a yield on investment of less than 3 per cent., is selling at a figure which admits of no other conclusion.

THE publication in these columns on Aug. 17 of the world's record of earthquakes and volcanic eruptions from April 10 to July 27 of this, year has been followed by activity of European scientists in adding to the list of nature's cataclysms and computing the thickness of the earth's shell and the possible contingency of some further dread disaster.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to add my word of approval to the course of action suggested by Annie C. Patterson in your issue of Sept. 22 in regard to the method of treatment to be used in bringing the high-handed coal operators to terms.

No attempt was made yesterday to arrest Laura Biggar, the actress, charged with conspiracy to obtain the whole fortune of the late Henry M. Bennett, and whose two chief witnesses. Dr. C.C. Hendrick and ex-Justice of the Peace Samuel Stanton of Hoboken, were locked in the Freehold (N.J.) jail on the ground that they had aided her in trying to prove a mythical marriage with the dead millionaire and the birth of a posthumous son.

WHILE all Europe is lying awake nights to devise ways and means to check the impetus of the "American business invasion" in their own domain, there arrives in New York a German promoter, who, through the medium of a newspaper advertisement, informs the public that he is prepared to furnish, in large lots, to restaurants, hotels, and groceries, a "prima" quality of snails, with shells, for the season now opening.

IN "A Country Girl," at Daly's, the song of the "Two Little Chicks" wins especial favor, and in this number William Norris as Barry and Minnie Ashley as Sophie create much amusement. The little song goes as follows:

TWO Harvard students were battling for the boxing championship. Both were prominent men in college athletics, and a crowd if enthusiastic supporters cheered on The match. One, a member of the senior class, had the advantage of a longer reach over his junior adversary, who, in turn, was a trifle the quicker of the two.

To the Editor of The New York Times: America! How seducing does this name sound to the Italian, tired of the land where labor is so little rewarded, and how does hope return to him at the mention of this land of freedom! He has seen his relatives and friends return from America rich, or at least well-to-do, and not the least shadow of doubt ever crosses his mind that he also will succeed.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The horse show to-day was more successful than on the opening day. There was no rain during the morning, and the social colony all turned out well. Miss Roosevelt, daughter of President Roosevelt, with the Misses Cutting, were among the first to arrive. The most interesting class during the morning was the ladies' appointment class.

Bishop POTTER'S charge delivered last week was marked by the frankness and good sense so characteristic of its author. That he recognizes the social uses of the liquor saloon, and does not insist that an institution so clearly founded in human needs "shall go," may again make him a subject for public prayer on the part of the W.C.T.U.

PARIS, Sept. 19. -- About Nov. 1 the longest submarine telephone line in the world will be opened between England and Belgium. The principal part of the cable has already been laid, terminating on the English side in St. Margaret's Bay, near Dover, and on the Belgian side in the little harbor of La Panne.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- The University of Pennsylvania football eleven opened the season on Franklin Field today by defeating Lehigh University by the score of 12 to 0.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27. -- Heavy line smashing by the tackles and back field were the features of Yale's play this afternoon in defeating Trinity in the first game of the season by a score of 40 to 0. From start to finish the visitors did not gain over five yards, while Yale's fierce game netted from five to twenty-five yards on every play.

The memorial of a special committee of the Municipal Art Society, handed on Friday to the Board of Estimate, with regard to City Hall Park and the housing of the various departments of the City Government is emphatic concerning the wastefulness of the present state of things.

President Cantor has received drawings made by Charles F. McKim of the architectural firm of McKim, Mead White, and submitted by Montgomery Schuyler for a new Municipal Building on the lines laid down by Controller Grout. These plans are elaborate and go into the matter much more in detail than any heretofore advanced.

Entries for the 500-mile reliability contest of the Automobile Club of America from this city to Boston and return, which will take place Oct. 9 to 15, have closed with a total of seventy-two vehicles, which insures an interesting and probably a record-breaking contest. Of the 72 entrants 54, or 75 per cent., are gasoline, 17 are steam motors, and only 1 has electricity as a motive power.
APROPOS of the interest in the forthcoming trial of the Molineux case, Canada also, as well as this country, is having its murder case, the determining point of which is handwriting evidence.

FOR 116 consecutive years the New York City Directory has made its annual appearance with marvelously increased dimensions. Last year it was a volume of 1,449 pages. This year it has 1,555 -- a decided difference from the modest little volume of 52 pages which was issued from 11 University Place in 1786 with an introduction by Noah Webster, when John Hancock resided at 5 Cherry Street and Alexander Hamilton at 57 Wall.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- "It is just like going home," said Sir Michael Herbert prior to sailing for New York to-day on the Cunard Line steamer Campania. The new Ambassador to the United States, who is accompanied by Lady Herbert, is eagerly anticipating his return to America. He expects to stay a couple of days in New York and then go to Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Boston and Philadelphia played two baseball games today. The visitors won the first, and the second was called at the end of the ninth inning on account of darkness with the score tied. Boston hit the home team's new pitcher hard in the first game. The second game was fairly well placed, both pitchers being effective.

The Wabash Road is not only to be one of the great trunk line roads, but it is going to be one of the great coal-carriers of the country before many years pass by; with this in view, it is securing land in West Virginia, in Pennsylvania, and in Ohio.

ENGLAND'S latest augmentation of her already strong West Indian fortifications, indicates her purpose to retain the full strategic advantage which their situation gives to her possessions in the Caribbean Sea or bordering upon it. Her present effort in carrying out this policy is the creation of two entirely new batteries defending the approach to Port Royal, the naval station, on the Island of Jamaica.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 27. -- J.H.P. Wharton of New York won the J.W. Reinhart Cup on the Hillside Tennis and Golf course this afternoon for the third consecutive season, and the trophy won now becomes his permanent property. His score was 80, 8, 72. The best scores in the putting and approaching contest were by Mr. arid Mrs. Evarts Tracy, 9; Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ackerman. 12; Miss Katharine Stewart, and W.T. Glenney, 14.

THERE have been many stories written recently about Schouchuak, the Eskimo centre rush of the Carlisle Indian football team. The report has gone forth and has never been publically contradicted that Schouchuak is a full-blooded Eskimo of the type found in the Far North by Lieut. Peary and other well-known arctic explorers.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- Money was easier today and there was less pressure, owing to borrowings from the Bank of England, which are expected to continue next week on account of consol settlement requirements. Discounts were firm.

The effort to secure from the present administration in this city a just and faithful application of the merit system as required by the Constitution and provided for by the civil service law has been frequently foiled by the insistence of the Mayor that competition is not "practicable" in a large number of cases.
Aaron M. Weil has resigned as President of the Indiana Association of Local Fire Insurance Agents, whose annual meeting will be held on Oct. 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In behalf of many readers of your paper and residents of the Borough of Richmond, on the line of the Midland trolley, we ask you to come to our aid in bringing that company to a realization of its unjustifiable and shameful treatment of its patrons.

IT IS reported that a seven-year-old child fell from the third story of a house in Fifty-second Street and landed in a pail of water standing on the doorstep, sustaining no serious injuries. This is what might be called a mere drop in the bucket.

To the Editor of The Newo York Times: An instance of what a Professor in a college of New York termed the madness of the present school administration, was seen in the legislation effected this last Summer in regard to the Teachers' Training School. Previous to last July the entrance requirements of the Training School demanded a four-year high school course, and ability to pass the entrance examination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing your editorial in to-day's TIMES as to the controversy between a gentleman and a cab driver, in which the gentleman was trying to ascertain the cab fare to a certain hotel, I would like to say a few words on the subject.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is hard to go without THE TIMES for a single day, and those among your readers who have lately returned from vacations spent in distant parts of the country (the present writer was in Colorado and Utah) have missed much with which they have had to familiarize themselves through reference to a file of back numbers.

CORINTH, Miss., Sept. 28. -- Tom Clark, alias Will Gibson, a young negro, was burned at the stake by citizens here at a late hour this afternoon. Clark had confessed to one of the most atrocious murders ever committed in this State, and said he deserved his fate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Commercial conditions in the United States are now the subject of very close attention by the financial and commercial journals of Europe. A copy of The London Financier, just received by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, discusses in great detail commercial and manufacturing conditions in the United States, and their bearing upon the manufactures and commerce of Europe, and especially of Great Britain.

LONDON, Sept. 28. -- The fact that the Bank of England's rate of discount, 3 per cent., to-day remains unchanged from the figure quoted for the past eight months has caused undisguised satisfaction and imparted a feeling of steadiness to a situation which is otherwise regarded as decidedly uncertain.

Petitions are being circulated throughout the country by the various organizations constituting the American Federation of Catholic Societies, asking President Roosevelt to use his good offices to end the coal Strike. The members of the Federation number at least half a million.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- When the Democratic State Committee meets to-morrow night to perfect the plans for the convention it will be notified of a number of contests. In the Ninth Assembly District of New York Frank J. Goodwin and his followers will attempt to have William S. Devery and his two associate delegates unseated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Senator W.A. Harris of Kansas, who has just returned from Europe, where he went to make arrangements for exhibits of live stock at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition at St. Louis, started West to-day. His journey did not develop any substantial interest in sending blooded animals of any kind to America for purposes of exhibition.
The St. Louis had among its passengers yesterday Weedon Grossmith, his wife, May Palfrey, and Maud Hobson, who open the Princess Theatre Oct. 6 with the English farce, "The Night of the Party."

HELENA, Mont., Sept. 28. -- Two large congregations in the Methodist and Congregational Churches waited in vain here to-day to hear Charles N. Crittenton of New York, the millionaire founder of the Florence Crittenton Rescue Homes for Fallen Women, and it is feared to-night that some fatality has happened to him somewhere between this city and Spokane.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Symptoms which are at least serious, but should not be alarming, made it necessary to perform another operation to-day on the President's leg. With six physicians present, the wound left by the operation last Wednesday in Indianapolis was opened down to the bone.

The little celebration Saturday night by the management and members of the cast in the play of "Notre Dame" in honor of their distinguished confrere, the veteran, Frank C. Bangs, on the completion of his fiftieth year as an actor, constituted an event in the history of the American stage, and went far to show that the American actor and American manager still treasure the traditions of the profession in this country.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The views of the Democratic leaders who are now here to attend the State Convention, although these leaders are not many in number, or especially powerful in the party councils, indicate that David B. Hill has trouble on his hands, and that unless he takes hold with a firm grasp when he arrives here to-morrow mischief may result.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial in to-day's TIMES on the "'Antis' and Mr. Root" you say the American idea is, "There is somebody wiser than anybody, and that is everybody," and that "the more people decide against them -- the 'Antis' -- the more they refuse to be convinced."

In his address on Saturday Chancellor MACCRACKEN commented on the interesting state of the school question in Great Britain and in France, with the general conclusion that the process of secularizing public education was being pushed too rapidly in the latter country and not fast enough in the former.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 28. -- William R. Weeks of New York, who was removed some time ago as trustee of the fund created by Edwin Lister for the benefit of his widow, Margaret C. Lister, has been officially declared to tie $21,000 short in his accounting to the estate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- "The submarine boat of the future should be propelled by electricity," said Lieut. Commander John R. Edwards, United States Navy, to-day. Commander Edwards, who is known as an expert student of marine propulsion, is making a special study of submarine torpedo boats.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Representative John Dalzell of Pennsylvania, who came to Washington on Saturday to open his residence for the season, says he thinks the Republicans will win in the coming Congressional contest.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 28. -- The Indianapolis physicians and surgeons who participated in the operation performed on the President at St. Vincent's Hospital last Tuesday, were shown the dispatch from Washington announcing that another operation had been necessary, and all declared that this was not unexpected, but was what they had feared.

The adjustment of the differences in the Republican Party in Wisconsin is important for the whole country. Substantially it leaves Senator SPOONER free to take his own part in the campaign, so far as National issues are involved, and to conduct his own canvass for re-election to the Senate.

The British bark Kentmere, Capt. Burch, after a voyage from the Orient that lasted 197 days, got in yesterday with a scurvy-stricken crew, four of them being in a very pitiable condition, and three others very little better off. Malnutrition is said to be the cause of the trouble, and the crew, it is understood, will report the fact to the British Consul General to-day.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 28. -- Richard Wagner of the Wisconsin Sugar Company said to-day in an interview that his company, which plans to build large beet sugar plants in the vicinity of Milwaukee, would wait until the Government disposes of the Cuban reciprocity question before beginning work.

VIENNA, Sept. 28. -- The body of Edmund Jellinek, the defaulting official of the cashier's department of the Vienna Laender (real estate mortgage) Bank, has been found in the Danube at Altenwoerth, near Krems.

The plan of Mr. T.W. RUSSELL, M.P., has a more practical arithmetical basis than seems to have been assumed by those who have prematurely criticised it. Mr. RUSSELL is now engaged in formulating the details of a scheme of land purchase in Ireland which will confer immediate and tangible benefit upon the tenant without diminishing the income of the selling landlord.

Several good matches took place at Casey's Brooklyn Handball Court yesterday, and there was a fairly large gathering of players and onlookers, despite the unfavorable weather. "Phil" Casey was beaten by Alderman Dunne in two straight games, and T. Dunne with M. Ryan defeated C. Rawley and W.L. Jones three straight.

The Deutsche Zeitung of Vienna, most German of the great newspapers printed outside the German Empire, and the only one quite free to say a great many things which no newspaper of the empire would dare to print, throws a flood of light upon one of the most active causes of German discontent with the apparent incapacity of those who assume to control the national destinies.

PARIS, Sept. 28. -- The French press has been following closely the "armed intervention" of the United States in affairs on the Isthmus of Panama, and the article published in the Prensa of Buenos Ayres, in which attention was called to the alleged tendency of the United States toward imperialism, has evoked comment in several newspapers.

Henry "Wilding, the English representative of the International Navigation Company, and the head of the Leyland Line of steamships arrived yesterday on the American liner St. "Louis. Mr. Wilding's presence here, it was said, was necessary for the arrangement of the final details of the shipping combine.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- In an editorial summary accompany his quarterly bulletin, o Commissioner of Labor Statistics McMackin points out that immigration during the past year has surpassed all previous records.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just perused with considerable interest the communication on "The Real Cause of Strikes," which appeared in your, journal three weeks ago. It undoubtedly contains much truth, but what I particularly admired was O manly tone. Obviously it was written by a son of toli who votes according to his honest convictions, regardless of anybody's frowns or favors.

The sweeping charges of corruption directed against labor leaders generally made by District Attorney Jerome caused much indignation at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Federation. He is to be called upon to give names or to withdraw his statements. Daniel Harris, delegate of Cigarmakers' Union No. 144, brought up the matter at the meeting of the central body yesterday, and said that it was imperative that Mr. Jerome should be asked to explain himself.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- Dr. Campbell of the United States Geological Survey has made an elaborate and interesting report on the borax deposits of Death Valley and the Mohave Desert, California, which will soon be printed. The discovery in 1890 of the borax crust in Death Valley revolutionized the industry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the storm of Wednesday evening, the 24th inst., the Union Railway Company again demonstrated its utter inability to handle, a crowd. "When traffic was at its height the axle of a "Westchester Avenue car going east broke down at One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street, blocking the road for thirty-five minutes.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Senator Patrick H. McCarren of Brooklyn, Congressman William Sulzer of Manhattan, Prof. William D. Lee of Cornell University, and John B. Stanchfield of Elmira were among the prominent Democrats who arrived in this city to-day and visited Senator David B. Hill.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The Andrew Reasoner Memorial Chapel, attached to the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church of this city, was dedicated this afternoon. The chapel, which cost $40,000, is the gift of Mrs. Abby Reasoner, widow of Andrew Reasoner, who was Superintendent of the Morris and Essex Railroad, as a memorial to Mr. Reasoner.

One of the passengers to arrive yesterday on the White Star liner Celtic was George G. Ward, Vice President, General Manager, and Director of the Commercial Cable Company, and Vice President and Director of the Postal Telegraph Cable Company.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 28. -- The coal situation has started a new industry in this city, that of recovering coal from sunken barges in the bottom of Long Island Sound. The Sound and Coast Wrecking Company of this place will begin "water mining" next week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice in to-day's issue your article entitled "Commissioner Against Chief." It is an anomaly in judicial proceedings that a man should prefer charges and then hear the charges himself. This is practically what is permitted under our municipal system. The sooner it is abolished the better it will be for everybody, both heads of departments and subordinates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Had the miners taken steps in the early days of the strike to organize a company for the purpose of mining and chipping coal, their combined capital with their expert labor would have given them financial strength and a standing with the community.

The Congregation Shaarai Berocho dedicated the new synagogue at 350 East Fifty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon. The synagogue was located formerly at 138 East Fiftieth Street. The Interior decorations are in white and gold. The Rev. Gabriel Hirsch, who has been the rabbi of the congregation for twenty-eight years, officiated, and the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman of Temple Emanu-El preached the dedicatory sermon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The Marine Hospital Service has issued an interesting bulletin by direction of Dr. Carter, on the transmission of yellow fever by the mosquito. The conclusion of Dr. Carter is firm in the belief that this is the only means of spread of the disease. He argues most convincingly by eliminating other alleged causes of infection, and shows that the facts all point to the mosquito as the cause.

The cage at the Central Park menagerie confining Rocky, the big grizzly, and Garibaldi, his unwelcome associate, since Saturday, was the centre of attraction for a large crowd during the entire day yesterday. It rained furiously at times, but the spectators were reluctant to give up the unusual performance of two ferocious animals bickering with one another.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- Dr. Ethelbert Talbot, Bishop of the Episcopal Church in Central Pennsylvania, has issued a signed statement reviewing the strike situation, which is favorable to the operators. He says the anarchy and rioting should be stopped in twenty-four hours. The letter in part is:

With the lapse of years the Hon. DAVID B. HILL has been restored to leadership and control of the Democratic organization in the State of New York. The Democrats are to hold their convention this week at Saratoga. They will nominate candidates and adopt a platform of principles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the present temporary financial stringency, which recurs regularly every Fall during the crop-moving season, there can be no question that an "emergency" circulation such as is issued by the Imperial Bank of Germany, referred to by ex-Controller Hepburn, would be the simplest and most effective device which could be applied as a corrective.

Lieut. Robert E. Peary, the arctic explorer, who arrived at New York Saturday night from Portland, Me., is at the St. Denis Hotel. With him are Mrs. Peary and his nine-year-old daughter Marie, both of whom went to the arctic regions last Summer on board the Windward, the ship that brought the explorer back to civilization after a sojourn of more than four years in the frozen North.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 28. -- The coal operators of the Wyoming and Lackawanna regions will make strenuous efforts to resume operations at some of their mines during the coming week. The programme is to concentrate what men they have in their employ at one or two points, then, if the strikers interfere, the militia will be called upon to give the workmen protection.

Ending his days as an inmate of the almshouse on Blackwell's Island, there has been identified in Adolph Boedesch, a one-time banker of Vienna, for whom the Austrian police have been searching for years. In Vienna, Boedesch was Adolph Bettelheim, and he is said to have disappeared with upward of $250,000 which had been deposited with him for safekeeping.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 28. -- By working his troops eight hours a day, regardless of the rain and the awful condition of the roads, Col. Watres of the Thirteenth Regiment has succeeded in restoring order throughout the Lackawanna country. Sporadic outbreaks of a comparatively trivial nature have occurred during the past two days, but the usual attacks by mobs on non-union men and companies' properties have not occurred.

That portion of the Tombs still standing will be emptied of its inmates this week and pass out of commission as a place of confinement for prisoners awaiting trial on criminal charges. They will be removed to the new structure on Centre Street, now practically completed, which done, steps will be taken for the immediate removal of the remaining portion of the old structure in its rear.

Whatever the immediate developments may be in the money market, it is very clear that the general money situation is measurably better than it was a week ago. Instead of a deficit in the surplus reserve account, as was then reported, there is now a fair margin above the 25 per cent, limit, and the promises are that there will be a further gain this week.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, who spent the past four months in Europe, returned yesterday on board the White Star liner Celtic. Although his trip abroad was undertaken chiefly for rest and recreation, he brought back with him a budget of opinions on the conditions of Ireland and the Irish, and a decided view on the trust question.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- At midnight Senator Hill made the positive declaration that he absolutely did not know Who the Democratic nominee for Governor would be. If Mr. Hill, who is the master of the situation here, made this statement in good faith, as he appeared to it would be idle for anybody else to make a prophecy.
PARIS, Sept. 29. -- Emile Zola, the novelist, was found dead in his Paris house this morning from asphyxiation.

The Alliance Realty Company will not be among the corporations that are to be merged into the new United States Realty and Construction Company. That fact was made public yesterday afternoon, in an announcement by Hallgarten Co., who have been managers of the underwriting syndicate that was formed in connection with the organization of the new company.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- In view of the approaching dissolution of the Greek Chamber of Deputies, says the Athens correspondent of The Times, ex-Premier Delyannis publishes his political programme in the newspapers.

In a report filed with Mayor Low late yesterday afternoon, William Barclay Parsons, George B. Post, and J.C. Breckenridge, appointed as a committee to examine the plans of Neils Poulson for the improvement of the terminal arrangements at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge, declare that the Poulson idea would not provide any satisfactory relief.

The coal strike is in its fifth month, and not one step of visible progress toward its settlement has been made. Arbitration has been refused, and no clear course has been pointed out to legislation or appeal to the courts. Meanwhile the time is at hand when the dearth of coal, which has thus far been merely an inconvenience, will become a source of public danger.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill, the arbiter of the Democratic situation, arrived here at noon to-day. As he stepped from the train the crowd in waiting was impressed by his farmer-like appearance. When Mr. Hill goes to New York he invariably wears a high silk hat, and his habits are in keeping with the dignity of his position.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29. -- Mrs. Vanderbilt closed The Breakers to-day and with her daughter Miss Gladys Vanderbilt, went to New York.
Isaac Dreyfus has bought the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 27 East Sixty-third Street, 20 by-100.

The breach among the Republicans in the Nineteenth Senate District is widening, and the criminations and recriminations are couched in anything but polite language. The indications are that at the convention to-morrow evening ex-Assemblyman William H. Smith will be nominated and that on Thursday Assistant Appraiser Harvey T. Andrews will be named for Congress.

SARATOGA, Sept. 20. -- The platform which is to be presented to the convention is a Hill platform from start to finish. It was written entirely by him, although a few of the planks, such as those on the tariff and the canal question, were submitted by him to men whom he considered experts on those questions.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 29. -- Money in Boston is firm, and yet Boston is probably the strongest city in the country to-day financially. This is because there has been no great speculation here for the rise and because banking methods have changed wonderfully for the better the past few years. Going rates are unchanged, but the banks are letting out money very slowly.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- An outbreak of scarlet fever among the students may result in the closing of Hamilton College at Clinton. Burton Loomis of Chittenango Falls, a freshman, died at Emerson Hall this morning, and twelve other students are dangerously ill. More cases will probably develop, as about one-half the students have been exposed.

ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., Sept. 29 Manufacturing jewelers here, who believe that the ratification of the French reciprocity treaty will tend to injure the industry of that community, have already begun their fight against the measure, in the expectation that it is to be introduced at the next session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The Gwfti arrived at Norfolk to-day.

Ex-Controller FITCH, in an argument before the local board for the Murray Hill district, opposing unconditional concurrence in the application of the New York Central Railroad for the concessions demanded as conditions precedent to the installation of electric traction in the Park Avenue tunnel, expressed public opinion very accurately when he said: "If we can tie them down in these things they so glibly promise we shall find that they will keep their promises better."

The first official information regarding the disposition of the Louisville and Nashville to the Atlantic Coast Line, reports of which have been current, with more or less authenticity, was made public yesterday by J. Pierpont Morgan himself.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 29. -- In remarkable contrast to last Monday and the Monday previous, to-day was wholly free from disturbances. Up to a late hour to-night not a single act of violence worthy of note has been reported.
Secretary of the Treasury Shaw came to the city yesterday, and has made arrangements, which will make available $130,000,000 additional credit to-day.

Everything seems to be made for a card party prize nowadays. There can be no other reason for decorating hand mirrors with designs of playing cards in pyrography upon the backs. Some of the mirrors are pretty things, and they are all comparatively inexpensive, being from 50 cents up.
Army. Capt. James Lockett, Fourth Cavalry, will report to Lieut. Col. Charles Morton, Eighth Cavalry, President of the examining board at Jefferson Barracks, for examination.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29. -- "Bloody Monday" night at Harvard this evening developed into something more than the usual fierce rush between the sophomore and freshman classes. The traditional bloody nose, torn shirt, and spraia were, it is true, found with as great a frequency as ever, but in addition to these the festive sophomore and the verdant freshman added another feature, the stopping of trolley cars.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 29. -- To win their right to erect a $300 traveler at the new Lake Shore Rock Island depot the Bridge and Structural Iron Workers' Union tied up buildings to-day that are to cost over $9,000,000. The dispute was originally between the iron men and the carpenters, but has spread until it affects every building trade in the city.
LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Money was in fair demand to-day owing to the quarter-end. Discounts were maintained.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 29. -- The Consolidated Naval Stores Company, will be incorporated in Jacksonville Wednesday, with a capital of $2,000,000. The concerns going into the combination are the Southern Naval Stores Company, Savannah; the Ellis Young Company, Savannah; the Downing Company, Brunswick, Ga.; the Mutual Naval Stores Company, Jacksonville; the Gulf Naval Stores Company, Tampa; the Florida Naval Stores Company, Jacksonville, and the West Coast Naval Stores Company, Pensacola.

More than once on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday panicky conditions threatened. The close of the market reflected what seemed to approach demoralization. Declines scored during the day were of size -- four, five, and ten point recessions not being exceptional.
According to one of the retail coal dealers yesterday the operators are using the present strike in order to freeze out the small dealers.
PHILADELPHIA, Perm., Sept. 29. -- John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers of America, met a representative of the coal operators and of J. Pierpont Morgan at the Hotel Walton here to-day.

-- In bringing about and permitting to continue for several days a savage and more or less sanguinary fight between two of the bears in their charge, the officials connected in various capacities with the menagerie in Central Park have invited a kind and amount of criticism which it would have been the part of wisdom for them to avoid.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 29. -- The local market to-day reflected rather keenly the reactionary tendency in Wall Street. There wag no rush to sell, but such selling as there was fell oh a flat demand; since the recessions in prices, Seaboard showed the sharpest decline, due to some speculative unloading.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The Navy Department was to-day advised of the receipt of the following cable dispatch from Vice Consul Ehrman at Panama:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 29. -- The great baseball parade held to-night in honor of the Athletic Baseball Club, which won the American League championship, was one of the most successful affairs of its kind in the history of the National game. A notable feature was the showing made by the amateur teams, fully 200 clubs turning out in full uniform.

The formation of a combination designed to control the entire output of lead in the United States was announced yesterday. The combination will be known as the National Lead Company, and will probably have a capital of $60,000,000. The American Smelting and Refining Company and several large financial interests, among them the Standard Oil interests, will probably be associated with the enlarged company.

The opening last evening of the new Belasco Theatre in Forty-second Street, near Broadway, attracted a large and fashionable audience, the larger portion of which arrived long before the time set for the beginning of "Du Barry," the play which Mrs. Leslie Carter revived as the first attraction at the new house.

Undeterred by recent disappointments in arctic exploration, and by the well-established fact that nothing very important is likely to be found in the frozen zones, the Scottish National antarctic expedition, under the leadership of Mr. WILLIAM S. BRUCE, will be ready to sail early in October.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- William S. Devery assembled his cohorts in the Ninth Assembly District to-day and started for this city determined to be admitted to the State Convention as a delegate or fight. The trip of the Devery delegation from New York was marked by many exciting incidents.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 29. -- The courts may be invoked to settle a bitter dispute among the managers of the Home for Confederate Widows and Mothers in thts city. They are all women prominent in charities and society. Mrs. John K. Cowen, wife of the ex-President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, founded the home, and she now claims to have been badly treated by the other managers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- The market here was unsettled to-day, owing to the demoralization which developed in New York. Weakness, however, was not pronounced, except in those issues which are traded in on the two markets, like the Readings, Pennsylvania, United States Steel, and Southern Railway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- After the President's physician had dressed his wound this morning the following statement was prepared and issued by Secretary Cortelyou:

A correspondent who advocates co-operative mining as a solution for the differences between operators and miners in the anthracite region states an undisputed proposition with what would seem to be unnecessary vehemence. He says: "There are capable, God-fearing men among the Pennsylvania miners.

In searching through the Bayonne sanitarium of Dr. C.C. Hendrick, Laura Biggar's lawyer and physician, two New Jersey detectives yesterday found an old check book belonging to the doctor. One of the stubs told of $30 paid by Dr. Hendrick to Samuel Stanton within the last two months.

The long-expected police change in the Tenderloin came yesterday, when Commissioner Partridge transferred Capt. Sheehan to the Old Slip Station, a post considered unimportant in the Police Department. Not alone did the Commissioner transfer Capt. Sheehan, but he also transferred Inspector Harley, whose district includes the Tenderloin Station.

Chief of Department Edward F. Croker reported in uniform at Fire Headquarters at 8 A.M. yesterday, in compliance with Special Orders No. 137, which restored him to full duty, from which he was "relieved" Aug. 19 by Special Orders No. 121, and went on trial on the omnibus indictment, comprising seven charges of fifteen specifications, preferred by Commissioner Thomas Sturgis at 10:30 o'clock.

President Andrew Freedman of the New York Baseball Club announced last night that he had disposed of his controlling interest in that organization, the purchaser being John T. Brush, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National League and former majority owner of the Cincinnati Club. This transfer of interest in the local club was not unexpected, but it was unlocked for at this time.

Charges of serious import alleging flagrant disregard of statutory requirements, are made against the administration of the Immigration Bureau of this port under Commissioner Thomas Fitchie in the annual report to the Treasury Department of the present Commissioner, William Williams, filed yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30. -- The break to 170 by Atlantic Coast Line common, followed by a partial recovery, was the most notable feature of to-day's trading. The break was ascribed to a forced sale at the market, which fell into the selling at the most inopportune moment. It was offered about the time Louisville and Nashville was looking its ugliest, hence the indisposition to buy except at a wide concession.
GLASGOW, Sept. 30. -- It is said here that the Scotch coal masters have secured large contracts for anthracite coal to go to the United States.
SARATOGA, Sept. 30. -- John B. Stanchfield, of Elmira, the temporary Chairman of the Democratic State Convention, addressed that body here to-day. He spoke in part as follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- Boston Bank Presidents and financiers received the proposals of Secretary of Treasury Shaw with divided feelings. That part of his announcement which says that he will not require the banks which are Government depositories to keep the 25 per cent, reserve on Government deposits meets with favor all around.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 30. -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company is rather hard pressed for coal, though the officials say the road will pull through so long as coal can be bought. There has been trouble in getting soft coal for the road ever since the strike began in the West Virginia coal fields last Summer.
