In view of the generally unsatisfactory conditions prevailing throughout England from the point of view of the mechanic and small tradesman, it is difficult to understand why there should be such an influx of alien immigrants into London who come there with the evident intention of remaining.

Horace S. Ely Co. have sold for Susan Nicho's the five-story building 21 Liberty Street, running through to 60 Maiden Lane, 21.9 by 88.4 by 22.1 by 82.11, adjoining the Montauk Building, which covers the adjoining block front on the west side of William Street, between Liberty Street and Maiden Lane.

SHEFFIELD, England, Sept. 30. -- Four hundred covers were laid at the Cutlers' feast, which was held here to-day. The principal guests of the occasion were Lord Kitchener and Ambassador Choate, who sat respectively at the left and right of Master Cutler Hobson. Military officers predominated among the guests, and the distinguished persons present included Gerald W. Balfour, President of the Board of Trade; the Duke of Norfolk, Gen. French, and Gen. Ian Hamilton.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The coming State Committee will have more than a dozen new committeemen. As far as can be learned to-night the composition will be:

The announcement of Secretary Shaw yesterday morning that he would no longer require the National banks, which were Government depositories, to hold a 25 per cent, reserve against Government deposits, caused the strongest reaction that the financial district has witnessed in some time.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The Democratic Convention, which was opened here at noon to-day, compared with the Republican Convention, held here a week ago, was almost as different in point of attendance and enthusiasm as an east side mass meeting is from a session of the Asiatic Association.

PRINCETON, Sept. 30. -- Mrs. Grover Cleveland, accompanied by her four children, has arrived in Princeton from the ex-President's Summer home at Buzzard's Bay. Mrs. Cleveland said to-night that her husband will return to Princeton on Saturday.

That the Secretary of the Treasury has taken the course be has announced under the conviction that it was both imperatively necessary and warranted by a proper interpretation of the law is not to be questioned. His view of the situation and his view of what he could do under the law have undergone a radical change within a very short time.

Small fields and a heavy track caused tame racing at the Gravesend course yesterday, but the regular visitors warmed up to genuine enthusiasm over the results, for the best backed horses practically carried the day. Though two favorites were beaten the betting crowd really went wrong in but one race of the six, this error being in the first event.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- If the present programme to throw out both the Devery and the Goodwin delegations from the Ninth District is carried in the convention to-morrow, one of the biggest sensations which ever attended a convention in the State is threatened. Devery will not only fight to the last ditch, but will endeavor to besmirch the political reputation of David B. Hill.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The Directors of the Cunard Steamship Company sent a letter to the shareholders to-night setting forth the terms of the proposed subsidy. It will include payment by the Government of $750,000 annually the company to build two large, fast steamers for the Atlantic trade. The agreement will remain in force twenty years after the completion of the second steamer.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The conference to-night in Mr. Hill's room, between Mr. Hill and Messrs. McLaughlin, Shevlin, and McCarren, began at 9:30 o'clock, and did not end until 10:30. When Messrs. McLaughlin, Shevlin, and McCarren walked out of the room, they were accosted for information on the Gubernatorial situation:

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- At the back of the stage, when the Republican Convention was held here, there was a picture of President Roosevelt. The Democratic Committee of Arrangements was somewhat puzzled over the selection of a picture for the Democratic Convention. When a picture of Bryan was proposed some objected that the prominent display of Bryan's picture might not be altogether pleasing to the Gold Democrats in the convention.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- It was learned late to-night that the sub-committee to which had been referred the question of a canal improvement and other planks had decided to recommend to the Committee on Resolutions to-morrow a plank declaring for a 1,000-ton barge canal.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 30. -- This evening the forty-fifth annual festival of the Worcester County Musical Association began with a presentation of "Judith," the lyric drama by George W. Chadwick, that was the principal novelty of last season's festival. Gertrude May Stein, for whom the part was written, appeared as before in the title role.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 30. -- Sam M. Jones, the golden-rule Mayor, to-day issued a proclamation calling upon citizens of Toledo to gather in mass meeting Oct. 2 to adopt appropriate resolutions in support of the movement by Boston citizens to ask the Federal courts to appoint receivers for the anthracite coal mines and coal-carrying railroads.

Language of conspicuous inexactness was employed by our neighbor, The Sun, in characterizing an argument made by Senator FORAKER in his speech at Akron on Saturday. The passage which our neighbor describes as "a peculiarly illuminating statement of facts in which the public mind happens to be at the moment absorbed" is here quoted:

Application is to be made shortly before Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court, by consent of all counsel, for the court's approval of a settlement of the Wertheimer claim of 2,000,000f. against Count and Countess Boni de Castellane, and for authority to pay over the money in accordance with the terms of the agreement, now made public.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Sept. 30. -- Through fog and mist, and over the soggy turf of the Country Club, plodded to-day nearly ninety of the best women golfers of the country in the 18-hole qualifying round for the National championship. Miss Margaret Curtis of the Essex County Club, Manchester, Mass., and Miss Louisa A. Wells of the home club, excelled all others and tied for first place, with scores of 89.

Columbia's football situation in regard to the temporary disqualification of Capt. H. H. Weekes and five other players took on a much brighter color yesterday, when it was said that Weekes had satisfied all the requirements of the Faculty committee on athletics and would be eligible to play. This is also true of the other players, and they are all likely to play in Columbia's opening game with Rutgers on Saturday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 30. -- Gov. Robert M. La Follette opened the campaign for the Republicans of Wisconsin in this city to-night before an immense audience. Gov. La Follette was enthusiastically received. He spoke in part as follows:
NEWPORT, Sept. 30. -- Mrs. J.P. Kernochan has closed her Seaview cottage.

Extraordinary things came to pass in Wall Street yesterday. They were all inspiriting. The panicky conditions of the day before had wholly disappeared. There was no scare or sign or scare anywhere. Instead vigor ruled in every part of the market. Transactions were large, quotations buoyant -- intrinsic values dominant.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- William S. Devery's cohorts throng the hotel corridors and the streets to-night, predicting that dire things will happen if their leader is kept out of the convention to-morrow. His contest was considered by the Committee on Contested Seats at its meeting this afternoon and evening, and, while no official announcement of the result of that body's deliberations was made, the opinion generally expressed is that Devery will be kept out.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- September wheat to-day sold at the highest price recorded on the Board of Trade since the Leiter deal in 1898, the price reaching 95 cents, and but for the leniency of the longs the price might, have been advanced indefinitely, as all available supply was practically in the hands of one or two traders.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- David B. Hill, after calling into consultation the leaders of every county delegation in the State, authorized his confidential advisers to let it be known to-night that the following ticket would be presented at the convention to-morrow:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions is as follows:

The trial of Edward F. Croker, Chief of Department was continued before and by Commissioner Sturgis at Fire Headquarters yesterday, and proceeded, as on the first day, through a storm of objections from John J. Delany, the accused's counsel. A feature of the day's proceedings was the appearance on the witness stand of Deputy Chief Charles D. Purroy.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- Money was in keen demand to-day, partly to meet the new Cape loan installment. Discounts were firm. Business on the Stock Exchange was overshadowed at the opening by a break in Americans, which impressed all sections, though the general depression was not quite as acute as yesterday.

Lieut Commander William V. Bronaugh, executive officer of the United States battleship Kearsarge, committed suicide yesterday in his cabin on that vessel, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, by shooting himself in the head with a revolver. The event caused a sensation at the yard, where several vessels of the North Atlantic Squadron are now lying.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Major Gen. Charles F. Roe, the commander of the National Guard of the State of New York, was injured to-night by being thrown from his horse in front of the Summer home of J.P. Morgan. His condition is not serious.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- The weather conditions continue their rapid changes. The disturbance on the Southern New England coast has passed out, the Middle West one has reached the eastern lower lake region with increased intensity and a third one has developed during the day over Colorado, with a high area of marked proportions to the immediate northward.

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- Commenting upon Secretary Hay's note to the Powers on the treatment of the Roumanian Jews The Times's Paris correspondent says that the French Government must not be expected to show any very great eagerness in supporting the contention of the United States.

Charges were filed yesterday with Police Commissioner Partridge by Inspector Cortright against Inspector Adam Cross, Capt. Charles L. Albertson, and Capt. John D. Herlihy. The charges are the result of the investigation by the special committee appointed by the Mayor into the conduct of the police at the riots on the east side which were incident to the funeral of Rabbi Joseph on July 30.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30. -- There was marked and general improvement in the local market to-day. Trading was active, 51,771 shares of stock and $123,000 bonds changing hands. During the morning few brokers cared to accept buying orders, but in the afternoon all this was changed, and the wires between here and New York were kept busy.

Official announcement of the organization of the shipping combination was made late yesterday afternoon in the office of J.P. Morgan Co. by Charles Steele, a member of that firm, in the presence of Robert Bacon and Sir Clinton E. Dawkins, also partners of Mr. Morgan. It disclosed the following facts: The name of the combination is to be the International Mercantile Marine Company.
SARATOGA. Oct. 1 -- The speech that Nathan Straus desired to make in the convention, when he was ruled out of order, was as follows:

An important step was taken in the silk fraud case yesterday, when Gen. Henry L. Burnett, the United States District Attorney, commenced a civil action against A.S. Rosenthal and Martin L. Cohn, composing the firm of A.S. Rosenthal Co., of 43 Greens Street, to recover $1,035,899. This amount, it is alleged, represents what was lost by the Government, together with penalties due on entries of Japanese silk which, it is alleged, were fraudulent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The totals of the naval estimates for 1904 were made public at the Navy Department to-day. There are over nine millions less than the amount asked for by Secretary Long last year. The estimates for 1903 were $98,910,984, and for this year they amount to $82,426.030.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The first quarterly period of the fiscal year 1903 closed yesterday with a highly favorable showing for the Treasury. At the close of the first month of the quarter there was a deficit of nearly $9,000,000. This was reduced by the operations of August to $1,552,064. The statement issued to-day for September shows that the excess of receipts for the month was $11,025,583, and for the three months $9,009,909.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The monthly comparative statement of Government receipts and expenditures shows that for the month of Septem, 1902, the total receipts were $48,580,381, an increase of over $4,000,000 as compared with September, 1901. The expenditures for September were $37,554,798, leaving a surplus for the month of $11,000,000.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- John Cunneen of Erie County is a lawyer with offices in Buffalo. He was born in Ireland, but came to this country when a boy. He was educated in the public schools in Rochester and began the practice of law at Albion.

Harmony was not a distinctive feature of the Republican Convention in the Nineteenth Senate District last evening before it named ex-Assemblyman William H. Smith of the Twenty-third Assembly District to succeed Senator Samuel Scott Slater in the upper branch of the Legislature. Some very severe remarks were uttered by William Sherer, manager of the Clearing House; ex-Judge W.M.K. Olcott, and others.

The general disappointment at the nomination of Mr. COLER will be in some measure allayed by the straightforward, sound, and firm declarations of the Democratic platform upon the public questions which now chiefly concern the people of New York. Against an opponent so formidable and well intrenched as Gov. ODELL the Democrats had need to put forward the best and strongest candidate who could be persuaded to take the nomination.

The Trustees of the Peabody Education Fund, which is devoted to higher education in the Southern States, held their fortieth meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. They received the report of the officers and of the general agent, and made plans for the distribution of the income for the coming year.
The "Devery Special," bearing the ex-Deputy Commissioner of Police and his friends back from the Saratoga Convention, at 11:40 o'clock last night, reached Thirty-fourth Street and Eleventh Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Princeton defeated Swarthmore here to-day in the opening football game of the season by a score of 18 to 0. Both teams found difficulty in playing on the muddy field, and they played poorly, fumbles and poor passes showing up frequently. A brilliant run of Hart's and McClave's centre dive scored the first touch-down after eighteen minutes' play.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 1 -- There was some buying of Seaboacds at fractionally better figures, due to a growing conviction that the system is likely to occupy a position which may develop better ultimate results for it than if it were to go in the Louisville deal on proportionate terms. Holders of the stock claim it is a bull point, it matters not how the sequel may turn.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. Lorillard Spencer are at their villa for the Autumn.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to your editorial of this morning I beg to say:

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Two of the six parts into which Bach's "Christmas Oratorio" is divided were sung in this evening's festival concert. The soloists were Mme. Marie Zimmerman, Miss. Janet Spencer, Theodore Van Yorx, and Frederic Martin.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- As usual the British press has completely misunderstood the gist of the latest development in the shipping combination, attributing it to motives which do not exist, and coupling with it weird secret agreements that were never contemplated.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- George R. Finch of Warren County, candidate for Slate Treasurer, comes from an old and distinguished family in the northern part of the State. He has for years been active in business and is an official in several large corporations. He was born at Sandy Hill, Washington County, in 1856.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Rain and miserable golfing conditions again in the second day's play of the women's National golf championship tournament took the snap entirely out of the competitions. The gallery was small, and, in justice to the players, the committee postponed the second match play round until to-morrow, when the third round will also be finished.

The Bostock animal show will open tonight in St. Nicholas Garden. All told there are perhaps 400 animals to be used for the exhibition and trick purposes. The Garden is incircled by steel cages, and an arena has been built.
SARATOGA, Oct. 1 -- In nominating Bird S. Coler of Kings for Governor, John L. Shea of Kings said in part:

A remarkable steeplechase, with a more remarkable result, was run at the Gravesend track yesterday, when, after all the horses save one fell, the stout, cross-country mare Miss Mitchell actually won the race in a jog trot. Miss Mitchell was the outsider in the betting, while the other three runners started at about equal prices.

With the second trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams only a few days distant, the announcement was made yesterday at the Criminal Courts Building that several witnesses against the accused man -- one of them at least of vital importance to the prosecution -- are missing.

The wedding of Goelet Gallatin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Gallatin, and Miss Edith Church Post, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Post, was celebrated yesterday in the picturesque little ivy-grown Church of St. Anne's, Bayport, L.I., by the Rev. Dr. Huntington of Grace Church, this city.

The plot, 27.2 by 120, at the northeast coraer of Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street has been sold by John Notman. Mr. Notman is at present in Europe and at his office in this city no additional details of the transaction were obtainable. It is understood that the purchaser will erect a handsome residence on the site.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- To-day's borrowing was extremely light, and the banks were giving their attention largely to the payment of quarterly interest and dividends. Rates both for call and time loans are nominally the same as have been quoted all along of late. Sterling exchange continues firm in tone.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- A dreary morning, sloppy streets, lowering skies, and drizzling rain greeted the delegates to the Democratic State Convention this morning and put somewhat of a damper on the proposed parade of the clubs front Albany and Troy and the New York delegation.

The wedding of Miss Alice Van B. Foos, daughter of Mrs. Lamar Foos, (Miss Mary King Fellows,) and Dr. Theodorus Bailey is to be celebrated on Saturday, Nov. 1, in the Church of the Incarnation, at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Miss Foos's sister, Miss Elsie Van K. Foos, will be her maid of honor.

President BAER of Reading, in giving the public assurances that there is no need of worrying as to the coal supply for the coming Winter, seems to have spoken without the deliberation which a man in his position should exercise in making an announcement so important. No matter how quickly the strike ends there is a shortage of eight to ten millions of tons which cannot be made up between this and Spring.

Price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday were highly irregular, some issues advancing and others declining. The volume of trading fell off materially, total dealings barely approximating 950,000 shares, as compared with Tuesday's figures of practically 1,200,000 shares.
SARATOGA, Oct. 1 -- Following is the platform adopted by the State Democrats in convention at Saratoga to-day:
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The demand for money slackened a little in the market to-day. About $45,000,000 changed hands in connection with various interest and dividend payments.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Yale students went on the rampage to-night, assaulted policemen, and created a general disturbance that finally involved a squad of policemen in a pitched battle with them. Three of the students in the crowd were placed under arrest with much difficulty, their friends endeavoring by main force to wrest them from the officers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- As the outcome of the Cabinet conferences held yesterday and to-day, and also of Secretary Root's investigation in New York, the President this afternoon telegraphed to John Mitchell and the leading anthracite coal operators, asking them to come to Washington and talk with him about the strike situation at 11 o'clock Friday morning.

E.J. Pelikan, a diamond broker living at 51 West One Hundred and Eleventh Street, denounced the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in unmeasured terms, last evening for the detention of his ten year old son Irving, who was held as a witness, and for the refusal of the officers of the society to permit him to see the boy.
SARATOGA, Oct. 1 -- In assuming the Chairmanship of the Democratic Convention, Martin W. Littleton said: "Gentlemen of the Convention:

Prices were firm in the outside market yesterday, but there were few stocks in which the fluctuations were of sufficient importance to attract special attention. Trading was on a somewhat smaller scale than on the earlier days of the week, the Rock Island stocks and others which had beep very active showing relatively small totals yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Yale played an Interesting football game this afternoon with Tufts College and came out with a lesson well learned. Tufts scored a touch-down and added a goal, making 6 points. The Yale eleven made a total of 34 points, and so won handily, but would have been satisfied with a much smaller score could the touch-down scored against them have been erased.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The one surprise, except to a few insiders, that was found in the platform was the plank declaring that the Government should own the anthracite coal fields, acquiring them by right of eminent domain. There had been no hint even that such a plank was to be inserted.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Rear Admiral James E. Jouett, United States Navy, retired, died at his home, The Anchorage, Sandy Spring, Md., this morning.

SARATOGA. Oct. 1 -- William S. Devery's political downfall took place to-day. He was read out of the Democratic State Convention on charges that his election had been accomplished by the grossest frauds which have been practiced at a primary contest under the new law.

William Nelson Cromwell, general counsel for the New Panama Canal Company, who returned Tuesday from Paris, where he went to examine the titles of the Panama Canal property, gave out a statement yesterday disclosing the results of his work in France. Mr. Cromwell finds that the titles to the property are unquestionable.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Charles N. Bulger was born at Volney, N.Y., Aug. 19, 1851. He was educated at the district schools, and entered Falley Seminary in 1868. He remained at the seminary but two years, and then began the study of law in the office of Stephens Pardee at Fulton, N.Y.
SARATOGA, Oct. 1 -- The Democratic Convention to-day nominated the following State ticket:

The invitation of President ROOSEVELT to Messrs. BAER, TRUESDALE, THOMAS, FOWLER, and MITCHELL, to meet him on Friday, "in regard to the failure of the coal supply, which has become a matter of vital concern to the whole Nation," is discreetly worded and the gentlemen addressed cannot very well decline it.

The reply of the City Magistrates to the report of the special committee that investigated the east side riots on the occasion of the funeral of Chief Rabbi Joseph was received by Mayor Low yesterday. The imputations in the report are resented. Mayor Low declined to comment on the communication.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 1 -- The text of the decision of Judge Amidon of the United States Circuit Court rendered in the case of Peter Power and Camille Weidenfeld against the Northern Pacific Railway Company, was made public to-day. Peter Power was the original plaintiff in the action, and by it sought to enjoin the Northern Pacific Railway Company from transferring its stock to the Northern Securities Company.

The letter from Mr. GEORGE F. BAER, President of the Reading Railroad, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, does not warrant any change in the point of view taken in the editorial article of the day before in which some suggestions were offered as to his duty is the representative of the anthracite operators.

In the Congress conventions held by the Democrats of New York and Richmond counties last night, the surprises were the turning down of Perry Belmont and Oliver H. P. Belmont in favor of Timothy D. Sullivan and William R. Hearst respectively, in the Eighth and Eleventh Districts.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- There will probably be a disagreement at the meting to-morrow of the Republican Committee on Resolutions to frame the State Republican platform, for the platform is asserted to be all written, and is said to be the work of Senator Lodge

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The Rev. Charles Tyler Olmsted, until recently the vicar of St. Agnes's Chapel, New York, was consecrated Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Church in the Diocese of Central New York in Grace Church, this city, to-day. Dr. Olmsted was formerly rector of Grace Church

The most solemn celebration in the Jewish calendar, ushered in on Wednesday evening, was continued yesterday. The climax will be the Day of Atonement, Oct. 11. Yesterday is known in the Bible as the Feast of the Seventh Month, the blowing of the trumpet being its ceremonial accompaniment. Not until rabbinic times did it develop into the New Year.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 2 -- President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers, accompanied by District Presidents Nicholls, Duffy and Pahy, left here this evening for Washington, via Philadelphia Mr. Mitchell conferred with the District Presidents through the day. It is not known what policy the Executive Board of the Miners' Union will pursue at the conference.

We hope that Mayor Low is gratified with the result of his action, in securing the rescinding of the approval of the Rapid Transit Commission of the franchise for the terminal improvements of the Pennsylvania Railroad. It would be a pity if the universal disgust and disappointment caused by this action was not offset by one faint glimmer of satisfaction on the part of the public officer who was instrumental in bringing it about.

Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, in a speech at the public hearing yesterday on the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel franchise, said he thought the city ought to be ashamed of itself to take any money from the railroad in payment for the franchise. He was the representative of the Chamber of Commerce that had asked the Rapid Transit Commission to adopt the tunnel franchise despite the objections of the labor unions.

He was the representative of the Chamber of Commerce that had asked the Rapid Transit Commission to adopt the tunnel franchise despite the objections of the labor unions.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- Some of the financial papers think the Relehsbank will follow the Bank of England's course and raise its rate of discount, in a few days, half or one per cent. It is pointed out that the demands on the bank are very heavy, for quarterly settlements. But the situation is already improving in the open market, the rate having fallen one-eighth to-day
The meeting at Washington to-day, called by the President of the United States, is an incident which appeals powerfully to the imagination, it is in every respect a remarkable incident.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The Bank of England's rate of discount was increased from 3 to 4 per cent, yesterday.

Payne. floor leader of the Republican Party in the House of Representatives, declared that to place the "trust-made" articles on the free tariff list would be a remedy worse than the disease.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 2. -- Thomas F. Barrett, President of the Westchester Traction Company, with offices at 115 Broadway, New York, was arrested here to-day on a charge of assault, and is now the defendant in a civil suit for $5,000 damages. The alleged assault took place during a meeting of the stockholders of the Danbury and Harlem Traction Company in the law offices of Judge James E. Walsh in this city.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The President has directed the advancement to the grade of Brigadier General of the following:

In the Eighth District Republican Congress Convention, held at 3 St. Luke's Place, Congressman Montague Lessler, who defeated Perry Belmont in the special election, was nominated. Under the reapportionment the district is strongly Democratic, and Mr. Lessler will have to fight Senator T. D. Sullivan.

A feature of the trial yesterday at Fire Headquarters of Chief of Department Edward F. Croker was the cross-examination by Mr. Delany, counsel for the accused, of Capt. Isaac Fisher, now in charge of the repair shops, who qualified as an expert in hydraulics and hydrostatics for the prosecution.

The court of inquiry named by Gov. Odell to investigate charges brought by Major Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment against Col. William G. Bates and Surgreon T.T. Marsh of the same regiment, said to have made false certifications to the State Board of Audit concerning losses sustained by them in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory fire, held its second session last evening in the Twelfth Regiment Armory.

A large number of spectators greeted Bostock's Animal Show, at its first performance in the St. Nicholas Garden, Sixtysixth Street and Columbus Avenue, last evening. It was after 11 o'clock before the last act was ended.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The " Iowa idea" came to the surface to-night at a mass meeting under the auspices of the National League of Republican Clubs, which met in annual convention here to-day.

Snyder, banker and promoter, on the charge of bribery in connection with the passage of the Central Traction bill was resumed, Frederick G. Uthoff, who was a member of the city council in April, 1898, was put on the stand by the State.

Evelyn B. Baldwin, the arctic explorer, who was in command of the expedition fitted out by William Ziegler arrived from England yesterday on the White Star liner Germanic. He was apparently in good health and good spirits. He was not inclined to discuss the criticisms that have been made concerning his management of the expedition by the artist J. Knowles Hare and other members who have returned to this country.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Two strong features from the popular point of view distinguished to-day's concerts in the festival series. In the afternoon Ossip Gabrilowitsch made his first appearance in Worcester and called forth the usual frantic demonstration accorded to a brilliant pianist.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- The coal Presidents en route from New York City to Washington arrived here in their special train at 6:20 P. M. President Baer of the Heading Company joined the party here. To this point the train consisted of a passenger coach and the private car Atlas. Here the coach was taken off, and President Baer's private car Philadelphia was attached.

SCRANTON. Fenn,. Oct. 2 -- Sentiment among the representatives of the coal operators here has undergone a change since yesterday regarding the action of President Roosevelt in assuming the role of an intermediary to settle the strike.

Sir Cavendish Boyle, Governor of New-foundland, is at the Holland House on his way to England. He is going there on a personal visit partly, but largely to discuss with members of the British Government the political conditions of Newfoundland. He said last evening that Newfoundland expects to derive great benefit from the reciprocity treaty which it is hoped the Premier, Sir Robert Bond, will succeed in negotiating with the United States.

MANCHESTER Oct. 3 -- The Daily Despatch this morning asserts that the terms of a British syndicate for a fast service of steamships between Montreal and Liverpool, Bristol, and London have been accepted.

MANCHESTER Oct. 3 -- The Daily Despatch this morning asserts that the terms of a British syndicate for a fast service of steamships between Montreal and Liverpool, Bristol, and London have been accepted.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- President Roosevelt's intervention in the coal strike attracts great attention in this country. Pending its result business in the American department of the Stock Exchange was yesterday virtually at a standstill, and the coal market is certain to be strongrly affected.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- Although a large number of books are published in London every week, and the book trade is apparently in a most prosperous condition, the publishers are not in good spirits, and insist that prosperity has not yet come to them.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3. -- The out-of-town absorption of Atlantic Coast Line stock was the sole feature of to-day's local market. There was some home purchasing on the long side, on the theory that the demand from other quarters will carry the stock higher. The general tone of this market is beneficially affected by this bullish point.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The announcement of the arrnagements between the British Government and the Cunard Line, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times, has created some excitement at Ham- burg.

"The Book of Joshua," among sacred books, occupies a somewhat similar position to that of " Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress " among the secular. Both bring before us in a very graphic manner truths of personal importance because they relate to spiritual experiences. The one, however, is a work of fiction.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. -- Considerable strength was displayed in this market up to the time report came out that the Controller had overruled Secretary Shaw. Weakness was quickly developed, but the only damage was the loss by certain stocks of a part or a whole of their early gain. Union Traction, which had been up to 48 3/4, a new high record, fell off to 48.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Oct. 3. -- The Leyland liner Bostonian, Capt. Foote, fifteen days from London for Boston, Mass., with a general cargo, arrived here this afternoon towing the German steamer Pallanza, Capt. Schaeffer, fifteen days from Hamburg for New York, with a general cargo.

Senator Timothy D. Sullivan, Charles F. Murphy, and a majority of the Assembly district leaders of Tammany Hall appeared at the Wigwam yesterday to hold an informal conference. Senator Sullivan made an open statement about his nomination for Congress and the "turning down" of Perry Belmont.

Henry van Dyke's New Book. Henry van Dyke has just arranged a new volume of short sto- ries which will be published in the middle of this month. There are nine stories in all, and they are grouped under the title "The Blue Flower."

THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS printed, on Aug. 23 last, an account of Dr. Watts's rarest books. That article described his "Horae Lyricae," 1706, a presentation copy of which sold for u59 at Sotheby's July 30, 1902; his "Hymns and Spiritual Songs," 1707, which brought u140 Dec. 4, 1901, and a presentation copy of his "Divine Songs," 1715, which brought u155 July 28, 1902.

We have already spoken in terms of the most cordial approval (and then merely in echo, so to speak, of the public chorus of praise) of Mr. J.M. Barrie's serial, "The Little White Bird," which for three months has occupied those pages in Scribner's Magazine to which the regular readers have first turned.
Isaac W. Brewer, Surgeon, is honorably discharged to take effect Nov. 7, his services being no longer required.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The convention of the National Republican League was brought to a close to-night with a mass meeting in the First Regiment Armory. The principal speaker of the evening was United States Senator Albert J. Beveridge of Indiana. Senator Beveridge's address was devoted largely to a discussion of the attitude of the two parties toward young men.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday expressed his apprehension on account of the crowded calendars awaiting the criminal courts, which convene next Monday. He declared that unless additional facilities for the trying of cases be provided any attempt on the part of his office to keep up with the pressure of work would be futile, and announced his intention to call upon Gov. Odell for the appointment of an ex- traordinary Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court.

Whatever may have been the true cause of the death of Emile Zola early last Monday morning in his house, 21 Rue de Bruxelles, Paris, enough is known to show how utterly out of harmony it was with his life as he had lived it. That life was one of seclusion, patience, and constant toil.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- At the temporary White House to-night the following official statement was given out concerning the coal conference to-day:

While the evening rush through Park Row to the Brooklyn Bridge was at its height last evening, the underground system of the Third Avenue Electric line became short circuited opposite the bridge entrance, causing an alarming pyrotechnical display. Crowded north-bound cars were following each other at short headway when one became disabled and the current began its erratic conduct.
BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Locally the market still continues firm, with the demand, however, light, and with going rates practically unchanged.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 3. -- The news from Washington that no agreement was reached at the conference had a de- pressing effect on all interests here. Some of the local operators who were interviewed think that the miners, now that all hope of arbitration seems to be gone, will grad- ually return to work.

For an hour -- the closing hour -- yesterday's security market was in turmoil. The panicky conditions of last Monday were reassertive. Conspicuous investment stocks fell whole points between sales, and declines of 4, 5, and 6 points scarred the whole market. A lie was responsible for it all.

THE appearance of a new and elegant edition of "Walden" may afford excuse, if excuse be needed, for recalling some of the facts about Thoreau's success, or lack of success, as an author. His first book, "Week on the Concord and Merrimac Rivers," was published by a firm, now forgotten.

It is a very long story, almost biographical in character, Mr. Jerome K. Jerome writes. One might fancy that the author presents his own personal experiences. We are forbidden, however, to associate too closely the book and the man. But if the narrative is an interesting one, as is "Paul Kelver," it is a compliment to think of such relationship being possible.

Big Tom, the Indian elephant of the Cen- tral Park Menagerie, was put to death yesterday morning in accordance with a sen- tence passed several days since by a court consisting of Park Commissioner Willcox, Director Smith of the menagerie, and Keeper Snyder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The monthly report of the statistician of the Department of Agri- culture shows the average condition of cotton on Sept, 25 to have been 58.3 per cent, as compared with 64 on Aug. 26; 61.4 on Sept. 25, 1901; 67 on Oct. 1, 1900, and a ten-year average of 68.9.

The fourth day of the Westchester County Fair and Horse Show, held at White Plains yesterday, was the most successful Friday in the history of the association, the fine weather having the effect of bringing out a good-sized crowd. The programme consisted of two fast classes in pacing, one in trotting, and a running race in half-mile heats, and the judging of eleven classes in the show ring.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- An unexpected attempt to amend the platform presented at the Republican State Convention to-day caused a sudden but very brief storm. The proposition to amend was overwhelmingly voted down. The ticket nominated was as follows:
Trade reports to the several commercial agencies grow better and better. Bradstreet's summarizes the situation as follows:

Expensively dressed and wearing jewel- ry said to be worth $20,000, a woman, giv- ing her name as Mrs. Edna Barton, was arrested last night and taken to the East Sixty-seventh Street Police Station, charged with having stolen a gold watch valued at $75. The complainant was Selma Rothschild, a daughter of Mrs. Pauline Rothschild, who keeps a boarding house at 127 East Sixty-first Street.

It is clearly not easy to weigh justly the claims to admiration and respect of a writer in a foreign language, but a writer who is known wherever his widely sown tongue is read, and known through translation in a half-dozen tongues other than his own, will inevitably have his claims weighed, whether justly or not.

The trial of Edward F. Croker, Chief of Department, was continued at Fire Head- quarters yesterday, and the proceedings were, as on the four previous days, punctu- ated with the strenuous objections of John J. Delany of counsel for the accused, and frequent clashes between him and Commis- sioner Sturgis.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- New York's baseball team lost both games of the double-header played here to-day. The local men won the first game with heavy hitting in the third inning, during which they scored six times on a base on balls, an error, and five hits. In the second contest the visitors held the lead up to the seventh inning, in which Moran sent the ball over the left-field fence for a home run.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 3. -- Unfair means of obtaining a valuable property at Rockville Centre ware charged against Philip H.F. Wiedersun, a real estate operator, of 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, in an action instituted by Mrs. Susannah Merrltt, seventy-six years old, and heard yesterday by Justice Gaynor at this place.

The Rev. Richard Tjader's International Union Church, which was opened for missionary work in what used to be St. James Episcopal Church, Seventy-second Street, near Lexington Avenue, at a cost of about $100,000, has been closed. It is said that the father-in-law of the Rev. Richard Tjader, Samuel Thorne, furnished the money.

The Westchester Horse Show at White Plains will close to-day, with every prospect of a large attendance. On the list for this afternoon are another of the polo games in the Squadron A open tournament at Van Cortlandt Park and several weddings.

THERE is still a certain number of readers to whom the appearance of a new novel by Henry James is the most interesting event in current fic- tion. We say "still" advisedly, for it is doubtful whether there are as many of them as there were ten years ago.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In accordance with my usual custom, I was this afternoon reading THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS and was gratified to find a word of commendation from your correspondent "Philistine" for the now apparently forgotten works of George Lawrence.

Tammany has sunk to a lower and dirtier depth than it ever reached before in the Congressional nominations this Fall. The nomination of TIMOTHY D. SULLIVAN in the Eighth District is so disgraceful and revolting that a petition to wipe that district off the political map and leave it unrepresented would receive thousands of signatures in the city.
The country will await with intense interest the next step in the efforts of the President to solve the distressing problem presented by the actual and prospective reduction of the coal supply.

For the first time within a week the Gravesend track was in fairly good condition yesterday, and with the changed going public form came to the rescue of the betting crowd, four favorites, three of these at odds on, winning in the course of the afternoon.

PARIS, Oct. 3. -- Contrary to previous announcements, ex-Capt. Dreyfus will not attend Emile Zola's funeral to-morrow. This decision was taken as the result of an interview with Mme. Zola, who pleaded with Dreyfus not to participate in the ceremony because his presence might lead to disorders.

Fur is so much in vogue that an evening gown shows embroidery in imitation of it. The gown is of white velvet, covered with black and white figures in imitation of ermine tails set at regular intervals all over the frock. This will be at least more comfortable than the startling frock of real ermine worn by Edna May at the Horse Show year before last.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- When President Mitchell and his lieutenants returned to their hotel after the conference they found a great crowd awaiting them, and for several minutes thereafter were fored to hold an impromptu levee, during which several hundred persons surged about the mine workers' President and shook hands with him, assuring him of their good-will.

"American Wood Engravings" is the title chosen for the new exhibition arranged by the Print Department of the New York Public Library. The work shown is mainly of the period from 1875 to the present. F. Juengling, E. Kingsley, F.S. King, F. French, T. Cole, T. Johnson, H. Wolf, P. Aitken, R.A. Miller, G. Kruell, E. Heinemann, and R.G. Tietze are all well represented.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 3. -- President Edward Flynn of the United Mine Workers of America, District of Alabama, stated to-day that he had issued orders for all the miners of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railway Company at the Blue Creek and Blockton mines to suspend work on Monday next.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- Gov. Odell has now taken a hand to check the revolt in the Republican ranks in the Fifth Judicial District over the candidacy of Attorney General John C. Davies for Supreme Court Justice. Mr. Davies, after a talk with the Governor this afternoon, departed for the scene of disturbance to check the growing opposition to him, if possible.

THE public, remembering Mr. Eden Phillpotts's previous books, can but open with pleasant anticipations his latest novel, "The River." He is not Mr. Hardy, but he belongs to the same school; he has studied his model well, he has a large share of natural talent, and the results of his literary labors have so far possessed a distinct artistic value.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- The contract for building the battleship Louisiana was awarded to-day by Secretary Moody to the Newport News Company, the bid of that company having been the lowest presented -- $3,900,000.

James Lindsay Gordon, counsel for Alderman William Dickinson of Brooklyn, yesterday hit back at the latter's accusers. Alderman Dickinson was arrested on the charge of attempted bribery, the complainant being Street Cleaning Commissioner Woodbury. A letter from the Brooklyn Alderman, offering to vote for streetcleaning appropriations in return for the reinstatement of a driver in the department, was the ground of the complaint.

Extracts of the annual report of the New York Central for the fiscal year ended June 30 last were made public yesterday. The report shows that the company has acquired 30,000 shares of the capital stock of the American Express Company at 150 a share, which is one-sixth of the capital stock of that company.
In their criticism of the nomination of Mr. COLER it will be well for the voters of the State not to forget everything they ever knew about Mr. ODELL.

The movement in some of the larger art centres of the world to express sympathy for Venice in the collapse of her Grand Campanile was started by the National Arts Club of New York soon after the disaster, and followed some weeks later by the Royal Academy of London, whose President, the painter Poynter, issued an appeal first to Academicians and then in the columns of The London Times to the public.

MRS. A. MURRAY SMITH'S aim in the volume under notice is "to link together the various memories of the dead," as the long chain is found in Westminster Abbey. The task proposed is an arduous one. For the perfecting of it history must be consulted for the "Roll-Call of Westminster" begins before the Conquest and ends almost to-day.

The Clearing House Committee on Nomi- nations met yesterday and placed James Stillman, President of the National City Bank, in nomination for the office of President, which is now occupied by George F. Baker. The annual meeting is to be on Tuesday next.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your highly readable issue of Aug. 23 one of your editorials entitled " Recognition of Genius" is open to discussion. Though a slight tinge of humor seems to color the article's trend of thought, it is to be hoped that you did not intend to slur genius.

THE world is cumbered with them," complained the wise man, two thousand years ago. "There are books here in Jerusalem, and in Thebes, and in Babylon, and in Nineven; even in Tyre and Sidon among the Philistines, no doubt one would find books.

HARPER BROTHERS will publish next week Anthony Hope's new novel, " The Intrusions of Peggy," which tells about a young and charming widow and her friend Peggy, who mixes in with other people's affairs only to make them happy in the end.
Vincent A. Ryan has sold for the Bunze estate the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 537 Madison Avenue, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets, on lot 25 by 100.

Wall Street was treated yesterday to what, in the opinion of many traders, was one of the most deliberately planned and cleverly executed " scoops " ever worked in the stock market. As a result of it, prices on the Stock Exchange broke in the short space of fifteen minutes anywhere from 2 to 6 points.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Some of the objections to the present Dingley tariff are so evidently well taken that they should be kept before the people.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 4 -- Charles T. Wales, manager of the Empire Foundry, was arrested this afternoon on the complaint of Charles C. Cole, President of the Iron Moulders' Union, charging him with atrocious assault and threats.

ENGINEERS on the rapid transit subway were beginning to think six months ago that they had overcome all the obstacles worth mentioning. Now, at the eleventh hour, they have found to one of the last streets to be opened problems as novel and arduous as any encountered in the earlier stages of the work.

LONDON. Oct. 4 -- "Chill October" has begun with a touch of Winter after the most unsummerlike Summer experienced here for many years. The holidays are over and the political truce has expired. Conservative, Liberal, and Irish politicians are stepping into the ring of party conflict.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- A reception was given on Wednesday at the Hotel Continental by Mrs. Humphrey Moore, wife of the American artist, and herself a painter of note, in honor of the Duquesa de Denia of Madrid. Among those present were the Due de Lerma, the Due de Pomar, the Marquis de Casa Riera, Mrs. Verner Reed, Mrs. J. Banford Saltus, and the Comtesse de Lambertye.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Sept. 29 "Housekeeper" asks information relative to soft coal, complaining that the soft coal supplied in this market is all dust.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 4 -- Senator George G. Vest of Missouri, who is in this city for the treatment of his eyes, in an interview to-day on the coal situation, said:

The baying of six large German board-hounds, the roars of several fat lions, and the snarls of tigers, leopards, and pumas furnished a blood-curdling accompaniment yesterday afternoon at the New York Theatre to a rehearsal in the adjoining roof garden. The animals belonged to Carl Hagenbeck's collection, and they will perform in the theatre to-morrow night and afterward.
MACHINES to do "cobbling," repairIng worn-out shoes, is the latest. The process is described as follows by The Providence Journal:

The whereabouts of Dr. William F. Bates, the wealthy physician, who left his home, at 567 Park Avenue, on Aug. 30, ostensibly to visit a patient, and has not been seen since by his family, are not known yet, A telegram from the missing man's father in Washington says that he is not in Europe, as had been supposed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from the Bishop of Central Pennsylvania printed in your columns to-day, coming as it does from an eminent Churchman familiar, presumably, to a high degree with the situation in the coal regions, and one feeling much sympathy for the suffering miners resident in his diocese, is an interesting and important contribution to the literature or the present great strike.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Ex-Police Commissioner Andrews of New York, when he went to Berlin to study the police system of the German capital, found a force differently constituted from that, of London or Paris. For the police of Berlin, like other cities of Prussia, is practically under the Prussian Minister of the Interior.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The first game of the Military Academy football season was played here this afternoon, the cadets having for their antagonists the team from Tufts College. The times were fifteen and ten minute halves, and the result was 5 to 0 in favor of West Point. The field was a little sloppy, and on this account there was considerable fumbling.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- A mob of fully 5,000 sympathizers with the Hudson Valley Railway strikers paraded the streets here to-night, stopping all cars as they came through and storming the cars, breaking windows and cutting trolley ropes.

To The Editor of the New York Times: The coal situation has got to be met. It has got to be met within a month. Coal has got to be brought to market. Not in driblets, but in sufficient quantities to keep the people warm at home and at work and to keep up business and transportation.

WORKING in the vicinity of Rochester are F.W. Baldwin and three assistants of the United States Geological Survey of Washington. They are engaged in work on the topographic map of the United States, a job that the Government began about twenty years ago and which, it is thought, will require about one hundred years more to complete, says The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- "I am highly gratified at the result of our conference with President Roosevelt. Things have taken a turn for the better. The strike will begin to disintegrate, and we'll soon be getting in more coal," said President Baer to-day before starting for his home in Reading, where he will spend Sunday.

HOW to illuminate tastefully, brilliantly, and effectively the three new bridges that are to span the East River in a few years from now is New York's latest problem. The most difficult sort of a nut to crack, for such bridge illumination as this will be is altogether a new idea and quite without precedent.

One of the most remarkable enterprises ever controlled by women is to be opened Monday to the public for two weeks in the Madison Square Garden. It is an exhibition in which men will have no part, except as spectators. It is the boast of the management that every detail will be carried out by women.

THE most remarkable jumping horse in the world, Heatherbloom, the holder of the best records for high jumping and the season's star of the horse shows, has reopened the question of what may be the extreme limit attainable by a jumping horse.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Gen. Henderson certainly displays the qualities of a true American citizen. It required a large measure of courage and a rugged devotion to duty to take a step which may end a brilliant public career and deprive him of an opportunity to win greater laurels as a statesman.

THE dire plight into which Ostend has been cast by the abolition of the public gaming tables has been a source of anxiety to the municipality of the Belgian city and to the taxpayers, whose burdens were immensely lightened by the enormous revenues derived from the leasing of gambling rights.

Polo during the coming week will have its centre of activity at Van Cortlandt Park, Squadron A being the host and entertaining the local clubs in the first open tournament ever given by the squadron's polo club. It will also be the first big polo event ever played at Van Cortlandt, but the success of polo there this year is simply an indication of greater activity next year.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Two questions are at present occupying the attention of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs-that of Slam, with respect to which negotiations have been proceeding for several weeks, and that of Morocco, which cannot fall to come up as a subject of discussion in the Chamber as soon as the next session begins.

IN a cozy room in Main Hall. Vassar, a group of reunited college mates were gathered in the gloaming of an October afternoon. It was too dark to distinguish more than a recumbent silhouette or two on the high-backed window seat, and a broad couch occupied by chatting girls, with many gay pillows for a background.

THE sole outstanding novelty in fashionable Fall and Winter jewelry is detachable, plain gold underwear buttons. These are put up in sets of four and six, and can be had in varying sizes and weights. A thoroughly serviceable set of six can be obtained for $30, and this size gives evidence of being the most popular.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 4 -- Sensational developments came to light late this afternoon in the investigation of the wholesale graveyard robberies that have occurred in this vicinity during the last few months, when detectives unearthed ten bodies in the cellar of the Medical College of Indiana.

A North Hudson County Railway trolley car, in which were about eighty passengers, on their way to the Hoboken Ferry, had a narrow escape from plunging down the Palisades, a sheer fall of 100 feet, at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

BRONX BOROUGH'S "house of many mysteries," as the old Casanova mansion at Oak Point on Long Island Sound is known, will soon be a thing of the past. It is falling rapidly into decay, and bereft of all its surrounding beauty the structure is of little value except to a dealer in second-hand lumber, into whose bands it will probably fall in the course of a few months.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- Dullness was very marked on the local Stock Exchange to-day, only 18,210 shares and $48,000 bonds changing hands. Nearly one-half of the transactions were in Reading common, sold by New York and traders, Shorts bought. New York also sold United States Steel in this market, offerings being taken by an investment house on Fourth Street.
Discussing the general financial and commercial situation, John H. Davis Co., in their monthly financial circular, have this to say:
WHEN Mrs. Betterton gave the conductor a quarter and he refused to give her any change, all the passengers who got wind of the transaction waxed indignant according to their temperament.

Those interested in schemes for improving the condition of the poor of New York, through the provision of better domiciliary conditions in suburban settlements, will find much food for thought in the lately published report of the London County Council, which gives voluminous information concerning the various housing schemes, and sets forth the many difficulties which beset all attempts to provide better and cheaper homes for the wage earners of that city.

Squadron A began its open polo tournament, the first ever given by the troopers, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Two teams from the squadron met in opposition, and next Thursday Westchester and Rockaway will have the field. The game was closely and well contested, the Squadron A quartet finally winning by the slim margin of one-fourth of a goal, scoring 4 1/2 goals to 4 1/4 for the Freebooters.

The Presidents of the coal-carrying roads admitted yesterday, on their return from Washington after the unsuccessful attempt of President Roosevelt to bring about a settlement of the coal strike, that the situation was very serious. They do not profess to believe that there is not a coal famine, and can offer no remedy for the present state of affairs, except the return of the strikers to work, whenever that may be.

ALTHOUGH it wants three months of Santa Claus season, Christmas toys are already on the market. All Summer long the creators of children's novelties have been at work, and the retailer is laying in his stock.

Mascagni will inaugurate New York's music season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday evening next. His engagement here will be one of the most unique in the history of that historic building. This will be perhaps the first time a composer of world-wide renown has appeared there presenting and conducting his own works.

THE conversation has assumed a tinge of pessimism. It had to do, in fact, with the "meanest man" each of the party had ever known, and in each case the crowning act of "meanness" had been related. Suddenly the girl on the divan entered the arena.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A member of the Spanish Ministry, now in England, who was Questioned regarding the reiterated rumors of a Franco-Spanish alliance, in conjunction with Spain's increased naval programme, said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- It is believed here that a resort to proceedings against the coal-carrying roads on the charge of imposing unlawful carrying rates while possible, is improbable, on account of its impracticability to accomplish speedy results in the present emergency.

A COMMISSION firm in this city recently received from Wrangel, Alaska, a shipment comprising a number qt bundles of deer skins, each containing about seventy hides, and while this fact in itself has nothing of startling interest, the fact that the skins were bought in that locality for as low as 10 cents each might give one an inkling as to the plentiful supply of deer in the wilds of Alaska.

Paris newspapers are commenting on another outbreak of lunacy which one of that city's strongest men, a gladiator named Calmesnil, had the other day. The results of this attack are said to have been disastrous to several policemen. Calmesnil, who originally came from Marseilles, has been several times confined in asylums, but he always managed to leave these establishments in order to give exhibitions of his muscular powers at fairs.

At the end of the first week of actual play, Yale, which has played Trinity, Amherst, and Tufts, leads the Eastern college football teams in the total number of points scored, 97 to 6. Playing the same three teams last year Yale scored but 58 to 5. Harvard, playing Williams, Bowdoin, and Bates, has scored 51 to 6 points this year, while last year the total score with these three teams was 44 to 6.

THE latest wrinkle in the list or drug store accommodations is a neighborhood directory. A west side pharmacy makes a specialty in this commodity. It keeps a sheet of foolscap paper tucked up on the wall next to the camphor bottles, and whenever anybody in the vicinity makes a change of residence he writes his name and address in the local directory, and thus leaves a clue whereby all anxious inquirers may locate him.

After a stormy session of five hours. spent in discussing consolidation with the National Brotherhood of Painters, Deoo- rators, and Paperhangers, a mass meeting of members of the Amalgamated Painters and Decorators of New York and vicinity was adjourned at Cooper Union last evening without decisive action.

Burglars made a rich haul in the residence of Richard C. Veit, a five-story dwelling at 81 Convent Avenue, some time Friday night, escaping from Mrs. Veit's bedroom on the front of the second floor with jewelry valued at from $10,000 to $12,000 and a pocketbook containing $700 in cash.

THAT there is always room at the top is nowhere more fully demonstrated than in the great department stores of this country, from which there comes an incessant demand for men with energy and ideas. Of the mechanical, routine workers there is a large supply, and the number grows daily to the despair and irritation of proprietors and managers.

It is rather a remarkable state of affairs that with the Treasury of the United States holding more gold than any other Government in the world it was, nevertheless, only by heroic and altogether unprecedented action on the part of the Secretary of the Treasury that a financial panic of serious proportions was last week averted.

Through the International Mercantile Marine Company, recently formed by J. Pierpont Morgan, an arrangement has been made by which the poor will not suffer on account of the coal strike. To the Editor of The New York Times: To-day's Democratic State Convention has simply committed political suicide by nominating David B. Hill's man, Bird S. Coler. Hill sprung his vest-pocket candidate on the convention, and he was nominated, which insures an overwhelming defeat, just when the Democrats had a good fighting chance in a strongly Republican State.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 4 -- Monday will be Town Meeting Day in Connecticut. All the towns in the State, with the exception of those which have the Town and City Governments consolidated, will hold annual elections of officers and transact any other business that may be brought up for consideration.

According to some of the correspondents of London, papers who went through the South African war, it was not the series of victories which resulted from the tactics of Lord Roberts, not the surrender of Cronje, not the entry of the British troops into Bioemfontein and Johannesburg, which caused the Boers first to lose their belief that they were bound to succeed.

ALBANY, Oct. 4 -- The Democrats in five Senatorial and two Congressional districts have failed to get their certificates of nomination of their candidates on file in the office of the Secretary of State, as required by law. The time for filing the nominations of the several recognized political parties expired at midnight.

OUR bark," said the Ancient Mariner, "had reached 'bout seventy-seven degrees north latitude, an' up to that time the v'yage hed been purty fairly prosp'rous; but then the trouble began, an' fer a while things looked duberous. The ice closed in 'round us, an' fer more'n three weeks we was ground 'tween the floes, an' it begun to look 'at we'd never grit out.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two recent occurrences make pertinent inquiry into the Sub-Treasury system of the United States, and the question of how that system came to be established. The system is denounced by students of public finance, yet it seems to linger with a persistency comparable only with the vigor with which it is assailed.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- The National League baseball season ended here to-day wiah a double-header between the Boston and New York teams. Malarkey and Mathewson pitched in the first game, but the former kept New York's hits well scattered, while the local batters managed to bunch theirs, winning by 5 runs to 2.

The laying of the cornerstone of the new Custom House at Bowling Green on Tuesday afternoon next promises to be an impressive function, and as the building is to be the finest structure for the customs service in the United States representative citizens and representatives of some of the important mercantile organizations will attend the ceremony.

I HAVE no doubt, Madam," said the cashier, "that you are Mrs. --, the person named on this draft, but the rules of the bank require that you must be identified by somebody known to us before I can cash the paper for you."

A DISPATCH from Berlin describes some electrical experiments which may resuit in a great decrease in the number of losses of life by live wire. The statement is made that Prof. Armetieff, who is well known in electrical circles, has invented a safety suit for electrical workers, in which it is impossible to obtain a deadly shock of current.

October is above all others the ideal month of the year for touring. The roads, dried out by the Summer sun and the sprinkled by the early Fall rains, are in their very best condition, firm and yet elastic, the air is cool and refreshing, yet not too cool for comfort, and the foliage, tinged with bright autumnal tints, adds a new attraction to even the most familiar routes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- In finding the bodies of John H. Coffin, eleven years old, and Price Jennings, three years his senior, in a weed-grown field on the farm of Hulings Lippincott, on the Chew's Landing Road, near Haddon Heights, about seven miles southeast of Camden, the police have on their hands a mystery which so far has baffled them.

Cards have been issued by President Butler for a reception in honor of the newly appointed professors of Columbia University, to be held in Earl Hall on Saturday, Oct. 18, from 4 to 6 o'clock. Opportunity will then be afforded for the Trustees of the three corporations, for the professors and adjunct professors of the university, and a few personal friends to meet the new officers who are just beginning their work at Columbia.

Vacation ends for the Supreme, Surrogates', and City Courts to-day. The Special and Trial Terms will open to-morrow and remain in session, except for the Christmas holidays, until the end of next June. All the calendars are full, and in the list of cases are many of financial importance and general interest.

Absolutely the only difference between the coal operators and President MITCHELL is the recognition of the United Mine Workers' organization. That was the sole point at issue when the President's conference ended, that alone stands in the way of an immediate resumption of mining.

A reception was given last night by the County Committee and members of the Liberal Democratic Party at the rooms of the Manhattan Single Tax Club, in West Forty-second Street to some of the State candidates nominated at the Cooper Union convention last June. The meeting place was filled, and corncob pipes and cut plug were distributed.

DIVERSE as the plow and the automobile would seem at first glance, Dr. Gatling, the famous inventor of the gun that bears his name, has hitched the two together and made farming a "thing of beauty and a joy forever."

Gen. William Booth, the founder of the Salvation Army, was welcomed enthusiastically when he arrived yesterday morning on board the American liner Philadelphia. Fourteen tugs, carrying nearly 1,500 Salvationists, left the Battery at 6:30 o'clock for Quarantine, where the steamship was anchored.

Why doesn't it go to show that a man who will propose to one girl after another has a warm heart and a desire for domesticity? Perhaps there are some women who would not think so, but a good, practical woman who has a head as well as a heart, might feel that it was a good augury for a happy married life.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The joyous predictions of President Baer would be more convincing if they were a trifle more explicit. That pious and public-spirited gentleman is quoted in this morning's TIMES as saying:

HAVANA, Sept. 30 -- Every steamer from the north is bringing back large numbers of Cubans who went to the States early in the season to spand the heated months at some of the Summer resorts, preferably Long Branch and Saratoga, which have never lost their charm for, Cubans. When the family discusses the Summer trip it is taken for granted that they think of one of those two places as their destination.
Marczy de Zoldy, the Hungarian, is going to play the violin here this Fall, yesterday his press agent issued a statement containing some particulars about him. It reads in part as follows:

AS THE SEASON advances and the eastbound movement of freight begins to assume heavier proportions, the question as to whether there will be a car shortage is beginning to absorb the interest of shippers and railroad men. Two new factors have made their appearance in the solution of the problem.

-- If Mr. ARNOLD Fox, whose letter about union methods we published Friday, wrote as a representative, believer in labor organizations, he made some most amazingly unwise revelations, and, so tar as he could, justified the severest criticisms that ever have been directed against the principles and practices of unionism.

MANILA, Oct. 4 -- Capt. John J. Pershing's column has completely routed the Maciu Moros, in the Island of Mindanao, killing or wounding a hundred of them and capturing and destroying forty forts. Two Americans were wounded.

The market during the past week saw several times the two-edged battleaxe of forced liquidation and bear pressure swung effectively. Prices simply crumbled, stockholders capitulated before 20, 30, 35 per cent. money. Promises of Treasury "relief" measures had gone for naught before the more effective factors which were still operative to draw upon the life blood of the market.

If not in all, at least in some of the projected extensions to the Rock Island system there are tolerably plain indications that official activity is not to be confined exclusively to the development of freight business, but that the passenger branch of the service will claim considerable attention.

A NEW and pat illustration of the straight common sense laconically expressed in the dictum "Never play the other fellow's game," was furnished by the ex-Superintendent of the playing card department of a world-famous printing house during an impromptu "smoker" in his Nassau Street office last week.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Oct. 4 -- The fight over the Stratton millions was renewed to-day, when the executors named by the multi-millionaire appeared before Judge James A. Orr, in the County Court, and offered the will for probation.

Sir Michael Henry Herbert, who succeeds the late Lord Pauncfote as Ambassador Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from Great Britain to the United States, arrived yesterday morning from Liverpool on the Cunarder Campania. He was accompanied by Lady Herbert who was Miss Lella Wilson, a daughter of R.T. Wilson, the banker, of this city, and a sister or Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and of Mrs. Ogden Goelet.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Miss Genevieve Hecker of the Apawamis Club, Rye. N.Y., won the women's National golf championship of the United States to-day for the second time. She defeated in the final round of the women's tournament on the Brookline Club links Miss Louisa A. Wells of the home club by 4 up and 3 to play.

FISHKILL, LANDING, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The forty-second annual report of Dr. Henry E. Allison, Medical Superintendent of the Matteawan State Hospital, for the year ended Sept. 30, 1902, has just been issued. Under the present provisions of the State law no male inmates of penal institutions can be admitted who become deranged while serving sentences for felonies.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Princeton defeated Lehigh's football team here to-day by a score of 23 to 0. Princeton's strong defense kept the ball in Lehigh's territory through the same, but the offense was so weak in the opening half that no score could be made. At one time the ball was pushed thirty yards down the field, but a confusion of signals on Lehigh's one-yard line lost the ball.

WHEN the Aqueduct racing season opens this Fall there will be a new face seen in the betting ring -- a face that has probably been seen there many times before, sometimes taking in or dealing out money, as his luck may run. It will be "Boston," and he will be the first Chinese bookmaker to be seen about this section, if not in this country.

There is considerable difference of opinion among the residents and taxpayers of the Borough of the Bronx as to the exact location of the proposed grand union station, north of the Harlem River, which is believed to be the inevitable solution of the congested and dangerous traffic through the present Park Avenue tunnel of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad.

WILKESBARRE, Oct. 4 -- President John Mitchell, accompanied by District President T.D. Nichols of Scranton, arrived at strike headquarters from Washington at 9 o'clock to-night. District Presidents Thomas Duffy of Hazleton and John Fahy of Pottsville did not come to Wilkesbarre, but went direct to their respective homes.
MY FRIEND Wm. Shakespeare," said the Idiot, "was a wonderful man, but once in a while he made a mistake. Whether he did it for dramatic effect or not I don't know, but he did it, just the same."

A REMARKABLE discovery has been made in Celebes by Dr. Paul and Dr. Fritz Sarasin, the well-known explorers. While recently traversing that country they found a race of wild men concerning which nothing was before known.

The failure of President Roosevelt's effort to effect a compromise of the coal strike was the subject of general discussion in this city yesterday. Among those who expressed their views thereanent was ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt, who said:

AROUGH opal that was once part of the backbone of a prehistoric animal, and is now one of the most remarkable specimens of its kind in the world, has recently been found in Australia. The stone, which is in the rough, is remarkable for its size alone, which is 2 1/4 by 2 1/2 inches. It weighs 1,150 karats.

DOWN on the East River side a pushcart vendor of cheap books has recently taken his stand. His specialty is books for the seafaring men who abound in his immediate neighborhood, but with considerable shrewdness the enterprising purveyor of "something to read for everybody" has chosen for his location a spot whence he can tap ferryites as well as the mariners and wayfarers.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- There has been little done this week on the stock market except to watch events in New York and to shape a course accordingly. Secretary Shaw's latest relief measures had rather a startling effect, since they involved the immediate adoption by the Executive of measures which the week before were indicated as possible objects of legislation on the meeting of Congress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No matter how rapidly soft coal may be rushed to the Eastern markets; no matter if every hard coal miner returned to work to-morrow, we still have to face the appalling fact that the shortage of coal for the coming Winter will equal all that could have been produced by the hard coal miners during the strike.

A DISCOVERY, which is likely to have far-reaching influence in settling disputed Biblical questions, is announced to archaeologists by Mrs. Ghosn-el-Howie, late of Toronto, now of Mount Lebanon, Syria.

Lovers of baseball will find considerable interesting and instructive material in the first volume of the "History of Baseball," compiled by Seymour R. Church of San Francisco. It is a quarto volume, elaborately illustrated with half-tones and colored portraits of prominent masters of the National game.

Dr. and Mrs. S.S. Porter, formerly of this city, but now of Marietta, Ohio, have been in St. Louis for a few days past visiting their son. V. Mott Porter, a well-known attorney and clubman, on route to their home from Colorado, where they spent the Summer. While at a small mountain camp in the Rockies called Twin Lakes, about eighteen miles from Leadville, they had a wonderful escape from Instant death.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 29 -- Quite the most-talked-of subject during the past few days has been the publication of President Palma's desire for the withdrawal of the United States troops and the subsequent, news that Mr. Root has taken the matter under consideration.
