CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Thirty-five thousand dollars for a broken neck was the verdict in Judge Kavanagh's ocurt to-day against the Union Traction Company in favor of Frederick Thoerfell, a carpenter, formerly employed by that corporation. About a year and a half ago, while building a shed for the company, Thoerfell fell from a scaffold, his neck being broken.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- A woman, who, according to her own report, was living at the time of the Boston "Tea Party" and the meeting of the first Continental Congress, is dead at the Home for Aged and Infirm Colored People. If the reports of her age should be correct, she was the oldest person in Illinois, and probably in the United States.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 11. -- Three masked men held up the Pacific Coast Express Train of the Burlington Road four miles from Lincoln just before 2 o'clock this morning. They used explosives on the express car, shattering it badly, and, after wrecking the safe, took its contents, valued at $50,000.

ALMOST every night in the week, when the weather is pleasant, a group of men and women may be found preaching to attentive listeners at Thirtieth Street and Eighth Avenue. Most persons who get a glimpse of them think they belong to the Salvation Army. They do not.
As an outcome of the coal strike situation there is a possibility that an extra session of Congress may be called to take off the tariff duty of 67 cents a ton on anthracite.

Very little is heard of the coal traffic of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, except in its own annual report, and yet it is the largest carrier of mineral fuel in the United States; once in a while, perhaps in such times as the present, there is a news item as to the continued heavy traffic, but then the public interest ceases when times are normal again.
To answer the following letter involves so great a responsibility that the task has been deferred some weeks in trepidation:

A WOMEN'S university club is the latest addition to the successful clubs in New York: a club that has a purpose and achieves it, and which promises to play an important part not only in the life of women college graduates in and around this city, but throughout the United States, for it has members in every State of the Union.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- The way of inventors is sometimes very hard. The sale of the submarine Goubet to a private purchaser is a case in point. Fifteen years ago France was electrified by the report that the difficulties of submarine navigation had been overcome, and that it had ceased to be a mere subject for fantastic speculation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 11. -- Thirty-seven points to 6 tells the story of the Cornell-Williams football game on Percy Field today. Cornell's coaches claim the scoring of Williams was due to an accident. After Cornell had made a safety and one touchdown, from which a goal was kicked, with the ball about in midfield, James signaled for a kick.
IT WAS the man with the samovar who was talking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am one of the unfortunates who live in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, and to get to my business must cross on the Roosevelt Street line of the Brooklyn Union Ferry Company. For the last year or so the boats of this company have been running very irregularly.

Leader Thomas F. Foley of the Second Assembly District has brought to a stop the trouble that has existed between the rival gangs belonging to the Five Points Club and the "Jack" Eastman Club, and the representatives of these rival factions have given their word that they will never more be bad, thus obviating the necessity of calling out the police reserves to quell riots and disperse gangs armed with pistols, clubs, and other weapons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The failure of the President to bring about a settlement of the differences between the operators and miners has caused widespread depression among the householders who have at last realized that they are fast facing a coal famine which will cause terrible distress throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The statement made last night by Secretary Moody in his speech at Madison, Wis., to the effect that the duty of 67 cents per ton on anthracite coal "was smuggled into the Tariff act in a sneaking and cowardly manner" and therefore ought to be repealed at the approaching session of Congress, attracted attention and excited comment here.

THE Opera Club, with its solid phalanx of seventy-five white shirt-bosomed members, comes into notice this week with the Mascagni performances. The Opera Club has been in existence some years, but there has been some talk of Grau needing the space which it occupies at the Metropolitan with its omnibus box.

WHEN President Roosevelt did not come to Kansas City, says The Journal of that town, he missed the gift of one of the handsomest storm coats that a man has put on his back since the days when buffalo robes became extinct. The coat will still be his when he comes after it, but it is hung up as an additional inducement to secure a visit to Kansas City from him.

After a period of dullness and irregularity, prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the last half hour of trading declined sharply, as the result of a very disappointing bank statement showing a slight decrease in surplus reserves and an altogether unexpected increase in loans.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Dr. James R. Wrightson, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, who had been ill for several days with grip, sailed to-day for Bermuda, on the advice of his physician. He will be absent for at least two weeks, but hopes to be able to return in time to make a hustling campaign of about ten days.
IT WAS a great cross to Mr. and Mrs. Crompton that Clinton was apparently devoid of any worthy ambition. Their two older boys were so utterly different.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 11. -- Dr. James R. Wrightson, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, who had been ill for several days with grip, sailed to-day for Bermuda, on the advice of his physician. He will be absent for at least two weeks, but hopes to be able to return in time to make a hustling campaign of about ten days.
IT WAS a great cross to Mr. and Mrs. Crompton that Clinton was apparently devoid of any worthy ambition. Their two older boys were so utterly different.

ITS a strange fact," began an old-timer at the New York Athletic Club the other day, "that systematic improvement in the speed a man can develop in running doesn't 'come off' in spite of long-winded coaches and sandpapered tracks.

EX-CONGRESSMAN JOHN ALLEN, known as "Private Allen," because he was the only private in the Confederate Army, was standing on Pennsylvania Avenue, Washington, last week, watching the Grand Army of the Repub- lic parade. With him were two ladies.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 11. -- The "bucket shops" of Indiana probably will be forced out of business by the Chicago Board of Trade if the finding of Edward Daniels, Master in Chancery, in the case of the Chicago board against L.A. Kinsey Co. of Indianapolis, and other stock brokers, which was filed to-day in the office of the Clerk of the United States Court, is sustained.

THIS was the motto for good advertising, recommended to the Sphinx Club of this city last Wednesday night by John Adams Thayer, manager of the department of advertising for the Butterick Company. He contended that, while from every point of view fraudulent advertising should not be accepted by publishers, there were many lines of advertising objectionable to some publishers and accepted by others.

AN INTERESTING organization has been formed in connection with the workshop department of Public School No. 166, in West Eighty-ninth Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. It is entirely new -- a pioneer of its kind -- and interesting in that it has for its avowed purpose the encouragement and development of spontaneous self-activity among its members.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- I have excellent authority for stating that an intimation was recently conveyed to Emperor William from an exalted British personage to the effect that if he (the Emperor) insisted on granting an audience to the Boer Generals, Botha, De Wet, and De la Key, he would have to give up his plan of visiting King Edward on the latter's birthday.

More than half of the professionals who played last week at Garden City in, the open championship tournament will be seen to-day and to-morrow in the professional tournament given by the Fox Hills Club, Staten Island. Over ninety entries in all have been received, and a purse of over $400 will be divided among the leaders.
GEORGE W. PERTH, Deputy City Controller of Milwaukee, and at one time Postmaster of that city, died at his home yesterday after a lingering illness.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 13 -- Although little more than a couple of hours' journey by rail from the New South Wales metropolis, the prettily situated township of Picton is merely a name to the multitude of holiday makers who annually leave Sydney during the hot, sultry Summer months in search of cooler regions, where they may inhale the invigorating mountain breezes.

Oliver Drew, the little handball expert, who will meet "Mike" Egan of Jersey City during the present season in a match for championship honors, played a fast, clean game yesterday in Casey's Brooklyn Court. His opponent was P.J. Corby, who is a member of Egan's Jersey City Club.

The United States cruiser Buffalo, Capt. Albert Ross. after a four months' voyage, in which she covered 25,000 miles, returned to port yesterday and anchored off Tompkinsville. The cruiser carried away with her 30 midshipmen who were graduated from the Naval Academy last Spring and 445 men, who were transferred to various ships of the European and Asiatic fleets, and 800 tons of supplies.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 12 -- The Erie Company to-night posted notices at its collieries at Pittston requesting all striking employes to return to work tomorrow.

BERLIN, Oct. 12 -- The Boerse last week was again much under American influences, and New York reports were watched with very great interest. Nevertheless the incidents at Montreal and the forced liquidation in Wall Street did not markedly affect quotations here, the return of cheap money rates, together with other factors, having given a certain firmness to values.

BRISTOL, R.I., Oct. 12 -- With the probability of so many of the sloops of the 90-foot class being in commission next season, there is so much fitting out to be done it is likely that the Herreshoff shops will be taxed to such an extent that the placing in fettle of at least one of the old sloops will have to be done elsewhere.

The Zola Literary and Benevolent Association, which was organized with the consent of Emile Zola, held a memorial meeting last night at Saltzman's Hall, 66 Essex Street. The entire hall was draped in black, as were the picture and name of Zola, and the members of the society wore bands of black about their left arms.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Secretary Root, who returned to Washington last night, refused to discuss his interview with J. Pierpont Morgan yesterday further than to say that he did not carry a message from the President to Mr. Morgan and did not telegraph the President from New York as has been stated.

PANAMA, Oct. 12 -- Gen. Julio Cordovez of the Government Army arrived here yesterday from Bogota by way of Barranquilla. He came through with troops, and gives the following account of conditions on the Magdalena River:

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 12 -- The heavy timbers in which Australia is so rich have become famous for their exceptional hardness and durability, but comparatively little is known outside the Commonwealth of the numerous soft woods admirably adapted for the manufacture of furniture and for other industrial purposes.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Le Soir announces to-night that the Jockey Club to-day withdrew the licenses of the American jockeys Milton Henry and J. Reiff, excluding them from riding on any French race course. This action is an outcome, says the newspaper, of very careful investigation made by the Detective Department, which secured proofs that Henry and Reiff upon several occasions have prevented horses that were favorites in the betting from winning races.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is hard to see how the Republicans are going to convince the voters of the country that theirs is the party to which they are obligated to support in the November elections. They do not seem to take into consideration the fact that people are paying more for the necessities of life than ever before, while the salary of the wage earner has not risen correspondingly.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- On the authority of a member of the Jockey Club the Echo de Paris this morning confirms the statement published in Le Soir yesterday that the Jockey Club had withdrawn the licenses of Milton Henry and J. Reiff.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Charles Melbourne, one of Rahway's prominent young men, is to be married next week. He rented a house on William Street, furnished it, and provided everything necessary to start housekeeping with, including a ton of coal, yesterday he was astonished to find that the roal had disappeared from the cellar, not as much as is necessary to start the first fire being left.

There were several spirited track and field contests decided yesterday at the annual games of the Hillside Bicycle Track Association at Belleville, Newark, N.J. Although the track and Held were rainsoaked, fairly good time was made in the running contests. M.J. Sheridan of the Pastime Athletic Club equaled his own world's record of 127 feet 9 inches in throwing the discus.

By a ruse Harriet Farnham, or Mapes, nineteen years old, was induced to leave her home yesterday morning, and was then taken to Jefferson Market Court, where her father, J.P. Farnham, charged that she was incorrigible, and asked to have her committed to an institution.

-- Having had -- and utilized -- frequent opportunities for scolding, deriding, and denouncing the automobiling fraternity for the follies or the sins which some of them have committed and the rest have not taken effective means to prevent, it is only fair to express high approval of the competition between the machines entered to make the journey between this city and Boston.

Senator Platt, when asked yesterday about the story which had been printed widely to the effect that Gov. Odell had been flooded with suggestions regarding the coal strike, including a proposition to call an extra session of the Legislature, said that he did not know whether the Governor would accede to this latter suggestion.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The Rev. Charles Henry Robinson, Honorary Canon of Ripon, has been appointed Dean of Westminster in succession to the Very Rev. George Granville Bradley, who has resigned.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Afton has disappeared from the map, for on Oct. 1 the Afton Post Office changed its name, and is now Florham Park. It is the desire of H. McK. Twombly to have the place represent, from a spectacular standpoint, all that he holds to be fit in a popular country community.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 12 -- An important conference of the Bishops of the Cincinnati Province with Archbishop Elder will be held here next Wednesday. The Philippine and other questions will be considered. Bishops Moeller of Columbus, Alerding of Fort Wayne, and Richter of Grand Rapids already have pronounced themselves in favor of the friars.

The Central Federated Union took up a great part of its time at its meeting yesterday in discussing the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel franchise and will make a supreme effort this week to prevent any contract from being signed for the work, which will not have embodied in it the labor clauses for which the unions have been fighting.

About 3,500 persons witnessed the usual programme of cycle races at the Valisburg track, Newark, yesterday afternoon. Marcus Hurley, the amateur champion, did not ride, and E.F. Root of Boston was the principal performer in the amateur events, winning first place in the half-mile, handicap and second to Charles Schlee of Newark in the five-mile handicap, both from scratch.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The experimental shipment of American fruits to Europe this season by the Department of Agriculture has proved a substantial success. The department on Tuesday shipped a carload of Keiffer pears from the orchard of J.M. Bradley, Niagara County, N.Y., to London, Hamburg, Glasgow, and Liverpool.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The operation which Mr. and Mrs. J. Ogden Armour hope will cure their daughter Leola, who has been a cripple since birth, was performed to-day by Prof. Adolf Lorenz or the University of Vienna. Prof. Lorenz pronounced it a complete success, and said he had not the least doubt that the child would be able to walk as well as the healthiest children when the plaster cast is removed next Spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The board of army officers which was appointed to examine enlisted men for promotion to the grade of Second Lieutenant and which assembled at Fort Leavenworth has reported to the War Department that the followingnamed candidates have passed the required examination and are accordingly recommended for appointment as Second Lieutenants:

All Wall Street Is bearish. There Is no balm in Gilead. Goal strike conditions are bad; money conditions are worse; prosperity has been discounted, is, indeed, on the wane; "big men" are "unloading" -- this is the tenor of the cry now heard almost everywhere in the Street.

BOONTON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Three burglars who broke into Harry Looker's grocery and had their exit therefrom marked by a fusillade of shots by Looker, his brother-in-law, Frank Husk; Henry High, and Thomas Heagon, yesterday morning, are being searched for by the officials of this town.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- It now appears that only one man was killed in the encounter at the Terre Noire coalfield on Friday between strikers and gendarmes, and that the victim was not connected with the strike. Nevertheless the Miners' Committee has issued a manifesto denouncing the killing of this man as murder, and attacking the Government for utilizing gendarmes and soldiers against the strikers.

The picnic arranged for by the Miners' Defense Committee of the Central Federated Union two weeks ago in Sulzer's Westchester Park in aid of the striking anthracite miners, which was to have taken place two weeks ago, but was postponed on account of inclement weather, came off yesterday, and was attended by at least 20,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- His royal Highness, Chowfa Maha Vajiravudh, the Crown Prince of Siam, who arrived in this city yesterday from New York, spent the day in his apartments at the Arlington, and in driving about the city. No visitors were announced. In the morning, accompanied by his brother, Prince Chakrapongse; the Siamese Minister, and one of his aides, he drove through the Soldiers' Home grounds.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 12 -- The officers of the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association have been elected for the ensuing year as follows: James M. Martin, Newark Academy, President; Robert Gray, East Orange High School, Vice President; Prof. C.F. Davis, Newark Academy, Secretary, and James A. Gill, Newark High School, Treasurer.

The Rev. Dr. David James Burrell preached last night at the Marble Collegiate Church. Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, upon "The Right of Work." There were four parties to be considered in the present coal situation, he said.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- A conference of ministers and Christian workers of prominence will open to-morrow in the seminary here. The Rev. Dr. Maitland Alexander of Pittsburg will preside at the morning session, when the question "The Minister and His Study" will be discussed by the new President of the seminary, Dr. Francis L. Patton, the Rev. Dr. B.B. Warfield, '71, and the Rev. Dr. John A. Davis, '79.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Knowing that you take greaat interest in all that pertains to our public parks and their management, I take the liberty of writing these lines, advising you to investigate the matter at once, and, if the conditions are found to be as stated, to sound the alarm.
CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The Rev. Dr. Charles De Kay Cooper, a well-known Episcopal clergyman, died suddenly Saturday afternoon at his home here, the cause of death being heart disease.

There has been a great change in the making of lingerie in the past few years. The liking for pretty, fine things is increasing, and the more expensive garments are becoming more and more beautiful, and with the advance is a sensible improvement in the lower-priced garments. A woman can find realy pretty things for little money.

READING, Penn., Oct. 12 -- George F. Baer, President of the Reading Company, left here late to-night on a special train for New York. His sudden departure was occasioned by a telegram reported to have been sent him by J.P. Morgan.

The Rev. A.B. Simpson, President and General Superintendent of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, succeeded yesterday morning at the Gospel Tabernacle, on Eighth Avenue, in making an audience of about 1,000 persons feel their responsibility to the unconverted so keenly as to give $53,476 in pledges and cash.

Henry A. Cassidy, aged thirty years and claiming to be an engineer, is locked up in the Morrisania Station on the charge of arson, and, according to the police, he was seen in the act. Policeman Stockmar last night saw flames in the two-story and basement machine shop of William Leyland Co., at 473 East One Hundred and Fortieth Street.

One of the most remarkable banquets ever held in New York was given yesterday at the Hotel Savoy by the Societa Musicale Pietro Mascagni, which was founded in 1902. If ever men did justice to their food, the members of the society and their guests did. They had waited from 1 o'clock in the afternoon until 5:30 for the appearance of the guest of honor, the Italian composer, and were ravenous.

It is difficult to imagine a more inane proceeding than that begun by Mr. DAVID WILCOX of counsel for the Delaware and Hudson Company to induce the Federal Government to prosecute the United Mine Workers as an organization existing in contravention of the provisions of the Sherman anti-trust law of 1890.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Members of the Citizens' Union of East Orange, who are also members of the Republican Club, have sent a written protest to the club against the taking of any action looking toward an indorsement of the party nominees by the club. The adherents of the union threaten to resign from the club if it takes any decided position in favor of partisan politics in the local election.

The Mascagni Sunday concert at the Metropolitan was worth a larger audience than heard it. The orchestra was not more than half filled and the boxes much less. On the other hand, rows of slanders lined the auditorium and the family circle looked very crowded. Madison Square Garden at a fifty-cent admission seemed to be " vindicated" as the most profitable condition for such a concert.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- William L. Penfield of the United States State Department, Archbishop Riordan of San Francisco, and others who were present at The Hague during the recent sessions of the International Court of Arbitration which heard the arguments in the Pious Fund case between the United States and Mexico, have arrived here.

We are at a loss to understand the action of the New York State Bankers' Association in advocating the repeal of the bankruptcy law. We suspect that the action was taken without careful investigation and deliberation.

There was a time when the European diplomat and the envoy who lies abroad for his country had a sure topic on which to display his profundity and so impress the hearer with his knowledge of the inmost springs of political action.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 12 -- Delaware is in the throes of a political combat. The battle is being waged around J. Edward Addicks as the central figure. It has been and is being conducted with intense fury. Charges and counter-charges of fraud and vote buying and debauchery are made by the rival Republican factions.

The voters of the First Judicial District have this year more than usual need of enlightenment and guidance from the Bar Association in respect to the fitness of the candidates for the Supreme Bench. The Republicans have nominated Judges STECKLER, KEENER, and HALL, who are already upon the bench.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 -- Archbishop Ryan touched upon the interests of capital and labor in general and the coal strike in particular in his sermon this morning in the Cathedral. He took for his text the parable from St. Matthew of the King who wished to settle accounts with his servants.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 13. -- Mrs. Le Moyne and Glen MacDonough's new play, "Among Those Present," were both seen for the first time to-night at the Academy of Music in this city. The occasion attracted the largest and most fashionable audience of the season, and bore all the marks of success.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 13, -- Senator John C. Spooner made his first speech of the Republican campaign in Wisconsin in this city to-night. A crowd of 3,000 persons turned out in a drenching rain to hear him, and he received an enthusiastic greeting. In the course of his remarks he paid an eloquent tribute to President Roosevelt.

"How the High Father of Heaven sendeth Death to summon Every Creature" -- this, according to the Tudor titlepage, is the argument of the "morality play" produced last night at Mendelssohn Hall. It is called "Everyman," after the name of the hero. The characters and the action are symbolical of how each and all of us shall some day be summoned to give over this life and face eternity.

United States Marshal Henkel returned as unsatisfied yesterday an execution against the property of James A. Simmons, ex-President of the wrecked Sixth National Bank, at Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway. The execution was secured by the White National Bank of Fort Wayne, Ind., against Simmons and William B. Burnet.

In a truly great race at the Morris Park track yesterday, Hermis, certainly the best of the three-year-olds of the Fall season, made a new bid for fame by winning the Mamaroneck Handicap Stakes under conditions that compelled the admission even from his detractors that L.V. Bell's colt safely holds the championship among the handicap horses of the Autumn.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- The semi-annual meeting of the shareholders of the Grand Trunk Railway of Canada this afternoon was largely attended, and the report was unanimously approved. The President, Sir Charles Rivers Wilson, was in the chair. His reference to the fact that second preferreds, on which interest has not been paid since 1883, would receive a full dividend elicited hearty applause.

As a result of Saturday's games several changes were made in the personnel of the different football elevens, and players who have looked upon their retention as practically certain are a little bit anxious about their chances of appearing in the big games later in the season. Fewer games will be played from now on, but the elevens will be more evenly matched.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The operators have agreed to the appointment of a commission to be appointed by the President of the United States, to whom shall be referred all questions at issue between the companies and their employes, whether they belong to a union or not, and the decision of the commission shall be accepted by the operators.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 13. -- Four bodies were found tied in sacks in Georgia Street and in the rear of the Central College of Physicians and Surgeons to-day.
WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., Oct. 13. -- United States Senator Quarles delivered a political speech here to-day in the course of which he said:
DULUTH, Oct. 13. -- United States Senator Knute Nelson handled the coal operators and coal railway managers without gloves in an interview here to-day. He said in part:
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

In Austria, as in Massachusetts, a bill has been introduced in the legislative assembly for the taxation of cats. The idea is not new. It has been the dream of every man who pays an annual license fee for a dog that the owners of cats should contribute to the municipal revenues.

Gov. Odell uttered the following significant remarks in the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening: "I believe that the coal strike is nearer to a definite settlement than it has been since it started. In my opinion, this week will see an end of it."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the editorial published in THE TIMES of the 10th inst., entitled "A Nimble Candidate," in which you criticise this association for not indorsing the canal plank in the platform of the Democratic Party:

Capt. Lansing H. Beach and First Lieut. Merriwether L. Walker will report to Col. Charles R. Suter, Corps of Engineers. President of the examining board, at the Army Building, New York City, for examination.

BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- Local money conditions are relatively firm, with call rates mostly 7 per cent. and all the loans at the Clearing House made at the figure. Very little business is doing, either in call or time loans and a feeling of conservatism still characterizes the whole situation. Sterling exchange remains quiet and firm.

The letter of R. FULTON GUTTING, Chairman of the Citizens' Union, to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, calling attention to the desirability of including in the appropriations for next year an amount sufficient to provide such necessary public conveniences as baths, comfort stations, small parks, playgrounds, and the like, is timely and characterized by excellent sense.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday visited Police Commissioner Partridge at Police Headquarters, and afterward went to see Mayor Low at the City Hall. He said his trips were on "private business," but on his return from Police Headquarters he paid a glowing tribute to Capt. Piper, and predicted that his methods would bring about a change for the better in the Police Department.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- New York exchange to-day was quoted at 25 cents discount. Time and call loans commanded 6 per cent.
Gov. Odell was the guest at a reception and dinner last night at the Union League Club of Brooklyn, where he was entertained by the Republican Editorial Association of the State of New York.

Persons passing along Broadway near the Casino yesterday afternoon were astonished to see forty or fifty chorus girls rushing out into the brilliant sunshine from the stage door, screaming "Catch it! Oh, do catch it!" The cause of the disturbance was a tiny monkey which was loose on the stage.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 13. -- Senator Hanna, who was taken sick at Ironton, Ohio, Saturday while on a speaking tour, and compelled to return home, was at his office to-day and feeling much better. The Senator expects to resume his trip Wednesday next, speaking at Xenia probably Wednesday evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 13. -- What became of the reckless crew who left this port a month ago to visit Tiburon Island, where the man eating Seris live, the crew who purposed killing the cannibals and gaining the island's treasure?
PARIS, Oct. 13. -- The Boer Generals Botha, De Wet, and De la Rey arrived in Paris at 12:55 P.M. to-day.

The movement of prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday was highly irregular and uncertain. In the early trading quotations broke sharply; in the final two hours of business they recovered substantially under the lead of the coal stocks and such standard shares as St. Paul and Union Pacific.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 13. -- According to the claims of the operators, work was resumed to-day at four collieries in this district -- the Bellevue and Hyde Park of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Company in this city, and the Johnson Nos. 1 and 2, of the New York, Ontario and Western Company in Priceburg.
The weights for the Westchester Highweight Handicap, to be run over the last six and a half furlongs of the Withers mile on Thursday, are as follows:

The absence of actual improvement in the general market situation as affected by the two factors now most important -- the coal strike and the money market -- induced further selling in the outside market yesterday, with the result that soon after the opening sharp declines were in progress in most of the prominent stocks.

NEWARK, Oct. 13. -- Messrs, Branley and Sharp of District Attorney Jerome's office were in this city this evening and had a long consultation with Detective Farrell relative to the Molineux case. Robert F. Zoller, who is wanted in New York to testify, to-day consulted former Prosecutor Elvin W. Crane as to his rights, and was told he could not be compelled to go to New York to testify.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The volume of mineral resources of the country for the calendar year 1901, now in press, United States Geological Survey, presents interesting statistics of the labor in the coal mines.
The Empire City Realty Company has bought the seven-story building 347 West Broadway, on lot 25 by 100.

BOSTON, Oct. 13. -- Dr. E.A.W. Harlow of Quincy, a retired physician and surgeon, died yesterday after a brief illness, aged nearly 89 years. He was a member of the Harvard class of 1841. Dr. Harlow was the oldest surviving member of the Mechanic Apprentices' Library Association, which contributed its mite to the final sums used in finishing the Bunker Hill Monument.

The Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel franchise is not likely to be acted upon by the Board of Aldermen to-day. The matter may be discussed informally, but the prevailing impression yesterday was that nothing definite will be done until after election. Concerning the possible fate of the agreement before the board Mayor Low would not say anything for publication.
PARIS, Oct. 13. -- Baron de Bradsky, the aeronaut, and M. Morin, his engineer, were killed by falling from a dirigible balloon this morning.
LONDON, Oct. 14.-On the London Coal Exchange yesterday prices advanced 25 cents per ton.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- Discounts were steady to-day. Day-to-day-loans were easy, in spite of which Stock Exchange loans were being arranged on the basis of 4 per cent., fully 1/4 above the last settlement. The stiffness, it was presumed, was intended to reduce somewhat the outstanding account. Americans were the feature of the account.

Some one lacking a knowledge of the vitality of Russell Sage and his love for his work started a rumor which was published yesterday that the aged financier would retire from business permanently. Whether it was this rumor or the desire for other reasons to return to New York is not known, but Mr. Sage came back to town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Interest is still very strong here in Secretary Moody's recent demand that the duty on anthracite coal be taken off, and in his statement that it was smuggled into the Dingley act in a sneaking and cowardly manner. It has already been shown that Mr. Moody was mistaken on the latter point, since the amendment was debated extensively before it was adopted.

At the last annual meeting of the Metropolitan Street Railway Association Mr. VREELAND, the President of the association of employes and of the company alike, referred to the enormous losses to capital and labor from strikes during the last twenty years. These amount to over $377,000,000.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 13. -- What was looked upon as an important day in the matter of resumption of work in the coal mines passed without any serious trouble, and each side to the controversy is claiming a victory. Reports received here from coal companies all over the region are to the effect that at least twelve collieries and four washeries started operations to-day.

The events of special interest to-day and to-morrow are the polo games at Lakewood, the racing at Morris Park, and golfing. Mr. and Mrs. George Gould have a house party for the polo games at Georgian Court, Lakewopd. Mrs. Gould was in town yesterday. An event of interest was the arrival here of Mrs. Roosevelt.

The statement cabled yesterday from Berlin to the Staats-Zeitung of this city, that German mine owners have offered the Municipality of New York 100,000 tons of coal suitable for steamships at four dollars and a half per ton and 10,000 tons of coal of smaller size at three and a half dollars per ton sounds like a fairy tale, in view of the situation here.

The annual report of the Erie Railroad for the fiscal year ended June 30 last was made public yesterday. Although, only one and one-half months of that year were affected by the anthracite coal strike, the report shows in various items the effect of the strike and what may be expected of the showing to be made for the present year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13. -- Brig. Gen. Frederick D. Grant arrived here to-day from Manila, on the United States transport Logan. Gen. Grant is in excellent health. He said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- A new departure was made to-day in the case of the reception of Sir Michael Herbert, the British Ambassador, by President Roosevelt. The usual custom was for the new Ambassador, in journeying to the White House to present his credentials, to drive there in his own carriage, accompanied by the embassy staff, first going to the State Department, where the party was joined by the Secretary of State.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 13. -- The new bowling green at the New Brunswick Golf Club was formally opened this afternoon with a game between picked teams of the Middlesex Bowling Green Club of Dunelien and the Golf Club. It had been planned to have four rinks, but owing to the bad weather only one was formed, with three players on a side.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- United States Ambassador Choate and Gens. Corbin, Wood, and Young were the guests of King Edward at a luncheon at Buckingham Palace to-day in honor of Lord Kitchener, prior to his departure for India, where he is to take command of the British forces.

A blush of shame ought to color even the experienced cheek of DAVID B. HILL. when he seeks to mislead an audience of Democrats by telling them that the acquisition of the anthracite coal mines by the Government through the exercise of the right of eminent domain would be neither revolutionary nor Socialistic, but constitutional, necessary, and right.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The Navy Department is in receipt of many anxious inquiries from relatives and friends of persons on the Island of Guam, in regard to the recent earthquake there. The department wishes it to be known that none of its advices to date tell of a single casualty as a result of the shock.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 13. -- Fine Autumnal weather greeted the automobilists on their appearance at the parade in Park Square this morning for the first day's run of the return trip of the reliability test between New York to Boston. There were no laggards. Every one was astir bright and early, getting the machines in readiness for to-day's jaunt to Springfield, ninety-two miles away, which is the longest stage of the trip.

NEWPORT, Oct. 14. -- Mrs. Victor Sorchan, whose three-year term as a member of the Newport Public School Committee expires next January, will tie a candidate of both the Republican and Democratic Parties for re-election, and will be chosen without opposition for another three-year term.
At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday the following letter from Mayor Low on the coal situation was read:

The two-and-a-half-year old daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Alexander C. Young is again the object of contention between the parents. On the charge of abducting it, Mr. Young was arrested last night in the Hotel Imperial by Detectives O'Neill and Curran. He was bailed out by Bartow S. Weeks.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- At a meeting to-day of the Parliamentary Committee of the Trades Union Congress, a letter from President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers, received in reply to inquiries, was read. The letter detailed the grievances and objects of the striking miners in the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- The library at Hawarden, erected as a national memorial to the late William E. Gladstone and which cost $50,000, was opened by Earl Spencer today. The building stands on the brow of a hill commanding a view of the Dee, so greatly admired by Mr. Gladstone. It contains the statesman's valuable collection of books.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 14. -- E.A. Schroeder of New York City committed suicide in a sleeping car near this city to-day.
Major Barrington K. West, Commissary, will report to the Commissary General for temporary duty in his office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The new rule of the War Department that fixes the term of service of a regiment at two years in the Philippines and four years at home is likely to be received with a good deal of criticism. The plan is to keep all regiments now in the island there until they have completed a term of three years, and after that the new rule will go into effect.

Western turfmen and Western horses all but swept the programme at the Morris Park race track yesterday, half the races going to that meteroic figure in racing, John A. Drake, of Chicago, alone. Lyne, the Drake stable jockey, was equally conspicuous with the Drake horses, he riding two of the stable's winners and twice being second.

Columbia seems to have the hardest problem to solve on the football schedule today. Her opponent will be the eleven from Swarthmore, and this team has shown a remarkably strong front this season. The showing against Princeton was creditable, while the University of Pennsylvania's representatives had their hands full to win by the small score of 11 to 6.

Announcement was made yesterday that a sixteen-story apartment hotel will be erected on Firth Avenue, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets, in the very heart of the so-called "Millionaires' Row."

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 14. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders and debenture bondholders of the Wabash Railroad Company was held here to-day. Eighty-three per cent, of the stockholders and bondholders were represented. The following Directors were elected by the stockholders:

Lawson Purdy, Secretary of the New York Tax Reform Association, signs the following statement and a circular giving the legal points involved in the contentions of the association in regard to the taxation on the personal property of non-resident corporations and individuals:

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 14. -- Postmaster General Henry C. Payne in an interview today said that the forthcoming annual message of President Roosevelt to Congress probably will recommend that a permanent Tariff Commission be appointed.

Without specifically mentioning the party organization, the New York Bar Association Last night adopted resolutions strongly condemning the failure of the Republican State Convention to name Judge John Clinton Gray as a candidate for re-election to the Court of Appeals.

District Attorney Jerome, Inspector Brooks, and Capt. Walsh of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station late last night raided five places, said to be among the principal gambling houses in the Tenderloin district. The raids were made on warrants obtained from Justice Wyeth on information furnished by Detective Jacobs of the District Attorney's staff.
LONDON, Oct. 14. -- Discounts were firmer to-day. The Directors of the Bank of England were reputed to be contemplating taking steps to reduce the plethora of money.
ROME, Oct. 14. -- The organ of the Vatican, the Osservatore Romano, publishes a violently worded article to-day on Hall Caine's drama, "The Eternal City," and says: ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The following changes in the Diplomatic Corps have been announced by the State Department:

Without doubt the appointment of Capt. PIPER to a deputyship in the police force has already resulted in distinct good. It is a great thing to have a man in his place who presumably knows and evidently cares nothing about "politics," but whose professional training makes him look upon the force as a military organization, in which discipline is the one thing needful.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 14. -- A notice was posted in the general shops of the Norfolk and Western Railway here to-day, signed by General Manager and Vice President L. E. Johnson, announcing an increase of 2 cents an hour in the wages of all machinists, machinists' helpers, and all laborers. This increase, which affects about 2,000 men, was made voluntarily, the men having made no request for an advance.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 14. -- The local market developed a better tone to-day, which made possible a recovering tendency on the part of several issues which have for some time been unduly depressed. United Railway incomes were among those most prominent in the rallying list. These bid fair to go higher, owing to the growing conviction that their margin of safety warrants an advance well up in the seventies.
THE HAGUE, Oct. 14. -- The Arbitration Court, in the Pious Fund case, has condemned Mexico to pay the United States $1,420,682 in Mexican currency. The decision of the court was unanimous.

Patrick F. Ryan, who is on the staff of Chief of Department Edward F. Croker as Chief of Construction and Repairs, was dismissed from the Fire Department yesterday by Commissioner Thomas Sturgis, the order to take effect next Friday at noon.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 14. -- It developed here to-night that Nathan Straus of New York, with the assistance of J. Pierpont Morgan, has been endeavoring for the past few days to end the strike. Mr. Straus was represented here by A.L. Kinkead, Sylvester Burns, and "W.L. Wilmer of New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- Plans for the great packers' combination have been successfully perfected to the satisfaction of all the large interests involved, and Dec. 1 has been set, contingent upon the condition of the money market, as the time for publicly launching the gigantic enterprise. The firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., the New York bankers and financiers, will head the underwriting syndicate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Speaking today of the coal troubles Senator Vest of Missouri said he was unable to see how Congress could do anything for immediate belief if called together. As to the proposition so irequently advanced by some persons, that the Government should seize and operate the mines under the right of eminent domain.

MANCHESTER, Oct. 14. -- A notable edition to the controversy over the Government's Education bill was made to-night by Premier Balfour in an address he delivered before a mass meeting held in connection with the annual conference of the National Union Conservative Constitutional Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14. -- There was no marked improvement in the local market to-day, notwithstanding the favorable turn in the coal strike situation. Prices improved fractionally, but the average net gain of the active stocks was less than one-half of 1 per cent. There were two reasons for this hesitancy: First, some apprehension that the miners might not consent to the operators' plan, and second, to a continued scarcity of loanable funds.

G. Leeds, the sixteen-year-old son of W.B. Leeds, President of the Rock Island Railroad system, who about four weeks ago slipped quietly away from Andover, Mass., where he was preparing for college, and went to Colombia to help Gen. Uribe-Uribe overthrow the Government there, got back home yesterday on the Ward Line steamship Seguranca, which at present is flying the flag of the Panama Company, to which concern she is under charter.

The open letter of Borough President SWANSTROM of Brooklyn giving reasons why, in his judgment, the franchise for the Pennsylvania terminal improvements should be ratified by the Board of Aldermen in the shape in which it was approved by the Rapid Transit Commission, is an admirable document.

LAKEWWOD, N.J., Oct. 14. -- George J. Gould's Lakewood polo team scored first honors for the Ladies' Cup to-day by defeating the Westchester Country Club by 7 goals to 4 3/4. The game was the opening one of the annual Fall tournament of the Lakewood Polo Club, and the fashionable cottage community was present in large numbers around the Georgian Court polo field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Official news of the result of the arbitration in the Pious Fund case was received here to-day from Mr Ralston, the agent for the United States before The Hague tribunal. He simply stated that the United States' contention had been accepted as to res adjudicata, and the full amount of the claim allowed, to be paid in Mexican silver.

BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- The demand for money is little different from what it has been, and rates are still being quoted very firm, call loans being made almost wholly at 7 and 8 per cent., and only a few specially favored borrowers getting any concession from these figures. Sterling exchange remains quiet, and posted rates are off half a cent all around.

The Board of Directors of the Commercial Cable Company, at a meeting held here yesterday, elected Clarence H. Mackay President of the company and George G. Ward Chairman of the Board of Directors and of the Executive Committee. Mr. Ward continues to be Vice President and General Manager.

Tammany's talkers, the men who are willing to appear at open-air meetings in fair or stormy weather and ever ready to address audiences from the rear end of a truck, appeared at the Wigwam last evening to receive instructions. They were not told to make the plank of the Democratic State platform declaring for Government ownership of the anthracite coal fields an issue.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14. -- After postponement for three days on account of the bad condition of the track, the racing was continued to-day. In the first heat of the fourth race, a serious accident occurred, which will keep Driver Middleton in the hospital for several weeks. While scoring in this heat, Laurette, with Middleton in the sulky, swerved into Lady Catherine, and both sulkies were overturned.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The Times, commenting editorially on the anthracite situation in the United States, says this morning that the miners will put themselves right with public opinion by placing themselves unreservedly in the hands of a tribunal nominated by President Roosevelt.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 14. -- Dr. William Riddick Whitehead, a distinguished physician and author of many works on medicine and surgery, died here last night, aged seventy years. He was made a Knight of the Imperial Order or St. Stanislaus by the Czar in recognition of services during the Crimean war.

Frank Leake of Philadelphia, a member of the committee of the National Manufacturers' Association, which conferred with John Mitchell in Buffalo last week, announced yesterday morning that the strike leader at this conference agreed to forego the question of recognition of the Mine Workers' Union.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 14. -- Secretary of the Treasury Shaw addressed a Republican mass meeting here this evening. In the course of his speech he said:

In accepting the offer of arbitration made by the coal operators Mr. MITCHELL has the best opportunity that will ever come to him to end a strike that was begun without his advice and cannot now long continue without destroying him as a labor leader.

To a representative of The Evening Post, who asked him his views in regard to the outlook for and the duty of the Democracy in the approaching Congressional elections, ex-President Grover Cleveland said:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 14. -- Attorney General Knox addressed the members of the Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Schenley here to-night. There were 700 guests present. The subject of his address was "The Commerce Clause of the Constitution and the Trusts." Mr. Knox spoke in part as follows: ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- One of the most pretentious Shakespearean revivals ever witnessed in America was seen at the Grand Opera House to-night, when Richard Mansfield put on "Julius Caesar" on a scale rivaling his "Henry V."

Of all the big collegre football elevens who took part in yesterday's games. Harvard's was the only one scored upon. The Wesleyan team opposed the Crimson, and after several trick plays in the second half of the game the Wesleyan team scored a touch-down on a delayed pass. By defeating Swarthmore with a score of 24 to 0 Columbia's team made a better showing than either Pennsylvania or Princeton against the same eleven.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 15. -- There was a great sensation in the session of the Supreme Court here to-day, when such eminent lawyers as State Attorney Eggleston, ex-Mayor William Waldo Hyde, and Charles E. Perkins, Nestor of the Connecticut Bar, were accused of having gone about the State seeking to inveigle witnesses and to corrupt the lower court.

John W. Gates, who has been spending a three weeks' vacation in Europe, returned yesterday on the White Star liner Oceanic, and said that he lost fifty pounds in weight during the trip. He still weighs considerably over 200. Mr. Gates was accompanied by his wife, and they were met at the pier by their son, Charles G. Gates, Joseph Harris, Jacob Field, John Lambert, William Oliver, Isaac Ellwood, and E.A. Ladew.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15. -- Dullness marked to-day's session of the local Stock Exchange, transactions aggregating only 26,733 shares and $50,650 bonds. Practically one-half of the stock sales were in Reading and Philadelphia Rapid Transit. Offerings were not large or urgent, so that even the little buying that appeared was sufficient to lead to fractional improvements.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Sharp advances were made in several stacks on the Chicago Exchange to-day. Swifts led in point of gain with over 6 points' advance, to above 160. The revival of the story that the combination will be effected when money is easier aided in this upturn. Pneumatic Tool was purchased by insiders and rallied 3 points.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 15. -- Post Office Inspector Hugh J. German to-day caused the arrest of the four principal officers of the Alt F. Clark Company, which conducts what is known as the Correspondence Institute of America, with offices here. The four men arrested were Alt F. Clark. President of the company; Conrad Lotz, Vice President, and Treasurer; Louis Conrad, Secretary, and William M. Bingham, General Manager.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Princeton easily defeated the Haverford football team here to-day by a score of 30 to 0. Haverford was light in both the line and back field, and could do nothing against Princeton. Only twice did they make the necessary five yards in the required downs, and their line held the hard rushes of the Princeton eleven but twice.

It is a pity that the President did not let the Attorney General speak first. Mr. KNOX has certainly spoken more wisely about the regulation of trusts, with fuller knowledge, with more careful reasoning, and, of course, with an understanding of the principles of law which the President did not possess.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Oct. 15. -- News has been received from Caracas to the effect that the battle near Victoria between the forces of President Castro and the Venezuelan revolutionists, which began on Monday morning, has so far been without definite result.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 16. -- Mr. Mitchell arrived here shortly before noon yesterday toy the Pennsylvania Railroad and proceeded directly to the White House, where he was expected by the President. Mitchell was met at the station by a number of newspaper men, who accompanied him to the White House on a street car, but he persistently declined to give any opinions or say anything in regard to the business that brought him to Washington.

The announcement in yesterday's papers that a speculator had bought in Fifth Avenue, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets, a twenty-five-foot lot, upon which he meant to build, in the absence of sufficient inducements not to build, a fifteen-story skyscraper, must have caused shudders to run down the backs of all the billionaires who have been buying or building themselves dwellings in that very costly neighborhood.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday visited all the places raided the night before, and known as the biggest gambling houses in the Tenderloin, said to be conducted by "Honest" John Kelly, Shang Draper, Louis Betts, and others generally known to the public. The District Attorney's purpose was to examine the safes in the various resorts, and in that he was aided by counsel for the supposed proprietors, who readily delivered to Mr. Jerome the combinations.

The wedding of Clarence G. McDavitt and Miss Edith Lauterbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lauterbach, took place at Sherry's last evening, the Rev. William J. Tucker, President of Dartmouth College, officiating. Miss Lauterbach, who was given away by her father, wore a white satin crepe de chine Princesse gown, with long, plain train, and the yoke and sleeves of Duchesse lace.
LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Discounts were firm to-day, owing to the condition of the rates of exchange, especially that of Paris.

The letter of Mayor Low to the Board of Aldermen announcing that the Board of Health will not enforce the smoke ordinance by prosecuting those maintaining a nuisance of this character while the difficulty of obtaining anthracite lasts seems to have been ill-advised. It commits the Health Department to a policy it should not be expected to adopt, and practically gives notice that the smoke nuisance will be tolerated even when unnecessary and preventable.

One half of the jury that will hear the second trial of Roland B. Molineux, charged with the murder of Mrs. Katharine J. Adams, was secured as a result of the opening day's session yesterday. In the former trial three days were required in getting one satisfactory juror, and about three weeks in getting the jury.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 15. -- In a secluded farmhouse on a country road, two miles from the village of Rochester, in Lorain County, a terrible battle was fought at 8 o'clock last night between three aged men named Meach and six robbers. As the result of the battle two of the robbers were shot to death, one probably fatally wounded, and two of the Meach brothers are badly beaten.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Representative Babcock, Chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, was here to-day and had a short conference with the President. His visit was mainly in regard to business relating to his district, but incidentally he discussed the outlook for the Republicans at the approaching Congressional elections.

Bird Sim Coler was formally notified on his nomination by the Democratic State Convention for Governor at the Tilden Club, at Broadway and Seventy-fifth Street, last evening, and in accepting he declared the issues on which he appealed to all citizens to elect him. David B. Hill was present. When all the ceremonies were over there were loud shouts and cheering for Mr. Hill and a forcible demand that he make a speech.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Gen. Young, United States Army, has secured the consent of Lord Roberts and the Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, the War Secretary, to a plan to send a dozen of the best British non-commissioned officers to America in order that they may give an exposition of the gymnastic training which is now given in the British service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- United States Minister Bowen at Caracas has cabled to the State Department asking that one or perhaps two more warships be sent to reenforce the gunboat Marietta at La Guayea the port of Caracas) in view of the present critical situation.
COPENHAGEN, Oct. 15. -- The Landsthing to-day began the discussion of the treaty providing for the cession of the Danish West Indies to the United States.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- "The Billionaire," a new musical comedy by Smith and Kerker, was put on at the Hyperion Theatre here to-night by Klaw Erlanger.
Capt. Odus C. Horney, Ordnance Department will proceed to South Bethlehem, Penn., on official business pertaining to the inspection of gun forgings.

Rockwater and River Pirate divided the honors at the Morris Park race track yesterday, the filly beating colts, whom she met on even terms, and the two-year-old beating old horses to whom he was making big concessions in the weights.
Bank of Bengal's rate of discount advanced from 3 to 4 per cent.

Timothy D. Sullivan made his first speech last night. Although, he has been a member of the Legislature for many years, and is now a candidate for Congress, he admitted In his address last evening at the Daniel E. Finn clubhouse, 141 Hudson Street, that for the first time in his career he appeared as a public orator.

When Perry Belmont bought the dwelling at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, several months ago, one of its most attractive features was that the adjoining houses on the north side of Forty-seventh Street were set far back from the street, affording for his house an exceptionally fine "rear," as real estate men say.

Gov. Odell left this city for Albany last evening and will remain there until he starts out on his campaign tour. The State Committee last evening announced one change in the Governor't itinerary. Instead of speaking at Geneva on Oct. 24, he will speak at Auburn. When asked what opinion he had formed of the situation in the State from the information he had received, the Governor said:

Sixty-seven of the seventy-five automobiles which started from this city last Thursday morning in a reliability contest of 500 miles to Boston and return of the Automobile Club of America finished the journey yesterday afternoon at the Plaza. Fifty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue; one other, which broke down almost in sight of the finish flag, was towed in, and seven others withdrew from the run at various points on the route.

MONTREAL, Oct. 15. -- Sir Wilfrid Laurter must resign the Premiership of Canada or pay the penalty with his life within a year. That is the intelligence conveyed to Dr. Henri Lasnier of this city by an eminent physician under whom he studied in Paris, and who was called on to give attendance to the Canadian Premier while he was in the French capital some weeks ago.

A letter on the subject of Raines law hotels was sent to Mayor Low yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst and Thaddeus D. Kenneson, as President and Secretary, respectively, of the Society for the Prevention of Crime. The letter was as follows:

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The demand for call money is such that rates are still held very firm at 7 per cent, and better, with a 6 per cent. rate given only to the best borrowers. Time money also is quoted at from 5 1/2 to 7 per cent. Sterling exchange, though quiet, continues to show a soft tone. Posted rates were all reduced 1/4 cent to-day.
BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- Rear Admiral Thomas Oliver Selfridge, United States Navy, retired, died at the McLean Asylum, Waverly, to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The great anthracite coal strike is settled. A commission of six persons, with a seventh, Carroll D. Wright, as recorder, will adjust the differences between the operators and the miners. President Mitchell of the Miners' Union will take the necessary measures to call the strike off.

It is plain that the movement in the Republican Party for the revision of the tariff is gaining strength. On Monday evening Senator SPOONER at Milwaukee made a speech in substantial agreement with the views expressed by President ROOSEVELT In his Logansport address, with the had intended to deliver at Milwaukee.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- The first regular stockholders' meeting of the Western Maryland Railroad Company since the control passed to the Gould Interests, was held here to-day.

As was expected, the challenge of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club on behalf of Sir Thomas Lipton for the America's Cup came on the White Star liner Oceanic yesterday. The Oceanic arrived at her pier at 11 o'clock in the forenoon, and the foreign mail was ready for distribution at the Post Office at 2 o'clock.

Anthony J. Drexel. who, after a year's absence abroad, returned yesterday on the White Star liner Oceanic. "While getting in touch with home news on the way up from Quarantine, he characterized Henry Watterson's recent attack on Newport society as "disgraceful, unjust, and uncalled for."

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The following information, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times, is from a source hitherto perfectly trustworthy, and throws a vivid light on the methods employed to "pacify" the disturbed districts:

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. - -The tightness in the money market is also the continuing feature of the securities market. The general tone of the latter market is better, but traders are unable to secure funds to take advantage of the improvement. Money rates are nominally at 6 per cent., and the situation remains safe enough to prevent any disturbance in outstanding obligations, but funds are not easily procurable for new ventures.
WASHINOTON, Oct. 15. -- The State Department to-day gave out the following statement in regard to a telegram received from J.H. Ralston, United States Agent at The Hague:

William J. Roome has sold for Mitchell A.C. Levy to Philip Livingston 18 East Fortieth Street, a lot 30 by 100, now occupied by a four-story dwelling. Mr. Lavingston will erect on the site a ten-story apartment house.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- Secretary Shaw is now on his way to Oakland City, Ind., where he will deliver a political speech tomorrow evening. When questioned in regard to the statement current in New York that the Secretary was planning to purchase a large block of bonds, the Treasury officials now here declined, in the Secretary's absence, to discuss the matter further than to say that the report probably was without foundation.

The decision of The Hague Tribunal or Arbitration in favor of the claims of the United States against Mexico in what is known as the "Pious Fund case" is in only a very subordinate sense a triumph for this country. It is in the largest and most important sense a veritable triumph for the principle of arbitration and for the specific plan of applying that principle established by The Hague Convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Stored with complete and interesting information concerning every branch of every army in the world is "Notes of Military Interest for 1901." made public to-day by Lieut. Col. W.A. Simpson, Chief of the Military Information Division.

Sharp words passed when Alexander C. Young, County Attorney of Hudson County, N.J., was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday charged with kidnapping his daughter, Louise, two and one-half years old, from his former wife, a niece of the late Ward McAllister. The father was arrested by a strategem in the palm room of the Imperial Hotel on Tuesday night.
NEWPORT, Oct. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. J.M. Clark have gone to New York for a month's visit, after which time they will return to occupy apartments here for the Winter months.
The new double bill at the Irving Place Theatre, affords an evening of light and buoyant amusement, at once wholesome and abundantly human.

When Capt. John J. Delaney of the East Thirty-fifth Street Police Station was placed on trial before Commissioner Partridge at Headquarters yesterday, charged with failing to suppress an alleged poolroom in the Sherman Hotel, 156 East Forty-second Street, Gen. B.F. Tracy, his counsel, indicated that he would seek to close the case by having the Captain retired on the ground that he is rapidly becoming blind from the effect of an old wound.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 15. -- A chrysanthemum wedding took place at noon today at the Summer residence here of Mrs. A.F. Warburton, widow of a former New York lawyer, when her daughter. Miss Grace Irving, was married to Myron J. Brown of the Empire State Bank, New York City. The bride wore white satin de chine, with lace and pearl trimmings, and carried orchids and lilies of the valley.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 15. -- Earl Whitney, the young man arrested here last Saturday, charged with the murder of A.B. Chinn and with seriously wounding ais son Asa, made a complete confession here today, admitting that he and Claude O'Brien, his "pal," did the killing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- At noon to-day at the Church of the Epiphany, Miss Anne Ingraham, daughter of D.P. Ingraham, deceased, of New York, and Hugh J. Jewett of Baltimore were married. The ushers were Harrison Thomas, Markhall Marshall, Richard Bayard, Benjamin Gerswald, Walter Lord, and Robert Garrett, all of Baltimore; Robinson Molinard of Philadelphia, William S. Scott of New York, and W.P. Reeves of Indiana.

DOVER, Del., Oct. 15. -- The General Assembly of Delaware is to be called into extraordinary session, unless circumstances and conditions now existing in the Republican Party of the State are revolutionized. Gov. Hunn is to issue the proclamation convening the Legislature at 12 o'clock next Monday to transact important business, not yet mentioned, but which may be specified in the proclamation.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In an editorial in THE TIMES of Monday, Oct. 18, entitled "The Opinion of the Bar," you speak of Judge Hall, one of the candidates for the Supreme Sench, nominated by the Republican Party, in the following language:

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Chicago is to have a restaurant trust, capitalized at $5,000,000 if the plans of certain promoters are carried out. All the large restaurants of the city, it is contemplated, are to be drawn under one management, the head of each establishment, however, to retain the direction of his own place.

Only one race was actually decided at the second day's races of the Parkway Driving Club's Fall Meeting, held on their track art the junction of King's Highway and Ocean Parkway, Long Island, yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 15. -- Onward Silver, the great chestnut son of Onward and Sylvan Maid, went-two miles over the Kentucky Breeders' Association track to-day in 4:29 1/2, breaking the American two-mile record of 4:32, made by Greenlander in 1803. Hudson was in the sulky, and Onward Silver had a running mate.

A neatly dressed young man yesterday morning gained access to the apartment of Mrs. Amy G. Watkins, in the Rosedale, 854 Seventh Avenue, on the plea of business, but really to demand money and jewelry, threatening to destroy Mrs. Watkins, her daughter, and himself with dynamite if the valuables were not given to him.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Almost immediately after Parliament was reopened yesterday afternoon there was a "scene," one of the Irish members almost going the length of assaulting the Right Hon. Arthur J. Balfour the Premier.

None of the college elevens suffered as a result of Wednesday's game, and nearly all of the players on the different teams reported for practice yesterday. It was an off day at Columbia, however, Dollin, Duden, Thorpe, Shaw, Weekes, and Smith were given but light practice, and the scrub was, therefore, able to do as well as the first team, two goals being scored in each case.

HAMILTON, Oct. 16. -- The ninth annual Herald foot race was run to-day and was won by Samuel A. Mellor, the representative of Hollywood Inn A.C., Yonkers, N. Y. Mellor and Lebarre ran neck and neck for eighteen miles. Lebarre was bitten by a dog and had to drop back.

District Attorney Jerome more than intimated yesterday that important results would follow the raids on alleged gambling resorts in the Tenderloin Tuesday night. While he would not say so in so many words, no one doubts that one of the immediate results will be the bringing of charges of neglect of duty against Capt. Michael Sheehan, recently in command at the West Thirtieth Street Station, and possibly against Inspector John J. Harley.

After much tribulation and in the face of many difficulties that would have daunted a man less resolute than he has shown himself to be, Signor Mascagni produced his opera of "Iris" at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening for the first time in New York. It was not the first time in America, for he had succeeded in putting it upon the stage in Philadelphia two nights before.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- The annual report of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1902, which was approved by the Board of Directors at a meeting yesterday, was to-day made public. The date of the close of the financial year having been changed from Nov. 30 to June 30, the report covers a period of seven months.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16. -- The general relief in sentiment occasioned by the settlement of the coal strike has produced a better feeling among the local lending institutions which, in turn, is making its favorable impression the tone of the securities market. The tone to-day was firmer, with brokers generally in a more cheerful mood.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Oct, 16. -- The battle near La Victoria, Venezuela, between the army commanded by President Castro and the revolutionary forces, which began on Monday morning, lasted until the afternoon of that day and recommenced on Tuesday morning, resulting in the retirement of Castro to La Victoria on Tuesday afternoon, was resumed again fiercely at 5 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The forthcoming volume of mineral resources of the United States for 1901, United States Geological Survey, estimates the world's production of coal that year at 866,165,540 short tons.

Four jurors were added yesterday to the six secured on Wednesday for the trial of Roland B. Molineux, charged with the murder of Mrs. Katharine J. Adams. It is believed that two jurors will be obtained this morning, and that the next step in the case will be the opening address of Assistant District Attorney James W. Osborne for the prosecution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Col. A.L. Mills, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, has made his annual report to the Secretary of War. He says that the discipline of the corps of cadets of the Academy had been very satisfactory throughout the year. He makes the following reference to hazing:

Sixty-one suspicious characters, the majority of them with prison records, and all considered by Superintendent of Elections McCullagh as doubtful persons, were rounded up last night at Police Headquarters by men of Capt. Titus's staff in accordance with a plan submitted to Commissioner Partridge earlier in the day.

Without doubt the person whom the inhabitants of those parts of this country which depend upon anthracite coal have mainly to thank for "a happy issue out of all their afflictions" is the President of the United States. He took a grave risk when he originally invited a conference between the representatives of labor and capital whose differences had resulted in an industrial crisis and a general apprehension of wide distress.

The details of Sir Thomas Lipton's challenge for the America Cup, through the Royal Ulster Yacht Club of Belfast, were made public last night at the special meeting of the New York Yacht Club. The time for the races, as was expected, has been set for August and the challenging yacht will be a 90-footer, as in the last two contests for the cup.

Deputy Police Commissioner Piper appeared as the trial judge at the Central Office yesterday for the first time. His manner was brusque and he saved time when possible. He had forty-eight cases, and some remained at the close of the proceedings.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has bought the Parker Building, a twelve-story mercantile structure at the southeast corner of Fourth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, on plot 131 by 150, giving in part payment the Westminster Hotel property, at the northwest corner of Irving Place and Sixteenth Street, 146 by 175 and irregular.

Senator Depew was the principal speaker last night at the opening mass meeting of the Republican campaign in the Twenty-seventh Assembly District, held in the West Side Lyceum, Fifty-second Street and Seventh Avenue, and confined his remarks largely to a discussion of Bird S. Coler's speech of the night before in accepting the Democratic nomination for Governor of the State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- There has been more comment on the selection of Edgar E. Clark, Grand Chief of the Order of Railway Conductors, than on that of any of the other Commissioners. While the suggestion is made that the President gave the term "sociologist" a most liberal interpretation to make it fit Mr. Clark, it is freely admitted that Mr. Clark is a man well fitted for the services to be performed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Notwithstanding the President's recent arduous labors, he was up early this morning and at work at his desk. Dr. Lung and Surgeon General O'Reilley, when they made their usual morning visit, found him in high spirits at the prospective settlement of the coal strike.

SCRANTON, Oct. 16. -- Thomas H. Watkins, the member of the President's coal commission whose appointment was due to his knowledge of the coal mining business, was formerly of the firm of Simpson Watkins, of which C.D. Simpson was the senior member. Mr. Watkins was born in West Pittston forty-five years ago, but has lived in Scranton for the last twenty years.
CAPE HAITIEN, Oct. 16. -- Limbe has been evacuated by the revolutionists.

A spectre -- that of a man's thoughtless youth -- stalked into the office of Commissioner Sturgis, at Fire Headquarters, while the trial of Edward F. Croker, Chief of Department, was in progress yesterday afternoon, went to the witness chair, laid its hand on Assistant Foreman John Rush of Engine Company No. 33, detailed as Supervising Engineer, and branded him as an ex-convict.

If nothing occurs to interfere with the resumption of mining under the modus vivendi arranged by the President pending the action by the Board of Arbitrators on the questions at issue between the striking miners and the operators the coal famine should be quickly relieved.

Our neighbor The Sun has gone about the discussion of Attorney General KNOX'S speech in exactly the right way. It attempts an exposition of his theories of the power of the Federal Government to control trusts and then seeks to make them appear dangerous and revolutionary.

-- That document which came, or seemed to come, from the non-union miners at work in the collieries of Forest City, Penn., was impressive enough in its way, and undoubtedly described with some approach to accuracy the emotions with which the men who did not join or have deserted the strikers contemplate the possibility of a compromise with the union.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- Stockholders of the Manufactured Rubber Company, one of the many enterprises promoted by W.W. Gibbs, held a special meeting in Camden to day and unanimously approved the plan of reorganization as formulated by the committee.
Announcement is made of the retirement from active service Oct. 15 of Brig. Gen. John I. Rodgers, at his own request.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 16. -- To-day was one of surprises at the golf tournament of the Brooklawn Country Club. The first surprise was when R.S. White, 2d, of New Haven defeated Charles H. Seeley, the State champion, in the first round for the Brooklawn Cup by 1 up. Seeley went to pieces on the greens.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Oct. 16. -- The election registrations have been a complete farce. The Federals were shut out in a majority of the precincts of the island as the result of an order of the Executive Council placing a majority of Republicans on each board.
