PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 16. -- Bishop Spalding, who has been named as one of the commission to arbitrate the coal strike, would not talk of the situation to-night. When asked for an interview, he said:

B. Hill is to make the principal spoken at the Tammany ratification meeting to be held in and around the Wigwam on Wednesday evening, Oct. 22. Leader Charles F. Murphy made this announcement yesterday, and many of the old-time Croker leaders were astonished. The speech next week will be the first delivered by Mr. Hill in Tammany Hall during the past fourteen years.

With pleasant weather, a fast track, and large fields the racing at the Morris Park race track yesterday was of an indeal character to all except the betting element. For the betting patrons of racing, however, the afternoon was a blank, of the most dismal character, for in the course of the six races run not a favorite won, the best backed horses being beaten with a persistence that went to the extreme of malignance.

Freshly mined anthracite in New York within twenty-four hours after mining has started, and plenty of it two weeks later, was what the anthracite operators predicted yesterday. The coal dealers made the time longer, but the operators say the dealers do not know how soon coal can be rushed to tidewater in the present emergency.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- New York exchange to-day was 10 cents discount. Time and call loans, 6 per cent.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., Oct. 16. -- One hundred striking miners at Rosemont have adjusted the trouble with the Weaver Coal Company and returned to work to-day. Final settlement was made last night. The miners got nearly everything they asked.
The third day of the Fall meeting of the Parkway Driving Club, held on their track at the junction of King's Highway and Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, yesterday, brought out the largest crowd of the meet.

Every day there are announcements of new engagements. From abroad comes the latest. It is that of Miss Alice Ward, the sister of Reginald Henshaw Ward of London, late of New York, to Capt. Cyril Blackburn Tew of the British Army. Miss Ward and her brother, Reginald Henshaw Ward, were formerly residents of Boston.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Hugh Armor Ward of New York and Sara, daughter of H.H. Gilfry, Principal Legislative Clerk of the United States Senate, were married at St. Margaret's Church, Westminster, at noon to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A paragraph in the last naval appropriation act which provides for the construction of one firstclass battleship at a Government navy yard, stipulates that the Navy Department shall keep an exact account of every item of expense incidental to the construction of the ship, with a view to determining the difference between the cost of building the ship at Government yards and by contract.

One of the responsibilities devolving upon the operators, and one which they cannot be permitted to forget or neglect, is to protect and defend against all comers the men who have had the courage to remain at work through the strike. So far as he could do so, President MITCHELL has promised them immunity from union molestation and persecution.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- The stockholders of the Pullman Car Company met here to-day, and re-elected all the old Directors for the ensuing year. The usual quarterly dividend of $2 per share from net earnings was declared, payable Nov. 15 to stockholders of record at the close of business Nov. 1.
Those pretty tapestry-covered writing pads cost $2. They are large, and when opened show a blotter-covered writing tablet on one side and pockets for writing paper, envelopes, , on the other.

Changes in the personnel of a number of legations and embassies indicate the growth at Washington of an intention to allow our diplomatic representatives to make diplomacy a career. The old way is to turn the favorite of a Senator into some legation or Consulate and keep him there until some stronger or more exasperating Senator shall manage to oust him for his own selection.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Vice Chancellor Emery to-day appointed Chauncey G. Parker of this city receiver of the New Jersey Agricultural Chemical Company in proceedings, growing out of confessed insolvency, that were begun a few minutes before the appointment. The company's plant is situated on the Passaic River, in Hudson County.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16. -- Young Corbett, the champion feather-weight pugilist of the world, was awarded the decision over Joe Bernstein of New York before the Eureka Athletic Club to-night in Music Hall. The men were to have boxed ten rounds to a decision at catch weights. Bernstein was in the pink of condition, and weighed in this afternoon at 124 1/2 pounds.

Wall Street received the official announcement of the coal stride's settlement with unqualified enthusiasm. The security market broadened, values hardening, activity extending in every quarter. Over a million shares were dealt in during the day, and with scarce an exception the whole list scored substantial net gains.

BOSTON, Oct. 16. -- The monetary situation is showing a tendency to soften. While rates at the Clearing House were still held to-day at 7 per cent., it was manifest the feeling was much improved. Call loans generally are still quoted mostly at 7 per cent, or higher, but concessions from these high figures are being made.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- There was general improvement in the local market to-day, but it was so limited in extent as to be disappointing generally. Trading was a little more active, prices fractionally higher. With the exception of International Powder, which was up 3 points, and Consolidated Lake Superior, which advanced 2 points, none of the local issues rose a point.

Two polar bears were passengers on the steamship Cymric of the White Star Line, which arrived here at her pier on Wednesday night. One was named Pinky and the other Panky. The latter wanted to see New York and have the reporters ask him as to his impressions of America. He attempted to escape, succeeded, and for a time gave his keepers a lively time to get him back into his cage again.
LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Money was fairly plentiful in the market to-day, but there was less demand for it. Discounts were easy.

A man of unusual girth, but commanding of countenance, sat alone in the "Amen Corner" of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday twirling his thumbs. On the lapel of his sack coat he wore a Loyal Legion button. He sat there for some time before he attracted any attention. Then some one in the crowded corridor said to the group with whom he was conversing: "I believe that is Gen. Shatter."
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Money was in somewhat better demand to-day, owing to tenders for $12,500,000 in Treasury bills.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- There is an easier feeling showing on all sides, in the money market. Call money was offered to-day to the best borrowers at 6 per cent. Sterling exchange naturally was stronger, by reason of the lower money rates and posted rates were advanced to-day, one-half cent all around.

If Mr. Farrow had published his book twenty or twenty-five years ago, when he was scouting, it would have been very interesting to many people. In those days the adventurous American might wander for weeks and months on the plains and in the mountains and find no roads but game trails and see no white man's face, and he might easily get scalped.

The action of yesterday's stock market demonstrates very clearly that such declines as were recently forced in quotations were due to selling induced, not by any doubt of the permanency and substantiability of the country's prosperity, but almost wholly by the stringency in the money market and the actual inability to obtain money to carry stocks on margin.

IN A state of society in which men are seldom taken at a higher valuation than their own the merits of Mr. J Foster Fraser's volume on Siberia are in danger of being underestimated. It claims to be nothing more than a record of personal impressions.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. G.A. England contributes to your issue of Oct. 11 a letter in criticism of Mr. Rudyard Kipling which seems to me not well inspired. If Mr. England had given S the matter a little more thought he might have revised his communication, or perhaps withheld it altogether.

BERLIN, Oct. 17. -- The Philharmonic House was filled to Its utmost capacity tonight, when the pro-Boer meeting was held. The sale of tickets realized $6,750, some persons paying as much as $23O for a scat. Military uniforms were almost entirely lacking.
Copyright, 1902, by John R. Whitney. SUBJECT. -- Joshua, and Caleb, Josh., xiv., 5-15.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The following telegraphic correspondence consisting of the message of President Roosevelt to John Mitchell. President of the United Mine Workers, and the latter's reply, was made public at the White House to-day:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In a desire to make a condensed statement in my letter that appeared on the 13th of September, I neglected to say that all my criticism was in reference to modern prose composition. This omission has exposed me to the arrows of ridicule, which, however, have not penetrated sufficiently to induce any return fire.

II. The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I was much interested in your note as to the authorship of Punch's memorable vcrses on the death of Abraham Lincoln. So great was the impression made upon my youthful mind by this magnificent requiem that the leaf of Punch containing it, and Tenniel's accompanying cartoon, was framed by me and hung up in my domicile, where it has remained ever since.

William Cruikshank's Sons and W. B. Parsons have sold for the Schermerhorn estate the northwest corner of Wall and Front Streets, a five-story building, on plot 33.9 by 35.5. The buyer is Frederick Beadel, who also owns 98 and 100 Wall Street and 120 and 122 Front Street, and who, with the corner just acquired, now controls a plot fronting 84.6 feet on Wall Street and 71.10 feet on Front Street.

SON of an eminent Italian historian and publicist, but possessing the advantages of English schooling and a cosmopolitan point of view, Luigi Villari has produced a little volume on Italy which is not only the most valuable item in Our European Neighbors Series, but also the most distinctive work on the subject treated of.
NEWPORT, Oct. 17. -- Mrs. H.B. Renwick of New York has rented for the season of 1903 the Leroy King cottage, which she occupied during the past Summer.

After serving thirty-two years on the police force, Inspector John J. Harley, who was in charge of the First Inspection District, yesterday tendered his resignation from the department to Commissioner Partridge, who immediately accepted it. The Inspector left the building after packing up his belongings, and was weeping as he did so.

THE only war that was ever determined by new and unsuspected mechanical contrivances was the short and conclusive campaign of Mr. Stockton's great war syndicate. In real war the cunning, secret weapons never do more than inflict a little local damage, destroy some property, and kill a few men, without the least effect on the result.
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- Gens. Corbin, Young, and Wood have tendered to Earl Roberts, Commander in Chief of the Forces, a cordial invitation to visit the United States.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 17. -- Reports were circulated to-night that the locals of the United Mine Workers in West Scranton, Pittston, and some other localities had voted to instruct their delegates to oppose the acceptance of the operators' proposition unless the companies would agree to discharge the non-union men, take back all the old employes, drop the suits instituted against strikers, and recognize the union.

Several important games are down on the football schedule for decision to-day. Chief among them is the Harvard-West Point contest on the field of the soldiers, although the annual contest between Pennsylvania and Brown at Philadelphia and Cornell and the Carlisle Indians are arousing more than ordinary interest.

It is the more surprising that the Bankers' Association of the State of New York should at this late date call for the repeal of the bankruptcy law on the ground that it has outlived its usefulness, when the House pf Representatives passed at the last session a bill to perfect and continue the law, the sponsor for which was one of our leading members of Congress, Mr. RAY, just appointed to the Federal bench.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- The National Shawmut Bank has sent to Washington $1,000,000 Massachusetts 31/2 per cent, bonds. This will release $750,000 United States Government bonds now pledged for deposit of Government funds, upon which the bank will take out additional banknote circulation.

Argument was beard by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday afternoon on appeals from two orders In proceedings growing out of the action of Fire Commissioner Sturgis in relieving Chief Edward F. Croker from duty recently. That was before formal charges had been made against the Chief.

With one juror still needed to complete the panel of twelve men who are to hear the second trial of Roland B. Molineux, the eleven men who had qualified were excused yesterday until Monday, and Justice John S. Lambert, who is trying the case in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, listened to a long argument on the question of admitting the "Barnet letters" in this trial.

Nobody will doubt the fruitfulness nor the exemplary character of the District Attorney's latest raid on the gamblers who weighs the significance of the fact that the "roll" discovered in "SHANG' DRAPER'S safe amounted to $800,000, lawful money of the United States of America.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 17. -- The annual International Convention of the Disciples of Christ, which convened in Omaha last night, is now in session with nearly 20,000 delegates from all parts of the United States and foreign countries. To-day's work was given over to the Women's Board of Missions of the Christian Church.

LONDON, Oct 5. -- Miss Elizabeth Banks's "Autobiography of a Newspaper Girl" has given rise to a discussion as to the ethics of reporting. Miss Banks came into notice here a few years ago by writing a series of articles describing her experiences as a domestic servant.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 17. -- After a three days' session in Louisville the State Railroad Commission to-night completed and forwarded to the Inter-State Commerce Commission at Washington a formal complaint against the alleged consolidation of the Louisville and Nashville, Southern Railway, and Atlantic Coast Line Roads.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The booksellers are so anxious to purchase good stock that the Autumn season has begun better than any since the disastrous one of 1899 when the South African war began. - - More novels than ever are demanded, and a remarkably large number of expensive art volumes are announced.
Major Ira MacNutt, Ordnance Department, will proceed to Fort Howard on official business pertaining to the inspection of the armament at that post and the work of mechanics thereon.
PANAMA, Oct. 17. -- Gen. Perdomo yesterday notified the foreign Consuls here that he had assumed the functions of supreme commander of the Colombian forces on the isthmus.

George Meredith and Lady Duff Gordon. That George Meredith, little as he now practices his art, has lost none of his thoroughly subjective style is shown in his preface to "Letters from Egypt," by Lady Duff Gordon, published by McClure, Phillips Co.

The defeat of the favorites in the first, four races at the Morris Park race track | yesterday completed a line of eleven straight defeats for first choices, counting in the races of the day before and the last event on Wednesday, the run of eleven losing favorites establishing a record for the year.

There is some very good characterization in Ellen Thorneycroft Fowler's new story. "Fuel of Fire," (Dodd. Mead Co.,) and the play of wit and epigram in her dialogue, though it may occasionally bewilder a plodding reader, never tires him. Miss Fowler preserves Her reputation for verbal smartness, and she tells her almost plotless story with sustained buoyancy.

Pretty clearly, the sentiment in Denmarh, against the sale of the Danish West Indies to the United States seems to bt merely a sentiment. Moreover, it is a distinct triumph of sentiment over reason. It is admitted on all hands that Denmark cannot make the islands pay, and that to keep them means a constantly increasing drain of money from a little kingdom which has none too much.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In every novel that I have read recently an important character (hero or heroine) meets with an accident, and is for a time laid up by it, usually with the accompaniment of "tenderly nursed." This is necessary to the plot, and must by no means be discouraged.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: TO a Scotchman from the "Outer Hebrides," who is of a different race from the general run of Englishmen, or Lowland Scotch -- who are the same race of people -- it is rather amusing to notice the antipathy that still exists on both sides of the Tweed.

I. The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have often wondered why I never saw any reference to Lincoln's curious practice of writing the names of the days of the week, beginning each with a small letter, as "monday." "tuesday," and so on. It is true that he did this only occasionally, but the fact that he did it at all excited my curiosity.

BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- Sir James Rennell Redd, whose "Myrtie and Oak," a volume of poems, will soon be published by Messrs. Forbes Co., is much better known in this country as Mr. Rennell Rodd, for his K.C. in the Order of St. Michael and St. George did not come to him until 1899, after his return from his mission to Abyssinia as special envoy to King Menelek.

It is a matter of much interest that the reform of the relations of the Treasury to the currency has been made the subject of a strong address in the meeting of the Ohio State Bankers' Convention now in session at Cincinnati. This was done by Mr. GEORGE R. BOHRER, President of the German National Bank, in his welcome to the delegates from the State.

Many critics of abundant zeal, and especially among the Germans, have roundly accused Corneille with pilfering his best ideas from the Spanish dramatists, and all over the world it has been a favorite subject of formal debate in college forensics and literary societies whether or not Corneille was a plagiarist. The truth of the question has never been recondite, and had it not been clouded by controversial zeal owould not be a matter of importance.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17. -- Senator John T. Morgan of Alabama, now visiting in this city, was interviewed to-day on the coal strike and on the isthmian canal outlook. Speaking of President Roosevelt's success in bringing about arbitration, the Senator said:

The announcement that Secretary Shaw had bought $5,OOO,OOO of bonds, and would buy more, which was posted in the SubTreasury yesterday morning, caused little surprise in Wall Street. In spite of the denials from Harvey Fisk Sons, Vermilye Co., the National City Bank, and others interested in the syndicate that such an offer had been made, Wall Street for the last few days has insisted that bond purchases were coming.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Recent advices from Cuba, declaring that great distress exists there, were verified to-day by Major George M. Barbour, for four years after the American occupation Sanitary Commissioner in charge of Santiago and neighboring towns, who said he had recently received a letter from a Santiago merchant saying that 14,000 men were out of work in that city.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 17. -- Frank Strong, ex-President of the Oregon State University, was installed to-day as Chancellor of the University of Kansas. Arthur Hadley, President of Yale, was the leading speaker. President Hadley dwelt upon the purposes of the American University, pointing out that the functions were different in various sections of the country.
SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 17. -- Thomas H. Watkins of tills city who has been appointed a member of the Mining Arbitration Commission, said to-day:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- The local market was strong in spots to-day, substantial net gains being recorded in several issues. Electric Storage Battery was up 2, to 86; Fairmount Park Transportation 3, to 27; United Gas 1/2, to 114 3/4; International Smokeless Powder 2, to 46, and United Companies of New Jersey 1, to 283.

From South Africa comes what purports to be a history of the great diamond which President KRUGER took with him to Europe, and which he has probably disposed of, though in what way is still a mystery. It appears that the stone originally belonged to MOSHESH, a Basuto chief, who was compelled to surrender it to 'TCHAKA, the Zulu King.

Mrs. Rachel Richman, the New York merchant's wife who was arrested in Alexandria Bay last Summer on the charge of having stolen valuables worth more than S25.000 from Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Delabarre, has been adjudged insane. Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court, yesterday confirmed the report of Vernon M. Davis, the referee before whom evidence as to the woman's mental condition had been taken.

Deputy Police Commissioner Piper accosted a policeman of the Seventeenth Precinct last night at the corner of Seventh Avenue and West Twentieth Street and informed him that he would prefer charges against him for talking several minutes to a civilian. Two other policemen also were the object of the Commissioner's attention.
The terms of the traffic alliance between the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul and the Union Pacific became known yesterday.

Superintendent of Elections John McCullagh yesterday failed to get judicial sanction for his scheme of a general roundup of "suspicious characters" to have them held in confinement during the last two days of registration. At his instigation Capt. Titus of the Detective Bureau on Thursday arrested sixty-seven men, most of them with prison records.

Beginning Oct. 28, Messrs. Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge will sell in London in ten sessions the choice stock of rare books, illuminated and other manuscripts, engravings, and drawings, English and foreign book-plates, , of the late Gilbert Ifold Ellis. formerly a book dealer at 29 New Bond Street, London.

So much has been written about Elizabethan England by the man of letters who has in view only the picturesque, sentimental, and literary interests of that great age that a great deal is to be forgiven the man who confines himself to hard facts. Mr. Hall views Elizabethan, society from the point of view of the public record office.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17. -- The advance in International Trust was one of the leading features in to-day's improving market. The stock is believed to be on the way to a full recovery from the recent depression. United Railways issues were higher on more confident general buying. G.B.S. Brewing issues continue to show improvement.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 17. -- In accordance with, the call issued yesterday by order of the Executive Boards of the anthracite districts of the miners' union, all "locals" throughout the coal fields began electing delegates to-day to the convention which will be held, here next Monday to consider the acceptance or rejection of the arbitration plan submitted by President Roosevelt.

Marie Corelli seems to have triumphed in her recent amusing controversy with the editor of a London periodical. The advertisement she has received from his publication of her letter and the reply, which have been telegraphed all over the English-speaking world, will do her no harm. Perhaps she made a slight error of judgment in writing to the editor, but her mistake was natural.

-- As the last party which set out for the purpose of "exploring" Tiburon Island frankly declared the intention of killing its inhabitants and seizing their treasures, the news that the explorers have probably been slaughtered and eaten by the islanders will produce little grief and less excitement in the public mind.

MR. HOWELLS has treated Thackeray with severity for chatting with the reader in his novels, but that is no reason why Mr. Howells should not chat with his own readers in fit times and places. There is nothing else that he enjoys so much, and because he imposes on himself a self-denying ordinance in his novels, he gives his inclination freer course on other tracks.

The Merchants Association is doing a good thing in sending its representative, Mr. H.D. DUMONT, to Cuba, to make a careful inquiry on the ground as to the situation of the island with reference to American trade and the probable effect of reciprocity.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 17. -- The attractive feature of the open golf tournament at the Brooklawn Country Club today was the professional match between Willie Smith of Midlothian and the open champion in 1899 and John Harland, the Brooklawn professional. A large gallery followed the players over the 18-hole course.

Judge Henry C. Coman of Madison County, the Republican candidate for Attorney General, was in this city last evening and called at State headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Judge Coman has been around the State to some extent since the convention in Saratoga. He says he finds the conditions generally favorable to the Republicans

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The export figures for September are considered encouraging. They are the largest ever shown for September, with the single exception of that month in the year 1900, and fall less than $300,000 below the highwater mark made in that year.

In the American National bowling tournament last night the Fidelia team scored 1,092, the highest score of the year so far in the city, and 5 points more than the highest team score of last year in that tournament, which was 1,087. The scores follow:

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- Secretary of State John T. McDonough gave a hearing to-day on the protest filed by Jay W. Forrest on behalf of the Liberal Democratic Party against the acceptance for filing of the nominating petition of the Greater New York Democracy.

Discussion of the possibilities of Chicago as a Literary Centre has often tempted Eastern humorists to cheap but harmless frivol, but the subject is really of serious importance to the whole country. It is important to know that Chicago now has not only the "largest bookstore in the world," but is the home of prosperous and growing publishing houses and of many writers of more than National distinction.

TRENTON, Oct. 17. -- The United States Packing Company, believed to be the "Beef Trust," was incorporated here to-day with a blanket charter. As was the case with the United States Steel Corporation, the papers filed to-day with the Secretary of State show a small capitalization, only $1,000,000, but it is understood that is to be quickly raised to $500,000,000.

WASHINTON, Oct. 17. -- The position which has been assigned by the President to Carroll D. Wright as recorder to the real strike commission of arbitration is one of the highest importance. He will have no vote in the deliberations of the commision, but will inevitably have a strong influence on the work of the commission.

Mrs. Cora Woodruff, wife of Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff, who has apartments in this borough at 2 West Thirty-eighth Street, was robbed of $330 worth of jewelry while out shopping yesterday afternoon and recovered the gems, which she had just purchased, after an exciting chase in the shopping district.

THIS long-delayed volume of the American Men of Letters Series is a welcome contribution to the mass of Longfellow literature Col. Higginson in a brief prefare says that the present work, like all memoirs of Longfellow, must rest partly on the "Life" of the poet, "so admirably prepared by his brother sixteen years ago," but that it will be found marked by three especial characteristics of its own:

Having exhausted his last resource in warding off exposure on a charge of embezzlement and with a criminal indictment staring him in the face William C. Turner, forty-five years old, ex-President of the Climax Bottle Company of 37 Murray Street, this city, a well-known business man and cousin of Gov. Odell, gave up the struggle yesterday afternoon and put a bullet through his brain.

"The Heart of the Doctor," by Mabel G. Foster, is a rarity for these days in a plain, simple, entertaining love story with neither historical events, historical characters, nor deep and painful social problems to take the place of that good old-fashioned requisite of a novel, a plot.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct, 17. -- Anything that a Biddle does in this city attracts attention, and for this reason alone the "letters of an American Woman," by Saran Biddle, would be insured of a success at least local. It may be added that the book, which is to be published during the coming week, is quite clever enough to warrant reading on its own account.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The Department of Agriculture's summary of the crops of the world shows that, owing to the remarkably cool and wet Summer experienced throughout a considerable part of Europe, the harvest of 1902 is one of the latest on record.

Seemed Like a Conspiracy. MR. TITU'S Las it in for his father-in-law. The old gentleman is in nowise to blame, but Titus has to fight it out with somebody, so he vents his spite on the leader of the opposition.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The brief note in THE TIMES of Oct. 12, signed by William Sabine, Jr., escaped my attention till this morning. The note says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: After some six years of travel over the elevated railroad in this city, and noticing signs at the stations concerning no smoking on platforms or stations and prohibiting the carrying of lighted cigars on the trains, I have come to this conclusion: Law and rules are farces, and common decency is not to be found in the average "smoker."
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 18 -- What is probably the last full week of the anthracite coal strike closed to-day without anything developing to change the peaceful trend of events.

The details of the financial policy of the Secretary of the Treasury of the King of Siam are not, perhaps, of exciting interest to business men of the United States, where we have troubles of our own in such little matters as an inelastic currency and an undue accumulation of the money of the country in the Treasury through customs and internal revenue collections in excess of disbursements.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- London is itself again. The fashionable thoroughfares are thronged with people, the shops in Regent Street and Oxford Street are displaying their most attractive wares, life and movement are apparent which are not often to be observed at this time of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The order of the President issued to-day in regard to the violation of the civil service law by Republican politicians in charge of the campaign in Pennsylvania and Ohio is interpreted here as a rebuke to those gentlemen.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- Siam's Crown Prince, Chowfa Maha Vajiravudh, looked over Cramps' shipyard and the Baldwin Locomotive Works to-day, and had a drive that showed him a good part of Philadelphia's residential section besides. He was on the go for six hours, but he had such a good time, he said, that he did not care how tired he became, adding, "It is all so big, so wonderful."
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Sir Thomas Lipton, in conversation with a representative of The Associated Press, to-day, said:

SYDNEY, Sept. 15 -- The Australian tariff, after eleven months' discussion, has been passed in a form very different to that in which it was introduced, the Federal Senate having insisted on numerous amendments, abandoning others at the last moment rather than prolong the state of suspense in which the whole Australian business world had so long been held.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The return of Mrs. Roosevelt to Oyster Bay to close her home there for the Winter, with the departure of Mrs. Shaw and Mrs. Payne for the West, has left but two matrons of the Administration circle in Washington, Mrs. Knox and Mrs. Hitchcock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The qualities which made Pension Commissioner Eugene F. Ware famous under the name of "Iron Quill of Kansas," have not deserted him, now that he is a public official. He created a sensation to-day among the Pension Bureau clerks by adopting a novel method of announcing promotions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- At the last session of Congress $20,000 was appropriated to defray the expenses of experiments to determine the practicability of using oil for fuel, particularly in the navy. In addition to that sum the Navy Department had $7,000 which was the balance of an appropriation for a similar purpose.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- At a meeting to-day of the Board of Governors of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Association of the United States, held in Independence Hall, Admiral Dewey was elected President.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- A Blue Book has been issued containing a detailed report of the officers appointed by the Commander in Chief of the Army to inquire into the working of the remount department. The report speaks generally favorably of the arrangements of the department and of the class of animals purchased.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While agreeing with the Society for the Prevention of Crime that the Police Department could enforce the laws against the so-called Raines Law Hotels, and especially against the 10 per cent, which "throw the law overboard utterly,' I beg to suggest that arrests by the police for violations of the excise law have not borne much fruit in the way of finally disposing of these bogus hotels.

AS A complimentary recognition of his devotion in their behalf the young women of the Architectural League in New York studying under the direction of Artist William Chase decided to have his portrait done by another American artist who has won a worldwide repute with his brush -- John Sargent.

In the football world yesterday the biggest surprise of the day was the defeat of Cornell by the Carlisle Indians at Ithaca, Pennsylvania was beaten by Brown, Princeton was scored upon for the first time this season, and the eleven at Yale had all they could do to win from Pennsylvania State College.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Ambassador Cambon leaves here on the Savoie to-day for America to present his letters of recall to President Roosevelt and to bid farewell to his innumerable friends in the United States.
CAMDEN, Oct. 18 -- William Early, a Merchantville lawyer, came here to-day to wind up some legal business for a client, and finished it in a way entirely unexpected.

On Tuesday, Nov. 4, forty-two States will elect Representatives to the Fifty-eighth Congress, 378 in all, the total membership having been increased by the reapportionment under the twelfth census to 386. Eight members, all Republicans, have already been elected -- four from Maine and two each from Oregon and Vermont.

WITHIN recent years a large number of famous sites and events in this city have been marked by memorial tablets. The majority have been wisely placed, but complaints have been made against others that they are misleading, sometimes in wording and sometimes in an unfortunate selection of locality.

AMONG the men who gathered at the Post Of- fice at Northwood on Saturady night to wait for the mail from Hinckley, after the usual Saturday night fashion, in the Adirondacks, were Lem Lawson, of the Seaberry Settlement, and Uncle Jimmie Keyes, who lives not far from Mad Tom's Hole.
OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 18 -- Two thousand more delegates to the National Convention of the Disciples of Christ arrived to-day.

ODESSA, Oct. 4 -- We had determined to spend a short time in the Caucasus if it could be in any way managed; so, in spite of discouraging reports from all sides as to the difficulties to be encountered at the Russian frontier, the trouble about passports, and the danger of bandits on the mountains, we started boldly forth, two women with a courier.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Treasury Department has detected a new counterfeit ten-dollar United States note of the series of 1901.

As the Autumn advances the suburbs and the country generally become more and more popular. About a fortnight ago it seemed as if every one was returning to town. But that was only the usual passing through after the weather became too cold for the Summer resorts. The first rainy and gray days at seaside and mountain, the first frost and indications of Autumn, drove the fashionable denizens of wood and shore to town.

At the annual meeting of the Board of Managers of St. Luke's Hospital yesterday afternoon the report for the year ended Sept. 30 was read. It announced that 2,663 persons had been treated; of these, 1,536 had been discharged as cured, 434 discharged as improved, 75 discharged unimproved, 292 had died, and 201 remained in the hospital.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- A knotty question is to be considered in the Fifth Judicial District, besides the political mix-up. The State election law legalizes the use of voting machines; it also provides for a ballot on which every party and independent candidate is entitled to a column and an emblem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Owing to the fact that at the election next month no local officers will be chosen in Maryland both parties are complaining of the indifference manifested by many of the voters.

THERE is not a club in the lower part of New York which has a more attractive floor for its headquarters than the fourteenth story of the Downing Building, 108 Fulton Street, where the New York. Business Woman's Club has its rooms. The club is less than two and a half years old, and it has proved conclusively that women can support a lunch club.

Rain and a heavy track put an end to the scheduled brushes that were to mark the Fall opening of the Road Drivers' Association on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday afternoon. The members, however, assembled in large numbers at the clubhouse on the Speedway, which has been thoroughly renovated during the Summer, and enjoyed a beefsteak dinner, at which President John P. Cockerill and Alexander Newburger acted as hosts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Democratic platform of New York has called out general discussion over its plank referring to the right of Governmental control of the coal mines by virtue of eminent domain, which was so ably defended by ex-Senator Hill in his speech in Brooklyn on Saturday night.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The action last night of the Bar Association of the City of New York relative to the failure of one of the great political parties to join in the renomination of Judge John Clinton Gray for Judge of the Court of Appeals, deserves the hearty approval of fair-minded men, whether Republicans or Democrats.

Hall Caine arrived from England yesterday on the Cunarder Lucania. He was accompanied by his wife and his eighteenyear-old son, who is now editor of Household Words, and who recently established a "Dickens Fellowship," an organization of admirers of Dickens's works.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 18 -- The steamship Monroe, building for the Old Dominion Steamship Company, was launched at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's yards here this morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Regarding the editorial of Oct. 13, in which it was said: "Nobody says anything against Judge Hall, or much in his favor." In the letter of Messrs. Wickersham Cadwalader you hear the professionals. I speak as a layman.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The polo contest on the Georgian Court polo grounds to-day was the final match for the Ladies' Cup presented by Mrs. George J. Gould, Mrs. Mary Kingdon, Mrs. W.A. Hamilton, and Mrs. H.L. Herbert. The Lakewood and Rockaway teams were the contestants, and the home quartet won by 6 3/4, goals to 5 1/2.
It seems to be admitted that the present British Government has challenged a very dangerous conflict by producing the Education bill, about which all England is more or less excited.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my article called "Denmark and the Treaty," published in the current North American Review, many things were left unsaid, and some of them must be reserved as a last resource. -- But other points may be brought out here, and one of them is suggested by the cable from Copenhagen published in the newspapers of last Thursday.

EVER since New York shops had windows the proprietors have used them, not for light only, but as a means for exposing their wares. As trade and luxury have advanced the setting forth of articles for sale has become more important, until to-day, in the largest and best establishments, a person is selected for the arrangement of the windows, and he has no other employment.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Loans between banks at the Clearing House were marked down to-day to 6 per cent., and such business as was done outside was largely at concessions from recently quoted figures. Sterling exchange remains quiet and firm. New Tort funds, It and 20c discount; call loans, 6 @ 7; time money, 5 1/2 @ 7; Clearing House exchanges, $23,962,123; balances, $963,795.

TALKING about gowns -- and what woman property constituted isn't talking of them more or less? -- those which Ida Conquest wears as the pretty young wife in "The Two Schools," at the Madison Square Theatre, are quite as smart as any to be seen on the stage in New York just now.

A movement has been started by Truant Officer McBane to establish homes for working boys. The work of the truant officer brings him into close personal contact with just the class of boys for whom the boarding houses are intended, and it has long been patent that something ought to be done for them.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 18 -- The fight between the Gould and Cassatt interests opened in earnest to-day, when the Western Union Telegraph Company, a Gould corporation, filed a bill in equity against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to restrain the defendant from taking away from the Western Union the right to use the telegraph lines along the Pennsylvania tracks.

THE situation which has developed in the anthracite district of Pennsylvania, could not possibly arise in Canada under Canadian law. Coal lands in Canada are not sold into private ownership. The Dominion Coal Company of Nova Scotia, for instance, does not own its coal mines.

Yale still leads the Eastern college football teams in the total number of points scored to date, having made 185 to 6 for the opposing teams. Tufts still having the honor of being the only team which has yet scored against the Blue. Cornell is next, with 178 points to 16 for opponents, having been scored against by Williams and defeated by Carlisle.

There were indications at Republican State headquarters, yesterday that the efforts which the Republican managers have been putting forth to infuse interest in the State campaign have not been without result. During the day telegrams were received from various points in the State giving information about the registration yesterday, and the information was of a character which was highly satisfactory to Chairman Dunn.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The plans for the state progress of King Edward and Queen Alexandra on Saturday, Oct. 25, have been definitely settled. The royal procession will so at a walking pace through the following thoroughfares:

THROUGHOUT the entire reconstruction of the new White House, or the "President's House," as it was called of old, the prevailing simplicity and richness and the harmony of all the details in furniture, hangings, carvings, and marble show the domination of one mind in the arrangement of the whole.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your remarks about translations yesterday you seem to have confused two distinct things -- the reading of translations apart from the original text for the sake of the thought, and on the other hand, the use of them to make easy the reading of that text when one is supposed to be mainly concerned with the latter.
The Populist vote in Georgia dwindled to less than 6,000 at the State election in October. In 1900 they cast over 23,000 votes for their candidate for Governor.

THE little Consular circle at the Calumet will be broken shortly by the departure of Count Prat of the Italian Consular Service. Count Prat has been attached to the office in this city, but has now been made a full-fledged Consul, with a post in China.

The opening up to trade of remote regions and the extension of civilization among barbarous people have called the attention of scientists to the need of a universal language which all may understand. There are to-day hundreds of different languages and dialects spoken in the four quarters of the globe.

ONE of the greatest sensations of the year among jewelers and precious stone dealers in the United States has been caused by the discovery of valuable chrysoprase mines in Tulare County, California. This stone has been practically lost to the world for centuries. The remarkable history of its rise and fall in popularity is an Old World legend.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your report of the resolutions condemning the National Bankruptcy act of 1898, adopted by the State Bankers' Convention on Friday, and published in Saturday's paper, I am much interested. Either the resolutions are badly worded or the framer of them was misinformed as to the nature of the act.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of the committee of the Bar Association on judicial nominations, containing a blanket recommendation of all the candidates for the position of Justice of the Supreme Court of this department, must not be accepted by the public as an expression of the sentiments of the large majority of the members of the Bar Association.

Miss Helen Drake, the only daughter of the late Albert Alson Drake, is to be married to James Arthur Mandeville in St. Thomas's Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, on "Wednesday afternoon, Nov. 5, at 3:30 o'clock. Miss Drake has selected for her maid of honor Miss Kathleen Gilbert, and her bridesmaids will be the Misses Anna Bell Englis of Brooklyn, Grace Edna Merrall, Florence Peterson, and Grace L. Brewster.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- T.P. O'Connor, M.P., has written for The Associated Press his impressions of the scene caused by the Irish members in the House of Commons Thursday and what he believes it portends, as follows:

Mascagni's last appearance in New York, for the present at any rate, will be to-night in a popular concert at the Metropolitan Opera House. After that he will start on his tour, which will take him to the Pacific Coast. Signore Pinto and Bianchini Cappelli and Signori Caffetto and Navarrini, of the opera company, will sing.

VINELAND, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The mystery surrounding the attack on Miss Clara Tuttle by a masked man on Thursday night still puzzles the police. The intruder is now believed to be a disappointed sweetheart masquerading as a burglar.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 18 -- Gov. Hunn late to-day decided that he would not call an extra session of the Legislature to give the Republicans one more chance to attempt to break the dead-lock and elect two United States Senators. Another plan of the Addicksites has gone astray, and the effects of this latest failure of their movement will greatly dishearten the Union Republicans on the eve of the election.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 18 -- The second day's sessions of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union was attended by 1,500 delegates. Reports of organizers and physical exercises conducted by Mrs. Frances W. Leiter, National Superintendent of Physical Education, occupied the time until the evangelistic hour, during which Miss Greenwood of New York presided.

-- There are several indirect blessings that may come from the coal strike, and one of them is likely to be the wider and more intelligent use of gas as fuel. Whether for cooking or heating purposes, gas of the sort now supplied costs more than coal at ordinary prices, if one considers only the number of heat units each produces for the same expenditure.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Major Evans Gordon, M.P., a member of the Royal Commission on Alien Immigration, who has just returned from a two months' visit to Russia, Poland, Galicla, and Roumania, where he has been studying the causes underlying the Jewish exodus thence, speaking to a representative of The Associated Press today, said:

A statistical exhibit of exceptional interest and value has just come from the National Treasury Department -- presenting in concise itemization the Government's revenue receipts and expenditures by fiscal years from 1856 to 1902, a review of forty-seven years of strenuous financial history. In this period -- virtually a half century -- are included the extraordinary finance performances incident to the civil war, wherein annual expenditures jumped from $66,000,000 to approximately $1,300,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The visit of Gens. Corbin and Young to England was concluded this morning, when they left Waterloo railroad station to embark on the American Lin steamship Philadelphia at Southampton. A crowd of friends was present, including Sir Thomas Lipton, Secretary Carter, representing Ambassador Choate; Naval Attache Clover and Military Attache Cassatt.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The mass meeting in Commonwealth Hall to-night was for the purpose of demonstrating the earnestness of the people of this city, represented by the Citizens' Union, in their efforts to wrest the control of the affairs of the municipality from the so-called ring. The building was packed before 8 o'clock and in the large audience were many women.

PITTSBURG, Oct, 18 -- Plans for the Wabash station are completed, and work of demolishing the old buildings on the site has started. A building nine stories in height, with a train shed of steel and glass covering three blocks, costing more than $1,000,000 will be erected. It is hoped to have the structure Completed by June 1, 1903.

COL. OPIE READ, novelist and playwright, was for many years identified with country newspapers in Kentucky and Tennessee. He says that one day he approached a Tanner in a Kentucky town and asked him if there was any news in his neighborhood.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- Two of the foremost living European Americanists, Profs. Seler and von Steinen, have been designated by the German Government to attend the Americanists' Congress, which will meet in New York this month. Their visit to the United States is of particular interest as both have given much time and attention to American exploration.

THE recent Grand Army encampment in Washington provoked a good deal of comment regarding the large numbers of civil war veterans who are still in good enough physical condition to endure the fatigue of a long march. Several Southern Democrats were discussing this in a Washingrton hotel lobby the other evening when Secretary Charles A. Edwards of the Democratic Congressional Committee said:

EASTON, Perm., Oct. 18 -- Lafayette defeated Manhattan in to-day's football game by a score of 38 to 5. The Manhattan line was comparatively weak, and the local players took full advantage of it. With the exception of a forty-yard and a fifty-yard run around the ends by Hall and Morrison, the Lafayette boys made all their games by plunging through the line.

DEAR JIM: There's nothing like having a scientifik mind. Pa says I've got one that's worth spending money on; but say, when a feller's got five sisters, all grown up and equipt with high-fallutin' ideas of manners and etiket, he needs something to make him forget the ignomy of being called "that small boy" fifty times a day.

O'DONOHUE was an Irishman of cheery aspect, and took the world and himself lightly enough. Yet when he was awakened at 3 o'clock of a cold morning by cries of fire and the very decided smell of burning wood, to say nothing of an ominous crackling sound, his face, as the people below the window of the blazing hotel in the Western town saw it, was a little pale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The information of the State Department concerning the status of the Danish West Indies purchase tends to confirm the report that the bill authorizing the sale is having a hard time getting through the Rigsdag. The majority in favor of the bill is so small that the illness of two members opposed to it is an important factor.

There hag been much said, "and, upon the whole, very ill-said," upon the question of the use of translations from the classics to assist the jaded undergraduate, ever since the Faculty of Hamilton made the question burning by denouncing the use of ponies altogether. No high license, no local option, no compromise with the evil thing among those austere men -- nothing but prohibition.

CONTRARY to the expectations of the tunnel engineers, the Board of Aldermen has suddenly changed front on the question of William Barclay Parsons's Astor Plaza scheme. By a good majority it was decided at the last meeting of the board that the private property on part of the block between Eighth and Ninth Streets, west of Fourth Avenue, should be condemned by the city rather than by the Rapid Transit Commission.

ITHACA, Oct. 18 -- Ex-Senator David B. Hill delivered the opening address of the campaign in Central New York here tonight before a large audience. The speaker was introduced by Prof. Duncan C. Lee of Cornell University.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Whom the gods would destroy, they first make mad," indicates the probable fate of the coal magnates who met the President on Oct. 3. They could not have had a better opportunity to let themselves down easy than was presented when Mr. Mitchell placed the interests of the miners absolutely in the keeping of President Roosevelt.

From time to time there is a revival of the project of establishing in the United States a theatre, similar to those maintained in France and Germany, for the presentation of plays which are classics, and hence possess interest for the student of the drama, but which are perhaps not popular enough to have the long runs indispensable to the present system of management.

How far New York is behind other progressive cities in handling, isolating, and treating contagious diseases is illustrated by the fact that whereas London cares for about 80 per cent. of the cases occurring within her municipal limits, New York has thus far been able to care for only about 10 per cent.

ACCORDING to the recently issued official returns dealing with the subject of immigration it appears that during the fiscal year which ended on June 30 last no, less than 22,000 residents of the United States abandoned their native or adopted country, and with bag and baggage and about $2,000,000, marched across the border into Canada, to take up their abode and become permanent settlers there.
The registration yesterday was fair for an off year, but the figures of Manhattan and the Bronx indicate a total for the four days under 1901 and 1900 and a little over those of 1898.

BASKETS are a specialty of the east side, more particularly of the German quarter. It is the ambition of every woman in the quarter to have a handsome and commodious market basket, and you may see hundreds of such baskets on the arms of men and women in Avenue A and the neighboring streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18.-The headquarters of the new steamship commission, the International Mercantile Marine Company, 'will be located in this city in about six months. All offices in this city of the various ship lines which compose the combination will be moved to the new Land Title and Trust Company Building, at Broad and Sansom Streets, which it is expected will be completed about April.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- The Liberal Democratic Party, after one defeat to-day administered by Secretary of State John T. McDonough, immediately carried its fight against the Greater New York Democracy into the courts. Secretary McDonough overruled the objection by the Liberals against the filing of the certificate of nomination by Sheehan's faction, deciding that the names of that party's nominees should be printed under the rooster.

NEVER in the history of this city have there been so many clairvoyants and professors of the pseudo-science of astrology practicing their arts as at the present time, and perhaps never in the history of the world has the seer been able to do such a lucrative business through the employment of modern methods which have recently been called to the attention of the District Attorney's office.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The Washington and Jefferson football team was defeated here to-day by a score of 23 to 5. The game was the hardest the Princeton- ians have played this season, and was full of brilliant plays. Princeton was in splendid trim, and her plays worked with precision and speed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- The University, of Pennsylvania football eleven was defeated on Franklin Field this afternoon by Brown University by the score of 15 to 6 in halves of twenty-five and twenty minutes each. Brown scored two touch-downs and kicked a field- goal, while Pennsylvania scored one touch-down.

The President of one of the coal railroads yesterday made public the following statement as representing his ideas on the influence of labor unions, and especially in connection with the anthracite strike. The statement was given out on condition that the name of the author be withheld. It reads as follows:

SEVERAL insurance companies have recently undertaken to insure owners of automobiles against damages which may be found against them as the result of accidents to individuals or to horses or other property arising from the use of horseless carriages. The policies are issued to cover losses in a single instance, and are made out either for $5,000 or $10,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Yale defeated the Pennsylvania State College eleven at football to-day by the score of 11 to 0. The game was the hardest that Yale has been called upon to play so far this season, and afforded the team invaluable practice. The play was marred by the fact that the ground was muddy and the ball wet and slippery because of the rain that fell before and during the game.

AT A certain exhibition of wild animals in New York the management has a woman in the box office to sell the tickets to the show. This affords a mild shock to the average purchaser, even if accustomed to the cashier women of French restaurants. The scale of prices ranges from $1.50 a seat to a general admission ticket for 50 cents.

When Joseph Sullivan and his brother-in-law, John Toher, returned to the Sullivan home at 2,310 Cambreling Avenue, in the Bronx, at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon they were unable to obtain any response from repeated knockings at the door of the apartments. Sullivan then thought that he smelled an odor of gas coming from under the door.

In undertaking to curb and regulate the abuse of public printing President ROOSEVELT has taken steps to render the country an important service. A great deal of public printing is undoubtedly needed, and it would be extremely unfortunate if the valuable work of some of the departments was allowed to remain inaccessible to those for whom it has especial interest.

KINGSTON, St. Vincent, B.W.I., Oct. 18 -- The eruption of the Soufriere volcano on Oct. 15 and 16 -- the fourth terrific outburst since the catastrophe of May 7 -- has plunged the colony into deeper distress than before existed, crippling its agricultural resources by further devastating the arrowroot fields and completely destroying wide areas of growing crops on lands which had been considered outside the volcanic zone.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The annual report of Commissioner of Immigration Sargent was made public to-day. It shows that of the 648,743 immigrants who arrived in the United States during the last fiscal year, 466,369 were males and 182,374 females. Of the entire number of arrivals Italy supplied 178,375, an increase of 42,379 over the number for 1901; Austria-Hungari 171,989, an increase of 58,599, and Russia 107,347, an increase of 22,090.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The striving to probe the mystery of the fate of earth will forever send men to seek the why and wherefore in the realms of the supernatural. The stimulus afforded by the quaint tales of Biblical times, the belief that the age of miracles is not past, nor that the number of God's prophets is limited, continues to extend the hope of spontaneous revelation.
THAT has always been my opinion, or, at least, always since I stopped letting mamma form my opinions for me," said a distinctly pleasing feminine voice behind him.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The following statement was made at the White House to-day relative to the report that President Roosevelt was interested in some Colorado mining claims:

OF all the strange nurseries out of which children have grown to men and women, the floating homes of New York's little "Water Babies" are the queerest. Up and down the Hudson, with banks bordered by palisades, through the East River, out into the bay and up the Sound the lighter, that snail of river traffic, carries many a mother and baby in its low, unpainted cabin.

WEST POINT, Oct. 18 -- Harvard defeated the West Point football team by a score of 14 to 6 here to-day. Six thousand spectators saw the game, which was hard fought from beginning to end. In the first half the elevens appeared to be evenly matched, and each secured a touch-down and goal. Superior condition, however, told in the second half for Harvard.

A GRAVE matter is engaging the best thoughts of our authorities on military science, engaging them as they have not been engaged since the close of the Hispano-American war. It is not the problems of present and prospective campaigns in the Philippines, nor the less vital questions of a new rifle, new revolver, new field piece, or the abolition of bayonet and sabre.

It is to be hoped that the letter of Mr. MITCHELL to the President accepting the Board of Arbitration as satisfactory is the last of the contributions to the controversial literature of the subject which will be inflicted upon a long-suffering public. Mr. MITCHELL'S position would have been much bolter if he had run a blue pencil through seven-eighths of his letter before having a clean copy made for transmission.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- There are two principal topics of discussion in Italy to-day -- the death of Emile Zola, whose last great novel, "Truth," is now appearing in the columns of La Tribuna di Roma, and the cyclone and floor disasters in Sicily. Nothing is more significant of the bonds of Italian unification than the sympathetic zeal with which the north has responded to the calls of help from the south.

PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Sept. 2 -- As an instance of what nature can do in the way of punishment when she gets a chance, the residents along miles of beach facing this town are confronted this morning with a shore strewn with the wreckage of upward of twentynine sailing vessels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Miss E.R. Scidmore of this city, who attended the International Oriental Congress, which assembled last month at Hamburg, has just returned home and gives an interesting account of her experience with the customs officers at New York.

Most of the $2,000,000 left by Countess Antoinette Seilern, a step-granddaughter of the late Oswald Ottendorfer, will go to her husband. According to a referee's report, submitted to the Supreme Court by Lawrence Godkin, the three children of the Countess do not figure in the division of the estate, and the will, made by her on her wedding day, leaving the greater part of her vast fortune to her husband, is valid.

Qualifying rounds for both the men's and women's club championship were playedyesterday on the links of the Englewood Golf Club. There was a large turnout of members and the fight for eligible places was well contested. Mr. Wilson, the present club champion, turned in the lowest score for the thirty-six-hole round, 166 strokes.

Charged with peddling from a dress suit case on Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, shirt waists from Siegel-Cooper Company's store Mrs. Ida Worth, a woman of forty years, was arrested last night by George Bernard, the firm's detective. At about midnight she was taken to the West Thirtieth Street Police Station with her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Maria Worth, aged twenty-eight, who was arrested in her home at 529 West Fourteenth Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 18 -- Soon after Paul Leicester Ford wrote "Janice Meredith," in which he placed some of the scenes near New Brunswick and the Rantan River, curious persons sought to establish the old Colonial mansion which the author described as the home of the heroine and at one time a headquarters for George Washington.

PEKIN, Oct. 18 -- The new Viceroy of SzeChuen Province, Tsen-Chun-Suan, reports that the Boxers have not been suppressed at Cheng-Tu and two other centres, and he asks the Ministers and missionaries to refrain from traveling in Central Sze-Chuen at present.

AS soon as the ice is out of the Yukon so that boats can safely navigate the stream the natives begin their pilgrimage to the nearest point where the annual festivities are to be held. Many of them travel 500 miles to enjoy the gossip of their countrymen and the pleasures which are to be found in the annual encampment.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In a recent issue of your valued journal I noticed a short article correcting Secretary Shaw as to the rebate to be had on shoes made for export from imported hides, and would say that the Secretary was in this case distinctly wrong, but the gentleman who corrects him does not go far enough.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

That William C. Turner, the man who in the office of Cantor, Adams McIntyre on Friday, shot and killed his ex-business partner, "William J. Mallard, Jr., and Albert Hamilton of Pittsburg, and then killed himself, was not by any means the bad man that some people seem to think. is the contention of Edgar M. Leventritt, the suicide's counsel.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The report of H.A. Walker, the expert sent by the London and Northwestern Railroad to America in order to investigate railroad conditions there, has been published. Mr. Walker sums up as follows:

THE most popular and least advertised lunching place on Lower Broadway is St. Paul's Churchyard, which lies around the venerable chapel at the corner of Vesey Street. Formerly the noon hour patrons included chiefly girls, with a taste for the romantic, and young men with an appreciation for pretty girls.
ELISABETH lay below the curb, spattered with mud, bleeding.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The coal troubles develop some unexpected phases. How completely are the best of us the slaves to our own narrow individual environment! What we wish, we believe; what we hope for, we expect; what our prejudices approve, we know.
DOCTORS in New York seldom marry their women patients," said the general practitioner. They know them too well."

HEARD the latest from the Philippines?" queried young Lieut. Gay at the Raconteurs' Club, as he glanced up from his newspaper at a number of the members who, cigar in mouth, were en- joying the post-prandial hour of dolce far niente, utterly indifferent, in their contentment and comfortable surroundings, to the wind that rattled and the rain that beat against the windows of their Fifth Avenue clubhouse.

The Merchants' Insurance Company of St. Louis, which has been formed through the efforts of H.M. Blossom Co., has been incorporated under the laws of Missouri, with $100,000 capital, and its charter has been approved by the Attorney General of Missouri.

Prices were well maintained in the market for outside securities yesterday, and in some stocks substantial advances were recorded. Activity was shown by a number of issues, including Northern Securities, Manhattan Transit, and some of the copper shares. Trading in the Rock Island stocks was not very large, but all the issues of the group were firm.

NEW YORK'S reading public will soon begin to reap the benefit of Andrew Carnegie's gift of $5,200,000 to the city for public libraries. In a few weeks the floors of the first library building erected under the Carnegie gift, at 222 East Seventy-ninth Street, will be opened.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 18 -- The Lehigh and the Navat Academy football teams played a tie game here this afternoon, each side scoring a touch-down. Lehigh scored in the first half on a spectacular run of 95 yards by A. Farabaugh. Annapolis scored in an unusual manner. Belknap punted from Lehigh's 35-yard line and the ball bounded and rolled for quite a distance behind the gpal line, where Whiting of the Navy fell on it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that the denunciation of Mr. Baer for his remark to Gov. Odell at the meeting held last week in the office of the Hon. Thomas C. Platt as indulged in by some of the daily papers, including THE TIMES, in its issue for to-day, has been without the justification that it should have for utterance.

Greatly improved character has been apparent in the business of the last few days. With the settlement of the coal strike, and prospects of an easier money market, and with the development of no new disturbing influences, a much more hopeful feeling could be noted in the conversation of brokers and operators.

One more snarl was put in the tangled problem of which is the best of the season's two-year-olds when, at Morris Park yesterday, the often-beaten colt Meltonian, a maiden up to the race for the Champagne Stakes, won that fixture after a rattling finish with the horses regarded as the chief claimants to the championship honors.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- The annual Fall regatta of the Yale navy was held at Lake Whitney this afternoon in a down-pour of rain. There were no spectators, for the first time in Tale rowing history, owing to the rain and the football game. The regular 'Varsity eight was not in training, and the veteran crew men were distributed through their class boats.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- During the debate on the Tariff bill in the Reichstag to-day Baron von Wangenhelm of the Farmers' Union, after stating that Chancellor von Billow's speech Thursday destroyed all chance of the passage of the bill, caused a scene of excitement and great uproar by declaring that if the Government continued to pursue the policy of the Caprivi era they were themselves sawing off the branch on which the monarchy rested.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The beautiful weather of the early part of the week, after a rainy Sunday, brought out a large crowd to pass the week. The recent frosts have tinted the forest leaves and make the park, with, the range of mountains, very picturesque.

THE mightiest two warships ever designed are now under construction in American shipyards. Their great size of 16,000-tons displacement will make them the peers of the largest battleships in the world, while their offensive power will give them a superiority over the most powerful ships in any other navy.

The opening games of the Knights of Columbus bowling tournament have been well attended and the members have a lively interest in the success of the tournament. The high team score at present is held by McGivney, of the Council, team with 803. Davis of the New Amsterdam Council leads the individual high average and high score list, the former with 194 and the latter with a score of 201.

MR. KNOX in his notable anti-trust speech failed to note, or noted only by vague implication, one of the main reasons for demanding publicity for the accounts of interState corporations. That reason is the large payments of these combinations to bosses, lobbyists, legislators, prosecuting officers, c., to procure injustice and to prevent justice.

DURING the Fall run of the Medford Hunt Club a man and a maid, both apparently lost to the world in the excitement of the chase, raced side by side across a rolling bit of pasture. They were well in advance of the field and hard on the heels of the pack, but it was their well-matched mounts and not their desire for comradeship which brought them thus together.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- The conspicuous feature in an otherwise narrow market was United Gas Improvement stock, which was traded in to the extent of 2,462 shares. The price was advanced nearly a point to 115 1/2, and closed strong at 115 1/4. The knowledge that the business of the company had largely increased by reason of the coal famine, and that most of this increase would be permanent, was responsible for the buoyancy.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 18 -- The last of the meetings of the locals of the United Mine Workers to elect delegates to Monday's convention were held to-night. Careful inquiry shows that there was a practically unanimous vote in favor of accepting the proposition. The declaration of President Nichols that it was not true that he opposed acceptance had much to do with this result.

Bird S. Coler was a visitor at the Hebrew Charity Fair in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. There he made a fiveminute speech on "Charity," bought several pounds of candy, took $10 worth of chances without taking the trouble to ask what they were for, donated $200 to the general charity fund, and made himself generally agreeable to those who are running the fair.
"You're all right, Mother Jones. You're a peach!" "No, I'm not a peach, I wouldn't be called that. It belongs to Depew, and, thank God, I'm not in his class."

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- At Fehrbellin, Brandenburg, to-day a monument was unveiled in the presence of Emperor William to the memory of the Great Elector and his defeat of the Swedes there in 1675. His Majesty in a speech took occasion to exhort young Germany to emulate the spirit of the Elector.

Whatever doubt may have existed in respect to the immediate future of the money market has been effectually dissipated by the developments of the last few days, chief of which of course, has been the purchase by the Secretary of the Treasury of several large blocks of bonds which will release a sum approximating $25,000,000 -- that is, when the so-called "odd lots" purchased are considered.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The Cornell football eleven was defeated on Percy Field by the Carlisle Indians to-day. The score was 16 points to 6, and all of the scoring was done in the first half. The Indians were at their best, and they could not have met Cornell when the Ithacans were in worse shape.

Dogs of high degree and pedigree will be placed on exhibition at the annual bench show of the Ladies' Kennel Association of America, which opens on Tuesday in the Madson Square Garden. In all, the entres number more than 1,600 dogs, great and small, handsome and homely.
MEMPHIS, Term., Oct. 18 -- T.C. Phelan of Memphis was nominated for Congress to-day by the Republican Convention of this (the Tenth) district.
THE old stager turned to the man beside him in the next orchestra chair and smiled knowingly.

READING, Penn., Oct. 18 -- About 120 cars of hard coal were brought down the Philadelphia and Reading Road to-day from the washeries and mines. It was expected that more would be sent out late to-night from different parts of the region. Most of this coal is being transported at night and goes through to Philadelphia.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Money was in fair demand to-day and supplies were abundant. Discounts were feeling the effect of the Treasury bills' allotment.

THE last few days have been crowded with weddings and, naturally, the chief interest, so far as dress costuming is concerned, has been in bridal gowns. Variations and innovations are now so numerous that the conventional plain white satin is almost a novelty. Crepe de chine, one of the most graceful fabrics, is being largely used, particularly that lustrous variety known as satin crepe de chine.

A variety of Wall Street clouds rolled away during the week past. Settlement of the coal strike and Government bond purchases are hailed as twin blessings by the Stock Exchange district. Quotations have recovered smartly from the depression ruling at the week's opening -- last Monday's security market having had even semi-panicky features.

Events in the career of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad Company have moved with rapidity during the past year or two. Suggestive indications of the growth may be gained in a glance at these mileage figures, taken from the recently issued report for the year ended June 30 last, and covering the period since'the organization of the present company:

To The Editor of The New York Times: The people of the United States have not just and equal taxation. It cannot be just and equal when the consumers bear the entire burden of Federal taxation, and every description of property, corporate or otherwise, is exempt from any Federal taxation whatsoever.

HAVANA, Cuba Oct. 10 -- As I write I can see all the large garrison flags floating over Morro and Cabana, showing that this is no ordinary occasion. On Morro there is more than that flag to see, for all of its signal flags are displayed, although, there is not a fleet of ships in sight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the article telling how to burn soft coal, as recently published in THE TIMES, there is one paragraph that is liable to mislead the public, and that is the one which says that "the check draught in the stove pipe, which with anthracite is usually kept open in moderate weather, cannot be opened much, if any with soft coal or the house will fill with smoke.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Money was very abundant at the beginning of this week. On Tuesday it was almost impossible to place balances, but subsequently there was less complaint of superfluity, and the rate for day-to-day loans advanced slightly.

A COAL dealer in a small-town up the State is a good, kind-hearted man whom his wife, an amiable but shrewd little lady, sometimes rebukes for his overlavishness. During the past Summer, with characteristic generosity, this dealer sold out every bushel of coal in his yard, and every bushel he could buy early in the season to his regular customers and at regular prices.
BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- The secretary of the Boer Generals informs me that Botha, De Wet, and de la Rey will soon visit America, Gen. Kruitzinger is already on his way there.

Few cities in the United States have had more banking institutions, come and go, within the past ten years than Boston, and for that reason it may be of interest to briefly analyze the banking history of the "Hub."

IT is no easy matter, according to Dr. Health, to get the consent of parents Lederle, President of the Board of for their children who go to the public schools to be operated upon for trachoma. In asking for an extra appropriation of $21,800 in order to have urgent cases treated at once, Dr. Lederle says that 18 per cent. of the pupils attending school in New York are afflicted with this malady.
