PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- George P. Corrigan, one of the attendants at the Medical Hall of the University of Pennsylvania, who was bitten by a rattlesnake a few weeks ago, was to-day discharged from the University Hospital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A wise Providence or a cruel Nemesis has annexed a penalty to every privilege. To the privilege of addressing the public is annexed the penalty of reading the reports of one's addresses on the following day in the newspapers.

Commissioner Woodbury of the Street Cleaning Department last evening banded to Mayor Low his report on the work of the department for the three months ended Sept. 30. In it the Commissioner lays special stress upon the conditions in the east side, and attributes dangers there existing largely to the ignorance of the indwellers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- An echo of the early days when religious societies emigrated to the wildernesses of America to found Socialistic communities was heard to-day in the United States Supreme Court. A decision handed down in the case of Christian Schwartz and others against John S. Duss, the well-known bandmaster, marks the latest chapter in the histody of the first society of this kind founded in the United States.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- P.S. Blodgett, General Manager of the Lake Shore Railway, died to-day at his residence, 36 Vienna Street, this city, after a long illness. Mr. Blodgett was fifty-nine years of age. Dropsy was the direct cause of death.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 27 -- The total per capita cost of maintenance of inmates of the charitable institutions of Illinois for the last three months, ending Sept. 30, was $41.11 gross and $37.93 net, according to the quarterly bulletin just issued by the State Board of Charities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin, who resumed his duties at the War Department this morning, was kept busy throughout the day answering questions about his experiences abroad and his impressions of people he met. With regard to the feeling of the German Emperor toward the United States Gen. Corbin said:

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- Sarah Bernhardt, for for the first time since 1870, played in Germany to-night. She appeared in "Fedora" at the Royal Theatre before an assemblage of members of the nobility and the leading social personages of Berlin. Neither Emperor William nor the Empress was present, but they sent a huge wreath to the French actress.

After Justice Truax had refused to allow Walter Damrosch to hum classical airs on the witness stand yesterday in the damage suit of Victor Herbert against a musical magazine, one of the lawyers, Gilbert Ray Hawes, raised his voice in song in summing up the testimony. The spectators giggled so audibly that the Justice and the court officers rapped loudly for silence.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Admiral O'Nell, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Ordnance, in his annual report, made public to-day, has much to say respecting speed varsus armament. He argues that a ship is naturally a compromise between various necessities, and says:

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- In its City article to-day The Times says money was in strong demand yesterday. It was believed that the Bank of England had engaged in more borrowing. Loan rates were decidedly firmer and discounts hardened perceptibly.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The Nationalist members of the House of Commons are jubilant over what they claim to be Premier Balfour's "climb down" from his refusal to grant a day to discuss the proclamation of the Crimes act. Blocking motions to prevent such a discussion were announced last week by Unionist members, but, through Government influences, these motions have been withdrawn.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- Little comment can be made on to-day's local market. Its chief characteristic was extreme dullness, the sales amounting to $15,644 shares and $19,275 bonds. Prices were a trifle lower, but the losses were limited principally to eighths and quarters. In Consolidated Lake Superior, Philadelphia Rapid Transit, Philadelphia Company, and Philadelphia Electric there was evidence of pool buying, but the remainder of the list was without feature.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 27 -- The five years' meeting of the Society of Friends to-day at their closing session issued the following call to all the Christian churches: To the Various Christian Bodies in the United States:

DENVER, Oct. 27 -- The fight for control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company will be transferred to St. Louis next week, when application will be made in the Circuit Court of Appeals for a writ of supersedeas, which will have the effect, if granted, of staying all proceedings until the case can be heard on its merits.

WILLIAM J. DISBRCW, son-in-law of ex-Consul General to Cuba Ramon O. Williams, died on Sunday at his home, 35 Cambridge Place, Brooklyn. He was born forty-four years ago in South Amboy, N.J., and was for many years in the freight forwarding business at 106 Wall Street, Manhattan.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- Henry. A. Everett of the Everett-Moore syndicate to-day resigned the Presidency of the Federal Telephone Company, and also of the Cuyahoga Telephone Company of this city. He is succeeded in both companies by Frederick S. Dickson of New Jersey, who is connected with the Roebling Company of New Jersey.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 27 -- The demand for spot cotton here last week was more active than at any time this season, and the sales were the largest ever recorded in a single week at this time of the year, standing at 22,550 bales against 12,650 bales last year, and 12,800 bales two years ago. The exporters were again the largest buyers, taking 80 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin, in reply to a question to-day in regard to the successor to Lieut. Gen. Miles, said that he betrayed no confidence in stating that Major Gen. Young would succeed Gen Miles upon the latter's retirement next August.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Anthracite Coal Strike Commission met to-day in the hearing room of the Inter-State Commerce Commission and held its first conference with the parties to the controversy. There was a full representation of both operators and miners, and a number of other interested parties were present.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- W.K. Vanderbilt's Quos Ego was second to-day in the race for the Prix Faisanderie at the St. Cloud meeting.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Secretary Hay to-day issued the following notice to the officers and employes of the Department of State:

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- The monetary situation continues quiet and with quoted rates nominal. Call money is now largely obtainable at 6 per cent., and is in moderately plentiful supply. In special cases as low as 5 1/2 per cent, is reported. The demand for time money is lighter and rates are showing signs of working lower, at 6 to 7.
Major John B. Porter will proceed to St. Paul for duty as Judge Advocate of the department.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- J.W. Matthews of the grocery firm of Matthews Company, of Newburgh, came to Albany to-night and swore out an affidavit exonerating Gov. Odell from any financial profit interest in their firm and alleging that the stock held in Gov. Odell's name was a personal loan to him and that he is owner of the pledged stock, simply subject to the loan.

There was trouble in Third Avenue between Twelfth and Thirteenth Street at 9:30 o'clock last night, and when it was all over a recount of the damage showed two men suffering from leg wounds and another grazed by a bullet. Seven or eight other shots which had been fired did no damage.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The ignorance and religious fanaticism of the Russian peasantry, says the St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times, are illustrated by the peasants' almost blasphemous veneration of the famous Father John of Kronstadt, which exists much against his will.

Persons who looked for cheap anthracite yesterday in this city were pretty sure to be disappointed. The expectations of big shipments following the renewed hum of industry at the collieries were not realized, and even the representatives of the coal -- carrying companies said that less coal than was expected was reaching tide-water.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 27 -- A decision of more than usual interest was rendered in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to-day, when the court decided that United States Army officers are amenable in the civil courts of the country for offenses other than those committed solely in violation of army rules.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Henry L. Blum of the Alexander Dye Works of Lodi and the operator of his automobile, C. Anderson, were fined $500 each by Judge Zabriskie to-day. The charge was that of maintaining a nuisance. On May 20 last the automobile caused the death of Richard Heuches, a gardener on the farm of Mrs. Mary Poor, widow of President Poor of the Park National Bank of New York.

Extremely dull, yesterday's security market presented few interesting features. Quotations were not buoyant; they actually sagged in the slow fashion that not unusually prevails under apathetic conditions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- There was a brief reminder of the Sampson-Schley controversy in the United States Supreme Court to-day, when the case of "The United States vs. W.T. Sampson, Rear Admiral, et al.," was called for argument. It involves the distribution of prize money because of the capture of the Spanish cruiser Infanta Maria Teresa in the battle off Santiago.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 27 -- The strong recovering tendency shown by some of the Cotton Duck issues was the main feature of to-day's market. They have been unduly depressed of late as the result of a misapprehension as to what the company is accomplishing. There have been efforts among shorts to hold them down in order to cover sales made under a false notion as to what the company would do in July.

-- That often-mentioned superiority of the European over the American press as regards accuracy of statement and the avoidance of sensationalism is well illustrated by a dispatch which we find printed in a prominent place and under a large "head" in The Paris Messenger. This dispatch has a Washington date line -- which gives it, of course, an authority at least semi-official -- and reads as follows.

NEWPORT, Oct. 27 -- Alwin Ball, Jr., of New York has purchased from Mrs. Edwin Booth Grossmatt, daughter of Edwin Booth, the latter's country seat, Boothden. This estate is located about five miles from Newport, in Middletown, and includes 9 3/4 acres, with a dwelling and bungalow attached, stable, and boathouse.
In the opening games of the New York Stock Exchange Bowling League last night Clarke, Dodge Co. won both their matches, defeating Ellingwood Cunningham and Cohen, Greene Co. The scores follow:

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- At a meeting of the Athletic Council of Cornell University held to-day a vote was taken on the proposition to send a crew to Henley next year, and the majority was largely in favor of the idea.

BRISTOL, Oct. 27 -- The fact that an order has been placed with the Herreschoffs for the construction of a new defender of the America's Cup is regarded here as responsible for the uncommon activity in the Bristol shops. Work on hand is being carried out with redoubled energy, and extra mechanics are being engaged every week, with plenty of work for all.

The moral of "The Silver Slipper," that was produced last evening at the Broadway Theatre for the first time in New York, is that you cannot achieve success a second time by doing over again the things that have once been successful. You must have something more than the method and the formula.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. McCurdy gave a ball at the Lyceum Hall here to-night, at which there were about 350 guests, a number from out of town being present. A number of President McCurdy's associate officers in the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York attended the ball.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Minister Wu Ting-Fang has not been advised of the appointment of Yuen Shi Kai as Minister of Commerce of the Chinese empire, as announced from Tien-Tsin yesterday, although, in his view, such an appointment would not be unlikely. Yuen Shi Kai is the Viceroy of Chi-Li Province.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28. -- The Pacific Mail Company's new steamer Korea arrived at noon to-day from Yokohama, breaking the record across the Pacific.

PORT JERVIS, Oct. 28. -- Several changes among the officials of the Erie Railroad became known to-day. Trainmaster Theodore Mackrill of the New York Division is appointed Passenger Trainmaster, with an office at Jersey City, and E.T. Reisler, who held the latter position, is promoted to the Superintendency of the Rochester Division.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28. -- The market (ailed to present any new features to-day. Its record was one of dullness and steadiness. There was a mixture of net changes, but the general tone seemed to resist reaction. There is no leadership manifest at this time, hence the absence of any definite market movement.

Opportunities for serious work of mural painting on a large scale seem to be increasing in this country, and more wall paintings of a large size by painters of note are ordered for other cities than for New York. Here, for example, is a decoration for Baltimore by Mr. Edwin H. Blashfield which deserves the most thoughtful consideration for the note it strikes and the technical qualities that are shown in its creation.

"Papa must be awful hurt, but I wish he'd get well; I want to go home," said four-year-old Andrew Clark, as he sat in a chair behind the Sergeant's desk last night in the Arsenal, in Central Park. In one hand the little fellow held a piece of apple pie, and in the other a banana. He shifted about a little in his chair, and then looked up into the face of Sergt Morgan.

Direct offers to prove that several witnesses who are wanted badly by the prosecution in the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the death of Mrs. Katharine J. Adams are detained in New Jersey through the influence of the defense were made to Justice Lambert yesterday by Assistant District Attorney James W. Osborne and District Attorney Jerome.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- Erroneous information respecting the politics of President Arthur T. Hadley of Tale and Judge Lynde Harrison has recently been sent out from here and published in various papers. It was said that President Hadley was a "life-long Democrat," but had suddenly changed his politics and become a Republican.

Following the timely warning thrice repeated in his dreams on Monday night, "The hand of death is upon you," George W. Curtis of 216 Avenue A. Bayonne, N.J., awoke from uneasy slumber shortly before daybreak yesterday morning and discovered that a woman had broken into his home, disrobed, and retired upon a kitchen table, after attempting suicide by asphyxiation.

The North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse arrived yesterday after a rough passage of 5 days 21 hours and 4O minutes. There were only two days on the entire trip on which the passengers could venture out on deck, and for the rest of the time varieties of weather, described in the log as storms, gales, and hail squalls, held full sway.

The Methodist Social Union held its first dinner of the season last night at the Hotel Savoy. About two hundred men and women were present, and speeches dealing with Methodism and missions were made by Bishops C.C. McCabe, J.M. Thoburn, and D.H. Moore. J. Edgar Leaycraft presided.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28. -- The Japanese students at Yale University, twentytwo in number, have in preparation an entertainment and celebration which will take place in Dwight Hall, on the campus, on Saturday evening, Nov. 1.

With an invocation by the Rev. Mr. Kohler, the sixth annual meeting of the New York State Assembly of Mothers began yesterday morning at 9 o'clock in the assembly room of the Board of Education, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The meeting will extend over three days.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 28. -- Cresceus failed in his attempt to-day to lower his mile record of 2:02 1/4, trotting the mile in 2:05 1/2. The weather was too cool for comfort, and a strong breeze was blowing directly down the backstretch. Before Cresceus made his appearance it was announced that record-breaking time was out of the question, but that the son of Robert McGregor would do his best.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 28. -- In order that Mitchell Day may be properly observed to-morrow there will be a general suspension of mining. The operators would rather the men would work, but under the circumstances they are helpless in the matter. The Superintendents of many of the collieries were notified to-day that the employes would not report for work to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The fearful ravages of cholera in the Old World are set forth in mall advices received by the Marine Hospital Service. From Manila chief Quarantine Officer Perry makes a conservative estimate that 75,000 cases of cholera have occurred in the Philippine Islands since March 20 last, with a mortality of 75 per cent.

An amusing little comedy was enacted at the meeting of the Arbitration Commission on Monday. President BAER of the Reading Railroad Company objected to the presence of Mr. JOHN MITCHELL if he was there as a representative of the United Mine Workers of America, but had no objection to offer to Mr. MITCHELL'S appearance if he came as a representative of the anthracite coal miners generally.
MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, Oct. 28. -- Secretary Shaw of the Treasury Department addressed a Republican mass meeting here to-day on tariff revision. In part he said:

Mr. FRANCIS BURTON HARRISON, who has been nominated by the Democrats in the Thirteenth Congressional District in this city, is a candidate for whom any Democrat may vote with pleasure and satisfaction, and whom every Republican who is weary of the tariff policy of his party may support without misgiving.

BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- The rate between the banks for call loans was down to-day to 5 per cent., and outside money was obtainable in many cases at a rate better than 6 per cent. Sterling exchange is a trifle firmer, with demand and cables up a quarter of a cent. New York funds, par; call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time money, 5@6 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $21,706,369; balances, $1,851,949.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday dwindled to insignificant proportions. Little more than 300,000 shares were traded in during the entire market session, with only ten issues dealt in to the extent of 10,000 shares or more each. Indeed, so altogether dull did the market become in the late trading that many brokers left the floor in disgust because of their enforced idleness.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- The American and other art collectors, who have loaned collections to the South Kensington Museum, have suddenly been notified that they must remove their paintings and other treasures within six months. The ostensible reason is that the museum needs the space for its own art objects, but it is publicly said that the authorities have come to the conclusion that the museum is only being used to save storage fees.

The Rev. A. Lincoln Moore of Atlantic City, in an address to the convention of New Jersey Baptists in the Parmly Memorial Church, in Grove Street, Jersey City, yesterday, made a plea for simplicity in worship, and said that "frills and finery in a Baptist church always end disastrously." The introducing of liturgical service, he said, has a dangerous tendency to make religion fashionable by destroying its divine character.

The Hungarian Republican Club of New York held a rally last night in Cooper Union. At times it looked as if there would be a serious disturbance, but the meeting wound up with a good-natured crowd of Democrats and Republicans leaving the hall together, satisfied that they had enjoyed themselves almost as well as if they had engaged in the conflict which occasionally appeared imminent.
BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- Emperor William and the Empress, accompanied by Crown Prince Frederick of Denmark, attended the Royal Theatre to-night and saw Sarah Bernhardt In "Fedora."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The return by President Palma of the reciprocity treaty between the United States and Cuba is not a surprise to the State Department. Practically is will not prejudice the prospect of a trade arrangement between the two countries. This will come in time. If President Palma had approved of the proposed treaty it would have had to run the gantlet of action in the Senate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The case of Esther Quimby, the seven-year-old child who died from diphtheria while under Christian Science treatment, was submitted to the Grand Jury to-day by District Attorney J. Addison Young.

There is not a dollar's worth of silver in the three, but that could not be expected, for there are three different designs of spoons, and they only cost $1 a set. They are of the little after-dinner coffee variety, with gold bowls. In one is the Brooklyn Bridge, in another Grant's Tomb, and in the third the Statute of Liberty.

Over thirty visiting golfwomen arrived at the Baltusrol Golf Club yesterday at Short Hills, N.J. They represent the teams of Philadelphia and Boston that will meet to-day in the first match of the triple inter-city golf competition. It is the first appearance of the Boston women as contestants for the Clement A. Griscom Trophy, but they have sent a strong team.

R.F. Hamilton, better known in this and several other countries as "Tody" Hamilton, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser "Wilhelm der Grosse. He had been in Europe just five years and two days, and every minute of his time was spent in keeping the European public duly impressed with the size, the excellence, the marvelousness of the Barnum Bailey Show.

The new Minister to Greece may not find all of his duties as agreeable as that of representing his country at the Court in Athens. Part of those duties consists of attending in Bucharest to the affairs of the United States with respect to Roumania; since Mr. HAY dispatched his famous letter about Jewish immigrants hither from Roumania we are not exactly cherished in that part of the world with a warm attachment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- James C. Lenny, attorney for the Isle of Pines Company, and the San Jose Company, doing business on the island, has filed a memorial with the State Department in regard to the island's legal status.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The feature of to-day's session of the American Section of Alliance of Reformed Churches holding the Presbyterian System was the discussion of evangelistic work by John H. Converse of this city, who recently gave $50,000 to the Evangelistic Committee of the Presbyterian General Assembly, and Dr. J. Wilbur Chapman, formerly of this city who has resigned his charge in New York to devote his whole time to evangelistic effort.

About 8 o'clock last night Policeman Lake of the Alexander Avenue Station noticed a crowd collected at One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, and found in its midst a well-dressed woman sitting on the curb in a dazed condition. She gave her name as Daisy Clark. Policeman Lake started to take her to Lincoln Hospital.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was very light. During the morning prices, with few exceptions, moved downward, but late in the day quotations became a little firmer. The day's fluctuations, however, were very narrow, and only in very few stocks were the variations of sufficient importance to attract any attention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- An Industrious astrologer from Hoboken, N.J., has devoted much of his time lately to warning the Navy Department not to allow any ships to put to sea on certain dates when great disturbances of the elements weresure to take place. In spite of these warnings ships have put to sea on the dates given, and the disturbances have fared to come off.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Gov. B. B. Odell was greeted by two large audiences at Stone Opera House this afternoon and evening, with an evening overflow meeting at the Court House. In his afternoon speech the Governor said in part:

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- The United States Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the decision of the district court that the Chicago Board of Trade can control its quotations and that no one has the right to use them without complying with the regulations of the board regarding their distribution.

Victor Herbert, composer and orchestra leader, has been awarded $15,000 damages because a New York musical magazine brandeo him as a plagiarist. Mr. Herbert sued for $50,000. The verdict was announced yesterday afternoon, the Supreme Court jurymen having deliberated for about an hour.
LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Money was in strong demand to-day. Discounts were firmer, partly due to the money situation, but chiefly owing to the rates of Continental exchange.

CHICAGO. Oct. 28. -- An important principle of law was established to-day when Judges Jenkins, Grosscup, Baker, and Bunn of the United States Court of Appeals banded down an opinion to the effect that the Western Union Telegraph Company has a right of property in the news which it gathers, and that such right does not cease when the news is published on the tickers rented to its patrons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The declaration which Gov. La Follette made In a speech last Friday night In reply to a Question, that he should support Senator Spooner for re-election when the latter should announce his support of the Republican State platform, which declares for taxation of corporations and primary elections, is likely to make the result in the approaching election more than ever uncertain.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The market to-day continued dull and listless; the volume of business being only slightly above that of Monday, the sales aggregating 18,074 shares and $46,112 bonds. Nearly one-third of the trading was in Philadelphia. Rapid Transit, which advanced 3/8 to 18 3/8 on buying by a house representing inside interests.

It is now the impression in the bestinformed quarters -- and this is true of Republicans as well as Democrats -- that the election in this State next week will be close. If that is the case a few thousand votes might easily assure the election of Judge GRAY to the Court of Appeals.

The formation of a National cricket association for North America was one of many ideas brought out at the annual Fall meeting of the Metropolitan District Cricket League, held yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Hotel. The proposal came from the President of the league, A. E. Rendle, who suggests that every league or association of cricket clubs in the United States and Canada should be eligible for membership.

BERLIN, Oct. 28. -- What purports to be the statement of a person identified with the Ministry, probably Home Secretary Posadowsky, appears in the Tageblatt today, in which, after affirming that the Government intends firmly to keep Its present position, tariff possibilities in connection with commercial treaties are discussed, as follows:

The body of Miss Mary A. E. Carter as it lay prepared for burial in the old Carter homestead, Decatur Avenue and One Hundred and Seventy-sixth Street, Borough of the Bronx, did not deter burglars from breaking into the death chamber early yesterday morning and ransacking every room on the second floor, on which were Miss Carter's apartments.

YOKOHAMA, Oct. 18. -- The efficacy of the measures taken to stamp out the bubonic plague, which was discovered in this port on the 6th inst., is demonstrated by the fact that up to date only five cases have occurred. After the first case had been authenticated a military cordon was established around the whole district involved.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 28. -- Official figures from the five big companies having their main offices in Scranton, show that 90 per cent of their collieries are in operation and that the output is now more than three-quarters of what it is normally.

Senator HOAR of Massachusetts is a statesman, "lined," as our French friends have it, with a fanatic, and a not too thin interlining of the demagogue. His admirers rely rather too much, and possibly so does he, on the statesman and the fanatic to excuse the demagogue.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Vice Chancellor Emery to-day made permanent his temporary appointment of Chauncey G. Parker as receiver of the New Jersey Agricultural Chemical Company, which was the outgrowth of the insolvency proceedings begun Oct. 16 by Clarence T. Russell, President, and George H. Meeker, Treasurer of the concern.

Within less than two years after the original suit was brought against Howard Gould by his former valet for $25,000 damages the case has come up for a second trial in the Supreme Court. All the evidence was taken yesterday before Justice Truax.
Frederick Zittel has sold for Mrs. Catherine C. Hall to a client for occupancy the five-story American basement dwelling 325 West Eighty-sixth Street, 20 by 100.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the interview with me "upon the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary," reported in this morning's issue of THE TIMES, I find that I am quoted as using the following words: "Some of the Directors have felt that if the throat department was to be continued, it should be established upon the same degree of skill in treatment as the other departments."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on "The Methodists and Alcohol" of Oct. 23 does not state the question fairly. The Methodist ministers do not doubt the conclusions of Prof. Atwater because they are anti-Methodistic, but rather because they are contrary to honest conclusion deducted from Prof. Atwater's own experiments.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 29. -- United States Senator W.A. Clark's faction of the Democratic Party won a decided victory over that of F. Aug. Heinze, when the Supreme Court, this afternoon, by a unanimous decision, declared that the Clark Democratic ticket and not the Heinze ticket, as decreed by the County Clerk of Silver Bow County (Butte) should have the column in the official ballot headed "Democratic."

John G. Underhill, who has managed several real estate transactions for President Charles M. Schwab of the steel trust, and whose real estate office is at 435 Fifth Avenue, is the defendant in a suit for absolute divorce. The plaintiff, Grace K. Underhill, is his second wife. After setting forth in her complaint that his income is more than $113,000 annually, she charges cruelty and desertion.

Gov. Odell will address meetings in New York this evening at Cooper Union, Durland's Riding Academy, and Brommer's Park, in the Bronx. The Republican County Committee has been arranging for these three meetings for two weeks, and Chairman Morris is confident that each will prove to be a notable demonstration.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Francis G. Brigham, '05, of Flushing, N.Y., has been elected Captain of the Colgate University basket ball team.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- There was a great gathering of book buyers at Libbie's auction room to-day, when the library of the late Edwin F. Conely of New York was disposed of by auction. Record prices were obtained for books, and the gem of the collection, a copy of Hawthorne's "Fanshawe," the first edition and an uncut copy, was sold for $840, more than twice the price ever before paid for the work.

Complications caused a climax in the troubles of the Export Lumber Company yesterday, and Justice Hall of the Supreme Court appointed three temporary receivers at the request of a majority of the stockholders. Simultaneously, Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, appointed two temporary receivers for the Atlantic Coast Lumber Company, a corporation to which the other concern had loaned large sums of money.

Yesterday's security market was kept under pressure. The professional element on the Stock Exchange, already committed largely to the short side, extended their contracts for delivery in free and easy fashion, notably in the closing hour of business. They were able to force some recessions of substantial size in various parts of the market, though nowhere did there appear indications of liquidation of important character.
BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- In a political speech here this evening, Secretary of the Navy Moody discussed the question of free raw materials.

Incidentally, a vote cast next Tuesday for any Republican candidate for the Senate or Assembly will be a vote for the re-election of THOMAS C. PLATT to the United States Senate. It would be futile to address to average partisan Republicans words concerning the character and career of Mr. PLATT.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The status today of the Colombian canal negotiations is that both sides here are awaiting a decision of the Colombian Government as to whether Minister Concha shall proceed under his original instructions to present to the State Department the Colombian response to the department's proposal for a treaty.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- The musicians of the Paris theatres, at a meeting this afternoon, voted unanimiously in favor of a general strike, beginning to-morrow at noon. Twelve hundred musicians were represented at the meeting.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday made public the budget for 1903. It calls for $97,119,031.10, a decrease of $1,500,569.78. The following table shows in detail the items for the different departments with the increases and decreases compared with the budget of 1902:
Sale on the Stock Exchange of four shares of Corn Exchange Bank stock at 425 1/2.

The meeting held in Cooper Union last night, under the auspices of the Greater New York Democracy, to ratify the Democratic nominations caused a crowd esti- mated at 3,000 people to gather in the hall. The meeting was very noisy. Controller Grout, President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan, Augustus Thomas, the playwright, and William Hepburn Russell, who did the speaking, all receiving very demonstrative welcomes.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- The Debate Committee at noon to-day announced the result of competition for places in the Cornell-Pennsylvania debate, which will take place Dec. 12. The following were selected: Floyd Leslie Carlisle, Watertown; F.H. Hiller, Cobleskill, and C.B. Dowd, Cortland.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- It is understood that Mr. Kruger's memoirs give a narrative of the ex-President's career, but do not go deeply into political or diplomatic matters, or advise the Boers as to the best policy to be pursued after the writer's death.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct.- 29. -- Two world's harness racing records were broken at the Memphis Driving Park trotting meeting today, and one other record was equaled. In all these events the races were against time, but the fast condition of the track and the general expectation that old marks would be eclipsed aroused much interest and drew a large attendance.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The demand for money was brisk to-day on prospects of increasing indebtedness to the Bank of England and the strength of discounts, which did not affect Continental exchanges.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The efforts of the promoters of the Morgan "tube" railway scheme to procure the re-establishment of the parliamentary status of their original franchise bill as a whole led to an hour's debate in the House of Commons last night, the only result of which was the withdrawal of the endeavor.

-- For our enlightenment as to the real reason why the Methodist ministers are attacking Prof. ATWATER with such vehemence, we are now told that the professor is not denounced because his conclusions as to the food value of alcohol are anti-Methodistic, but because an honest conclusion from his experiments would be contrary to his.

The steel door and the porch of the same metal which have just been added to the dwelling house in West Thirty-third Street, presumably to baffle raiders, for the place, according to common report, soon is to be opened as a gambling house, received their first triel yesterday, when a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES was terribly beaten in the place.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 20. -- The Emperor of China has issued a decree which orders the Viceroys and Governors of Chinese provinces to send Chinese students to the United States and Europe for purposes of study rather than to Japan.

In some parts of the outside market yesterday trading was more active than it had been on recent days but the market as a whole was narrow and presented few features of interest. Prices declined in some quarters, but there was in the outside market no such, general drop as occurred on the Stock Exchange.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- The demand for money Is very moderate and call loans are being shaded more generally now than for some time past, many loans being made at 5 1/2 per cent., and in a few cases it is said that as low as 5 per cent. has been obtained. Time money is in fairly good supply, and call rates show a tendency to soften.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The report made by Prof. Jeremiah Jenks of Cornell University, on his observations in the English and Hollandese possessions in the Orient, was made public to-day by the War Department. Prof. Jenks visited those dependencies at the instance of the Bureau of Insular Affairs for the purpose of making a study of methods of administration with a view to recommendations for our own government of the Philippine Islands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- A severe shakeup is to be made soon in the immigration service at Ellis Island, following a secret investigation into the condition of affairs in the island. Some of the facts are to be placed before the Grand Jury in New York. The Department of Justice is understood to be handling the facts for presentation to the Grand Jury.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Vice Chancellor Emery to-day decided the second suit to restrain the United States Steel Corporation from issuing $200,000,000 bonds in place of preferred stock of a like amount. The Vice Chancellor advises a preliminary injunction preventing the conversion. This amounts to it being granted, as the Chancellor never overrules the Vice Chhancellor.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The race for the Cambridgeshire Stakes, in which William C. Whitney's English-bred horse, Ballantrae was a hot favorite and an easy winner, drew a large and fashionable crowd to the Newmarket race course to-day. King Edward was an interested spectator of the day's sport.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 29. -- "Mitchell Day" was celebrated in all the principal towns of the anthracite coal region to-day, and in order that all the mine workers might have an opportunity to participate in the exercises the mines were closed down. The principal demonstration was held in this city, and President Mitchell took part.

One of the most enthusiastic Republican meetings of the campaign was that held at the Murray Hill Lyceum in Thirty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue, last night, under the management of the political organizations of the Twentieth Assembly District, of which Capt. F. Norton Goddard is the leader.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 29. -- The Doukhobors have started from Yorkton for Winnipeg, saying the Lord has told them to go. They have left the women and children.

After nine hours and twelve minutes' play the match game between Lipschitz and Lasker, a contest which was begun at the Manhattan Chess Club on Sunday afternoon, resulted in a draw yesterday evening, when eighty-nine moves had been recorded. As will he remembered, Lipschitz could have won at his twenty-seventh move, but he failed to make the right play, and allowed the champion to get slightly the better game.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Hundreds of four-paged circulars under, the caption "How Odell Fooled the Railroad Men" were distributed among the employes of the Erie Railroad in this village to-day, with a view of showing the duplicity on the part of Gov. Odell when he appointed George W. Dunn Railroad Commissioner against the wishes of the railroad organizations of the State who indorsed John Lundrigan for the office.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- President Roosevelt to-day issued his proclamation designating Thursday, Nov. 27, as a day of thanksgiving. The proclamation is as follows:

Most of the football cripples from last Saturday's games returned to work yesterday, and fast practice was the rule with most of the large college teams. Next Saturday's games are the most important of the season so far and all promise to be hard-fought contests, even harder in most cases than those of last week.

Patrons of the Aqueduct track yesterday had a taste of Winter racing and shivered all the afternoon in a cold breeze that all but smothered enthusiasm over the betting problems presented. Favorites were beaten in four of the six races.

The guests of the numerous house parties at Tuxedo for the Hallow'een ball to-morrow evening will leave this afternoon and to-morrow for their destination. Tuxedo will begin the celebration of the "carnival" this evening by dinners in many of the cottages. The second day at Baltusrol yesterday brought out many well-known people from the Oranges and Morristown and that vicinity and from town.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- After a firm opening, general weakness developed in the local market to-day, in sympathy with the decline in New York and the break in Lehigh Valley, as a result of the attack upon the financial position of the company. Every broker on the Street received an anonymous circular embodying the points of the attack, which was headed with the caption, "Is Lehigh Valley Insolvent?"
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- The report of Evelyn Cecil, M.P., Chairman of the Parliamentary Subsidies Committee, on the matter of British ship subsidies makes the following recommendations:

Boston women proved superior in golf yesterday to the Philadelphia women, and the first match in the intercity team competition for the Clement A. Griscom trophy went to the association that challenged for the right to play for the cup last Winter. With fifteen women on a side, the fair golfers from the "Hub" administered an unexpectedly heavy defeat to the Quaker forces, scoring 44 holes to 11.

The members of the Church Club last night became affiliated with the Actors' Church Alliance of America at a meeting in the clubhouse, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. Heretofore the membership of the Alliance has included only theatrical folk and clergymen.

GIBRALTAR, Oct. 29. -- The latest reports from the interior of Morocco indicate a state of serious unrest, which, it is believed, may break out into a general rebellion and an attempt to install Mulai-Mohamed, the Sultan's brother, as Sultan.

It is improbable that DEVERY is acquainted with the works of MOLIERE. For one reason one of the apothegms of DEVERY which most commend themselves to his constituents is: "When you're caught with the goods on you, you don't want to say nothing." Whereas, on a similar occasion, MOLIERE found something to say, to wit: "I take my goods wherever I find them."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Here is, I think, a problem, in casuistry that presents more difficulty of solution than your famous boy-and-package puzzle, and I should be glad to have the views of your other readers as to their course of conduct under similar conditions.

Rumors of baseball deals and the signing of players by the big rival leagues at fabulous salaries continue to crop up. The latest report is to the effect that John T. Brush of the New York National League Club has signed one of the star infield players of the American League at a salary of $23,000 for two years.

One of the largest Democratic demonstrations held in Williamsburg since the last Bryan campaign took place last night in McCadden Hall, on Berry Street, near South Third Street. The meeting was under the auspices of the Fifth Assembly District Democratic Campaign Committee. The hall was crowded with an enthusiastic gathering.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- New York exchange to-day was quoted at 40c discount. Time and call loans, 6 per cent. Local traction issues were of some interest on the Chicagro Exchange. A report to the effect that Directors of the Union Traction Company yesterday had discussed the necessity of reorganization -- a report that was at once denied by several Directors -- hurt the West and North Side stocks somewhat.

Columbia's annual Fall rowing regatta will be held on election day from the Columbia boathouse, at One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and Riverside Drive, according to an announcement made by Robert B. Bartholomew, Captain of the 'Varsity crew, yesterday. There will be single scull races, and contests for eight-oared crews.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- In an article written for The Youth's Companion, which will be published nest week, Theodore Roosevelt gives his ideas of the duties and responsibilities of the President of the United States. President Roosevelt wrote the article in 1900, while he was Governor of New York and previous to the Republican National Convention which nominated him for Vice President.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 29. -- At the annual meeting here to-day of the stockholders of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railway, (the Big Four route,) the following Directors were elected for the term of three years: W.P. Bliss, J.D. Layng, H. McK. Twombly, and F.W. Vanderbilt, all of New York.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 29. -- Capt. Napoleon Lajoie of the Cleveland Baseball Club, referring to a report that he had, or was about to sign a three-year contract with John T. Brush of New York for a compensation of $25,000, said this evening:

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Because he furnished the prison authorities here with information that led to establishing the guilt of four prison keepers who were supplying the prisoners with forbidden articles, Charles Roller, received from Essex County in November, 1901, on a seven-year sentence for forgery, was granted his release to-day on parole from the Court of Pardons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from the pen of Mrs. Monachesi on the subject of the imported dinner service for the White House must be of interest to the general public and also to those artists who have labored so long and so earnestly to develop the ceramic industry in this country.

Virginia C. Conte appeared before Supreme Court Justice Scott yesterday to ask the annulment of her marriage with Jose Conte in April last, on the ground that she was not eighteen years of use at the time of the ceremony. Section 4 of the domestic relations law declares a marriage void when either bride or bridegroom is under the age of consent.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 30 -- The second day or the Belle Meade dispersal sale drew a larger crowd than the opening day. The prices were fairly good. The best sales were:

KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, B.W.I., Oct. 30 -- Henry Powell, Curator of the Government Botanical Station here: J.P. Quinton of the British Botanical Station in Sierra Leone, West Africa, and E.W. Poster of the British Botanical Station at Lagos, West Africa, accompanied by guides, visited the Soufriere volcano Oct. 28 and spent an hour and a half on the summit.

William G. Johnson, the man who surrendered himself to the police of the Greenpoint Station on Wednesday night, insisting he was the murderer of Albert C. Latimer, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Furlong in the Gates Avenue Court, Brooklyn, and, although his story is generally discredited, was nevertheless held without bail for a hearing fixed for Nov. 7.

Charles A. Becker, who has the contract for placing the illuminated street signs on lamp posts, yesterday complained in the office of Borough President Cantor that he was being seriously hampered in his work by the Municipal Art Commission. Mr. Becker has all the material ready, but there is some difference of opinion between the city authorities with relation to the height of the letters to be used.

Gov. Benjamin E. Odell, at a Republican mass meeting at Cooper Union last night, responded to Bird S. Coler's challenge to the Governor to discuss his attitude on the subject of Ramapo. He also sought to defend his policy in advocating the taxation of savings bank surpluses. Incidentally, he called Mr. Coler a "weather cock." and the audience roared its applause and laughter.

Ex-Gov. Frank S. Black made a vigorous effort yesterday to have Justice John S. Lambert dismiss the indictment against Roland B. Molineux and direct a verdict of acquittal. The court refused to grant the ex-Governor's motion, and the trial was adjourned another day to allow counsel for the defense to prepare their evidence.

HAZLETON, Penn., Oct. 30 -- The strike at the seven collieries of Coxe Brothers Co., the four mines of G.B. Markle Co., and the Silver Brook operation of J.S. Wentz Co., was officially renewed today through an order issued by District Secretary Gallagher of the United Mine Workers, upon instructions from President Mitchell.

MANILA, Oct. 30 -- Libel proceedings have been instituted against the editor and the proprietors of Libertas, a Spanish newspaper published in Manila, on account of the publication of an article attacking Gen. J. Franklin Bell and his plan of aiding the people of the Provinces of Batangas and Baguna, Luzon, and of the Island of Mindoro.
In the New York Stock Exchange Bowling League tournament last night, the McIntyre Marshall bowlers won two games, defeating the teams of Vermilye Co. and A.S. Leland Co. The scores follow:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Nothing is known in this city of William G. Johnson, who surrendered to the New York police, stating that he had killed Albert C. Latimer in Brooklyn on July 2. The address given by Johnson, 464 North Eighth Street, is a stable, and has been for several years. No person by the name of Johnson is known in the neighborhood.

The Madison Square Garden has made one of those transformation scenes that people love to see on any stage. In an incredibly short time the big plaster equestrian monuments and colossal stone figures, the busts, pediment figures, bronze bas reliefs, and memorial statuary, big, middle-sized, and little, which constitute the exhibition of the National Sculpture Society have been erected on pedestals or placed on some wall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A cable dispatch from Guatemala was received at the State Department to-day from Consul General McNally reporting that the eruption of the volcano at Santa Maria, adjoining Quezaltenango, continues; that the city is covered with six inches of volcanic matter; that rich coffee plantations on the coast side are buried under seven feet of sand and ashes from the volcano, and that detonations from the eruption were heard in the capital.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- John Carroll Lathrop, John Quimby, and his wife, Georgiana Quimby, have been indicted by the Grand Jury on the charge of manslaughter in the second degree. They have not as yet been rearrested, and may not be taken into custody until next week, as the bonds given for their appearance continue to hold good until formally dismissed by the court.

To-night in this city a distinguished company will assemble to celebrate by a memorable dinner the eightieth anniversary of the birthday of a man never in office and never to be in office, but whose work has contributed more to the upbuilding of our National wealth and material prosperity than that of many statesmen whose names are inseparably associated with American history.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES in to-day's leading editorial adjudges Gov. Odell a stockholder in the corporation of J.W. Matthews Co. If the writer of the article had investigated the matter as a question of law he would not, in fairness, have left it simply there.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Ex-President Cleveland spoke to-night in Lyceum Hall here. The hall was packed, and the ex-President received an ovation when he was introduced by Judge Willard W. Cutler, who presided. Delegations were present from all parts of the district, Special trains brought the Union County delegation and another that from Warren County.

The confusion created in the public mind by what at first glance appear to be conflicting decisions by the Vice Chancellor of New Jersey in the matter of the plan of the United States Steel Corporation to convert its preferred stock into bonds at lower interest will probably disappear when the nature of the issues raised in the Berger and the Hodge suits are contrasted.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the editorial under the caption "Gov. ODELL" in your issue of the 24th inst., you state:

Very little interest was taken in the outside market yesterday by traders or others. Here and there a little activity appeared, but it was so scattered that little attention was given to it. The Rock Islands improved a little, and showed larger totals than of late, and Northern Securities was fairly active, but the only other active stocks were found among the low-price issues.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Senator Jones of Arkansas was here to-day and called on the President, with whom he had a short chat, mostly of a personal character. There was some badinage over the probable result of the approaching elections, the Senator assuring the President that the Democrats were likely to elect Bird S. Coler in New York.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 30 -- The Fall meeting of the Memphis Trotting Association closed to-day. To-morrow at a matinee, Cresceus will trot against his record, and Dan Patch and Prince Alert, pacers, will try for marks at a mile. To-day the majority of the races were dashes for beaten horses. Lord Derby trotted against the world's record, 2:02 1/4, but was timed in 2:06 1/4.

The story which comes from Pittsburg about the reception in that city to one of the militia regiments which had gone out, on the call of the Governor of the State, to keep order in the anthracite region is calculated to inspire every decent American in the first place with disgust and shame, and in the second with indignation.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 30 -- James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railway and the Northern Securities Company, has begun the creation of a steel and iron industry in the West, which will rival anything of the sort in the world. He arrived in Great Falls, Mont., to-day to arrange the first definite project in his great enterprise.

From three of the big university football camps discouraging reports have emanated, and the outlook for to-morrow's contests is not very bright. The Columbia men are fearful that Capt. Weekes and R. S. Smith, who now practically are invalided, may be forced out of the game against Pennsylvania should they receive any further injuries.

While thousands of Tammany paraders were making Lexington Avenue echo last night with their bands and cheers, the Tammany ratification meeting was in progress in the Grand Central Palace, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets. The noises from the passing procession floated into the big auditorium and mingled with the applause with which 3,000 listeners greeted the speakers.
The Medical News of this city will publish in its issue of to-morrow the following letter from its London correspondent:

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Referring to the Russian-Afghan question, the Simla correspondent of The Times quotes an article in The Pioneer. This paper says the Ameer knows that the Russians are in one of their restless fits, which usually precede action of some kind.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Trading today was the dullest of the year, the sales aggregating 15,143 shares, and $114,762 bonds. A third of the dealings was in Reading common, which was sold for the New York account. Prices generally were firm, but the improvement did not extend beyond the small fractions, except in Bell Telephone, which was up a point.

Not since the great crowd gathered during the last municipal campaign has Durland's Riding Academy been crowded as it was last night at the meeting of the West Side Republican Club. As on the other big occasion, it became necessary to close the doors shortly after the meeting opened -- this as a matter of public safety.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Money was in increased demand to-day for month-end requirements, notwithstanding large borrowings from the Bank of England. Discounts were sympathetically firm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Secretary Root has approved recommendations that the dsappearing gun carriage be used in connection with guns of six-inch calibre as well as with those of larger bore. This action marks the close of a contention lasting many months among the fortification authorities of the War Department.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- The appointment of Dr. Lewald as Imperial German Commissioner at the St. Louis Exposition will, it is expected, be announced in two or three days. Emperor William has approved the selection of Dr. Lewald, whose work at the Chicago Exposition was satisfactory both to the fair management and to the German exhibitors.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 30 -- The Iowa Supreme Court to-day reversed the decision of trial courts in Iowa on the question of C.O.D. liquor sales by express companies, and handed down opinions which will effectually put an end to the liquor traffic through express agents.

The United States Realty and Construction Company, with an authorized capital of $30,000,000 preferred and $36,000,000 common, of which there has been issued $26,651,000 preferred and $32,858,600, had its initial entrance on the Stock Exchange yesterday marked by sales of stock, of which a little over 3,000 shares of common were dealt in between 31 1/8 and 32, and 1,500 shares of preferred between 74 and 75.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- "There is undoubtedly a strong movement toward paying off the American indebtedness in London, but whether it can be done with foodstuffs and merchandise, or whether it will necessitate the importation of gold, the bestposted man in the world could not tell at the present moment."

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 30 -- The report that a surgical operation had been performed on Robert Mantell, the actor, now appearing in "The Dagger and the Cross," is denied by his manager, M.W. Hanley. The rumor arose from the fact that Mr. Mantell strained his arm in the mimic sword fight. He will appear in Cincinnati next week.

The first trial of the suit of Mr. HOWARD GOULD'S valet against him, for breaking an alleged agreement to take care of the valet during his life, resulted in a large verdict against the defendant. The second trial has just resulted in a verdict for the defendant, which is to say the declaration by a jury is that the defendant does not owe the plaintiff anything.

Before an audience filling the big auditorium at Prohibition Park, Staten Island, David B. Hill last evening returned to "the Matthews charges," furnishing new and detailed information concerning purchases made by State institutions from the Newburg grocery concern since Gov. Odell became interested therein.

Prof. Germain Martin of the University of Paris delivered last night before the members of the New York Group of the Alliance Francaise, in the West Side Y.M.C.A. auditorium, Fifty-seventh Street, a lecture in French on "Gothic Churches." The President of the society, James H. Hyde, introduced M. Germain Martin, who said in part:

Judge John Clinton Gray of this city is one of the seven Judges of the Court of Appeals elected as such by the people of the State upon a general ticket. His term expires this year, and he is a candidate for re-election. No one has ever questioned his eminent fitness for the place he adorns.

Carl Schurz, in an Interview yesterday, opposed the opinion expressed by Senator Morgan of Alabama that it would be better if the Democrats did not control the lower house of Congress, because under present conditions they could only act as obstructionists.

As was states in THE NEW YORK TIMES a fortnight ago, Cornelius Vanderbilt will be an active member of the syndicate that will build a new yacht to defend the America's Cup against Sir Thomas Lipton's Shamrock III., and the boat will be managed by C. Oliver Iselin, with Capt. Charles Barr as skipper.

EDWARD B. MALTBY of Boston died yesterday at his home of paralysis, aged sixty-three years. Mr. Maltby formerly was President of the Boston Electric Light Company, and was a Director of the Edison Company. He also was Vice President of the New England Cotton Yarn Company, Vice President of the Copper Range Consolidated Company, and Director in numerous other companies.

Honors came plenteously to John Fritz, the ironmaster and inventor of Bethlehem, Penn., at a dinner in his honor which was given at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. It was the occasion of his eightieth birthday, and he responded heartily to the presentation speech, which was made by Civil Engineer John Thomson.

Mr. Henry M. Alden, in his article in the Editor's Study of Harper's Magazine, from which we quoted last week, has something to say in an amiable but convincing way of the manuscripts daily rejected by the periodical he so ably edits. Four out of five of these, he insists, exactly answer Di. kens's description, in a letter to Mrs. Gaskell, of the manuscripts rejected by Household Words under his editorship:

THE increasing use of the Rocky Mountains as a Summer resort, not to speak of their large resident population, and the popular interest in birds combine to make this a welcome book in spite of the fact that an extensive ornithological literature relating to that region already exists.

A BOOK so beautifully printed as this and made so handsomely in every way makes a demand on the matter presented that is not easily met. If Mr. McMaster's book is not so attractive in its matter as in its outward appearance, it is still very attractive.

Trade reports to the several commercial agencies continue highly favorable. Bradstreet's sums the situation up as follows:

An added starter in the shape of A.L. Aste's smart two-year-old Plater, running for the Lynbrook Handicap, six furlongs, at the Aqueduct track, yesterday, turned betting affairs topsy-turvy and made what seemed for the moment to be a racing scandal. The race was the fourth on the card, and Plater was one of two added runners, a field of ten horses thus running.

The author of "New Amsterdam and Its People" thinks "the burlesque history of New York does not seem to be called for per se any more than a burlesque history of the Plymouth Colony." Mr. Innes admits that "the type of the early Dutch, as Irving sketched it has passed insensibly in the popular mind into something like the embodiment of truth."

Kingship, which is so much of a mystery and curiosity to Americans, probably reached its full flower in Louis XIV. He was the state. He was "it" in a way difficult to realize to-day, because he was the greatest King at a time when class distinctions were stronger and national distinctions weaker than they ever were before or since.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: We read in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Oct. 18 a communication on "Funny Errors." Since it concerns Victor Hugo. I thought it just and right to say something about it. "When a man of Victor Hugo's magnitude undertakes to set aside any objection to his use of "bugpipe," "balafre," and "falaise premiere des quartre," instead of bagpipe.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Oct. 31 -- Frank A. Vanderlip, Vice President of the National City Bank of New York, and Assistant Secretary of the Treasury during President McKinley's first Administration, was the guest of honor and principal speaker at an elaborate banquet given here to-night under the auspices of the Chamber of Commerce, the leading trade organization of the city.

WE have this week to call to the attention of our readers two books of unusual interest and value, which throw much light on serious problems offered for study and for solution to the Ameriran people. Both relate to the government of colonies and dependencies. The little volume of Prof. Reinsch is only an introduction to the study of colonial institutions, and is mainly historical and expository.

No interruption is announced in telegraphic communication between Bogota and Washington. In one direction it brings to Minister CONCHA information of events which he thinks Warrant him in overruling the instructions of his official superiors, and in the other direction it carries to those superiors Secretary HAY'S query as to whether the zealous -- not to say too zealous -- Minister is correct in his view of his duty and his country's policy.

For the first time since his arrest upon the charge of murder, Roland B. Molineux yesterday took the witness stand and related his associations with Harry S. Cornish and the other persons whose names have been associated with the mysterious poisoning of Mrs. Katharine J. Adams on Dec. 28, 1898.

FROM a twelve months' residence in Borneo, the greater part of time spent among the Kayans and Kenyahs, Mr. William Henry Furness became perfectly at home among the Borneo head-hunters. Man assimilates himself more or less to his surroundings, and so the author writes that there was a certain charm in his family life among these tribes which was not dispelled "even by the skulls hanging from the rafters of their houses."
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 31 -- A dispatch from Yorkton, N.W.T., quotes Colonization Agent Speers as saying to-day:

History in some of its forms is more attractive than any work of fiction because it has the basis of truth together with dramatic elements which are often beyond the conception of the creative genius. And in these days of historical romances and of adventure stories containing a large element of truth, it is but a step across a narrow border to a realm of actuality pregnant with romance and adventure.
Frank L. Fisher company has sold for George P. Fellows the seven-story apartment house with stores at the southwest comer or Lexington Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- General strength was developed by the local list today, but except in spots it was not attended by any material increase in activity. Reading displayed more life than of late, but dealings were largely by board room traders. Electric Storage Battery broke two points, to 85, on sales of only 200 shares, on rumors that the proposed consolidation had been indefinitely postponed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The nineteenth annual report of the United States Civil Service Commission for the last fiscal year has been submitted to the President.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 31 -- Patrick Calhoun of New York addressed the Young Men's Democratic League of this city in the Grand Opera House on National issues tonight. Mr. Calhoun said, in part:

A conference of physicians on the prevalence of trachoma at the present time was held yesterday at the office of Dr. Ernst J. Lederle, Commissioner of the Board of Health. Dr. Lederle reported that since the beginning of the school year and up to Oct. 24 the total number of children excluded from the public schools by Health Inspectors was 14,000, and out of that number 6,667 were excluded because of trouble with their eyes.

One of the reflections excited by the debate in the House of Commons over the struggles of two American but rival concerns to supply that ancient and populous town with better and cheaper means of getting about in it is, what a howling absurdity it is that what calls itself an "imperial" Parliament should be called upon to take cognizance of such a question.
