Before a throng of college men and their friends, oarsmen of Columbia, yesterday competed in their annual Fall rowing regatta off the Columbia boathouse at One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and the Hudson River. Although there were only two races, six eight-oared crews competed, and each contest proved very close and exciting, victory not being decided in each case until just before the eights reached the finish line.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 4. -- These Congressmen are elected in Maryland:

Superiority of ponies and sheer dash and brilliancy in the last period won the polo match for the Rockaway Club team yesterday. They scored the victory by 9 1/2 goals to 8, defeating the troopers of Squadron A in the final competition of the latter's open Fall tournament on the field at Van Cortlandt Park.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 4. -- Harry W. Smith's steeplechaser Ting-a-Ling, that used to be a street car horse, and was twenty-two years old, got cast in his stall and broke its neck this morning.

Francis Burton Harrison, who was a Congressional candidate in the Thirteenth District, has bought Aeolian Hall, a new twelve-story structure on the west side of Fifth Avenue, just north of Thirty-fourth Street. The building is occupied by the Aeolian Company under a twenty-one years' lease at an annual net rental of $36,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The United States Senate in the Fifty-eighth Congress will be Republican by at least sixteen majority against the present majority of twenty. The present Senate contains fifty-four Republicans and thirty-four Democrats in a total of ninety seats, there being two vacancies from Delaware, where the Republican Legislature failed to elect.

The returns from all the Senate and Assembly districts in the State indicate that the Republicans have elected 32 out of 50 Senators, giving them a majority in the Senate of 14, and that they have elected 91 out of 150 Assemblymen, giving them a majority in the Assembly of 32.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- The Times's correspondent at St. Petersburg quotes from an article published in the Novoe Vremya on Finance Minister de Witte's recent visit to Vladivostok, where he received representatives of the commercial element of the community, who made various complaints.

As the election excitement was at its height in Madison Square, shortly before 10 o'clock, a terrific explosion of fireworks occurred, transforming in an instant the entire east side of the park into a scene of death and carnage which a battlefield could scarcely have surpassed in its horror.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The cost of the temporary work of the twelfth census, according to the Director's annual report, was $11,834,818, or an average cost of 15.5 cents per capita of the population of the United States. The total cost of field work in connection with the twelfth census was $4, 358,670, or an average cost of 5.7 rents per capita.
"You can say for me that Odell is certainly elected by a plurality of from 15,000 to 20,000. I am going to bed."

Although politicians expect that the American people will change their attitude somewhat in "off " years, the Republicans were very confident until a few weeks since that there would be no reverse for them this year. They went into the canvass very gayly on the sole issue that they were willing to recognize -- prosperity.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4. -- Indications point to the Democrats having carried the State by a decreased majority. Richard Bartholdt is re-elected to Congress from the Tenth District, given to the Republicans by the recent gerrymander. In the Eleventh District, it is claimed, John J. Hunt has defeated Charles F. Joy by 4,500 votes.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 4. -- Late advices from all points in the State add, to the vote of Van sant (Rep.) for Governor, yet Democrats will not concede his election, though Republicans talk of a margin of 50,000. Advices indicate that the latter is more nearly the correct estimate than that Rosmy has any show at all.
Election over, professional wall Street has lost another of its scarecrows, and business on the Stock Exchange may now proceed along normal lines.

The statement prepared by President MITCHELL of the United Mine Workers for the information of the Coal Strike Commission will not bear critical examination as well as such a document should. "Whether this is a defect or a quality of excellence depends somewhat upon the writer's purpose.

Not enough attention has been paid to the report of Prof. JENKS of Cornell, who was sent out, months ago, by the War Department to inquire into the methods of the nations which had had most success in governing colonies, and whose report was published in a brief summary a week or more ago.

Yale, Harvard, and Columbia all went through some lively football practice yesterday. Fourteen coaches looked after the interests of the New Haven team, and nearly as many were out on the Harvard field studying the weak points of the Crimson team. Several of the members of the latter team did not appear, including Capt Kernan, Graydon, Jones, Bowditch, and A. Marshall.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 4. -- The Democrats again elected a Governor of Tennessee and a full State ticket, but the Republicans held their own in the Congressional districts heretofore Republican, and the complexion of the State's representation in Congress remains the same, with eight Democrats and two Republicans.

Six golf competitions were played yesterday on the links of the Richmond County Country Club at Staten Island, and they brought out nearly every golfing member of the club. The women took an active part in the mixed foursome event, for which, special election day cups were offered. Miss Botsford and C.A. Blyth won in 87 strokes net, from 4 handicap.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- Estimates from more than half the counties in Pennsylvania outside of Philadelphia and Allegheny Counties show gains for the Democratic State ticket. These gains are offset, however, by heavy Republican gains in Philadelphia and Pittsburg. The returns indicate a Republican plurality in the State of from 130,000 to 200,000, of which Philadelphia contributes over 100,000 and Pittsburg from 30,000 to 40,000.

EFFINGHAM, Ill., Nov. 4. -- At Bogota, a small hamlet in Jasper County, thirty miles southeast of this city, this afternoon Hale Johnson, a Prohibiton leader of National prominence and the Vice-Presendential candidate on the Prohibition ticket in 1896, was murdered.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- The worst political corruption ever known in Philadelphia was practiced in to-day's elections. Repeating in the interest of the machine Republicans was general throughout the city. One hundred and fifty negro laborers on the proposed city filtration plants were used as repeaters in the Forty-first and Thirty-fifth Wards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The annual report of the Commissioner of Navigation shows that on June 30, 1902, the documented tonnage of the United States was the largest in its history, comprising 24,273 vessels, of 5,797,002 gross tons. The increase over last year is almost wholly in large steel steamers. In ten years the number of American, British, and German squarerigged vessels has decreased 50 per cent.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Nov. 4. -- A troop or 1,200 Fouchardists which entered the capital yesterday, returning from the campaign against Gen. Firmin, had a conflict with the civil authorities. There was heavy firing during all the night. Seven persons were killed, and many were wounded. The situation is grave, threatening a new civil war.

Gov. ODELL has been re-elected, but with an exemplary reduction of plurality which shows him to be weaker than his party. Had the vote in the State of New York reflected no more than the general diminishment of Republican strength as shown in other States, Gov. ODELL would have been elected by the highest plurality claimed for him in the estimates of his sanguine managers.
Returns from the entire city, all boroughs, with nineteen election district missing, give Coler 319,372 and Odell 199,253 or a plurality of 119,419 for Coler.

All records of arrests at election times were broken yesterday as far as the City of New York was concerned. Before 5 o'clock in the afternoon, when the polls closed. Superintendent McCullagh of the State Bureau of Elections, announced that his deputies had made 257 arrests in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx.

Gov. Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., has been re-elected by the Republicans of New York State. His plurality over Bird S. Coler, the Democratic candidate for Governor, was about 8,500 ,and returns received after 2 o'clock this morning indicate that the margin may be still smaller before the final count is completed.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- The United Fruit Company's steamship Admiral Sampson, which arrived here to-day, reports that she collided with the three-masted schooner Charley Bucki, bound from Eddyville, N. Y., for Boston, about ten miles off the Cape Cod Lightship at 2 o'clock this morning.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- The engagement of Miss Ellen Drexel Paul of this city to Paul Denckia Mills of New York is an announcement of great interest to New York, Newport, and Philadelphia society.
LONDON, Nov. 4. -- Money was in good demand to-day, but the tone was fairly easy. Government disbursements increased the supply of funds. Discounts were fractionally easier.

Fine Autumnal weather and a promising programme of steeplechcases and pony races attracted a large assemblage of fashionables and almost the entire Long Island hunting set to the Meadow Brook Club yesterday. The club members and their guests had a most enjoyable afternoon's sport, and many of the visitors, including men and women, followed the contestants in the longer races on horseback.

Two very interesting trotting races made up the programme at Inter-State Park, L.I., yesterday. About 1,000 spectators were in attendance, many ladies being among the number. The track was in perfect condition, and fast time and close finishes in the six heats, combined with the balmy day, enabled the assemblage to thoroughly enjoy the day's sport.

The House of Representatives in the Fifty-eighth Congress will be Republican. Precisely what the majority will be it is impossible to state owing to lack of returns from a number of districts and conflicting claims as to certain other districts.

We tender to the bar of the State of New York, and especially to the bar of this city, and to the Republican lawyers in both who have risen above partisanship in the matter of the re-election of Judge GRAY our hearty congratulations. They have rendered to the people of the State a very great service in a manner particularly honorable, a service that will be as lasting as it is valuable.

Duse is again with us -- the Duse that a scant decade ago burst upon us all as a revelation. But she is scarcely the Duse we have known. The woman whose impersonations were as varied and cosmopolitan as her travels has, from motives of patriotism or of private predilection, narrowed her art to one country and to one playwright.

New Jersey remains in the Republican column, but the Democrats made considerable gains. Chief interest centred this year in the election of Congressmen in each of the ten districts. The Republicans elected seven of their candidates, as against six whom they had under the old apportionment.
First Lieut. Robert B. Grubos, Assistant Surgeon, will report for temporary duty at the general hospital at San Francisco.
NEWPORT, Nov. 4. -- Henry Redmond of New York has rented for next season the cottage which he occupied the past Summer.

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- Alan Gregory Mason, a member of the celebrated Mason family and a Harvard graduate of 1886, was arrested this morning on suspicion that he is the man who clubbed to death Miss Clara Morton, an attendant at the McLean Asylum, last Saturday night, and that he is "Jack the Slugger," the author of half a dozen mysterious assaults on women which have terrified the suburban communities for months.

HAZLETON, Penn., Nov. 4. -- The statement of the anthracite mine workers' case, which was filed with the strike commission on Sunday night, was made public today. Copies of the statement have been furnished to the operators, who will reply in three or four days. The miners' statement in full is as follows:
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Gov. Odell received the election returns at his father's house, and seemed perfectly confident throughout.

All of New York City was given up last night to the din and merrymaking of postelection celebration. From the time the polls closed until the result was definitely announced every one of the main thoroughfares was taken possession of by surging crowds of men and women, who moved where their fancy swayed them, jostled each other, at times completely blocking traffic, and making free use of every noisemaking device known to inventive genius.

PLAINFEILD, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The last competitions of the season were held at the Park Golf Club to-day. The bogey handicap was won by Frank Rogers. Herbert Rogers won the Holiday Cup handicap, the leading scores being:

MOUNT CARMEL, Nov. 4. -- The Arbitration Commission appointed by President Roosevelt to adjust the differences existing between the anthracite coal miners and their employers visited the Shamokin region to-day, and to-night are resting in the mining town of Mount Carmel.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 4. -- The annual report of Gen. A. W. Greely, Chief Signal Officer of the Army, says the corps have built and put in working order in Alaska 1,121 miles of land lines and submarine cables within a period of twenty-four months.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- David B. Hill retired about 11 o'clock. He would say nothing for publication.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 5 -- Spanish Honduras has before her a political situation which is totally different from anything that ever occurred in a Spanish American republic. They have held an election, and under the constitution have elected no President, and now it is "up to" the Congress to select one of three men to fill the office.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Nov. 5 -- There was no serious disorder anywhere in Porto Rico yesterday. The elections, which resulted in a sweeping Republican victory, passed off quietly. This was largely due to the fart that Gov. Hunt sent twenty-two special representatives, covering the whole island, with plenary powers to adjust differences summarily.

The National Association for the Study of Epilepsy and Treatment and Care of Epileptics held its annual meeting yesterday in the lecture hall of the Academy of Medicine. Two sessions were held, one in the afternoon and another in the evening. Dr. Frederick Peterson, the President of the association, presided.

NEWPORT, Nov. 5 -- P.F. Collier has rented for next season the A.M. Coats cot tage on Wickham Road. This is the firs time Mr. Collier has taken a cottage a Newport, although he has for several Sum mers spent a portion of the season here while he conducted the hunts of the Monmouth County Hounds.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 5 -- The New York Life Insurance Company of New York was to-day granted a temporary injunction by Judge Nash, restraining C.T. Richardson, Helen B. Richardson, and Willis Meredith from transferring, hypothecating, selling, or letting go out of their possession or the possesison of any other person or corporation five certificates of deposit which are alleged to be with the Exchange National Bank of Dallas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A report issued by the Census Bureau to-day places the quantity of the present crop of cotton which had been ginned up to the 18th of October at 5,925,872 commercial bales, which is estimated to be a little more than 60 per cent, of the entire crop.

The plot of nineteen lots at the southeast corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Fifty-seventh Street, and nearly opposite the entrance to the Boulevard Lafayatte, has been sold by Charles H. Kerner. The property has a frontage of 100 feet on Broadway and extends 475 feet along the street, to a point 300 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue.

Official inquiries into the Madison Square tragedy were started yesterdy by both District Attorney Jerome and Coroner Scholer. There is full co-operation between the two officials in the case, and both asserted that their respective investigations would be of the most searching nature.

A curious feature of the carnival which now follows every important election is found in the fact that the celebration is general and without regard to the more or less intense partisan rivalries of the preceding canvass. On Tuesday night upper New York was the scene of a popular frolic in which, for the time, social as well as political distinctions were forgotten, and representatives of all classes joined in hilarious celebration of -- what?
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Discounts were easier to-day owing to the abundance of cash in the market and Continental bill buying.

With the reading of the President's annual address by the Rev. William Byron Forbush, Ph. D., of Winthrop Church, Boston, who took for his subject "The Art of Being a Godfather," the Congress about Boys, conducted by the General Alliance of Workers with Boys, was opened last evening in the assembly rooms of the United Charities' Building.

The extremes of racing were in evidence at the Aqueduct track yesterday, when the winners included the gift horse Maclcay Dwyer, first in a good race before a fair field, and the ten-thousand-dollar two-year-old Futurita, who after repeated failures at last managed to scramble home in front of an extremely bad lot of maidens.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- J. Edward Addicks at the request of The Public Ledger to-night, writes the following:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Early this morning Champion Lasker suffered his first defeat here in a match game on even terms at the Franklin Chess Club, when the young and talented expert C.S. Martinez, a member of the club and last year's champion, beat him after 44 moves.

In his second term Mr. ODELL will be a minority Governor. The total vote cast for Mr. COLER and for the candidates of the Prohibitionists, the Bryan Democrats, the Social Democrats, and the Socialist-Labor men will exceed by several thousand the total of Mr. ODELL'S vote. He is elected over Mr. COLER by a plurality of a little more than one-half of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Advices that have come here to-day from leading Republicans in Wisconsin show that there cannot be the slightest doubt of the re-election of Senator Spooner. Of the State Senators elected yesterday all but one were Republican.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Peking correspondent of The Times says that the Chinese Director of Railways, on behalf of the Viceroy, having petitioned the Russian Legation to permit the dispatch of 1,000 disciplined troops outside the Great Wall to protect the railway and restore order, the Russian Minister, after referring the question to Port Arthur, has granted the request.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 5 -- If the story that was brought into publicity by the winning of the third Newell crew in the graded crew races on Monday is true there is a very unhealthy condition of affairs existing in Harvard rowing circles. The old charge of societies affecting the make-up of the crews has come to light again, and this time with more seeming truth in reports than ever before.

Professional Wall Street worked itself into a curious mood yesterday. At the opening of the market and during the first hour some of the more conspicuous traders worked on the bull side energetically, and quotations showed strength throughout the list; then of a sudden the entire contingent of board room speculators rushed with one accord into the bear column, and throughout the rest of the day they rammed and jammed away assiduously.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- Admiralty Secretary von Tirpitz gave a farewell dinner to Ambassador and Mrs. White last evening. Foreign Secretary von Richthofen, Finance Minister von Rheinbaben, Minister of Instruction Studt and Secretary of Embassy Jackson and Mrs. Jackson were among those present.

MAHANOY CITY, Penn., Nov. 5 -- The Anthracite Strike Commission ended its tour of observation of the coal fields in the Panther Creek Valley to-day, and the members of the party will return to their homes to-morrow and will meet again at Scranton on Nov. 14 to take the testimony of the miners.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The complaint of William Randolph Hearst of New York, against anthracite coal-carrying railroad, charging that the latter's rates for the transportation of coal from the anthracite fields to New England. New York, Maryland, and the District of Columbia are unreasonable and unjust, was filed with the Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Almost all the papers this morning discuss the elections in the United States.

RALEIGH, Nov. 5 -- Semi-official figures with one county lacking give the Democratic State ticket a majority of 64,266. Democrats elect 45 of 50 State Senators. The House is 97 Democrats, 21 Republicans, 1 independent Democrat, and 1 doubtful.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- Local financial circles were well pleased with the election results as a whole, but beyond a slight improvement in the early dealings they had little influence for good on the market. The excellent tone was not long held. The Montana defeat was something of a disturbing influence, in view of the fact that it had been so confidently anticipated that the Amalgamated forces would win out.

The Louisville and Nashville made public yesterday its annual report for the year ended June 30 last. The gross earnings were $30,712,237, as compared with $28,022,206 for the previous year. Operating expenses increased from $18,233,033 for 1901 to $20,902,487 for the year just passed. Net earnings were $9,809,819, as compared with $9,789,173 for the previous year.

The subject of the admittance of the eleven Cuban children, whom the Universal Brotherhood would educate and incidentally a "demand" that was sent from Santiago were before the Court of Inquiry on Ellis Island yesterday. Commissioner Williams presiding. Excitement was created soon after the 8 o'clock boat had cast off at the Bat-Battery.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- The crowd that occupied Music Hall this evening at 8 o'clock expecting to hear Mascagni's Italian company produce the opera "Ratcliff" were doomed to disappointment of their desire for music -- but they got their money back.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says that Leopold Delisie, the head of the Bibliotheque Nationale, was congratulated yesterday on the jubilee of his entrance into the library by the Minister of Education.

-- whatever may be shown by the investigation now in progress as to direct and immediate responsibility for Tuesday evening's terrible accident in Madison Square, the real lesson of the catastrophe is that modern "fireworks," the more pretentious form of which involves the use in large quantities of high-power explosives, require far more cautious handling than they can possibly receive in a public street crowded with reckless and excited people.

The excitement consequent on the elections having died out, society is beginning to prepare itself for the Winter season. Arrivals have been many in town, and the house parties arranged for over Election Day have broken up. Those who went to Newport to vote returned early, and among these were Elbridge T. Gerry and his sons.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- Senator Hill was in his office at Albany all day receiving and tabulating the returns. He refused to be quoted about the result, but the carefulness with which he is making tabulations would indicate he is ready to make an attack on the credibility of the returns.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- General weakness developed in the local market to-day, and, while there was little pressure to sell stocks, no support came from commission houses. The political group, including Philadelphia and United Gas, receded on selling by holders who were disappointed that the market did not at once respond to the Republican sweep in Pennsylvania.

The calamity period of the football season has arrived, and though the best part of the championship season for the teams representing the important colleges remains, reports generally indicate that there is more than a little truth in the complaints of discouragement that have come from all points.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 5 -- The city election in Stamford yesterday was of much interest, owing to the candidacy of Charles II. Leeds for Mayor on the Democratic ticket. Mr. Leeds is wealthy, having inherited a large amount of money, and he has also been successful in some Wall Street transactions.

The west-bound Black Diamond Express, on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, which left Jersey City at 12:12 o'clock yesterday afternoon, crashed into a locomotive just outside of Newark and fifteen persons were injured, among them Carrie Nation, the saloon smasher. The accident, believed to have resulted from a wrongly placed switch, occurred on the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which are used by the Lehigh Valley for running into Jersey City.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- A statement made by an Afghan merchant who has just arrived in Calcutta, from Kabul is contained in a dispatch to The Times from the former city.

The corrected returns on the State Senate show that the Republicans have elected twenty-eight members and the Democrats twenty-two. This gives the Republicans a majority of six in the Senate. In the present Senate the Republicans have thirty-five members to the Democrats' fifteen, or a majority of twenty.

The latest election returns do not differ to any great extent from those published yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES. They do not change the political complexion of the House of Representatives as forecasted yesterday, nor reverse the standing of parties in any State Legislature.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- The most significant feature of the California election is the tremendous reduction of Republican pluralities in four years. Gage carried California four years ago by 19,000 plurality and he carried San Francisco against a popular Democratic candidate, ex-Congressman McGuire, by 3,500.

The returns of the vote for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals have not yet been collected and transmitted fully enough to enable us to draw entirely satisfactory conclusions about the effect of Boss PLATT'S nomination of a new man against a sitting and satisfactory Judge for the Court of Appeals.
Statement that the New Orleans Sugar Exchange will adopt the innovation of dealing in futures.
ORANGE, Texas, Nov. 5 -- Three men are dead as a result of a shooting affray here to-day. The dead are Jeff Chenault, City Marshal Jordan, and Tony Jones.

WASHIGTON, Nov. 5 -- The marriage of Mrs. May Clagett Perin, widow of the late Clifford Perin, to Mr. George Howard, son of Sir Henry Howard, British Ambassador to The Hague, took place at noon today at the Church of St. Aloysius, in the presence of a small family party, the Rev. F.X. Fink, the rector, officating.

Francis Asbury Palmer, the aged banker who died last Saturday at his home in Madison Avenue, left none of his fortune to Mrs. Susan Lewis Rockwell, his grandniece. His will was filed for probate yesterday. The estate, according to the petition of the lawyers who filed the document, amounts to about $950,000, including $800,000 in real and $150,000 in personal property.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Prof. H.V. Hilprecht described the more scientific Plan adopted by the fourth expedition of the University of Pennsylvania, in continuing the excavations at Nippur, in his fourth lecture on Babylonian research here to-day.

The responsibility for the fireworks explosion, which caused death and injuries to many on Tuesday night in Madison Square, will be sought not only by the District Attorney and the Coroner, but by Mayor Low, who already has interpellated Police Commissioner Partridge in regard to the catastrophe, and who to-day will address a communication on the subject to the Board of Aldermen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- "The election of a Republican majority in the House of Representatives," said O. P. Austin, Chief of the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, talking of the elections of yesterday, "gives to President Roosevelt an indorsement and support such as few Presidents have ever received in the middle of a Presidential term.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- W.K. Vanderbilt's Biltmore was fourth in the race to-day for the Prix Fontaine at the St. Cloud meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The controversy between Chicago and St. Louis over the pollution of the Mississippi River by the Illinois drainage canal turns on the old question as to how long a distance it is necessary for a river to flow in order to purify itself.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 5 -- Senator Depew was the principal speaker to-night on the occasion of the celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the First Congregational Church. Senator Depew spoke in part as follows:
Fern Council won two games in the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum League bowling tournament last night on the Elephant Club alleys, Brooklyn. The scores:

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 5 -- The marriage of Miss Nora Kathleen Lemon and Ernest Lawrence Dinning took place here to-day. The bride is a daughter of John Lemon of Belfast, Ireland, and the niece of Alexander Godby of this city, with whom she has resided for several years.

For nearly six hours yesterday the jury in the trial of Roland B. Molineux listened to the evidence of handwriting experts for the defense. Three were on the stand and their testimony was consistent in tin essential particular that they did not believe the defendant wrote the disputed writings in this case.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, which was postponed from Oct. 1, was held here to-day. Aside from receiving and approving the annual report of President Milton H. Smith no business was transacted, and an adjournment was taken until Dec. 17, in this city.

The official account of the conferences between Mr. CHAMBERLAIN and the Colonial Premiers has been published. It fully confirms the view which we ventured to take from such information as our dispatches conveyed at the time, that anything like mutually preferential trade between the colonies and England would be found to be utterly impracticable.

Item. Mr. John Drew will hereby take notice that henceforth it is perilous very to express jovial acquiescence by swinging his forearm in a half circle, or to denote an off-hand acquiescence by bringing both palms slap upon his thighs. If he wants to know why, let him suspend the Hubby and the Bumming Bird long enough to go to Weber Fields's and see himself as Mr. William Collier sees him.

Yesterday's morning market continued the weakness of the day before, and the entire list's quotations fell. In the afterroon, however, there was a rally which almost made good the early recessions, leaving final quotations in large majority representing only fractional changes. These changes were for the most part declines, but Stock Exchange sentiment at the close of the day showed material improvement.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 6 -- The Founder's Day celebration in Carnegie Hall attracted an immense throng this afternoon, and before 2 o'clock every place in the Music Hall was occupied. The speakers of the afternoon were Whitelaw Reid, Richard Watson Gilder, and Joseph Jefferson, the veteran actor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Trading again fell off in the stock market to-day, sales aggregating 24,826 shares and $39,462 bonds. Nearly one-half of the stock sales was furnished by Reading common, which was dealt in to the extent of 11,773 shares. Room traders were alone active, concentrating on Reading in their effort to secure a scaiper's profit.

If reports published in the best local authority are correct, Chicago has lately made a discovery of unusual interest. It appears that, wholly " unbeknownst " to any one except the parties immediately in interest, a company has been for a long time quietly at work constructing tunnels under the city, and fourteen miles have been finished without betraying the fact by any surface indications.

One of the most important matters considered at yesterday's session of the Chamber of Commerce was the tax burdens of the property owners of the City of New York. Ex-Deputy Controller Edgar J. Levy pointed out in a pamphlet some of the bad points of the sinking fund, and the present Deputy Controller, James W. Stevenson, has brought forward a plan to relieve taxation and correct the sinking fund evils.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The annual report of Lieut. Gen. Miles, commanding the army, is a brief review of the reports that have been submitted to him by other officers. He indorses the recommendation of Gen. Brooke for a readjustment of the geographical limits of the different departments with a view of equalizing conditions.

BUFFALO, Nov. 6. -- John Cunneen, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, announced to-night that he was sure of his election. For two days he has been getting the returns of the Prohibition and Greater New York Democracy vote in all the counties of the State. He said this evening:

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- The Ranking Committee of 1902, Richard Stevens, B.C. Wright, and L.E. Mahan, having submitted their reports to the Executive Committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, the following ranking of American lawn tennis players has been adopted for the year 1902. The ranking list in singles is:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Samuel Gompers, President of the Federation of Labor declines to talk about the prospect that John Mitchell is to be a candidate to succeed him. His only reply to a question today to the rumors afloat was: "Oh, that's all right."

R. Wittenberg of the Pastime Athletic Club won the bag punching contest last nigtet at the New Polo Athletic Club, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Park Avenue. There were fourteen contestants and a large crowd witnessed the sport. The men in the preliminary trials punched the bag for two rounds of two minutes each.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- The severe chill to which financial circles were subjected on Wednesday was partially overcome to-day. Prices moved up and down by turns, but for the most part within relatively narrow limits. A strong London market served to bring a firm opening, and for a time prices were fairly well held.

Mr. ALFRED MOSELY, who reached this country on Saturday, comes on an errand the possibility of performing which speaks well for the broadmindedness and liberality of American manufacturers. He will be followed in a few days by representatives of English labor employed as iron founders, boiler makers, shipbuilders, cotton spinners, tailors, bookbinders, printers, weavers, electricians, carpenters, masons, plasterers, and many other trades.

There are signs all around of the coming Horse Show. Shops of all kinds are showing " horsey " wares, and the latest thing in this direction are the jockey caps, natural size and in pretty, bright colors, but in basket work, for bonbon boxes.

BOSTON, Nov. 6. -- Developments to-day in the case of Alan G. Mason, the wealthy business man charged with the murder of Clara Morton, a laundress at the McLean Asylum, last Saturday night, have been of a startling nature. It was learned that the watch of the victim had been found in a Cambridge street pawnshop, where, it had been pawned for $4 by a young colored man.

Dr. Frederick W. Holls, member of the American Commission to the International Court of Arbitration at The Hague; Joseph C. Hendrix. President of the National Bank of Commerce; Dr. J.H. Senner, and President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University were the speakers at a festival held last night in honor of the seventieth birthday of Andrew D. White, ex-United States Ambassador to Germany.
Senator Thomas C. Platt's attention was called last night to the fact that a contest against him for re-election was being agitated in certain quarters.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Chicagoans will not have an opportunity of hearing Pietro Maseagni's Italian opera company after all. Milward Adams of the Auditorium, where Mascagni was to have presented several of his operas next week, received a telegram early this morning saying all the composer's Western engagements were canceled.

A well-dressed woman, extremely agitated, ran into the East Twenty-second Street Station house last evening. She took some time to calm herself on reaching the Sergeant's desk. Sergt. Walsh talking quietly to her and asking what had happened.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 6. -- The Democratic tax officials of the county to-day at a secret meeting voted to take from Henry Mergenthaler the contract under which he has been operating for several years as tax inquisitor of the county.

The following is the protest of Fire Commissioner Sturgis to Mayor Low, alluded to in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, against the suspension of the fireworks ordinance from Oct. 27 to Nov. 10, which if heeded, would have averted the awful catastrophe in Madison Square Tuesday night:

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- A.C. Bird, Third Vice President of the St. Paul Road, took a bold stand before the Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day when that body began an investigation into the rates on cattle and packing house products between Chicago and the Missouri River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- It is accepted at the outset of the canvass for the Speakership of the Fifty-eighth Congress that there is to be a bitter factional fight. Mr. Cannon of Illinois, by reason of seniority, will be the leading candidate. To Scotch shrewdness he has added the wisdom of a lifetime of experience in the forefront of politics and legislation.
LONDON, Nov. 7. -- Wilson Barrett produced his own new play "The Christian King" at Bristol last night with the greatest success.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The Chamber of Deputies, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, has sanctioned an agreement by which the Municipality of Paris becomes the owner of the site of the Palace of Machines, erected in the Champ de Mars for the exhibition of 1889.

Counsel for Roland B. Molineux yesterday called to the witness stand Mrs. Anna C. Stephenson, wife of a Brooklyn policeman. Her appearance was awaited with great expectancy by those in the courtroom. She swore very positively that she saw the poison package of this case mailed at the General Post Office on the afternoon of Dec. 23, 1898, and that Molineux was not the man who mailed it.

There was a leave-taking by the members of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday of the old quarters of the organization in the Mutual Life Building, and the next gathering of New York's merchants will be in the handsome building now completed for their use.

Vice Chancellor Stevenson, at Jersey City yesterday, began the hearing of further testimony in the suit brought by Adrian Hitt to compel Dr. William W. Varick, administrator of the estate of Mrs. Augusta A. Thompson to pay two notes, one for $10,000 and the other for $32,000.

The skilled chasers in the factories of the master silversmiths affected by the present strike who had not already quit work when the strike began, went on a sympathetic strike yesterday. About 110 chasers in all are now on strike besides the silversmiths. After to-day the strike is to be extended to other branches.

The Merchants' Association is doing very good work in the direction of stirring up public opinion in favor of the immensely advantageous offer of the Pennsylvania Railroad for the aggrandizement of the city, and in disfavor of the absurd handicaps upon that proposition proposed by some few fools who pretend to represent " organized labor."

W.E. F.B. Taylor have sold for the Trustees of Columbia University the three five-story buildings 711, 713 and 715 Seventh Avenue, 50 by 100, together with the dwellings 168 West Forty-eighth Street, 21 by 100.5, and 170 West Forty-eighth Street, 20 by 50. These properties combined form a it, the shape of an "L " around the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Chairman Gray, Recorder Wright, Brig. Gen. Wilson, and Mr. Parker, four of the seven members of the Anthracite Strike Commission, and Assistant Recorder Moseley and Neill, arrived here late this afternoon from the coal regions, where they have just ended a week's tour of the coal belt.

In preparation for to-morrow's battles on the gridiron all of the leading football teams had hard practice yesterday, and in some instances the outlook for success was very discouraging. This was particularly the case at Columbia. A week ago, just prior to the game against Pennsylvania, there were gloomy forebodings among the Morningside students, but there was a glimmer of hope then, where all is dark and dull to-day.

Mrs. Rose Dale, fifty-six years old, of 545 West Thirty-sixth Street, tried to cross Broadway last evening about 6 o'clock at Thirty-sixth Street. She was very feeble and nervous. As a north-bound car went past, she started backward out of the way, and stepped in the track of a south-bound car piloted by Motorman Alexander Jacobson of 929 Columbus Avenue.

The matter of the proposed clearing house for cotton margins and contracts came up yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Board of Managers of the New York Cotton Exchange. After a long discussion it was decided to put the whole matter before the Exchange members, and for this purpose an informal ballot is to be taken next Tuesday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 -- The market developed nothing new to-day, though the tone continued eminently satisfactory under the circumstances. Holders maintain confident views, so far as local securities are concerned, and show no inclination to sell at any market concessions. The general price record was somewhat mixed, but the changes are nearly all limited to small fractions.

CHARLES JOHN PINNEY died at Amityville yesterday. He was at one time cashier for Alfred Corning Clark, and lived at 20 West Thirtieth Street, but left the city two years ago. He was a member of the St. Nicholas Club and of the Colonial Order.

All of those who followed the beagles yesterday at Wheatley Hills in the annual field trials declared that they had enjoyed a fine day's sport. Trudging all day through wet underbrush and briars after the dogs over acres of rain-soaked ground seemed to be Just the ideal of the experts, and the most enthusiastic member of the party was Mrs. Theodore Hauser of Chicago.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- The relations of Baron Burchard von Munchhausen, with the socalled "marriage syndicate" which financed his journey to the United States in 1898, with the object of obtaining a rich wife, have been made public through a prosecution for blackmail brought by the Baron against Hermann Pineus, Moritz Mendelsohn, and Adollf Mendelsohn, three tradesmen, who were members of the syndicate.

After a 1,400-mile jaunt in an open boat, with water-soaked bread and moldly beef, Capt. J. Nevius Kay, his young wife, nine seamen, and "Whiskers," the cat, of the British barkentine Florence B. Edgett, arrived here yesterday from St. George, Grenada, on the steamship Grenada. The barkentine sailed for Buenos Ayres from Bear River, N.S., on Aug. 11, with 500,000 feet of spruce deal.

-- A paper on " The Amelioration of Our Spelling," read by Prof. CALVIN THOMAS of Columbia at the annual meeting of the Modern Language Association, has been issued in pamphlet form, and ought to be read by everybody whose interest in its subject takes the form of a desire to bring at least an element of common sense and consistency into what Lord LYTTON, with more truth than elegance, called " our accursed spelling."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The frightful tragedy of election night in Madison Square may not be without some value if it serves to call as pronouncedly as it should to the public mind the indifference displayed in increasing magnitude by the officials of the City Government to the observation of the laws and the safety and rights of the people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The President has received a cablegram from the King of Siam extending his Majesty's earnest thanks for the kindly reception accorded to the Crown Prince on his arrival in the United States.

The sharp decline which occurred in prices at the close of the market on Wednesday was not repeated yesterday, the market being dull, but steadier. The fluctuations in the Rock Islands and the few other stocks that were more or less active were relatively narrow and net changes were in few cases important.

Events that jarred harshly on what was agreed upon as popular results. meaning that the best backed horses did not win, continued at the Aqueduct race track yesterday, when a majority of the races furnished surprises for the betting crowd.

JOHN MITCHELL, President of the United Mine Workers, and SAMUEL GOMPERS, President of the National Federation of Labor, stand as the representatives of two principles in labor organization which in some respects are radically at variance. Mr. GOMPERS is perhaps the most intelligent man now prominent in the leadership of organized labor, and his intelligence has made him conservative.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7 -- Joseph Nemser, the Boston pawnbroker who had the watches of the two women murdered in this vicinity within the past month, today failed to pick out A.G. Mason as the man who pawned one of the watches when he looked over a row of prisoners at the jail in East Cambridge to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- A firmer tone was developed in the local market to-day, but that was the extent of the improvement, as trading continued dull, sales amounting to 27,542 shares and $131,500 bonds. Local houses having New York correspondents were advised by them of a less bearish feeling on Wall Street, and expressed the view that a substantial recovery from the present level of prices was probable.

In the present volume the author of "Madame Recamier" has presented a life of the most famous "left-handed queen" of history in an entertaining narrative that is well worth reading. Evidently Mr. H. Noel Williams has no special sources of information. He presents no new phase of life or character, nor does he argue against well-supported and accepted theories.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The body of a murdered man was found in the woods near the Bedford Reformatory for Women, at Bedford, this morning. The identity of the man has not been established. He appears to have been an Italian, but his clothing indicates he was of the better class.

THERE are two ways of writing biographies. One is what Carlyie would call the Dry-as-dust method, in which all the facts are collected with elaborate care and set down with scrupulous accuracy in their chronological sequence, and the result is as uninspiring and monotonous as a dictionary.

Official figures reported to the headquarters of the Prohibition Party, in West Fourteenth Street, seem to establish beyond question the election of John Cunneen, candidate for Attorney General on the Democratic and Prohibition tickets.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- At a dinner given at the Whitefriars Club to-night, Gilbert Parker, M.P., presiding, Moberly Bell, manager of The London Times, was the guest of the evening. The topic of dis- cussion was "The Ideal Newspaper."

The second hearing in the case of the Cuban children brought here last Saturday, prospective students at the Rajah Yoga School, at Point Loma, presided over by Purple Mother Katherine A. Tingley, was concluded yesterday afternoon at Ellis Island.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Weismann's new work on "The Theory at Evolution" will be published here next Spring by Edward Arnold, in a translation by J. A. Thomson, Professor of Natural History at the University of Aberdeen.

In his speech at Pittsburg, Mr. WHITELAW REID enumerated with somewhat startling frankness those rather numerous imperfections in our form of government the effects of which most of us, whatever we may think about them in our hearts, are accustomed, in conversational or oratorical moments, to ascribe to the wickedness or incompetency of our political opponents.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- Call money is still in good supply, loans being made mostly at 5 and 5 1/2 per cent., while many loans at clearing were made at 4 1/2 per cent. Time money is in better supply, and is showing an easier tone. Sterling exchange was firmer and posted rates were up 1/4 cent all around.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Allegations of fraud in the Fifth Ward were made before the Election Court to-day by Henry Johns Gibbons, son of the Rev. Hughes O. Gibbons, pastor of Old Pine Street Presbyterian Church.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Denis A. Spellissy, candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party for the office of Attorney General, to-day certified to the Secretary of State that his election expenses were $468.50. The expenses of Montague Lessler, the Republican candidate for Congress in the Eighth District, were $913.34.

WE have here a very notable addition to our stock of John Fiske's writings, the more precious because the brain and hand that conceived and fashioned all this beautiful and noble work are stilled in death.

Justice Hall of the Supreme Court yesterday ordered that Mrs. Louise Beauchamp Hughes, widow of a prominent merchant of this city, be released from Dr. Theodore H. Kellogg's Riverdale sanitarium. Justice Hall took that action after hearing arguments upon a writ of habeas corpus issued by Justice Scott several days ago.

Those gay dogs who prefer life in the metropolis to a humdrum existence on the old farm have found a champion in Presi- dent John P. Haines of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, who is prepared to combat this ordinance, introduced in the Board of Aldermen by John L. Gold-water of the Bronx:

Baroness von Munchhausen, whose husband caused the exposure of the "Marriage Syndicate" in the trial that was ended in Berlin recently, is visiting her father, Joseph Beckel, at 59 West Sixty-ninth Street. She shed yesterday a good deal of new light on the operations of the syndicate, and incidentally cleared her husband from misapprehensions that arose from inaccuracies in the cable dispatch.

TO WRITE a successful "political novel" reqiures extraordinary ability. Disraeli's "Coningsby" is a masterpiece in its way, but then methods are so different in England from our own, that is, as far as electioneering is concerned.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Six thousand striking coal miners held a meeting at Lievin, Department of Pas-de-Calais, to-day.

HAVANA, Nov. 7 -- The Cuban press is at present making a campaign for the appointment of Frank Steinhart as United States Consul General at Havana. Mr. Steinhart has had charge of the Department of Military Records. It is understood that President Palma has intimated to Washington that Mr. Steinhart would be persona grata to the Cuban Government.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- "I admire gall. I admire gall, and this is gall sublime."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- Albert C. Lowe, who for the last third of a century was a prominent figure in the city's business life, was killed this morning by the Black Diamond express, on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, at the Tenth and Diamond Streets grade crossing.

What a striking contrast is there between "The Book of Joshua" and "The Book of Judges!" In the one we see the children of Israel going on from victory to victory -- entering into the enjoyment of all that God had promised them -- and with thanksgiving making a solemn covenant to serve Him in sincerity and in truth.

The report of the Smithsonian Institution for 1901 contains fifty articles, many illustrated, nearly all prepared by specialists, telling clearly the latest progress in the principal branches of knowledge.

Mr. Chadwick's admiring review. In another part of this paper, of the volumes of essays of the late John Fiske, posthumously published, gives just emphasis to the predominance of Mr. Fiske's historical writings over those of a speculative and philosophical character.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Prof. G.R. Parkin of Toronto, who has been charged with putting the Cecil Rhodes scholarships in the United States into effect, has made inquiries at Oxford University as to how the Rhodes scholars will be received. He has ascertained that every one concerned in the matter is ready to co-operate heartily.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- After an exciting debate the Chamber of Deputies to-day by 278 to 235 votes invalidated the election of Count Boni de Castellane as a member of the House. The question came up when the Committee on Contested Elections presented its report without recommendation, leaving the Chamber to pass on the question.

Both the defense and the prosecution ended their evidence yesterday in the trial of Roland B. Molineux for the murder of Mrs. Katharine J. Adams. Court then adjourned until Monday. Ex-Gov. Frank S. Black and Assistant District Attorney James W. Osborne will on that day sum up their respective cases, and the cause will be submitted to the jury either Monday night or Tuesday morning.

In the little volume called "Siena, Its Architecture and Art," Mr. Gilbert Hastings, a writer of considerable charm of diction and of more than ordinary knowledge of Italian culture, presents' a collection of three essays on the architecture and art of Siena. The author fully appre ciates the fact that in no department of artistic endeavor did Siena ever rise to a leadership in Italy.

It was learned in Jersey City yesterday that the work of extending the old North River tunnel at the foot of Fifteenth Street has been progressing favorably. It was said that the bore had been extended 75 feet, and that at the same rate of progress the union of the Fifteenth Street bore with that extending from the foot of Morton Street, this city, may be effected within six months.

Delightful Alexandre Dumas! You may not begin writing about him without lapsing into eulogy. You cannot be practical or prosaic where he is concerned. Miss Wormeley, in her prefatory note, gives you a good idea of what a traveler was the great writer of romance. He ran over a large part of Europe.

With the single exception of Princeton, all of the big university football elevens will take part in hard gridiron battles throughout the country to-day. The principal games scheduled are as follows: Harvard and Pennsylvania at Cambridge, Columbia and Brown at the Polo Grounds, Yale and Bucknell at New Haven, United States Naval Academy and Lafayette at Annapolis, United States Military Academy and Union at West Point, Amherst and Williams at Amherst.

Taking a young novelist of the hour to task for an obvious straining for "brilliant" effect in dialogue, The London Academy says: "Within the scope of the strong personality there is room for almost infinite diversity, but it is a diversity subject to a master control.
Wisdom is published monthly, in Boston and John Forster Benyon edits it. Henry Cabot Lodge is a contributor. It prints pictures.
R.P. Bliss of Charles H. Easton Co. has sold for the Ludin Realty Company the four-story dwelling 152 West Forty-fourth Street, 20.6 by 100.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- Ambassador White opened to-day the letter which President Roosevelt sent him several weeks ago, marked: "To be opened on your seventieth birthday." Mr. Roosevelt said Mr. White had served his country as few citizens had had the opportunity to do, and thanked him personally and in the name of the people for his services.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The ease of money, with the firmness of Paris exchange, which was thought to be due to remittances by New York, through. Paris, for London, weakened discounts. Much indebtedness to the Bank of England was liquidated.

Notification from Washington was received at the New York Custom House yesterday that John Pierce, who obtained the contract for building the basement and lower floor of the new Custom House, has received authority to proceed with the construction of the rest of the building.

It is a curious and striking instance of the way in which the development of this city outstrips the most sanguine expectations of its managers that the sinking fund, on terms established less than a quarter of a century ago, will, in another twenty years, amount to some $300,000,000 more than the debt which it was intended to secure and wipe out.

IN the little book called "Some Ethical Phases of the Labor Question," Dr. Carroll D. Wright has combined four essays which have no particular correlation, save in the fact that the subjects of which they treat are all of a kind admitting of classification under the general principle of ethics.

THE new story from the pen of Miss Alice Caldwell Hegan, author of the now famous "Mrs. Wiggs," will begin its serial run in the December Century. The story is named "Lovey Mary," after the heroine, who, fleeing from a home of poverty, finds refuge with Mrs. Wiggs and her geographically named family.

Publishers have often noticed that sea stories and works on maritime adventure find a larger sale in the western prairie States than along the seaboard, where ships and the men who sail them are familiar objects. People who have never seen the ocean and know ships only through pictures show a lively curiosity about all that pertains to the romantic life upon the deep.
Senator Platt will be a candidate for reelection as Senator, and the probability is that he will be unopposed. Speaking upon the subject of his candidacy, the Senator said last night:

Capt. Miles O'Reilly of the Oak Street Police Station spent a full two hours on the witness stand yesterday at the trial of Sergt. Thomas McCormick, accused before Commissioner Partridge of accepting $5 for permitting William McIntosh of 319 East Thirteenth Street, a prisoner charged with intoxication, to be balled out at the station.

The snack! Perish that vulgar word, which means a hunk of bread and a wedge of cheese, bolted in haste. The luncheon is a social function, something that comes between breakfast and dinner and sustains life. Mary Ronald's "Luncheons" is the most appetizing of books. The reading of it is certain to make you hungry.
In the Stock Exchange Bowling League tournament last night the Clark, Dodge Co. bowlers won two games, defeating the Charles Head Co. and the Goldsmith, Wolff Co. teams. The scores follow:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Statehood bill, by which it is proposed to admit Oklahoma, New Mexico, and Arizona, will be contested by the Republican leaders in the Senate. Senator Beveridge, Chairman of the Committee on Territories, accompanied by a sub-committee, will go next Monday to visit the three Territories and take testimony on all questions involved in the claim of the three Territories to admission.

THE accidental discovery of a time-worn document in a small printseller's shop in Paris recently has, now, nearly a century after the event, led to the clearing of the name of a gallant officer of the American Navy from charges that caused his imprisonment and darkened his last years, and has led Mr. James Barnes to write some early American history in the form of a sea story.

THAT admirable series of brief biographies, English Men of Letters, which the Macmillans have lately revived, receives an excellent addition to its ranks in Sir Alfred Lyall's study of Tennyson. One says "Study" advisedly, rather than "Life," for, while the work follows the course of the great Laureate's career, it is more intimate in dealing with his poetry than with the facts of his existence.

We have received an extraordinary communication this week from a bookseller who utters a prayer for deliverance from the "flood of books" -- a reactionary merchant who yearns for fewer thing's to sell. There are few such old- , fashioned booksellers in this country, though they are said by irate London publishers to predominate in the book trade of the British Isles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The annual report of Major Gen. Henry C. Corbin, Adjutant General of the army, deals with every feature of the army, and begins with a statement showing how the army is to be reduced by Dec. 1 to 60,020 men, of which 2,877 belong to the staff departments.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- The market continues more or less perfunctory, due to the disposition to wait long enough to find out whether New York will escape an epidemic of bearish sentiment. The local buying is of an investment character, there being very little speculative purchasing, especially purchasing on margin.

The remarkable account of the Russian procedures in Manchuria given to The London Times by its correspondent at Peking, upon which we commented some weeks ago, has aroused in the press of Continental Europe the attention which it was calculated both to attract and to repay.

Emanuel Jacobus, a lawyer, of 132 Nassau Street, reported to the police yesterday morning that his home at 1.325 Madison Avenue had been entered by thieves Thursday evening and jewelry and other articles valued at $5,000 stolen. Mr. Jacobus has no clue to the identity of the thieves, nor does he know exactly when the theft was committed, although it probably took place while the family was at dinner between 6 and 7 o'clock.

Early in December John Anderson, Jr., will hold a special Whittier sale which will bring into the auction room an exceedingly large number of items relating to the poet. As stated last week in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, the sale will be held for the benefit of a fund for the restoration and care of Whittier's birthplace at Haverhill and his home at Amesbury.

Yesterday's stock market was consistently strong up to the last hour of business, when a concerted attack upon values by the bear contingent resulted in forcing declines throughout the list, especial weakness showing in Sugar Trust stock, which sold off nearly 3 points from the high of the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Representative Overstreet of Indiana, Secretary of the Republican Congressional Committee, stopping here on the way home to-day, said: "The contest was peculiar and difficult. There was no overshadowing National issue on which public attention could be centred.

AROUND whom does the interest in these volumes centre? It is a divided one. The Guardian of Marie Antoinette" covers no small part of the history of France. There is the conclusion of the reign of Louis XV. and the beginning of that of his successor, the unfortunate Louis XVI.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Miss May Acker and Michael Brady of this village were married in New York on Aug. 17, but the fact was not known here until yesterday. On the date mentioned they journeyed to New York and went to the Little Church Around the Corner. They were without witnesses, but found a young couple from Staten Island there in the same plight as themselves.

Every student of the complex problems of the government of cities, and every friend of reform who is interested in movements designed to arouse civic patriotism and appeal to civic pride, will find pleasure and profit from the proceedings of the meeting of the National Municipal League held in Boston in May last.

Yesterday's foxhound pack trials in the vicinity of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club were productive of the best sport of the week to those who rose after the bounds in the Long Island hunting centre. The packs tried yesterday belonged to Thomas Hitchcock, Jr., from Aiken, S.C., and the Green Spring Valley of Maryland.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 -- The reduction in the price of steel tubes, amounting to about $5 a ton, which went into effect within the past week, is said by steel men to mark the opening of an aggressive warfare by the steel trust against the independent manufacturers of tube steel.

It is a sorry showing that has been made by the Danish opponents of the transfer of the Danish West Indies to the United States. The objections to the transfer, which have for the present prevailed, were doubtless of a mixed character. They were partly sentimental and patriotic, betokening an opposition to parting with one of the jewels of Denmark's crown, and to that extent were highly respectable.
The Duse that was seen last night at the Victoria Theatre was Duse at her greatest and most complete.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The body of a man, apparently fifty-five years of age, was discovered to-day in the river, about half a mile above the Fishkill Landing Station. The remains were brought here, and the Coroner notified.

On the strength of a decision handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, District Attorney Jerome will at once take up the prosecution of several cases pending against persons indicted as poolroom keepers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Congressman John Dalzell has formally entered the Speakership contest and claimed the support of the Republican delegation from Pennsylvania, and the contest so far as the announced candidates are concerned has become triangular, with Mr. Cannon of Illinois and Mr. Littlefield of Maine also in the arena.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your issue under "Cost of Libraries," statistics are given proving in round numbers that it costs $1 per volume to purchase a book and $2.50 to care for it. The figures are correct by our books, and the cost of running the library is two-and-one-half times the cost of new accessions.

LA VICTORIA, Venezuela, Nov. 7 -- The Government soldiers, who are following up the defeated revolutionists scored their first success yesterday morning by the capture of Gen. Ramon Luizi, who was making his way in the direction of Alta Gracia with 300,000 rounds of ammunition and 4,060 men to reinforce the revolutionists.

"Cap'n Titus: Sketches of New England Country Folk," by Clay Emery (Doubleday, $1,) introduces once more the neckwhiskered philosopher and humorist of the country store. The New England "dialect" is still with us. Cap'n Titus is a seafaring man, who is a trifle out of his element driving a horse; he is another David Harum in the matters of story-telling and trading, and he is a bit of a liar, too.

American people are born good natured and thus far have been good naturedly tolerant of trusts, as they are also of most other public abuses or impositions. But there is a limit, unlikely as the statement may seem, to average American good nature, also a limit to American patience in its attitude toward trusts.

THE morning had drifted along, until the teacher found herself opposite that period of time on her programme devoted to "phonics." She noted (with satisfaction) that she had progressed along the alphabetical way until she was in the immediate vicinity of "S."

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- A team from De La Salle lined up against the team of the Chappaqua Institute here this afternoon and were defeated by the score of 12 to 0. The home team were strengthened by Prof. Armstrong and several strong local players. Considering the forces against them, the De La Salle boys played a good game.

W.H. Gilstrap, Curator of the Ferry Museum, has returned from a few weeks' visit in and about historic Champoeg, in Oregon. Mr. Gilstrap is artist, historian, and curio hunter all in one, and he found many things in Champoeg to arouse his interest. When all the Northwest was Oregon, Champoeg was its capital.

The soul of Joseph, the waiter, is much vexed. And when you consider there are 20,000 Josephs in Paris, the matter is serious. He -- that is, certain chosen representatives of the family of Joseph -- has invoked the law in his aid. It is not, as you might suppose, a question of tips, though his spirit groans within him at times at the degradation of it, but a quarrel with his master.

THE very serious illness of Mr. Johnston Livingston, President of the Knickerbocker Club, calls attention again to the history of that organization. Mr. Livingston succeeded the late Judge Alonzo Monson, who was President of the club for many years, and, indeed, its founder.

THE day of the mining prospector is not past," said John Elderkin to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter. "Mining is now being pushed with more energy in Northern Arizona than ever before. This plateau, elevated by volcanic action several thousand feet above the level of the southern section of the Territory, is now known to be a field of mineral wealth of vast extent.

"Beauvoir, the post-bellum home of Jefferson Davis, is to be made a home for Confederate veterans, and the first contribution for the purpose was made at my suggestion and through my efforts,'' said Willis L. Hall of Denver.

N point of fascination for the casual investigator there is probably no feature of the local Post Office system which can compare with the department where knotty problems in badly addressed letters are solved.

There was a bad break in prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday under which quotations for many representative stocks fell from 3 to 4 points each, with an extreme decline of 19 points recorded in Lackawanna.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The Orange County Hunt covered eighteen miles to-day in fast time, a field of some twenty odd riders participating. E.S. Craven, as usual, carried the horn. The drag was laid from Goshen to Glenmere over a semi-circular stretch of country. The scent was good, and the Irish pack, numbering fourteen couples, set a hot pace.
NEWPORT, Nov. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. W.W. Sherman and Dr. and Mrs. J.J. Mason have closed their cottages and returned to New York to-day.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Liberals are jubilant and the Unionists, are proportionately disgruntled by the results of the by-elections in the Cleveland and East Toxteth Divisions. The large increase in the Liberal majority in the Cleveland Division is generally admitted, even by the Conservative organs, to be due to dissatisfaction with the Education bill, which is still wending its way through the House of Commons.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- Ere this reaches you lovers of Italian architecture may have an additional cause for mourning other than that given by the fall of the Campanile di San Marco. Reports from Aqulla, a small although historic town -- the birthplace of Sallust and for years the residence of Margaret of Austria -- say that the Campanile di San Bernardino at that place is in imminent danger of falling.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- A short paragraph in The Times of last Monday has created one of those periodical scares in regard to the supposed intention of the Irish "Physical Force" party to renew its activity.
I first made the acquaintance of the particular parrot concerning whom I propose to relate certain things at the house of a friend in Liverpool.

OVER in Third Avenue, where "the drama of the people" flourishes each and every night and thrice weekly at matinees, the perennial struggle between virtue and vice was again illuminated last week in "A Ruined Life," set down on the bills as a thrilling and realistic melodrama by E. Laurence Lee, whose name likewise headed the list of players on the programme.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I -- and many others, no doubt-are daily receiving from promoters letters, accompanied by prospectuses, asking me to subscribe for stocks and promising me large returns in the form of dividends always in the future. My purpose in writing is to suggest some method of governmental control of this practice for the protection of the public.

IN SOME PARTS of the country "middlin'" or "from fair to middlin'" is compelled to perform yeoman duty in the daily conversational intercourse between the natives. Everything from the state of one's health to a conflagration or an earthquake comes under one or the other of these headings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Bureau of Navigation is ready to distribute to enlisted men the West Indian Medal awarded under act of Congress approved March 3, 1901.

Mr. and Mrs. John L. French have decided to start on their long tour to the South in an automobile Monday morning, Nov. 3. Their destination is Orlando, Fla., where they expect to join friends on a hunting and fishing trip. Their exact route has not been ascertained on account of the impossibility of securing accurate information, and it will depend somewhat on the roads.

Dr. W.G. Cassells, an old Tacoman, is in the city renewing acquaintances of ten years ago. He comes now from Dawson, whore he has established a big practice and done well in every way. The doctor is well-known here to a host of people, and his success in the ten years he has been absent will prove interesting.

THE recent experience of an East Orange clergyman whose wife brought a woman over from Germany with her this Fall with the object of making a domestic servant out of her, only to have the woman fall into the clutches of an "immigrant missionary," recalls the experience of a man connected with the United States Diplomatic Service.

Affairs of serious moment having been settled, the social season in New York begins with this week, but large entertainments are not to be given until after the Horse Show. The early opening of the opera, however, will do away with the interregnum between the first event at the Madison Square Garden and the second at the temple of music on Broadway.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 26 -- The ignorance and the religious fanaticism of the Russian peasantry are illustrated in a striking manner by the almost blasphemous veneration of which the famous Father John of Kronstadt, much against his will, is made the object. A short time ago a peasant in the Government of Kostroma wrote a hymn in honor of Father John, placing him almost on an equality with the persons of the Trinity.

The annual meeting of the National Association for the Study of Epilepsy and the Treatment and Care of Epileptics, held in the Academy of Medicine in this city on Wednesday last, served to call attention anew to the work being done in the State of New York alone in the attempt to provide a home where the epileptics may be segregated and treated.

Before the election The Mobile (Ala.) Register said that there were two Republican parties in Alabama -- "the lily whites and the lamp blacks." But when the votes were counted on Tuesday night the two parties seemed to have gone into oblivion together.

We desire to thank President BUTLER of Columbia University for some plain things he says in the current number of The Review of Reviews. The editor of that enterprising periodical submitted to Dr. BUTLER a series of questions regarding the proposition for a two years' course in college as an alternative to the present one, which is nominally four, but so far as the strictly collegiate curriculum is concerned is practically three.

THE savings of a lifetime -- $1,300 -- which a Philadelphia woman had just drawn from a savings bank a few days ago, fell to the floor in the bag in which she was carrying the money, and remained for a time unnoticed in a store in which she had been shopping, but the bag was eventually found and returned to its owner.

Prof. Warner of this city recently addressed at Seattle the students of the State University. His remarks were interesting. The logic of them was correct only in a general way. When he said: "Every wish is sure to come true," he was saying too much. There is a point to which even the most robust optimism may not attain, and the point in question is much this side the realization of every wish.

A good deal of time and effort is being wasted just now in the effort to secure the replanting along the Boulevard of the trees destroyed by the subway excavation. Park Commissioner WILLCOX is very much interested in the matter, and he has the energetic, if misdirected, cooperation of the West Side Association and of many public-spirited citizens.

As the result of a fire which, originating in the subway excavation adjoining, caused slight damage to the mailing and pressrooms of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday afternoon, two men were killed and two boys were overcome by smoke. One of them is in a serious condition and may not recover.

THE second passing, for the present at least, of the Steamboat Squad, or Eighty-first Precinct, which guarded part of the water front of Manhattan, and whose headquarters were at Pier A, North River, recalls interesting reminiscences. Its existence was due to Col. Joel B. Erhardt, who sought to check depredations by thieves along the North and East Rivers and the operations of gangs of water-front highwaymen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Minister Wu has finally served official notice on this Government of the change to be made in the Chinese Legation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Princeton practiced behind closed gates to-day. The coaches said the work was the most encouraging of the season. The men started fast, the interference formed quickly, and there was no fumbling to mar the plays. Notwithstanding an exceedingly heavy scrub the 'Varsity had little difficulty in scoring three touch-downs and a field goal from the thirty-yard line.
COME outside and settle it, if that's what you want." "I'm not looking for trouble, but I can oblige you."

A POPULAR Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the Far West staid a few days with a ranchman. When the Bishop left his host shook him warmly by the hand and said: "Bishop, we all like you out here; you are not stuck up, and you are no blooming aristocrat. We like you because you are so darned common and no gentleman.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has to ask the indulgence of its readers to-day, and may have to ask that indulgence for another day, on account of the crippling of its mechanical facilities which resulted from the outbreak yesterday of a fire in the basement of its building.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 8 -- The football team of the Annapolis midshipmen defeated the eleven of Lafayette College her this afternoon by a score of 12 to 11. The score does not indicate that the navy lac' played the better game, for Lafayette has a splendid attack. The famous guirds' back formation formerly used by Pennsylvania was the means by which they made good gains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will THE TIMES be good enough to indulge me to the extent of devoting a little more of its space to some comments on the answers elicited by the "Mr. and the Hired Man" question?

A decision of Justice Fitzgerald of the Supreme Court promises to end forever the disputes over the estate of Samuel J. Tilden, who ran against Rutherford B. Hayes for the Presidency of the United States. The Justice has confirmed the report of Lawrence Godkin, the referee appointed to determine questions relative to the claims of Samuel J. and George H. Tilden, nephews of the famous Democrat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire to submit some observations supplemental to your editorial of this date, entitled "The City's 'Talk' With Mayor Low." An analysis of the vote cast for Mr. Coler in Greater New York will show that at least 33 per cent. of such vote was meant as indicating dissatisfaction with the varying policies of the present city administration.

AN ASSERTION that it is next to impossible to get a properly boiled or baked potato in Chicago has called forth voluminous correspondence in The Chronicle and incidentally several suggestions about the cooking of that useful vegetable. One man, who signs himself "A Mining Camp Caterer," says: "All the trouble with the boiled potato arises from the stupidity of not pouring off all the water in which the potatoes have been boiled.
