No surprise was manifested at the University of Pennsylvania at the information received from Constantinople that the Sultan of Turkey had again refused a "firmin" or permission to an American named Banks to excavate "Tel Ibrahim," a mountain about nine hours' ride northeast of the ruins of Babylon, where a tradition of the country has it that the tomb of Abraham is situated.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- The Cadet football team defeated Union College to-day by a score of 56 to 0. Union was not in the same class with the soldiers. The feature of the game was Daly's first appearance in the Cadet line, and his h to a touch-down one minute after the ll went into play.

That the present is a time for caution, for the ascendency of conservative over too liberal methods in matters financial, may be admitted; but that it is a time when pessimism should be encouraged and depression be considered the proper attitude of mind accompaniment thereto may as strongly be doubted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This morning's paper contains an article announcing the timely and creditable action taken by Alderman John L. Goldwater of the Bronx in introducing in the Board of Aldermen "Resolution No. 193. An ordinance in relation to the harboring and keeping of dogs in the City of New York."

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- R. Henri Bauer, whose new piece "La Maitresse," produced at the Vaudeville Theatre, has caused a vast amount of discussion in literary circles, is a half-brother of the late Alexandre Dumas fils, and a son consequently of the great novelist, whom he resembles a good deal more than did the author of "Francillon."

WE have all wondered at the sudden rise to prominence of laundry starch in Queen Elizabeth's time." said the up-to-date girl serving tea as her friends sat in the middle of her studio threading their lingerie with Tom Thumb ribbons. "There was the exaggerated ruff; there was the stomacher, 'with cuff and farthingale and things,' as Shakespeare says.

Among the visitors to Colorado Springs are Brig. Gen. John W. Barlow and wife of Washington, D.C. Gen. Barlow is a retired army officer, but is now in the service of the State Department. He is on his way to San Diego, Cal., to meet Jacob Blanco, a Commissioner of the Mexican Government, for the purpose of inspecting with him the monuments marking the boundary line between this country and the Republic of Mexico.

The following article has been written from notes taken from the diary of a United States Senator. It is interesting as a record of the amount of work that may be crowded into the limits of a single day, and should have value as a truthful and graphic story of conditions in Washington as they exist at present. -- [G.B.]

DEEP-sea fishermen in New York say that the startling figures published of fatalities among Gloucester, Mass., fishermen for the past thirty years are no criterion of what is to be expected in future. The old-style fishing sloop is fast going out of use.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- A bill attacking the right of twenty-one fire insurance companies to do business in this State, and asking that a judgment of ouster be entered against each one, and that a fine of $25,000 be imposed on each concern, was filed in the Circuit Court to-day by State Insurance Superintendent Yates.

The suggestion of Winter in the air yesterday caused a run on the coal dealers by customers, who tried in vain to coax them to deliver coal at a given time. Claims of old acquaintanceship were listened to with apathy, and only persons with special influence could get any kind of a pledge as to future delivery.
A LITTLE boy, in the city for the first time, called to his mother when an organ grinder stopped in front of the house.

The stock market during the week just passed was dull and highly irregular, heaviness showing on some days, strength on others. It is a fact, however, that such heaviness as there was was due in large measure to selling for the short account. Substantial interests appeared as buyers on yesterday's severe decline, but made no effort to bid up prices.

All the big college football teams played yesterday with the exception of Princeton, which canceled the game arranged with the Orange Athletic Club in order to give the Tiger team more time to recover from the effects of the hard game with Cornell a week ago and to avoid the possibility of disabling any of the players upon the eve of their most important contest.

William Gillette, the playwright-actor, has for three years absolutely refused to be interviewed. So the other day when he entered the office of his manager and found a newspaper woman awaiting him, he politely said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The War Department made public to-day a statement by Gen. R.P. Hughes in reply to charges contained in a letter written by Henry Loomis Nelson in a Boston newspaper Aug. 26, 1902 and which letter is embraced in a pamphlet stoned by Charles Francis Adams, Carl Schurz, Edwin Barrett Smith and Herbert Welsh committee, under the title of "Marked Severities; Secretary Root's Record in the Philippine Warfare."

TUXEDO PARK, Nov. 8 -- The early part of the week at Tuxedo was rather dull, the time being passed in town by many of the cottagers, but on Thursday they all returned, and in consequence many social functions were scheduled for the week's end.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- New York was responsible for the weakness which was developed in the local market to-day, as the bulk of the selling here of the locals was to enable operators to better protect their holdings of New York stocks. With the exception of the arbitrage stocks -- Reading, Pennsylvania, and United States Steel -- the losses were in must cases fractional.

The relations between the United States Shipbuilding Company and the Trust Company of the Republic, which have been the subject of some talk in Wall Street, were again brought prominently before the attention of the Street yesterday, when it became known that a new syndicate had been formed to take over certain of the securities of the United States Shipbuilding Company which were owned and vouched for by the Trust Company of the Republic.

Up to the time of yesterday's decline prices the week's stock market had been without notable incident. Election pessimism disposed of, the room trading contingent declined to abate their energy on the bear side, and throughout the eek their assaults had continued uninterruptedly.

This is the time of the year when the darky down in Dixie is his happiest, for it is cotton time. They raise corn, tobacco, sugar cane, and many other things down South, but there is nothing that appeals to the average colored person like cotton. The love for it is probably born in him, as his ancestors had to do everything from hoeing the plant to toting it to the press.

It is reported that a bill is to be introduced at the next session of the General Assembly looking to the maintenance of the color line in certain criminal circles. It is said that the proposed measure will provide for separate cells and accommodations for the white and black chain-gang convicts of the State.

The reports by officers appointed by the Commander in Chief to inquire into the working of the Remount Department broad were issued on Oct. 18 as a Blue Book, [Cd. 995.] The reports cover the inquiries held by Col. R.C. Stewart and Leiut. Col. E. Holland, R.F.A., with regard to the purchasing and shipping in the United States of America and Canada.

With roaring lions, snarling tigers, crumpeting elephants, docile antelopes, and shattering monkeys on board, besides a goodly assortment of nearly everything else that roams the fields, inhabits the air, swims the waters, or haunts the jungles, the Atlantic Transport liner Minneapolis, for the trip the Barnum Bailey circus ship, got in from Dunkirk, France, yesterday morning.

The first of the whalers to return to port this season was the bark Alice Knowles, Capt. P.D. Montgomery, which came into the harbor Saturday, Oct. 25, fourteen days from Fox Island, bringing 1,540 barrels of sperm oil Only one right whale was seen during the long cruise, but it could not be overtaken.

SIDE By side two girls were speeding up the lake, the sharp click, click of their skets ringing clear and musical in the crisp, still air. Easily the miles slipped away behind. Points of land rushed up and past, dim and shadowy in the white light of the moon; and once or twice in the far distance they heard the sinister voice of some night-prowling animal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of "Fiat J." relates that an employe objected to being addressed without the prefix "Mr.," and asks if an employer or superior has a right to address an underline without the dignifying "Mr."

BERNICE BARDINE, a Texas girl, who is yet under twenty years of age, has displayed better judgment and business acumen of a higher order than a score of male competitors who are engaged in the same business that occupies her attention at the present time, says The Chicago Tribune.

There is a reasonable possibility that a unity in rules may soon be established between the English and American Polo Associations. Until last Spring no really prominent American player except Foxhall Keene had been brought into prominent contact with foreign players since 1886, when an English team visited this country and won the international cup which our team tried ineffectually to bring back from the Hurlingham Club this year.

Far more successful than Tom L. Johnson in a circus campaign was A.H. Jackson of Frement, Sandusky County, whose election as Congressman from the Ohio Thirteenth District over James A, Norton (Dem.) of Tiffin was the culmination of one of the most remarkable contests in recent political history.

There are two preachers in Cartersville, Ga., who are brothers. They bear the name of Jones, and are widely known. One is Sam Jones, the Methodist evangelist and lecturer, and the other is Joe J. Jones, the Baptist evangelist. Both of these men have tasted the dregs of dissipation.

WHY is it that "education" is an idea that is supposed to be so distasteful to large masses of people when they think of music? Or why is it so often considered distasteful to think about music at all? A careless tickling of the ear and a mere pleasing of the senses are commonly regarded as the highest good that can come of music where the uncultivated masses are concerned.

The cornerstone of the Winnie Davis Memorial Hall at the Georgia State Normal School in Athens, that State, was laid on Saturday afternoon, Nov. 1. The building is designed to accommodate sixty students, daughters of Confederate soldiers. There was a large assembly present, including Georgia legislators, Daughters of the Confederacy, the Chancellor of the university, and the President of the Normal School and students thereof.

In response to instructions from the Department of State, the United States Consuls in the principal cities of Europe have forwarded information regarding the manufacture, sale, and use of automobiles in Europe, advance sheets of which have been issued by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce, Department of State.
BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were firmer on more encouraging coal reports from the pits in the Ruhr district. Later stocks were generally weaker on London advices.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- At the Mercantile Library in this city Champion Lasker gave a simultaneous exhibition of play against twenty members of the chess section yesterday evening, and when play was concluded at an early hour this morning, the champion had won seventeen games, had drawn two, and lost one to Charles H. Bousoll.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 8 -- The plants of the Nonpareil Cork Manufacturing Company, the Camden Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of chemicals, and McAndrews Forbes, liquor manufacturers, comprising about a dozen frame buildings at Kaighan's Point, in the southern section of this city, were destroyed by fire to-day.

I have been taken through Zola's town house. He seems to have had a presentiment that he would be killed in his bed at night. To secure himself against murderous burglars he had a forged iron grating of a beautiful design placed across his bedroom in order to isolate the part in which he slept from the rest of the apartment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial, "The Growth of the Whisky Habit in England," and incidental observations on kindred conditions here are interesting, and would be more so had your spirit trade experts, who ascribe the failing off in consumption of light wines to the increasing appetite for whisky, explained the cause for this change in the Anglo-Saxon appetite.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- The annual shoot between the Harvard and Pennsylvania Gun Clubs was held at Soldiers' Field to-day. Harvard won by a score of 135 to 96. There were five men on each team, and each man shot at fifty birds.

Dr. Samuel McCune Lindsay, United States Commissioner of Education in Porto Rico, has written for The Philadelphia Sunday School Times an article giving his first impressions of the children there, in the course of which he says:

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- Call money was offered freely at the start to-day at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent., but after the announcement of the poor New York bank statement the rate was generally marked up all around to 5 per cent., and it was hard to obtain even at that figure. Time money, although not offering in large amounts is still obtainable at recently quoted rates.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- Though only a few friends were in attendance, one of the most interesting events in social circles during the past week was the marriage of Judge William White Wiltbank of the Common Pleas Court and Miss Fanny De Lancey Welsh at the country home of the bride in Germantown.

Mayor W.M. Drennen sent to Chief White Eagle of the Ponca tribe a handsome silver cup, on which was engraved the inscription: "To White Eagle. Chief of Poncas, from Mayor Drennen, Birmingham. Ala. November 1, 1902."

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Nov. 3 -- Back from a cruise of seven months in exploration of the depths of the South Pacific Ocean the United States Fish Commission steamer Albatross has reached this port. The cruise has been one of highest importance to scientific and commercial knowledge.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- There has been an epidemic of sensational criminal cases here during the past week, each of which is typical enough of certain phases of social decadence. We have had the arrest of the Marquis de la Torre, the flight of Canon Rosenberg, and the arrest and subsequent escape of the banker Boulaine.

HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- In thinking of Cuba as a country offering excellent opportunities for acquiring riches or even a good livelihood, and acting upon the thought, many American men and women have found that they were mistaken.

SEATTLE, WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The United States revenue cutter Negros, the first vessel for that service ever built in Asia, was given her trial trip at Pootung on Aug. 16, according to mail advices from the Orient. The Negros is one of ten cutters which have been built or are being built for the United States Revenue Service in the Philippines.
JUST after "Charlie" Adler, the sometime Assemblyman from "De Ate" District, returned from a trip across the Continent, he told this story of himself:

THOSE small property owners who have built tenement houses on their narrow lots and in strict compliance with all of the minute regulations of the new tenement house law have proved that there was slight foundation for the prediction of many who opposed the act when it was before the State Legislature that the proposed law, if passed and enforced, would mean the ruin of the investor of small means.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It were desirable if persons who pretend to pronounce judgment on the Irish question would inform themselves a little on the philosophy of the matter, or, in other words, would con a few leading facts of Irish history.
XXI. WELL, Mr. Idiot," said Mr. Brief, as the guests assembled, "I see that the President has issued his Thanksgiving proclamation and that, as usual, everything is lovely and the goose honks high."

ONE enterprising young woman in New York makes a comfortable income taking care of the pet dogs of rich society women. Not only must a dog in this class have a tailor and hospital for his especial benefit, but he is becoming more fastidious than Mother Hubbard's remarkable pet.

In a conversation on Wednesday, Oct. 29, ex-Senator Henry Laurens Dawes's eightysixth birthday, the venerable statesman recalled the celebrated tariff debates of thirty years ago, when he took a middle ground, in favor of moderate tariff reform, such as now finds many advocates in the protection camp.

The announcement of Charlemagne Tower's new diplomatic position at Berlin has recalled to many Duluth persons his five years' residence in this city in the capacity of President of the Duluth and Iron Mountain Road. He was much admired and respected, but was considered rather distant, despite the fact that he was really quite approachable.

Ex-Congressman Felix Campbell, one of Brooklyn's oldest citizens, died yesterday morning at his home, 1,315 Pacific Street, after a week's illness. Death was caused by pneumonia. Mr. Campbell was prominent in financial circles in this city, and had held a high position in politics in Kings County.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The German Imperial yacht Hohenzollern, with Emperor William on board, accompanied by the escorting German cruisers and a flotilla of British torpedo boats, reached Port Victoria at 8 o'clock this morning.

It is said that there is as much drinking now as there ever was, but that men do not drink in the same way as of old; and that public drunkenness is now comparatively rare. Occasionally we sec men upon the streets who are under the influence of liquor; but one might go from one end of Memphis to the other and not find a drunken mail in a day's journey.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Fitch are at present at their Chateau de Pradines in Vaucluse with Mrs. Harold Fitch, who will return to her hotel in the Rue de Lota for the remainder of the year.

"Probably not 30 per cent. of the outof-the-State sportsmen who come into the Maine schools and return with game shoot it the " said a registered guide who was in Thursday. "It is something of a trick to shoot a deer, and if it wasn't for the fact that they are accompanied by guides a great many of them would return home empty handed.

The game of football, which is attracting such large crowds in late years, was a favorite pastime centuries ago. That is to say, the Romans played a game with an inflated ball, which is doubtless the embryo of the modern pigskin, and likewise the Greeks had a game in which the players of one side carried the ball across a line defended by others.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Englishmen as a whole are extremely ignorant of American politics, and although events are gradually opening their eyes to the greatness of the Republic and her potentialities, they may even be said to be extremely ignorant of all things American. It is not too much to assert that the average Englishman has not the least conception of what America means.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 28 -- There is much opposition in Belgian artistic circles to the proposed sale of the famous Rubens in the Church of Saint-Martin, at Alost, to an American collector. Some time since it was stated that, in order to raise the necessary funds to complete the church, which has long been in an unfinished state, the Board of Vestrymen intended to dispose of the painting for $300,000.

The only notable feature of the money market last week was the rise in sterling exchange to the highest figure of the season, this of course starting all kinds and conditions of talk of gold exports in considerable volume. Those who talked evidently had not been following the exchange situation very closely, else might they have been more moderate and certainly less committal in their statements.

Readers of THE TIMES will remember the interviews with Gens. YOUNG and CORBIN printed upon their return from Europe. Gen. YOUNG generalized that, while Englishmen studied Europe, its people, and its institutions, their history and habits, they were comparatively ignorant about America and Americans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The contractors have notified the Navy Department that two submarine boats will be ready for their official trials Monday next, and that the trials will begin as soon afterward as the trial board is ready.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- A great deal of interest has been created in English art circles by the announcement from Berlin that Emperor William recently gave an audience to Herr Gehrke, the well-known artist, and discussed with him the question whether it would not be possible to revive the manufacture of pure majolica ware.

While it is true that more women than men successfully pass the Civil Service examination, fewer of them are appointed than formerly. In the past year or two a prejudice against the appointment of women as clerks has grown up among the several heads of the departments. No particular reason or cause for this prejudice is assigned by the Civil Service Commission, but it exists and seems to be growing.

ODESSA, Oct. 16 -- The Turkestan Gazette, published at Tashkend, gives some further details of the terrible loss of life and property wrought by the recent earthquake in the region of Kashghar. The populous settlement of Nijni-Artish, lying to the northeast of Kashgar, was practically razed, many of the dwellings being wholly or partially engulfed in huge fissures; at that place 1,700 persons perished.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- The Yale freshmen were defeated by the Princeton freshmen by a score of 5 to 0 to-day. Both teams were evenly matched and the game was closely contested. Yale did slightly the better work on the offensive, and in the second half cut through the Princeton line, but a disastrous fumble by Twitchell and a rally by Princeton saved the goal.

The celebration at Sault Ste. Marie on the opening of the power canal of the Lake Superior Power Company brings into prominence the wonderful industrial development with which Mr. F.H. Clergue's name is associated. The moving spirit of these enterprises has often declared that the advantages offered at the Soo cannot be duplicated in the world, and he has given many practical demonstrations that its development is in capable hands.
THE old gentleman played a queer trick on me the other night," said the young man, as he lit a cigar after dinner. It was rather awkward for me, but I guess it was a good thing after all.

The minister of Leavenworth who conceived the idea of utilizing the phonograph to sing hymns at funerals doubtless meant well, tout such good intentions are proverbially fit paving material for a road leading in quite the opposite direction from that along which he would dispatch the souls of dead and dying parishioners.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A general victory throughout the country indicates a firm confidence in the Republican Party and approval of the party policies. The party is given a further lease of power and an opportunity to demonstrate the wisdom of its course and to redeem its pledges to the people.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 8 -- In the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Matheson Sutherland, 64 Carnegie Avenue, this afternoon, their daughter, Miss Florence Helena M. Sutherland, was married to Charles Stewart F. Campbell of Glen Ridge by the Rev. Oscar F. Moore, assistant rector of Grace Episcopal Church.

It is known with reasonable certainty that Earl Roberts, designated so widely throughout the empire with affectionate familiarity as "Bobs," is to visit Canada at no distant day. The exact date is not fixed, but there is little doubt that he will be here next Summer as Commander in Chief of the British Army.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A general victory throughout the country indicates a firm confidence in the Republican Party and approval of the party policies. The party is given a further lease of power and an opportunity to demonstrate the wisdom of its course and to redeem its pledges to the people.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 8 -- In the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Matheson Sutherland, 64 Carnegie Avenue, this afternoon, their daughter, Miss Florence Helena M. Sutherland, was married to Charles Stewart F. Campbell of Glen Ridge by the Rev. Oscar F. Moore, assistant rector of Grace Episcopal Church.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday.

The Missouri Valley Homoeopathic Association, having been goaded into the adoption of a resolution declaring kissing unsanitary, ought now to stand on one side until report of the popular opinion of the proceeding begins to come in, when it will no doubt reach the conclusion that it may judiciously go out of business.

When so great an artist as Duse has been at the pains of presenting to us so noted a playwright as d'Annunzio, one would go great lengths in order to be appreciative; but even this most cosmopolitan hospitality has limits. There is a favorite story in Continental cafes of an Englishman who observed to a Frenchman that "pain" is an extraordinary name for bread.
THE poet's name was John -- which is but partly true, for if all his name were printed it would be recognized at once.

"The Problem of China" was the subject of an address delivered before the Academy of Political Science at Columbia University by Prof. T. Iyenaga last Monday evening. Prof. Iyenaga at one time held an important position under the Japanese Government and was also a professor in the Higher Commercial College of Japan.

[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Money has been plentiful this week, partly owing to Government disbursements, as shown by the decline of L2,122,000 in the public deposits at the Bank of England, L1,178,000 of this having gone to private deposits, to that extent adding to the market's supplies of banking credits.

Frank Calvin, the North Indianapolis consumptive, who has been sleeping and living out of doors during the Summer, has gained thirty pounds by the treatment, his hemorrhages have been stopped, and he has started to the South on a novel open-air treatment trip.

David Lamar's bay pacer Nathan Straus, with a mark of 2:05 1/2, added a third victory to his credit in the championship brushes held yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River Speedway under the auspices of the Road Drivers' Association of New York. Kingmond, 2:09, driven by his owner, Claus Bohling, carried off the honors in the championship trotting class for the third time.

S. Forest Seaburg, a theatrical manager, who for several years has been handling companies through Russia, Japan, China, and the Philippines, has arrived in the city from Yokohama. This is the first time he has been in this country in two years, and his mission is to get new people for the play-loving public across the Pacific.

While the marshes are glowing with the tints of red, copper, and gold, and on mountain side or in swamps a single tree is relieved against the Autumnal foliage like a steadily burning flame of orange or crimson, the scientist is puzzling his brain as to the why and wherefore of these colors that vie successfully with the gorgeous hues of sunset.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -- As the latest step in looking after the health of the so-called "typical Harvard man," Harvard University has just opened a new hospital -- the Stillman Infirmary -- through a gift made about a year ago by James Stillman of New York. This new building is a perfect example of the best modern hospital construction.

SUCH a disagreeable storm was raging on Saturday night that no more than a dozen men were found gathered around the stove at the Post Office to wait for the mail from Hinckley. And because a commercial traveler from New York, who was staying over in order to go hunting rabbits next day was present, and because the woodsmen are usually shy in the presence of city strangers, those who had come were unusually quiet.

The medical faculty are keen upon microbes, but never before has the Englishman's "tub" been assailed. Now we are not only warned against the dangers of the daily or weekly bath, but deliberately told that we are courting pneumonia and various diseases.

A call was sent out yesterday for the annual meeting of the Industrial Department of the National Civic Federation. It wil be held in this city Dec. 8, 9, and 10. The hall in which the meeting will be held has not yet been announced. Regarding the object of the meeting, Ralph H. Easley, the secretary of the Federation, said yesterday:

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- A Baronet of ancient family was admitted a few days ago as an inmate of the West Ham Workhouse, at Leytonstone, in the East End of this city, and will probably stay there for the remainder of his life.

The Rev. Dr. Bailey, President of the Westminster College, at Salt Lake City, Utah, who is visiting the East in the interest of that institution, addressed the ministers' meeting in Witherspoon Hall Monday morning upon the subject of Mormonism.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -- The score of to-day's football game on Soldiers' Field, Harvard 11 and Pennsylvania 0, caused the visitors to cheer madly after the contest, and the Harvard men to walk off the field discouraged and dissatisfied. Although the Crimson actually won, the game was regarded as virtually a victory for Pennsylvania.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With reference to the letter of T.D. Semple, Esq., in your issue of Nov. 3, I beg to state that the rule laid down in the cases cited by him is that "an agreement by one party to support another during life is an entire continuing contract, and upon total breach thereof the latter may recover full and final damages."

Maurice Grau arrived yesterday on the French liner La Lorraine with a number of members of the French opera company which will sing this Winter under his direction. Mr. Grau went abroad on a tenor hunt. "They thought I would have no new tenor," he said yesterday, "but I have engaged three -- Anthes, Burgstaller, and Gerhauser."
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times says a strong feeling exists in favor of the abolition of the Russian institution the Mir, or village commune.

The Rev. Dr. Donald Sage Mackay preached on the subject of "The Perils of the Street" at the Collegiate Church. Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, yesterday. He took as his text, "The chariots shall rage in the streets; they shall jostle one against another in the broad ways; they shall seem like torches; they shall run like lightnings."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- Rabbi Joseph Krauskopf, D.D., of the Reform Congregation Keneseth Israel, one of the bestknown Jewish clergymen in the Eastern States, to-day delivered a sermon entitled "Secretary Hay and the Roumanian Jew," in which he criticised the note sent by the Secretary to the European powers on the question of the Roumanian Jews.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- With the exception of some possibly significant decorations for Portuguese and Japanese officials, the long list of honors in connection with King Edward's birthday is rather uninteresting. Some promotions in connection with the coronation ceremonies and the South African war, and because of services rendered to commerce and in Parliament, are announced.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9 -- More than 150 ballots that were cast for Joseph S. Hoff, the defeated Democratic candidate for Sheriff in Mercer County, may be thrown out on a recount which starts to-morrow because Princeton students who voted them marked their class numeral, "'05," on the margin of the ballots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Representative Cannon's candidacy for the Speakership is meeting with considerable opposition. The farmers and the agricultural press are against him because he is said to be favorable to the packing interests and opposed to the oleomargarine law passed last session.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The Daily News this morning asserts that Emperor William's visit to King Edward is concerned with the question of the evacuation of Shanghai and with an endeavor on the part of Germany to secure a quid pro quo for German quiescence while Great Britain completes her arrangements with Portugal with reference to Delagoa Bay.

A ten-months-old baby had a narrow escape from death yesterday afternoon as the result of a runaway accident at the corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Fifty-third Street. The baby, Charles Wylie of 198 West One Hundred and Fifty-first Street, was in a baby carriage propelled by his mother, who was also holding a five-year-old daughter, Wilhelmina, by the hand.

The pipe gallery in connection with the extension of the rapid transit subway, from Ann to Morris Street, is born of much tribulation. The time between May and September was unfortunately lost, and during this interval plans for the subway without pipe galleries were prepared, contracts for structural material placed, and other preparations made which must be changed if the gallery is to be built.

A rumor was current in New York and at Tuxedo yesterday that Mrs. Maud Lorillard Tailer, the ex-wife of T. Suffern Tailer, was to be married within a few days to the Hon. Cecil Baring. There was no definite announcement of this wedding plan, which is, it is said, to take place in London.

POMEROY, Ohio. Nov. 9 -- Harry Allemang, a ball player, who pitched in the Southern League this season and who had signed with Cincinnati for the coining year, was shot and mortally wounded at Mason, West Va., his home, early this morning.

Mn. BABCOCK of Wisconsin, sheading the annoying restrictions of the Chairmanship of the Congressional Committee of his party in a heated campaign, feels himself free to resume his advocacy of tariff revision.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The First Baptist Church of this city began to-day the celebration of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of its organization. The anniversary sermon was preached by the Rev. S.Z. Batten, the pastor. Special exercises of the Sunday school took place this afternoon, and to-night an address was delivered by H.C. Vedder of Crozer Theological Seminary.

Gen. Leonard Wood, "who, with Gen. Young and Gen. Corbin, represented the United States at the recent German military manoeuvres, returned yesterday on the American liner St. Louis. He was accompanied by Mrs. Wood, his two sons, and two daughters, and by the Misses M.L. and Elaine Pelayo, who are members of a prominent Cuban family.

-- A dispatch from St. Louis, after announcing the intention of that city to go into the electric light business to the extent of establishing plants of its own for the illumination of certain public buildings and an insane asylum, with truly charming ingenuousness adds: "The construction of the two plants will cost $45,000.

The expansion of co-operative trading in Great Britain is one of the most remarkable of modern instances of commercial development along lines created by changing social and economic conditions. The British trading societies are both wholesale and retail. The former are usually federations of the retail distributive societies, and buy for them in so large a way as to secure all the advantage to be derived from magnitude in transactions and unquestioned credit.

The rights of the non-union worker were defended and unscrupulous labor unions and unscrupulous capitalists condemned by the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, preaching yesterday morning in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, on the subject of capital and labor. "National Righteousness and Justice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Democrats are beginning to pay some attention to the question of who shall be the minority leader in the next House of Representatives. James D. Richardson of Tennessee is the present minority leader. He and Oscar W. Underwood of Alabama are the Democratic members of the Committee on Rules, and Mr. Underwood acted as "whip" for the minority during the last session.

SANDRINGHAM, England, Nov. 9 -- King Edward was sixty-one years old to-day, and in the course of the day his Majesty received a host of birthday congratulations and gifts. Emperor William, whose visit to England at this time is in connection with his uncle's birthday, gave a valuable vase to the King.

Grand Circuit trotters and pacers, hardened by the season's campaigning, were much in evidence on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning and played an important part in the many brushes that made up the day's sport. The fast steppers of C.K.G. Billings's string and the horses of E.E. Smathers's racing stable were especially conspicuous and successful in this their first appearance on the road this Fall.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Walter W. Ross of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, has outlined the plan of the Lackawanna Railroad Company for maintaining its own ferry service between points in New York City and Hoboken. The railroad company's deal with the Hoboken Ferry Company by which the Lackawanna's passengers are transported by the latter company's boats will expire next year and will not be renewed.

About 2,000 persons, mostly small boys, gathered at the foot of Houston Street, on the North River, yesterday to watch the unloading from the Atlantic Transport liner Minneapolis of the Barnum Bailey Menagerie. It was about 7 o'clock in the morning when the unloading of the animals was begun under the supervision of Superintendent Wyatt.

German Day was celebrated for the first time yesterday in Madison Square Garden, and the speakers said that, as the recent visit of Prince Henry had united the German societies, the project was not only feasible for the future, but sure to be a success. The celebration was begun at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and was continued until midnight.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The special correspondent of The Times who has been writing a series of articles on "The Middle Kastern Question." says, in a dispatch from Mohammerah, Persia, that recent developments in connection with the reorganization of the Persian Customs service by Belgian officials in the Karun district compel him to modify a previous statement.

WASHINGTON, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Dr. T.S. Dedrick, surgeon of the Peary arctic expedition, who left the other members of the party in the north because of certain alleged differences with Lieut. Peary, has issued a statement, giving his side of the case, which he says is the only authorized statement made by him since his return.

Two men were killed and one of the pumping stations of the city's water supply system on the Shore Road in Queens Borough totally destroyed by an explosion yesterday morning. One of the two big boilers which furnished the power for the pumps blew up. Windows were shattered in buildings half a mila away.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 9 -- President Roosevelt this evening asked for a conference in Washington with Henry B. Thompson. Chairman of the regular Republican State Committee, which has been resisting the attempts of John Edward Addicks, the gas magnate, to have himself elected a United States Senator.

The delegates at the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday in the large hall of the University Settlement Building were informed by the Trusiees that they may have a large hall in the near future, and that Robert Hunier, the head worker of the University Settlement, had said that some rich men connected with the Settlement are planning the erection of a building far labor meetings.

The Rev. Dr. George C. Lorrimer, in the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, last evening preached on the subject, "The Debt of the World to the Jew." He said that the persecution of the Jewish race had been one of the great crimes of the ages and that the survival of the Jew was nothing short of a miracle.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Miss Madeline G. Wallace, daughter of Mrs. Katherine Wallace of Montclair and the late John F. Wallace, proprietor of Wallace's Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street, New York, who took on Saturday the final vows as a member of the Sisters of St. Dominic, took the white veil this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The rooms of the Franklin Chess Club in this city were crowded yesterday afternoon and evening, when Champion Lasker gave a simultaneous exhibition against twenty-one of the strongest members, of the club. Lasker won fifteen games, lost one to Bampton, and drew with Livingstone, Newman, Voigt, Reid, and Robinson.

Less than three weeks now remain of the football season and the next three Saturdays will be made memorable by the three principal games of the year. Next Saturday Yale and Princeton will play at Princeton, on the followings Saturday Harvard and Yale will meet at New Haven, and on the Saturday after Thanksgiving the annual army and navy game between the West Point and the Annapolis cadets will be decided at Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Senator Dubois, who reached Washington to-day from Idaho, explains that the Republican victory in that State, by which that party elected a Representative and will secure a Senator to succeed Senator Heitfeld, is attributable mainly to the passage of the irrigation act at the last session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Roosevelt to-day delivered the hardest blow he has yet given to the movement to establish a White Republican Party in the South. He announced the removal from office of Julian H. Bingham, Collector of Internal Revenue of Alabama and the Republican National Committeeman from that State.

NEWPORT, Nov. 10. -- Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont made arrangements to-day to place in Trinity Church a window in memory of Mr. Belmont's mother, Mrs. August Belmont. The Belmonts have been identified with Trinity Church for many years.

The return to town is almost general. Fifth Avenue and the Park were crowded with equipages yesterday, and strangers are flocking to the hotels for the Horse Show. Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor will be in the city this week. Mr. and Mrs. Orme Wilson are to move up from Long Island, and Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills are coming down from Staatsburg.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Frank W. Higgins, who was elected Lieutenant Governor on the Republican ticket, spent $5,063.88 for election expenses. His certificate filed with the Secretary of State today shows that $5,000 went to the Republican State Committee, $48 for traveling expenses, and $15.88 for telephone,

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 10. -- President Rosevelt will attend the football game at Philadelphia between the Naval and Military Academies on Nov. 29. There is no doubt that he will be the guest of the navy during one-half of the game and of the army the other half, crossing the field during the intermission, as he did last year.

Apparently there is nothing either out of the way or out of the common in the visit of an Emperor to a King, a King newly "acceded," who happens also to be his uncle. Nevertheless, a considerable part of the European press, including a considerable part of the English press, seems to be seeking diligently for "motives" for the present visit of Kaiser WILHELM to King EDWAKD.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Henry F. Rogers, son-in-law of Mrs. Katherine J. Adams, who was the victim of the poison supposed to have been sent to Harry S. Cornish, is dead at his home in this city. He leaves a wife and one child.

EASTPORT, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The third annual field trials of the Pointer Club of America were concluded here to-day with the decision of the all-age stakes, which were won by Charles Coster's Fred C.W. P. Austin's Brimstone was second, and Teddy B. was third. The three dogs were almost evenly matched, but Fred C. was admirably handled, and won by the excellence of his points.

The late political campaign in this State was to an extent almost unprecedented a campaign of the town against the country, of the city against "up tne State." The city had rolled up a majority quite unheard of and unexpected, in such an election, against "up the State."

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- Addressing the members of the Economic Club of Boston at their banquet to-night, President Eliot of Harvard denounced the labor unions of the country as opposed to the education of young men, and for what he termed "their fight against the development of manly instincts."

Yesterday's Stock Exchange trading total was well toward a million and a half of shares. During much of the day demoralization was threatened. Not merely was there professional manipulative pressure, but manipulation played an important part in the day's market movement.

During the trial of a suit against William L.Marks, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, the defendant admitted on cross-examination that he obtained the asphalt contract for repaving Fifth Avenue for the Fruin-Bambriek Construction Company by means of influence used in the departments of the City Government.

As a result of extensive liquidation, prices in the outside market yesterday suffered heavy declines. At times during the day there was very little support given to any section of the market, and prices declined with an ease that was disheartening to those long of stocks. Eventually, however, buying orders became more numerous, and more or less substantial rallies occurred.

Roosevelt left Washington to-night to be absent nearly two weeks. He was accompanied by Secretary Cortelyou and his physician, Dr. George A. Lung of the navy. In addition a corps of servants and Secret Service officers were of the party.
The head of one of the largest Western railroad systems received yesterday morning the following dispatch from Chicago from one of the officials of the system there:

"Among Those Present." which Mrs. Le Moyne presented last night at the Garden Theatre, was prevailingly bright and sparkling by virtue of the witticisms with which Mr. Glen Macdonough has besprinkled the lines, and thrilled once or twice by virtue of interpolated bits of dramatic situation; but as far as could be judged from the prevailing lethargy in the first night audience, it is toppling on the edge of the abyss.

A continuation of the bear drive which broke prices so badly in Saturday's stock market, together with liquidation of an urgent character in the early trading, resulted yesterday in a further sharp decline in prices on the Stock Exchange, in the course of which many active and representative stocks lost from 2 to 6 points each, while an extreme break of 12 points was recorded in New York Air Brake.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- Pietro Mascagni, the Composer, who was arrested Saturday night on a mesne process in a suit brought by his ex-managers, Mittenthal Brothers of New Tork City, was released after a hearing in the Superior Court to-day on $4,000 bonds, which he furnished himself. Mascagni immediately retaliated by suing the Mittenthals for $50,000 for alleged false arrest.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- The Council of the University of Paris, says The Times's correspondent in the French capital, has accepted Robert Lebaudy's offer to endow scholarships for French students at American universities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The question of Cuban reciprocity will be given emphasis in the President's forthcoming message. He realizes that the enemies of reciprocity are prepared to make a desperate struggle to prevent the adoption of his recommendations in behalf of the people of Cuba, and that it is their hope that by delay and obstruction they may prevent action until the few weeks of the session shall have passed.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- Money conditions remain practically unchanged, but there is none the less manifest a slightly firmer tone in certain directions. Sterling exchange continues firm, but with posted rates unchanged. Clearing House rate, 4 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 5c premium. Call loans, 56.

WASHINTON, Nov. 10. -- J. Edward Addicks came to Washington to-day and paid a visit to Postmaster General Payne, the political manager of the Administration. The object of Mr. Addicks's visit was to point out to the Administration that he had proved himself the choice of the Republican rank and file in Delaware;

There has been some disposition manifested in speculative quarters to misinterpret and exaggerate the significance of recent announcements indicating a purpose on the part of the United States Steel Corporation through its constituent companies to readjust prices in certain important lines by timely reductions.

There was encouragement for at least two of the leading college football teams in the opening of the week's work yesterday, but the strain of the football campaign showed rather plainly in the condition of other college elevens. The fortunate two teams are those of Harvard and Yale, both of which came out of their games Saturday in surprisingly good shape.

The contrast between the little room in Fraunces's Tavern, in which, in the Spring of 1768, a score of merchants met to organize the Chamber of Commerce and the splendid home into which the Chamber moves to-day is but a feeble indication of the change that has come over the commercial community represented by the Chamber and the great industrial and trading people of which this community is but a modest part.
The annual report of the Union Pacific Railroad Company for the year ended June 30 last was made public yesterday, and was very favorably received.

ROME. Nov. 10. -- The arrest of Signor Mascagni at Boston has caused an unpleasant impression in Italy, and much indignant comment is heard. The papers ask if, in view of the personality of Mascagni, his arrest could not have been avoided, and inquire what would have been said in the United States if Mark Twain had been arrested in Rome for breaking the law through ignorance.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The Western Union Telegraph Company has only nineteen more days in which to comply with President Cassatt's notice to remove its poles and wires from the railroad's right of way by Nov. 30, but up to this time it has remained silent as to its plans. The order includes all the lines east of Pittsburg and Buffalo.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Money was in better demand to-day and the supply was abundant. Discounts were easy.
"Sure. I'm innocent. I'll beat the case easy enough, but it will be mighty expen esve."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Senator Mason has not given up hope of being elected to succeed himself by the Ilinois Legislature. A thorough campaign of the State made last Summer by Senator Mason. Represemative Hopkins, and Charles VV. Dawes. ex-Controller of the Currency, who resigned his position for the especial purpose of making a campaign for the Senatorship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Illinois Central and the Cincinnati, New Orleans and Texas Pacific Railroads, two lines named as defendants in the complaint of the Kentucky State Railroad Commission, charging merger of interests of all the roads in the Southern territory, to-day filed answers with the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

William Waldorf Astor has leased the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, a plot 67 by 150, now covered by a six-story store and apartment building, known as the Lenox, with an adJoining four-story structure on the street. It is reported that the entire plot may be reimproved, although no additional particulars regarding the transaction could be gathered yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- New York exchange to-day was at 10 cent premium, time and call loans 6 per cent.

Archbishop Ireland at a dinner of the Minnesota Society of New York in the Waldorf-Astoria last evening declared his belief that Canada eventually will be under the domain of the United States and that the flag of this country will wave over all the country from the Gulf of Mexico to Hudson Bay.

For more than six hours yesterday the jury which is hearing the trial of Roland B. Molineux for murder listened to the speeches in summing up of ex-Gov. Black and Assistant District Attorney Osborne. At a little past 6 o'clock last night Justice Lambert adjourned court until this morning.

The purchase of the contract held by J.E. Pepper on the services of the noted lightweight jockey Arthur Redfern for 1903 has been completed by S. Paget, acting as agent for William C. Whitney, and all arrangements have been made for Mr. Whitney's racing stable to have first call next year on Redfern, the most successful light weight of the past season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Fall meeting of the Washington Jockey Club on the Bennings race track opened to-day with splendid weather and a large crowd in attendance. Many improvements have been made on the track by the Washington Club since the last meeting. The course, for one thing, has been reconstructed, making it several seconds faster than heretofore.

An army retiring board is appointed to meet at Governors Island. Detail: Col. George H. Burton, Inspector General; Col. William E. Dougherty. Eighth Infantry: Col. Henry Lippincott Assistant Surgeon General: Col. Edward Hunter Judge Advocate: Major William H. Corbusier. Surgeon: First Lieut. John F. James, Eighth Infantry, Recorder.
ORSON H. BROWN, a banker and insurance agent, of Oswego, N. Y., died there yesterday, aged eighty-six years.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 10. -- In the Church of the Holy Communion here this afternoon Miss Marion Page Souther, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edwin Souther of Scotland Road, South Orange, was married to Thomas C. Watkins, also of South Orange. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lewis Cameron.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., Nov. 11. -- Foxhall Keene was arrested on the road this afternoon for speeding his automobile faster than the law allows.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Money is a trifle firmer to-day, and the Clearing House rate for many of the loans to-day was 5 per cent. Outside money was mostly quoted at 5 1/2 and 6 per cent. Sterling exchange remains quiet but firm. New York funds sold at 5 cents premium and par. Call loans, 5@6; time money, 5 1/2 @6; Clearing House exchanges, $27,356,294; balances, $1,971,799.

The ceremonies of the day that marked the opening of the new building of the Chamber of Commerce were brought to a close in the evening by a banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was notable for the presence of the President, who made an address of some length, and for the elaborateness of the decorations, the distinction of the company of guests, and for the extensive and costly menu.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- There was an appreciable decrease in the volume of local business to-day, sales aggregating 43,426 shares and $44,250 bonds, against 66,550 shares and $135,400 bonds yesterday. This lessened activity, however, was due almost wholly to the falling off in the dealings in Reading and United States Steel, which were as was the case Monday, leaders in to-day's operations.

NEWPORT, Nov. 11 -- E. Moore Robinson of Philadelphia has rented for next season the Ruthven Pratt cottage, Arleigh, which for two Summers has been occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Lehr. Mr. Robinson occupied the Warren villa on Narragansett Avenue the past Summer.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Members of the Cabinet and of the Reichstag, scientists, authors, journalists, financiers, and manufacturers, comprising as representative an assemblage as Berlin has seen in years, gave a dinner to-night at the Kalserhof in honor of former Ambassador Andrew D. White.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A large attendance gathered at the Bennings race track to-day, in spite of cloudy and threatening weather. The track remained good, however, and fast time was the rule, while fields larger than the average furnished excellent sport straight through the card.

The Stock Exchange had yesterday another million-share day; and again quotations were weak. Reasons for the declines were nowhere available -- current explanations (and there were many) bearing for the most part disproof upon their own face. Free and easy reports circulated as mediums of assault upon credit, it being represented by the busy rumor mongerers that "trouble" was impending in various quarters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Whether Mr. Babcock will be an active candidate for Speaker will depend upon the Wisconsin delegation. The ten gentlemen who were chosen by the Republicans at the recent election to represent that State will meet Saturday next at Milwaukee and consider whether they will present Mr. Babcock as a candidate.

After a morning of comparative steadlness, in which some issues advanced a point or more, the stock market yesterday afternoon became heavy, in sympathy with a five-point decline in Amalgamated Copper per to a new low record, and finally broke sharply in the concluding fifteen minutes of business, influenced thereto by a nine-point break in Northwest and a six-point drop in St. Paul.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Baer of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company has filed with the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission the reply of that company to the demands made by John Mitchell, President of the Mine Workers of America, concerning the points involved in the anthracite coal strike.

Fire again started about 7:30 o'clock last night at the Manhattan end of the new East River Bridge. Capt. Brogan of Engine Company 11. Acting Chief of the Fourth Battalion, with his engine and men, worked on the fire until 11 o'clock yesterday morning, and were the last to leave. At that time there was not the slightest sign of fire.

A leak in the gas main or meter in the basement of the seven-story tenement at 121 Avenue C, near Eighth Street, and a small fire of unknown origin in a pile of wood in the same room, caused a tremendous explosion soon after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The floor of the store on the ground floor was ripped up and the front was blown out with terrific force.

We have received from the Executive Committee of the Inter-State Commerce Law Convention a copy of the amended bill which that committee, with the cooperation of "important Eastern railway interests," has framed and submitted to the Senate Committee on InterState Commerce.

A decisive victory was won by the Tammany members of the Board of Aldermen yesterday over their Republican-Fusion brethren. While the fight for the control of the board was not marked by any bitter disputes, the Tammany members outgeneraled their opponents, and on the final vote changed a Fusion majority of 4 to a Tammany majority of 7.

Sprited contests and great enthusiasm were the features of the athletic games held by Company G of the Ninth Regiment at their armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street, last night. With ten events and over 230 entries the spectators were treated to several well-contested races.

RICHMOND, Ind., Nov. 11 -- Dr. J. Wilbur Chapman, formerly one of the best-known clergymen of New York, now at the head of the Presbyterian National evangelistic campaign for which $100,000 has been raised, is favorably mentioned for Chancellor of the National Technical School, to be located in Indiana.

The new building of the New York Chamber of Commerce, 63 Liberty Street, between Broadway and Nassau Street, was opened yesterday afternoon with simple ceremonies. With businesslike promptitude the exercises started with the entrance of Morris K. Jesup, the President of the Chamber, escorting the President of the United States, ex-President Cleveland, and the other distinguished guests following.

The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club held its fifth annual meeting last night in the club's city house, in the Mansfield, 12 West Forty-fourth Street. Minor changes were made in the by-laws, the chief change being that members of Class B, over thirty-years of age, hereafter shall be assessed $23 annually.
William A. White Sons and E.A. Cruikshank Co. have sold for the Colgate estate the four-story brick building 67 Fulton Street, 24.10 by 96.2 and irregular.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 -- The twenty-eight annual convention of the American Bankers' Association assembled in Tulane Hall to-day, beginning a three days' session. Fifteen hundred delegates had registered at headquarters to-night, in addition to nearly 500 visitors and ladies. President Herrick replied to the welcomes and delivered his annual address.

Justice has indeed moved with a leaden foot in setting free RONALD B. MOLINEUX, and while she was reaching her conclusion that he is innocent he has been made to suffer a penalty greater than the law inflicts upon those proved to be guilty of any save the gravest crimes. But it is plain that justice has done this wrong to MOLINEUX through the imperfections of her instruments.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Discounts were steadier to-day. Rates were strengthened by the fall in French exchange and less Continental inquiry for bills.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- The local chess expert, Walter Penn Shipley, was called upon to play a match with Champion Lasker at the Franklin Chess Club, in this city, a game which was to conclude the champion's engagement at the club. Shipley won the toss for the move, and elected to play the white pieces, opening with a Ruy Lopez, to which Lasker adopted the Berlin defense, 3. .Kt-KB3.

Moderate practice was the rule with most of the college football teams yesterday, as the coaches fear to risk overtraining the players, in view of the importance of Saturday's games. Defensive plays were practiced assiduously at both New Haven and Princeton, and some experiments were made with the line-up of both teams.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The President has appointed William M. Byrne, former United States District Attorney for Delaware, again to that position, Mr. Byrne having resigned to become the Union Republican candidate for Congress, with the result that both he and the regular Republican candidate were defeated and a Democrat elected.

The first official step to fix the responsibility for and establish the causes of the fireworks disaster in Madison Square on election night, which thus far has caused the death of fourteen persons and maimed and injured scores of others, was taken yesterday, when an inquest was begun before Coroner Scholer and a jury.

Mr. JOHN MITCHELL'S withdrawal as a candidate for the Presidency of the American Federation of Labor was undoubtedly discreet, for reasons already given in these columns, but it will greatly disappoint those in the membership of labor organizations who oppose the idea of autonomy in the unions of the various trades and who are desirous of seeing the disastrous experiment of the Knights of Labor repeated under a more aggressive leadership than that of POWDERLY.

Roland B. Molineux is free. The jury which had heard the evidence against him upon the charge of murdering Mrs. Katharine J. Adams reached a verdict of "Not guilty" upon the first ballot, and without discussion. It was Just thirteen minutes from the time Justice Lambert dismissed, the jury until information came to the court officers that a verdict had been rendered.

Col. John Y.F. Blake, the West Pointer who left this country eight years ago for the Transvaal, and who commanded the famous "Irish Brigade" through the Boer war, arrived here yesterday on the White Star liner Oceanic. He was accompanied by Commandant Malan of the Boer Army, and they will lecture here.

With but two days remaining before the championship football game between Yale and Princeton on Saturday, the practice of the two rival teams was practically concluded yesterday. At Yale the regular men practiced only a short secret half and five minutes open half, and were then all bundled back to town, while the subs played a hard half.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12. -- Benjamin F. Chadsey, a lawyer of Brooklyn N. Y., was arrested to-day on the charge of embezzlement. He was taken into custody just as he landed from a Panama steamer.
Application made to the Stock Exchange to list $6,500,000 additional Chicago Great Western common stock and $10,000,000 Michigan Central Railroad 3 1/2 per cent, first mortgage bonds of 1952.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- New York exchange was quoted at par to-day; time and call loans, 6 per cent. Erratic activity was manifested on the Chicago Exchange. As usual, Swift's was the specialty. The low level reached to-day was 122 1/2, a drop of over 12 points from yesterday's figures, and of over 50 points since the heyday of the packing combination gossip.

Roland B. Molineux spent a quiet day yesterday at the home of his father, 117 Fort Greene Place, Brooklyn. Only intimate friends of the family were admitted to the house, and there were few of these. Two policemen were on guard in the block to protect the home from intruders. Gen. Molineux in the evening gave out the following statement:

The explanation given by Secretary SHAW of his order instructing the customs officials at the ports to which coal was brought to construe the law so liberally as to disregard its specific provisions is more creditable to his sympathies than to his sense of official duty. In a special dispatch to the Evening Post Mr. SHAW is quoted as saying that:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Henry W. Diederich, United States Consul at Bremen, in a report to the State Department dated Oct. 18, gives the estimates for the sugar crop of 1902-3, as issued by Mr. Gieseker, the noted Belgian statistican, and Otto Licht of Magdeburg, a veteran publisher of Sugar statistics.
In his latest Delaware appointment the President has made an illogical application of a bad principle, not in a way to correct its badness, but in a way to aggravate its badness.

The police last night, after a chase, captured Thomas Jenkins, a negro, of 423 East Ninety-seventh Street, whom they charge with having committed numerous highway robberies, in which women were the victims, in Madison and Fifth Avenues. Mrs. Addie F. Stewart of 724 Lexington Avenue was robbed last night.

The Civil Service Commission yesterday held a long session, which ended about 7 o'clock in the evening. President Willis L. Ogden and Commissioners Vanderbilt, Mason, and Spencer were present. One of the most important matters considered was the problem of what to do with 1,200 applicants for places as patrolmen who tried to pass the civil service ordeal at the last examination.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12 -- The attitude of the American Bankers' Association toward the currency question was fixed to-day. No decisive stand was taken on the questions of assets, currency, or branch banking, it being considered unwise to act until a solution of the question shall have been evolved; but provision was made for the appointment of a committee to consider carefully the entire subject and to report at the next meeting.

Negotiations involving the old Hotel Brunswick site took such form yesterday as to justify an announcement on the part of the promoters of the enterprise, and this announcement is that a twenty-story hotel will be erected on the property, and that work upon it will be begun on May 1. 1903.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Money was in moderate demand to-day, and the supplies were fairly plentiful. Discounts were firm on the weakness of foreign exchanges and tenders for Treasury bills.

Members of the Nineteenth Century Club to the number of nearly two hundred gathered last evening in the rooms of the Aldine Club, Eighteenth Street and Fifth Avenue, to listen to a discussion of the relation of the public to the coal strike. President Walter S. Logan presided and introduced John R. Dos Passes as the first speaker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A conference bearing on the subject of the Cuban reciprocity treaty was held at the War Department to-day, those taking part in it being Secretary Hay, Secretary Root, and Gen. Tasker Bliss. The last-named was called into the conference at Secretary Hay's suggestion because of his expert knowledge of the existing Cuban tariff.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- At St. John's Episcopal Church at noon to-day President Palmer Chamberlaine Ricketts of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, was married to Miss Vora C. Renshaw of Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The announcement that the President had decided to recognize the Union Republicans in Delaware caused more talk among politicians around town to-day than anything that has occurred of late. The common belief is that the purpose is to give the "regular" members of the Legislature a chance to change their minds if they desire and vote for the election of Addicks to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The panic spread among the Southern Republicans by the President's warfare upon the "white party" movement is growing, and it is reported from Alabama that the Federal officials down there are confidently expecting to have to follow District Attorney Vaughan and Internal Revenue Collector Bingham out of office.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Edward W. and Clarence H. Clark of Philadelphia have subscribed $100,000 to found a Professorship of Assyriology at the University of Pennsylvania. The Messrs. Clark have been among the largest subscribers to the Babylonian expeditions of the university for the past fourteen years, and the success of these expeditions -- now known all over the world -- has led them to endow this professorship.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Weakness in the local market became more pronounced in this morning's trading than at any time since the downward movement in stocks began, and was attributable largely to selling by interests who could not or did not care to respond to the call for margins which had been made upon them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- George E. Roberts, the Director of the Mint, has completed his report on the production of the precious metals for the calendar year 1901. The final figures for the world's output by countries are as follows:

Twelve hundred thousand shares changed hands on the Stock Exchange yesterday. There was no new feature of consequence. A rally, due chiefly to the covering of short contracts, marked the opening and closing hour of the day's business; but during most of the session professional speculators were showing their power to keep quotations in check.

Senator Platt was shown a published statement last night in which it was set forth that, while Gov. Odell had declared that he knew of no opposition to the re-election of Senator Platt, except such as emanated from a few newspapers, he refused to say that he himself was personally in favor of the re-election of the Senator.
Army. Second Lieut. Malcolm P. Andruss is assigned to the Seventh Company, Coast Artillery.

The holdings of the Peter Harmony estate at 63 and 65 Broadway, according to a report current yesterday, have been sold. These two buildings cover a frontage of 79.8 feet on the west side of Broadway, 78 feet south of Rector Street, and extend through to Trinity Place, with a depth of 215 feet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Justice to all" has ever been the aim of the Cloth Spongers' Union, and it has been a surprise to the members of this organization to learn that a movement is on foot, whose sources are unknown to us, but which has evidently the purpose of discrediting the good work done by the organization.

Sixteen events made up the programme of the sixth indoor athletic games of the First Regiment Athletic Association of Newark, N.J., which were decided last night. The contests took place in the armory of the First Regiment, National Guard of New Jersey, Sussex Avenue and Jay Street, Newark, and the big structure was filled with a very representative assemblage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Catholic University of America was held to-day at the university. The finances were reported to be in a most satisfactory condition. During the year the receipts amounted to $158,917 and the disbursements to $155,268.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Track records were reduced at the Bennings race course to-day in sweeping style, new marks being hung up for four of the six events. In the race for the Dixie Stakes, one mile and three-quarters for three-year-olds, Adelaide Prince, favorite at even money, was an easy winner, and reduced the old record for the distance 11 4-5 seconds, by running in 3:06 3-5.

There were many weddings yesterday. Arriving steamships, especially the Oceanic and the Kronprinz Wilhelm, brought many well-known people who have been away a greater part of the Summer. Quite a number of the younger element are at Idle Hour, the country seat of William K. Vanderbilt, where a large house party is being given by the host in honor of his nephew's fiancee, Miss Cathleen Neilson.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- There was a pressure directed against the Seaboard group to-day which weakened those issues enough to have a decidedly adverse effect on the whole list. The selling was due to the closing out of several moderately large accounts, which the owners preferred to liquidate rather than put up additional support.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Call loans at the Clearing House were again all at 5 per cent, and outside money ruled from 5 to 6 per cent. Sterling exchange continues firm, but posted rates are unchanged. New York funds sold at 5c premium; call loans, 5@6 per cent.; time money, 5 1/2 @6 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $28,166,116; balances, $2,317,996.

Another hearing was had before Special Examiner Frederick G. Ingersoll yesterday in the Post Office Building in the proceedings instituted by the United States to test the legality of the merger which created the Northern Securities Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- In addition to the reply of President Baer of the Reading Company to President Mitchell's statement for the miners, others have been filed by the Delaware and Hudson Company, the Delaware and Lackawanna, the Lehigh Valley, the Pennsylvania, and the Scranton Company.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The old fight of the Eastern standard roads against the diffenential lines is being thrashed out once more by the Central Passenger Association, and unless existing troubles are adjusted there is a probability of a conflict both on rates and time between Chicago and New York.

It is pleasant to learn from the speech delivered by the Chairman of the "German Day" meeting in Madison Square Garden that organization of the various German-American societies of the country into one harmoniously working band is not for the purpose of segregating our citizens of German origin or descent from their fellow-citizens in the United States, but to provide opportunities for closer friendship and more intimate intercourse with those other Americans.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 12 -- President Roosevelt is speeding down through Kentucky to-night on his way to Smedes, Miss., about twenty-five miles north of Vicksburg, for a four days' bear hunt.

C. Oliver Iselin, the yachtsman, identified with the racing management of boats that defended the America's Cup in several international races, and who will be the managing owner of the new sloop planned to defend the cup from Sir Thomas Lipton's latest challenger, arrived in New York yesterday on the White Star Line steamship Oceanic, accompanied by his wife and daughters, after having been abroad for about four months.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 12 -- The legislative body of the Jobbers' Association has completed and signed an agreement that will protect the window glass trade for the present season.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The silversmiths employed by Tiffany Co. of New York at the Forest Hill shops and the leather workers who struck in sympathy profess to be confident of success. It is said offers of employment are coming to them from New York, and are being accepted wherever the conditions for which the strikers are striving prevail.

Mayor Low received yesterday the representatives of foreign Governments who came to New York to attend the dedication ceremonies of the new Chamber of Commerce. The delegation was headed by Prince Henry of Pless, and the following were also present:

Among the Princes, potentates, sovereigns, and Chief Executives of all the nations of the earth there are but two who could have made the speech to which the members and guests of the Chamber of Commerce listened as the first address of the evening at the annual dinner of the Chamber.

Hugh McLaughlin last night expressed admiration for and confidence in Mr. Hill, commended James Shevlin and Senator P. H. McCarren warmly, and roundly denounced the "carping critics" who, he said, were unsuccessfully attempting to create discord in the Democratic ranks in New York City and in the State.

The efforts of certain railway representatives to effect an agreement with J.C. Osgood, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, have failed, and the war for control is on again. Only this time the faction opposing the present management is headed by Edwin Hawley, George J. Gould, and E.H. Harriman.

Corporation Counsel Rives has been asked by Fire Commissioner Sturgis for an opinion relative to the powers of the latter in determaining the quality of the sheathing of inclosures and partitions used by contractors where excavations make apertures in buildings necessary. Fire Marshal Freel in a letter to Commissioner Sturgis contends that the sheathing used by the subway contractors under THE NEW YORK TIMES Building was highly dangerous.

Richard Butler died yesterday after a prolonged illness in the Hotel Renaissance, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street. He was born on Aug. 9, 1831, in Birmingham, Ohio. He came to this city in 1846 and entered the importing house of A.W. Spies Co., and five years later he became a partner in the firm of William H. Cary Co., and continued in the Business until its dissolution in 1879.

A man is responsible for the devotion of women to household drudgery, Miss Thomas, President of Bryn Mawr College, told the members of the Emma Willard Association yesterday at their twelfth annual banquet at Sherry's. Only two or three men were present when Miss Thomas spoke, and a long line of Presidents and Deans, sitting at the President's table and representing every other woman's college in the country, listened with smiles of satisfaction.

In the city of Cleveland, Ohio, of which Mr. TOM L. JOHNSON is Mayor, there is a Director of Charities, Mr. HARRISON R. COOLEY by name, who is of an inquiring and sociological turn of mind. He has been examining into the condition of the workingwomen of Cleveland, and declares that he is "grievously surprised " at the result.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 13. -- It is understood that the Southern Railway will buy the Tennessee Northern Road and build through the Bowel Valley into Middleborough, Ky., where a connection will be made with the Harland and Middleborough Road. The plan is to penetrate every available coal point in the Kentucky and Tennessee Mountains, tapping the vast tracts which are being rapidly bought up by northern capitalists.
BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The Reichstag to-day adopted by 192 to 71 votes the paragraph of the Tariff bill authorizing the Government to retaliate on any country discriminating against German goods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A banquet was given at the Arlington Hotel to-night in honor of the representatives of foreign commercial bodies who came over to America to attend the dedication of the New York Chamber of Commerce Building, and who arrived in "Washington from the metropolis for a short visit to-day.
