PARIS, Nov. 23. -- The investigation into the circumstances of Mrs. Gore's death has made no progress during the last forty-eight hours, and will probably remain at a standstill until Tuesday, the day fixed by the investigating Magistrate for the examination of witnesses and the formality of the "reconstruction of the scene," which will take place in the room in which the tragedy occurred and in the presence of de Rydzewski.

Col. W. G. Rice of Albany, United States Civil Service Commissioner under the last Cleveland Administration, was at the Holland House yesterday, and in reply to an inquiry as to conditions up the State, said:

It is an incident of some significance that at the Union League in Philadelphia on Saturday evening, after the President had made a flattering review of the Administration of the Republicans in power for the period since the election of Mr. McKINLEY, Senator LODGE should take up the question of the duty of the party with reference to the tariff.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The annual report of Secretary of the Interior Hitchcock has been submitted to the President. The duties and responsibilities of the Interior Department are more multifarious than those of any other department of the Government, and the Secretary's report is, therefore, unavoidably bulky.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- "The Land of Unbounded Possibilities" is the title of a series of articles on conditions in the United States prepared by Ludwig Max Goldberger of Berlin, Royal Privy Councilor of Commerce and member of the Imperial German Consultative Board for Commercial Measures, to be republished by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- The first assumption that Herr Krupp, the gunmaker, whose death was recorded yesterday, committed suicide is yielding to precise and abundant testimony to the contrary. Prof. Binswanger, a physician of the first reputation, was in the apartment adjoining Herr Krupp's sleeping room when Herr Krupp was stricken yesterday morning, and Dr. Pahl.
LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The Servian outlook continues to attract considerable attention in Vienna, says The Times's correspondent there.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 24 -- The Department of Customs has notified the Canadian Wheelmen's Association that they will be held responsible for the duty on wheels coming into Canada under the American Association's guarantee. Customs allow wheelmen to cross the line on producing their association badges.

The saying is as old as SHAKESPEARE, and probably much older, which sets forth that "Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown." But SHAKESPEARE could not have foreseen how much the hard fate of hereditary monarchs would be aggravated by the twentieth century, especially of monarchs who retained in an irreverent and inquiring age the pretensions and the illusions of the monarchs he knew about.

HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- As the result of conflicts between the police and the men on strike here to-day, two strikers are dead and eighty-two other persons are wounded. Five of the latter, one being a Lieutenant of Police, whose throat was cut by a striker, have injuries of a serious nature. Eight other policemen are wounded.

The season of opera was opened last evening in the Metropolitan Opera House with all the brilliancy that has ever attended such an occasion. The house presented the most festal appearance, and the spirit that prevailed on both sides of the footlights was one that rejoiced the hearts of all lovers of the lyric drama in its highest estate.

The State Railroad Commissioners, after a hearing at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, granted the application of the Pennsylvania, New York and Long Island Railroad Company to construct a tunnel railroad in this city to connect the Pennsylvania, and the Long Island Railroad.

The reading public will be startled by the statement in the report of the Secretary of the Interior that during the year the Pension Bureau received information of the death of 50,128 old soldiers, of whom only 27,043 were on the pension roll.

The Low-Sturgis-Croker situation was not cleared yesterday by any statement from the Mayor or the Fire Commissioner. Commissioner Sturgis said that he could not say when he would render his decision in the Croker case, and would not give an inkling of what it might be.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Speeches which were delivered yesterday by the Earl of Dudley, (the new Lord Lieutenant of Ireland) and by John E. Redmond, the Irish leader, have aroused much comment, as striking a more hopeful note of conciliation in regard to the Irish question.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- For the first time on any stage, Clyde Fitch's new play, "The Bird in the Cage," was presented at the Boston Museum to-night. An immense audience was present. From the German of von Wildenbruch Fitch has constructed a butterfly play in his cleverest vein. The story deals with the young beauty, Rosalie, who, engaged to one she does not love, finally, of course, weds the real object of her affections.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 24 -- Surrogate Petty to-day admitted to probate the will of Jesse Carll of Northport. The estate, which is valued at $200,000, is bequeathed to the family of the testator, except $250 to the Methodist Church and a like sum to the Presbyterian Church.

Organized labor seems to be afflicted with the madness which precedes and presages destruction. At the meeting of the American Federation in New Orleans the committee of the Executive Council submitted a report denouncing what has been designated as "government by injunction," tempered by the following qualification: "We recognize the authority of the courts to issue injunctions to prevent the destruction of property and violations of law."

Stocks fluctuating materially yesterday were influenced by special factors. The general market showed no pronounced tendency so much as to stay passive. More noteworthy than anything else was the failure of the bear contingent to knock down prices as they started in to do at the close of business on Saturday.

Three armory records were broken last night in the semi-annual athletic games of the Twenty-second Regiment, held in the armory building, at Broadway and Sixty-eighth Street. They were done in the two-mile bicycle race, the 220-yard dash for novices, and the three-legged potato race.

Vice Chancellor Stevenson at Jersey City yesterday somewhat modified the restraining order made at Paterson last week in regard to the proposed merging of the Prudential Insurance Company and the Fidelity Trust Company of Newark.

Mrs. Annie Mayers, sixty years old and prosperous looking, of 329 East Thirty-second Street, was sent to the Workhouse for six months by Magistrate Crane, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, as a vagrant. She admitted sending begging letters for the last twenty years to persons of wealth and prominence.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Money was in brisk demand to-day. Discounts were firm.

Declaring that he agreed to pay her $300 a month on condition that she would not sue him for breach of promise, Mrs. Julia Langer, otherwise known as Julia Reel, instituted an action in the City Court against Warren B. Smith, a wealthy carpet manufacturer of this city and Yonkers, member of the Metropolitan Club and other social organizations, yachtsman, traveler, and turfman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The newspaper criticisms of the Administration's recognition of the Addicks faction in Delaware to-day provoked the following statement from the White House:

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 24 -- The latest reports about Philipp, the mesmerist, who is said to have had the Czar completely under his influence, are that he was formerly a French physician, and that he is a naturalized American. He has been in Russia for about a year, living in the homes of two Montenegrin Princesses who married Russians.

At a meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New York, at 17 West Forty-third Street, last evening, the retiring President and the newly elected President delivered addresses. Christian Science was pilloried, and the organization of the American Army was criticised. The desire was expressed for reorganization or abolishment of the Coroners' office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The arrangements by which the deep-sea soundings and surveys made by the Nero, under the direction of the Navy Department, are to be turned over to the Commercial Cable Company for use in laying the Pacific cable beyond the Hawaiian Islands were completed to-day.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Gov. Odell to-day held a conference with Major Thomas W. Symons of Buffalo and Abel E. Blackmer, counsel for the New York Produce Exchange, regarding a proposition which will be submitted to the Legislature in connection with the construction of a one-thousand-ton barge canal at a cost of $80,000,000.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 24 -- The Ministerial Alliance of Salt Lake to-day adopted resolutions strongly opposing the proposed election to the United States Senate of Reed Smoot, one of the twelve apostles of the Mormon Church. A copy of the resolutions will be sent to every ministerial alliance of prominence in the country at once, and also probably to President Roosevelt, every Congressman, and United States Senator, and others prominent in political life.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest in the Sunday edition of THE TIMES the short article on "Odd Corners," describing the English colony at and about Abington Square. I am afraid I shall have to dissent with the writer, though, as to the presence there of "half-and-half."

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- At the Women's Institute this evening Frederick R. Burton made public some of his discoveries made recently in the music of the North American Indians. He is an Ojibway Indian by adoption, the tribe having made him a member as an appreciation of his work in putting their songs into notes and harmonizing them.

CARACAS, Nov. 24 -- Gen. Velutini, the representative of President Castro in the eastern provinces, will leave to-morrow for Barcelona and Ciudad Bolivar with 2,500 men to inaugurate a campaign against the revolutionists. In an interview to-day Gen. Velutini said:
S. Steingut and Froelich Rosenblatt have sold the southeast corner of Irving Place and Sixteenth Street, 43.3 by 80, for the Oppman estate to Isaac Kleinfeld.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Out of a total of 40,426 shares dealt in on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to-day, no less than 27.538 shares were Reading common. The trading element was active in the stock, and took the cue from the movement in New York. There was little feature in the dealings outside of this issue.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- After a lengthy debate the House of Commons last night passed a resolution approving the action of the British Government in signing the Brussels sugar convention by 213 votes to 136.

It was a hospitable idea of Director Conried's to throw open his house yesterday afternoon and give a taste of his quality to actors and actresses from Broadway; but the experiment was scarcely calculated to show off his company at its best.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The War Department is in constant receipt of data concerning the canteen question and no effect of its abolition upon the army. Anropos, the statement is made at the War Department that only such information as has been contained in the reports of army officers upon the subject has been given to the public, and it is denied that any effort has been made to influence public opinion on the matter.

The "Old Glory" sale of light harness horses, the greatest offering of its kind, was opened yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden before an attendance representing the trotting turf of the entire world. Buyers from European countries were present in person, while South America and Australia were represented by agents commissioned to secure good American racing blood.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Crowds besieged the County Courtroom to-day at the beginning of the trial of Mrs. Eliza Heath of Mamaroneck on the charge of criminal libel that had been preferred by Miss Anna L. Lynch. Mrs. Heath, wife of Thomas Heath, is the editor of the Mamaroneck Democrat and a member of the Citizens' League.

Dullness was the principal characteristic of the outside market yesterday. In Northern Securities and one or two other stocks trading showed some little animation, but by far the larger part of the list was extremely inactive. So few changes of any size were recorded that the results of the day's trading so far as prices were concerned were of little consequence.

Interest in Thursday's football games mainly centres in the Cornell-Pennsylvania game at Philadelphia, though local collegians are interested in Columbia's contest with Syracuse in this city. Cornell's football team took their last hard practice yesterday, and to-day the Cornell party, consisting of at least twenty-five players, besides managers and coaches, will leave for Philadelphia.

Mayor Low announced the appointment yesterday of three engineers to make a report on the sources of water supply for Greater New York in accordance with the request of Commissioner Monroe of the Water Supply Department. The committee consists of Prof. William H. Burr of Columbia University, Rudolph Gerring of 70 Broadway, Manhattan, and John H. Freeman of Providence, R. I.

Those are strange stories which are telegraphed to us from Kentucky about the homicide of one FITZGERALD by one young HUNTER at the capital of Guatemala. The stories are to the effect that the friends of young HUNTER in Kentucky have assurances from "the United States Government" that young HUNTER "will be returned to Kentucky in safety."

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The Gore case has assumed an international aspect by the action of Consul General Gowdy in following out the instructions of the State Department at Washington and appointing a commission, composed of four American doctors residing in Paris, to conduct an independent post-mortem examination.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Representative Cooper of Wisconsin is inclined to adopt the Iowa idea in regard to the reduction of tariff duties, and believes a few of the schedules might be revised and the rates reduced without producing the widespread injury to the business of the country that is predicted by those who are against anything being done.

Policemen dashing from every station house in the Borough of Manhattan yesterday afternoon attracted the attention and aroused the curiosity of passers-by. Many of the peace guardians were buttoning their coats as they ran for trolley cars, the motormen of which they instructed to make no stops to pick up new passengers.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times says that the Viedomosti publishes a long article on Afghanistan which seems to reproduce the views held in competent Russian quarters.

An "Alice in Wonderland" story served Mayor Low as an illustration of the velocity of New York in his welcoming address to the Phi Delta Theta college fraternity, which met in its twenty-seventh biennial convention yesterday at the Hotel Majestic. The Mayor thought it best, he said, while telling the visitors about the metropolis, to inform them how fast it was, and he did it in this way:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers of America, accompanied by his counsel, C.S. Darrow and H.D. Lloyd, arrived here from Washington at 10 o'clock to-night. The three gentlemen will leave for Scranton tomorrow morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 25. -- The juniors won from the seniors in a sharp football match at Yale Field this afternoon by the score of 6 to 0. The game was the first in a series of interclass football games instituted to bring out promising 'Varsity material for next year. Line up:

An action brought in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, by Augusta M.C. Higgins against her mother, Augusta M.C. Young, as executrix of the will of Gilbert G. Young, for the purpose of setting aside Mr. Young's will, came on for trial yesterday afternoon before Justice Rich and a jury.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Senator Frye of Maine does not sympathize with the agitation in favor of tariff revision. Speaking of this question to-day, he said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Trustees of the Carnegie Institute met in the New Willard Hotel to-day in annual session with Dr. Billings, Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees, in the chair. The principal business of the forenoon session consisted of the reading and discussion of the report of the Executive Committee appointed at the meeting held last January.

There were meetings yesterday of the Executive Committee of the Manhattan Railway and of the Directors of the Inter-Borough Rapid Transit Company, the former being held at the offices of the company. 145 Broadway, and the latter at the office of August Belmont. For a time it was believed that some statement might be made regarding the reported Manhattan-Inter-Borough deal.

Members of the Hudson County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, whose home is at Grand and Warren Streets. Jersey City, were indulging in expressions of sorrow yesterday over the death of two pet monkeys of the marmoset species, whose homes were originally in South America.

Prompted to action by the clamor on the part of various medical bodies for the abolition of their office, as well as by the repeated attacks by District Attorney Jerome, the Coroners are preparing a statement, in which they purpose to show the public by facts and figures that a Coroner is a very necessary factor in the administration of justice in a civilized community.

It looks as if the name of "educational Governor," which was originally given to Gov. MONTAGUE of Virginia and Gov. AYCOCK of Georgia, would soon cease to be a distinction in the South. The title at first indicated that the bearer of it was exceptionally interested in promoting the extension of free common schools, especially in the rural districts of his State.

-- That correspondent of ours who said that during a residence of five years in England he never heard a native mention such a drink as "half-and-half" or found one who knew what it meant, was somewhat hasty in deducing from these facts the conclusion that the term is a "Britishism" which exists, nowadays, at least, only in the imagination of others than Britons.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- Argument was heard by Judge Platt in the County Court to-day on the demurrer to the indictment charging John Carroll Lathrop, a Christian Science "healer." and John and Georgianna Quimby with manslaughter in the second degree in connection with the death of seven-year-old Esther Quimby, who died from diphtheria without having had proper medical care.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 25. -- Col. Thomas P. Ochiltree died here at 1 o'clock today of heart trouble. He had been in a sinking condition since yesterday morning, and it was a surprise to his physician, Dr. F.W. Chapin, as well as to others that he lived until to-day. He was conscious this morning, but soon grew worse and died.

The opinions of Congressmen are often interesting, sometimes important. Representative MINOR of Wisconsin, a Republican member of the House Committee on Merchant Marine, expresses the opinion that no ship subsidy bill will be passed at the coming session of Congress.
DENVER Col., Nov. 25. -- The following dispatch was received here to-day from John C. Osgood, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company:
In the tournament of the Plumbing and Steam Supply Bowling League last night the manufacturers' team scored 916, which is a new high team score for the tournament. The scores follow:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The gentlemen who have been laboring under the impression that the President was wailing to hear from them before closing his message will be relieved to learn that that important State paper is complete, and that the President to-night has in his possession printed proofs of the entire document.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- John W. Yerkes, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, in his report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1902, says that by the two acts abolishing the war revenue taxes internal revenue taxes have been reduced about $100,000,000.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- The story was current about the Capitol to-day that Gov. Odell had determined to appoint Col. Dickey of Newburg State Railroad Commissioner in place of Col. Ashley W. Cole, whose term has expired but who is still serving as a member of the board.

These are busy days with the knights of the "jimmy" and dark lantern in Brooklyn. From all parts of the borough during the past few weeks there have come daily reports of the operations of members of the housebreaking craft, and in most cases the cracksmen have gotten well and clear away with their loot.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 25. -- The Democratic Executive Committee met here today and ordered a primary election for the election of all State candidates, to be held May 9, 1903. The calling of a primary is an innovation with the party in this State, conventions having been held heretofore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- There will be an effort this session to renew discussion of the oleomargarine law, but it is probable it will come to nothing. The manufacturers of renovated butter are complaining bitterly of the effect of the Oleomargarine bill on their business. They say it has practically annihilated it.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have been a constant worker as a machinist in New York for nearly fifty years. I have never belonged to any union, but have worked and mingled freely with union men, criticising and often opposing their methods, yet I have never noticed any unfriendly act or feeling on the part of any labor unions or workman.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Weakness, general and pronounced, was developed in the local market to-day, under the lead of Reading, of which stock New York was a persistent seller. Lehigh Valley slumped sharply, opening 5/8 below its last sale yesterday, and then losing another half point, final sales being at 33 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Cabinet today gave considerable attention to the status of the canal treaty with Colombia. The hitches that have occurred in the negotiations were discussed, as also were the prospects of settlement.

In the opinion of the Republican State machine a miss is as good as a mile. Some Governors would have been sobered, conceivably a machine might have been put upon its good behavior, by a drop of 100,000 in the party plurality. Gov. ODELL and the Republican organization, however, believing that for all practical purposes of spoils and patronage a plurality of 10,000 is sufficient, have resolved to go their impenitent way.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 25. -- By a decision handed down in the Supreme Court to-day, the Indiana school fund will profit $685,424 at the expense of the Vandalia Railroad. The judgment against the road is for $913,905, but of this 25 per cent. goes to attorneys who have handled the State's case.

In announcing the suspension of the local ordinances designed to suppress the smoke nuisance at the time when only soft coal was available, his Honor Mayor Low made a mistake which might have entailed, and perhaps will yet entail, serious embarrassment to the administration. Perhaps he was under the mistake of supposing that the law which he decided should not be enforced for a time, was one prohibiting the burning of soft coal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Senator Allison, who has been a member of the Finance Committee for more than a score of years, and who participated actively in the making of all tariff acts placed on the statute books since 1880, does not view the proposition to create a commission for the revision of the tariff with favor.

Four very wet and at the same time very dry policemen were huddled together last night in such shelter as they could find in the doorway of 160 West Forty-fourth Street. The house had been designated by Capt. Schmittberger as one in which gambling is the chief occupation, and they were besieging it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- New York exchange to-day was 35c discount; time and call loans, 6 per cent. There was little interest in local stocks. Box Board preferred was traded in to some extent, with little demand to meet offerings and a consequent show of weakness. Swift's made fractional declines on light trading.

The belief asserted itself in Wall Street yesterday that George J. Gould and John C. Osgood had joined forces in the struggle for the control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company. This belief was strengthened when it became known that Mr. Osgood and Mr. Gould had had a conference during the day.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The Socialist organ Vorwaerts, in a page and a half to-day, deals with what it calls the "hypocrisy of idealizing Herr Krupp as a benevolent genius." The paper does not touch on the immediate charges which it brought against the deceased, but analyzes the pension system of the Krupp firm, which, it says, is a "species of refined swindling," adding:

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- Money was in active demand to-day for the payment of $15,000,000 in Treasury bills, the settlement, and month-end requirements. Discounts hardened, in view of probable large exports of gold.

At a meeting of the coal road Presidents and independent operators, held in this city yesterday, the suggestion that the operators should meet Mr. Mitchell and other representatives of the United Mine Workers on Friday was rejected, thereby putting an end to all prospects for an adjustment of the trouble except through the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission.

It took the jury only little more than half an hour to decide last night that Mrs. Julia Langer, otherwise known as Julia Reel or Julia Seymour, was entitled to $600 from Warren B. Smith, the wealthy manufacturer, whom she sued on the ground that he failed to carry out a contract to pay her $300 a month provided she would not bring an action against him for breach of promise.

The Cornell football squad of twenty-five men left Ithaca last night for Philadelphia, where to-morrow it will line up against Pennsylvania in the last game of the season. Fully 1,500 undergraduates turned out to see the eleven off, and every member of the team was cheered by name and given an encouraging Cornell yell.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S explanation of the reappointment of Mr. BYRNE as United States District Attorney for Delaware must be accepted as disproving any intention to "recognize" ADDICKS." He would have been reappointed," says the President, "without regard to the circumstances under which he ran, or the faction with which he was allied."

Another of the delights of the musical season brought from Boston for the delectation of New York was imparted to a large audience last evening in Mendelssohn Hall, when the Kneisel Quartet began its eleventh season. Its hold upon the hearts of chamber music lovers here is stronger than ever and becomes stronger year by year -- there is abundant evidence of it in each succeeding season.
Crum Foster of this city have been appointed general agents of the Peter Cooper Fire Insurance Company for the entire United States.
SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 25. -- President John Mitchell of the United Mine Workers is to write a book. He announced this to a company of personal friends in this city Sunday evening.

The members of the Professional Woman's League are in a state of agitation over the collapse of the scheme that was to provide them with a clubhouse and fill their treasury to overflowing. They had depended on the Woman's Exhibition, which was held in the Madison Square Garden for two weeks prior to Oct. 18, to accomplish those purposes, and had been working for months to make the exhibition a success.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- In consequence of the voluntary act of loyalty on the part of the people of Tutuila in ceding to the United States the sovereign rights of that and other islands, President Roosevelt has sent them a message of greeting, and, in addition, has presented each Chief who signed the instrument with a silver watch and chain and a silver medal.

Frank J. Farrell, whose name has been mentioned often in connection with New York gambling institutions, and who is known as a friend of ex-Chief of Police Devery, testified on the witness stand in the Supreme Court yesterday that he had never been inside a poolroom and did not know what such a place was like.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The controversy between Mr. Gage when Secretary of the Treasury and the Russian Minister of Finance, which occurred about two years ago in regard to the importation of sugar from Russia, has been the means of prejudicing the Russians against American importations and has resulted in retaliatory measures on the part of the Russian Government which seriously handicap American trade with that country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The interview with Borough President Cantor, published this morning in New York, on his return from the West, in which Mr. Cantor declared that a Presidential boom for Judge Alton B. Parker existed in many Western States, is the first public announcement of a state of things which is well known here.

On the application of Dos Passos Brothers, as counsel for John F. Plummer, papers of attachment were issued yesterday by Justice Fitzgerald in a suit for $1,000,000 brought against the International Power Company and Joseph H. Hoadley. Mr. Plummer asserts that Sir. Hoadley promised him $1,000,000 on condition that he would engage a banker to finance the International Power interests when they were organizing the American Locomotive Company.
ST. ETIENNE, Nov. 26 -- The committee of the Coal Miners' Federation of the Loire held a meeting to-day and resolved in favor of the resumption of work at all the mines in the district on Friday.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 26 -- The application of the Western Union Telegraph Company for an injunction to restrain the Pennsylvania Railroad Company from compelling the plaintiff company to remove its poles and wires from the right of way of the Pennsylvania Railway Company by reason of the alleged expiration of the contract between the companies came up for argument in the United States Circuit Court before Judge Buffington to-day.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 26 -- Quite in contrast with the happy faces of the independent operators' committee when it returned from New York last night were the countenances of the miners' representatives when they returned to-day from their disappointing trip to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Roosevelt received to-day the members of the British Labor Commission, who are making a tour of the United States as the guests of Alfred Mosely, the British philanthropist.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 26 -- Capt. A. Lincoln Ford of Sound Beach, Conn., rescued two Brooklyn seamen to-day from what seemed certain death on Barge No. 3 of the Export Lumber Company just before it was wrecked. The barge, which had been anchored off Norwalk Harbor, broke away from its moorings in the storm last night and drifted out into the Sound with its two occupants, William and John Geary.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The continued decline in the price of silver causes considerable comment in financial circles. According to the best-informed houses it is regarded as being directly due to China flooding the market with silver in payment of the indemnity to the powers.

Cornell won the championship of the Inter-Collegiate Cross Country Association of Amateur Athletes of America at the meet held at the Morris Park race track yesterday afternoon for the third time since the event was instituted. Yale was second, Pennsylvania third, Harvard fourth, and Columbia fifth.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The Shamrock III. will be launched at the end of March or early in April. She will be much more ready for sea than was the Shamrock II. when the latter was launched.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Freight rates in the territory east of Chicago and St. Louis will not be advanced to such high figures as were generally expected. The average advance in the rates as finally agreed upon at the meeting of the general traffic officials of the Central Freight Association Lines in Chicago to-day, will not exceed 10 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The fourth annual international exhibition of the Philadelphia Dog Show Association began to-day in Horticultural Hall. The entries are numerous and the judges were kept busy all day making the awards. In addition to the association's prizes, there are many special trophies offered by foreign kennel clubs, among them being the New South Wales Kennel Club Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Prospects for a clear afternoon drew a good-sized crowd to witness to-day's races at Bennings. Although the track was in a very sloppy condition, players of form did better than for some time, four favorites and two second choices capturing first money. The only upset of the day was the fifth event.

HAZLETON, Penn., Nov. 26 -- Coxe Brothers Co. and their striking employes settled their differences to-day and work will be resumed at the seven collieries of the company on Monday. All the men except those under indictment for misdemeanors alleged to have been committed during the strike and the slate pickers, whom improved machinery has displaced, are to be taken back at once.

DOVER, Del., Nov. 26 -- Gov. Hunn has issued a proclamation calling for a special election for a member of the Legislature in District No. 9 of Kent County, the election of Nov. 4 having resulted in a tie.

BALDWINS, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Arthur E. Wilson, the detective accused by Mrs. Adele R. Lederer, wife of George W. Lederer, the theatrical manager, of having entered her apartments at Baldwins on the morning of Oct. 23 and refusing to leave, and with acting in an improper manner, had a hearing to-day before Justice W.H.F. Jay.

Lawrence Murphy, ex-Treasurer of the Journeymen Stone Cutters' Union of New York, against whom a warrant had been issued early in September on the charge of grand larceny of $10,000 of the funds of the union, was arrested last night at a meeting of the union. The meeting was held in Brevoort Hall, Fifty-fourth Street, near Third Avenue, and was largely attended.

The only surprise about the vote of the British House of Commons, ratifying the action of the Government in signing the Brussels Sugar Convention, is that the majority was not larger. It was in fact very substantial, the vote being 213 to 136. But the case was so clear that even the spirit of faction and the desire to discredit the Government at every opportunity would not account for so large a minority.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary Shaw telegraphed a summary dismissal from the customs service of W.H. Theobald. Special Agent at the New York Custom House, late this afternoon. No explanation of the charges on which this action was based was given by the Secretary beyond the remark that "it was for the good of the service."

Society is passing Thanksgiving in a royal fashion. Never have there been so many large house parties or so many dinners given to celebrate what may be called the National festival. Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, who have a Thanksgiving dinner to-day, will not have Sir Michael and Lady Herbert with them, as they will give a dinner in Washington.

The much-talked-of deal by which the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was to secure control of the Manhattan Railway Company finally received official confirmation yesterday. According to this statement the Interborough Rapid Transit Company will lease the Manhattan on a basis of a seven per cent. dividend guarantee of the latter company's stock by the former.

The second night of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House was devoted to a performance of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" that was a delight to lovers of the old comedy. Public interest in it did not seem to be in the highest, and there was a certain void in those parts of the house, small this season, that are not occupied by subscribers.
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase of 63 and 65 Broadway by the American Express Company.

-- We rarely publish a letter more provocative of wonder than was the one from "A Veteran Workman," printed yesterday. The writer described himself as a machinist who had worked in New York for fifty years. For all that time he has remained a non-union man, but constantly in association with unionists.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- There was little disposition to trade in this market today, the sales amounting to only 25,460 shares, of which 14,341 shares were Reading common. Prices generally were heavy, but reactions did not extend to a point except in J.B. Stetson warrants and Philadelphia Electric 4s.

Before an audience which completely filled the auditorium of the Educational Alliance Building the Rev. Dr. Emil G. Hirsch, rabbi of the Sinai Congregation in Chicago and Professor of Rabbinical Literature at the Chicago University, last night delivered an address, the topic of which was "The New York East Side Problem."

A number of more or less substantial advances were recorded in the outside market yesterday, but reactions occurred in most cases, so that the net results of the day's trading furnished little ground for satisfaction. Interborough Rapid Transit advanced to 121 and closed at the best price of the day as a result of the official announcement of the Manhattan lease, but the movement in this stock was exceptional.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 26 -- A valuable find of iron ore has just been made on the Mesaba Range, three miles from the Hawkins mine, owned by the International Harvester Company. The first drill put down struck ore, and is now down eighty-seven feet and still in ore, indicating an extensive deposit.

Thanksgiving celebrations will be numerous to-day, and few indeed, even of the very poor, need be disappointed in a big dinner as the chief feature of the holiday, for the high prices of the delicacies of the season have not prevented preparations for great charity feasts. Special church services, too, will be held throughout the city.

The lease of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company affords a most remarkable proof of the fallibility of human judgment -- even of the judgment of great capitalists. The underground rapid transit project had no more determined foe, was nowhere opposed by any influence more powerful, than the Manhattan Company.

An arrival on the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, in yeslerday from Bremen and Cherbourg, was Eugene Fischof, one of the best known racing men of the French turf. Mr. Fischof was accompanied by his two young sons, who will enter St. Paul's School, Concord, N.H. Mr. Fischof will remain in the country about three months, and may make arrangements to race several of his horses in this country next year.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- In one of the most exciting meetings in its history the Trades Assembly to-night declared off the boycott against the Schenectady Railway Company. The vote in favor of rescinding was three to one, and the meeting lasted nearly three hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- George E. Roberts, the Director of the mint, in his annual report says that the coinage mints at Philadelphia, New Orleans, and San Francisco were in operation throughout the fiscal year. In number of pieces the coinage of the year has never been exceeded, aggregating 191,419,506, but in value it has fallen from $136,340,781 to $94,526,678, this being due to the greater demand for the small denominations.

HAVANA, Nov. 26 -- With the exception of the cigarmakers, all classes of laborers returned to work this morning and business generally has resumed its normal condition. The cigarmakers still have a few minor points under discussion.

Many of the close friends of Mrs. Emita W. May and Isidor Lewi were surprised to learn last evening that the couple had been married at noon in the home of the Rev. Dr. Gustav Gottheil, at 861 Madison Avenue. Mrs. May was the widow of Lewis May, who died on July 22, 1897, having been known for a quarter of a century as one of the leading financiers of New York.

The failure of the effort to settle the issues of the anthracite contention "out of court" is not at all surprising, considering the method taken to bring it about. The records show that the suggestion of a conference for purposes of agreement began with the representatives of the miners.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- A wedding ceremony here this evening was postponed for a while because the bride-groom had been arrested. Miss Mabel Beekman, daughter of William Beekman of 67 South Street, was the bride, and Charles Munson, a young man from Yonkers, was the bridegroom.

BRISTOL, R.I., Nov. 26 -- About one hundred tons of lead were poured into a mold in the Herreshoff boat shops to-day to form the keel of the New America's Cup defender. As far as the mechanical work was concerned the casting was successful, but the actual state of the keel will not be known until Saturday, when the mold is torn to pieces.
To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading in your valued paper the sermon of the Rev. Dr. Silverman on "Zionism," I would ask of you to grant me permission to write a few words in answer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The President and a gathering of his friends were astonished while at dinner in the White House a few nights ago by most phenomenal conduct on the part of the electric lights, which was for a time unaccountable. From the full brilliancy of the well-lighted room, while jest and laughter were affording relish to the dinner, the company were suddenly plunged in the midnight darkness of primeval chaos.

Washington dispatches indicate that the Secretary of War will make no recommendation, in his forthcoming report, concerning the army canteen as a feature of the army post exchange, but that he will content himself with transmitting to Congress the reports of officers commanding troops, and will leave the responsibility to the legislative body.

Although there is no one great football game scheduled for to-day which will attract such widespread interest as the annual contests between Yale and Princeton, which used to be such a feature of the celebration of Thanksgiving Day in this city, yet, as the list of games in another column shows, there will be several matches of importance decided.

TRENTON, Nov. 26 -- The charitable and penal systems of New Jersey are severely criticised in the annual report of the State Charities Aid Association, as prepared by General Secretary William H. Alien, and which is now in the hands of Gov. Murphy. One of the most urgent needs of the State, the report says, is a reformatory for girls more than sixteen years old, and for women.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Mrs. Roosevelt to-day issued cards for her first afternoon "at home" Friday, Nov. 28, from 4 until 6 o'clock. So speedily has work on the house progressed under the urging of the President, that there will be no trouble in taking care of the guests comfortably.

Postmaster Van Cott yesterday received directions to reinstate Mrs. James McIntosh, a clerk in the money order division who was recently ordered dropped from the Government pay rolls because she had married. Mrs. McIntosh was Miss Irne Isabelle MacArthur and is said to be a niece of Gen. MacArthur.

A valuable overcoat, in the pockets of which were two bonds valued at $1,000 each, was stolen from the billiard room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. The coat and bonds were the property of John D. Underhill, the real estate dealer of Thirty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue, who lives at the Hotel Navarre.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The demand for money was active to-day and rates were easier. Discounts were firm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Senator Hale was among those who talked with the President to-day. Mr. Hale thinks there will be very little general legislation at the coming session. "The great appropriation bills," said he, "which now approximate an aggregate of nearly a billion dollars, will occupy most of the time of Congress.

After reading an elaborate set of affidavits. Justice Bischoff of the Supreme Court refused yesterday to grant a writ of mandamus against Commissioner Partridge on the application of Frank Goodrich, doorman of the Twelfth Precinct Station, who claimed that his salary of $1,000 was not in proportion to his arduous duties, and that the Commissioner ought to be made to employ an assistant doorman.
COPENHAGEN, Nov. 26 -- Dr. Sven Anders Hedin, the Swedish traveler, has been invited by several American universities to lecture before them on his explorations.

ESSEN, Prussia, Nov. 26 -- The presence of Emperor William at the burial of Herr Krupp to-day was designed by his Majesty to show his absolute disbelief in the accusations that caused the gun manufacturer's death.

With the exception of the trading in Manhattan, announcement of whose lease by the Interborough Company was not made until a half hour before the close of business, yesterday's stock market was made up almost wholly of operations by the professionals. Inasmuch as these professionals are bearish almost to a man, it is not in the least surprising that prices at the close of the day generally showed declines.
BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- Three additional cruisers, the Niobe, Ariadne, and Amazona, have been ordered to leave Kiel and proceed to Venezuela.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- Emperor William, at a farewell audience given to Ambassador White to-day, presented to him the Gold Medal of the Empire for Science and Art, which is given once a year to the person, either German or foreigner, who, in the opinion of the Government, is best entitled to it.

Lawrence Murphy, ex-Treasurer of the New York Journeymen Stone Cutters' Association, who was arrested on a charge of embezzlement at a meeting of the union in Brevoort Hall on Wednesday, after an absence of over two months, was arraigned before Magistrate Crane in the Yorkville Court yesterday morning.

Straus -- Abraham. The wedding of Percy S. Straus, son of Isldor Straus of New York, and Miss Edith Abraham, youngest daughter of Abraham Abraham of Brooklyn, was celebrated at noon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The myrtle room, which had its walls covered with smilax, and an improvised altar embowered in greens, with a canopy of white chrysanthemums and leaves, was the scene of the ceremony.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 27 -- The British steamship Brinkburn, Capt. Edmunds, New Orleans, Oct. 30, for Manchester, has arrived here, bringing the crew of the American three-masted schooner Lucy A. Daevis. Capt. McKown, from Brunswick, Oct. 28, for Boston, which sprung a leak and was abandoned in a waterlogged condition off Cape Hatteras on Nov. 11.

Though stray grouse will continue to be bagged till Dec. 10, and though sportsmen here and there stay on for a few days' pheasant and partridge shooting during November, the Scottish shooting season may be said to close with October. Indeed, the greater number of the lessees usually leave the north before the middle of the month, deer-stalking generally finishing about the 10th.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Money was in strong demand to-day and discounts were firmer.

DERBY, Conn., Nov. 27. -- After four months' constant search complete mystery surrounds the case of George F. Long, sixteen years old, son of Henry A. Long of this city, who dropped from sight July 6 last, 300 feet from his father's door. Two legacies of $10,000 each await the boy, but in spite of wide publicity even these have failed to bring him to light.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 -- In a furious southwest gale on Lake Erie Sunday night the steamboat Sylvanus J. Macy sprung a leak off Port Burwell, Ontario, and plunged to the bottom, probably carrying her entire crew with her.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The Government recently submitted to the Council of State the action of the greater part of the French Episcopate in signing last month a manifesto for presentation to the Senate and Chamber of Deputies, in which the Law of Associations was discussed at length, and which urged a return to the principles of the Concordat as the only means of securing religious peace in France.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 27. -- There was a unique Thanksgiving service here to-day when Rabbi Isaacs and his congregation at the invitation of the Rev. Dr. Charles D. Shaw celebrated the day with the congregation of the Second Presbyterian Church. Dr. Shaw and Rabbi Isaacs delivered addresses.

HAVANA, Nov. 27 -- Two of the men who were wounded last evening while on a street car by shots fired from neighboring houses, died to-day. No disturbances have occurred since yesterday. The Mayor has ordered the police to arrest all the occupants of the houses from which the shots may have been fired at the street cars yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- In the police station this evening the night platoon was addressed by Chief Foley on neglect of duty. Several days ago Patrolman Gleitsman was convicted of being asleep on post, and the sentence was a fine of sixty days' pay and a public reprimand. The Chief delivered the reprimand after the night patrol had lined up for inspection.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The President has sent the following communication to a prominent citizen of Charleston, S.C.:
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Times announces that Lord Reay has been elected the first President of the British Academy.

-- Attention is called in the Law Department of The Medical Critic to the fact that Mrs. EDDY'S recent order forbidding the practitioners of "Christian Science" to treat contagious diseases until the existing hostility to those who let children die of neglect has subsided is only the last of several proofs that when "Mother" is confronted with a choice between consistency and safety she has always chosen the latter.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 27. -- Michigan's victory over Minnesota at Ann Arbor to-day, 23 to 6, gives the University of Michigan team undisputed and deserved title to the Western football championship. Michigan had been scored against only once when the Case School made six points early in the season, while Minnesota had been beaten once, when Nebraska won 6 to 0.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- The great purchase of land at the East Boston flats last Spring by the New Haven Railroad was a part of the plan to so increase the freight facilities of the railroad that the New Haven could handle the great traffic which in the future will be diverted from Jersey City to Boston for export by reason of the new traffic agreement with the Pennsylvania system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The project of a commercial commisison to China and the East, in the furtherance of which Senator McCumber has conversed with the President, and to promote which he has a bill before a committee of the Senate, is not a new one.

May Lewrazzo, a sixteen-year-old Italian girl of 46 Oak Street, according to the police, was shot and instantly killed by her sweetheart, Leo Michelli, thirty-five years old, of 31 Monroe Street, last night, because she refused his attentions, although the girl's parents say Michelli paid for her passage from Palermo, Sicily, to this country.

Chief Flynn of the United States Secret Service, in the Federal Building, announced yesterday the capture by himself and Agent Murphy at Niagara Falls on Wednesday of Andrio Romano, the last of the Frauto band of counterfeiters at liberty. The band, numbering a score, according to Chief Flynn, has worked more mischief in this city than any other bands in the same line of criminality for many years.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Nearly 500 American citizens and a sprinkling of distinguished English men and women participated in the annual Thanksgiving dinner held at the Hotel Cecil last night under the auspices of the American Society in London.

The Rev. Dr. Mottet, rector of the Church of the Holy Communion, in his Thanksgiving sermon yesterday morning, preached on the theme, "The Nation and the Citizen," and, in drawing the lesson of the meaning of the material prosperity of the Nation as the imposition by God of a great trust upon the Nation and the individual citizen, he said in part:

It was announced yesterday that J.G. Phelps Stokes, son of Anson Phelps Stokes of this city, had finaly removed his belongings from his father's large house at 229 Madison Avenue to the University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, and there permanently taken up his abode, with the intention of devoting his life to the settlement work.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Henry Trothead, assistant foreman of the Edison General Electric Works at Harrison, owes his life to Annie Gebhardt, a girl employed under him. She was busy at her bench when she heard a scream and saw Trothead writhing in agony. An electric current was passing through his body.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 -- The attendance at the opening of the Crescent City Jockey Club's Winter meeting broke all local records. The track was good and the card far above the average of a Winter meeting, despite the fact that the principal event, the Inaugural Handicap, went to W.J. Deboe an outsider, who was 30 to 1 in the betting.

MEDIA, Penn., Nov. 27 -- Mrs. William H. Culley this morning received two letters from her daughter, Mrs. Felix Maldonado, who was supposed to have been lost by the recent eruption of Santa Maria volcano, Guatemala.

Those who are disposed to regret that the miners and the operators did not succeed in patching up a peace of some sort which would end the investigation undertaken by the Anthracite Strike Commission, would do well to bear in mind the fact stated by President ROOSEVELT in his discussion of the subject, that there are three parties to this controversy -- the operators, the miners, and the public.

Thanksgiving, like Christmas, is more of a family than a society festival. It was celebrated with much eclat throughout the country, especially at country houses, where, falling in the middle of the week, it gave an excuse for house parties of several days. Although some of the fashionables will come up to-day for the opera, the majority will remain away from town until Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Carlisle Indians vanquished Georgetown here to-day by the score of 21 to 0. For the first half of the contest the playing was all in Georgetown's favor. The conditions were exactly reversed in the second half when Carlisle had her own way completely, with almost exclusive possession of the ball, and outplayed Georgetown at every point of the same, scoring four touch-downs and kicking one goal.

When the folks living in the neighborhood of Atkins and Belmont Avenues, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, got stirring about yesterday morning and saw that there was not even a single piece of "wash" hanging on the clothes lines in the back yard of the Gandley cottage, on Atkins Avenue, they winked at each other knowingly and observed:

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- The order of the Secretary of Agriculture placing an embargo on the shipment of cattle from the port of Boston, and declaring in quarantine cattle and swine from Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut, gives assistance to the Massachusetts Cattle Commission in its efforts to stamp out the epidemic of foot and mouth disease in this State.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The University of Pennsylvania football eleven to-day defeated the Cornell team by the score of 12 to 11. The Ithacans kicked a goal from placement and scored a touchdown from which a goal resulted in the first half, while Pennsylvania scored two touchdowns and kicked two goals in the second half.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Secretary of Agriculture Wilson to-day issued a sweeping order, directed to the managers and agents of railroad and transportation companies of the United States, stockmen and others, notifying them of the establishment of a quarantine of cattle, sheep, and other ruminants and swine in the New England States, and prohibiting the exportation of such animals from the port of Boston until further orders.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Chancellor von Bulow's concession to the Agrarian majority in regard to the minimum duties on barley, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times, is not only inconsistent with his previous declarations, but cannot be reconciled with the assurances advanced by the Government in the memorandum which accompanied the Tariff bill.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- In the early morning hours yesterday Robert Pack, a fireman on the Lackawanna Railroad, suddenly disappeared from his engine between Avoca and Wallace stations. It was very dark at the time, and Engineer Donovan does not know how long his assistant had been gone before he was missed.

Edward F. Croker, Chief of Department, will to-day be dismissed by Fire Commissioner Thomas Sturgis as guilty of some of the seven charges and fifteen specifications on which he was tried between Sept. 29 and Nov. 4.
Alexander Bremer, President of the Musical Mutual Protective Union, made public yesterday a letter, sent by him to President Roosevelt, in which he said:

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- A Thanksgiving ball was given to-night by the American Colony of this city and was largely attended. President Diaz being among the invited guests. The affair was a great social success, many representatives of the highest society of Mexico being present.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 27 -- The State Board of Agriculture will meet on Saturday to take action on the cattle disease. An appropriation of $5,000 will be asked from the Legislature, which meets next week, and a quarantine against Massachusetts cattle, similar to the quarantine of that State against Rhode Island, is proposed.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- A large holiday crowd was in attendance to-day at the second day's exhibition of the fourth annual International Dog Show, at Horticultural Hall. Among the winners of first prizes were the following:

Followers of football who attended yesterday's games were rewarded by seeing some of the most evenly contested and most interesting matches of the season. Tie games were payed between Columbia and Syracuse in this city; by the Universities of Virginia and North Carolina in Richmond; by Ohio State University and the University of Indiana at Columbus, and by the Charleston Associated players and the Furman College team at Charleston.

A couple of weeks since, Lord GEORGE HAMILTON'S announcement that "in a few months they would see a very material improvement in the condition of Ireland," was received with derision in the Liberal press of London, and with ridicule by some of the most active Irish Members of Parliament.

It didn't make so very much difference whether the sun shone over Greater New York or not yesterday, for the people with one accord carried a bit of sunshine around in their hearts. If in all the great city there was a man or woman or child who went to bed last night with an aching heart the wound must have been very deep indeed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The order recently issued by the Postmaster General against continuing in the public service women clerks who marry has been supplemented by an order issued by Mr. Machen, General Superintendent of the rural free delivery system. That order requires every woman employed in the division to send in a written statement setting forth whether she is married or single, the name of her husband, if she has one, and his occupation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Interesting developments are promised in connection with alleged frauds on the part of cattlemen who have for some time been grazing their herds on the public lands of the West.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 27 -- The following letter has been received by The Age-Herald from Booker T. Washington:
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- "The day of the professional burglar is past. His successor, the 'yegman,' has killed him off and buried him. This revolution in crime is due to the use of nitro-glycerine."

ROME, Nov. 27 -- Hundreds of Stars and Stripes hanging from the houses of Americans announced Thanksgiving Day to the people here. A special service was held in the American Church, the Rev. Dr. MacCracken of New York officiating.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The sixth annual horse show of the Orange Riding and Driving Club opened to-night, with every box occupied and a brilliant society turnout from the Oranges, New York, Morristown, and other places in the vicinity. In point of excellence of the horses which have entered the various competitions, the large number of boxholders, and special features this show excels all previous ones held in Orange.

The suggestion is made that the Republic of Colombia will upon one pretext or another decline to come to a treaty agreement with us in respect to the Panama Canal until the year 1904, when she may declare the concession forfeited and put up the right to build a canal through her territory for sale to the highest bidder.

Walter J. Travis, Findlay Douglas, and Charles B. Macdonald, all former golf champions of the United States, gave a National championship tone yesterday to the open tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club. The competition will continue to-day and to-morrow. The event yesterday was an 18-hole medal play round, and three sets of16 qualified for three cups.
MANILA, Nov. 27 -- The constabulary are carrying out an aggressive campaign against the ladrones and fanatics in the northern part of the Island of Leyte, and in the Island of Biliran.

We have heard much, of late of the wrong suffered by strikers who find their places filled by others when it suits them to return to work, and no grievance is deeper or less forgivable than that which the union workman who has been on strike has against the man who has "taken his job."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- William J. Youngs of Oyster Bay is to be appointed United States District Attorney for the Eastern District of New York. He will receive the appointment when the term of George H. Pettit, the present incumbent, expires, which will be on Dec. 20. There is nothing against the record of Mr. Pettit, who has held the office for four years.

IN the December number or Harper's Magazine, quoting a sentence attributed to Mr. Kipling, Mr. Booth Tarking ton rejects its implication that certain Americans pronounced "review" to rhyme with "too," and says that "no adult American without physical impediment or speech" has ever pronounced "review" "revoo."

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Though the pressure was lessened, money was in active demand to-day for month-end requirements. Its scarcity has compelled borrowings from the Bank of England of $17,500,000 during the week, with the prospect of an increase in the demand. Discounts were slightly easier.
Edward F. Croker, Chief of Department, was yesterday dismissed the Fire Department by Commissioner Thomas Sturgis, the dismissal to take effect next Monday.

THE Macmillan Company announce for publication this week "Sun Dials and Roses of Yesterday: Garden Delights Which Are Here Displayed in Very Truth and Are Moreover Regarded as Emblems," by Alice Morse Earle; "Furniture of the Olden Time," illustrated by numerous half-tones of quaint and valuable pieces, by Frances C. Morse; "Sir Edward Burne-Jones," by Malcolm Bell:

William Morris Colles, one of the foremost of the English literary agents, who has been making a brief visit in New York, sailed for Liverpool on the Majestic last Wednesday. Before sailing he said he had found the views expressed to him by a large number of American publishers, authors, and reviewers of the present literary situation in this country most interesting.

The prospectus of The Booklover's Magazine does not go very far into the future, as the nature of much of the material of this periodical depends on current events. The January number, however, offers an estimate of Charles Dickens by Andrew Lang, together with an article entitled "Contemporary French Fiction."

In his "Study of Prose Fiction," just published by Houghton, Mifflin Co., a book which is analytical, synthetical, but not primarily historical, Bliss Perry, editor of The Atlantic Monthly, chooses his examples as far as possible from fiction which has become standard and can be judged, as it were, in perspective.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The wish expressed in your REVIEW of Nov. 15 that a new American edition of Mrs. Ritchie's stories might be published will find an echo in the hearts of all who are familiar with them. While most of her novels and sketches are to be found in the Tauchnitz volumes, comparatively few of them have, I think, been published in this country.

William Landau of Buffalo, whose arrest on Thursday afternoon was followed up with a statement by the police that he had swindled the banking firm of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. out of $200,000, or more, was arraigned before Magistrate Deuel in the Tombs Police Court late yesterday afternoon and held under $1,000 bail for examination on Dec. 8.

-- That the architects have succeeded in solving the problem of making buildings in which it is hardly possible for a fire to spread beyond a single floor or room has been demonstrated many times of late, and it now behooves them to attack the almost equally important problem of confining smoke as well as fire within narrow spaces.

ASSOCIATIONS with the Temple are innumerable. Wherever English is spoken traditions of the Temple survive, for within its precincts have lived great statesmen, politicians, makers of romance, dramatists, historians, lawyers, "whose names are household words."

The northeast winds during the past few days affected the waters of the Sound so that the tide rose from six to eight feet above the normal and flooded the easterly shore of City Island. For the past two days residents whose houses are on Main and Bridge Streets have been obliged to go about in rowboats, and several hotels and business houses have been damaged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Whether there will be legislation in the coming session of Congress in regard to Chinese exclusion from the Philippine Archipelago or not cannot be told at this time. There is a strong sentiment in favor of admitting the Chinese. Wherever they have gone prosperity has followed in agriculture and commerce.

In spite of the fact that historical novels ought to be condemned for the amount of damage they do to historical accuracy, still now and then one comes across a historical novel which is so delightful that he would fain blink over the bristling historical inconsistencies. Mary Raymond Shipman Andrews has constructed a fabrication using poor Napoleon as a cornerstone.

Florence Burns, the Brooklyn girl who last Winter gained much notoriety through her alleged connection with the murder of Walter Brooks, was married on Wednesday night to Charles W. Wildrick. The bridegroom is the son of Lieut. Col. Abram C. Wildrick, United States Army, whose memory is honored by a monument at West Point, and a grandson of Isaac Wildrick, a contemporary of Henry Clay in Congress.

As soon as news was telephoned from Fire Headquarters to the Mayor's office that the order dismissing Chief Croker had been issued, Secretary James B. Reynolds, for mayor Low, made this commentary public:
LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph Parker, minister of the City Temple, who had been seriously ill for some time, died at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

THE autobiographer, even if his life has been commonplace, may, nevertheless, recall some interesting events of the past, but when such an eccentric person as is George Francis Train tells of his experiences many strange happenings will be presented.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Increased interest and greater enthusiasm marked the second night of the horse show which the Orange Riding and Driving Club is holding this week. In all 104 horses had judgment passed upon them to-night. The evening opened with a competition for a cup offered by F.S. Flower, in which six pairs of carriage horses were judged.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- C.B. Houston of Chester, Penn., proprietor of extensive mining operations at Elkhorn, West Vas died to day at a hospital here. He was seventy years old. While at Elkhorr Mr. Houston was struck by a small locomotive and seriously injured. Wednesday, the injured man was brought here and are operation was performed.

President August Belmont of the Rapid Transit Subway Company replied last evening to the letter of Controller Grout in reference to purchases of real estate for the subway. The correspondence was started by President Belmont because of alleged statements of Controller Grout, before the Rapid Transit Commissioners, that he knew the subway company was purchasing real estate for speculative purposes along the line of the route.

BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The stormy scenes of yesterday were renewed in the Reichstag to-day, and at one point in the proceedings the uproar reached such a pitch that Vice President Buesing, who was in the chair, had to resort to a suspension of the sitting, a measure without precedent in the House.

The fancy, illustrated calendars published this season by the Frederick A. Stokes Company include the usual classes of humor, art, and usefulness, but greater care than formerly has evidently been employed in the selection of the artists, and, in turn, by the artists themselves in the selection of their subjects.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28. -- The market today was brought to an almost complete halt by the loan calling at the instance of some of the banks and trust companies. Since the accounts called were mostly of purchases in Wall Street the consequent selling fell in that market instead of this one.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The President has denied thirty-two applications for pardon, has restored five applicants who have served out their terms of imprisonment to citizenship, and has acted favorably upon six other cases.

ROBERT LOUIS STEVENSON'S inimitable book of leisurely saunterings in pleasant places, "An Inland Voyage." is published in a new edition, convenient in shape to fit a pocket of reasonable size, and not too handsome and expensive to carry about and dip into at odd moments.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Though there is no fear that China will fail to meet her engagements, says the Peking correspondent of The Times, considerable uneasiness has been caused by the continuous fall in exchange since the signature of the settlement protocol. The value of the tael was then fixed at 3s.

MANY a heart is doomed to disappointment in the reading of Alfred Ollivant's new dog story "Danny," for with the reputation of "Bob, Son of Battle," to live up to he has fallen far short of his own record, a well-high fatal thing for an author to do.

There are so many books by well-known critics on famous collections of paintings which run either to a technical analysis of the artist's art or to the popular extreme of presenting bare fragmentary biographical notes that it is a matter of satisfaction to handle a work which achieves a middle course.

The new "variorum and definitive" edition of the writing of Edward FitzGeraid, which Messrs. Doubleday, Page Co. publish here, comprises seven volumes. George Bentham is the editor, and he contributes personal and literary notes, and a bibilography. There is a preface by Edmund Gosse.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The market here to-day was absolutely featureless. Trading was almost at a standstill, and prices were in about the same condition. There was further good buying of Lehigh Valley, and Reading was also well taken, but with these exceptions trading was limited largely to the room trading element.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The Gorky boom is a feature of the season. There are half a dozen London publishers who are issuing translations of Gorky's books. In more than one instance two publishers have published the same Gorky book, each with a title differing from the title of the other.

The right of dogs to enjoy life in New York apartments was fully vindicated in the City Hall yesterday before the Aldermanic Committee on City Ordinances. To say that the dog had his day would be putting the fact mildly. The defenders of New York house dogs appeared in hundreds, and beat down all opposition.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- It is learned that important steps were taken in London yesterday with a view to satisfying all the financial and diplomatic claims by foreign powers and bondholders against Venezuela. It is maintained that if the contemplated action meets with approval Germany and Great Britain will have no cause to take the vigorous steps now contemplated.

The animus of the attack of Vorwarts, Herr BEBEL'S Socialist organ, upon the character and work of FREIDRICH ALFRED KRUPP, and which is supposed to have so shocked him as to cause his sudden and premature death, is perfectly understood by those who know how little progress has been made at Essen in the propaganda of this mischievous cult.
LOOKING for happiness is doubtless an old pursuit. Dr. Hillis calls the quest of happiness the oldest topic known to man.

August Belmont, President of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, admitted yesterday that he would probably assume the Presidency of the Manhattan Railway, succeeding George J. Gould, as soon as the lease to the Interborough Company goes into effect. "When I lease a railroad," said Mr. Belmont, "I of course expect to assume the management."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Representative Payne of New York, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, who would be charged with the direction of tariff revision if that shall be undertaken, said today:

Trade reports to the several commercial agencies continue highly favorable, the only complaint being of somewhat unseasonable weather in some sections, though by one agency this weather seems to be regarded as more helpful than harmful.

She has for friend Lily, and both have a liking for art. As the two have some means at their command, they arrange a visit to England and France.

MR. MALLOCK is nothing if not brilliant and ingenious in his thought, lively and interesting in his style, but he would be more satisfactory if we felt more sure of his reality. We appear to be dealing with a mind which is fascinated by the intellectual problems of religion much more than it is engrossed with religion as a spiritual power.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- When one of the large Broad Street department stores closed to-night there was found leaning against a counter in one of the aisles a good-sized pasteboard box. On the top was written:

Dec. 3-5 Stan. V. Henkels will sell in Philadelphia a private collection of engravings, etchings, and original drawings, including many rare and choice items. A feature of the sale is the collection of fifteen original chalk drawings by Sir Edward Burne-Jones, who, in conjunction with William Morris, established the celebrated firm of Morris Co., noted for its artistic work in beautifying the great English cathedrals, colleges, and mansions.

GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Jacob Click, the proprietor of a variety store, has received a letter from Seneca Falls asking him to find a person who would murder F. G. Miller, a real estate agent of Seneca Falls.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The fate of the Western Immigrant Bureau still hangs in the balance. Its future existence depends, now on the outcome of a conference of a committee consisting of Passenger Traffic Managers Sebastian of the Rock Island. McCormick of the Southern Pacific, and Nicholson of the Santa Fs, appointed to-day at a meeting of the chief passenger traffic officials interested in the immigrant business to California.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I am pleased to see that Mr. Mills, the author of "Historic Houses of New Jersey." has answered in his interesting work the serious charges of Mrs. Gertrude Atherton against the name of the late Mme. Jumel.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- On Franklin Field to-morrow afternoon the Army and Navy elevens will wind up the college football season of 19O2. Both teams, accompanied by their substitutes and coaches are here, and each side is ready for the annual battle. Late to-night there was lively betting on the result with the West Point team a strong favorite at 2 to 1.

The Rev. S.L. HAMILTON, a leading member of the California Methodist Conference and long connected with the University of Southern California, died Thursday night at his home, in Los Angeles.

John L. Sullivan, the ex-champion pugilist, filed a petition in bankruptcy here yesterday, in order that he might so to Boston and appear there in a show without being arrested at the instance of creditor -- J.H. Lewis of 417 Washington Street, that city -- on five notes, amounting to $450.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The other day after finishing Mrs. Singleton's charming book on New York in the eighteenth century, my attention was called to a novel ("God's Puppets," by Imogen Clark,) which appeared about two years ago. I do not know if it had a large sale or not, but I do know that it should not be allowed to slip into the limbo of forgotten things.

As a first novel there is much to commend in "The Taskmasters," by George K. Turner, although it is true that many of the errors of a maiden effort creep in, and the book as a whole has the ring of immaturity. There might have been a great deal less talk, so to speak; Mr. Turner ambles along slowly and garrulously at times, and there is a lack of grasp and concentration to the story.

Messrs. Bangs Co. sold last week in their Fifth Avenue auction rooms an interesting collection of rare and beautiful books, including many uncommon items from the Aldine and Elzevir presses. One of the most important items in the sale was the first edition of Goethe's "Faust," in the original boards, as first issued.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 28. -- A confidential circular letter was received to-night by a few active Dallas Republicans, inviting them to attend a State conference at Dallas on Dec. 3. The conference is styled an "independent movement of Republicans to more thoroughly reorganize the party in Texas and furnish a basis of harmony for our party leader."

The West Side Club at 80 Sixth Avenue was filled with members and guests yesterday afternoon, there being more than 300 clubmen in the place, when for some reason Sergt. Edward S. Walling and Roundsman Ennis of the Mercer Street Police Precinct, with Policemen Dondero and Duran of Inspector Grant's staff, appeared in the clubrooms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Mrs. Roosevelt held her first large "at home" of the year to-day from 4 to 6 o'clock, when she welcomed several hundred visitors in the Red Room, this apartment and the State dining room, adjoining, being thrown open for the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- A fair-sized crowd attended the racing at the Bennings track to-day, and far the greater portion of these kept in the betting ring to avoid a cold northwest wind. The course has dried considerably, but the going still is heavy. Three favorites, Gould, Sam Craig, and Florham Queen, won, while Lord Advocate and Benckart, well-supported second choices, also finished first.

The sale of the great pacer Anaconda, (2:01 3/4,) styled the "king of campaigning pacers," was the chief attraction at the "Old Glory" horse auction in Madison Square Garden last night, when the largest evening crowd of the week witnessed the offering of the celebrated horse, who was shown in harness.

Reason and the teachings of experience stand opposed to the theories by which President ROOSEVELT attempts to justify his appointment of a colored man as Collector of the Port of Charleston.
