Manifestly it cannot be for the good of the Customs Service that the office of Collector at that port should be held by a man whose appointment is distasteful and offensive to ninety-nine-hundredths of the persons having business to do at the Custom House.

AT THE close of his two volumes of recollections Dr. Hale writes: "Some library will preserve this volume, and it carries witn it my charge to my sons' grandsons, that in 2001 one of them shall write his Memories of the Twentieth Century."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The fighting strength of the American Navy, counting ships launched, under construction, and authorized by act of Congress, has increased to four times what it was at the commencement of the war with Spain. This is the vital fact in the report of Secretary of the Navy Moody, made public to-day.

PUSSY! Who is Pussy? She is the spouse of Fred, and Pussy before she married the Englishman was a young and rich widow. You never learn even indirectly what their names are. You are led to suppose that Fred is some kind of an attache to the English Legation at Cairo, and engaged in secret service.

BOSTON, Nov. 28. -- J.A. Hathaway, one of the largest exporters of cattle in this country, who controls several stock yards, among them those at Watertown and Brighton, considers the order of the Secretary of Agriculture forbidding the expertation of cattle from New England a very serious blow to dealers in live stock.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Messrs. Smith, Elder Co. will publish Dec. 8 Mr. Sidney Lee's "Biography of Queen Victoria." The article in the Supplement to the Dictionary of National Biography, on which it is founded, has been completely rewritten, and much new and important information is included.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- After eluding arrest for several months, Charles F. Kelly, the ex-Speaker of the St. Louis House of Delegates, who is wanted in the Western city in connection with the bribery cases unearthed there some time ago, was arrested in this city at 1:10 o'clock this afternoon.

MANILA, Nov. 28. -- Gov. Taft and Archbishop Guidi have commenced the negotiations for the settlement of the pending questions between the Church and the State, and have agreed to hold at least three sessions weekly until a conclusion has been reached.

OF COURSE, every woman knows that her very first and most important duty in life is to look her best. One can never tell what may happen and she must always be prepared for the worst -- or the best. Think of it, some day she may go down town in an old gown, and just that day of all days she might meet -- some one.

PERU, Ind., Nov. 29 -- A fast run was made on the Wabash Railroad by Engine No. 536, pulling a regular train yesterday, the distance of 106 miles from Peru to Montpelier, Ohio, being covered in 114 minutes. The train slowed down five times and made as many full stops.

The London Mail finds cause for rejoicing in the fact that German locomotive builders are not able to fill orders quickly enough to capture them in every instance from British bidders, and that when satisfactory promises of prompt delivery have been made such promises have not always been kept. It says:

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- With a deafening report a boiler in Swift Co.'s plant exploded shortly after 10 o'clock this morning. Thirteen lives were sacrificed and scores of employes, visitors, and others were injured.

AS an additional milestone at the end of a long journey seemed the 10,000 mark in July, 1901, when the story of the collection of dinner menus that Miss F.E. Buttolph is making for the New York Public Library was first told in Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES. She had 8,000 specimens, the first and finest collection of the kind in the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Thre is no certainty as yet that the new army uniform will be made in New York instead of in Philadelphia. The bids for the material call for its delivery at the New York Arsenal, but it is said at the War Department hat this does not necessarily mean that the work is to be done there.

Ralph M. Easley, General Secretary of the National Civic Federation, yesterday received word from ex-President Grover Cleveland, saying he intended to be present at the annual meeting of the industrial department of the Federation, and will probably have something to say in relation to the matters touching trades unions, which will then be discussed.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Society's observance of Thanksgiving at Lakewood included attendance at divine service in the morning, luncheon at the Country Club of Lakewood, with an hour or two spent in observing the players in the big tournament, and then a quiet little dinner party in the evening at the Lakewood Hotel, Laurel House or Laurel in the Pines.

Upward of 50,000 apple trees shipped into the State from New York in one lot are to be destroyed at once to the uttermost branch by order of the State Commissioner of Horticulture. State Commissioner A. Holderbeke returned from Seattle, having been called there to inspect a shipment of three carloads of trees from a nursery at Rochester, N.Y.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- The Cunard Line steamship Sylvania, which will be the last vessel to leave Boston with cattle for a British port until the embargo against their shipment on account of the prevalence of the foot and mouth disease in New England is raised, hauled into the stream about 6 o'clock to-night and will sail for Liverpool to-morrow morning with 664 cattle and 750 sheep on board.
THE Autumn girl who gathers leave Won't hit it, we surmise, Like the Autumn girl who stays at home And turns out pumpkin pies.

MEN haven't half as much taste as an apple toddy. HER MAJESTY. This caustic criticism and the signature are scrawled in large, angular letters directly across her portrait. The words "much taste" spoil the beauty of the dimpled chin, while "her Majesty " partly covers the perfect throat.

HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- Various members of the Cuban Congress have been much exercised this Fall as to the where-abouts of the Kanawha, which was used as the Governor General's official yacht during the military government. President Palma has not a yacht, and for such trips as he may make about the harbor he uses a modern naphtha launch, as his immediate predecessors in the Executive chair have done.

Edward F. Croker will not cease to be Chief of Department under Fire Commissioner Sturgis's sentence of dismissal, at 8 A.M. to-morrow, while the extension of the official existence may be brief. His counsl, John J. Delany, yesterday obtained from Supreme Court Justice James Fitzgerald an order of review and a stay of the determination of Mr. Sturgis, and the court issued a writ of certiorari and a stay of the order of dismissal.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The Horse Show, which was opened by the Orange Riding and Driving Club on Thursday, was brought to a successful close to-night, the attendance at afternoon and evening exhibitions being heavier than on either Thursday or Friday nights. The show has been the most successful the club has ever given.

Under the deceptive title of "What Shall We Do With the Tariff?" Mr. THOMAS B. REED, in the current number of The North American Review, reflects at some length and with his accustomed grace on the supreme expediency of doing nothing with that sacred statute of taxation.

Every nook and cranny of the five-story building at 112 Fulton Street was searched for two burglars by Policemen Mulvahill and Dogenhardt of the Old Slip Station at an early hour yesterday morning. Armed with lanterns, night stick, and revolvers, the policemen were called to the place by August Meyers, an old-time optician.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although an ardent admirer of President Roosevelt and a thorough upholder of Republican policies in general, still I must protest with my whole soul against the proposed appointment of Dr. Crum to the Collectorship of Charleston, S.C. Why should the dominating social and moral sentiment of a community be outraged in this manner?

For the first time in a good many years A.T. Bliss, Governor of Michigan, heard himself called an uncomplimentary name without resenting it. The person to give the affront was a bell boy at a prominent city hotel of which he was a guest. The Governor stood aghast for a moment, and those who witnessed the affair expected him to rebuke the offender.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: If it were not in itself pathetic, it would be ridiculous that the people of New York should be solemnly told of the dangers they run in being allowed to keep dogs in their families. The proposed "dog ordinance" is, on the face of it, absurd. If you will kindly allow me space in your paper, I should like to examine the question as it stands to-day.

That must have been a good game of football to see that was played yesterday at Franklin Field, in Philadelphia. It was as good a day for the purpose as could be asked for, and much better than could reasonably be expected at the end of November. The result is eminently satisfactory to the patriot and philosopher, who, in such a controversy, would scorn to be a partisan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- In pursuance of the purpose of the Agricultural Department to spare no effort for the extermination of the foot and mouth disease prevailing among live stock in the New England States, Dr. Salmon, Chief of the Bureau of Animal Industry, decided to-day to go to Boston and take charge of the work in person.

WHILE the December days are the shortest, not being more than 9 hours and 20 minutes in length the first of the month and diminishing to 9 hours and 4 minutes from the 19th to the 23d, the sun comes to our rescue on the 22d by turning his face once again in our direction.

OF ALL the remarkable things that strike the eye of a, new-comer to this city, none is more amazing than the rapidity with which the great skyscrapers rise to their dizzy heights. First a great excavation, then an inconglomerate mass of granite, bricks, and steel girders: then the steel skeleton, a few finishing touches, and in less than a year a twenty-story building, with quarters for a thousand tenants, is complete and ready for occupancy.

All is now in readiness for the visit of the German Emperor to Lowther Castle. The suite of rooms which he will occupy are in the older and more secluded portion of Lord Lonsdale's historic seat, and command an extensive view over the gardens of the south front away to where the mighty peaks of Helvellyn and Skiddaw are outlined in the shadowy horizon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The racing at the Bennings track to-day brought to a close the Fall meeting or the Washington Jockey Club. The fine weather, aided a pood programme in attracting one of the largest crowds of the meeting. The feature of the card was the Maximum Stakes, for three-year-olds and upward, at three miles on the flat.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Nov. 28 -- What may be termed a most remarkable season is now closing upon the great lakes. The ore piled in the vicinity of the mines is beginning to freeze. The smaller craft have already hied themselves to Winter quarters. And for the period when traffic upon the water will be suspended the dock companies are planning a busy campaign of installing many mechanical innovations.

I HAVEN'T seen your name among the distinguished persons present at any of the football games this season. Mr. Idiot," observed Mr. Brief as he and the Idiot reached for the flapjacks simultaneously, with the result that each hesitated long enough in seizing them to permit the Anglomaniac to secure possession of the prize.

HOW she acquired it does not really matter -- possibly by teaching school, painting fire screens, or washing. Anyway, when she found herself in possession of the sum, she set about to see what she should do with it.

BRISTOL, R.I., Nov. 29 -- That Tobin bronze will be the material from which the cup defense sloop now in course of construction at the boat shops here has been definitely decided upon and the important information was given out as the result of a conference between C. Oliver Iselin and the designer, Nat Herreshoff.

THE Opera Club started on Monday last with quite a flourish. All the old members were in their places in the omnibus box. There is no question as to the popularity of this club. There have been dire rumors that, owins to the great demand for seats at the opera, this club would not be granted a new lease, and that the seats would be forfeited.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.-Senor Rafael S. Lopez. who has just arrived in Washington to represent the Government of Salvador as Minister Plenipotentiary, presented his credentials to President Roosevelt to-day. Senor Lopez represents his Government in a Ministerial capacity not only in Washington, but also at Havana, where he intends to reside the greater part of the year. He succeeds Senor Rafael Zaldivar.

BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- A case has just come to trial in Breslau which has caused a great sensation in the art circles of Germany. Carlo Boecklin, son of the great painter, has brought a libel suit against Prof. Muther of the Breslau University, one of the foremost art critics of the Fatherland.
I NEVER like lo be introduced to myself in a strange mirror," said a pretty woman, as the maid in waiting divested her of handsome evening wraps and left her free to approach the dressing table.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- The route of the canal, under Engineer Bond's plan, will be about as follows:

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- A large delegation of farmers, under the auspices of the German Agricultural Society, is going to the United States in April for a three months' tour, studying American agricultural methods. The German Embassy at Washington negotiated the affair with the Agricultural Department, which will furnish a guide during the entire trip.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 29 -- The argument in the proceeding of John S. Wise to invalidate the new Virginia Constitution was resumed in the United States Circuit Court here to-day. Chief Justice Fuller sitting with Judge Waddill.

Wall Street is discussing just now the probable strength of the various factions who are contesting the control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company. Many guesses have been made, but those in authority have declined to discuss the matter. The following guess was ascribed in the Street yesterday to a stockholder in the company who holds a considerable block in the stock:

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 9 -- One of the many complaints made by the local agricultural committees, which at present seem to have more or less usurped the function of a Parliament in reviewing and criticising the whole internal administration of Russia, has been that the financial policy of the Government is at variance with the true interests of the country and especially of the rural population.

THE Paris concierge (janitors) have just formed a "trades union." The average man thinks twice before venturing to beard one concierge in his den: what will it be now that each member of the fraternity will feel that he had the support of the whole combination behind him?

Gov. Odell on the occasion of the victory dinner given in his honor last night at the Republican Club, 450 Fifth Avenue, first amazed and then won the hearty applause of his hearers in a straight-from-the-shoulder blunt address. He predicted danger for the Republican Party in the next National election if the members of the party in this State cannot settle their differences.

There seems to be a disposition to boom the old athletic sports of Ireland just now, and hurling in particular is assuming a place which is by no menus unenviable, judging from the enthusiasm by which the old game is being taken up by athletes of this and other cities. A championship match betwen the Dalys and Wolf Tones was played at Celtic Park.
THE man who spends half his time trying to classifly people said he never saw so many left-eyed passengers in one car.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- General dissatisfaction has been caused among the negro Republicans of New Jersey because of the announcement that President Roosevelt has appointed Timothy Thomas Fortune, who recently moved from New York to Red Bank, as a Special Commissioner to the insular possessions, with an annual salary of about $5,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- "All fairs conducted for benevolent purposes, whether by churches or fraternal orders, are an abomination to this age and civilization," declared the Rev. Joseph Howell, pastor of the Hamilton Square Presbyterian Church, to an audience at the Shepherd's Delight Lodge Fair last night.

Shortly before the closing yesterday of the National convention of the Phi Delta Theta fraternity, which has been in session in the Hotel Majestic during the past week, by a spontaneous burst of feeling on the part of the delegates from the chapters, a mortgage on the home of the widow of the founder of the fraternity was wiped out and an annuity for the remainder of her life was provided for.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been burning a mixture containing soft coal and the smut annoys me as much as you say it does my neighbors.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- The Rev. Thomas H. Shahan, pastor of the Sacred Heart Church, Maiden, died at Carney Hospital this morning. Father Shahan was the oldest priest in the arch-diocese of Boston, being eighty-two years of age. He was noted as a church builder and organizer, and was a classmate of Archbishop Williams.

There is never very much going on in society before Thanksgiving, and now that the festival has passed into history there will be openings of dancing classes, debutantes' teas, and many private entertainments. During the week there were meetings of a few of the lesser dancing classes, and yesterday the Wednesday Cotillion, which is a social institution sui generis, had its reception at Delmonico's.

ONE feature of the naval manoeuvres in the West Indies which deserves particular attention is the results which may be expected in the way of confidence acquired and responsibility recognized by commanding officers of launches, engineers, and seamen. Each commanding officer of a launch will feel a certain per- sonal responsibility in which he could share but remotely were he at his proper station aboard ship.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- London, and, indeed, England, lost yesterday by the death of the Rev. Dr. Joseph Parker, one of the most original characters and striking personalities in public life. Coming so soon after the death of the Rev. Hugh Price Hughes, the loss, though expected for some little time, has created a painful feeling of national bereavement.

The widening of London Bridge, now in progress, is an event of considerable importance to Londoners; it is also an engineering task of no little difficulty, especially as it has to be carried out without stopping the traffic. London Bridge has long been too small for the work it has had to do.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- The excellence of to-day's card drew another large crowd to the track. The best contest was the third race, in which McChesney and Old Hutch finished the mile a neck apart. Buchanan took it too easily with the favorite in the early stages, und was forced to ride him out at the end.

The invasion of the ten foreign cycle riders who arrived in New York on the steamer St. Paul last week, and who will test their ability against the American bicycle riders in the international championship six-day bicycle race to be held in Madison Square Garden, New York, during the week of Dec. 7, has livened the interest in this sport, and will tend to make it more popular than ever this Winter.

SILENCED by a whipping he thought he did not deserve, Jerry Miller is now a hermit in a farmhouse in the wild regions of Ohio, not far from Chillicothe, says The Chicago Tribune. He is now past forty years old, and no one can remember having heard him say a dozen connected words.

The reception at the Savoy yesterday afternoon given by the Technical School for Girls, situated at 267 Henry Street, was attended by many prominent people. The display of the work done by the pupils of the school was interesting. This included dresses and millinery, the work of the girls, with beautiful embroidery and art needlework; bookkeeping, typewriting, and penmanship.

IF YOU want a church nowadays, all you have to do is to place your order with the church builder, just as you gave your order to the yacht builder, when you wanted a yacht. Heretofore when churches were projected builders who were engaged in general work were called on to undertake the job. Now it is different.

The sixth and last Fall matinee of the New York Road Drivers' Association was held on the Speedway yesterday afternoon under rather unfavorable conditions. An excellent card of events had been prepared, but a strong biting wind swept over the lower stretch, and this, combined with the soft footing, prevented many starters from putting in an appearance and caused several who did answer the call to refuse to start.

Transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange for the month of November aggregated 17,115,723 shares, ad against 16,348,147 shares in October, 20,952,017 in September, 14,317,393 in August, 16,317,957 in July, 7,813,049 in June, 13,485,777 in May, 26,578,512 in April, 11,954,672 in March, 12,950,699 in February, 14,763,391 in January, and 16,672,343 in December.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- F.R. Bryan of Philadelphia, one of the best-known Americans here, died last week at the age of seventy. He was a grandson of Reuebell, the famous member of the Directoire during the French Revolution, and nearly all his life had been spent in Paris, where he was one of the few American members of the Jockey Club.

INVARIABLY on a Sunday, when a man has a mind to sleep, or in the evening when he pants for rest and quiet, the pianos begin their work. Then, especially if it be a neighborhood of fiats, there issues from every window the dulcet strains of "The Maiden's Prayer," "Cavalleria Rusticana," " Telegraph My Baby," " Rip Van Winkle Was a Lucky Man," and a host of other rare classics.

AT FIRST the Little Boy, as became one of his sex, looked on the Little Girl with a sort of majestic indifference, very much as the sun might be presumed to look on the earth, mercury, the asteroids, and the other comparatively inconsequential bodies on which he shines.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29 -- The navy's defeat by West Point to-day did not create any great surprise in Annapolis, although a few believed that the navy might win. When the result of the first half was received many thought that the navy had taken a brace and would win out, but this belief was dashed when West Point scored again early in the second half.

The ridiculous boycott at Schenectady, by which it was hoped to paralyze the Intercommunication of three cities until a small body of contented and well-paid employes of a local electric railway had been dragooned into affiliation with the Trades Assembly, has been "declared off."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Tearing great gaping holes in the Navy line, smashing, crashing, and plunging for three, four, and five yards at a time, breaking down the Navy defense by its bull-like attack, the West Point football eleven literally plowed its way to a great victory over its opponent on Franklin Field this afternoon by a score of 22 to 8. Belknap subsequently kicked a beautiful goal from an angle.

BATUM, Transcaucasia, Oct. 30 -- It causes one quite a delightful sensation to be told that the shortest way home (Tiflis for the time being) is by the Caspian Sea Route, but such is not the case when the starting point is Viadikavkaz, the "other" side of the Caucasus; all the diligences "complet" for three days to come, and no extra horses to be had on the mountains.

KEY WEST, Nov. 24 -- The sponge beds in Florida comprise what are locally known as the "key grounds" and the "bay grounds." The former extend from Key West eastward and north-eastward at least as far as Cape Florida. In this region the sponges are found in the shallow water among the keys and along the reefs.

Those who are acquainted with the facts in the case look forward to great things in the near future for the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railway Company, from the strategic position it occupies in a railroad sense in those western counties of Pennsylvania where the mineral deposits are large; the line would be a great acquisition for certain of the trunk lines, so called.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I fancy the reason your correspondent. Mr. Willam Alpin, did not succeed in finding half-and-half in London was because he did not know how to ask for it. This was my experience until by patient effort I learned to make myself intelligible.

Dr. Ernest Lederle, the Health Commissioner, in an address last evening at the Saturday night smoker of the East Side Civic Club 254 Grand Street, divulged some of the new plans of the Health Department, which contemplate large expendi- tures, reaching into millions, and a greatly increased oiganization.

DELMONICO'S at luncheon time of a perfect Spring day not overcrowded, but Where the swish of satin met the frou-frou of silk, as highly bred and thoroughly, well groomed women passed out or in; bits of greeting here, there, and everywhere, nods and smiles galore, until one might almost fancy one's self at a private function, so few were the merely lookers-on in the spacious room.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 20 -- There has been a revival of racial conflicts in Belgium of late, brought about by the excessive demands of the Flemings, who claim equal rights for the Flemish language with French. The Flemish element in the population has for several years past been carrying on an active campaign throughout the country under the pretext that Flemish is really the national language of Belgium, and that French is but a foreign importation.

A few years back the long valley of Wilmerding, Pennsylvania, was little better than a wilderness. Here and there stood a farmhouse, and the passing trains seldom stopped to let down chance passengers.

AS to all this talk about the cost of a college education," remarked a young graduate at the Yale Club the other evening, who felt himself old enough to "reminisce" a bit, "the cost is, of course, largely a matter of one's environment. I remember that in my senior year Vanderbilt Hall and White Hall, which held the greater part of the class, represented two opposite standards of living.
THE West has some great lawyers," said the Missouri Colonel to the crowd that had been discussing rapid-fire cases in court.

HERE is the latest story which Bishop Potter is telling on himself. On Friday evening, Nov. 21, the Bishop performed an ordination ceremony in Staten Island, and, as is customary on such occasions, wore a small red hood at the back of his surplice.

Headlined at Keith's for the coming week are Mong Toom and Mong Chet, Burmese foot jugglers, Lewis McCord and company present Willard Holcomb's sketch, "Her Last Rehearsal," best described as "a scene behind the scenes." Lew Sully, in . black face comedy, is seen once more. The Martinetti troupe of acrobats, the Harmony four, who mix music and comedy.

CUERNAVACA, Mexico, Nov. 16 -- A lonesome but not unpleasant sound rises above the flat roofs of Cuernavaca just as the last bell ceases proclaiming the hour of midnight from the church tower. In the broad, soft sheets of light that vibrate from the moon one can see the plumes of the "royal palm" waving from many a patio.

DERBY, Conn., Nov. 28 -- The most ambitious scheme in trolley road management ever attempted in Southern New England is now expected to be accomplished by the middle of next Summer. This is a through line from Waterbury, Conn., down the populous Naugatuck Valley to Derby, thence through Bridgeport and the Norwalks to Stamford, a distance of nearly eighty miles.
BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- The naval demonstration against Venezuela is not considered tragic here, but it is regarded as politically important.

A fire in a four-story apartment house at 724 Carroll Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, caused a great deal of excitement in the Park Slope district of Brooklyn at noon yesterday. A fireman fell four stories while fighting the flames, and received injuries which resulted in his death.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial in your columns of Oct. 11 on the city's water supply so impressed me that I am prompted to supplement it by recounting a few personal experiences illustrating the soundness of your views. For over a quarter of a century I was engineer in charge of the direct handling of the supply of water and its general distribution.

Mrs. Fiske's production of Paul Heyse's "Mary of Magdala" at the Manhattan Theatre has proved popularly very successful, a fact which demonstrates, as Mrs. Fisk has so often demonstrated before, in spite of the pessimistic view which commercial managers take of the enlightenment of the metropolitan public, a genuinely artistic performance is sure of support.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Fire started in the basement of John Sabey's wholesale hat store to-night. The smoke was dense and entered the stage of the Wieting Opera House just about the conclusion of an opera. The stage manager informed the company that there was no danger, but to avoid a panic they should show no alarm and finish the opera.

WENT into a Broadway restaurant the other evening to get a plate of kartotfel-pfankuchen mit preiszel-beeren, which translated is potato pancakes with preiszel berry sauce, a sauce that is far finer than cranberry, and a few glasses of Muenchener," said the observant man.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It's really too bad our unsophisticated friend. Mr. "Willie" Alpin, never had the pleasure of meeting a certain gentleman who was fond of talking about "The Little Nipper." There's the man who could have given him some information on the momentous question, "Is there or is there not half-and-half in England?"

At the first matinee of the opera yesterday there was a great audience present to hear an admirable performance of "La Traviata." It was lifted out of the old routine of conventionality and commonplace by a number of things that pleased the eye and the ear of the listener, and that were calculated to warm the hearts of even those to whom the woes of the consumptive courtesan are a weartress.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The fears that the Bank of England rate might be raised materially hardened the money market this week. Money has been in increased demand owing to the payment for u3,000,000 new Treasury bills and to the Stock Exchange pay day. The Bank of England has done a large business in loans and discounts.
Richard Mansfield has the reputation of doing things in ways peculiarly his own, and in his production of "Julius Caesar" he has cut out the ghost so far as the vision of the audience is concerned.

ST. JOHN'S. N.F., Nov. 26 -- The possi- bility of the resumption in the near future of the negotiations between Newfoundland and the United States the consummation of which was made impossible twelve years ago by the influen- tial opposition of Canada, calls attention to the value of the deep-sea fisheries on the Northern Atlantic seaboard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with much interest your short article in Sunday's paper about the British Quarter of New York, also your correspondent's letter appertaining to the Cockney's drink, "half-and-half." Evidently Mr. Alpin did not inquire at the right places, or he would certainly have had the opportunity of sampling this favorite beverage.

WHILE the Rapid Transit Commission's chief business is the building of the subway system in three boroughs, a separate and distinct piece of subway work is progressing rapidly along Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, where the Long Island Railroad is to transfer its surface tracks by degrees to a depression that will get them out of the way of surface traffic.

Findlay S. Douglass won the Lakewood Cup yesterday in the final round of the open tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club. He met Charles B. Macdonald in the deciding round, and won by 3 up and 2 to play. Both are former champions of the United States, Macdonald having won in the first regular tournament ever held by the National Golf Association, at Newport in 1895.

WHEN New York was young a tower clock was built in the tiny steeple of a little churcn that then stood at the corner of Beekman and Cliff Streets. That was nearly two centuries ago, but the clock is still ticking away and keeps just as good time as ever. Its hands are not as artistic and gorgeous as those that point the time in many of the tower clocks today.

MY FRIEND THE ELEPHANT" is the title used by Herman Lee Ensign for the account of his experiences and friendship with Jumbo, the most famous elephant that ever lived, for The Woman's Home Companion. He says:

What Mrs. Fiske considers as one of the highest compliments yet paid her was that of Paul Heyse when he chose her as the best fitted of all American actresses to play his "Mary of Magdala." About two years ago he submitted the translated drama to her, and asked if she would produce it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A report from Capt. Swinburne, commander of the Texas, touching the accident on board that vessel yesterday while at target practice, says that one of the hydraulic cylinders which returns the gun to battery was cracked because it had been left filled with water when the gun was discharged.

There was little new feature to the money market during the week just passed. The most significant was the more liberal offerings of long time money at slightly easier rates -- a fact that goes to bear out the steadily growing conviction that after the turn of the year it will be found that rates will work lower.

HAVE you ever observed how, from the way he plays a game of billiards, a man's temperament may be judged?" asked an old gentleman of the writer, as we stood looking at an interesting game in a billiard room down town. Receiving a negative answer the old gentleman continued:

Broken by the Thanksgiving holiday, the Wall Street week has had few exceptional features. The bear contingent staid more or less in repose; bull leadership has been nowhere aggressive. In two or three conspicuous issues sharp advances have taken place -- for reasons wholly apart from general market conditions, however.

THE recent competition inaugurated by the General Passenger Agent of a Western railroad offering a substantial prize for the best name for a new fast train between Chicago and St. Paul and Minneapolis has just been decided by the division of the prize among five persons who suggested the name of the "North Star Limited."

Football for the year 1902 is a thing of the past. The contests between the leading college teams have been well fought, the number of spectators drawn to the fields has been larger than in all previous years, and this widespread interest has been, intensified by well played and, in several cases, closely fought contests between the leading elevens.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 29 -- The managers of the Intercollegiate Basketball Association have announced the schedule of games to be played between the members of the association. The schedule consists of twenty games and is so arranged that each team meets every other team twice. Should a tie occur for the championship an addi- tional series of games will be arranged.

Prices were firm in the outside market yesterday, but there was not much activity. The securities which had for some days shown an upward tendency made some further advances. Among these was Virginia Iron, Coal and Coke, which sold up to 36, an advance of 2 points, this gain resulting from the purchase of only 400 shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- It is very probable that numerous bills will be presented next week in both branches of Congress, aimed at the control of trusts and combinations in restraint of trade. Representative Hepburn is among those who believe authority should be given to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to fix a value on all stock of corporations which does not represent actual value, as is done in the case of cigars and liquors.

WILKESBARRE, Pa., Nov. 29 -- It is said a big electric railway deal was consummated here to-day. The Wilkesbarre and Wyoming Valley Traction Company and several other important electric railway systems in this State. New Jersey and Delaware, of which J.A. Rigg of Reading, Penn., is the President, are said to have been sold to a syndicate headed by George Gould of New York.
IT was after the Saturday matinee at Wallacks, and two girls were discussing the scenes of "The Crisis," as they came forth.

Two attempts have recently been made by New York theatrical managers to provide entr'acte music on a dignified and artistic plane especially to interest the spectators of new stage productions. For "The Eternal City," Mr. Hail Caine's melodramatic play, dealing with events in Rome, Mascagni was, appropriately enough commissioned to compose music, including an overture and shorter pieces to be heard between the acts, one feature being a boatman's song delivered behind the curtain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The return of Herr von Holleben brings the full quota of Ambassadors to Washington, although the early departure of M. Cambon shortly will leave the French Embassy in charge of its First Secretary, M. de Margerie, to await the coming of M. Cambon's successor.

ALARGE number of white or very pale-tinted frocks were worn at the opening night of the opera,and jewels, save in a few instances, were conspicuous by their absence. Many of the older women appeared with few, if any. Mrs. Astor always wears magnificent gems, and departing from her usual custom.

ARCHANGEL, Russia, Nov. 5 -- Some days ago, accompanied by the Adjutant of the Governor of the Province of Archangel and a young Hollander who had traveled from Moscow with me, I visited the Prison of Solonbola, in Archangel. The prison is a largre two-story building which can hold 900 to 1,000 prisoners condemned for a term of from one to six years.

It is the natural tendency of mankind, and has been before as well as since the days of the Apostle PAUL, to magnify their respective offices. Hence it is curious to find Mr. ALEXANDER BREMER, President of the Musical Mutual Protective Union, elaborately belittling and disparaging the craft which he represents, the craft of orchestral musicians, in his letter to the President of the United States.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The speech of Mr. Schurman, President of Cornell University, published in THE TIMES of Nov. 16, seems to me decidedly illogical.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Lieut. Robert E. Peary, the arctic explorer, delivered an address to-night before the National Geographic Society on the subject of arctic exploration.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Money was in active demand to-day. Discounts were steady.

VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- Hauptmann's new drama "Der Arme Heinrich" was produced at the Hofburg Theatre to-night, and scored a great success. Kalnz's impersonation of the role of Heinrich amply justified the production of the play in this city rather than at Berlin, which was necessary in order to secure his services.

No one save officers of the law and all attorney was permitted inside the brownstone-front residence at 146 East Forty-seventh Street yesterday. A private policeman in a gray uniform stood by the door and denied all callers admittance and information concerning the strange case of Leonard Frederick Roos, the art connoisseur, who died in the house Thursday evening under circumstances so suspicious that Ceroner Jackson has ordered an inquest.
An exhibition of the work of Miss Julia Thompson will open at the Knoedler Gal leries to-morrow. Miss Thompson is a Washington woman, and her portraits are highly spoken of by out-of-town critics.

The Canal Association of Greater New York will meet to-morrow afternoon for the purpose of considering the Canal bill which has been drawn up by Major Symonds, the Government engineer, who has charge of the works at Buffalo, and Abel E. Blackmar, the attorney for the association. The bill provides for the construction of a 1,000-ton barge canal along the Erie route.

It is a token of the high cosmopolitan character of this city, not exceeded by Rome or Alexandria in their most prosperous periods, that the Chinese residents here intend to found a hospital where their countrymen can be treated according to the medical usages prevailing in their own land.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- What promises to develop into a beautiful quarrel between ex-President Kruger and Gen. Sir Evelyn Wood has begun.

PORT OF SPAIN, Island of Trinidad, Nov. 29 -- Venezuelan gunboats have recently seized four British merchantmen in the Orinoco River, and the protest made regarding these seizures has not been heeded. An American ship is now here, bound for the Orinoco, and is awaiting a decision from the Washington Government as to whether or not the blockade is effective.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- A special from Chattanooga says that Guffey Galey, the Pittsburg oil firm, have disposed of all their Kentucky holdings to the Standard Oil Company. The purchase price was $850,000, and the deal includes the Mount Sterling Oil and Gas Company, the famous Ragland Farm and other holdings steel tanks, and plants.

DEXTER, Me., Nov. 30 -- Mrs. Hattie L. Whitten, who was arrested yesterday charged with having poisoned her nine-year-old daughter, from whose funeral she had just returned, committed suicide to-day by hanging from a bedpost while in the custody of Deputy Sheriff Curtis.

Without doubt the most important part of the report of the Secretary of War is that which deals with the Mational defense and looks to a much closer co-operation and co-ordination of the militia with the regulars than has ever been attained heretofore. When Mr. ROOT took office he announced his view of his functions by saying that the chief use of maintaining an army in time of peace was to make ready for war.

One of the objects for the attainment of which Secretary ROOT has labored, ever since his incumbency of the Secretaryship of War made it incumbent on him to ascertain what was the matter with the United States Army, is the creation of a General Staff.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe that if you Knew the facts of the non-acceptance of a Carnegie library by the City Council of Halifax you would not consider the action of the City Council "disgraceful," or blameworthy, therefore for the credit of our city and the Council I write these facts for publication, assuring you they are reliable and in accordance with the Council's records.

Many Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church from far away places are here to aid in conducting the great Episcopal mission revival now in progress. Some of them filled pulpits in this city yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- Announcement was made to-night that documents have been illed at Trenton incorporating the East Cape May Company, having for its object the improvement and devlopment of Cape May, the oldest seashore resort in the country, to an immense degree. A gentleman interested in the project says Pittsburg capitalists have bought over 4,000 acres of land in and around the city and propose making changes that will revolutionize that resort.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30 -- Two bright Radcliffe College girls are proprietors here of a bakery which is unlike any other in the world. Miss Stevenson, a South Carolinian, is the manager. Her partner is Miss Frances Eiliott, the daughter of a Toronto physician, a graduate of Toronto University and Radcliffe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your very opportune editorial note in to-day's TIMES on the construction of buildings, relative to the confining of smoke as well as fire within narrow spaces, voices a sentiment which has been for some time held by the Bureau of Buildings for the Borough of Manhattan.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 4 -- The Empress Dowager's second reception to the ladies of the Pekin Legations yesterday was a dignified function, without any exchange of presents or of effusive compliments. The ladies went to the palace by way of the canal in a boat towed by a steam tug.

Dr. G.R. Parkin, C.M.G., Principal of Upper Canada College, Toronto, who has been commissioned by the Trustees of Cecil Rhodes's educational bequests to devise some scheme to put into effect the provisions of the will relating to the establishment of colonial and American scholarships at Oxford, arrived yesterday from England on the Cunarder Campania.

The American linpr St. Louis, which sailed from Southampton on Nov. 22, and was due to arrive here on Saturday afternoon, was not righted until this morning. She arrived at the bar at 1:20 o'clock. On one trip last Summer she was twenty-four hours late, having been delayed by a leaky boiler, and since that time she has rarely made this port before Sunday morning.

William E. Jacques of Detroit, Mich., inventor of a cement wheel track peculiarly suited to use for automobiles, and Alfred C. Crozier, a Michigan capitalist, are guests at the Waldorf-Astoria, awaiting a conference which they say has been arranged with John Jacob Astor and the officials of the Automobile Club of America regarding the use of the Jacques track in the proposed automobile route between New York and Chicago.

By his criticism at the Republican Club banquet of the work done by the local Republican organization during the last campaign Gov. Odell has stirred up a political hornet's nest, judging from the interviews had with some of the leaders yesterday. National Committeeman Frederick S. Gibbs, who is also the leader of the Ninth District, was especially outspoken.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- According to Senator Knute Nelson of Minnesota, there is no general demand in that State for tariff revision. He said to-night:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I chanced to overhear a conversation at a certain Brooklyn Club the other night which proved to be very interesting. Two young lawyers, just admitted, were playing at cards -- let us call them Doe and Roe. Doe won, and floe was his debtor to the amount of about $50.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- At noon to-morrow the second session of the Fifty-seventh Congress will begin. It promises to be a dull session, with few features. The general belief that this will be the case is shown in the smallness of the number of strangers in town. Even the Congressmen did not come in in any considerable numbers until within the past few days.

It was a very noticeable fact that following the publication of Saturday's unexpectedly unfavorable bank statement, giving to the market what traders please to term a "chill," there was a very limited supply of stocks for sale -- and this, though the professionals used their every endeavor to force recessions and to bring about a general selling movement.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- "Had not so many of our burghers proved false to their own colors England, as the great Bismarck foretold, would have found her grave in South Africa." That is the keynote of Gen. De Wet's book, entitled "Three Years' War," published by Archibald Constable Co. here, and dedicated by the Boer General "To my fellow-subjects of the British Empire."

The Rev. Percy Stickney Grant, rector of the Church of the Ascension, preached last night at his church, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, on the attitude of educators toward public schools. He said in part:

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 30 -- The United States is confronted with the question of announcing its attitude regarding the blockade of the Orinoco River, which has been declared by the Venezuelan Government.

The Central Federated Union decided yesterday to make a final effort to-morrow at the meeting of the Hoard of Aldermen to prevent the adoption of the amended franchise for the Pennsylvania tunned, that is without the labor clauses. The subject was discussed at length and the Chairman asked the delegates that attended the hearing before the Committee on Railroads on Wednesday last to attend the meeting of the Aldermen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Italian Ambassador and Mme. Mayor des Planches entertained their first large company in America this afternoon, when they gave a reception at their embassy from 4 until 6 o'clock, the guests being invited to meet Mme. Duse, their talented compatriot, who closed her professional engagement in Washington last evening.

Seventy-two riders took part in the handicap unpaced half century bicycle road run, which was brought to a successful conclusion yesterday by the officials of the New York State Division of the Century Road Club of America. This event was to have been decided on Thanksgiving Day, but it had to be postponed owing to the wretched condition of the roads at that time.

The the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to suggest that the assertion in Wednesday's editorial, "the net result of the struggle of the unions to establish this average grade among wage earners is that, while inferior workmen are paid somewhat more than they are worth and could command on their merits, the better workman is paid less than he is worth, * * *" is so incomplete as to be glaringly inaccurate.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 30. -- Charged with speeding his automobile faster than eight miles an hour on the village streets, a young man who said he was Arthur K. Bourne, son of Frederick G. Bourne of Manhattan, was arrested here this afternoon. With him at the time were a man and two women.

The funeral of Leonard K. Roos, the art connoisseur, who died on Thursday evening at his home, 140 East Forty-seventh Street, took place yesterday at 1:30 o'clock. There were few friends of the deceased present, and no religious ceremonies of any kind were held. The interment was at Kensico Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The net results of the business operations of the Government for the five months just ended do not compare favorably with the figures of the corresponding months of last year. There has been loss of revenue in the aggregate, and the expenditures have continued to climb upward, until they have reached $22,000,000 over those for the five months ended Nov. 30, 1901.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Patrick Fiannagan of Perth Amboy, who died in St. Michael's Hospital, this city, a few days ago, has bequeathed his entire estate, which is estimated at $7,000, to that institution.

Congressman HEPBURN has been turning his mind toward the correction of the evils of trusts since the election. He says that a few weeks since he hit, apparently by accident, on the notion of establishing a bureau in the Internal Revenue office for squeezing the water out of the trusts, and he is confident that when this is done there will be no harm possible from these dreaded corporations.

For the first time in several years there will be opposition and probably three slates at the annual election of officers in the Star Athletic Club to-morrow night. The voting will take place in the clubhouse on Vernon Avenue, Long Island City, at 7:30 o'clock and a lively time is expected. The Star A.C. has been very successful during the past season and is now in first-class standing financially.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in your issue of Nov. 28, entitled "Taking Another Man's Job," must appeal to all reasonable men. There are always two sides to a question, and reasonable men try to look upon both sides, but most of the men in labor unions do not seem capable of doing this.

Benjamin F. Chadsey, a lawyer, who disappeared from Brooklyn two months ago, and who was found in San Francisco two weeks ago, was brought back to Brooklyn under arrest yesterday, and will be arragined in the County Court this morning charged with grand larceny. The complaining witness is Mrs. Elizabeth F. Miller, guardian of William Meyer, an infant.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 30 -- At a banquet tendered the Midshipmen football team this afternoon at the Naval Academy Charles Carroll Soule of Boston, Mass., was elected Captain of the team for the season of 1903.

The first popular concert by Mr. Grau's operatic forces given last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House was chiefly of interest as making a further disclosure of the powers of the new conductor, Mr. Hertz. The orchestral numbers included Beethoven's "Leonore" overture No. 3, Liszt's symphonic poem "Les Preludes," and the prelude and final scene from "Tristan und Isolde."

Senator FRYE is a naive and persistent gentleman. He has been for many, many years an advocate of subsidies to American shipping. In the course of these years he has taken up many forms of bills, and has worked more or less willingly with many classes of subsidy hunters.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that it is time for an outsider or two to commend the Post Office authorities for their heroic attempt to make women more womanly and men more manly. The woman who marries a man without means is sentimental than sensible, while the man who expects his wife to help support the family other than in her own home is hardly a protector.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- In his annual report, made public to-day, Secretary Root makes a number of important recommendations, chief among them being these:

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Two cats that had lived away from the haunts of man long enough to lose the graces of civilization made an attack this morning on George S. Hillery and Samuel K. Dougherty, who said they were students of Columbia University, and who were on a tramp over the mountains.

NEWARK. N.J., Nov. 30 -- The expert who has been going over the books of the Board of Street and Water Commissioners has prepared his report, and it will be presented at the meeting of the board on Thursday next.

A gathering of fully 2,600 persons witnessed a Gaelic football match between the O'Connells and Young Irelands of this city at Equitable Park. Sixty-seventh Street and Eleventh Avenue, yesterday. The game resulted in a tie score of 2 goals and 2 points for each side. In the first half the O'Connells made 2 goals and the Young Irelands 1 goal and 1 point.

During the storm last evening four persons nearly lost their lives on Long Island Sound through the sinking of a coal barge, which ran on the rocks off North Brother Island. They were rescued by the crew of the tugboat Hattie B. of the McWilliams Towing Line, from which the barge had become separated through the snapping of the hawser.

Richard Croker will return in the Spring. This information was obtained last night from John Fox, President of the Democratic Club. Mr. Fox was in Europe this Summer and had several talks with Mr. Croker. He said that Mr. Croker told him that he expected to visit New York during the coming year to see his relatives and old friends.

It is incredible that the Washington dispatches correctly report Senator CULLOM when they represent him as intimating that the United States will have full authority to dig and operate a canal through the territory of Colombia as soon as it has taken title to the property and concessions of the New Panama Canal Company.

-- Harper's Weekly suspects -- "shrewdly," it says, but that's as may be -- that the chief purpose of Mr. BOOTH TARKINGTON in getting himself elected a member of the Indiana Legislature was "to acquire knowledge from experience for the subsequent delight of his readers, rather than to inflict additional laws upon his countrymen."

In the Episcopal Diocese of Newark a convention is to be held in January, it is said, to elect a Bishop Coadjutor, who will have the right of succession to Bishop Starkey. The belief is that, at the convention the extent of the progress made by the High Church party is to be indicated. The High Church party has control of four diocese.

On their way across the Brooklyn Bridge late Saturday night to take a train at Jersey City for an extended shooting trip in the South, Lowell M. Palmer, Jr., a Brooklyn clubman, and son of Lowell M. Palmer, the coal merchant, and his friend Mr. Marshall, a retired cordage man, met with a mishap which nearly cost them their lives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The activity of the manufacturers of the United States, measured by the figures of imports of manufacturers' materials and exports of manufactured articles, is greater than ever before.

Three trotting favorius of the Harlem River Speedway -- Swift. (2:15 1/2.) Sally Simpson, (2:11 1/4.) and Alice Barnes, (2:10 1/4) -- all prominent figures in the matinee races of the season closing, made up a three-cornered brush on the Speedway yesterday that resulted in three of the fastest and best contested heats ever witnessed on that famous drive.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Senator Hoar of Massachusetts thinks little legislation will be accomplished this Winter outside of the general appropriation bills.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Bishop Thomas A. Starkey of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark has not applied for the appointment of a Bishop Coadjutor, and he will not discuss the matter. There is to be a special meeting of the Standing Committee on Monday, Dec. 8. The issuing of the can for a special convention rests with the Bishop, unless he asks the committee to relieve him of all responsibility in the matter.

Negotiations are now in progress looking to the improvement of one of the most important plots facing Long Acre Square -- the southeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street, opposite the site of the proposed new building of THE NEW YORK TIMES. This property has frontages of 104 feet on Broadway and 169 feet on Forty-third Street, and is owned by Mrs. Mary A. Fitzgerald of Litchfield, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The fight over the Statehood bill began to-day in the Senate before the session was half an hour old. It did not project itself into the proceedings in any way, but it was the subject of quiet discussion on the floor, and immediately after the adjournment there was a conference of leading Senators in the Naval Committee room to consider the matter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- Local trading continued listless to-day. Reading common provided nearly one-half the day's business. A tone of uncertainty pervaded the entire market, and at the close net gains and losses were very evenly divided. Few stocks varied more than small fractions, the prominent exceptions being J.B. Stetson warrants, which advanced 6 points; Lehigh Navigation, which was up 1/2, and Lehigh Navigation allotments, which rose 2 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- M. Cambon, the retiring Ambassador from France, entertained at a farewell dinner this evening at the embassy, on Rhode Island Avenue, the guests being the members of his staff, with Mme. de Margerie, wife of the First Secretary, and Mme. Vignal, wife of the united staffs of the two embassies.

MARSEILLES, Dec. 1. -- The strike of stokers, sailors, and others here is assuming gravity with the arrival of many more steamships. The sailors and stokers on their arrival immediately leave their ships, and the passengers are unable to proceed to their destinations.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 1. -- In an interview to-day with the correspondent of The Associated Press, President Joseph Smith of the Mormon Church defined the present position of the Church with respect to polygamy, also the ecclesiactical position of Apostle Reed Smoot, whose candidacy for the United States Senate has resulted in an active campaign against him by the Ministerial Alliance.

It will be time enough to consider Gov. ODELL'S canal policy when he shall have accepted or declined responsibility for the plan of canal improvement worked out by State Engineer BOND. It may as well be said at once, however, that the embodiment of this plan in a legislative bill would insure the defeat of the measure.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1. -- Robert Mather of Chicago, Second Vice President and general counsel of the Rock Island Railroad, has been here several days investigating the legal requirements governing the building and operating of railways in Mexico.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1. -- The Schorr stable furnished the only beaten favorites to-day, Ordnung and Commissioner Forster. Presiding Steward Clarence McDowell arrived from Bennings to-day. The Crescent City Jockey Club refused to permit John J. Ryan to book to-day upon receipt of a telegram advising that he had been ruled off at Fort Erie.

That it has been unanimously agreed among the English labor delegates who have been recently touring the United States under Alfred Mosely for the purpose of studying American methods as regards the relations of capital and labor to establish a civic federation in Great Britain similar to the National Civic Federation of America was announced last evening by Mr. Mosely.

The address delivered by Controller GROUT before the Manufacturers' Association in Brooklyn has been printed in full, and it is a document which all citizens desiring to understand the very important and very complicated financial methods of the city should read with care.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When I noticed the heading of your leading editorial this morning, "The Charleston Collectorship," it was with a feeling of pleasurable anticipation that I settled down to the luxury of seeing the manly, liberal, and just stand taken by the President in this matter cordially commended by your paper, which is generally taken up with articles filled to the brim with justice.

ROANOKE, Va., Dec. 1. -- The Norfolk Western Railway to-day announced the following appointments of division superintendents: A.C. Needles, acting superintendent of Norfolk Division, with headquarters at Crewe, to be superintendent of the Pocahontas Division, with headquarters at Bluefields; W.S. Becker, chief clerk to general manager, to be superintendent of Norfolk Division.

At the meeting or the Chamber of Commerce on Thursday action is to, be taken on two reports from the Committee on State and Municipal Taxation. One of these approves the plan that was submitted by Deputy Controller Stephenson, with the approval of Mr. Grout and the City Administration, for reducing taxation in the city, and was presented at the meeting on Nov. 6.

A very important conference was, or at all events should be, that held the other day under the auspices of the Municipal Art Society. There were represented at it the Merchants' Association, the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, the Manufacturers' Association, the American Society of Civil Engineers, the Architectural League, the National Sculpture Society, the National Society of Mural Painters, and the Municipal Art Society.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association will begin its regular annual meeting in Parlors H and I in the Murray Hill Hotel this morning. The sessions will probably last three days. The members of the board are Morgan G. Bulkeley, Hartford, Conn.; John C. Welty, Canton, Ohio; George W. Archer, Rochester, N.T.; U.C. Blake, Cedar Rapids, Iowa; P.P. Johnston, Lexington, Ky., and John H. Shults of this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The customary scenes were enacted to-day when the Fifty-seventh Congress convened to open its second and short session. The opening of Congress is a society as well as a political event, as is annually attested by the presence in the galleries of large numbers of handsomely gowned ladies, and this year was no exception to the rule.

RESTRICTIONS ON THE FREEDOM OF THE PRESS. -- The Harvard Law Review, in its November number, comments on the freedom-of-speech clause in the Constitution of this State, which Herr Most claimed gave him the right to publish his article advocating the wholesale murder of Government officers.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- The cattle bureau of the State Board of Agriculture began to-day a systematic inspection of the cattle reported as having the foot and mouth disease, the prevalence of which in New England has caused an embargo on traffic in cattle, sheep, and hogs.

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- President Castro of Venezuela handed, probably last Thursday, to the German Minister at Caracas a written acceptance of part of Germany's claims, sufficiently comprehensive to delay the presentation of a joint ultimatum by Germany and Great Britain, if not rendering it altogether unnecessary.
LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The feature of the money market to-day was the International Mercantile Marine Company's payment for its purchases of steamship lines. Discounts were firm.

For two acts and a half last night at the Herald Square Theatre Mr. Richard Mansfield's highly renowned production of Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" proved pleasing to the eye and intellectually interesting. At the end of the third act the Marc Antony of Mr. Arthur Forrest, aided by a well-drilled crowd that punctured his famous oration with interpolated ejaculations, roused a burst of enthusiasm that was possibly more fervid than judicious.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The number of bills introduced in the House to-day was not very large for the first day of the session. The first bill introducted was offered by Representative Brownlow of Tennessee, and provided for the establishment of a good roads bureau in The Department of Agriculture with an appropriation of $60,000,000.

Two raids were made by Capt. Walsh of the West Thirtieth Street Station and his men last night. One was at Frank Farrell's, 33 West Thirty-third Street, the house made famous by its steel portico and door, which were supposed to be police-proof.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The attack on the Virginia State Constitution, which was begun in the House to-day by Representative Taylor of Ohio, was the outcome of a conference held just before Congress met. Up to this morning Mr. Taylor knew nothing of the matter, and had no idea of presenting a resolution.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1. -- Capt. McGrew of Harvard's Varsity crew is being somewhat censured by loyal crimson supporters for a freshman rowing notice which appeared in this morning's edition of The Harvard Crimson. In requesting freshmen candidates to report for duty Capt. McGrew drew some rather unusual distinctions.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The Brussels correspondent of The Times says that the services of Baron Lambermont, Belgian Minister of State, who arbitrated the British-French West African disputes concerning the Waima affair and the gunboat Sergent Malamine, have been handsomely recognized by both Governments.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Undoubtedly, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times, the disorderly conduct of the Social Democrarts and their obstructive tactics in the Reichstag have welded together those heterogeneous elements of the majority which were formerly at sixes and sevens.

By far the most sensational raid of the series beginning with the activities of the committee of Fifteen and continuing intermittently through the fusion administration, was the invasion last night of the gambling establishment of Richard A. Canfield, at 5 East Forty-fourth Street. District Attorney Jerome and Police Inspector Nicholas Brooks led the raid.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 1. -- The "Sultan of Sulu," George Ade's satirical musical comedy, was produced here to-night, and was well received. Apparently the audience appreciated most those features of the play which illustrated Mr. Ade's skill as a satirical writer. The music and the situations did not make much of an impression.

Notwithstanding a generally lower range of prices sent over here at the opening from London, the local stock market opened yesterday firm, and, despite heaviness in a few issues, soon developed distinct strength, which was well maintained up to the close of the business session.

DETROIT, Dec. 1. -- Barney Oldfield of this city, driving Tom Cooper's gasoline racing automobile to-day at the Grosse Points track, lowered the world's one mile automobile record for a circular track to 1:01 1-5, and the five-mile record to 5:20. Oldfield's five miles is eight seconds under the previous world's record.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1. -- The market to-day was again flat and featureless. Money remains too light for active trading. The scarcity of funds, together with the uncertainties relative to New York during the ensuing month, have put buyers completely out of the inclination to purchase freely. Money on call was at 6 per cent.

Dr. Newton M. Shaffer, head of the Chair of Orthopedic Surgery at Cornell University Medical College, announced yesterday that he had received a large gift of money from a private source donated for the purpose of extending the work of Prof. Adolph Lorenz, who soon will visit here and treat the children of the poor for congenital dislocation of the hip bones.

At the Blaney Theatre in Jersey City last night the case of Roland B. Molineux was the subject of a play, which would have been gruesome had not some of the cast proved themselves clever. While the production was not really wholesome, its thrilling climax pleased the audience.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- The Clearing House rate to-day was 5 per cent. New York funds par; call loans, 5 1/2@6; time money, 5 1/2@8; Clearing House exchanges, $19,380,176; balances, $1,629,213. The weekly statement of the associated local banks, issued to-day, shows a loss in the reserve excess of $708,572.
Senator Elsberg replied yesterday to the strictures passed upon him and other Republicans in the Twenty-ninth Assembly District by Fred S. Gibbs. Among other things, Senator Elsberg said:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- Mrs. Kate Hassett, aged twenty-eight years, leading woman in Keith's Eighth Street theatre stock company, was shot and killed tonight by Barry Johnston, a well-known actor, who was formerly a member of Richard Mansfield's company and who is well known to theatrical people throughout the country.

Months ago we urged upon the State Department the propriety of preparing a primer of the Monroe doctrine for the use of the Chancelleries and also incidentally but very particularly of the newspaper offices of Continental Europe. To the best of our recollection we excepted from the implied criticism the British newspapers, as not needing the instruction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Nov. 29, 1902, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $958,097,281, which is a decrease for the month of $410,440.

"Keeping New York Streets Clean" was the topic discussed last night by Commissioner Woodbury of the Department of Street Cleaning before the League for Political Education, at Berkeley Lyceum, in West Forty-fourth Street.

Not in the seven years that she has been traversing the Atlantic has the American liner St. Louis, in yesterday from Southampton, experienced such a rough time as she did on the homeward passage that ended yesterday morning. Great seas enveloped her time and again and broke with terrific force over her sides.

Three score contractors and manufacturers of explosives went yesterday to Fire Headquarters to attend a public hearing of the Municipal Explosives Commission on the subject of rules and regulations governing the transportation, storage, use, sale, , of high explosives for blasting and other purposes in the City of New York.

UNITED STATES FLAGSHIP IOWA, PORT-OF-SPAIN, Island of Trinidad, Dec. 2. -- In spite of the superiority of Admiral Higginson's squadron over that of Admiral Sumner, the latter is confident that he will be able to seize without disaster during the coming naval war game a port to form a base of operations against Cuba and the American coast.

MANILA, Dec. 2. -- Orders have been received from Washington directing that Major Edward F. Glenn, of the Fifth Infantry, shall be put on trial a second time for alleged cruelty commited during the Samar campaign. Major Glenn is charged with having ordered the execution of several native guides for misleading the American column sent against the enemy's stronghold.
According to Detroit dispatches, the bondholders of the Michigan Telephone Company have secured an injunction restraining the company from disposing of its property.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The fight between the Administration and the reorganizers of the Republican Party in the South, the so-called "Lily Whites," is fairly on. Senator Pritchard of North Carolina, the leader of the movement, to-night made a statement which removes all doubt about his position.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- The market to-day was dull and heavy, failing to respond to the early strength in New York, but declining when that market weakened. Philadelphia Rapid Transit led the movement, breaking nearly a point, on rumors of an early assessment. No call will be made, however, before next Spring, as this payment will not be required before July, 1903.
LONDON, Dec. 2. -- With the Consol settlement satisfactorily ended money to-day tended to easier rates. Discounts were fairly steady.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The second annual message of President Roosevelt was sent to Congress to-day. It is as follows: To the Senate and House of Representatives:

NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 2. -- At the blood-stock sales here to-day W.C. Whitney's Ballantrae and Spectrum were both bought in for $21,875 and $18,750 respectively. Frank Gardner's Dakota III, was sold for $9,375.

The gist of the President's recommendations about the trusts is that a case be made up for the Supreme Court. That is what this part of the message comes to, and all that it comes to, when its meaning is distilled out of the phrases of caution and conservatism that he has made the vehicle of its communication to the public.

Salem Howe Wales, who had been for more than half a century identified with various important interests in New York, both public and private, died at his residence, 25 East Fifty-fifth Street, at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. His death was caused by a stroke of apoplexy received one week previous.

CONFLICT OF LAWS. -- A case showing what a curious state of affairs may sometimes arise from the conflict of laws was lately decided in England. A testator domiciled there bequeathed money to the next of kin of a certain person residing in Germany. The next of kin according to the German law was this person's niece, according to the English law his step-sister.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The legislative feature of the day in the Senate was Senator Cullom's Anti-Trust bill, which had been expected and for which the claim has been widely advertised that it would represent the President's ideas of the method of controlling trusts. The fundamental idea of the bill is to bar the transportation of trust-made products from one State to another.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Representative Hull, Chairman of the House Committee on Military Affairs, to-day introduced a bill creating a general staff corps of the United States Army. It provides that the staff be composed of officers detailed from the army at large, under such rules as the President may prescribe.

The following-named volunteer officers are honorably discharged, to take effect Dec. 31: Capts. (Assistant Surgeons) Henry W. Eliot, William W. Calhoun, Robert Boyd, Reuben M. Bonar, Percy L. Jones, Fred W. Palmer, Paul Mazzuri, Thurston Smith, Elwin W. Ames, George A. McHenry, Fred F. Sprague, Arthur D. Prentice, Arthur Jordan, Hyman M. Cohen, and Majors (Surgeons) Joseph N. Henry, George B. Lawrason, and Charles B. Nichols.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 2. -- There will be launched at the Nilson Yacht Building Company's works here next Saturday afternoon the largest private yacht ever built in Baltimore. She will probably be named the Constant, and is being built for Richard P. Hart, a millionaire cattle dealer, now residing in New York.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- Ex-Judge of the Court of Appeals Robert Earl died at his home in Herkimer at 5:30 this morning. He was stricken with paralysis on the evening of Nov. 22 and never rallied.

While a Sheriff's jury was examining witnesses yesterday in the case of Mrs. Louise Beauchamp Hughes, the aged and incompetent widow of David M. Hughes of this city, it was brought out that the old woman had been an intimate friend of the late King Humbert of Italy, of Herr Krupp, the great gunmaker, just dead, and of Garibaldi.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- Developments to-day in the murder of Kate Hassett of Keith's Bijou Theatre stock company, who was shot and killed last night by Barry Johnstone, an actor, formerly with Richard Mansfield's company, indicate that the crime was premeditated.

With one part of the President's message everybody who reads it must sympathize. Everybody, that is to say, except that dwindling band of anti-imperialists who are so worthy of the designation of "Little Americans." Those persons recall the designation of the "Little Englanders" of his time by CHARLES READE, "people who want to make John Bull over again into John Calf."

It is not surprising that the passages of the message of the President which relate to capital and labor should be in a sense academic. Legislation with reference to the subject cannot at present come within the province of the Federal Government, and, if it could, the President has no distinct project to submit.

The selling of St. Paul and Union Pacific was on the reports from Omaha that there "is said to be a grave possibility" that the traffic agreement recently entered into between the companies may be called off even before the date fixed for it to go into effect. If this is so none of the officials of either of the companies here knows anything about it.

Mr. Hermann Hans Wetzler has learned wisdom from the experiences of his first concert a fortnight ago, when the length of his programme came near carrying the end of it over into the next day. Whatever were the circumstances that led him to put such a superabundance of good things into a single evening's performance, the results were of a sort to give pause to the most resolute and the most ambitious of young conductors.

Although President ROOSEVELT suggests no definite measure of legislation in regard to the currency -- and there would probably be little hope of passing one should he urge it never so strongly -- it is gratifying to find him giving his emphatic approval to the principles on which the currency system should gradually be modified.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- The Clearing House rate to-day was 5 per cent. New York funds, 5@10@12 1/2 discount; call loans, 5 1/2@ 6; time money, 5 1/2@6; Clearing House exchanges, $27,296,565; balances, $2,420,674. United States Mining was the leader of the stock market, advancing to 22 3/4. Copper Range sold at one time as high as 57 3/4, but finished at 56.

The Women's Health Protective Association met yesterday to discuss with the Metropolitan Railroad Company men the question of what can be done to relieve the crowding in the cars. The Health Protective women were present and discussed the subject, thrashing it through and through from every standpoint, but the railroad men had nothing to say, for they were not there.

Upon the general subject of the National defense the President has been so exhaustively delivering his views all over the country that the remarks in his message on that topic will not be novel to anybody who reads the newspapers. But the very fact that the remarks are not new makes in favor of their being true.

Mrs. Jennie Leys, widow of the Superintendent of Altman's dry goods store, received from a Supreme Court jury yesterday a verdict of $100,000 on account of the death of her husband in the Park Avenue tunnel wreck last January.
