She sued the New York Central Railroad for $250,000. The amount she gets under the verdict is the largest sum ever awarded in any country in a suit for damages because of death.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- The police tonight divulged the identity of a mysterious prisoner who has been under surveillance at a hospital since last Tuesday night, when he was arrested by Policeman Carroll after a desperate encounter. The man gave his name as Charles Westcott, but admitted it was an alias.

A new system of weights and measures, somewhat similar to the duodecimal system proposed several years ago and almost forgotten, and having many advantages, its author declares, over the metric system now before Congress, was suggested by Sidney A. Reeve, Professor of Mechanical Engineering in the Worcester, Mass., Polytechnic Institute, before the American Society of Mechanical Engineers last night.

The Pennsylvania tunnel franchise was not considered at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. A meeting of the Railroad Committee has been called by Chairman Diemer for 2 o'clock this afternoon. Whether there would be a quorum at the meeting was discussed yesterday at the City Hall.

During most of the day the trading in outside stocks yesterday was accompanied by a steady advance in prices, but during the last hour there were sharp recessions in a number of stocks. This was due to the declines which occurred on the board partly as a result of the advance in call money rates.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Capt. L.B. Purnell of the university hockey team today issued a general call for candidates. The freshmen have been practicing for several weeks. Daily practice in team work, goal shooting, and blocking will be held and every effort made to put a fast team on the ice for the games to be played in Pittsburg during the Christmas holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The path of Mr. Cannon of Illinois to the next Speakership was formally cleared of all obstacles today when Mr. Payne of New York and Mr. Dalzell of Pennsylvania withdrew in his favor. Mr. Dalzell has really been the only candidate in opposition to Mr. Cannon, the candidacy of Mr. Payne and Mr. Littlefield being recognized as hopeless from the start.

Notwithstanding the spectacular character of the raids on the luxurious gambling palaces of Frank Farrell and Richard A. Canfield on Monday night, the net result was found to be of more of a moral than a material character. The evidence obtained by the raids was inconsequential, and it was said that the prisoners held in court very likely will escape prosecution.

That part of President ROOSEVELT's message which relates to the tariff might be called the confessions of a sensitive mind not in unity with itself. The President does dimly see that there are bad spots in the tariff. His native integrity prompts him to suggest correctives, but his native loyalty to party triumphs, and he dismisses the subject by suggesting the "barren ideality" of a tariff commission.

CARLISLE, Penn., Dec. 2. -- James Johnson, who has been the quarter back of the Carlisle Indian football team for the past three years, was to-day elected on first ballot by the members of the eleven as Captain to succeed Capt. Williams, retiring. Johnson received his football training entirely under Coach Glen S. Warner here.

No. 419 East One Hundred and First Street, for a two-story brick workshop, 17 by 40; J. Hunt of 416 East One Hundred and Second Street, owner; S.I. Schwartz of 160 Fifth Avenue, architect; cost. $800.

"To interpret Nature, to untangle Truth, to unfold Humanity" a convention of "advanced thinkers" was held last night at Civic Hall, 128 East Twenty-eighth Street. The hall was crowded with those prepared to put on a common basis all "the health, progress, and reform movements of the United States."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The issue between the Administration and the "Lily Whites "in the South is soon to be brought to a focus, and Senator Pritchard's statement of yesterday clears the way. Mr. Pritchard is about to demand, in the name of the white people of North Carolina, that a white successor be appointed to S.H. Vick, the negro Postmaster at Wilson, N.C.

An ejectment suit that has occupied the attention of the Hudson County courts in Jersey City for ten years was ended yesterday in the Circuit Court, before Judge Henry M. Nevius. The suit was originally brought by John G. Smith against Paul Hailer, but the complainant and defendant have since died.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- In the event of Dr. von Holleben's retirement from the post of Ambassador at Washington, which is considered possible within a year, Emperor William's choice for his successor is Prince Henry XV. of Pless. The Prince returned from the United States, where he attended the dedication of the new building of the New York Chamber of Commerce, with a keen desire to obtain the appointment at Washington when a vacancy occurs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a visitor in a children's ward in one of the large hospitals in this town, and have seen many pitiable cases. The children, while there, are most tenderly cared for, but as soon as they are able they are sent back to their often miserable homes, where the quarters are close, the air bad, and the food worse.

Gov. Odell and his defeated rival, Bird S. Coler, met last night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel for the first time since the election. Their meeting was preceded by an amusing circumstance. Mr. Coler dined at the Fifth Avenue with a friend, and when he emergred from the cafe he was introduced by his friend to ex-Senator Hobart Krum of Schoharie.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Dec. 3 -- The Wilson family troubles are attracting attention again. William Wilson arrived here yesterday looking for an officer to go to Commack and dispossess members of his family.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3. -- It was announced to-night by Capt. J. B. Thomas of the Yale Track Athletic Association, that a dual track meet has been arranged between Yale and the Princeton track team. The meet will be held in this city on May 9 next. The track meet between Harvard and Yale will be held in Cambridge on May 23, and the intercollegiate track meet at Berkeley Oval on May 30.
Rival bowling teams from Newburg and Goshen, N.Y., respectively, met in a match game at Thum's White Elephant Alleys last night, and the Newburg bowlers won three straight games. The scores follow:

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 3 -- The anthracite coal companies and their employes having failed to come to an agreement during the Thanksgiving recess of the Strike Commission, the hearing of the miners' side of the case was continued to-day as heretofore, and, unless something is done by the lawyers on both sides to curtail matters, its proceedings will surely run into next year.
WASHINGTON, Dee. 3 -- The Senate Committee on Territories to-day agreed to report a substitute for the House Omnibus Statehood bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Thomas B. Reed is ill with catarrhal appendicitis. On Monday Mr. Reed was ailing and called at Dr. F.A. Gardiner's office complaining of gastric distress. On Tuesday his physician compelled him to remain in bed and made a diagnosis of appendicitis.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Notwithstanding the repayment of a large amount due to the Bank of England rates for money were easier to-day and supplies were more abundant owing to the release of the money paid out by the International Mercantile Marine Company and to Government disbursements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Yesterday the President's message was read, and in it was a clause suggesting that anthracite coal be placed on the free list. To-day the first legislation in line with that suggestion was offered. It was presented by Mr. Gaines, (Dem., Tenn.,) and Mr. Cannon of Illinois objected to its consideration.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Great Britain and Germany, according to official statements made here yesterday, have commenced punitive measures against Venezuela.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- While Yuan-Shi-Kai, the Viceroy of Pe-chi-Li, was at Shanghai, says The Times's correspondent in that city, he had an interview with a prominent foreign official, and intimated to him that China had decided to repudiate payment of the indemnity in gold and to limit her liability to 450,000,000 Haikwan taels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The statistician of the Department of Agriculture estimates the actual growth of cotton in the United States in the year 1902-3 as 10,417,000 bales of an average net weight of 490.7 pounds.
Extra dividends declared by the Commercial Cable Company, Maryland Coal Company, and Boston and Albany Railroad, as well as the regular payments.

At the regular meeting of the City Club last night, Horace E. Deming, Chairman of the committee on the city's water supply, declared that the waste of the water in the city was of the most startling nature.

In reply to a letter inviting him to become a member of the Civil Service Reform Association, Justice Hinsdale of the Court of Special Sessions last night addressed a communication to Everett V. Abbot, Chairman of the Committee on Membership of that organization, in which he declined the invitation and stated his reasons for doing so.

Activity in the outside market yesterday was confined to a very few stocks, and the improvement which had occurred in the market on Tuesday was followed by a selling movement which brought about reactions in most of the active issues. A few gains were recorded, but they were far outnumbered by the stocks which showed at least fractional declines.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association continued in session at the Muray Hill Hotel yesterday, and a number of decisions were rendered after the close of the executive session in the evening. The most important of these was in regard to the Elderone case, regarding which the following statement was made:

The foreign telegrams announce that Dr. ASSER, the Dutch jurist who arbitrated the claims of American sealers for damages by Russia's seizures, has awarded them in excess of $100,000. To the individuals concerned the money was the thing. To Americans at large the point of interest is the principle involved.

ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 3 -- The Naval Academy will lose by graduation four, and perhaps six, of its regular members of the football team of this season. In accordance with a recent order of the Navy Department, the first class will graduate in February next and the second in June following.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I. The United States Government withdrew from Cuba without first securing the latter's trade -- one of the richest in the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has decided to resume consideration of the reciprocity treaties which were authorized under the Dingley Tariff act in 1897. These treaties were negotiated during 1899 by Mr. John A. Kasson, the special Commissioner Plenipotentiary appointed by President Mckinley for that duty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The amendment which Senator Lodge proposes to offer to the Consular and Diplomatic bill when it comes from the House, and which is intended to reorganize the Consular system, will in all probability pass the Senate. Mr. Lodge has had assurance of strong support for the measure, which leads him to believe its passage a foregone conclusion.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- At a meeting yesterday of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, says The Times, Sir Alfred L. Jones, the President of the Chamber, read a letter from Asa Thompson of Gainesville, Ga., in reference to the West African cotton-growing experiments.

S. Osgood Pell Co. have sold for William M. Benjamin to Derrick Lane the plot of three lots on the north side of Eighty-eighth Street, 200 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 75 by 100.8. Mr. Benjamin bought this property about a month ago from the City Real Property Investing Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read the speech made by Gov. Odell wherein he warns the local leaders, and I do not think that was necessary, because the Governor knows right well the reason for the slump in the Republican ticket. Let him help Mayor Low to modify the civil service rules and put the people in office that the people voted for in electing Mayor Low.

The comments of the Citizens' Union in its review of the first year's work of the reform administration include mention of the Department of Water, Gas, and Electricity in language so guarded as to suggest that the results of reorganization are still so far indeterminate as to leave it still a matter of doubt whether in this detail the city is to be congratulated on the changes due to the success of the Fusion movement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's issue of THE TIMES, in a letter under the heading, "Heads I Win; Tails You Lose," the writer relates a conversation he overheard about two young lawyers. The one, "Roe," loses at cards to "Doe" $50. They make an agreement the money will not be payable until Roe will win his first lawsuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- On Friday the London Dock bill will be taken up in the House. The majority of the Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce has made a favorable report on it. but there is a minority report in the negative, signed by Col. Hepburn of Iowa and Mr. Sherman of New York.

All afternoon yesterday and until late last night the members of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, in their annual meeting at the Sturtevant House, argued for and against a revision of the standard of weights and measures in use in the United States. The debates were spirited and at times somewhat acrimonious.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Practically the whole policy of the Post Office Department, in its recent classification reforms, is involved in three decisions rendered to-day by the District Court of Appeals. In two of the cases the decisions are against the Post Office Department and in the other the Government is sustained.

Eben M. Betts, an insurance man with an office at 1 Madison Avenue, is the defendant in a suit for absolute divorce brought by Mrs. Louise Betts. He is sixty-four years old, and she is two years his junior. They were married only a year and a quarter ago. According to the plaintiff, she gave her husband $25,000 in cash and jewels worth $2,000 within thirty days after the wedding ceremony.

Canal men, merchants, and friends of the Erie Canal improvement, who have most attentively studied the problem, and are best acquainted with its elements, are in substantial agreement as to Engineer BOND'S plan for diverting the Erie Canal by the Oneida River to Lake Ontario, using the waters of the lake for 112 miles and returning to the present Erie Canal west of Lockport.
To the Editor of The New York Times: If the account published in your issue of this morning under the heading "A Double Case of Heads I Win," c., is true, history certainly repeats itself.

W.S. Vanderbilt Allen, the artist, and great-grandson of Commodore Vanderbilt, was released yesterday from the private sanitarium of Dr. F. D. Ruland, in Westport, Conn., where he had been confined for six years, and he will remain a free man during the next six or eight weeks at least.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The Pennsylvania Railroad Company operates more than 10,000 miles of railway. It transports inter-State, transcontinental, and international traffic. The company wishes to connect its lines upon Long Island with its continental system by tunnels under the North and East Rivers and the Borough of Manhattan.

The New York Board of Trade and Transportation at its meeting yesterday decided to ask the Board of Aldermen to approve speedily the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel franchise. Oscar S. Straus presided, and there was an unusually large attendance. The resolutions in favor of the approval of the tunnel franchise, offered by William McCarroll, and adopted unanimously were:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- In his annual report made public to-day, Secretary Wilson of the Department of Agriculture gives some interesting figures illustrative of the magnitude of the argricultural industry in the United States. The latest statistics available on the subject show that the fixed capital of agriculture in this country is about twenty billions of dollars, or four times that invested in manufactures.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3 -- The French Club of Yale University, composed of undergraduate students, to-night enacted publicly the three act comedy by Eugene Labiche, entitled, "Les Vivacities du Capitaine Tic." The comedy was played in College Street Hall. The audience of several hundred, including many professors and students, received the piece enthusiastically.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The Education bill was finally passed by the House of Commons yesterday by 246 votes to 123.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- The Clearing House rate to-day was 5 per cent.; New York funds, 15 cents discount; call loans, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; time money, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $25,437,766; balances, $1,014,955. The stock market was rather slow and narrow, and closed generally weak.

The big meet of amateur athletes, announced by the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association, to be held in Madison Square Garden on Dec. 27, is responsible for remarkable activity in all the local clubs. Men are training for the games in unprecedented numbers, and, while, all contests will be restricted to amateurs, the preparations being made are as rigorous as would be exacted of professionals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Navy Department has made public the conditions of the naval search problem on which the combined European, North Atlantic, and South Atlantic fleets are to begin work tomorrow in the West Indies. The details of the squadron organization already have been made public, and the announcement to-day concerns the rules which are to govern in this mimic warfare.

The greater part of the two sessions of the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday was taken up with the Investigation of the case of the association against W.R. Cox of Nashua, N.H., and William O'Neil of Lexington, Mass.. who were charged with being implicated in the fixing of a race at the Nashua (N. H. ( Fair last July.

Daniel Birdsall Co. have sold for the estate of the late ex-Mayor William L. Strong the three three-story dwellings at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, on plot 90.11 by 72, and, for F. Mason North, the adjoining house, 1,961 Madison Avenue, 10.6 by $9.

COMMITTING FOR CONTEMPT. -- A summary order of commitment for contempt will not be issued against a lawyer who has collected and failed to account for moneys belonging to his client, when it is shown that the attorney is in destitute circumstances. Such an order would be futile, Justice Scott of the Supreme Court yesterday held.

Upon the recommendation of its Committee on Finance and Currency, of which two ex-Secretaries of the Treasury are members, the Chamber of Commerce yesterday indorsed a series of proposed amendments to the banking and currency laws of the United States which are to be presented by the committee in person to President Roosevelt.

At Marshall Field, "Chicago, to-morrow afternoon, an interesting football game for interscholastic honors will be decided between youthful players from the Brooklyn polytechnic Preparatory School and the Hyde Park High School of Chicago. The Brooklyn team, with six substitutes in charge of Prof,' Charles P. Dudley and Coach Aubut, accompanied by several alumni and students of the " Poly Prep," left yesterday for Chicago over the Delaware and Lackawanna Railroad.

The scene in the vicinity of the historic old Fraunces Tavern in lower Broad Street yesterday afternoon presented a curious study in contrasts. Since the days when the famous old taproom was the resort of Gen. Washington and his men -- the aristocratic rendezvous of the aristocracy of brains and valor -- things have changed considerably with this historic place.

Trading in the outside market yesterday reflected the same conditions which had influenced the market on Wednesday. The further declines which were recorded in the Stock Exchange market prevented any expansion in trading in outside stocks, for the reason that it unfavorably affected sentiment and made the public, and traders as well, unwilling to assume the responsibility of buying stocks.

As bearing upon a subject discussed at some length in our issue of yesterday, we learn with satisfaction that the commission appointed by the Mayor, consisting of Messrs. FREEMAN, BURR, and HERRING, to consider and report upon the water supply of New York, will first investigate and report upon the existing waste and the possible and practicable means of preventing it.

So far as can be determined from the debates in the House of Commons and the discussion in the press, the Education bill which has just gone to the Lords, and had its first reading before three noble members of that illustrious legislative body, is a thoroughly English measure.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4. -- Shoo Fly and Prince Blazes were the winning favorites and after his race the latter was run up to $1,100 and bought in by his owners, Durnell Herz. Sarner was claimed out of the second race by Mrs. C.E. Durnell for $700. On account of her temper, the stewards Have ordered the refusal of further entries of the mare Nannie J. Weather clear and cool, track mudy.

In its letter to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment relative to restoring Park Avenue to the public use and making other necessary improvements in its New York terminal, the Central Railroad management says, with the worthy pride born of conscious rectitude and the impulse of noble self-sacrifice:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The leading sensation to-day in connection with the Statehood contest was the publication of the fact that Senator Quay had written a letter last Summer advising the Statehood leaders of Arizona to see to it that that Territory went Democratic in the recent National elections if they wanted the Senate to pass the Statehood bill.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- The Hudson River Water Power, Company will on Dec. 23 consider the proposition to increase its menital stock from $2,000,000 to $5,000,000.

There is one of the relatively minor suggestions as to the currency in the report of the Secretary of the Treasury which is so practical and of so much importance to the business community that we trust the Senate will this session pay attention to it.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 -- J.F. Stevens, General Manager of the Great Northern Railway, said to-day that he was in ignorance of J.J. Hill's intentions regarding entering the Canadian wheat belt. Personally, however, he believed there was room for several lines there. That country in a few years would be producing a billion bushels.

NEWARK, Dec. 4 -- Sergeant Brown of the Fourth Police Precinct was the only male passenger in a Clinton Avenue trolley car this morning when the twelve women in it were frightened by mice that one of their number brought in unconsciously. At Bergen Street the woman who caused the commotion boarded the car.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Although the regular public receptions by the women of the Cabinet will not be resumed until the first Wednesday of January, a number of these hostesses were at home to visitors this afternoon. Mrs. Hay, wife of the Secretary of State, receiving for the first time in eighteen months.

"WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The Japanese Minister called at the State Department in haste to-day to communicate to Secretary Hay a cablegram he had received from the Minister for Foreign Affairs at Tokio stating that while Minister Buck was on a hunting trip this morning he was taken suddenly ill and expired.

Charles F. Murphy, the new leader of Tammany Hall, stood last evening near the large mantelpiece in the red room of the Democratic Club in the identical place where for several years the faithful followers of Richard Croker gathered almost nightly to pay homage and seek positions and power.

Mystery which surrounds the death of George L. Leyh, the wealthy trussmaker who died Tuesday at his home, 73 Broadway, Williamsburg, after taking a drink of poisoned beer, was complicated yesterday by the disappearance of Robert Westphal, the fourteen-year-old office boy, who was the only person in Leyh's presence when he drank the liquid.

Yesterday's total Stock Exchange transactions fell below 400,000 shares. This reflects the speculative indisposition of professional traders as well as the public. Few changes of consequence took place in quotations. Here and there a few stocks went up or went down as much as a whole point; but the market as a whole stood almost still.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Harry Ruit, a thirteen-year-old lad employed as a riveter's helper at the American Locomotive Works in South Paterson, met a horrible death early this morning, as the result of a prank played upon him by some youthful companions. These, five in number, are now held without bail on a charge of homicide.

Deep poverty because of idleness inforced by the long strike was the excuse made by David J. Flynn, twenty-nine years old, at 581 First Avenue, when charged before Magistrate Crane in the Yorkville Court yesterday with stealing a ton of coal, which he should have delivered at the residence of the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, rector of Trinity Parish, at 27 West Twenty-fifth Street, adjoining Trinity Chapel.

Thomas A. Edison, in inventor, was called yesterday as a witness before Commissioner Shields, sitting as a master in an action brought by the New York Phonographic Company against the National Phonographic Company, the latter being one of the Edison companies, claiming to hold all the selling rights for phonographs made under the inventor's patents.

PORT OF SPAIN, Island of Trinidad, Dec. 4 -- The United States Consul has been authoritatively informed through agents of the departure this morning of the "enemy's" squadron under Rear Admiral Sumner. Its destination is uncertain, but is believed to be Porto Rico or Culebra. The ships passed through Boca Grande, going slowly.

The New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company yesterday presented to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment new plans for the improvement of terminal facilities in this city which it is believed will be acceptable to the authorities and satisfactory to the public.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The new yacht Shamrock III., in course of construction by Sir Thomas Lipton as the challenger for the America's Cup in the international race of 1903, had a narrow escape from being destroyed by fire, which caused much damage in Denny's shipbuilding yards at Dumbarton to-night.

Mr. Ossip Gabrilowitsch since his return to America after an absence of a year has shown a considerable growth in his art, a broader outlook, a mellower and maturer style. This has been the testimony of his playing so far in New York in concerted music, and it was confirmed yesterday afternoon by his recital at Daly's Theatre, the first he has given here upon his present visit to America.

SCHENECTADY, Dec. 4. -- In special term of Supreme Court at Albany this afternoon, Justice Wesley O. Howard granted an injunction restraining the Painters' Union, No. 20, of this city, from in any way treating William Potter as not a member of the union.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4. -- "The Cavalier," the dramatization by Paul Kesier of George W. Cable's romance of that name, was presented here by Julia, Marlowe and company to-night for the first time. The play was well received and Miss Marlowe was repeatedly called to the curtain by an enthusiastic house.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4. -- John R. Dewitt, 1904, the big guard who did such good work for the Princeton football team, this evening was elected unanimously to the Captaincy for next year. DeWitt lives in Rieglesvllle, Penn., and is twenty-one years of age. He has played on the University eleven for the past two years at tackle and guard respectively.

Mrs. Anna Haight, thirty-five years, wife of James Haight, mining engineer, and formerly of Pittsburgh, last evening leaped from a second-story window of the Von Hoffman apartment house, 29 West Twenty-sixth Street, into the street. The police of the West Thirtieth Street Station declare that the woman was laboring under a temporary aberration of the mind.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Money was comparatively easy in the market to-day. Discounts were unsteady, chiefly owing to the improvement of the rates of Continental exchanges.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The Chamber of Deputies ratified to-day an additional monatary convention between France, Italy, Belgium; and Switzerland, authorizing each country to issue additional silver coins to the value of $2,500,000.

In the tournament of the New York Royal Arcanum bowling league last night the Colfax Council bowlers won two games, defeating the New York Council and the Metropolitan Council teams, the latter by a single pin after a tie. The scores follow;

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 4. -- At the session of the Anthracite Strike Commission to-day the representatives of the mine workers continued to call witnesses, mostly practical miners, who told their, story of conditions as they exist in the Hazleton, or Middle, coal fields.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Sanitary Conference of the American Republics, which has been in session here since Tuesday, came to an end to-night. Santiago de Chile, was selected as the next place of meeting, which will occur March 15, 1904.

Peace has been patched up in the Republican County organization, which hereafter will be under the dual direction of Senator Thomas C. Platt and Gov. Odell, with Robert C. Morris as executive officer to carry out the plans which Senator Platt and Gov. Odell may agree upon as best calculated to promote party success.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- There is an inclination to mark up call money, and many banks are now quoting 5 1/2 per cent, as the best figure at which they will make loans. The demand for time money is relatively light, and rates are mostly nominal, Sterling exchange is quiet and showing a slightly easier tone.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Fourteen persons among the scores crowded into the Lincoln Hotel, at 176 Madison Street, met death by fire just before 6 o'clock this morning. Some perished in their rooms, some chanced all in jumping, and lost, while others were found in the hallways, where they had expired with their fingers dug into the cracks of the floor.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Ninety-seven thousand inhabitants of the Grande Chartreuse district, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, have signed a petition to Parliament asking for authorization for the monastery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The condition of ex-Speaker Reed to-night is regarded by his physicians as critical. He is now suffering from well-developed uremia, the result of a pre-existing inflammation of the kidneys. The outlook is very grave. The appendicitis feature is entirely eliminated from the case so far as being a factor in the production of any symptom is concerned.

It seams that the Shipping bill which the devoted Mr. FRVE piloted with great difficulty, but with success, through the Senate last session has gone the road to dusty death in the pigeon holes of the House committee. Its demise was foreshadowed by the conspicuous absence of all mention of it in the message of the President.

Several changes in the Columbia Yacht Club were proposed at a gathering of more than one hundred of its members at Healy's, Sixty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue, last evening. The speeches after the "beefsteak dinner" developed the fact that there has been considerable dissension in the club for several months and that a recent effort to bring about certain reforms was frustrated.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 4 -- The Indiana Company, capital $1,000,000, with $300,000 paid in, filed papers of incorporation here to-day to construct railways and, electric light plants in Indiana. The incorporators are Thomas Dolan, Randall Morgan, Franklin H. MacMorris, Clinton N. Latourette, and George H. Martin.

E.B. Thomas, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Erie Railroad, was elected President of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company yesterday, succeeding Alfred Walter, whose resignation took effect on Monday. The election was held at a special meeting of the Directors in Philadelphia, and the announcement made at the offices of the company in this city, where it was stated that Mr. Thomas had also been elected President of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company.

Col. George R. Dyer of the Twelfth Regiment, and Col. David E. Austen of the Thirteenth Regiment, formally announced to Col. Charles H. Luscomb yesterday their decisions that their regiments should not appear nor compete in the tournament of the Military Athletic League, to be held in the Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Gen. Bates, Paymaster General of the army, has sent a communication to Adjt. Gen. Corbin in regard to the army canteen question, in which he says:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: One or two critics, in writing of "The Last Word," with otherwise kindly commendation, have pointed out that it takes much too rosy a view of the prospect opening before a young woman who "goes to New York to succeed in Journalism." These gentlemen evidently fear that such a tract as "The Last Word" will flood the Eastern market with feminine Journalists incompetence.

Recent investigations by the Vicomte de Spoelberch ds Lovenjoul, a Balzac scholar, show that Honore de Balzac's ancestors were not natives of Tourraine, as has been often stated. Balzac's father, BernardFrancois Balzac was born in the hamlet of La Nougayrie, in the Canton of Monestier, "arrondissement" of Albi, the scion of an old Albigenses family.

It was announced yesterday by the law firm of Black, Olcott, Gruber Bonynge, of which ex-Gov. Frank S. Black is senior member, that they had accepted a retainer from the owners of the property at 33 West Thirty-third Street -- commonly regarded as Frank Farrell's gambling house -- and that action would be taken against those responsible for the raid on those premises on last Monday night.

Another of the outworn operas of the Italian list was taken down from the shelf and dusted off last evening, when "Rigoletto" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House. It rested in oblivion last year; two years ago it was revived for the appearance of Mme. Melba in the heroine's part, but it has chiefly been reserved at the Opera House for the patrons of the Saturday night popular performances.

This is the rush season in the book stores; the only time they are uncomfortably crowded. There are few indications of the change in the appearance of the stores themselves, except the Christmas cards and calendars in the windows and festooning walls, columns, and ceiling. But the treasures displayed on the counters and in the cases seem to grow in esteem yearly with the buyers of holiday gifts.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Money was fairly plentiful in the market to-day, but rates were harder. Discounts were firmer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The War Department to-day issued an order providing for the exchange of fifteen Philippine regiments with the same number of troops in the United States.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5. -- Jack Demund was the only beaten favorite to-day. In tiie last race Nobleman stumbled and fell, breaking his leg and had to be killed. There was a general mix-up in the handicap, and Haack, on Jessie Jarboe, was suspended for two weeks for rough riding. The mare was disqualified and second place was given to Jack Demund.

WHAT could be better for beginning a list of children's books for the holiday season than that dear old classic "The Night Before Christmas"? As thoughts turn to holly and mistietoe and Christmas good cheer and good-will the dear old rhymes appear each year in a little more attractive form than the last, and are heartily welcomed by the children of a larger as well as those of a smaller growth.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I want to give nearly as he wrote it an opinion of "The Virginian," written by a young man familiar with life as it is in Wyoming, in the Sierras, and on the great plains of the Southwest, I had written him in unmeasured praise of a book that has given me more satisfaction than any novel I have read in a long time.

W.H. Paige, attorney for the assignee of The Daily Telegraph, which has been sold, together with The Metropolitan Magazine, for $100,000, yesterday gave out the following statement in regard to the sale:

It is a notable thing when the Chamber of Commerce adopts with but a single negative vote recommendations so definite and in a way so radical as those adopted on Thursday with reference to National finance. It is almost a truism in a representative Government that the laws regulating business must reflect the general opinion.

BELOW will be found two lists of books suitable for holiday gifts, published, in accordance with the regular custom of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS. These lists include books issued since Jan. 1 of this year, and are chosen mainly for their value as gift or holiday books.

THE efforts of the authors of American Animals was to make a work "sufficiently free from technicalities to appeal to the general reader, and at the same time to include such scientific informstion relative to our North American mammals as would be desired by one beginning their study."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In "The Life of William Dampier," the great buccaneer of 1584 and thereabouts, is the following: "It may be remembered that when Capt. Watling and his company escaped from Joan Fernandez, three years before, they left a Mosquito Indian on the island, who was out hunting goats when the alarm came.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Twenty barges and canalboats line the shores of the Hudson from Hastings to Dobbs Ferry. Two men have been drowned, two are missing, two are in the Dobbs Ferry Hospital, while one man has pone to New York in a condition that should render him a fit subject for hospital treatment.

The effect of the real scarcity of coal in this city, notwithstanding the promises of dealers and operators that there would be plenty once mining was resumed, was accentuated by the cold snap yesterday. Dealers were in receipt of all sorts of messages asking why coal ordered several weeks ago had not been delivered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Italian Ambassador and Mme. Mayor des Planches entertained at dinner this evening the British Ambassador and Lady Herbert, the Princess Suasa of Rome, and the Marquise de Talleyrand of Paris, with their hosts, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Walsh, the First Secretary of the French Embassy and Mme. de Margerie, the Minister from the Netherlands, Mr. Hansen of the Russian Embassy, and Count Gherardesca of the Italian Embassy.

The eleventh annual exhibition of fine book bindings began at Bonaventure's on Dec. 1, and will continue until the 8th. As usual, the showing of French bindings was particularly strong. Pomey was represented by a beautiful (modern) book of hours in chiseled leather, upon which a griffin and a dolphin appeared as supporters on either side of a sacred tree, all being in rather high relief.

When a District Attorney wishes to make an evening call upon a great gambler, should he seek ingress by the door or by the window? This is a question of profound interest to the students of the usages of good society.

AT THE ninth annual banquet of the Edinburgh Sir Walter Scott Club, Nov. 15, Augustine Birrell was elected President for the ensuing year. Sir Henry Craik, the retiring President, delivered a noteworthy address on the influence of Scott, from which the following significant passages are extracted:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Apropos of Mr. Alden's very just remarks on the work of the writer calling himself Jack London, it seems to me only fair to the reading public that an announcement should be made of the true character of that writer's work from the standpoint of truth to local color.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The Rome correspondent of The Times says that the expropriation clause of the Municipalization of Public Services bill, as amended in committee, proves that Signor Giolitti (Minister of the Interior) has a genuine desire to redeem his promise to protect capital, whether foreign or Italian, invested in existing enterprises.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5. -- Jan. 1 the $1,800,000 7 per cent. bonds of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Indianapolis Railroad mature. These bonds will be paid off by the company, and holders will be offered new first mortgage refunding 4 per cent. bonds. The basis of exchange, however, has as yet not been announced.

The death on Monday, Nov. 24, of Myron B. Benton, at his artistic residence, Troutbeek, in the village of Leedsville, (Amenia Township,) Dutchess County, N.Y., removes a unique personality -- a gentleman of the rarest quality, a modest author, who wrote poetry and prose that some authors of resounding fame could not equal.

PIAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 6. -- All traffic on the main line of the Central Railroad of New Jersey is blocked by head-on collision between two freight trains, which occurred at Raceland, about eight miles from here, at 11:30 o'clock last night.

During the Horse Show Mrs. Mary Washington Bond Morosini, wife of Attillo P. Morosini and daughter-in-law of Giovanni P. Morosini the millionaire banker, attracted a good deal of attention by her lavish display of gems. An enterprising burglar on Thursday evening made a determined but unsuccessful effort to secure possession of the brilliants that the society reporters had described.

This is the rush season in the book stores; the only time they are uncomfortably crowded. There are few indications of the change in the appearance of the stores themselves, except the Christmas cards and calendars in the windows and festooning walls, columns, and ceiling. But the treasures displayed on the counters and in the cases seem to grow in esteem yearly with the buyers of holiday gifts.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 5. -- At 2 o'clock this morning Dr. Caroline H. Marsh of 79 Livingston Street, was awakened by a noise in her room, and she saw the figure of a man moving about. She reached under her pillow for her revolver, then sprang out of bed and grabbed the burglar.

IN HER preface the author of this sprightly volume explains that she has had no experience in writing, but from an altruistic desire to open a window to "shut has done her best to describe the varied life of the foreign lands she has visited in the course of her journey from London to Moscow.

Enthusiasm was at a low ebb in the outside market yesterday, and it was only in a few stocks that there was any activity at all. Several of the copper stocks which had been relatively quiet for some days were again taken in hand and advanced on active trading. In other parts of the list also there was some improvement, but these advances were to a considerable extent offset by the declines which occurred elsewhere.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 5. -- At the Orange Memorial Hospital this morning the supply of coal was only enough to last until tomorrow. The hospital authorities were unable to purchase any, and accordingly an appeal was made to house holders who have a supply. In response some coal has been sent the hospital, which now has enough to last until Sunday.

Miss Woods has written her book, "Edges," after the manner of the impressionists -- in spots. One might almost call it a collection of little literary scraps rather loosely strung together. Her heroine is distinctly posterish, with her hair "like a sullen blood-stain wine-red at the edges," and her gray-green eyes.

The Rev. Whitwell Elwin, author of "Some Eighteenth Century Men of Letters," just published in London, with an introduction and memoir by his son. Warwick Elwin, was once editor of the famous Quarterly Review. He was also a friend of W.M. Thackeray. Their friendship, says The London Globe, dated from 1854, when Thackeray contributed to The Quarterly (which Elwin had just begun to edit) an essay on Leech's drawings in Punch.

BRESLAU, Dec. 5. -- Emperor William, addressing a deputation of workingmen today, made a bitter anti-Socialist speech, declaring it was a lie to say that the workmen had to rely on the Socialist Party for the improvement of their position. The Socialists, he adaed, had terrorized and trod the workingmen under foot, and as men of honor the workmen must have no more to do with them.

W.L. Courtney in The London Daily Telegraph. Many years ago, before he took to politics and thought that the great problem of the age was decentralization and the encouragement at provincial, as contrasted with Parisian, life, M. Anatole France, one of the greatest of contemporary French authors, wrote "Le Crime de M. Sylvestre Bonnard" and "Le Livre de mon Ami."

Saturday, Dec. 20, Messrs. Sotheby win sell in London an interesting collection which includes a number of important relics, drawings, and autograph letters of W. M. Thackeray. The latter are only thirty in all, but they are certain to attract more attention than many recent sales with thirty times that number of lots.

Two apt quotations find places on Mr. E.P. Roberts's title page to "The Adventures of Captain John Smith." We credit Mark Twain with the first one. "Truth is stranger than fiction, for fiction is obliged to stick to probability, and truth ain't." The other is Thackerayan. "Oh, dear me, child!" said Lady Maria, "what a pity it is that he should have the horrid name of Mr. Smith!"

SIR HORACE RUMBOLD, lately British Ambassador at Vienna has just published in London "A Diplomatist's Recollections." The latest date touched upon is 1873. Sir Horace was born in Calcutta, brought up in Paris and the South of France.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The "book of the week," naturally, is Gen. De Wet's long-awaited "Three Years' War," which is reviewed at great length in all the newspapers.

Prof George Albert Coe, in his book on "The Religion of a Mature Mind," sets himself the task of meeting as a Christian philosopher the "thought movements" of the time, the essential justice of which he regards as already established. These movements are presented as follows:

VEDANTA philosophy is erpounded in a little book by Swami Abhedananda on the principles of the Yoga, as applied to the Vedanta. For Christians interested in foreign missions this book is of moment, as showing the method of reasoning which they must be prepared to meet if they are to influence the educated Hindu.

THOSE who cry "Plagiarism!" whensoever they detect a chance resemblance will hardly be able to refrain if they read Mr. A.E.W. Mason's "The Four Feathers," and remember Miss Maud Howard Peterson's "The Potter and the Clay."
Mrs. MARY HOLLINGSWORTH MORRIS DAVIS, widow of Henry Winter Davis, the Maryland statesman, died yesterday in Baltimore from ailments incident to old age.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 5. -- The lawyers for the mine workers continued to call witnesses to-day before the Strike Commission to testify to the alleged blacklisting methods pursued by several coal companies in refusing to reemploy strikers who took a more or less prominent part in the affairs of the mine workers' union during the recent suspension.

Presumably Gen. Christian Rudolf De Wet's book is "the book of the week," one that arrests attention in spite of the absorbing literary topic of the hour, holiday books, to a consideration of which, from various points of view, this number of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW is largely devoted.

BELOW will be found two lists of books suitable for holiday gifts, published in accordance with the regular custom of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS. These lists include books issued since Jan. 1 of this year, and are chosen mainly for their value as gift or holiday books.

From the point of view of the City and of its householders that solution of the Fourth Avenue tunnel problem would be best which should depress the yard and tracks all the way from the Grand Central Station to about Ninetieth Street, and completely close Park Avenue over them, so that the surface of that thoroughfare would be wholly open to use and travel, like Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The first move in the anti-trust campaign was made today, when the Committee on Judiciary met and took up the question. The central figure of the occasion was Mr. Littlefield of Maine, who made his first appearance as Chairman of a sub-committee to which had been referred the Littlefield "Publicity" bill.
ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 5. -- Capt, Charles Rose and Chester Howell were overcome this afternoon while crossing Great South Bay by the fumes from the gasoline used to drive their launch.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I was much pleased with Mr. Alden's caustic arraignment of Gorky and D'Annunzio in your last number. I was surprised, however, to come across a concession on Mr. Alden's part, which virtually takes the sting out of his frank censure of a school of literature, whose vogue has no excusable justification in the plea that it is after all the product of genius.

The stock market of yesterday was scarcely worthy of the name. Total dealings dwindled to still lower figures than the day previous, approximating barely 350,000 shares, and these were largely the result of the professional operators who for the moment are in control of the market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The test fight over the "Lily White" issue has begun. As already stated, it is in the case of Samuel H. Vick, the negro Postmaster at Wilson, N.C., whom Senator Pritchard desires to have replaced by a white Republican. President Roosevelt is to decide whether he will uphold Senator Pritchard and the Republican organization in North Carolina or allow the colored Postmaster to retain his place.

Robert J. Thompson has compiled and publishes for himself, in Chicago, a book of 368 pages called "The Proof of Life After Death." This is described as "an assembly and collation of letters and expressions from eminent scientists and thinkers of the world, giving the strongest and best reasons known to the world to-day, as substantial evidence of the continued existence of the soul after death."

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times says that the local committees which were appointed to inquire into the condition of agriculture, and which have been voicing the widespread discontent with political and economic conditions in Russia, are now being made to suffer.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I. THE present is invariably prosaic: it is only the past and the future that are poetic. Before we reach the half-century make in our earthly pilgrimage.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In a somewhat extended review of "The Confessions of a Wife" your critic assumes and asserts that Dana's illness, the morphine disease -- disease, not "habit" -- was caused by Mama's nagging, and so driving him to that drug.

Dr. Herman Knapp, in the Hosack Hall of the New York Academy of Medicine, last night delivered a discourse on the structure of the eye and ear to show the importance those branches of surgery and also of the purposed enlargement of the New York Ophthalmie and Aural Institute, under the auspices of the Trustees of which the lecture was held.

BAHIA, Dec. 5. -- The British bark Prooyon, Capt. James, which sailed from San Francisco Aug. 10 bound to Queenstown, has put into this port with loss of her compass boat, and some sails. She reports having jettisoned thirty tons of her cargo. While mooring here she went aground and lost anchor and chain. She is leaking at the rate of half an inch per hour.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A friend kindly called my attention to an article in yours of Nov. 22, which in a busy week I had not noticed, entitled "A Poem by Hervey." The assertion that T.K. Hervey was the author of the poem. "I Know Thou Hast Gone to the Home of Thy Rest," appeared about forty years ago in The Boston Transcript.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- At a Cabinet Council held at the Elysee Palace to-day Premier Combes announced that he had suspended the salaries of the Archbishop of Besancon and the Bishops of Orleans and Sees, in connection with the action of the greater part or the French Episcopate in signing the recent manifesto for presentation to the Senate and Chamber of Deputies.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- The local monetary situation is, as compared with conditions in New York, quite comfortable. The banks are fairly well supplied with money and are ready to take care of their customers, but are not inclined to do much in the outside market. Call money is loaning mostly at 5 1/2 per cent., and the minimum on time money, excepting in special cases, is 6 per cent.

Two of the first weekly periChristmas odicals to make their appearWeeklies, ance in holiday dress are Harper's and Collier's. The former spreads itself over a hundred pages in illustrations and reading matter. For the current number the usual editorial paragraph section has been dropped, and its place is taken up by what is probably the most conspicuous collection of short stories and color illustrations which has ever appeared in a weekly magazine.

The Clarence apartment house, at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, has been sold to Leslie R. Palmer, President of the Knickerbocker Mortgage and Realty Company. The property has frontages of 100 feet on Sixth Avenue and about 70 feet on Fifty-eighth Street.

Coney Islanders were badly scared yesterday by Topsy, the elephant, whose home is at Luna Park, to which she was committed when she became too vicious for exhibition purposes in a circus several years ago. It was all the fault of Frederick Ault, known as "Whitey," who has been the animal's keeper for over a decade, and is the only person who can handle Topsy.

In consequence of the amount of time spent on the sensational cases of Wednesday and yesterday, the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association, in session at the Murray Hill Hotel, failed to clear its docket yesterday, as originally expected, and in consequence will sit to-day, prolonging its session into the evening if necessary, as the out-of-town members do not wish to remain in the city over Sunday.

Miss Hartshorne's book on Japan vividly reproduces the country and people, and has the power of making us see and enjoy. From, the inevitable "jinrikisha" ride, to the visits to shrines and temples, and the flower festivals, and to the full, fragrant, and artistic life of the people -- it is all to be found in freshness and charm in these pages.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 5. -- The three-masted schooners William D. Hilton and Melville Phillips, together with several smaller craft, were blown ashore in the harbor and lower bay. The tug Underwriter, which, was towing the wrecked Wesley M. Oler

The examination of talesmen in the case of Thomas Tobin, a bartender, who is on trial in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, on a charge of murder in the first degree, was interrupted yesterday afternoon after nine seats in the jury box had been filled. The cause of the interruption was an outbreak by Tobin while Abraham Levy, his counsel, was examining a talesman.

Mr. Jack London, in his romances naving to do with life in the extreme North, gives us some slight idea of the dogs which draw his heroines over the snowy distances. A good many of us who love the dog have long wanted to know the precise kind of canine on whom, the voyager depended when undertaking long journeys through the white wilderness.

It is very gratifying to observe that the ladies who originally conceived the scheme of converting the site of Fraunces's Tavern, near the south end of this island, from private to public ownership and custody, have not wearied in well-doing. They have been urging their case upon the President of Manhattan Borough and have secured Mr. CANTOR'S warm and intelligent interest.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Everything is in readiness for the Eastern and Western Junior football game to-morrow on Marshall Field. The Polytechnic Preparatory School, with its substitutes and coach, arrived here late to-night. The Hyde Park team indulged in some light practice to-day, and Coach A. A. Stagg of the University of Chicago virtually determined upon the line-up.

The representatives of the three factions in the battle for the control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company left yesterday for Denver, where the election of Directors will take place on Dec. 10, and it is said that they will open regular headquarters in the various hotels and make earnest endeavors to capture as many as they can of the stockholders who are expected to attend the annual meeting.

Everybody who has made the pleasant journey by coach, omnibus, or carry-all from historic Richmond in Surrey to Hampton Court knows the quaint village of Teddington, one of the prettiest places in the London suburbs. R.D. Blackmore, the author of "Lorna Doone," dwelt there, and Lucy Derby Fuller thus describes the village and the novelist's home in the December Scribner's:

There is something particularly charming about Josephine Hamilton Nicholls's "Bayou Triste," especially in those readers who are familiar with the old-time Southern darky. Alas! the type about which Miss Nicholls writes is fast becoming extinet, and the Southern darky of to-day stands almost as bare of romance as does his Northern brother.

The second volume of Mr. Saintsbury's opus magnum reproduces the general characteristics of the first, but the application of the writer's mind to a new order of phenomena affords us many new effects. Here, as there, we have an average dullness illuminated by vivid characterizations of men and books, and, where Mr. Saintsbury's wrath waxes hot against some dunce or some opinion different from his own, a brilliant corruscation.

THE terrible History of crime began, according to the Biblical legend, with Cain. Before the first stone axe was fashioned murder was perpetraied. Man has but slowly thrown off his animal origin, but we may not dwell on the much discussed subject of penology.

Throughout yesterday morning and well into the afternoon the Manhattan elevated railroad was crippled. In the early morning rush hours the whole service "went to pieces" with locomotor ataxia, and it was after midday before normal running on schedule time was established.

STILLWATER, Minn., Dec. 5. -- Fire, which broke out under the stage in the Grand Opera House at 3 o'clock this morning caused a loss of $175,000. The Opera House Block, owned by a local syndicate, was totally destroyed, with a loss of $75,000; insurance, $121,000. Other losses were: J.C. Nolen, grocer, $15,000; Holcombe Block, $10,000; Disch Block, $10,000; Zeigler Block, clothing, $40,000; C. Kirk, shoes, stock of $12,000 badly damaged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The improvement in the condition of ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed, noted in the physicians' bulletin this morning, continued during the day, although they say it is still critical. Tonight after their visit to the patent, which lasted for more than an hour, they issued the following bulletin:

PRINCETON, Dec. 5. -- Quite an extensive schedule has been arranged for the university gymnastic team this Winter. A new departure from the general schedules is the presence of the University of Pennsylvania and Rutgers College on the list. No joint exhibition has been held with the former since 1897.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- Baron Heyl zu Herrnsheim, Count von Kanitz, and Baron von Kardorff, together with sixty-four Conservative, National Liberal, and Anti-Semitic members of the Reichstag, introduced to-day a resolution directly aimed at the United States.

The interest now taken by collectors in early American engravings was interestingly shown at the recent Whitmore sale in Boston, which brought into the market, among other treasures in this department, a remarkable collection of mezzotints by Peter Pelham, the first artist and engraver in America, who came to Boston in 1726 and died there in 1751.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Preyer has furnished us with a very ingenious but facetious derivation of Hoboken from the German. It is certain that in this city the English and German languages undergo a sort of "chemical reaction" upon each other, much to the detriment of the latter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Pension Commissioner Ware yesterday announced thirty promotions, made under the system which he inaugurated soon after he got into office and has been perfecting ever since. Mr. Ware appointed a civil service board of his own, consisting of three Chiefs of Bureaus.

Among athletes generally and Irish athletes in particular unusual interest is being manifested in the forthcoming indoor carnival of sports which the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association has arranged for at Madison Square Garden, Dec. 27. A long and varied programme has been carefully prepared by the Athletic Committee of this association, and no expense has been spared in order to make the meeting a memorable one in the annals of amateur athletics.

The banquet in the Hotel Cecil, London, Nov. 21, at which many of the foremost men of Great Britain assembled by invitation "to meet the editors of and contributors to the Supplement to the ninth edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica" was memorable alike in its object and the eminence, political, social, or professional, of most of the diners.

NOBODY of the present generation, or generations, can remember when the holiday season was not the holiday season in point of fact the present interest in Christmas is a revival, just about a century old. Christmas, as the general holiday it is now, had pretty much faded out of the consciousness of English-speaking mankind during the seventeenth and particularly during the eighteenth century.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: MAY I have the privilege of a word with your readers in the Christmas time about a book which has gone so quietly into the rushing Christmas throng that many may overlook it who, if their attention were drawn to it, would enjoy it most?

On Wednesday, Nov. 26, G.V. Henkeis sold in Philadelphia a collection of original and contemporary manuscripts of the laws of Pennsylvania and papers relating to the legal practice of the Colony from 1682 to 1774. The sale also included a number of scarce works on American history, early Pennsylvania newspapers, Franklin and other imprints, journals of the Continental and First Congresses, c.

Prof. Robinson's introduction of about twenty-five pages is an interesting summary view of his general subject. The whole book in its arrangement and tone suggests Demogeot's excellent history of French literature, a textbook which illustrates the superiority of the best French school books to our own.

NOW that Cecil Rhodes is dead and his holdings scattered, some of the secrets of the great diamond monopoly he created are beginning to come out. It is gravely asserted that there are now within easy reach enough diamonds, if mined and sold, utterly to demoralize the diamond market throughout, the world and render the stones to which such a high value is now attached worth little more than so many pieces of glass.

This elaborate monograph constitutes Vol. IX. of "Harvard Historical Studies," which are published from the income of the Henry Warren Torrey Fund. In its original form it was accepted as a dissertation for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy at Harvard University. It was also awarded the Toppan Prize in 1899.

Fire of somewhat mysterious origin, although it is believed to have been due to some stray high-tension electric current, crippled the service of the John Street telephone exchange for many hours yesterday. It was quickly extinguished by the office employes, but it was said to have destroyed 90 per cent, of the wires running over the switchboards in that office.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6. -- Durnell and Herz added the Palmetto Sweepstake to their list to-day, Prince of Endurance walking away with the feature of the card. Henry McDaniel was the even-money favorite, hut could make no showing in the heavy going. The Prince, at the comfortable odds of 7 to 1, took the best path as the barrier rose and went through his field with barely any effort, winning by three lengths.
THERE was evidently something on his mind, for he did not even notice that the coffee was cold and that the cook and the housemaid were quarreling audibly in the kitchen.

AS DUSK gathered on the gridiron at the Polo Grounds last Thanksgiving Day and twinkling lights began to shine on the gaunt structure of the elevated road of a sudden the clear-cut whistle of the referee sounded out, marking the end of the football game for the twenty-two young warriors of Columbia and Syracuse.

Even sober Americans may be pardoned some dizziness at the adoption of American ideas in the most unlikely quarters. Who, for instance, could have expected from Germany an echo to American comments, apropos of Sir MICHAEL HERBERT'S appointment as the British Ambassador, as to modern functions of diplomats and diplomacy?

WHEN Richard Mansfield travels he travels in state. He has a train of his own for the company and production, and he lives in a palace car of splendid convenience and comfort. He enjoys indulging himself in quizzical whims when speeding across the country, and many a good story is told of the Mansfield tour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- In addition to the state functions at the White House beginning with the Cabinet dinner Thursday, Dec. 11, and terminating with the army and navy reception Feb. 12, Mrs. Roosevelt has arranged for a series of evening musicales to be given each Friday in January.

Thomas Brackett Reed, member of Congress from the First District of Maine for twenty-two years, and Speaker of the House of Representatives during eight sessions; lawyer, public speaker, debater, and author, and. in 1896, a prominent Republican candidate for the Presidential nomination, was born in Portland, Me., sixty-three years ago.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 27. -- The work of restoring the famous old Town Hall of Ypres has just begun. Many portions of this noble edifice, the most perfect specimen of civic architecture in Flanders, and one of the finest in the world, have fallen to decay, and the entire building was, indeed, seriously threatened.

The sale of 60 Cedar Street by Charles A. Gould for about $150,000 furnished another remarkable illustration of the increase of values incidental to the expansion of the financial district, and the announcement that the buyers will erect a banking house on the site served to direct attention anew to the possibilities in the improvement of those isolated lots which cannot carry tall structures.

[Copyright. 1902.] LONDON, Dec. 6. -- President Rooserelt's message was awaited here with much expectant interest, but frankness compels me to say that it was received with something like disappointment. So much has been said and written of the President's determination to take strong action with reference to the trusts that the actual terms of the message appear extremely mild and unexciting.

A fire that started in the basement of Joseph Schnapman's ostrich feather and artificial flower establishment at 4 Bond Street at about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, frightened about fifty girls who had been putting finishing touches to flowers, stopped the Broadway cars for awhile, and damaged about $30,000 worth of flowers and feathers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- Two guardsmen from New York did some wonderful three-legged running in the Seventy-fourth Regiment games to-night. They were P. .A Sayles and W.S. Edwards of the Twenty-second Regiment, and they ran 100 yards in 11 seconds flat, breaking the amateur record of 0:12 2-5.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a leter signed "Constant Reader," In your issue of Dec. 4, a plea is justly made for some oversight of the convalescing children of the poor after their discharge from the hospital. "If only a home could be provided for them where they could reap the benefit of the time spent in the hospital perhaps they might eventually become entirely well."

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The grip is unusually severe this Winter and has already been felt throughout England, with the result that all who can do so are leaving town. Hundreds of people are on their way to India to attend the Delhi Durbar, and thousands are flocking to the south of France and the Chanel Islands.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- According to an official of Local No. 62, Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators, and Paperhangers of America, ex-Gov. David B. Hill is to be retained by that organization in its endeavor to maintain its stand with regard to the case of William Potter, whose expulsion followed his refusal to retire from the National Guard of the State when ordered to do so by his union.

PARIS, Nov. 21. -- Recent events in Morocco have fully confirmed the information which I forwarded to THE NEW YORK TIMES that risings are being prepared there which must ultimately lead to the intervention of France and perhaps Spain. And in this connection the rumors of a secret treaty between France and Spain, with a view to combined action in Morocco, are becoming more and more persistent.

THE combination of the elevated and underground railroad interests of the city is the chief topic of talk in rapid transit circles. The question that has been asked often is: "What advantage is the public to get from the deal?" An official of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was asked to answer this question the other day.

HELENA, Mon., Dec. 2. -- Joseph Soss, the well-known Western contractor, after completing the new State House in this city last Spring, started on a tour around the world, and reached the starting point a few days ago. In an interview Mr. Soss gave the following information concerning the large number of Jews who are living in China:

BRUSSELS, Nov. 21. -- The principal immediate results of Rubino's attempt upon King Leopold will be to enhance the sovereign's popularity, which lately -- and more especially since the King refused to meet Princess Stephanie at Spa -- has been on the wane, and to cast discredit upon the Belgian Socialistic Party.

NOVORISSIYSK, Russia, Nov. 10. -- To say farewell to Batoum was good-bye to the Caucasus, with its mountains beyond compare, its wonderfully good-looking men, its extortionate hotels and cheap railways, its delicious peaches, and lastly, to its fleas. And in spite of the drawbacks it was to us a painful ceremony.

FOR many years all the artificial eyes used in this country came from Germany, and their manufacture included certain picturesque features denied to the latter-day factory. Like the German toys, they were made by families of peasant artisans living in the Black Forest or other remote regions. The secret of the manufacture was carefully guarded and passed down generation after generation.

The National banks of New York have lost a considerable portion of their deposits and increased loans to a small degree, according to the currently published reports filed in compliance with the call of the Treasury Department for statements as to condition at the close of business on Nov. 23.

THE duck girl is an important person on Long Island, where farmers make a specialty of raising ducks on scientific principles. Her work consists in picking the White Pekins and other tancy breeds before they are shipped to the New York markets. Nearly every man in Speonk and Eastport is in the duck-raising business: and the young women, with few exceptions, work as pickers.
To the Editor of The New York Times: With your kind permission I would like to say a few words upon a subject Which I will call the "Evolution of the Robber Baron."

WHAT is it now? Look here, I don't keep an infant school. Three times three is nine, add one, put down the naught and carry the one. No. hang it, I guess that isn't the way! Why don't you get your own lessons, sonny? Oh, Miss Hoxey said you were to ask me, did she? We'll see about that.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The first day's battle between the negro Republicans and the "Lily Whites" leaves the latter at a disadvantage. The discovery that his candidate for Postmaster in the test case which has been prepared for President Roosevelt was a bartender disconcerted Senator Pritchard.

The first arrivals of representatives from outside of New York of the industrial department of the National Civic Federation, which begins to-morrow at 203 Broadway, in the rooms of the Board of Trade, are expected to-day. Senator Hanna, who will preside at the meetings, will arrive this evening, and will go to the Waldorf-Astoria.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By publishing in your Thanksgiving Day issue a report of my address of Wednesday, Nov. 26. at the Educational Alliance, you have inadvertently done an injustice to myself and to many others. Perhaps this was unavoidable, as your space did not permit to include in your extract what preceded or to add what followed.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates were reported to-day as below: Clearing House rate, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 25@20c discount; call loans, 5@6: time money, 5 1/2@6; Clearing House exchanges, $21,632,394; balances, $1,272,411.

DENVER, Dec. 6. -- Mayor R.R. Wright, Jr., and eleven Aldermen were sentenced this afternoon by Judge Mullins of the District Court to serve four months in jail for contempt of court in disregarding the injunction issued by Judge Mullins to restrain the enactment of an ordinance, grunting a franchise to the Denver City Tramway Company in the form in which it was presented.
To the Editor of The New York Times: On Nov. 23 there died in Washington a man whose heroic work for the welfare of humanity deserves more than passing approbation from the citizens of this country.

JULIAN MITCHELL, whose ability as a master of the ballet is reflected from the heels and toes of the chorus at Weber and Fields's, is interested in "The Wizard of Oz," a musical comedy which has not yet been seen in this city, but which has, according to all accounts, been successful in Chicago.
