[Copyright, 1902.] LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Money was plentiful this week, but there was a rather keen demand on Monday, owing chiefly to the consols pay-day requirements.

When Policeman John Hessian of the West Thirtieth Street Station found a man hanging in a helpless condition over the railing of the Manhattan Club, at Twenty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, last night, he little dreamed that within an hour a small fortune would be found in the man's clothes.

SENTIMENTAL Tommy has come to life again. When J.M. Barrie impaled him on an iron spike outside Lady Dintoul's garden every one believed his career was ended. But they counted without their Tommy. This advertisement appeared recently in the personal column of a daily paper:

SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., Dec. 6. -- Mrs. Fanny D.B. Chase, wife of Simon B. Chase, is dead at her home at Hallstead. She was prominent in temperance and missionary circles. She was the first National President of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and an ex-State President of the organization.

If the outlay of $100,000,000 the Grand Trunk Railway system, which now reaches from Portland and Quebec to Chicago, expects five years from now to appear in the railway world as the second great trunk line that will reach with its own rails from ocean to ocean, from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

MRS. RICHARD T. WILSON, SR., made her first appearance at the opera in a pale gray satin trimmed with sable. The bodice was almost high, and it had full sleeves that came half way between wrists and elbows. Narrow bands of sable fur finished the sleeves and also outlined the lace that formed the yoke and front of the bodice.

The Republicans in the Board of Aldermen are to be lined up on the Pennsylvania tunnel franchise bill. This was the decision reached yesterday as a result of conferences which Senator Platt held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel with Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, Chairman Robert C. Morris of the Republican County Committee, National Committeeman Gibbs, Postmaster Van Cott, and a number of the district leaders.

Prices were steady in the outside market yesterday, but very few stocks were actively traded in. It was the Copper group which again supplied the largest number of transactions and to which most attention was given. In other parts of the list trading was very desultory and the stocks which showed more than a few hundred shares were exceptions.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6. -- Efforts are being made to consolidate the Hammond Ice Company of Baltimore with the American Ice Company, or trust, although officials of the former deny it. J. Edward Carter and H.L. Horton of New York, the latter a member of the banking firm of H.L. Horton Co., have held conferences with the Baltimore parties the last two days.

This part of December is regarded by theatrical managers as a dull period which precedes the round of Christmas gayety and hence not a propitious time for the launching of new plays. Consequently Julia Marlowe, whose trying role in "Queen Fiametta" caused her to change plays, will have the week to herself to make her annual bow to Broadway. Her engagement begins Monday night at the Criterion.

LAKE WOOD, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Boating on Lake Carasaljo, coaching, golf, croquet, and cycling are some of the diversions that keep Lakewood's many visitors out of doors these pleasant days. The hotels and cottages are deserted during the day, except at meal time, when the health and recreation seekers throng in, aglow with the exhilaration of exercise, and demand almost everything on the menu for their voracious appetites.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 6. -- Six persons were killed in a wreck on the Inter-Colonial, the Canadian Government railway, at noon to-day near Belmont Station, seventy miles from Halifax. The Canadian Pacific express for Montreal rolled down an embankment, completely wrecking the locomotive, the postal, express, and baggage cars and several passenger cars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The eleven Cuban children who have been detained at New York during several weeks by the immigration authorities were ordered released to-day by the Treasury Department and they will immediately proceed to Point Loma, the Universal Brotherhood School, in California.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of Dr. Lorenz, the eminent orthopodic surgeon, I would like to make just one point. There is not a single doubt but he most, emphatically deserves the popular recognition accorded him by the profession and general public, simply because he possesses that specific mental quality that creates its own methods, making him the central figure in the circumscribed world of original thinkers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, Mr. David C. Preyer, has certainly slipped his etymological trolley when he says that the up-to-date little city across the Hudson, at whose expense vanity-struck Gothamites joke so much and know so little, derives its appellation from the fact that it was once the haven of the tramp or hobo.

THE prettiest gown in "Audrey," the play from Miss Johnston's book of that name, now at the Madison Square Theatre, is a ball gown which Miss Eleanor Robson, who plays the title role, does not wear here in New York. The history of the gown which no New York audience has seen is one of the small tragedies of stage life of which women off the stage know nothing.

Trading in yesterday's market fell to a very low ebb. barely 130,000 shares being traded in throughout the session, and these almost wholly as the result of professional operations. Price movements were in no sense consequential, either on the side of advances or of declines.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6. -- According to the annual report of the Board of Managers of the State Village for Epileptics, submitted to Gov. Murphy, there are upward of 2,500 epileptics in New Jersey. The report deprecates the fact that the State has not been more liberal in caring for this class of dependents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading your paper of the 26th inst. I noticed an article which I should be pleased to comment upon and trust you will recognize it. The title was "The Views of a Non-Union Workman."

E.A. Caswell, the honorary manager of the Quadrangular Universities' Chess League, composed of the chess clubs affiliated with the Universities of Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton, announced yesterday that the annual tournament for possession of the college trophy has been decided by a vote of the colleges, to be played on Dec. 29, 30, and 31 at the Columbia Grammar School, in this city, the tournament to begin at 1 o'clocK on Monday, Dec. 29.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- Mrs. Alice Freeman Palmer, ex-Dean of the women's department at the University of Chicago, and well known in educational circles throughout the country, died suddenly in Paris to-day, according to a cablegram received here by A.A. Sprague, whose niece was traveling with Mrs. Palmer.
IN his message to Congress at the opening of the present session President Roosevelt said concerning the relations of labor to capital:

CHRISTMAS cards are out, and it is time to make selections while variety is obtainable. Enormous numbers of cards are brought out each year, but as a matter of fact the output of the purely Christmas card is decreasing. The calendar has taken its place almost entirely. The same sentiments may be used, the same designs, and a little calendar tacked away in one corner or worked into the design.

Every room in the New York Athletic Club, from the natatorium in the basement to the restaurant on the top floor, was given over to the ladies yesterday. The fair visitors utilized their advantage to the utmost and took such complete possession that it was with difficulty the members could crowd their way into any of their old accustomed places.

TOKYO, Nov. 10. -- Among the celebrations which turned all Japan into a festival ground when the Anglo-Japanese convention was signed, the one at the northern port of Hakodate included a procession, in which a herculean figure in the uniform of a Japanese Admiral smiled benignly down upon England, dressed as a midshipmite.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- It was noon by the village clock when Peter Spies, finishing his drink, banged the heavy mug down on the little table in the bar of the Railroad House, on Railroad Street, and, turning to Christopher Ream, the tavernkeeper, said:

MANY well-known members of the Four Hundred maintain small theatres in connection with their establishments. Some of these, especially those attached to large country mansions, are heard from occasionally, as, for instance, the theatre which is part of George Gould's estate, Georgian Court at Lakewood, where performances given by professionals, or by professionals and amateurs in conjunction, frequently take place during the Winter.

ANCHORAGE, Ky., Dec. 6. -- As the result of an attempt to go to sleep in a trunk. John Alien. Jr., the six-year-old son of John Alien, a resident of this place, is dead, and his eight-year-old sister is in a serious condition.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6. -- Hundreds of students of the Maryland University, with other medical men, crowded the campus of the oldest school of medicine in Baltimore and cheered Dr. Lorenz this afternoon as he passed into the amphitheatre, crowded with the lending surgeons and physicians of Baltimore, to give the public clinic for their benefit.

As an introductory to the six-day bicycle race, which will begin on the high-banked board track in Madison Square Garden to-night, there was a series of races and exhibitions in the Garden last night, in which nearly all of the well-known professionals and amateur riders took part. The big structure, was uncomfortably crowded, as over 8,000 persons were present.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Sir William B. Richmond, R.A., whatever one may think of his work in St. Paul's Cathedral, must be regarded as a man competent to speak of what is artistic and what is not, and therefore his declaration that the bridge which is to be built across the Thames at Vauxhall will be a monstrosity, and absolutely unworthy of the British capital, deserves some weight.

PROF. JAMES MACBETH CHITTENDEN is a great scientist. No one questions that. His researches in psychology, particularly with reference to hypnotism, that strange state so little understood, has made him famous.

HAVANA, Nov. 28. -- Havana is well used to strikes. In Spanish times they were frequent, but as a strong military force was always present, they were Strickly suppressed. During the military government there were also several. The building of the electric lines was much retarded by strikes among the workmen.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6. -- Twenty war vessels of light draught will be present in St. Louis Harbor April 3O, 1903, when the dedicatory exercises of the World's Fair take place.

Yachting during the coming year around New York will be the longest in its season of activity, the most interesting, and from many points of view the most important in the history of that sport in this country. With the full knowledge that the America's Cup challenge was coming from Sir Thomas Lipton.

XXV. THE Idiot seemed rather solemn as he addressed himself to the waffles the other morning. It was clear to his comrades at Mrs. Pedagog's table that he was vexed in his mind over something, but they didn't know exactly what it was that made him seem distrait.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of to-day I read a letter signed by Mr. L.H. Goodkind regarding the Charleston Collectorship, condemning your able editorial of a few days ago.

EAST SIDE leisure is one of the mysteries of New York. Besides the hosts of the unemployed that crowd the public squares whenever the weather permits, there are hundreds, and perhaps thousands, that lounge at all hours of the day in the cafes, beer saloons, and wein stuben, where they must pay for what they eat and drink and must eat and drink in order to secure the privilege of lounging.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6. -- The Hyde Park High School football team to-day overwhelmed the Brooklyn Polytechnic eleven on Marshall Field, winning by a score of 105 points to 0. The Eastern players were never dangerous to the Chicago High School boys.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The increases in freight rates soon to be applied on the roads running from the Mississippi River and points beyond to the East and South will be investigated by the Inter-State Commerce Commission, which has fixed Dec. 16 as the date, for a hearing to be held at the offices of the commission in this city.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- If a letter posted in Great Britain and addressed to Rochester ten years ago had arrived at its destination when due John Blackmore might have been alive to-day. The letter was received by Clerk Rudolph of the Surrogate's Court in the morning's mail and was signed by John Blackmore of Woolwick.

THE bridal couple minded neither the smiling looks of the passengers nor the grains of rice that fell occasionally from the folds of her dress. For the hour and a half from New York to Sandy Hook they were rosy and loving, but when the ocean swell began the roses paled, and it was not long before he was holding her arm and helping her to the stateroom.

Capt. JOHN McAULEY PALMER, United States Army, inherits an honored name. It was only six years ago that we had the pleasure we cannot exactly say of advocating the election, but of congratulating the country upon the candidacy of his grandfather to be President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- At the December dinner of the Gridiron Club, in the Arlington Hotel to-night, the Washington correspondents who compose the organization made use of recent events and prospective happenings for their burlesques. The menu souvenir was a book of rules of the House, with many cartoons showing the stringent manner in which Mr. Cannon will govern that body.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The following part of the President's message was by a mistake of the printer left out: "There is one important question upon which I must say something, although there has already been very much said upon the matter. I refer to the Dingley tariff. This tariff, as you are probably aware, was passed at a time when there was a great business depression in the country.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The second volume or Joseph Reinach's "Histoire de I'Affaire Dreyfus" has just appeared here. It is mainly devoted to Esterhazy, and, consequently, throws a bright light upon the relations of the traitor with Col. von Schwarzkoppen, the German Military Attache in Paris in 1894-7.

THE leaden sky contained snow and flakes were falling spasmodically. All around in the dense woods drifts were heaped high. Donald StalWorlh, with snowshoes sinking deep in the flaky crust, stood panting with his exertions. The mighty stillness of the woods oppressed him.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 6. -- Owing to the continued prevalence of smallpox in this city and the total inadequacy of Hope Hospital, the municipal lying-in institution, for patients of this class" it has been announced that George Eastman, head of the Eastman Kodak Company, with offices on both continents, will offer a residence on East Avenue, the most fashionable thoroughfare in the city, as a hospital for smallpox patients.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- Baron Heyl zu Hernnsheim, a member of the Reichstag from Worms, who, with others of the Righ, introduced a motion asking the Reichstag to pass a resolution requesting the Imperial Chancellor, when negotiating commercial treaties, not to dissolve the most-favored nation relations with those countries which grant to Germany full reciprocity, was seen by your correspondent in the Reichstag yesterday.

By securing a write of prohibition from Justice Fitzgerald of the Supreme Court, Coroners' Physician Albert T. Weston yesterday prevented the Board of Coroners from trying him on charges which he claims have been preferred in a thinly disguised effort to oust him from office.

The luckiest man on the Allan State Line steamship Laurentian. which arrived yesterday after a stormy voyage from Glasgow, was William Rye. of Chicago, able seaman. He is our of the few American sailors serving under the British flag, and on Nov. 29. seven days out, he was taking in the starboard forward light, when a tremendous wave came over the port bow and dropped him into the ocean.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That much-discussed subject of the army canteen has been one of great interest to me, and in my opinion your closing paragraph in the editorial of Nov. 27 contains the only sensible deduction that can be drawn from the true facts.

THERE are ghost stories in great abundance, but ghost stories related with circumstantiality as to time, place, and events, sworn to by reputable and judicious persons, are not particularly common. Wisconsin has two remarkable ghost stories, or rather stories of two ghosts, since neither ghost has contented itself with one manifestation.

America is said not to be a favorable place for the development of conductors, and it is doubtless true that the opportunities for young men to gain experience and show what they can do at the head of an orchestra are few. Opportunities do not come for such in the regular course of things, and have to be carved, as it were, out of the solid rock of ambition and energy.

OAKLAND, CAL., Dec. 1. -- To the California orchardists the labor question is now the absorbing problem. One county alone (Santa Clara) has a hundred square miles of bearing trees, the biggest fruit drier in the world, the biggest fruit packing house in the world, and the biggest fruit cannery in the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In yesterday's issue in an editorial on "Coercing Venezuela" in which I and possibly others among your readers fail to catch your true meaning. I write to ask for further elucidation.

THERE is a restaurant in lower New York which is supposed to be devoted to the improvement of the physical well-being of mankind, where they cook a cereal until it is something to dream of -- not to dream on. It is steamed whole wheat, and the quality and the cooking make it one of the best dishes of the kind ever offered.
THEY called him "Boozer," and as far as appearances went it was a name that fitted him better than did his shaggy hide.

URUAPAM, Mexico, Nov. 20. -- It is a great day for Uruapam. Along the roads that lead from the station some of the citizens have planted young banana trees, others have decorated their humble cots with the Mexican colors, while all who have not gone to the railway are in their doorways, clad in clean Sunday raiment.

The manufacturers' Underwriting Agency has been appointed Brooklyn agent of the Royal Exchange Assurance Company.

LONDON, Dec, 6. -- The past few months have found in the United Kingdom an unprecedented number of American buyers of thoroughbred cattle, whose purchases of high-class breeding stock aggregate many thousands of pounds. A number of the animals bought are intended for exhibition at the St. Louis Exposition.

Commissioner WARE of the Pension Bureau seems pretty well to have solved one problem of administration which has bothered many an older head in Washington than his.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 6. -- The Rev. J. J. Curran of Wilkesbarre, who was on the stand yesterday when the Coal Strike Commission adjourned, resumed the witness stand when the commission began its session at 10 o'clock to-day.

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- The Chamber of Deputies was the scene of voilent disturbance this afternoon, during which a general melee occurred in the space in front of the tribune, requiring the summoning of the Militarv Commandant of the Palais Bourbon with a platoon of colonial infantry, who forcibly elected two disorderly members who declined to retire after an order for their temporary expulsion had been voted.

More than 300 guests sat down last evening to the anniversary dinner of the St. Nicholas Society at Delmonico's, and they listened not only to the first important speech made by Gen. Chaffee since his return from the Philippines, but witnessed numerous quaint and curious ceremonies, some of which were performed last evening for the first time.
BOB" JONES was the "star" salesman for a big Manhattan wholesale drug house. He had a fine trade through the northern part of Pennsylvania and made frequent trips in that territory.

The Meiningen Orchestra, under the direction of Fritz Steinbach, has recently been astonishing and delighting London, to use the words of the critic of The London Times, making an impression that is described as "wonderful." The orchestra is the one that has been maintained by the Grand Duke of Saxe-Meiningen, and of Which Hans Von Bulow was conductor for five years.

Mrs. E.N. Tailer, the mother of T. Suffern Tailer, the well-known whip, and mother-in-law of Gen. Burnett, United States District Attorney for this district, had a startling experience last evening while nearing her home at 11 Washington Square North, after a drive in her private closed carriage.

The bill which Mr. LITTLEFIELD is to take up in his sub-committee on anti-trust legislation is practically the bill he introduced last session, with some amendments and extensions. It is understood to have the approval in a general way of the President, and certainly embodies the ideas Mr. ROOSEVELT has endeavored to present in his numerous public utterances.

Events in the outside market during the past week were not of a kind to be watched, with more than passing interest. In no part of the market except in a relatively small number of stocks in which there was much inside manipulation were the transactions sufficiently large to draw the attention of the public.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In defense of football let me say that I fully concur with your views as set forth in Tuesday's editorial. Having been a lover of athletic sports all my life, and having on two occasions imperiled my life through overzeriousness in the pursuit of them.

When the argument on a motion to grant a new trial in the case of Albert T. Patrick, the lawyer convicted of having murdered William Marsh Rice, the aged millionaire, was resumed yesterday before Recorder Goff, John C. Tomlinson, counsel for Patrick, launched into a scathing arraignment of the District Attorney's office, bringing accusations of improper methods employed to secure the conviction of his client.
PARIS, Dec. 6. -- Robert McCormick, recently appointed United States Ambassador at St. Petersburg, is spending a few days here prior to presenting letters of recall to the Austrian Emperor at Vienna.

THE recent experiments made by the Fire Department at the Flat Iron Building, to test the water pressure in the upper stories, was only one of many precautions which are taken to insure the safety of tenants of sky-scrapers and employes in big department stores. The building regulations applying to structures 130 feet high or higher are in themselves a great safeguard.

VIENNA, Nov. 26. -- If a communication sent from Constantinople to the Deutsche Zeitung is true, Germany holds the commercial interests of the Turkish Empire in the hollow of her hand as completely as though she had spent millions in conquering the country by the sword.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. --Thomas Brackett Reed, ex-Speaker of the House of Representatives died here this morning at 12:10 o'clock in his apartments in the Arlington Hotel. The immediate cause of death was uraemia.

THE annual dinner and installation of officers of the St. Nicholas Club took place on Saturday evening. Stuyvesant Fish, the new President, was one of the officers to be installed.

The news we get from Russia sheds new light upon the condition of anarchy and lawlessness which, in our time, a nominal autocracy really produces and represents. The Czar himself, conscious of wishing ill to no man, has apparently endeavored to discover why and how it is that so many of his subjects bear ill-will to him.

THIS is certainly cozy. In all probability there is no time in the lives of two human beings who have been made one that is more memorable than that blissful moment when, after the hurry and excitement of their weddine journey, they are seated for the first time at their own dinner table in their own little home.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have lived in New York City for some years past, but am a native of the State of Kentucky. I read with much regret your editorial of Nov. 25, relating to W. Godfrey Hunter, Jr., in particular, and Kentuckians in general.

WHEN John Ashe returned from the city and found that the farm next to his had been sold he was vastly displeased. He had intended to buy that farm for himself, but had evidently delayed too long. It wasn't John Ashe's way to take things on hearsay, so he visited the County Clerk's office to make certain the sale actually had taken place.

William Brookfield said yesterday that at the coming session of the Legislature he would have reintroduced his bill for direct nominations by the people. This bill was before the Legislature at the last session, but died in committee. Mr. Brookfield thinks that the passage of this bill would do away with all friction in the Republican organization in New York County and would strengthen the organization with the people.

MARK TWAIN will probably never forget the attempt of two of his Hartford friends to invade his realm of writing humor, and the disastrous consequences of it. In the Twain-Twichell-Warner group was the Rev. Dr. Parker, a Congregational clergyman of learning and eloquence, whose church occupied relatively the same position in the south part of the city as Dr. Twichell's did "on the hill."

AIKEN, S.C., Dec. 6. -- William C. Whitney, with a large party of guests, is expected here just prior to Christmas for the Winter season. The addition of Mr. Whitney's East Street cottage is being rushed to completion. This work is mostly done by Northern workmen.

Charges were filed yesterday afternoon at Police Headquarters by Assistant District Attorney Morgan against Capt. William Hogan, now in command at the Eldridge Street Station, and Detective Israel Resenberg, one of Capt. Titus's men.

It is perhaps ungracious to say that the record of last week's festivities has been a chronicle of small beer and skittles. There has been only one kind of entertainment to recount, and that has been the bringing out of the debutante. It is true that there have been slight variations, and here it was a reception, and here a tea, and there a dance, but the object was the same.

One of the features that points to the close of the active golf season in Eastern links is the exodus that begins about this time of professional players to Southern and far Western clubs. This has already commenced. Alexander Smith, the professional of the Nassau County Club at Glen Cove, left last week for the Los Angeles Country Club in Southern California.

The forty-second athletic and military games of the Seventh Regiment in the regimental armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, last night were witnessed by a record attendance and produced record-breaking results in four of the events on the programme, new figures for the regiment being achieved in the shot put, pole vault, military mile bicycle race, and the military wall-scaling contests.

COL TOM OCHILTREE'S career as European correspondent was a brief and decidedly exciting incident in his globe-trotting life. The editor of a Texas newspaper that was just beginning to feel its way to a safe salary list was taking dinner with Ochiltree in John Chamberlin's, Washington, when Ochiltree showed him a letter from John W. Mackay requesting the Colonel to come to Paris without delay.

OMAHA, Neb. Dec. 7 -- Decidedly ensrgetic action from Washington will be necessary to force officials here to carry out President Roosevelt's demand for the removal of unlawful fences on the public lands of Nebraska, it is believed. The cattlemen believe that they are in no danger from Special Agent Mosby.
Cupid has stolen a march on Col. Edward Duffy of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, and taken from him on the eve of annual inspection one of his best-known officers.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Dec. 7 -- Thomas Nast, the Consul General of the United States in this city, died at noon to-day from yellow fever, after an illness of three days.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 -- Changes in Baltimore and Ohio officials are announced to take effect to-morrow as follows: Arthur Hale, assistant to General Manager Potter, will become General Superintendent of Transportation, vice J.C. Stuart, who resigns to go into another business. L.G. Hass, General Superintendent at Pittsburg, will succeed Mr. Hale, and I.G. Rawn, General Superintendent of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern at Cincinnati, will assume the duties of General Superintendent at Pittsburg.

A.G. Spalding and the other theosophists who are determined that the eleven "Lotus Buds" shall reach Mrs. Tingley's Universal Brotherhood School at Point Loma, are not taking chances that their journey shall again be interrupted. The order for their deportation, secured through the efforts of the Gerry society, was revoked on appeal to the Treasury authorities on Saturday, and the order for the children's release was telegraphed to Commissioner of Immigration Williams yesterday morning.

A darins robbery wag committed late Saturday night in the jewelry store of J. Lindner, at 2,328 Third Avenue, within a block of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station. One hundred dollars' worth of jewelry was taken, and the thieves would probably have secured more had not one of them in leaving the store knocked his hand against the door jamb, dropping a quantity of diamond stickpins.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- United States Ambassador Porter and the British Ambassador, Sir Edmund Monson, have now put into execution their plan to make friendly representations to the French Government with a view to securing a reconsideration of the case of the Passionist Fathers, who have been included among the religious orders to be expelled from France.
Postmaster Van Cott yesterday had a talk at the Fifth Avenue Hotel with Senator T.C. Platt relative to the proposed site for a new Post Office Building in this borough.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The violent scenes in the Chamber of Deputies which marked the close of the session yesterday have been followed to-day by a lively discussion of the incidents in parliamentary and official circles. A portion of the press treats the affair humorously, as indicative of the excitability of the parties concerned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your admirable editorial of to-day, like some others which have preceded it, tells the story of the waste of water in a graphic manner and rightly sums up the situation when it says, "To spend millions to increase the supply that the present waste may continue unchecked would be a criminal misuse of the public money."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 7 -- A letter received by W. A. Hunter of Louisville from Guatemala City gives what purports to be the details of the shooting of William Fitzgerald by W. Godfrey Hunter, Jr., son of the American Minister. The letter is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- There was a dramatic scene in the large banquet hall of the Arlington Hotel last night while Mr. Reed was dying In the same hotel, almost within sound of the revelry that marks the monthly gatherings of the Gridiron Club, whose first dinner of the season was given last night.

Though professional Wall Street has been pleased to ignore it, choosing rather to give all consideration to the money market situation, there came about last week a development of far-reaching consequence that must have important influence not alone in the money market, but in the security market as well.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 7 -- Judge John W. Henry, for many years Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court and now Judge of the Circuit Court here, is dying at his home in this city.

The postal clerk is interesting to society beyond any ornamental aspects which have been ascribed to him. It is not intended to assert that in these he is less favored than other people; the probabilities are that a competitive delegation from his ranks would present an appearance of mingled dignity and pulchritude not inferior to that of an equal number of parsons or stock brokers.

David Belasco and his theatre have occupied a prominent position for about a week. Following the charge that a small part of the play, "The Darling of the Gods," had been plagiarized, came the play, and, according to the critics, it exceeded the fondest hopes of its builders. The stage management has been praised for obtaining the combinations of light.

-- Among the things important or interesting to be learned by studying the details of the recent vote in this county, as reported by the official canvassers, the one that deserves as much attention as any other, perhaps, is that our present system of printing and marking ballots disfranchises so many qualified voters that an immediate improvement in the system is, as the doctors say, "indicated."

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 7 -- Since his arrival in Baltimore, it was stated by a physician to-night. Dr. Lorenz has been offered a fee of $10,000 to perform an operation upon a deformed child of an official of the Standard Oil Company in this city. The name of the official is not given.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- In Venezuela's "Yellow Book" for the year 1901, a copy of which has been received in Washington from the Foreign Office at Caracas, are the exchanges between the London and Caracas Governments last year in regard to the ownership of Patos Island, which has been in dispute between the two countries for many years.

Miss Smith, as she called herself, lived for five years in Mrs. Southwick's boarding house, at 271 West Eleventh Street, never got a letter, never had a visitor, appears to have starved herself because she would not accept food or drink she could not pay for, and last nigrht was taken to the Bellevue Hospital insane pavilion suffering from what two doctors diagnosed as melancholia.

The biggest boat race in the history of the United States Navy is soon to take place in the Caribbean, where the most formidable fleet the American Government has even gotten together in peace or war is about to engage in Winter manoeuvres under the direction of Admiral George Dewey.

In the fitting of the keel of the new cup defender at Bristol for the placing of the keel plate in position much work has to be done in the way of arranging the fastenings, which are principally heavy screws, nearly an inch in thickness. Here is the main connection between the framing and the keel of the craft.

GLOUCESTER, Mass. Dec. 7 -- Among the arrivals here to-night was the fishing schooner Mary A. Gleason. She was quickly followed by the coasting schooner Winchester. The latter was in charge of a crew of eight men from the former. Aboard the Gleason were the Captain and five of the Winchester's crew who were rescued at sea Saturday morning and bandoned their vessel.

In a letter to Judge Hinsdale of the Court of Special Sessions, replying to a communication in which the Judge detlined to become a member of the Civil Service Reform Association, and expressed his opinions on the administration of the civil service law, Everett V. Abbot, Chairman of the Committee on Membership of the association, says:

A well-dressed man giving the name of "W.P. Carey," jumped from the Fall River Line steamboat Priscilla some time early yesterday as the boat was on its way from Boston to this city. The man was not seen to make the leap, and his absence from the stateroom to which he had been assigned was not noticed until the Priscilla reached her dock at the foot of Chambers Street, North River, yesterday morning.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman of the Temple En anu-EL at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, yesterday preached his second sermon on Zionism. In his first sermon, which was delivered two weeks ago. Dr. Silverman said that Zionism was a dream utterly impossible of realization and that it was only believed in by a small minority of the Jews all over the world.

While the weather yesterday was unpropitious for Gaelic outdoor sports. It had the effect of crowding the handball courts in Jersey City, New York, and Brooklyn with scores of players. The Irish game of handball has increased in popularity during the past few months so that every Sunday the local courts are patronized almost to a point of congestion.

While guests of the Fifth Avenue Hotel crowded the dining room last night a welldressed man of distinguished appearance suddenly mounted his chair and with outstretched arms proceeded to deliver an oration.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- The first performance in Germany of Hauptmann's drama "Der Arme Heinrich" was given at the Duetsches Theater here last evening. It was apparently a brilliant success, and the author was called before the curtain over twenty times. The critics, however, generally agree that the play lacks dramatic qualities.

Henry Lewis Gassert, one of the oldest wholesale tobacco merchants in this city, and who had the reputation of having been New York's original newsboy, died yesterday at his home, 751 Carroll Street, Brooklyn. His death, was due to blood poisoning, which he contracted last May, as the result of an accident he suffered on Park Row.

The "Philippine Catholic Centre," said to be the strongest and most representative body of Roman Catholic laymen in the Philippine Islands, has addressed a letter to the clergy, press, and people of the United States, thanking their American brethren for support and sympathy and paying especial tribute to the friars.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Nov. 28 "Statist" seems to be inspired by bullish sentiments in view of the prosperous showings of industrial and railroad corporations in general. It is unquestionably true that we are witnessing an era of unparalleled prosperity, and there is no apparent reason for alarm.

Dazed and only half appreciating his predicament Harry G. Marsh, Jr., twentyseven years old, of Woodland Station, yesterday stood a prisoner before Magistrate Cornell in the Jefferson Market Police Court. He was held in $1,000 bail for examination to-morrow. The young man had been seriously discussed for promotion by his employers the day before.

Under the auspices of the Ancient Order of Hibernians of New York County there was a mass meeting last evening in Carnegie Hall. It was not largely attended, but tickets had been bought in wholesale lots by enthusiastic Irishmen of means for the purpose of assisting the movement for the erection of a building to stand as a monument to the fealty of the Irish element in the community.

Gov. ODELL'S remarkable utterance in respect to the Pennsylvania tunnel franchise is the occasion of undiminished surprise and much speculation. That the Executive should venture thus frankly and confidently to commit the legislative branch to a certain specified policy may be considered an official impropriety.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- Dr. William W. Keen, the surgeon of this city, who recently was summoned to Annapolis to perform an operation on Midshipman Aiken to relieve him of the effects of injuries sustained in a football game, attributes the success of his operation to knowledge gained through experiments in vivisection.

That jealousy is a strong element in the psychological make-up of the wild beast was shown yesterday, when Lopez, a jaguar in the Bronx Park zoological exhibit, killed Bella, another jaguar. The keepers say that it was because she had paid more attention to another of his kind there confined in a cage, and Lopez had watched her casting secret glances from her big eyes toward Dan, who had an adjoining apartment.

An attachment has been obtained against Benjamin P. Jones, a dock builder of 1 Broadway, for $1,101, in favor of Edward W. Vanderbilt, doing business as Vanderbilt Hopkins, lumber dealers, on a note dated April 23, payable sixty days from date, given by Mr. Jones for lumber, which was not paid when it fell due.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- A series of court tennis matches between the amateur champion of the United States, Joshua Crane, Jr., of the Boston Athletic Association, and Cecil Fairs, known as "Punch," the celebrated English professional of the Princess Club of London, at the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club of Tuxedo, were finished to-day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- Edwin A. Nash, low Justice of the Supreme Court, of Avon, Livingston County, was designated to-day by Gov. Odell as an extra Associate Judge of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Fourth Department, the Presiding Justice of the division having certified to the Governor that an additional Associate Justicc war necessary for the expedition of business before that court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The inquiries made by L.T. Michener in Indinana with regard to the feeling in that State toward Presidential candidates have convinced him that Senator Fairbanks can hold the delegation against either Roosevelt or Hanna if he should decide to be a candidate.

BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- The Clearing House rate was advanced to-day to 6 per cent., though most of the loans were made at 5 1/2 per cent. Outside call money was also a shade higher, some of the banks marking their rate up to 6 per cent. Time money rates ranged from 5 1/2 to 6 1/2 per cent., with most of the business doing at 5 1/2 and 6 per cent.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Replying to a question in the House of Lords yesterday regarding the reminiscences of Sir Horace Rumbold, Bart., (ex-British Ambassador at Vienna,) published over a month ago in London, the Foreign Secretary, the Marquis of Lansdowne, somewhat tartly commented on the ex-Ambassador's "reprehensible indiscretion."

To obtain from the Pennsylvania Railroad Company a statement of its plans and purposes with respect to certain debated points that have been brought up in the consideration of the tunnel franchise matter, the Merchants' Association of New York on Dec. 5 addressed a letter to President Cassatt, in which direct questions were asked on the mooted subjects.
CARACAS, Dec. 8. -- The Venezuelan press publishes an open letter from President Castro on the embroglio with Great Britain and Germany. In this communication Gen. Castro says:

Suddenly throwing aside his prepared farewell sermon, the Rev. George K. MacDonald, pastor of the East Avenue Baptist Church in Long Island City, on Sunday night, delivered himself of an extemporaneous address in which he charged by name certain members of his flock with leading him into the temptations of strong drink.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Harry McCalmont, the well-known sportsman and Conservative Member of Parliament for Newmarket, dropped dead on the doorstep this morning as he was leaving his residence, 11 St. James's Square. He was apparently in his usual health as he passed out of the door, but before he reached the sidewalk Mr. McCalmont fell, and died almost instantaneously, supposedly of heart disease.

It was announced on Sunday morning that Mrs. Marion S. May had been married last Thursday to Herbert Janes, who had appeared as defendant some months ago in a breach of promise suit brought by the present bride. Mrs. Janes declared yesterday that within two hours of the solempization of the marriage her husband had deserted her, and that she had not been able to gain trace of him since.

Defiance was hurled at the managements of the elevated and surface railroads at a well-attended meeting of the Car Passengers' Rights Association at the home of Mrs. William Tibbits Salter, 306 West Eightieth Street, yesterday when Mrs. T. St. John Gaffney was elected honorary President.

CARACAS, Dec. 8. -- The British Minister, W.H.D. Haggard, and the German Charge d'Affaires. Herr von Pilgrim-Baltazzi, left Caracas this afternoon for La Guayra, (the port of Caracas,) where Mr. Haggard went on board the British cruiser Retribution and Herr von Pilgrim-Baltazzi boarded the German cruiser Vineta.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 8. -- The National Fuel Gas Company was incorporated here to-day with a capital stock of $2,500,000. The incorporators are George Chesebro and George W. Colton of Brooklyn, and John Bushnell of Plainfield. The company is authorized to operate pipe lines, to deal in oil and to make distribution of gas.

Two negroes were arrested yesterday as the burglars who chloroformed several guests in hotels and robbed them of their valuables. As the men, according in Capt. Titus, have been pictured and numbered in the Rogues' Gallery, the capture is regarded as important. The management of the Hotel Navarre claims that the house detective, Thomas Maxwell, did the work, and the police say that Patrolman Flood made the actual arrest.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The condition of the money market and the rates of discount were practically unchanged to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Two new moves were made to-day in the "Lily White" fight. One was by Senator Pritchard and the other by the Democrats, who have hitherto been spectators of the fight, but who to-day entered the ring and administered a blow both to Pritchard and to the negroes.

Most of the changes which occurred in the outside market yesterday were on the side of improvement. In some cases the advances were substantial and in others fractional, but the tone of the market was better than it was a week ago and more confidence seemed to be felt. A few stocks were traded in auite actively, but for the most part the trading was still within relatively narrow bounds.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 8. -- The first of a fleet of fourteen one-design boats known as Bar Harbor thirty-footers was launched and tried from the boat shops here to-day. The craft are for New York yachtsmen who will draw for them by lot in the Spring.

Trading in yesterday's stock market was even more dull and stupid than in the concluding days of last week, when dealings fell off materially. Yesterday the day's total transactions fell below the 300,000-share mark, which signifies that in the entire session there was less activity than was wont to prevail in a single hour of what not a long time past was considered but an ordinary day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice that in THE TIMES of Dec. 6 you give what purports to be an account of the ruling of the court in the proceeding to mandamus Superintendent Stewart to compel him to remove wood which was alleged not to be properly treated from three buildings in New York City.

It is not at all likely that the award of King EDWARD of England, upon the controversy between Chile and Argentina, which he was chosen to arbitrate, has satisfied either of the contending parties. But it has done more and better. It has removed from the domain even of controversy a dispute which seemed, not so long ago, to admit of no other arbitrament than that of arms.

While the output of coal at the anthracite mines is at least normal, many persons in this city have been obliged to make small fires with wood because they could not get coal. The condition applies also to towns in the vicinity. In Stamford, Conn., where the thermometer went down to 6 degrees above zero two days ago, coal had to be obtained in bushel lots.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- Mrs. Langtry's final appearance on the stage prior to her American tour was made to-night under exceptional and brilliant circumstances. It had been intended to give a private performance at the Imperial Theatre of the play "The Crossways," of which she is a joint author with Hartley Manners, and which has already been produced with success in the provinces, when King Edward expressed a desire to witness the performance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- Prof. Adolph Lorenz arrived here from Baltimore tonight. He will remain hero until Friday. From this city Prof. Lorenz will go to New York and Boston, returning to his native country about Christmas.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Great Britain and Germany have presented ultimatums to Venezuela, which will be followed by the seizure of the Venezuelan customs unless a satisfactory settlement is forthcoming within a brief period.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Rogers Morgan have returned from New York and while repairs to their house occasioned by last Friday evening's fire are being made they are staying elsewhere.

Cornelius Vanderbilt is seriously ill at his house, at 22 Park Avenue, with typhoid fever following a severe cold and condition of general debility. Mr. Vanderbilt has been confined to his bed for a week, although the diagnosis of typhoid was not made until Thursday of last week. Bulletins issued during the afternoon and evening stated that the patient was resting comfortably and that no complications had developed.

The very thoughtful, intelligent, and scholarly paper of Mr. CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS before the Civic Federation, pointing out the impracticability of compulsory arbitration in industrial disputes in this country, and commending investigation by boards constituted for each emergency as it shall arise, will repay careful perusal.

The mystery by which George L. Leyh of 73 Broadway. Wllliamsburg, met his death last Wednesday was clothed with new interest last night by the arrest of Robert Westphal, his fourteen-year-old office boy, on a technical charge of being "a suspicious person," and the lad's subsequent admission to Brooklyn police officials that he had emptied a half a bottle of "bromoseltzer" into the glass of beer which Leyh drank just before his death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The Senate occupied itself to-day with the subject of immigration. There was a long hearing, first during the morning before the Immigration Committee, of which Senator Penrose is Chairman.

There has always been some mystery as to the origin of the curious currency provisions in the Philippine Civil Government bill of last session. The general character of the bill was sound, conservative, and practical, and the House had passed a measure with reference to the currency which was in harmony with the spirit of the rest of the bill.

To those who have watched Miss Marlowe's progress from the earlier days when she shone -- in Philadelphia and in Boston, if not on Broadway -- as Viola and Rosalind and Juliet, her reappearance brings a mingling of regret and of rejoicing -- regret that those heroines of pure passion and poetry should know her no more, and rejoicing that, in whatever guise, we are permitted to delight in her again.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- Although declaring that his proudest boast is that he is an American citizen, Carlo Cattopani, Marquis of Cordova, became fiery with resentment when his right to bear the Italian title of one of the nobility was called into question to-day at City Hall. Cattopani triumphantly produced papers to prove his right to the title he has thrown aside to become an American citizen.

As the two chief parties in Spain differ from each, other in ways rather than in principle, no fundamental change of policy may be expected now that Senior SILVELA and his Conservative friends find themselves, in the places lately occupied by Senior SAGASTA and his Liberal supporters.
Pease Ellenmn have sold for Miss Mary P. Hoadly, widow of ex-Gov. George Hoadly, the five-story dwelling, 33 East Fiftieth Street, 45 by 64.

Although the annual meeting of the National League baseball owners will not be convened until noon to-day at the Victoria Hotel, on Broadway, some important preliminary conferences took place among some of the delegates yesterday at the hotel as well as in the association's headquarters in the St. James's Building nearby.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 8. -- There was a flurry at the afternoon session of the Coal Strike Commission when Ira H. Burns of Scranton, attorney for the independent companies, referred to the President of the United States as "Teddy Roosevelt."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 8. -- M.W. Savage of this city has bought Dan Patch, the famous unbeaten pacer, from M.E. Sturgis of New York for $60,000. M.E. McHenry, who has driven the horse many a fast mile and scored 1:59 1/4 with him, has signed a contract with Mr. Savage to handle the horse for the racing seasons of 1903-4.

New York City and the Pennsylvania Railroad will have the Thirty-fourth Street tunnel, giving a rail connection beneath the waters of the two rivers, with Long Island upon the one hand and New Jersey upon the other. That may in all confidence, with all positiveness, be set down as a fact.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The Washington City Post Office, being under the same roof with the department to which it is responsible and under the scrutiny of the department officials, is regarded as a model office. Whenever any new device is proposed for the postal service it is first tried on the Washington office.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- An income of $18,369.163 for foreign missionary work is reported in the annual summary of Protestant Foreign Missions, of the Rev. E.E. Strong, D.D., Editorial Secretary of the American Board, which was made public to-day. The figures show in most items an increase over the previous year.

MENOMINEE, Wis., Dec. 8. -- Fire last night destroyed the general store and dwelling of Max Manthey, at Colgate, five miles north of here. Mr. Manthey and a child lost their lives, and three others were injured.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- Trading today was the smallest of any day this year, amounting to 9,471 shares and $68,700 bonds. Many of the leading issues were not even quoted. Changes in prices were equally unimportant, the exceptions being Guarantee Trust, which was up 25 1/4 points, and Indianapolis Street Railway stock, which declined 3 points and recovered 1 point.

After a debate lasting two hours, during which the fate of the Pennsylvania tunnel franchise hung in the balance, it was decided by the Aldermaric Railroad Committee to make a favorable report to the Board of Aldermen at its meeting to-day. The contest to force a favorable report was closely contested, and the vote of one member swung the committee from opposition to a decision to report out the tunnel franchise.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8. -- The Cincinnati, Dayton and Fort Wayne Railway Company of Dayton was incorporated today with a capital stock of $1,000,000. The termini are to be Cincinnati and a point on the Indiana line in Van Wert County, where it will connect with another part of the system running to Fort Wayne, Ind., and beyond.

COPENHAGEN, Dec. 8. -- The widespread suffering here resulting from industrial stagnation and commercial depression has been intensified by the unusual severity of the Winter, which set in a month earlier than usual. Building operations have had largely to be abandoned, thus increasing the number of persons unemployed to an extent surpassing most records and seriously taxing the resources of the charitable organizations.

-- Anti-vivisectionists will have to exercise all of their remarkable ingenuity in the handling of facts if they are to save themselves from being seriously impressed by what Dr. W.R. KEEN of Philadelphia calls his "single concrete example that Knowledge gained by animal experimentation is an immense boon to humanity."

C.L. Hendrickson, manager of the Columbia baseball team, has nearly arranged his schedule for this year. About twenty-seven games will be played by Columbia. Three home contests have been arranged for so far. They are -- Saturday, April 18, Williams; May 6, Pennsylvania, and May 15, Cornell.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Harry Brown, a butler employed by Albert Rothschild of 81 Carnegie Avenue, East Orange, was arrested to-day charged with stealing a quantity of jewelry. Brown, who was once a member of a traveling theatrical troupe known as the Smart Set Company, says he lives at 139 West Twenty-seventh Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- United States Consul Kenneday, reporting to the State Department from his station at Para, Brazil, calls attention to the alarming decrease in the caoutchouc in certain parts of Peru where heretofore the greatest output was gathered. The Consul says that the caoutchouc forests of Peru, from which nearly the whole supply of this product has heretofore been drawn, are practically exhausted.

Serious consideration of yesterday's stock market is not necessary. Trading dwindled to even smaller proportions than lately have appeared, while such dealings as there were came about largely as the result of operations by professionals in whose control the market at present is.

At midnight last night it was stated that there was no change in the condition of Cornelius Vanderbilt, who Is ill with typhoid fever at his residence, 22 Park Avenue, corner of Thirty-fifth Street, and that he was resting comfortably. The day had passed without especial feature, and the patient's heart action, which had previously given some concern because of difficulty in years past, remained fairly satisfactory.
JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 9. -- Speaker S. Fred Nixon is ill at his home in Westfield. He has had an attack of heart trouble, to which he is subject.

During the opening address of Assistant District Attorney Clarke to the jury yesterday, Thomas Tobin, the bartender on trial for the murder of Capt. James B. Craft at the Empire Cafe in the Tenderloin last September, tried to jump over the table where he was seated with his counsel and attack the prosecuting attorney.

It must be admitted that the case of Venezuela is one calculated to exasperate the creditors of that republic. It is also a fact that the creditors were "charged with knowledge," long before they became creditors, that the relation of a creditor to Venezuela was one calculated to exasperate the person who held that relation.

In yesterday's market for outside securities the principal feature was the activity and well-maintained strength of Northern Securities. The fact that this stock has assumed a place which makes it the most prominent stock of the day has aroused considerable interest, especially as the course of the stock is not entirely in keeping with present market conditions.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- The schedule for the Cornell track team, which has just been announced, shows a change of programme from that of former years. Heretofore only smaller colleges have been met by Cornell in preparation for the meets with Pennsylvania, Princeton, in the early Spring, and for the intercollegiate on Memorial Day at Berkeley Oval.
The National Civic Federation at its second session, held yesterday in the assembly room of the Board of Trade and Transportation, had as its chief guest ex-President Grover Cleveland.

Representatives of the National League and American League baseball clubs were in session yesterday and they were busily engaged preparing for the season of 1903. At the Victoria Hotel the club owners of the National League began their annual session, while President Ban Johnson, Vice President Somers, and J. F. Kilfoyle of the American League held a conference at the Criterion, Forty-first Street and Broadway.

Mrs. Winifred Owens, thirty-one years old, with her three-year-old boy, John, was found dead yesterday afternoon in her home on the top floor of a four-story double tenement at 162 Hope Street, Williamsburg.

The Sigel Monument Committee, through its officers, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, President; Carl Schurz, Vice President; Richard H. Adams, Treasurer, and Francis Irsch, Secretary, has issued an appeal to the public for funds to carry on the work. The appeal is as follows:
William Blair has been appointed Baltimore manager of the London and Lancashire Insurance Company of England and the Orient Insurance Company of Hartford.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Kogoro Takahira, the Japanese Minister, called upon Secretary Hay to-day to make inquiries about John Barrett, who has been selected for Minister to Japan. Mr. Takahira did not object to the appointment of Mr. Barrett, and if he is appointed it is stated that no objection will be made by the Japanese Government.

ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- There were some errors in the tabulated vote of the November election as published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday morning. The tabulations have been completed and the tables are ready for the meeting of the State Board of Canvassers. According to the official returns, the pluralities received by the officers-elect are:

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 9. -- The cold wave has covered the North Shrewsbury River with two inches of hard, smooth ice, and the ice yachtsmen are busy. At least eight new iceboats will be launched this season, and the indications point to an unusually lively Winter among the boatmen. If the present weather should continue for two days longer the ice would be thick enough to hold the third-class boats.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9. -- Scorpio was the only winning favorite here to-day. In warming up for the third race. St. Cuthbert ran into the fence and was cut badly. He was ordered scratched and twenty minutes given for a new book. On account of unsatisfactory riding, particularly on If You Dare in his last two starts, the Stewards have recommended that Jockey T. Walsh be allowed to accept no more engagements at present.

ATLANTA, Dec. 9. -- Fire destroyed nearly a block of buildings in the heart of the city to-day, and the loss is placed at $400,000. It started in the furniture store of the Snook Austin Company, in Whitehall Street.

MAYAGUEZ, Porto Rico, Dec. 9. -- A notable victory was achieved this morning by Admiral Sumner, in command of the White Squadron, with the Iowa, Illinois, Alabama, and the Chicago. He captured Mayaguez without resistance at 6:24 this morning and immediately mined the harbor.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- Money was in good demand to-day, but was not abundant. Discounts were quietly firm.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 9. -- All German and British subjects in Caracas were arrested to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The dinner by the bar of the Supreme Court of the United States at the New Willard Hotel to-night to Justice John Marshall Harlan, in recognition of the completion of twenty-five years of service on the bench of the Supreme Court, was a brilliant function. The banquet hall was handsomely illuminated, and the tables elaborately decorated with palms, American Beauty roses, and laurel.

Fifteen-year-old Elizabeth McCourt of 920 Second Avenue proved herself a heroine last evening by stopping a runaway horse on Park Avenue just as it was about to dash through the gate at Forty-eighth Street, leading into the New York Central Railroad yards. The Montreal Express, which leaves the Grand Central Station at 6:35 o'clock, was just rounding the curve to enter the tunnel as the runaway was brought to a stop.

John Noonan, driver for John Gallagher, got into trouble yesterday afternoon while hauling a load of sand on Park Row, opposite City Hall Park, and over the subway excavation. At this point a red flag fluttered on a pole above the roadway, and the sub-contractors, Degnon McLean, claim they had a man there to warn drivers of danger in passing along that way.

There are comparatively few white British subjects in Caracas, probably less than fifty. The Caracas-La Guayra Railroad is a British concern, and its General Manager and other high officials are Englishmen. There are some English engineers on the line. Other Englishmen in Caracas are employed in commercial and industrial pursuits, and Englishmen are found among the clerical force ct commercial houses.

Winter clutched New York City and the surrounding country in a very tight grasp yesterday. It was the coldest Dec. 9 since 1876, the thermometer registering but 8 degrees above zero at 8 o'clock in the morning. The fact that the day was somewhat windy made conditions more severe, but the day was made extraordinarily miserable for the poor by the scarcity of coal.

The death of Mr. REED emphasizes the fact that he was "the scholar in politics," the absence of whom from them so many orators at so many commencements have for so many years been in the habit of deploring. Mr. REED'S own characteristic and caustic saying that a statesman is "a politician who is dead" indicated that the grievance of the orators was not a grievance to him.

Something of the interest taken by official German circles in the controversy as to what wine was used in naming Emperor William's yacht Meteor III. has been brought to light in recent hearings before Referee Frank Walling, who was appointed by the United States Circuit Court of the Eastern District of Wisconsin to take testimony here in a suit instituted by the American agent for Moet Chandon champagne.

George Ranger has sold for the estate of John R. Ford, to Boehm Boehm, the plot at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street, 100 by 90. The property will probably be resold for improvement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Minister Bowen at Caracas has cabled the State Department confirmation of the report that the British Minister and the German Charge d'Affaires withdrew from Caracas yesterday. Before they left these officials requested Mr. Bowen to take charge of the interests of their countries in Venezuela.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., Dec. 9. -- Deeds conveying right of way to the Cripple Creek and Pueblo Railroad Company were filed here to-day, and simultaneously articles of incorporation were also placed on file. The purpose of the company is to construct a thirty-three-mile railroad connecting the gold camp with Pueblo.

Yesterday was a day of debutantes' receptions and dances. To-day Mrs. Seth Barton French will give a reception for the Misses Atterbury, who are relatives of her husband. This evening the first of two dinners given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Poor for Miss Edith Poor takes place, and tomorrow the Assembly.

The hardest day of the six-day bicycle grind in Madison Square Garden was yesterday, and when it closed at midnight, although the leaders were over forty miles behind the forty-eight-hour record, nearly all of the eleven teams now remaining in the race appeared strong enough to continue the test of endurance to the end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- There is considerable feeling in Administration circles with regard to the action taken by the North Carolina Democrats yesterday in interfering in the fight between the "Lily Whites" and the negroes. This question is recognized as one of the most serious and vexatious with which the President has to deal, at least from a political standpoint, and the intrusion of the Democrats is resented.

The New York Stock Exchange has been without an official Chairman since Monday last, when the resignation of McPherson Kennedy took effect. On the morning of that day Mr. Kennedy called the board to order for the last time, and since then the gavel has been wielded by Assistant Chairman Niles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The London Dock bill was debated, voted upon, and defeated in the House to-day. This was effected by striking out the enacting clause. The vote was 129 in the affirmative and 138 in the negative. It is a victory for the shipping interests of the country as against their customers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Rear Admiral Gibson of the navy has submitted a claim under the provisions of the Personnel act the result of which is being watched with great interest by naval officers. Nearly three years ago Admiral Gibson was retired, at his own request, while holding the grade of Captain.

The measure known as the Coal Commission Appropriation bill and officially numbered H.R. 15,327, seems to have created more excitement than the facts of the case warrant. It is designated in its title as a bill "to provide for the expenses and compensation of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission appointed by the President of the United States."

MAYAGUEZ, Porto Rico, Dec. 10. -- Admiral Higginson arrived here at 11 o'clock last night and sent a letter to Admiral Sumner under a flag of truce, the Hist serving as a messenger, announcing his presence with four battleships and a number of cruisers. He further stated that if the harbor was properly mined he would concede the victory to Admiral Sumner, and congratulated the latter on his success.

The bears in the stock market had a field day of it yesterday. Taking advantage of the Venezuelan developments they very adroitly but none the less persistently circulated a variety of disturbing and depressing rumors bearing on the situation and calculated to give pause even to the most ardent bull.

Dr. Lyman Abbott addressed the Graduates' Club at Columbia University in Earl Hall last evening, his subject being, "Our Industrial Problem." He dealt with capital, labor, present conditions, and political uprightness, condemning and praising combinations of capital and labor organizations without reserve, and expressed as his opinion that there is a movement on foot toward the dissolution of social formations in the United States and a tendency toward a Socialistic basis.

In and about the coal yards of this city yesterday there were enacted scenes unique in the history of New York. It is true that the weather had moderated somewhat from the day before, but the little supply of fuel that families, particularly on the east side, had been able to secure on Tuesday had generally been exhausted.

Reactions occurred in nearly all outside stocks yesterday, the curb in this respect following the course of the Stock Exchange market. While the outside declines were not in most cases as heavy as those on the board, there were very few issues which passed through the day without some loss. Northern Securities, which of late has been the centre of interest, was the stock which suffered most by the day's liquidation.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- Hypnotism was brought into the case of Nellie Howell, daughter of W.B. Howell, the wing shot, who to-day was committed to the Reformatory for Women, at Bedford, by City Judge Kellogg, for soliciting contributions for a Christmas dinner for St. Andrew's Church, in this city, without proper authority.
ALBANY, Dec. 10. -- The Oriental Bank of 122 Bowery, New York, to-day certified to the Secretary of State that it had increased its capital stock from $300,000 to $600,000.
LA GUAYRA, Dec. 10. -- The combined British-German fleet is entering this harbor, and the first vessels are not 300 feet from the Custom House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial relating to the Department of Health in to-day's issue you gave well-merited praise to Dr. Lederle and his subordinates. You have failed, however, to refer to the one thing which proves more than all others together the changed atmosphere and the new spirit in that department.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Administration averted a serious bit of trouble today largely through the shrewdness of Postmaster General Payne.

The Meyerbeer tradition still holds at the Metropolitan Opera House, as it does a others where the theatrical scheme of things can be made to count by the production of elaborate pageants and the exhibition of star singers in brilliant casts. These are the things that keep alive the three Meyerbeer operas that survive upon the contemporary stage -- "Les Huguenots," "Le Prophete," and "L'Africaine."

The public meeting of the Civic Federation for general discussion, which has occupied the past three days, was of benefit to the interests represented. One who attended every session and listened patiently to all that was said would be likely to ask himself whether the time devoted to the meetings was wisely and profitably employed.

PRINCETON N.J., Dec. 10. -- A.R.T. Hillebrand, Captain of the championship 1899 football team and the 1900 baseball team, has been engaged to coach the Princeton candidates this Spring in baseball and next Fall in football. Hillebrand played at right tackle on the eleven, and for two years was the all-American choice for that position.

Pearl dominos are among the pretty things shown for holiday gifts. Ivory dominos are to be found also in little Japanese leather boxes, each box with shelves, so that the dominos need not be scratched.

-- Life in a town named Tunkhannock might reasonably be expected to give a man accurate as well as extensive knowledge about forest trees and their habits, but the resident of Tunkhannock whose letter we published disappointed that expectation, and, while revealing an admirable judement in the matter of editorial paragraphs, at the same time betrayed a most deplorable ignorance of arboriculture in general and of Christmas trees in particular.

The three days' session of the Civic Federation was brought to a close last evening by an address by Senator Hanna, in which he summed up what appeared to him to be tangible results likely to flow from the exchange of ideas between some of the leading manufacturers, some of the leaders of labor, and some of the noted economists of the country.
Prof. GALVIN W. GREEN, Professor of mathematics of the Illinois Wesleyan University, died at Bloomington, Ill., yesterday, aged forty-five years.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Dec. 10. -- The treaty between the United States and Great Britain regarding commercial relations between the United States and Newfoundland was made public to-day. The treaty is as follows: Article I.
Bishop Potter addressed a largely attended meeting of young men in Grace Chapel, 415 East Thirteenth Street, last evening on the lessons of the recent coal strike.

TAOOMA, Washington, Dec. 10. -- Quietly but strenuously the greatest political fight in the history of this State is now in progress. On one side are Gov. McBride, State Senators Warburton of Tacoma and Preston of Seattle, together with farmers and all others who favor the creation by the Legislature of a State Railroad Commission to regulate transportation rates.

Army. The following-named officers of the Artillery Corps will report to Col. John P. Story, Artillery Corps. President of the examining board, at Fort Monroe for examination: First Lieuts. Winfred B. Carr, Percy P. Bishop, Henry J. Hatch, and Elmer J. Wallace.

It is reported from Washington that the President is annoyed by the interference of the North Carolina delegation in Congress, all Democrats, in the matter of the negro Postmaster whom Senator PRITCHARD is trying to dislodge. We venture to hope that it is the emotion of Postmaster PAYNE and not that of President ROOSEVELT that is referred to.

DETROIT, Dec. 10. -- The National Reciprocity Convention opened here to-day. There were present nearly 100 delegates from the Northern tier of States and several from Canada. F.D. Smith, President of the Detroit Chamber of Commerce, called the convention to order. He said:

Neither law nor custom forbids a diplomat to mask the real reason of an action behind an avowed reason. The inquiry which the Japanese Minister has made at the State Department concerning the President's reported intention to appoint Mr. JOHN BARRETT Minister to Japan does not indicate, however, that Mr. BARRETT would not be persona grata.
What do you want? My husband. Madam, I haven't got your husband. Any one, to hear you talk, would think I never had a husband!

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- "It is a skedaddle," said Senator Quay at the conclusion of the first day's engagement on the Statehood bill. The remark was intended to apply to the act of Senator Nelson, who for the Committee on Territories withdrew the substitute bill providing for the admission of Oklahoma and Indian Territory as one State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- United States Minister Bowen, at Caracas, has accepted the trust of looking after the interests of British and German subjects in Venezuela, and this has brought him into conflict with President Castro.

More sensations marked the progress of the six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden yesterday than have been seen since the start of the long grind. Two teams dropped out, leaving nine to continue the dizzy whirl around the track, and two new world's records were established in exhibition runs by the champion short-distance rider, Frank Kramer.

The congestion of the elevated railroads and the general lack of system and discipline shown in the management of the train service, especially on the west side, indicate a lack of capacity in the executive direction of the system which warrants great popular complaint. The so-called express service is thrown into confusion by the slightest of pretexts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to-day decided to postpone consideration of a supplementary treaty extending for a year the time for the ratification of the cession of the Danish West Indies to the United States. The rejection of the original treaty by the Danish Parliament makes action in regard to the supplemental treaty unnecessary at this time.

The report of the Sloss-Sheffield Steel and Iron Company for October and for the quarter ended Nov. 30 (November estimated) was made public yesterday. The October figures showed profits from operations of $180,950, net profits of S162,510, and total profits after allowance for bond and tax charges, $142,510.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 10. -- In accordance with the agreement reached late last night between the proxy committees of the three factions who have been contending for control of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, the following Directors were unanimously elected at the stockholders' meeting to-day:

Judge Hinsdale of the Court of Special Sessions, sent yesterday to Everett V. Abbot, Chairman of the Committee on Membership of the Civil Service Reform Association, a letter in answer to the letter from Mr. Abbot that was published on Monday. The controversy began with Judge Hinsdale's reply to an invitation from Mr. Abbot to become a member of the Association, in refusing which Justice Hinsdale criticised the administration of the present civil service law.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10. -- Plans are under way at both Harvard and Yale to come to a mutual agreement during the coming Christmas holidays regarding both a new schedule of athletic meets between the two universities and a new set of eligibility rules.

There was a break in prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday, during which many active and representative stocks declined from three to five points each, while there was an extreme break of six points in Westinghouse Manufacturing first, preferred stock on the execution of a single selling order involving 100 shares.

BOSTON, Dec. 10. -- The money market continues quiet, with call money generally on a 6 per cent, basis. Very few borrowers are able to better this figure. The business doing in time money is still light, but the banks are, for the most part, taking care of their regular customers at 5 1/2 to 6 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- There was increased activity in the local market today, and it was at the expense of values. The calling of loans by financial institutions induced some liquidations, and the market took the offerings only after concessions. Consolidated Lake Superior broke 1 1/2, the preferred 3/4; International Smokeless Powder preferred, 1; Pennsylvania Railroad, 1 1/4; Reading, 1 5/8, and several others 1/4 to 1/2.
