OSWEGO, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- Grace Presbyterian Church was thronged with a fashionable assemblage at 7 o'clo'ck this evening for the marriage of Miss Ruth Woolsey Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Dole Johnson, to Luther Wright Mott of this city.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 10. -- The team of Canadian football players arrived here to-day on the Allan Line steamer Bavarian, (from St. John, N.B., and Halifax,) and proceeded to Dublin. They will play several matches in Ireland before playing in England. On their way across the Atlantic the Canadians practiced daily.

ASSOUAN, Egypt, Dec. 10. -- The great Nile reservoir and dam were opened to-day in the presence of the Khedive, the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, Lord Cromer, (the British Agent and Consul General in Egypt) and Lady Cromer, the Ministers, and many other distinguished persons.

The Ministers of Great Britain and Germany having withdrawn from Caracas, our Minister, Mr. BOWEN, has, with the approval of the State Department, accepted the duty and responsibility of safeguarding the interests of resident subjects of those powers. The significance of this transfer of authority to the American Minister will be as clearly perceived in Venezuela and other South American republics as it is in Europe and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- United States Minister Bowen, at Caracas, wishes to play the part of peacemaker in the dispute between Venezuela and Germany and Great Britain, and the State Department, after considering his statements, has decided that he may do this only upon application from Venezuela for his good offices, and if the same shall be acceptable to the British and German representatives.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The rates for money were unchanged to-day and discounts showed a disposition to harden.

The application made by Reed, Slmpson, Thacher Barnum and opposed by John R. Dos Passes to vacate the one-milliondollar attachment against the International Power Company, obtained at the suit of John F. Plummer, under which about $3,000,000 worth of property was seized, has been denied by Justice Leventritt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Statistician of the Department of Agriculture estimates the newly seeded area of Winter wheat at about $4,000,000 acres, an increase of 5.16 per cent. upon the area estimated to have been sown in the Fall of 1901. The condition of Winter wheat on Dee. 1 was 99.7, as compared with 88.7 in 1901, 97.1 in 1900, and a nine-year average of 91.4.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Ex-Speaker Galusha A. Grow delivered to-day what may be called his farewell speech to the House. It is not really that, for in the various debates which will take place before next March Mr. Grow will probably participate like others and make extemporaneous remarks as occasion offers.

BOSTON, Dec. 10. -- W.W. Crapo, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Pere Marquette Railroad, is authority for the statement that the control of this property has not passed into the hands of outside parties. He declares that he has not sold any of his personal stock nor deposited it with a voting trust.

A published statement to the effect that the late THOMAS B. REED had an ambition to become a member of the Senate is contrary to what Mr. REED said when he left Congress, and seems to rest on no substantial foundation. It was one of Mr. REED'S characteristics that he frequently satirized the Senate and he declared on his retirement that he had no desire to become a member of that body.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Willemstad, Curacao, dated yesterday, says:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The cause of the conflict between Venezuela on one side and Great Britain and Germany on the other is of long standing. It grows out of claims made by the Governments of Germany and Great Britain for losses sustained by their respective citizens by revolutions and disturbances.

Mrs. Charles A. Post wore a gown of black satin, combined with black tulle, and embroidered in gold flowers. Black and gold flowers finished with a diamond aigrette were in her hair. Mrs. Lloyd Bryce wore an elaborate gray, gown, richly embroidered with pearls. Mrs. John Jacob Astor was in white satin, velvet and black lace, trimmed with gold.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The President and Secretary Hay are watching closely the progress of events at La Guayra and Caracas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Representative Pugsley of New York, a member of the Committee on Banking and Currency, today introduced a bill "to render the currency more elastic and responsive to the financial and commercial requirements of the country." It is said that Chairman Fowler of that committee has announced as his ultimatum that unless his own currency bill is passed none shall be passed.

The Manhattan Railway Company, with its recently installed electrical system received its second serious set-back yesterday when soon after four o'clock the drizzling rain that had fallen most of the day turned into a thin layer of ice on the "Contact" or "third" rail, and prevented the transmission of power from that rail into the motors in the propelling cars.

Drs. Andrew H. and Davison H. Smith have acquired, through Brokers Andrews, Bell Co., from the Post estate, the four-story dwelling 26 East Forty-second Street, on lot 24 by 78.9 and irregular, adjoining the small lot at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street, 28 by 36.7, for which they recently paid the record figure of $250,000, and also adjoining their previous holdings, 18 to 24 East Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- All barriers against the organization of the most powerful railroad protective bureau in the history of railroading were removed to-day, when the Executive Committee of the Western Passenger Association decided to recommend to the association membership in the proposed bureau.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 11. -- The delegates to the National Reciprocity Convention in its closing session this afternoon adopted the following resolutions:

The schedules of the Intercollegiate and the Amateur Hockey Leagues for the coming reason have been announced and give promise of a lively contest in both organizations. The Intercollegiate League is composed of Harvard, Yale, Columbia, Princeton, and Brovrn, and all its games, twelve in number, will be played in this city, beginning Jan. 10.

At the meetings of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, which were held on Tuesday and Wednesday at 66 Nassau Street, among the many topics discussed none excited interest equal to that of the proposition to greatly increase insurance rates on property facing streets where wires, carrying currents of high voltage, are supported by poles.

At the National Arts Club on Wednesday evening an interesting lecture on "The Development of Art in the Middle West" was delivered by L.H. Meakin of Cincinnati, whose landscapes have been attracting much attention at the exhibition of work by Western artists at the club.f
Two girls in torn jerseys, with battered straw hats, two men in check trousers, abbreviated coats, and flashy ties, "The real t'ing from, the Bowery, see?"

Pendleton Brothers of 48 South Street, this city, who a little more than a week ago lost their fine four-masted schooner Pendleton Brothers in a gale off the Virginia Capes, received the details yesterday of the loss of their barkentine Olive Thur low from Mate Charles Florian and two seamen, who arrived from Norfolk on the Old Dominion Line steamship Jamestown.

The proceedings in the Supreme Court for the appointment of a receiver of the property of Mrs. Sarah N. Waters of 451 West Twenty-first Street were stopped yesterday morning by the death of Mrs. Waters. Coroner Scholer and the District Attorney were notified, and an autopsy was performed in the afternoon by Dr. Otto Schultz.
ADEN, Dec. 11. -- A rumor has reached here of the assassination of the Mad Mullah in Somaliland.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Former President Cleveland presided to-night at a public meeting in aid of the Berean Manual Training School, which aims to give negroes the benefits of industrial education, Mr. Cleveland was the principal speaker and Booker T. Washington, President of Tuskegee Institute, also made an address.

The ceremonies on Wednesday attending the opening of the Assouan Dam and Reservoir seem like an intrusion of the practical and material present upon the sacred and prehistoric past. The Nile, with its traditions reaching back to an antiquity so remote that history and mythology are inextricably blended, seems to have no place in the economy of the present century, and to dam it and impound its waters seems almost like a profanation.

Little Michael Kruck, a newsboy, has been murdered. A policeman patrolling his lonely beat along the bridle path in the depth of Central Park late Wednesday night, found the lad's lifeless body lying on his unsold papers. Yesterday morning the identification was made, but that afforded no solution of the mystery that surrounds his death.

One of the best presents for the holiday comes in a tiny square box, the outside of which has a design of holly, with the bright scarlet berries, and in the centre inside an indentation into which fits a five-dollar goldpiece. That is sure to buy something some one wishes.

Coal operators strenuously denied yesterday that any effort was being made to hold up supplies of coal which should come to New York City, and they declared that every ton that could be raised was being rushed to this port. At the same time the very inclement day -- with its weather so precisely favorable for stirring up grip and pneumonia -- found the coal yards of the east side practically without supplies.

Columbia's basket ball players defeated the National Athletic Club team at the clubhouse of the latter players in Brooklyn last night by a score of 19 to 17. The contest was hard fought throughout, and Goodwin, a Columbia forward, was taken out of the game for rough play in the second half.

Andrew Carnegie, whose intended sailing from England a fortnight ago was delayed by his illness in London, arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Oceanic. He said that he never felt better in his life, but he looked a little pale and shaken and his step had lost some of its accustomed sprightliness.

The unexpected course of events in Venezuela increases the anxiety with which we regard the joint demonstration of Great Britain and Germany against that republic. The public avowal of the intention of the two powers has justified the belief that it was limited to the seizure of Venezuelan Custom Houses and of the duties there paid upon imports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Senate spent less than one hour on the Statehood bill to-day, but the play of strategy on both sides was unique and enjoyable. At 2 o'clock President Frye declared the bill before the Senate. Not a Senator stirred, and profound silence ensued.

The regular monthly meeting of The Jocky Club was held yesterday afternoon in the offices of the club in the Windsor Arcade, with sixteen members present. These were August Belmont, J.H. Bradford, F.K. Sturgis, Jesse Brown, S.S. Howland, F. R. Hitchcock, J.G. Follansbee, H.K. Knapp, J.G. Heckscher, P.J. Dwyer, A. H. Morris, W.C. Eustis, James R. Keene, Andrew Miller, Perry Belmont, and W.C. Whitney.

The day after the Assembly is generally one of rest. To-day a few more debutantes will be added to the list. Mrs. Hilborne L. Roosevelt of 301 Lexington Avenue will bring out Miss Dorothy Roosevelt, and a small dance is to be given at Sherry's for Miss O'Brien, the daughter of Morgan J. O'Brien.

Yesterday in the outside market, as in the Stock Exchange market, was a day of liquidation. Without exception the Stocks which contributed to the day's transactions suffered more or less substantial losses, and in few cases was there any recovery from the low prices brought about by the selling movement which was in progress.
William S. Devery, the Ninth District Tammany leader, last night denied the story that he intended to resign his leadership in favor of Alderman Frank Dowling or Peter J. Garvey.

The Evening Post yesterday did a timely public service in printing the full text of the contract between the city and the Pennsylvania Railroad now before the Board of Aldermen. It explains that it did so for the purpose, of showing how carefully the rights and interests of the city had been safeguarded in the preparation of the contract.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Money was much wanted to-day in connection with operations on the Stock Exchange, the market being largely dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were quietly firm.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The announcement of the dispatch from the United States of a challenge for the James Cordon Bennett Cup was received by the members of the Automobile Club here with great satisfaction. It will be the first time that America has been represented in the race.

Semi-panicky conditions ruled at times in yesterday's Stock Exchange market. Close to a million and a quarter shares were traded in, and almost every stock on the list went down. Some fell points between sales. The professional contingent of traders maintained attacks all day long, the selling of short stock in free and easy fashion being upon an extended scale.

What is claimed to be the life romance of the young Crown Prince of Siam has just been brought to light. It appears that while in England he became infatuated with a woman of comic-opera fame, Maybelle Gilman. He wanted to marry her, but was forced to go to Russia. He ran away from the Siamese legation there, it is said, and returned to meet her in London.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- A lengthy official dispatch has been received at the Foreign Office here from Caracas, saying that the boats of the German warships, in seizing the vessels supposed to belong to Venezuela, also captured a French merchant steamer, the Ossun.

The money market which has been grumbling along with more or less violent eruptions at intervals for the last three months, again took on a dangerous aspect yesterday. But while heretofore the cause for anxiety had been mainly in the high rates for call money, the trouble now lies more in the tremendous demand for time loans.

The crippled service on the elevated road last night nearly precipitated a riot at the Twenty-third Street up-town station of the Second Avenue branch soon after 11 o'clock. Over 200 people got off a train that had crawled in about half an hour from Fourteenth Street and demanded their money back.

-- When the news first came that the British and Germans had seized the Venezuelan navy, it was natural to wonder what they were going to do with it. Remembering the course usually pursued when a creditor has secured possession of a debtor's property, joyous expectations were excited -- expectations that the two Admirals who made the levy would offer it for sale to the highest bidder.

At the second concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, given last evening in Carnegie Hall -- which was, by the way, the hundredth performance it has given in New York -- Mr. Gericke played two modern pieces, one of them for the first time in New York, and two classics that belong in the highest walks of music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hay this afternoon received a deputation representing all religious bodies in the United States that are doing missionary and educational work in the Turkish Empire. The deputation was headed by Morris K. Jesup, President of the Chamber of Commerce of New York and President of the Board of Trustees of the Syrian Protestant College at Beirut.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Testifying before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor to-day, during the consideration of the bill which limits work on all Government contracts to eight hours a day, J.H. Mull of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, in denouncing the methods of labor organizations, created a sensation when he told of an act which, he said, was perpetrated by members of the International Association of Machinists during the Spanish-American war.

It is no exaggeration to say that the paintings from the collection owned by George A. Hearn, which are on view at the Union League Club, are the most important, interesting, and Valuable now being exhibited in New York. The first thought that occurs to one on seeing these treasures of art is regret that they can be examined by so few.

The banquet hall of the Hotel Manhattan resounded with cheers and with the songs of old Union last night, when 150 alumni of the up-State institution met for the annual dinner of the Union College Alumni Association of New York. Toasts were made by President Andrew V.V. Raymond, D.D., of Union College; ex-Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith, ex-Judge Judson S. Landon of the Court of Appeals, ex-Senator Warner Miller, and others. Frederick W. Seward presided.

Sprinting was the order of the day yesterday in the six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden. Four different teams each gained a lap, the leaders were reduced to two teams tied for first place, and Frank Kramer made a new world's record for the quarter-mile unpaced bicycle sprint in 0:25.

The sharp decline in prices on the Stock Exchange on Wednesday was succeeded yesterday by an even more violent break, in the course of which active stocks fell from 3 to 4 points each, while there were several single declines of 6 points and one extreme break of 12 points -- this latter in North American.

It would be a pity if an important public benefaction should fail of public appreciation because it has been misdescribed. The bill before the House of Representatives to incorporate a "General Educational Board" has been rather absurdly interpreted in print as an endeavor on the part of Mr. ROCKEFELLER to outdo Mr. CARNEGIE and Mr. CARNEGIE'S "National University."

In the tournament of the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum Bowling League last night the Lefferts Council team, last year's winners, won two more games, which gives it a commanding lead in the series, with 8 games won and only 2 lost. The scores follow:

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- The money situation remains without change. Clearing House rate, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 15c, 12 1/2c, and 8c discount; call loans, 6 per cent.; time money, 5 1/2@6 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $26,620,370; balances, $2,675,167.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 11. -- The representatives of the miners during to-day's proceedings before the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission called one of the independent operators to the witness stand to tell the exact price he received for his coal, and the mine owner refused, giving instead, after much questioning, an average of the price he received.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You printed a short article of mine recently in which I made the statement that the drink "half-and-half," so called, was not known, nor so much as known even by name, in England. This has called out a score of correspondents to your excellent newspaper in rebuttal.

Black Diamond, a horse employed in the trucking business of Holland Co., contractors, and residing at the livery stable at 493 West Broadway, was arrested yesterday by Policeman Upham of the Mercer Street Station charged with trespass and disorderly conduct. The technical charge was walking without an invitation into the factory of Rossig Brothers, makers of artificial foliage, on the second floor of 497 West Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- The twenty-second annual meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League began here to-day. During the afternoon the annual report of the Executive Council was read. The report commends the policy of President Roosevelt in making Federal appointments, and calls attention to the persistent hostility of professional politicians in both the great National parties to civil service reform.

The most important literary announcement of the week is made, with characteristic modesty, through his publishers, the J.B. Lippincott Company, by our foremost Shakespearean student and editor, Dr. Horace Howard Furness. It is that the responsibility and labor of editing that monumental work, the Variorum Shakespeare, are henceforward to be shared by Dr. Furness's son, Horace Howard Furness, Jr.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- In consequence of the disquieting news received last week from Tesa, says a dispatch from Mekinez to The Times, the Sultan of Morocco has returned to Mekinez with his army, and has dispatched several thousand infantry and cavalry to reinforce the troops already at Tesa.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- There were three important developments to-day in connection with the collapse of the shares of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company, which began yesterday and continued during to-day's operations on the Stock Exchange.
BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- The sending of the cruiser Falke to Puerto Cabello is understood here to have been for the same purpose as the operations at La Guayre.

SECOND ARTICLE. IT SEEMS sometimes these days that books are turned out on the Penny-in-the-slot plan, there are such infinite numbers of them. But with the increasing quantity there is increasing quality, as a rule, increasing variety, and there is something to please everybody to the boots for the holidays.

An amusing controversy has grown out of the speech of Edmund Gosse, from which we quoted last week, at the banquet in London to the contributors to the Supplement of the Encyclopaedia Britannica. It was begun by Sir Edward Clarke, K.C., who is a lawyer of note and is also of some prominence in the world of letters.

The array of calendars which E.P. Dutton Co. present this year are of more than usual artistic value, not only on account of the artists employed, but because the color work is the result of Bavarian printing, which is noted the world over for the lustre of pigment, the harmony of shades, and the admirable registering of plates.

Roger Wolcott, who died in 1900, at the age of fifty-three, after having been four times elected Lieutenant Governor and thrice Governor of Massachusetts, was a New Englander of a peculiarly attractive type. His fine old English name came from Somersetshire, where it is now spelled Walcott.

The recent remarkable divagations of the Doukhobors in Canada lend a particular interest to the relation of Tolstoi to the sect, as described by his friend and literary representative at Paris, Mr. J.W. Bienstock, in the current number of The Independent.

The comparative statistics compiled by the editor of Dun's Review show that the cost of living, as measured by the prices of the necessary staples of family consumption, is showing a slight decline. During October the shrinkage was equivalent to about 1 per cent. The September average, built up on prices of commodities proportioned to consumption per capits, was $100.57; the October average $99.74.

TO THE average reader of German current news Teutonic interest seems to centre around three subjects -- the idiosyncrasies of the Kaiser, the crimes against lese majeste, and the augmentation of the German Navy.

The British steamship Hillglen, which arrived yesterday from the Far East, was reported the other day as having put into Newport, R.I., for coal. Her agents, Irwin, McBride Co. of this city, were greatly surprised when they heard that she had called there.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- As a result of the announcement that Venezuela has asked United States Minister Bowen to act as arbitrator in the controversy with Great Britain and Germany, Senor Schotborgh, Venezuelan Consul here, last night made an important statement.

WHAT are published this season under the hackneyed title of "gift books" seem to require some brief work of explanation, for, individually and as a whole, they are of unusual excellence in several particulars.

In commenting on the complete breakdown of the electric system on the elevated railroads in consequence of the coating or the contact rail with ice deposited by the storm of Thursday night, THE TIMES has no other wish than to do the management full justice. Criticism which overlooks essential facts and fails to recognize conditions which cannot be avoided or conquered, usually falls of its purpose.

The annual meeting of National League baseball club owners, which was concluded last evening at the Victoria Hotel, will undoubtedly mark the beginning of a new and successful era in the history of the national game. When the meeting began last Tuesday war measures were considered necessary to frustrate the workings of the American League officials.

It is not too late to arbitrate the questions at issue between Venezuela and Great Britain and Germany. The intimation that matters have now gone too far to permit the acceptance of the request for arbitration preferred by President CASTRO through the American Minister, if authorized, is senseless, and, if unauthorized, is mischievous.

IN THE introduction to "The Eldorado of the Ancients," Dr. Carl Peters dwells somewhat on the reason for his leaving the German service and finding employment in England. In 1891 Dr. Peters was appointed Imperial High Commissioner of the Kalimanjaro District.

Dr. Adolph Lorenz, the distinguished Viennese surgeon, who has created a furor among the specialists in this country within the past few months in his treatment of congenital hip disease, will arrive in the city this afternoon at 4 o'clock, coming from Philadelphia. He will find every hospital in New York open to him, and, were his strength equal to it, he could find subjects by hundreds for treatment.
SUBJECT -- Samuel the Judge. -- First Samuel, vii., 2-13.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- A secret wedding on the night of Dec. 3, in the office of Justice of the Peace Beaman, developed into a genuine sensation to-day when it became known that William Heaton, twenty-two years old, of 12 Chestnut Street, was parted from his bride, who was Miss May Robinson of 109 Orchard Street.

A will of Mrs. Sarah Ann Waters of 451 West Twenty-first Street, whose death on Tuesday stopped the proceedings in the Supreme Court for the appointment of a receiver for her property, was offered for probate yesterday. The petition was filed by the attorneys of the executor, William G. Conklin, cashier of the Franklin Savings Bank.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Maurice Hewlett is now writing two hooks, one a novel in which Mary, Queen of Scots, will be the Chief figure, the other entitled "Impressions of Italy."

BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- President Castro's war preparations and his public utterances are regarded in official quarters here as "designed to see how far the allies are willing to go, as a test of the further attitude of the Administration at Washington, and, above all, as efforts to unite his own people and reconcile them to his dictatorship."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The little controversy anent New Jersey's place in American literature, it appears to the undersigned, is in danger of being diverted into something like an apotheosis of one Freneau, over whose birthplace a contention seems to have also arisen as an outcome thereof that promises, if it meets with no check, to emulate that historic one concerning which seven ancient cities, it is said, were once involved.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The Pilot died a few days ago regretted by a wide circle of friends. Its death was, of course, long ago seen to be inevitable, for it was a new literary weekly, and London has no room for such ventures.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I notice in your issue of Nov. 29 an "Inquiry" from Watertown, N.Y., with the above heading. "The query is, How was it possible for us to discharge the debt due Russia for sending a fleet for our protection by taking Alaska from her?"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Postmaster General Payne to-day wrote to Senator Simmons of North Carolina, attempting to appease that statesman's wrath over the intimations that his interference in the "Lily White" fight was not approved by the Administration. Mr. Payne assured, the Democratic Senator in this letter that he much regretted that any such report should have gained currency.
JEANNE D' ARC was untutored, unlettered, and only eighteen years old, yet she accomplished marvels. Mr. T. Douglas Murray, enthusiastic as to his heroine writes:
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The rates for money were steady to-day and much cash was wanted. Discounts were inclined to slacken.

Class enthusiasm in Columbia University resulted last night in what might have been a riot in front of Healy's restaurant, at Sixty-sixth Street, and Columbus Avenue. Capt. Kear of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station had been notified by Mr. Healy that the college freshmen had an engagement in his "dungeons" for dinner.

The New york Times Saturday Review of Books: Having given your readers a conundrum to answer in regard to the once famous Cavalier poet, John Clieveland, and time enough to answer, may I now proceed to guess it myself? Although nobody has sifted out all the genuine verse and prose of this scholar from that mixed with his or ascribed to him, (either by sincere mistake or to sell the books.)

Col. John N. Partridge, Commissioner of Police, yesterday tendered his resignation to take effect Jan. 1, 1903. It has been informally accepted by Mayor Low, who states that thus far no successor has been determined upon.

William E. Callender has sold for the States Mortgage and Realty Company (Judson S. Todd) to the Collins Building and Construction Company, 70 and 72 West Forty-ninth Street, a plot 41 by 100.3, upon which a nine-and-one-half-story apartment hotel will be erected.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- In its City article to-day The Times says the money market was fairly active yesterday and the rates for loans were well maintained. Discount rates were steady.

In connection with District Attorney Jerome's plan to raise a host of witnesses to be used in the warfare he has begun for the avowed purpose of driving every gambler out of New York, a small army of process servers yesterday invaded the fashionable Fifth Avenue region.

ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 12 -- The proposition of holding future contests between West Point and Annapolis under the eligibility rules of the Intercollegiate Association will be discussed at the next meeting of the representatives of the two institutions, which will take place at an early date for the purpose of arranging the details of next season's football game.

The library of the late R.C. Naylor of Kelmarsh Hall, Northampton, was sold by Messrs. Sotheby Nov. 24 and 25. The most important item was Bridges's "History and Antiquities of Northamptonshire," 1791, extra-illustrated with portraits and drawings and extended from two volumes to six. This brought L215.

Giacomo Puccini's opera "Tosca" was given last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season. This, one of the latest products of the young Italian school of operatic composition, has been heard in New York at the opera for two seasons, having been produced first in February, 1901, and its grisly story of passion, jealousy, and implacable hate has become thoroughly familiar to the frequenters of the opera in New York.

SEVERAL histories of the United States or of the American people have been written, varying in style, tone, plan, and aspiration, from the volumetric grandeur of Bancroft to the conscientious plodding of McMaster. In the main these histories have been more or less polemic, and in their pages constantly crop out with more or less vehemence the zeal and passions of political contests or of personal feads long past and gone.

An exhibition of posters from the collection of Wilbur Macey Stone of New York was opened in the assembly room of the Free Public Library of Newark last week. Some 500 posters, many of which were autograph copies, were hung from Mr. Stone's collection of over 1,200 examples. The invitations to attend the exhibition contained a miniature reproduction of one of the chap book posters.

George F. Baer was the central figure and coal was the predominating subject of interest at the fourth annual banquet of the Pennsylvania Society, held last night at the Woldorf-Astoria, and presided over by its President Bishop Henry C. Potter.

It is not in the least in any spirit of hostility to Commissioner PARTRIDGE that we cheerfully take him at his word in his resignation of his office, and bid him farewell. It is because we hold that Tammany domination of this city is simply a public curse, which is to be averted by all legitimate means, and because Commissioner PARTRIDGE'S incumbency of his office has directly tended to bring back Tammany domination.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Mrs. Coralie Franklin Cook, instructor in oratory at Howard University, and a well-known woman suffragist, is here delivering lectures and is being entertained royally by Rochester society. This afternon Miss Susan B. Anthony, the famous woman-suffragist leader, held a brilliant reception in her spacious mansion at 17 Madison Street in honor of the colored educator.

Early Social Life in New York. Styles change and the things that our grandparents did are not always the proper things to do now, yet if Miss Singleton is to be relied upon, there have been fewer changes in manners and customs since the days of the Georges than one might supposed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- L.E. Payson of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company, in testifying before the Labor Committee of the Senate to-day, referred to the strike at Newport News in 1901, and said that when the battleship Illinois was about to leave the yards on her trial trip labor unions declared she should not leave until their terms were complied with.

Mayor Low's action in transmitting to the Municipal Civil Service Commission charges filed against that body on Dec. 1 by the Civil Service Reform Association evoked a reply which was made public yesterday at the commission's meeting. The Commissioners criticised the association for making its strictures public and declared that, if the organizaton had conferred with those whom they attacked before doing so, the causes of the complaints might have been explained.

An exhibition of original and early editions of Italian books was opened at the Grolier Club on Dec. 4. Mr. Marion Crawford addressed the members upon Italian literature as illustrated by the showing of more than one hundred notable examples of books originating in Italy that were on view at the clubhouse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave the second of her series of teas this afternoon, when she welcomed several hundred guests in the Red Parlor, which, with the adjoining dining room, is now about completed. Receiving with the hostess were Mrs. Shaw, Mrs. Knox, Mrs. Payne, and Miss Wilson, all of the Cabinet circle.

Mr. Livingston's eighth volume of "American Book Prices Current" deals with the book and autograph sales which occurred in this country from September, 1901, to September, 1902, and appears in a larger edition than usual, 960 copies having been printed, as against an issue last year of 625.

Arrangements have been concluded by which, with the consent of the stockholders, the National Bank of the United States in New York will absorb the Western National Bank. The combination, it is said, will bring together the financial interests of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, the Mutual Life Insurance Company, and the Morton Trust Company, the three institutions representing the controlling interests of the two banks.

The last round of debutantes' receptions takes place to-day. There are several of the debutantes and each will have many others assisting to receive. One of the largest receptions will be that given by Mrs. Artemus Holmes for Miss Lillian Stokes Holmes. Mrs. Ernest Crosby and Mrs. William Baylis are also to give teas, and in the evening there will be the first of the Saturday night dances, Mrs. Charles R. O. Huntington's class.

Commenting on an anecdote touching the large influence of Will Carleton, published in a recent number of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, The Evening Wisconsin of Milwaukee says: "There have been many histories of American literature put forth within the past quarter of a century which have contained no mention of Will Carleton.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: One of the most urgent needs of our people in an educational point of view is a complete, well-arranged history of this hemisphere, a hemisphere justly characterized as the world's paradise. We have histories of a portion of it, but no complete history has been published.

Thousands of persons in this city were inconvenienced seriously yesterday by the tie-up of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad system. The abused "third rail" was insulated, and the antiquated little locomotives proved friends indeed. The electrical trains were in large measure out of business in the morning, and it was not until late in the afternoon that things were put into something like shape again.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Foreign Office has issued the text of a British-Abyssinian treaty which was ratified on Oct. 28.

ONLY yesterday, it seems, the newspapers announced the finding of the tusks of some huge animal far to the northward of Cape Nome. "Oh! how very long ago it must have been when that mastodon or mammoth was alive and kicking," says some one.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Venezuelan crisis is regarded less seriously here this morning. Lord Lansdowne's speech is held to show that the situation is in no way alarming, and although the opinion is expressed that President Castro's reported request for arbitration has come too late, this step on his part is welcomed as a proof of his anxiety to withdraw from his position.

"Industrial Peace" was the subject of the speechmaking at the conclusion of the Social Reform Club dinner, which took place last night at the Clarendon Hotel, on Fourth Avenue. G.W. Alger acted as Chairman, and the speakers were John A. Hobson of England, Dr. Felix Adler, Charles A. Cowen, Edward Motfett, A.L. Richey, and W.A. Perrine.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Authors have occasionally written about books of their own composition. Usually they have done this upon some special request, or because they wished to publish some particular informtion -- and not from mere vainglory.

A MATTER for encouragement is the brisk demand for the new twenty-four volume "Standard Library" edition of the late John Fiske's complete works. It is published only by subscription, so that, although its price is no higher than that originally set upon its contents, it represents a considerable investment; but even now.

IT IS always a little surprising to ordinary human belongs when a man who has long done one thing superlatively well suddenly demonstrates that he has decided talents in another direction, and there may also be a little envy mingled with the surprise, and some regret that it always has been and always will be true that "to him that hath shall be given."

MR. CAFFIN'S criticisms are explanatory rather than illumnating, but they give a reasonable idea of the character of the painters he describes as well as an interesting impression of their pictures, helped out to an important degree by the reproductions of the latter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- The market opened about as had been expected -- weak, lower, and excited, owing to the heavy liquidating orders which were sent direct from commission houses. A feeling of uneasiness everywhere was apparent, and the intensity of the strain was increased by breaks in Cambria Steel, Rapid Transit, United Gas, and the Consolidated Lake Superior issues.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 12 -- Industrial circles are stirred up over the apparent possibility of the consolidation of the Union Steel company and the United States Steel Corporation. It was current rumor to-day that the arrangement for a consolidation of these steel interests had been completed more than two months ago and that certain investors had a tip to buy Sharon steel stock for a rise.

BOSTON, Dec, 12 -- Money conditions remain quiet, and, while rates are still holding firm, there are no material changes in quotations. Sterling exchange remains steady. Clearing House rate, 5 per cent. New York funds, 16 2-3 and 12 1/2 cents discount. Call loans, 6 per cent. Time money, 5 1/2 @ 6 per cent.

The author of "Samoa 'Uma" refuses to see anything in the least romantic in these islands of the Pacific. The lady writes: "My opportunities were ample to become familiar with the steam of foreign and native life as it passed through the current of my dally life on the domestic side of the American Consulate at Apia."

Biography of the late Dr. Joseph Parker On account of the sudden death of Dr. Joseph Parker of City Temple, London, the Fleming H. Revell Company is rushing through the press his biography, for some time in preparation by his lifelong friend, Dr. William Adamson.

In the early trading in the outside market yesterday the downward movement of prices was even sharper than it had been during the two preceding days. Soon, however, the course of quotations began to change, and most of the stocks which had sold down recovered more or less substantially.

OF making many Omar books there is, indeed, no end, and the latest of these, Dr. Bjerregaard's "Sufi Interpretation of Omar Khayyam," which holds the Rubaiyat to be allegory, is not the least edifying.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 12 -- Frostbitten and exhausted by a twenty-four-hour battle with sea, storm, hunger, and bitter cold, Capt. R.H. Somerville and a crew of six men of the schooner Belle Wooster reached here to-day.

In these three volumes or poems we look in vain for the "subtle perfection of phrase "and" happy coalescence of music and meaning" which, in Lowell's words, are needed to "make all ears converts and partisans." "Tangled in Stars" is by far the best of the three in both form and suggestion, yet the writer frequently is content to introduce the most slipshod lines and roughest collocation of consonants.
In the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum bowling tournament last night the Commonwealth Council bowlers won two games, defeating the Alert Council and the Washington Irving Council teams. The scores follow:

The tendency toward the consolidation of banks and the establishment of close relations between great financial concerns has of late been frequently noted in this city. There is a like tendency in London, where many of the old and solid private banks have been acquired by the joint stock institutions, resulting in closer concentration of capital.

Concerning the problem of coal supply it was said in the offices of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Com- pauy yesterday that the peculiar weather conditions had made the handling of coal difficult. Whole trains of anthracite were stalied at Hoboken because the rain and sleet had fallen on the coal, binding it into a compact mass.

For the third successive day Wall Street had yesterday a highly exciting time. Prices on the Stock Exchange crumbled away in the early trading anywhere from 2 to 12 points, incidentally carrying down fortunes with them, but rallied later so substantially that in many instances the early losses gave way to important net gains.

Who says all the plots are used up? That of "The Disentanglers" is originality it self. unique in its conception, and equally unexpected in its unfolding. Two young Englishmen of education, fashion, and distinguished connection find themselves "stoney broke," "down to hard pan," and cast about for a means of retrieving their fallen fortunes.

Recent London auction prices testify to Charles Lamb's popularity with the collectors. On Nov. 20-21 Puttick & Simpson sold the library of Alderman John Walker of the Woodlands, Acton, together with other properties. The principal item was Lamb's "Tale of Rosamund Gray." 1798, London imprint, bound in half calf, which sold for L51, a very good price for this imprint.

-- Incredulity has been excited in some quarters by the statement that ex-Speaker REED belonged to the eighth generation of a Portland family. This statement appeared in several obituary articles, and it did seem inconsistent with general impressions as to the antiquity of American families and towns.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12 -- The report concerning the severing of track athletic relations with Cornell has aroused much comment here. It seems, however, that it is simply a matter of conflicting dates, and there is no intention of severing the friend- ly relations which have always existed between the two universities.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 12 -- Judge P.S. Grosscup of Chicago, United States Circuit Judge for the Seventh Judicial District, in the course of an address on trusts, delivered to-day before the University of Nebraska, criticised the Sherman Anti-Trust law as unwise, and declared that as one step toward curing trust evils that act should be repealed.

Considering the subject of Jewish missions, or the movement to convert Jews to Christianity, a topic dwelt on by Mr. A.F. Thompson, it might be called mercenary to regard it alone in the light of the expenditures. There are so many ways in which money could be more advantageously spent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A cablegram, received at the State Department to-day from Minister Bowen at Caracas, states that the Venezuelan Government has requested him to propose to Great Britain and Germany that the difficulties arising out of the claims for alleged damages and injuries to British and German subjects be submitted to arbitration.

The "Life and Letters of the Right Hon. Friederich Max Muller," edited by his widow, has been published in two stout volumes by Messrs. Longmans, Green Co. In a purely anecdotal way, as a mere glance shows, this work adds much to the "Autobiography" published in 1901. Much of Miller's correspondence had been destroyed before his death.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12 -- Little Scout and Shoo Fly were the beaten favorites today. If You Dare was run up to $1,000 and bought in. John W. Gates was among the spectators. Weather cloudy, track heavy.

Justice MacLean of the Supreme Court has handed down a decision overruling a demurrer filed by ex-Charities Commissioner John W. Keller in a suit for $25,000 damages brought against him by Virginia Pleasants, widow and executrix of Cornelius Pleasants, who died in Bellevue Hospital on April 26, 1900.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is an old proverb that says "Coming events cast their shadows before." While I would not deny this, I would add that sometimes "past events shine more brilliantly further on." This thought came to me when I saw the account of the death of Elizabeth Cady Stanton.

Three specimens of rare interest have just been made ready for exhibition in the Department of Vertebrate Paleontology in the American Museum of Natural History. These specimens have been prepared under the direction of Adam Hermann, and they are considered of very great value from a scientific point of view.

WHEN it was all over the man in the light overcoat said he believed the conductor put the nickel there himself, just as a trap, but of course he didn't. He merely happened to see it lying on the floor as he passed through the car, and he picked it up and asked the man in the light overcoat if it belonged to him.

YOU sees, honey, dat one col' Wintah day Mistah Hoppergrass get hungry, an' he remember him o' de pantry o' de Ant fambly, an' off he go to Miss Ant. An' when Mistah Hoppergrass come to Miss Ant's doah he knock. and den he say to Miss Ant: "Please, Miss Ant, won't ye gib me some' in' to eat?"

Bum, the old patrol dog connected with the West Thirtieth Street Police Station, was a wise but sad dog yesterday. He is fourteen years old, but in all his life he had never had such an experience as befell him on Thursday, when he was picked up by the dog catchers and taken in company with a wagonload of common, ordinary street mongrels to the pound.
NO BABE was ever born in Montana with such brilliant prospects before it as the little stranger who came to the home of Mr. and Mrs. W.A. Clark, Jr., on Monday, says The Butte Inter Mountain.

Announcement was made a short time ago that the Hurlingham Club of England had consented to give a series of games next season to be played under the American rules. It will be interesting to polo lovers in this country to learn that the American Polo Association has practically decided to adopt a similar method here and play a series of games under the English rules.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a member of the Citizens' East Side Improvement Association and a reader of your admirable paper, I desire to thank you for your excellent editorials in defense of the people in their fight against the New York Central Railroad. Our association is in this fight to win.

TUESDAY, DEC. 16 -- By Bryan L. Kennelly, administrator's sale, 135 West Seventy-second Street, north side, 344 feet west of Columbus Avenue, 22 by 102.2, four-story brownstone-front dwelling, with extension.

It is said that the last artist who painted the Campanile at Venice before it fell was an American, F.K.M. Rehn, who spent last Summer in Venice. He did a good deal of work in the famous city on the Adriatic, which will be placed on view in New York this Winter.

The weather, which during the past few days has been busy rehearsing for the Winter season, wound up the week yesterday by going through the whole scale, beginning with a gentle downpour of rain and ending with a blinding snowstorm. All the variations were accompanied by a cutting northeast wind, which during the morning reached a velocity of forty-five miles an hour, and later fell with the temperature.

Why "the" Congress? Whoever read President ROOSEVELT'S message must have been struck by the recurrence of this phrase. To some it must have sounded like an affectation, while others may have thought there was something statesmanlike about It. The more homely and popular usage certainly drops the "the," and there is equal authority for dropping it.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 -- Despite unfavorable conditions, there were fifteen starters in the preliminary Derby Handicap, worth $2,375 to the winner, and the best stake of the meeting so far decided. F.M. Dick's pair, Kittanning and Sweet Alice, coupled, were favorites at 5 to 2, but neither proved a contender.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Money was in fair supply in the market to-day. Discounts were quiet and easy.

Wall Street has had an excited week. Net changes are declines. But at one time the record was much worse than the closing figures are, for a rally marked the last day and a half of the week's business.

Henry Mosler, the artist; Mrs. Henry Mosler, Miss Agnes Mosler, Gustave H. Mosler, and Dr. F.H. Mosler, who have been abroad for the past year, will arrive in this city on the steamer Noordam, which is due here to-day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We note with appreciation your timely criticism of the management of the Manhattan in this morning's paper. We beg you now to direct your influence toward the Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Street crosstown lines, and any others which are suffering for the want of a little coal.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The Vauxhall Bridge controversy is proceeding merrily in the papers, and, from all indications, the London County Council will be forced by public opinion to withdraw its action in sanctioning the erection of what is declared to be nothing else than a monstrosity.

In the face of unparalleled records, and despite some hindrances to the proper movement of traffic, whose congested condition has been well enough known to render it only necessary to mention the fact in order that it may be brought to mind -- in spite also of a tendency which has not been altogether favorable to rates -- the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company continues to make further marked progress with its earnings.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 13 -- The miners called witnesses to-day before the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission to testify to the conditions existing at the collieries of the Philadelphia Reading Coal Iron Company. These were the first persons to appear against the company of which George F. Baer is the head.

The State banks of New York City have enjoyed a prosperous period during the past six months, as shown by the statements just filed in accordance with the call of the State Banking Superintendent for reports as to condition at the close of business Dec. 4, as compared with the statements of Sept. 6, the date of the last call.

THE COURT OF "CONFLICTS" IN FRANCE. -- An old court, which has long been regarded as an obsolete institution, has just been revived in France for the purpose of settling the questions which have arisen in the various conflicts between the Executive and the judicature in the application of the associations law.

The most savage and futile of the demonstrations of hostility toward the trusts on the part of a leader of the Republican Party in the Senate is made by Senator CULLOM of Illinois. It is in the form of an amendment to the so-called anti-trust law passed in 1890 under the guidance of JOHN SHERMAN.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The press here is still hot on the trail of the Humberts, and opinion is divided as to whether their continued inaccessibility is owing to the indifference of the Government or to the alertness of detectives in Mme. Humbert's pay which she evidently left behind her.

One of the erroneous ideas concerning yachting and yacht racing that are accepted by persons whose knowledge of the sport is only such as is gained by the casual reading of the yachting columns of daily newspapers is that it is a sport in which none but men of considerable wealth may participate.

RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- The sudden cold snap this week put a fine coating of ice on the North Shrewsbury River at this place. Down the river, neav Fair Haven and Oceanic and the Highlands, whore the tide is considerably stronger, the surface of the river was only skimmed with ice. In front of Red Bank is the widest part of the Shrewsbury, the river at this point forming a big bay.

THE prosperous times prevailing in the United States will have their effect this year in many homes in Europe, to which Christmas gifts in the shape of money orders, bills of exchange, and drafts on banks are now speeding across the ocean. These gifts, while in the main for only small amounts of money, run up into an aggregate of millions of dollars.

Despite the almost universal complaint about high prices, and the uncertainties of the new tax assessment plan and half a dozen other elements in the present market that would ordinarily furnish fine ammunition for pessimists, actual business continues to show a steady increase in volume and constant improvement in its general character.

Automobilists view the general tendency toward the registering and licensing of operators and machines with considerable apprehension, not because of a desire to avoid such regulation, but because of fear of the abuses which may be likely to result from the general enactment of license laws by local authorities.

HOOSICK FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The rural free delivery service, first installed by the Post Office Department as an experiment, has developed so remarkably that under the present operation the Congressional appropriation for the fiscal year was $3,500,000 for 11,650 routes. This now popular branch of the Postal Service was established in Eastern New York last July, and was a success from the start.

The repertory at the Metropolitan Opera House is chiefly a question of artists -- who they are and what roles they can sing. Mr. Grau's list of sopranos and tenors this year is principally responsible for the fact that the season, so far as it has gone, has presented an aspect so unfamiliar to frequenters of the Opera House in recent years.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- James J. Hill to-day forecasted his retirement as head of the Great Northern Railroad, and perhaps the other great corporations in which he is the leading spirit. He declared that he was as much in love with hard work as ever, and with difficulty conceived himself as being a man of leisure.

With the annual meeting of the National League Baseball Club owners over and the majority of the delegates gone to their respective homes, the local followers of the game have begun to think that after all the peace proposals, so unexpectedly made by the National Leaguers, will bring about the very best results.

IT WAS Christmas Eve, and the regulation mantle of snow covered the entire assembly district except for a small black and bare spot where the wagon of the Street Cleaning Department was being loaded with samples of the wintry covering to be presented to the Commissioner.

PARIS Dec. 13 -- Bellamy Storer, the new Ambassador to Austria-Hungary, has arrived here from Madrid, and will probably proceed to Vienna as soon as advised of the time appointed for the official letters referring to the appointment to be exchanged. He will afterward call on Ambassador Porter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The receipt letter of Mr. Thomas G. Sayre of Newburg, though more or less accurately assuming the soldier to be merely an employe of the United States, does not correctly represent the status of the army canteen. And the letter of Corp. S.G.B., late Twenty-second Regiment, United States Volunteers, does not make the matter much clearer.

Track and field athletics have had a most successful season during the past year, and in some respects an advance has been made over previous records. The improvement has been very marked in Europe. France, Hungary, Austria, and Germany are doing especially well, and it will not be long before athletes from these countries will have to be reckoned with in international competition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Secretary Root appeared to-day before the Military Committee of the House and submitted an extended argument in support of the War Department bill introduced by Mr. Hull of Iowa, to provide for a general staff in charge of preparations for the National defense and the mobilization of military forces in time of war.

Charged with receiving stolen property, Andrew M. Copeland, aged seventy-four, a dealer in second-hand books at 34 Church Street, who lives at 103 Leroy Street, and Thomas E. Keane, aged forty-three, manager of the bookstore, of 254 Hudson Avenue, Hoboken, N.J., were in cells in Police Headquarters last night.

Testimony that amused spectators and jury was given yesterday in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, by a physician who appeared as a witness for a local railroad company in a suit for damages brought by a woman who had been injured in a collision between a trolley car and a carriage. The physician had visited the woman while she was in the hospital.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- "Revolution in Oil Painting" is the heading used by such an ultra-conservative paper as The Times over a dispatch from its Paris correspondent dealing with the invention of J.F. Raffaelli, the well-known French artist, by which the use of brushes and palette by artists can be dispensed with.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- There was some further liquidation in the local market to-day, but very little excitement attended the trading, which for a Saturday, was quite active 33,222 shares and $25,400 bonds changing hands. Prices closed, as a rule, below, last evening's close, but the losses were fractional, excepting in Electric Storage Battery, which was down 4 points, and Indianapolis Street Railway, which was off 2 points.

NOW is the appointed season for the display of new gowns, whether they be the filmy creations worn at balls, the somewhat heavier materials such as silk and brocades seen in the boxes at the opera, or the cloth and corduroy walking gowns. There is one material that is above others a favorite for every conceivable purpose save walking costumes, and that is crepe de chine.

It should be borne in mind that the Port-of-Spain dispatch from the German Charge d'Affaires, informing the Berlin Government that President CASTRO'S reply to its ultimatum is an unqualified refusal to comply with the demands made, was sent more than a day prior to CASTRO'S request that our Minister, Mr. BOWEN, should use his good offices to bring about an arbitration of the dispute.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The automobile show at the Grand Palais is the great attraction of the week. W.C. Rieck, who leaves Paris for New York to-day after a visit of about three weeks, says that it is quite the most wonderful show of its kind he has ever seen.
The dullness of the week preceding the Christmas season is to be broken by two new musical productions, one at the Princess and the other at the New York.

'THIS," said the Dean of the Training College for Lady Novelists, flinging open the door of a room in which about a score of girls ranging in age from twelve to eighteen years were bending over small cook stoves, "is the freshman class, as it were, in the course preparatory to the degree of Historical Romanticist."

To the Editor of The New York Times: A growing evil, and one that should find a speedy remedy, is in the annoyances that frequently make life in apartments, flats, and tenement houses intolerable. These properties usually are in the hands of agents who for the most part concern themselves in the collecting of rents, taking no further interest in the tenant, whose just complaints, if any there be, fall on deaf ears.
SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Dec. 13 -- Admiral Dewey is conferring with the squadron commanders regarding the impending evolutions.
Senator Henry M. Teller of Colorado was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Speaking about the Venezuelan situation, the Senator said:

Up to the time of the publication of the bank statement, yesterday's stock market was strong, in continuation of the upward movement in progress when the market closed on Friday. Good investment buying and some covering for the short account were in evidence, while it was clear also that some of the erstwhile prominent bears had changed their speculative position and were buying in conservative manner for the long account.

YOU'VE often heard funny stories about the petty annoyances to which druggists are subjected," remarked a prominent Columbia Heights (Brooklyn) druggist, "but I think I can tell you a hard-luck story that will beat them all.

WE have arranged to build the Broadway section of the Brooklyn tunnel so far below the surface that the pipes and conduits will not have to be shifted except in isolated instances," said Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons last week, in answer to a question about the difficulties he expected in the work below the Post Office.

PRESIDENT CANTOR of the Borough of Manhattan has begun the work of providing New York City with a seven-mile driveway along the Hudson River, the cost of which will mount up in the millions. At the present time Riverside Drive ends not far from Grant's Tomb, and the Manhattan viaduct marks the end of the journey northward for pleasure seekers.

Alfred Mosely, who came to this country from England five weeks ago with a number of representatives of British labor unions for the purpose of studying American industrial conditions and the relations here between labor and capital, sailed yesterday on the Cunarder Umbria. The delegation which came over was known as the Mosely Industrial Commission, and three of its members, Messrs. Dyson, Madison, and Wilkinson, sailed with Mr. Mosely yesterday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 13 -- When Lakewood's visitors read of zero weather in New York this week and then consulted the big thermometer in the porte cochere of the Lakewood Hotel, they were convinced of the remarkable difference in temperature between the city and this resort, only ninety miles away.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If you are in the middle of a car, always wait until your destination is reached before trying to get out; then make a frantic rush for the door. This method has been found to greatly relieve the monotony of travel; besides, it stirs up the animals and makes 'em lively.

RIGHT in the path of progress, within sound of modern mechanical tri- umphs which are replacing the labor of men's hands, under the very shadow of a university which is liberal if not iconoclastic in its teachings, lives a small sect of men and women who will yield not a jot of their Christmas traditions to the onward march of new thought and twentieth century customs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The subject of my letter is old. One that has estranged families and friends, caused bloodshed, riot, destruction of property, lives of noble men, and left ruin, desolation, and poverty in its tracks across the fields of industry, commerce, and finance, and is to-day just exactly where it started more than fifty year ago -- "labor against capital."

ALLOW me, Madam,'" "Thank you." And the quarter is passed up to the driver -- no, not to the driver, but to the hole, where it remains tapping on the glass during the intervals when the hand is not engaged in ringing the bell.

The eleventh annual intercollegiate chess tournament between Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton will be contested on Dec. 29, 30, and 31 in this city, play to begin at the Columbia Grammar School at 1 o'clock on Dec. 29. While Columbia and Harvard will practically have the same teams which did duty last year, Yale will have to play minus her best men, and Princeton will also be handicapped in this respect.

WEDNESDAY, DEC. 17 -- By Herbert A. Sherman, foreclosure sale, William L. Turner, referee, 2,193 Firth Avenue, east side, 74.11 feet south of One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, 25 by 75. five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $15,564.

In a final sprint over a distance of a single mile, George Leander, from Chicago, riding for the Western team of Leander and Floyd Krebs, won the six days' bicycle race for the long-distance championship of the world in Madison Square Garden last night.

The first and second of the Christmas Bhips of 1902, the Cunarder Umbria and the North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm, sailed for Europe yesterday, having on board hundreds of thousands of dollars in Post Office money orders and presents innumerable, either in the shape of mail or express packages, from persons in America to relatives or friends on the other side of the Atlantic.

The representatives of British industry forming part of Mr. ALFRED MOSELEY'S party to Investigate the causes of American prosperity, who spoke at the opening session of the Civic Federation, were extremely discreet in their reference to conditions at home. This was to be expected.

With the snowflakes there came yesterday a new supply of coal, not for those who think they need it most, but for those who must have it. The anthracite-carrying railroads supplied the dealers who sell coal to the poor with amounts varying from 75 to 100 tons each. This coal yas sent usually in small carts carrying a ton each.

Intercollegiate golfers will meet in this city at the Holland House for their annual meeting next Saturday. The officers of the association will decide upon the course for their championship tournament next year, and some changes to the rules may be made. The college golfers have made quite a reputation for experimenting, their chief fad being an attempt to find some new and equitable method for scoring in team matches.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13 -- The decision of the Henley Stewards against professional coached crews was received practically without comment by the rowing contingent at Harvard. Capt. McGrew of the Varsity crew is away and those members of the Weld and Newell Boat Clubs who were seen absolutely refused to be quoted.

TWO most marked peculiarities about Betrothalosis are that it is universal and that it always attacks its victims in pairs. Properly speaking, it is not so contagious as infectious. Another peculiarity is that it is always a matter of doubt whether its victims suffer most themselves or those with whom they are surrounded.
Bar silver was quoted in the London market at 22 B-16d per ounce and in New York at 48c per ounce. Mexican dollars were quoted at 37 1/4 @ 39 3/4 c.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 13 -- The two great ice-producing rivers of Maine, the Kennebec and Penobscot, are now frozen solidly, the ice being from five to seven inches thick. Although the fields were considerably broken up by tugs and vessels just as the freeze came on, a smooth surface can be had by a little planing.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13 -- The following are authentic copies of the demands presented by the German and British Ministers Monday, Dec. 8, before embarking at La Guayra:

We read a great deal these days concerning the formation, management, and prospective earnings and the possibility of the failure of the United States Steel Corporation. It naturally attracts the attention of thinking men because of the magnitude of the enterprise and because in some ways it is a new venture in the commercial world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is there any way by which the Metropolitan Traction Company can be induecd or compelled to give the people, who do business below Fourth Street on the Sixth Arenue line better service? This morning (Friday) I stood on the corner of Eighth Street and Sixth Avenue, wanting to go to my place of business.

A great many thousands of people are very much interested at the moment in the answer to the question whether the management of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad deems it consistent with its interests and those of the public to pin its faith on steel brushes to keep its contact rail clear of ice.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates were reported to-day as below. Clearing House rate, 5 per cent.; New York funds, 25 and 20 cents discount. Call loans, 6 per cent. Time money, 5 1/2 to 6. Clearing House exchanges, $24,989,252; balances, $1,631,891.

The sleighing season on the Speedway opened yesterday afternoon, when a number of enthusiastic horsemen braved the driving snow for the sake of an exciting dash up the road. Better conditions for good sleighing could not have been desired, as the sleet and rain of Thursday and Friday glazed Seventh Avenue and the Speedway with a coating of ice a half inch thick, and when the snow began to fall it held firm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer last night boarded an elevated train at Seventy-second Street to go to Fifty-ninth Street, Nearly one hour was consumed in going the distance of one station. When he left the train he demanded his fare refunded, together with many other people, but any refund was sternly refused.

I DON'T know or anything I dislike so much," said a boarding-house keeper who has the reputation of being unusually considerate of the feelings of her lodgers, "as holding baggage for security, and I never do it if there is any other chance of getting my money. Occasionally I am driven to harsh measures, and then I keep whatever baggage I can lay hands on.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Hearings were begun to-day before the Sub-Committee on Judiciary of the House, consisting of Representatives Littlefield of Maine. Overstreet of Indiana. Powers of Massachusetts, De Armond of Missouri, and Clayton of Alabama, on the anti-trust bills.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- In the Reichstag to-day Chancellor von Billow opened the discussion of the third reading of the Tariff bill, saying that the allied Governments had agreed on the bill as it passed its second reading, and would also accept the abolition of the municipal octrois, now that the date of its taking effect had been fixed for 1910.
HEIGHO! sighed the Idiot, as he absent-mindedly appropriated the Poet's roll and broke it in two.

THE six young men who thought they were smart had arrived at the stage of their lunch when they were ready for dessert, and the pretty waitress, who didn't think she was smart, but who really was, waited for their orders.

WE asked for bread, and you gave us a stone," is no longer the cry of the destitute of New York. According to administrators of charity throughout Greater New York, whose mission it is to alleviate the sufferings of the poor, the popular complaint during the past week has been "We ask for coal and you give us food."

Another week of the season has passed. Nearly all of the debutantes have had their coining out teas and receptions, and they have made their bow before the selected Reception Committee at the Assembly -- the New York Drawing Room -- and for little more than a month there will be dinners and dancing and amusements and entertainments of all kinds.

ANDOVER, Mass., Dec. 13 -- No matter how great may be the achievements of Sir Liang Chen Tung, the successor of Wu Ting-Fang, in the field of diplomacy at Washington, he will always be remembered at Phillips Academy as the pitcher of its most famous baseball nine -- the undergraduate who introduced the curved ball.
Having received the report of the commission of experts on the Blackwell's Island bridge. Mayor Low gave out yesterday the following statement on the subject:

TRENTON, Dec. 13 -- The annual report of State Road Commissioner Henry I. Budd has been sent to Gov. Murphy. It is shown that 796 miles of stone roads have been built in New Jersey under the law providing for State aid. Toward the construction of these roads the State has appropriated $1,265,168.

Chairman Dunn of the State Republican Committee, returned last night from a hurried trip to Washington where he went to consult with Senator Platt about State politics. He took a morning train for Washington, and returned in the afternoon. He was not at the National capital over two hours.

MISS BLANCHE BATES began the task of collecting Japanese "atmosphere" for "The Darling of the Gods" at the somewhat early age of three years. That was at her home in California, and the effort was an unconscious one. The little Yo-San who was to be had at that time a Japanese nurse and there were two Japanese boys employed in the family.

Activity in the curb market yesterday was confined to Northern Securities, Montreal and Boston, and Bay State Gas. The balance of the list held about steady, with the exception of Otis Elevator common and Seabeard Air Line preferred, both of which advanced a point.

There has long existed in Paris a foundation for the annual distribution of prizes to well-conducted young women who are employed in shops, offices, and factories, or manufactories of various sorts. The money for these awards was left by a Mme. Batifol, and it is distributed by the Municipal Councilors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Word was re ceived at the State Department to-day of the withdrawal of the Venezuelan Consul from Port of Spain. Trinidad, by orders of his Government. Notice of the fact came to the State Department from United States Consul Smith at Port of Spain. It is presumed that Venezuela has sent out similar orders to all of her other Consuls in British and German possessions to withdraw from their posts.

Frederick Saunders, who died on Friday last in the ninety-sixth year of his age in his home, at 400 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, passed his long life among books by right of birth. His father was the head of the publishing firm of Saunders Otley of London, in which city the future librarian and author was born on Aug. 14, 1807.

Whether or not Mr. Belasco and Miss Blanche Bates are the darlings of the gods, there is no doubt that they are the darlings of those who inhabit the padded two-dollar orchestra chairs. As we anticipated, the new show at the Belasco Theatre is off for a run that promises to rival that of "Du Barry."

After the Bronx Zoological Park had closed night before last and it was almost dark, Esau, the largest and hardiest of the three sloth bears in Den 5, went to the swimming tank to get a drink and slipped into the water. The water was not only icy cold, but half covered with broken ice. The steps and sides of the pool were covered with ice from the sleet then in progress.

IN a pawn office on first Avenue, near Tenth Street, a red-nosed woman handed in a Marseilles quilt and a pair of sheets which had evidently been in recent use. The pawnbroker flung them back with a crisp, "Don't want 'em; they ain't clean."

VIENNA, Dec. 4 -- Owing to a resolution recently adopted by the Reichsrath, Count Welsersheimb, Minister of National Defense, has given orders to the commander of the troops in Pilsen, Bohemia, to institute an investigation in regard to the death of Private Joseph Rous of the Seventh Landwehr Infantry.
MESSRS, BADOUIN CO., English silk merchants of Canton, were in a dilemma which apparently did not have even the two proverbial horns for them to choose between.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The House Democrats to-day indulged in some sharp criticism of the alleged loose way in which big appropriations are pushed through Congress. They also attacked the machine headed by the Speaker and the Committee on Rules for tying the hands of the opposition.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 28 -- King Leopold has himself put an end to all the rumors concerning his forthcoming abdication. In the course of a speech made in reply to an address from the President of the House of Representatives, congratulating the sovereign upon his escape from the attempt upon his life, the King said:

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- If there is one thing more than another which the typical Englishman enjoys on Christmas Day it is to survey his well-spread table, graced by his comely wife and happy children, and to reflect with pride that he and the British Empire are at peace with all mankind.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 13 -- In the race of the yacht builders of the challenger for and defender of the American Cup, honors appear to be about even, and from present indications it would seem reasonable to predict that the launching of both craft might occur within a fortnight of each other.

Army Transfers to the Artillery Corps: Capts. David Price to the Thirty-eighth Company, R.E. Callen to the Thirty-first Company, Lawrence S. Miller from the Thirty-first Company, Coast Artillery, to the Thirty-fifth Company, Coast Artillery; James C. Bush to the One Hundred and Eighth Company, Clarence H. McNell to the Thirty-sixth Company: John P. Allen to the Ninth Battery, and Samuel E. Alien to the Fifteenth Battery, Field Artillery.

Dr. Austin Flint, Jr., who is associated with Dr. Janeway, in attendance upon Cornelius Vanderbilt, said last night that published reports that Mr. Vanderbilt's life was hanging in the balance were exaggerated, though he admitted that the case was serious. He declared that interviews accredited to him had been exaggerated.

THE wealthy New Yorkers who have country seals among the picturesque hills and valleys of Westchester County go in for a form of diversion which is probably unique among the country club "sets" of the United States. There are devotees of polo in Westchester County, just as there are at Lakewood and West bury and other places where the rich have homes.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- I had a very interesting talk this week with Axel Delmar, the author of the Hohenzollern plays, which are to be presented by the Arion Society of Brooklyn at the time when the Statue of Frederick the Great, the gift of the Kaiser to the American Nation, will be dedicated in Washington.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Money has been in demand througrhout the week, and the Bank of England has done a large business, especially on Wednesday, in loans and discounts.
