Discount rates have been firm at 313-16 per cent, for three months' bank bills. Foreign houses were buyers at a shade under this, and the tendency was weaker toward the end of the week, owing partly to the inquiry from the Continent.
ONE evening when Mr. Broadway went home he found Mrs. Broadway's cousin Ethel shut up in the back parlor with his wife, and each woman running a sweing machine for clear life.

The Post Office clerks of this city next Thursday evening will present to one of their number a token of esteem in recognition of his long and faithful service in handling the mails in this city, the length of service said to exceed any of which there is previous record in this country or elsewhere.

DISOBEDIENCE BY ENGINEERS OF RAILROAD RULES -- An action brought by Mary Clark against the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company to recover damages for the death of her husband, a workman in its employ, was submitted to the jury on the theory that Clark was killed because of the negligence of the railroad's engineers in disregarding rules requiring them to slow up at sight of a green flag and stop when a red one was displayed.

Alderman Timothy P. Sullivan said yesterday that he was certain that the Pennsylvania tunnel franchise would be defeated at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen on Tuesday next. When asked about the statement of Albert B. Boardman, counsel to the Rapid Transit Commission, and also of the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroad Company, that enough votes had been secured to pass the tunnel franchise, Alderman Sullivan said:
BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- The debate in the Reichstag regarding the most-favored-nation treaties has been postponed until next week, when the trade relations between Germany and America will be discussed.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 13 -- Before the Twentieth Century Club this morning President J.G. Schurman of Cornell University spoke on public schools. He dwelt upon the system as it exists in this country to-day, and in conclusion said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in yesterday's issue arraigning the elevated road management was timely and to the point. The officials either do not care or are incapable of handling the crowds that travel on their lines. On Monday night at the Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street Station there was a small sized riot every time a Harlem train pulled in.

The lady in the chinchilla boa remarked to the other that, really, although the play had been very enjoyable, she did not like the manner in which certain of the characters were made to swear. "One can scarcely go to any theatre nowadays," she went on, "without having one's cars assaulted by the sound of the "big, big D --."
YE-ES," said the girl, hesitatingly, "it is, as you say, a pretty scene -- but I am an American."

A midnight marriage Friday night in the parsonage of the Tompkins Avenue Methodist Church, Tompkins and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, had an unusual tinge of romance. The contracting parties were Charles Clark, an engineer, forty-one years of age, and Jeannie Laird Clark. The Rev. Alfred Hodgett, the pastor of that church, performed the ceremony after he had been aroused from his slumber by the violent ringing of the doorbell.
CARACAS, Dec. 13 -- It is now stated that Italy has handed to the Venezuelan Government similar demands to those made by Germany and Great Britain for the payment of her claims.

WHEN Thomas B. Reed was Speaker of the House he was approached by a member who asked his aid in securing an appropriation for improving a stream in his district. Mr. Reed promised to investigate. When the Congressman next appealed to him, Mr. Reed was ready.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A little byplay for the advocates of statehood and their opponents is promised before the contest in the Senate is entirely over. Senator Gallinger, who has espoused the side of Senator Quay and the admission of the three Territories that are demanding to become States, has, as Chairman of the District Committee, introduced a resolution to amend the Constitution and make a State out of the District of Columbia.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Dutch Guiana, Dec. 1 -- It was 9 o'clock in the morning. The sun had already run above the scale of mere temperature into that of tangible weight. If a white man in the open allowed it so much as to touch him it was like a huge, firm hand flattening him to the fiery earth.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 15 -- After occupying several days, the trial of Arthur Bently Worthington terminated in a verdict of guilty. The jury did not require much time to arrive at a decision. The evidence against Worthington was too conclusive, and revealed a career of rascality which the presiding Judge said eclipsed anything in the criminal annals of the country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The benefits of the "canteen" system and the absolute insanity of the misguided efforts, to suppress it were never better illustrated than they have been under our very eyes at the State Camp at Peekskill.
The New Jersey State Board of Education reports that the cost of running the public schools of the State last year exceeded $8,000,000.

HAVANA, Dec. 5 -- Beyond question the most attractive feature of Havana is its antiquity and its many traditions. Its fortifications date back to an earlier time than anything in our country. The foundation of St. Augustine took place in 1565. Yet before 1335 the Fuerza and the City of Havana had been laid in ruins by pirates.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The annual Oxford and Cambridge football match to-day resulted in a tie, both sides scoring a goal and a touch-down.

ROUND trip tickets, which are literally round trip tickets in that they reach all around the globe, will soon be for sale at a ticket office in this city. The route which they will cover will be from New York to Paris via steamships and railroad, thence to Peking, China, via the Trans-Siberian Railway, and from Peking via San Francisco back to New York.
Vette Hoffman have been appointed St. Louis general agents of the Northwestern Life and Savings Company.

EXPLORERS journeying southeast from Chatham Square along James Street come upon the wholesale banana quarter, the greater part of three blocks of that thoroughfare below Madison Street. James Street is narrow and lined with somewhat forbidding brick tenements, many of them originally the dwellings of single families.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg leave to state a few facts that have a bearing on the canteen question, some of which may not be familiar to the general public.
JOHN VAN HORN, ex-Vice President of the Western Union Telegraph Company, died at his home in Pewee Valley, a suburb of Louisville, yesterday, aged seventy-five years.

Curlers throughout this country and Canada are elated over the prospect of exciting and interesting international matches this season. A picked team, representing the flower of the Scottish rinks, will arrive in this country within a few weeks. The Scotchmen are coming here to engage in all of the series of competitions and bonspiels, both in the United States, Canada, and British Columbia.
Mayor Low took a complacent view of the police situation yesterday, and said before leaving the City Hall:

Alfred L. Seton, Jr., by the death of his father this week, is now the head of his branch of the family. He is a member of the Union and Tuxedo Clubs and married a Miss Barbey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henri-Barbey and a niece of the late Pierre Lorillard. The most picturesque member of the family is Mgr. Seton, now abroad.

The Scotchmen are coming here to engage in all of the series of competitions and bonspiels, both in the United States, Canada, and British Columbia.

He is a member of the Union and Tuxedo Clubs and married a Miss Barbey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henri-Barbey and a niece of the late Pierre Lorillard. The most picturesque member of the family is Mgr. Seton, now abroad.

A writer who, as the case may be, disguises or reveals himself under the pen-name of "J. Weston," in the current number of The Nineteenth Century and After, raises an interesting question and writes an interesting article. It is quite evident that he does not "experimentally" know his United States. Apparently he knows, except by hearsay and statistics, only his British Islands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Does a street railway operating under a city charter incur any obligation to make regular trips between the limits permitted by the charter? If it does, then the lines operating above One Hundred and Eighty-fifth Street on Amsterdam Avenue habitually disregard this obligation, thereby causing great inconvenience to passengers living near the upper end of the routes.
Some of the little carpet sweepers that children could use comfortably can be bought for 17 cents each, and others a little larger for 34 cents.

The Federation of American Zionists desires to have an explanation from the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman of Temple Emanu-El. Some of the members jotted down some of his utterances recently in his two lectures against the movement for the segregation of the Jews in Palestine, and they want to thrash the subject out with him publicty.

The past season among the American athletes on track and field has been reviewed at quite some length, and what has been accomplished by the Yankees in this respect shows to what a high degree of excellence this character of sport has attained here as compared to other countries.

The meeting in Philadelphia last week of the National Civil Service Reform League may well call to the attention of the public the important changes that have taken place in the mode of selection for the public service since the league was formed twenty-two years ago.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 14 -- The entire Rocky Mountain region, from Northern Wyoming to Southern New Mexico, has been visited by a snowstorm during the past thirty-six hours. The ground in the plateau sections is covered to a depth of six inches, while the fall in the mountains has been much heavier.

President BAER drew with a sure hand the picture of the great Republic in her long vigil at the altar of Liberty. No wonder the diners of the Pennsylvania Society got on their feet and shouted their enthusiastic approval when he turned the sketch to their delighted eyes.

PUERTO CABELLO, Dec. 14. -- The British cruiser Charybdis and the German cruiser Vineta bombarded the fortress here at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and quickly silenced it. The bombardment lasted for forty-five minutes.

-- Moved to renewed comment on what it calls " the bob-tailed curriculum " by the statement ascribed to President BUTLER that it is better for students to dawdle through two college years than the canonical four, The Electrical World and Engineer wants to know why the students should be allowed to dawdle at all.

With a force of 2.5OO of its own men and 1,500 hired helpers, the Department of Street Cleaning yesterday undertook the problem of removing from the city streets five inches of snow and ice which had accumulated during the two days' storm. The clear weather all day did much to favor the work.

The Rev. Father Thomas Ducey preached yesterday afternoon to the New York Chapter of the Actors' Church Alliance at St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twenty-eighth Street. He has been one of the Chaplains of the alliance ever since its organization.

The Central Federated Union spent two hours yesterday over the letter of James Keyes, Secretary of the United States Licensed Masters and Pilots Association, to the central body, in which it was said that five labor delegates were offered $500 each to oppose the Pennsylvania tunnel franchise.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why not double-deck all surface cars in this city, and so haul twice as many passengers as now and seat twice as many? The power is there; so is the right of way and the demand. Even if the upper deck be not covered it would be more popular than the main floor five days out of six, as the Fifth Avenue stages are today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The thousand and more employes of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing are viewing the immense smokestack on the bureau building with something like the same feeling that the inhabitants near a volcano behold smoke issuing from a crater.

ST. PAUL., Dec. 14 -- J.J. Hill returned to-day from an Eastern trip, and said that the alleged interview with him, sent out from Chicago, in which he was made to take a pessimistic view of industrial and financial conditions, was purely imaginative and that he did not talk with newspaper men in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Mrs. Ulysses S. Grant, widow of President Grant, died at her residence in this city at 11:17 o'clock to-night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read an article in THE TIMES of Dec. 12 entitled, "The Assouan Dam," and a series of articles in the American press of the same character -- veritable paeans to the British god who has wrought such wonders in Egypt! Is it possible, Mr. Editor, that these articles have been inspired by London correspondents?

The coal famine is becoming acute, and in view of existing and threatened weather conditions may become so serious as to necessitate extraordinary measures of relief for the tenement dwellers, who are compelled to buy fuel in small Quantities at prices equivalent to $15 per net ton, and likely from short weight or scanty measure to average nearer $20.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- John W. Ela, a delegate to the recent National Civil Service Reform Convention and President of the Civil Service Reform League of Chicago, is critically ill at a hospital here. Mr. Ela, who is sixty-five years of age, spoke at the session of the convention held last Friday night, and a few hours after returning to his hotel he was suddenly stricken with apoplexy.

Some of the liveliest handball games of the season were played yesterday by the leading experts in the Brooklyn and Jersey City courts. Owing to the heavy fall of snow, all of the Gaelic football and hurling matches, which were to have been decided during the afternoon in Greater New York, had to be postponed indefinitely, and a great many of the Irish players visited the handball courts instead.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Senator Gallinger of New Hampshire, who also is a Member of the medical profession, gave out the following letter to-night on vivisection, in reply to the published letter of Dr. W.W. Keen of Philadelphia, sent him a week ago:

Prof. Adolf Lorenz, who arrived in this city on Saturday, operated upon two cases of congenital dislocation yesterday morning. Both, he said later in the day, were entirely successful. One was a very hard case, though it took only ten minutes to get the hip bone into the socket. A local doctor performed a similar operation, following those made by Dr. Lorenz.

The Columbia Oval Cricket Club, which tied the Essex County team of Newark for the championship of the New York Cricket Association during the past season, has issued its annual report. This shows that of a total of 27 games played 16 were won, while the first eleven of the club was credited with 13 wins against 3 defeats.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A hearing on dentistry was given yesterday by the House Committee on Naval Affairs, and many leading dentists were present to urge that a bill be passed raising the grade of naval dentists.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- At their meeting to-morrow afternoon the Directors of the Consolidated Lake Superior may settle the question as to who shall succeed Frank S. Lewis as President, and also announce that they have obtained a temporary loan.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The critical situation created in Germany by the Reichstag coalition, by the attitude of the Government, and by the tactics of the Social Democracy, has created widespread anxiety, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Minister Bowen, in a dispatch received by the State Department this afternoon, said he had been informed by President Castro that British and German warshins were bombarding Puerto Cabello.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of your editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day entitled " The Elevated Railroad Paralysis," I should like to advance a suggestion which, perhaps, might bring to life again the apparent paralysis in the ingenuity of the elevated road's engineers and induce them to see fit to make use of it in the service of the public.

A fleet of overdue steamships from many ports and sailing under many flags arrived together at Quarantine yesterday morning, and gave the revenue officers the busiest time they have had for many a day. All the steamships belonging to what is known as the "Saturday fleet" were there, including the American liner St. Paul, the French liner La Touraine, and the Cunarder Lucania.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The news that the first shots have been fired in Venezuela has awakened the most apathetic of the critics to the gravity of the situation which is developing in that country, and the demands that the Government present the official papers in the matter to Parliament are now most insistent.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 -- J.J. Bardwell, one of the oldest photographers of the country, died here to-day at the age of seventy-nine years. Five years ago the National Association of Photographers discussed a proposition to give him a home in recognition of his services to photographic art, but he refused to acquiesce. He was at one time President of the National Association.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The Daily Mail's correspondent at Willemstad, Curacao, says the Venezuelan Government has declined the offer of a loan, made by a German banker of Caracas, to settle the foreign claims against the country.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- " In memory of John W. Mackay, I christen thee Pacific Cable. May it always carry messages of happiness."

Prof. John Philip Sousa and his band were expected at the Metropolis Theatre, Third Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-second Street, yesterday afternoon, and practically a full house did the expecting. Prof. John Philip Sousa and his band came at 2:30 o'clock, just when the audience was becoming impatient.

Although the heavy fall of snow made cross-country running a somewhat heroic feat yesterday, representatives of six athletic clubs took part in the three runs which were decided. The principal contest was a three-club affair, in which a pack of eighteen athletes were competitors for a silk banner.

A man with his hat in one hand and frantically fanning the air with the other entered the West Thirtieth Street Police Station about 9 o'clock last evening. "Ma femme! Ma chere femme!" he was exclaiming, but that was not explanatory to Sergt. Mott, who was behind the desk. The latter thought he had a crazy man on his hands until some one noticed that he was merely an excited Frenchman.
CARACAS, Dec. 14 -- The situation here continues to be critical, and there is intense excitement among the German residents of Caracas.

This week is counted among theatrical people as the dullest of the forty which go to make up the season, but if It can beat the record of the one just finished it will do well. In its early part the usual dropping off in the theatres, caused by the disinclination of Christmas shoppers to go anywhere at night, began and was rapidly increased by the storm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The coming week is likely to be marked by more effective attention to business in both houses than has been shown in the first fortnight of the session. In the Senate the immigration bill is practically completed, and an agreement will be reached for a final vote Wednesday or Thursday.

BRISTOL, Dec. 14 -- The prompt delivery of the first of the metal for the construction of the hull of the new cup defender the past week sets a good pace for the launching of the craft in April next, the time arranged for her completion, providing there is no delay in receiving the material. This is especially pleasing to Mr. Iselin and the Herreshoffs.

The opinion gained strength yesterday that Major John McGaw Woodbury, Commissioner of the Department of Street Cleaning, will succeed Col. John N. Partridge as the head of the Police Department next month.

Eight thousand dollar automobiles, in the language of Policeman McGuire of the Central Park squad, looked like "30 cents " yesterday. The automobilist leaned low over the steering wheel, or lever, in very shame at the blundering jolting vehicle, and those who have looked scornfully down upon the pedestrian public cuddled among their furs dejected and disheartened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- There is an interesting contest in progress between the House and the Senate which has been given little notice, mainly for the reason that the matter in controversy is one that affects the House only. There always has been a vigorous outcry against the sale of intoxicating liquors in the Capitol building.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Dec. 8 you refer editorially to the defects of the New York ballot law as respects the difficulty of casting an independent or " split " vote, and say " our present system of printing and marking ballots disfranchises so many qualified voters that an immediate improvement in the system is, as the doctors say, " indicated."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 14 -- Fencing has sprung into unprecedented popularity this season at Harvard. At the last report 101 candidates were trying for the team. This is not so large a number as the basketball squad contains, but this fact may be accounted for by the disparity in expense between the two forms of sport.
John H. Berry has sold for Elias and Martin Kempner to an investor, for about $100,000, the apartment house 219 and 221 West Eighty-third Street, on plot 50 by 100.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Miss Elizabeth Parkinson of Kansas City, Mo., made her debut here to-night in the title role of "Lakme," which was revived at the Opera Comique for the occasion. Miss Parkinson is attractive in appearance. Her voice is a high soprano. She was much applauded, receiving several recalls.
